DOC.HEADLINE: CDC FORESEES NO HUMAN BIRD FLU INFECTION AT LEAST BY END OF MARCH

TEXT.P: Taiwan is not expected to see any cases of humans contracting bird flu at least before the end of March, a senior Department of Health (DOH) official said Sunday.
Shih Wen-yi, deputy director of the DOH's Center for Disease Control, said Taiwan now has only found a low-pathogenic strain of the avian flu virus known as H5N2, which cannot infect humans.
According to medical records, Shih said, it will take several weeks to six months for the H5N2 strain to mutate to the highly pathogenic strain of H5N1 virus which can infect humans.
In terms of this time frame, Shih said, no human avian flu infection is expected to occur in Taiwan at least by the end of March.
Nevertheless, Shih said, Taiwan must remain on high alert because the potential of human infection remains high.

In his view, Shih said, avian flu has been on mainland China for some time. "Late last year, the animal disease control unit already discovered the H5N1 virus in a batch of ducks smuggled to the frontline island of Kinmen from mainland China," Shih said.

As the H5N1 virus continues to spread across Asia, Shih said, Taiwan must step up border controls to prevent live animal smuggling and to quarantine incoming passengers suspected of having come down with avian flu.

Asked whether local citizens should still eat poultry, Shih said he sees no problem in eating chicken meat bearing the "CAS" foodstuff logo. The label certifies that the bird has been screened by the government and deemed safe for human consumption.
However, he urged people to refrain from purchasing chickens slaughtered on the spot at traditional markets.
"As slaughtered-on-the-spot chickens have not undergone tests and refrigeration, they may spread the bird flu virus," Shih said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DELEGATION TO ATTEND 2004 U.S. NATIONAL PRAYER BREAKFAST
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 31 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Peng Ming-min, a senior advisor to President Chen Shui-bian, will lead a four-member Republic of China delegation to attend the 2004 National Prayer Breakfast gathering scheduled to be held in Washington, D.C. Feb. 5, a source in the United States said Saturday.
The members of the delegation include Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Kau Ying-mao, Legislator Chen Tan-sun, Professor Joanne J.L. Chang and Chairman of Chia Hsin Cement Co. Nelson A.P. Chang.
The source said that Peng and the other members of the delegation should arrive in the U.S. capital separately Feb. 3.
Besides attending the National Prayer Breakfast gathering, the ROC delegates may possibly meet with some U.S. officials.

The National Prayer Breakfast is an annual religious gathering attended by up to thousands of dignitaries including U.S. President George W. Bush, many senior U.S. officials, congressional members as well as diplomats and religious leaders from various countries around the world.
The purpose of the gathering is to promote world peace and conciliation.

DOC.HEADLINE: BELARUS HAS SUPPORT OF TAIWAN TO JOIN WTO
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Jan. 31 (CNA) (By C. H. Lu and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: A senior Republic of China trade official in Geneva has made clear Taiwan's support for Belarus's bid to join the World Trade Organization (WTO), saying that positive results from future bilateral consultations with the former Soviet nation's WTO bid will reinforce relations between the two countries.

Kou Shio-tie, Taiwan's deputy permanent representative to the WTO, passed on the island's friendly message of support at the fifth WTO working group meeting for Belarus's bid to join the world trade regulatory body. The meeting was held Jan. 30 in Geneva.
During the meeting, Kao also said that future bilateral consultations between Taiwan and Belarus on the latter's WTO bid will certainly bring a lot of trade opportunities to the two countries.

Pointing out that relevant agencies of the Taiwan government have been preparing detailed lists of goods and services as topics for consultations, the official said that Taiwan will put forth the preliminary lists in the coming few weeks.

It is expected that during consultations with Belarus, Taiwan will express its concern over such trade items as computers, computer parts, semiconductors and fuel products (except crude oil) , among others.

Taiwan has attached great importance to WTO bids of all commonwealth independent states and hopes to strengthen its trade and economic relations as well as other relations with these countries through consultations with them within their WTO bids.
Taiwan's permanent mission to the WTO recently held an informal meeting with its Belarus counterpart in Geneva as well as establishing a good communication channel between the two delegations.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRAZILIAN GRANDMA URGED TO COME TO TAIWAN TO TAKE BACK BOY

TEXT.P: The uncle of a Taiwanese-Brazilian boy at the center of an international custody battle said Sunday he hopes the boy's Brazilian legal guardian will come to Taiwan to take back the boy in person.
"I'll feel at ease only when I can hand over my nephew to his Brazilian grandmother in person," said the boy's uncle Wu Hou-yen.
Taiwan's judicial authorities have meted out a final verdict that the boy's guardianship belongs to his Brazilian grandmother, Rosa Ergui.

The grandmother said earlier that she was glad to learn about the Nov. 13 Taiwan Supreme Court ruling that the boy, Iruan Wu Ergui, should be returned to her. However, she said she has been unable to come to Taiwan because she wants to avoid the media spotlight, which she feels is bad for the boy. Ergui has instead commissioned Brazil's representative to Taiwan, Paulo A.P. Pinto, to take the boy back to Brazil on her behalf.
Wu said he fully respects the judicial ruling, but stressed that he hopes Ergui can come to Taiwan to take back the boy instead of asking him to hand over the boy to her proxy.
The Kaohsiung District Court has ordered Wu to hand over the boy, better known as Wu Yi-hua in Taiwan, to his grandmother's representative by Feb. 5.

It remains unclear whether the district court will seek local police's assistance in forcefully taking the boy away from his Taiwanese uncle's home if Wu fails to voluntarily hand over the boy by the deadline.

Iruan was born out of wedlock in Brazil in July 1995 to a Brazilian mother and a Taiwanese father. His mother died six years ago and he was brought to Taiwan in March 2001 by his father, who died a couple of weeks later. Since then, the boy has been living with his uncle in the southern Taiwan county of Kaohsiung.

His grandmother, who became the boy's legal guardian upon his mother's death, decided to take legal action to regain custody of her grandson after his Taiwanese uncle refused to let her take him back to Brazil in 2001.

According to Taiwan regulations, if Wu refuses to comply with the court order, he can be fined between NT$30,000 and NT$300,000 (US$890-US$8,902), and if he still refuses to hand over the boy, the court can keep fining him. If Wu continues to hold out, the court will ultimately order the police to implement the transfer of custody.
A support group has been formed in Kaohsiung County, which has called for donations of NT$10 (US$0.296) per person to help Wu pay for the fines and support fees for the boy.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNEMPLOYMENT RATE TO DROP TO 4 PERCENT IN 2004: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President chen Shui-bian said Sunday Taiwan's unemployment rate will drop to 4 percent this year as the local economy has fully recovered from its year-long recession.

Addressing a rally in Changhua County's Yuanlin township in central Taiwan in support of his re-election bid, Chen said Taiwan's major economic indicators flashed a "yellow-red" light on the government's composite measurement system in December last year, indicating that the domestic economy is getting hot.
"Our economy is now at its best shape in 48 months," Chen said proudly, adding that the rally in the local stock market in recent days showcases a strong economic recovery.

Noting that Taiwan's 4.81 percent economic growth for 2003 was better than those registered in the United States, Hong Kong and Singapore, Chen said he is convinced that Taiwan's economic records will be even brighter this year. Among others, he said, the jobless rate will drop from last years' 4.5 percent to 4 percent this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT CALLS FOR UNITY IN FIGHT AGAINST AGGRESSION

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui said Sunday the people of Taiwan should stand united in the face of mainland China's ever-mounting military threat and diplomatic stranglehold against the country.

Lee made the appeal while taking part in a rehearsal in the southern county of Tainan for a "one-million-persons-hand-in-hand" rally scheduled for Feb. 28 in support of President Chen Shui-bian's re-election bid.

More than 60,000 residents in the Tainan area joined the rehearsal, holding hands together along a 63-kilometer stretch of road in protest of Beijing's missile threat and in a show of support for Chen's referendum plan and re-election bid.

Lee served as the commander of the northern section of the 60,000-person human chain. He traveled on a vehicle from Tainan County's Houpi township southward to Shanhua township, the center point of the human chain. Lee waved to the participants along the way to boost their morale.

Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, who supervised the southern section of the human chain, traveled from the county's Yungkang township northward to Shanhua where Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih was overseeing the proceedings of the whole event.

Lee and Hsieh arrived in Shanghua at around 2:20 p.m. They joined Su in leading all participants in shouting, "Missiles no, peace yes" at 2: 27 p.m. The participants then turned to face the Central Mountain Range and shouted, "Holding hands together to save Taiwan" and "peace referendum" at 2:28 p.m.
The participants also sang patriotic songs, including "Stand United for Taiwan" and "Taiwan All Victory."
Addressing the rally, Lee said the people of Taiwan should not be daunted by the nearly 500 missiles deployed by Beijing to intimidate them.

"We should not flinch under Beijing's threat. We must instead stand up to resist mainland China's aggression. With courage, resolve and unity, we'll be able to defeat any enemy and protect our democratic homeland," Lee said.

He further said the Feb. 28 "one-million-persons-hand-in-hand" rally will be a very important event in Taiwan's 400-year history. "It will tell the world that the people of Taiwan, regardless of their ethnic backgrounds, gender, or age are united and resolved to protect their homeland with peace."

Meanwhile, Lee said President Chen's planned referendum alongside the March 20 presidential election is a necessary step to consolidate Taiwan's young democracy. He urged local people to support Taiwan's first-ever referendum, using their ballots to express their desire for peace, not war.

Speaking on the same occasion, Kaohsiung Mayor Hsieh said the Feb. 28 hand-in-hand rally is seeking to break the world record for the longest human chain since the Baltic Chain in 1989 when the people of the three Baltic countries -- Tstonia, Lithuania and Latvia -- formed a human chain to express their opposition to interference by Russian Army.
Hsieh called on local citizens to come out on Feb. 28, which is Taiwan's Peace Memorial Day, and take part in the "hand-in-hand" rally to set a new record for Taiwan.

Quoting public opinion survey results, Tainan County Magistrate Su said the "hand-in-hand" program has received the support of more than 70 percent of local citizens and that even 40 percent of the supporters of the opposition presidential ticket of Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong alo support the "hand-in-hand" program.

"I hope more than one million people will join the rally on that day and hold their hands together along the north-south provincial highway from Keelung City to Pingtung County for a distance of 500 kilometers," Su said, adding that the rally will symbolize unity of Taiwan people and support for the island's first-ever referendum.

President Chen announced in last month that a referendum will be held to coincide with the March 20 presidential election to ask local voters whether Taiwan should buy more anti-missile weapons if China refused to withdraw its missiles, and whether Taipei should forge a framework with Beijing for peaceful interaction.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUNG CHILDREN TO BE OFFERED FREE FLU INOCULATIONS FROM OCTOBER

TEXT.P: The government plans to offer free flu inoculations to children under age 10 from October, a senior Department of Health (DOH) official said Sunday.
Shih Wen-yi, deputy director of the DOH's Center for Disease Control, said foreign clinical records show that 6- and 7-year-olds have a high risk of contracting avian flu.
Against this backdrop, Shih said, the DOH is scheduled to hold a meeting of specialists Tuesday to discuss measures to prevent avian flu from infecting young children.
The meeting is expected to approve the proposal to have children younger than 10 inoculated with flu vaccines from October this year, Shih said.

At the moment, Shih said, humans do not have antibodies against the bird flu virus. Those who contract the virus, particularly young children, are likely to succumb to the disease. "Therefore, we have tentatively decided to offer free shots of bird flu vaccines to children aged under 10 from October," he explained.

Taiwan has offered free flu vaccinations to senior citizens aged 65 and over and several other high-risk groups, including medical personnel and poultry farmers. The decision to expand free inoculations to young children comes amid an increase of bird flu cases in humans in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GIRL AND PARTNER TAKE AUSTRALIAN OPEN JUNIORS DOUBLES TITLE

TEXT.P: Fourteen-year-old Taiwan student Chan Yung-jan and mainland Chinese Sun Shengnan won the juniors girls' doubles title at the Australian Open Sunday.

The second-seeded Sun-Chan duo beat the Czech Republic pair of Nicole Vaidisova and Veronika Chvojkova in the finals 7-5, 6-3 held in Melbourne Sunday on the last day of the 2004 Australian Open that ran Jan. 19 to Feb. 1.

The victory made Chan the first Taiwan tennis player to win a Grand Slam championship in girls' doubles in 15 years after her predecessor, Wang Si-ting won the same title with an Australian partner in the French Open in 1989.
Chan, who will turn 15 in August, is also the youngest Grand Slam title winner from Taiwan.
Chan, whose home was destroyed in the killer earthquake on Sept. 21, 1999, is at present a student at Hsinhsing Junior High School in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Feb. 1, or the 11th day of the first month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1650: Rene Descartes, French mathematician and philosopher known as the "father of French philosophy," dies at the age of 54. His philosophy is based on the rationalistic premise: "I think, therefore I am."
1893: Thomas Edison, the American inventor who patented more than a thousand inventions, opens the first film studio in West Orange, New Jersey.
1901: Clark Gable, American film actor who became an international heart throb, is born. He played Rhett Butler in "Gone With the Wind."
1902: The Ching dynasty orders the lifting of a ban on marriages between the Manchus and the Chinese.
1913: The first Far Eastern Games are held in Manila, the Philippines, with athletes from the Republic of China, Japan and the host country attending.
1924: Britain recognizes the Communist government of the Soviet Union.
1948: The Bank of Taiwan issues a new edition of the 100-dollar bill.
1950: Deputies of the National Assembly respectfully invite Chiang Kai-shek to succeed acting President Lee Tsung-jen as the president of the Republic of China. Lee remained in the United States following the Nationalist government's retreat to Taiwan after being defeated by the Communists in China's civil war.
1951: The U.N. General Assembly condemns the Chinese Communists as aggressors in Korea.
1952: The U.N. General Assembly finds the Soviet Union guilty of violating the 1945 Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance.
1958: The first U.S. satellite, the Vanguard-1, is successfully launched into orbit.
1963: Taiwan's `king of iron and steel' Tang Jung dies at the age of 83.
1967: President Chiang Kai-shek establishes the National Security Council. Vice Premier Huang Shao-ku is named secretary-general of the organization and Ku Shu-tung is named deputy secretary-general.
1973: One hundred and four members of the National Assembly and the Legislative Yuan, 20 mayors and magistrates and the 73 members of the fifth Taiwan Provincial Assembly are sworn in.
1974: An economic mission headed by Economic Affairs Vice Minister Chang Kwang-shih leaves for Saudi Arabia for a five-day visit.
1978: The Central Daily News, the oldest newspaper in the country, marks its 50th anniversary.
1979: Iranian religious leader the Ayatollah Khomeini ends 16 years of exile, returning from Paris to a frenzied welcome at Tehran airport.
1980: Taiwan's North Link (Suao-Hualien) Railway is opened with ceremonies in Nanshenghu, near Ilan, and Hualien. The project cost the government NT$7.3 billion and took six years to complete.
1982: Alfred Britain III, chairman of the Bankers Trust Company of New York, opens the bank's branch office in Taipei.
1990: South African President F.W. de Klerk announces the legitimacy of the African National Congress and other political organizations. He also promises the unconditional release of jailed ANC leader Nelson Mandela within two weeks.
1991: An earthquake rocks Pakistan and Afghanistan, killing more than 1,200 people.
1992: U.S. President George Bush and Russian President Boris Yeltsin sign the Camp David declaration stating that their two countries no longer regard each other as adversaries.
1995: Communist Vietnam and the United States begin a new chapter in their relationship by opening liaison offices in each others' capitals.
1995: The World Trade Organization passes a resolution to accept the Republic of China as an observer country.
2000: Premier Vincent Siew presides over a ceremony to unveil the name plaque of the newly established Coast Guard Administration and swear in CGA Director-General Yao Kao-chiao.
2001: Nobel laureate Gao Xingjian, at the invitation of the Taipei City Government's Cultural Affairs Bureau, arrives in Taiwan from Hong Kong.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In my method of teaching, I always wait for my student to make an effort himself to find his way through a difficulty, before I show him the way myself. I also make him find his own illustrations before I give him one of my own. When I have pointed out the bearing of a subject in one direction and found that my student cannot himself see its bearings into other directions, I do not then repeat my lesson."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO UNVEIL PLAN FOR PEACE NEGOTIATIONS WITH BEIJING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will unveil his plan for negotiations with Beijing on a peaceful interaction framework at a press conference Tuesday.

According to an advance copy of the president's prepared statement to be read out at the press conference, Chen will say that his planned negotiations should based on one principle and should cover four issues.
The principle would be to ensure peace across the Taiwan Strait, and the four issues to be discussed are:
-- associating on an equal footing; for example, by setting up liaison offices on the other side;
-- building up political ties on the basis of mutual respect and benefit; and
-- preventing military conflict, for example by setting up a non-military zone.
The statement is a follow-up to the president's call for a referendum on whether the country should set up a peaceful interaction framework with Beijing through negotiations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WILL CONTINUE TO CONTRIBUTE TO GLOBAL DEVELOPMENT: FM

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will continue to contribute to global development under the guidelines of three pivotal ideas of its diplomacy, Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien said Monday.

Speaking at a Lunar New Year party he hosted in honor of foreign diplomats stationed in Taipei, Chien said that the three pivotal ideas are democracy and human rights, economic prosperity, and peace and security.
Chien said that the ROC will continue to make contributions to the international community based on these three guidelines.

Ambassadors, representatives and other diplomats from 54 countries attended the party, at which Ambassador Jacques Sawadogo of Burkina Faso, in his capacity as president of the diplomatic corps, thanked the ROC government for the assistance it has extended to their countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TIES TO BE IMPROVED AFTER HIS RE-ELECTION: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that cross-Taiwan Strait relations will move toward reconciliation, cooperation and eternal peace if he is re-elected.

Addressing a tea party hosted by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in Taipei to mark the Lunar New Year, Chen said that his administration has taken various measures to improve relations between the two sides of the strait since he took office May 20, 2000, including the opening of the "three mini-links, " allowing mainland Chinese journalists to be stationed in Taiwan, allowing remittances between offshore banking units and their mainland Chinese counterparts, opening cross-strait charter flight services to transport Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland and their dependents home for the Lunar New Year holiday, and helping establish schools for children of Taiwan businessmen on the mainland.
The mini three-links refer to the direct transportation and trade links between the two Taiwan-controlled outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu and the mainland's Fujian Province.
Based on the existing achievements, Chen claimed, cross-strait ties will definitely take a big step forward if he is re-elected in the March 20 presidential race.
The president said that his re-election would not only represent a personal victory for him, but would also cement Taiwan's democracy and write a chapter of history for the people of Taiwan.
Regarding the prospects for the new year, Chen said that he wishes Taiwan more economic prosperity, better social order, more consolidated freedom and democracy, and cross-strait peace.
The president also exchanged views on education, referendum, parliamentary reforms, labor policy and other topics with the nearly 200 civic organization leaders present on the occasion.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO NEW CASES OF H5N2 BIRD FLU IN TAIWAN: COUNCIL OF AGRICULTURE

TEXT.P: No new cases of the bird flu caused by the H5N2 virus have been found since Saturday in Taiwan, a government official reported Monday,

Yeh Ying, deputy director-general of the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine Department under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) , said quarantine workers have stepped up inspections of fowl populations in central and southern regions and that no fresh cases have been discovered since Saturday, when about 34,000 chickens were culled at two poultry farms in Chiayi and Tainan counties.

The bureau will further intensify inspections and controls to contain the spread of the less virulent H5N2 strain in Taiwan, at a time when global concern over the increased spread of the far more virulent H5N1 virus in mainland China is mounting, Yeh said. She vowed that the bureau will immediately announce new developments regarding the disease at home in order not to provoke public panic.

COA Chairman Lee Chin-lung said the potentially fatal H5N1 virus is also likely to invade Taiwan on the grounds that many neighboring countries have reported repeated bird flu cases infected by the pathogen.
Lee said the COA must take into consideration the worst-possible scenario for Taiwan and must take effective measures to contain any spread of the disease.

Meanwhile, Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) Minister Chen Chien-jen urged the public to conduct self-health control and management by taking their temperatures and washing their hands frequently every day. The DOH will also strengthen checkups at immigration and customs points across the country, he added.

In line with the central government's efforts to prevent the transmission of the H5N1 bird flu virus from the mainland and the rest of Asia, the coast guard authorities on outlying Kinmen Island have moved swiftly to clamp down on smuggling along the coast.

Coast guard personnel all wear protective gear and are equipped with disinfection facilities to carry out their mission. They have also called on the Kinmen residents not to buy mainland-made products in a bid to better protect the island, just opposite the mainland's Fujian Province.

Ten Asian countries, including the mainland, Japan, South Korea, Indonesia, Thailand and Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos, have reported cases of H5N1 bird flu and the COA has banned imports of poultry products from the affected countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES BEIJING FOR TRANSPARENCY ON AVIAN FLU IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun called on mainland China Monday to level with the world about the avian flu situation on the mainland and to work with neighboring countries and the World Health Organization (WHO) to combat the disease.

After being briefed by officials from the Department of Health, the Council of Agriculture and the Environmental Protection Administration, the premier said the country should be placed on high alert to prevent the disease from invading the island.

As viruses are often passed to human beings from poultry, the premier asked the customs authorities and the Coast Guard Administration to exercise the same great vigilance to stop poultry smuggling as they do to prevent narcotics and weapons from being brought in.

In light of the world's experience of fighting severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) early last year, Yu said that the free flow of information about epidemics in different countries is vital to eradicating these diseases.

Since the WHO suspects that the mainland is not being honest about the bird flu situation there, Yu called on the Beijing authorities not to repeat the mistake it made when it tried to cover up the outbreaks of SARS in southern China in early 2003 and to instead join hands with other countries to defeat the disease.

Noting that avian flu cases have been reported in South Korea, Japan, the Philippines, Vietnam and mainland China, the premier said Taiwan is besieged by countries that have fallen into the grip of this disease, and it is quite possible that the high pathogenic H5N1 virus, which exists in the systems of poultry and causes flu symptoms in humans, will be brought into the island and that the government should do its utmost to prevent this.
When it comes to fighting avian flu, the premier said, it is better to err on the side of caution.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT DETERMINED TO DEVELOP TAIWAN INTO ASIAN FINANCIAL HUB

TEXT.P: The government is determined to development Taiwan into an Asian financial hub and welcomes multinational enterprises that wish to invest in the country and forge joint ventures with their domestic counterparts, Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i said Monday.

Addressing a ceremony in which Britain's Prudential Group and Taiwan's E-Sun Financial Holding Company signed a strategic alliance accord, Lin said that the government is determined to bring Taiwan's financial sector into the international arena.

Over the years, he noted, the government has lifted restrictions on investment in the domestic bourse by qualified international investors, increased the ceiling on overseas investment by domestic insurance companies from 20 percent to 35 percent of their total assets and opened cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges of insurance, among other things.

In addition, said the vice premier, who also doubles as chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , financial reforms have produced fruitful results since the government took concrete measures in this direction in June 2002.

As of the end of last year, he continued, Taiwan-based banks had written off a combined NT$648 billion (US$19.23 billion) in bad debts, lowering their average overdue loan ratio to 4.33 percent from a peak of 8.04 percent recorded in March 2001.
In the last year alone, he said, domestic banks earned a total of NT$293.8 billion and wrote off NT$163.8 billion in bad loans, while new non-performing loans registered only NT$3 billion.
In comparison, he added, domestic banks earned only a total of NT$262 billion and wrote off NT$230 billion of bad loans in 2001, while their overdue loans increased by NT$543 billion.
These figures show that the operation of domestic financial institutions has returned onto a healthy track, according to Lin.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH TO HOLD MEETING ON AVIAN FLU PREVENTION

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) will call a meeting Tuesday to discuss measures to cope with a possible avian flu outbreak in Taiwan, a senior official said Monday.

Su Ih-jen, director of the DOH's Center for Disease Control, said the meeting will focus discussions on preparation for avian flu vaccines, including expanding the categories of people eligible for free inoculations.

Su said the DOH is considering either establishing a laboratory for producing vaccines against the highly virulent H5N1 strain of avian flu virus or contracting a noted multinational pharmaceutical plant to produce the vaccines for Taiwan.
Su said he hopes the Legislative Yuan will support the budget proposal for the vaccine production plan.
So far, bird flu has struck at least 10 Asian countries in recent months and has killed more than 10 people.

Su said the bird flu strain spreading through Asia, known as H5N1, has not reached this island. Taiwan, however, has culled 98,000 chickens and ducks infected with a milder strain of flu, H5N2, which cannot infect humans.

But Council of Agriculture Chairman Lee Chin-lung said he is afraid the more virulent H5N1 strain could be carried to the island by migratory birds or by fowl smuggled from mainland China. Over the weekend, the council said it believed that bird flu had struck mainland China as early as last December, noting that several ducks smuggled from the mainland to the Taiwan-held frontline island of Kinmen had tested positive for the H5N1 strain.
Premier Yu Shyi-kun urged mainland China Monday to be more open about its bird flu outbreak, saying hiding information about the illness ravaging Asia could help the virus spread faster.
"We know that countries sharing information will be crucial for containing the disease," Yu said.
The premier said Taiwan will also take extra measures to prevent the bird flu, including a crackdown on smuggled fowl and closer monitoring of chicken diseases at farms.

Over the weekend, the World Health Organization also appealed for more urgent action by mainland China against bird flu, calling on the communist government to share more information about the disease and step up monitoring for possible human cases.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2004 TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL BOOK EXHIBITION ENDS ON STRONG NOTE

TEXT.P: The 2004 Taipei International Book Exhibition wrapped up Monday at the Taipei World Trade Center, posting a record high in visitor numbers and business revenues for the six-day event, the organizing authorities said.

Jan Jung-tze, chairman of the organizing group, said the number of visitors reached an all-time high of more than 428,000, while the value of business deals agreed upon is worth over NT$500 million (US$15 million) , an increase of 30 percent over the previous-year's level. Income generated from entry fees totaled around NT$17 million, he noted.

Pointing out that the audience figure is higher that the levels ever registered in book fairs held in Paris and Hong Kong, Jan said that many book publishing companies based both at home and abroad are satisfied with the show's performance.

The enthusiastic response is an indication that there is a host of book lovers in Taiwan and the exhibition's success serves as a benchmark experience for the organization of similar activities in the future, according to Jan.

Some Taiwan-headquartered publishers achieved their business targets before the conclusion of the event, he noted, adding that generally speaking, participants from France notched up the best results among the foreign companies that took part.

Forty publishers from France took part in the annual book exhibition, represented by 12 staffers who served their customers. One of the French publishing houses sold the royalties for 70 books, while a company from South Korea obtained on-the-spot business worth U$$40,000.
A total of 951 publishing companies from 51 countries and areas participated in this year's fair.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TRADE CONTINUES TO SURGE: BOFT

TEXT.P: Bilateral trade between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait registered a 23.2 percent year-on-year rise in the first 11 months of last year, the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) reported Monday.

During the 11-month period, Taiwan exports to mainland China amounted to US$31.91 billion, up 19.5 percent from the year-earlier level, while imports from the mainland totaled US$9.78 billion, up 37.3 percent.
Last November alone, Taiwan exported US$3.53 billion-worth of goods to the mainland, marking a 25.5 percent increase from the same month of 2002.

BOFT officials said that Taiwan's exports to the mainland will continue an upward swing this year thanks to rapid growth in mainland exports and domestic demand, as well as a strong recovery in the global information technology industry.

With the mainland accelerating its infrastructure construction, BOFT officials said, Taiwan's steel and petrochemical material exports to the mainland have grown substantially in recent years, while the mainland's burgeoning auto industry is also good news for Taiwan's auto parts exports to the mainland.

President Bush will establish a bipartisan commission in the next few days to examine American intelligence operations, including a study of possible misjudgments about Iraq's unconventional weapons, senior administration officials said Sunday. T
The panel would also investigate failures t o penetrate secretive governments and stateless groups that could attempt new attacks on the United States.
Wall Street Journal: Halliburton hits snafu On billing in Kuwait.
Halliburton Co. allegedly overcharged more than $16 million for meals at a single U.S. military base in Kuwait during the first seven months of last year, according to Pentagon investigators auditing the company's work.
The allegations, involving food-service work done by Halliburton subsidiary Kellogg Brown & Root, come on the heels of another KBR dispute and have spurred an expansion of an already widening inquiry into Halliburton's government work in Iraq.

DOC.HEADLINE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS BLOCKING SIGNING OF AGREEMENT WITH GUGGENHEIM

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said Monday that he is anxious to sign an agreement with the Guggenheim Museum to build a branch in the central Taiwan city, although there are still technical issues that need to be sorted out.
Hu made the remarks when he visited a photo exhibition held at Taichung's National Museum of Natural Science Monday.
During the visit, Hu stopped in front of a photograph of the Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao and spoke about the benefits and developments the museum brought to the Spanish city.
Hu stressed again that he hopes to get a branch of the museum for Taichung, so that the city can have bigger and better development.

He said that with the central government having promised to provide more than NT$200 million (US$5.98 million) in financing for the program, there should be no big problems in signing a contract with the museum.

However, he added that the dateline for signing an agreement with the Guggenheim has passed and said that if the city cannot ink the agreement soon by obtaining the trust and the support of the Guggenheim Museum and overcoming the technical problems, the program might have to be aborted.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSUMER CONFIDENCE LEVELED OFF IN JANUARY

TEXT.P: The Consumer Confidence Index leveled off in January, despite indications that the country's economy is turning upward, according to the Research Center for Taiwan Economic Development, National Central University in Chungli, Taoyuan County.
Chu Yun-peng, director of the center that compiled the index, said the index was prepared according to consumers' forecasts in six economy-related fields for the next six months.
The survey asked people six questions and translated their answers into scores which were used to prepare the consumers' confidence index, according to Chu.

Compared with one month ago, Chu said, the study showed that people's confidence in "the time to invest in the stock market" had risen by 2.9 points, their confidence in the description that the economy will be steady for the next six months remained unchanged, but the scores for "the time to purchase durable goods" dipped by 0.7 percent to 100.75. This level is still beyond the 100 points threshold indicating optimism.

The confidence in the consumer goods prices dipped by 2.45 points, probably because the survey was conducted against the background that the country's two fuel suppliers were raising their oil prices, said Chu.

The confidence levels in the economic prospects and the employment rates also dipped by 1.3 points and 0.7 points respectively, however, they are still 3.2 points and 8.25 points higher than January, 2003, according to Chu.

Chen Sheng-teh, the general manager of the Chinatrust Commercial Bank, said the leveling off of the confidence index indicates the public concerns about the political impacts as the presidential election campaign heats up.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR BLOOD DONATION DRIVE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged local people Monday to donate blood to help relieve a serious blood shortage facing the country.
Chen made the appeal during a visit to Taipei City's blood donation center.

Chen said he had originally intended to donate blood himself. However, his blood was rejected as he had visited Panama -- a malaria-endemic area -- less than a year ago. Chen made an official visit to Panama last November to attend that country's centennial celebrations.
According to government regulations, those who have visited a communicable disease-affected area cannot donate blood within a year of their return.
"I feel regret that I cannot donate blood this time around," Chen said, adding that he will instead encourage the Presidential Office staff to donate blood to inspire more people to follow suit.

In his view, Chen said, donating blood is both an act of self-interest and altruism that can help boost social harmony. "Through donating blood, we can help save our own lives, those of our families and those of other people, " he said. "Let us be happy blood donors."
Medical sources said nearly all major domestic blood banks are in dire shortage of various types of blood at the moment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SIGNS INVESTMENT PROMOTION ACCORD WITH SWITZERLAND

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Switzerland signed an agreement Monday to cooperate in promoting investment in each other's countries.

Angela Chu, director-general of the Industrial Development and Investment Center (IDIC) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, and Ernst Balmer, president of the Swiss Taiwan Trading Group (STTG) , inked the documents on behalf of their respective countries at a ceremony held in Taipei.
Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-lung and his Swiss counterpart David Syz were also present at the ceremony.

Under the terms of the agreement, the two sides will increase exchanges of information on investment environment and incentives; improve frameworks and provide assistance for facilitating bilateral trade; establish working-level committees to promote cooperation and technical exchanges between the two nations; help each other's visiting trade and investment missions; and explore other opportunities for bilateral cooperation.
IDIC officials said that Switzerland is Taiwan's fourth-largest capital supplier in Europe, behind the Netherlands, the United Kingdom and Germany.

Two-way trade between Taiwan and Switzerland amounted to US$1.365 billion in 2003, with Taiwan exporting goods worth US$1.075 billion to Switzerland and importing US$290.7 million-worth of goods, up 33.2 percent and 11.6 percent, respectively, from the previous year's levels.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IT MISSION HEADS FOR INDIA TO SIGN MOU

TEXT.P: A delegation of representatives from the domestic information technology (IT) industry, including personnel from the Institute for Information Industry (III) , left for India Sunday, a spokesman for the semi-official III said Monday.

The main purpose of the visit is to sign a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with its Indian counterpart -- the National Association of Software and Service Companies (NASSCOM) -- to bolster two-way industrial and economic exchanges and cooperation, the spokesman said.
III Vice Chief of Executive Huang Kuo-chun and NASSCOM President Kiran Karnik will ink the MOU on behalf of their respective organizations, he added.

The two sides will set up a joint group to handle and promote bilateral cooperative issues such as forging joint ventures to pave the way for technology and manpower transfers, he said, noting that the mission will also visit leading Indian companies like Infosys, Wipro, TCS, Tata Elxsi, BPL and Reliance while there.

The delegation is also slated to pay a visit to the Karnataka provincial government to gain first-hand understanding of its investment climate, as well as take part in the NASSCOM 2004 annual meeting, where it will organize seminars to introduce Taiwan's investment and business conditions and its latest industrial trends to Indian businessmen.

The mission also comprises officials from the Science and Technology Advisory Group under the Executive Yuan, the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs and private company executives.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP WELCOMES OPPOSITION CAMP TO HOLD APPROPRIATE ACTIVITIES FEB. 28

TEXT.P: The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Monday it would like to see the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) sponsor appropriate activities on Feb. 28, the island's Peace Memorial Day.

Wu Nai-jen, spokesman of the presidential ticket of Chen Shui-bian and his running mate, Annette Lu, for the ruling party, made the remarks upon learning that the KMT and the PFP are also planning to hold large-scale activities that day as a part of the campaign to drum up support for their presidential bid.
KMT Chairman Lien Chan will run against President Chen Shui-bian, in the March 20 presidential election.

Wu said, "February 28 is a day when Taiwan people reflect upon events that are trauma of the nation, " referring to the tragic incident that took place Feb. 28, 1947 and during the ensuing "white terror" period where hundreds of local elites were killed.
"All parties are welcome to plan for activities appropriate to themselves," Wu said.
On the part of the DPP, it will hold a "one-million-hand-in-hand" campaign, with people around the island joining hands on that day to form a colossal human chain.

President Chen said last week that the campaign scheduled for Feb. 28 is aimed at promoting ethnic harmony and demonstrating to the world that the people of Taiwan are determined to peacefully protect their homeland.

The president said that the problem Taiwan faces today is by no means ethnic disharmony, but rather a problem of national identification. He said that he regretted that some people who decline to identify themselves with Taiwan have distorted the national identify issue as one of ethnic disharmony.

"This sort of distortion has undermined mutual trust in society and is detrimental to Taiwan's social harmony, " Chen said, adding that in the face of the military threat from mainland China, such a move could bring unprecedented danger to the people of Taiwan.
The president urged all local people to come out for the campaign to show their resolve to protect Taiwan's hard-won economic and democratic achievements.

Meanwhile, an ethnic equality alliance comprised of cultural and literary figures announced Monday that it has canceled its scheduled walk in reminiscence of the darkest chapter in Taiwan's history on Feb. 28.

Ku Yi-ling, the liaison official of the recently launched organization, said that the alliance has decided to adopt another way to commemorate the day to avoid ethnic issues from polarizing the public.

Ku said that the alliance is not opposed to the activities by the ruling or opposition parties, but the ethnic issue does not only revolve around national identification, it also deals with the aboriginal people and foreign spouses of Taiwan citizens, but obviously the latter two category of peoples are not equally represented.
She said that the alliance does not want to emulate the approach of the political parties to mobilize a multitude of people on the street, so that they may "blur the real issue that matters."

DOC.HEADLINE: UNI AIRWAYS TO LAUNCH TRANSPORT JOINT VENTURE ACROSS TAIWAN STRAIT

TEXT.P: Taipei-based UNI Airways Corp. is planning to start a joint venture later this month with a Xiamen-based ferry company to transport Taiwan businessmen traveling between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, according to a spokesman for the aviation company.

The joint venture set up by UNI Airways and the Xiamen-based ferry company, to be launched on Feb. 16 under the "mini three links" framework, will offer a sea-air round trip coupon at NT$5,200 (US$155) for travelers between Xiamen and destinations on Taiwan proper via the outlying island of Kinmen, the spokesman said.

Passengers will first ferry between Xiamen and Kinmen before proceeding to destinations on Taiwan proper -- Taipei, Kaohsiung, Taichung, Tainan and Chiayi -- on board a UNI airplane from the island, he explained.

According to the spokesman, the joint venture decision was announced on Jan. 28 after UNI Airways General Manager Su Hong-i paid a visit earlier the same day to Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng to seek his approval and cooperation.

The "mini three links" -- direct trade and transportation service opened in Jan. 2001 between the Taiwan-held islands of Kinmen and Matsu, and Xiamen and Mawei ports on mainland China's Fujian province -- are important channels particularly for the many Taiwan businessmen based in the mainland before the establishment of full links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Su was quoted as saying.

Su said that hopefully, Kinmen can be developed into a transshipment hub across the strait to partially replace Hong Kong and Macau as regional centers to transport a large number of Taiwan businessmen traveling across the strait.

According to Lee, about 200,000 people, including 150,000 Taiwan business people and their families living in mainland China, use the "mini three links" gateway every year to travel between the two sides.

Kinmen County authorities now are trying to make the central government ease its current rules on the "mini three links" to facilitate and expand bilateral exchanges between Taiwan and mainland China, Lee noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTIVIST GROUP CALLS FOR LAW TO LEGALIZE SEX TRADE WORKERS

TEXT.P: Members of a women's rights activists organization, along with a group of prostitutes, appealed Monday to presidential candidates from both the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the opposition Kuomintang to come up with more lenient laws to legalize sex trade workers.

Wang Fang-ping, secretary-general of the private Je-Je-chuen Compassionate Concern Association, which fights for the rights of licensed prostitutes, laborers and housewives, said her group wants the presidential candidates to promise that Article 80 of the Social Order Law will be amended so that neither prostitutes nor their patrons will be punished for engaging in the sex trade.
Under the existing law, Wang said, only those who provide sexual services are punished.
Taiwan's law runs against the world trend as most of advanced countries have legalized the sex trade and the interests of sex trade workers are legally protected, Wang said.

Wang said her association is scheduled to organize a rally by sex trade workers on Feb. 7 to take their appeal to the streets. During the rally, the answers from the candidates regarding the prostitutes' appeal will also be made public, she added.
Wang is known for her strenuous efforts to protect the rights of women working in the sex trade.
During her campaign seeking a seat on the Taipei City Council in late 2002, Wang championed legalization of the sex trade in Taipei.

She also criticized the city government for its failed efforts to crack down on illegal sex workers, pointing out that even though licensed prostitutes and related businesses have been put out of action, the city has not become any "cleaner, " but instead, the illegal sex trade has become "even more frenzied."

Wang, who decided to run for a city councilor's seat from the Chungshan and Tatung districts, which boast the greatest number of pubs, brothels and other sex business locations in the city, failed in that election.

DOC.HEADLINE: INCOMING ALIEN WORKERS MAY BE MONITORED FOR BIRD FLU VIRUS: CLA

TEXT.P: With the number of people dying of bird flu virus in southeast Asia rising, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) may consider taking preventive measures on incoming foreign workers to prevent the disease from entering Taiwan, CLA Chairwoman Chen Chu said Monday.

Chen said the CLA may consider adopting preventive measures similar to the ones taken during the height of the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) last year -- on incoming workers from Southeast Asian countries that have been identified as avian flu-affected areas by the World Health Organization.
One of the preventive measures could be temperature-taking at the airport upon the Asian workers' arrival in Taiwan, Chen added.
Implementation details, however, will be worked out after the CLA communicates with the Department of Health (DOH), Chen added.

Meanwhile, officials from the CLA Employment and Vocational Training Administration said that during the SARS onslaught last year, workers from the Philippines and Vietnam who were coming to Taiwan for employment were monitored medically in both their own countries and Taiwan.
At present, the DOH has not yet notified the CLA about any preventive policy regarding Southeast Asian workers, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUIDELINES NEEDED TO STOP SICK PEOPLE FROM INFECTING OTHERS: DOH

TEXT.P: To prevent the spread of influenza, clear guidelines should be established regarding when a person should be prevented from going to work or school because they are ill, an official of the Department of Health (DOH) said on Monday.

Shih Wen-yi, deputy director-general of DOH's Center for Disease Control, made the remarks as more cases of avian flu caused by the H5N1 virus were reported in Asian countries. Tens of thousands of chickens have already been destroyed and two more people in Vietnam have been infected and died from avian flu..
Though Taiwan is still a bird flu-free country, the authorities are on high alert and have ordered the killing of tens of thousands of chickens and ducks.
Shih said that wearing surgical masks and monitoring a person's temperature are ineffective measures to combat the problem since the illness develops before a fever is present.
It is therefore necessary to establish clear standards to stop those people who appear to be sick from influenza from going to work or school to avoid infecting others.

Shih noted that if avian flu leads to human to human transmissions, it could be more serious than severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) was last year and the need for vaccines, flu-fighting medicines and hospital beds will also be greatly increased.
Shih said that about one in 10 people in Taiwan come down with the common form of the flu each year and between 3,000 and 4,000 die.
If the influenza virus mutates and there are no antibodies in humans, as is the case with the N5N1 avian flu, then the mortality rates of humans after contracting the disease could be 75 percent.

Shih said that there have been serious global outbreaks of influenza every 30 years and each time it was an avian flu virus passed to pigs, and after one or two years of development, the virus was passed on to humans.
He said the global outbreaks of influenza in 1918, 1954 and 1967 followed the same pattern.

As the top health agency of the nation, Shih said that to prevent any forms of flu from mutating, vaccination programs will be expanded to children, and the purchase of influenza-fighting medicines will be increased. Medical treatment networks will also be expanded and field hospitals will be established if needed.
"Overall, the scale of mobilization against the influenza will surpass that of SARS," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PREPARED TO SIGN MEMORANDUM ON LABOR AFFAIRS WITH INDONESIA

TEXT.P: Taiwan will work to sign a memorandum on labor affairs with the Indonesian government in the near future to facilitate bilateral cooperation, Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Chairwoman Chen Chu said Monday.

Chen, who visited Indonesia Jan. 29-Feb. 1 at the invitation of the Indonesian Ministry of Manpower and Transmigration, said at a news conference that the CLA is likely to lift a freeze on the introduction of new Indonesian laborers shortly as she is positive now that part of the situation that led Taiwan to freeze the import of Indonesian laborers has improved substantially.
The memorandum is expected to be forged in three months and will serve as a guideline for both sides to follow when labor disputes or controversies arise again in the future, Chen noted.

The CLA imposed the freeze in August 2002 in retaliation for the high rate of absconding and illegal work among Indonesian laborers in Taiwan, as well as the excessively high brokerage fees charged by the Indonesian side.

Calling her just-concluded trip to Indonesia a success, Chen said she and her Indonesian counterpart, Minister of Manpower and Transmigration Jacob Nuwawea, discussed a wide range of topics, including how to lower the absconding rate of Indonesian workers in Taiwan.

Chen said during her visit, she and Kuo Fang-yu, director-general of the CLA Employment and Vocational Training Administration, were kept abreast of the latest measures that the Indonesian government has implemented to improve the absconding situation, Indonesia's labor training and export policy, the qualification verification system, and the manner of assigning and collecting fees.
Chen's visit to Jakarta marked the first official visit by a high-level Taiwan official to Indonesia since Vice President Annette Lu visited Indonesia in August 2002.

For his part, Kuo said at the news conference that before the labor affairs memorandum can be signed, the two countries must iron out some details, including the question of age. Indonesia hopes that Indonesian citizens aged 18 or above will be allowed to go to Taiwan for employment, against the CLA's regulation of a minimum age of 20.
The two sides must also seek an agreement on the minimum wage issue. Indonesia hopes that it should begin from NT$16,000, whereas the CLA's standard is set at NT$15,840, Kuo said.

On efforts to curb the trend of Indonesian workers to flee from their workplaces in Taiwan, Kuo said the CLA may consider resorting to economic means or direct introduction or employment of workers from Indonesia.

Before Taiwan and Indonesia forge the labor affairs memorandum, Kuo said, the CLA agreed to adopt a pragmatic policy for a "transitional" period, allowing members of the 56,000-strong Indonesian expatriate body whose work contracts are expiring to stay on until the bilateral memorandum is hammered out.

Over the past several months, according to CLA officials, the situation regarding Indonesian workers absconding in Taiwan has improved following closer cooperation and communication between the governments of the two countries.

The CLA's offer of a three-month assessment period, during which time foreign laborers who had absconded were allowed to turn themselves in voluntarily, has also contributed to improving the situation, the officials said.
According to CLA tallies, about 70 percent of the foreign laborers who turned themselves in to Taiwan police between Sept. 1 and Nov. 30 last year for absconding were Indonesian nationals.

Taiwan had approximately 280,000 legal foreign workers as of June 1, 2003, with most being employed in the manufacturing sector and some working as household helpers and caregivers. Of the total, Thai nationals accounted for the largest group at about 102,000 workers, followed by Indonesians at 73,000, Philippine citizens at 66,000, and Vietnamese nationals at 37,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL VOTE PARAMOUNT OVER REFERENDUM: WANG JIN-PYNG

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said Monday that voting for the presidential election must take priority over that of a referendum and that the two must be taken as completely separate issues.

Wang stressed that the presidential election should be held first, and urged the Central Election Commission to be careful about separating the voting. This, he said, would conform to the practice of democratic procedure.
Wang made the remarks as legislators of the ruling and opposition parties began to register for the new legislative session, which will open Friday.
He said that a referendum is the embodiment and implementation of the people's civil rights and should be respected, but he stressed it should be separate and unconnected to the vote for president.

Each eligible voter will be given three ballots on March 20, one to vote for president and two for the referendum questions -- whether Taiwan should strengthen its anti-missile capability in the face of the military threat from the mainland and whether to establish a peaceful and stable framework for cross-strait interactions.
Meanwhile, Wang told legislators across the party spectrum to remain neutral, saying, "This will help the image of the Legislative Yuan."
He stressed that legislators are entitled to support their favorite presidential candidates, but they should refrain from using administrative resources and rights to stump for them.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stocks futures market were lower on Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for February moved down 51 points to close at 6,330, with 24,702 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for March fell 53 points to finish at 6,335, with 448 contract transactions, while June futures lost 12 points to close at 6,376, with 13 contracts traded.
December futures decreased 57 points to finish at 6,342, with 6 contracts traded. No transactions were reported for September futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,381 for February, 6,388 for March, 6,388 for June, 6,399 for September, and 6,399 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
February TE futures lost 3.15 points to finish at 263.7, with 4,097 contract transactions, while March TE futures fell 3.4 points to close at 263.8, with 54 contracts traded.
September TE futures moved down 3.3 points to finish at 265, with 3 contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.
February TF futures moved down 12 points to finish at 943, with 5,259 contract transactions, while March TF futures lost 8.8 points to close at 942.8, with 65 contracts traded.
June TF futures fell 6.8 points to finish at 948.6, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were reported for other month.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 55.42 points to close at 6,319.96.
The bourse opened at 6,379.98 and fluctuated between 6,388.97 and 6,319.96 during trading.
A total of 6.24 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$121.8 billion (US$3.66 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories posted losses, with bank and insurance shares moving down the most at 1.5 percent, followed by construction stocks at 1.1 percent, electrical shares at 1 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.4 percent, and cement stocks at 0.1 percent.
The other major stock categories gained ground, with food stuff shares moving up the most at 2.3 percent followed by textile issues at 1.4 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 429 to 411, with 112 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 55.42 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Monday, with the weighted index moving down 55.42 points to close at 6,319.96.
Market turnover amounted to NT$121.8 billion (US$3.66 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE TO SUBMIT REFERENDUM QUESTIONS FOR APPROVAL

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office is scheduled to submit the two questions for the "peace referendum" to the Executive Yuan Tuesday for approval, sources from the Presidential Office said Monday.

The Executive Yuan, in turn, is expected to give its approval Wednesday to the questions advocated by President Chen Shui-bian, paving the way for the holding of the referendum on the presidential election day slated for March 20, Presidential Office officials said.

Quoting Article 17 of the Referendum Law, which was passed late last year, the officials said that President Chen is empowered by the law to call a referendum when the nation faces an obvious outside threat to its sovereignty.

President Chen announced Jan. 16 that a "peace referendum" would be held alongside the March 20 presidential election to ask voters whether Taiwan should further beef up its anti-missile defenses if Beijing refuses to withdraw the hundreds of ballistic missiles pointed at Taiwan and whether a mechanism should be established for negotiating with Beijing a framework for peaceful cross-Taiwan Strait interaction.
It is estimated that it will take only 26 days for the country to get fully prepared for the March 20 "peace referendum," the officials said.

Since the referendum is being initiated by the president himself rather than by the Taiwan people, the initiation process will be much shorter than the 60-80 days that would normally be required, Central Election Commission Chairman Huang Shih-cheng said last week.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO RISK IN CONSUMING CHICKEN MEAT OR EGGS: COA HEAD

TEXT.P: The head of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) assured the public on Monday that there is no risk in consuming chicken meat or chicken eggs as high temperatures can kill the bird influenza virus.

COA Chairman Lee Chin-lung tried to allay the public's jitters about the recent outbreaks of avian influenza which have so far led to the culling of tens of thousands of ducks and chickens on farms in southern Taiwan.

As wire reports have also said that thousands of chickens on poultry farms have been destroyed out of fears of avian flu outbreaks in Asian countries and that an additional two cases of humans being infected with the deadly A(H5N1) virus were reported in Vietnam, the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has invited officials from the COA, the Department of Health and the Environmental Protection Administration to give reports.
Lee said that Holland, Belgium, Germany and several countries in Asia have reported the A virus, while Taiwan is still a bird-flu free area.
He said that all the fowl on the five chicken farms and one duck farm in Taiwan where the low pathogenic H5N2 avian flu virus was detected have since been destroyed.
The government has also stepped up disinfection work and compensated the poultry farm owners, Lee said.

But he also pointed out that as Taiwan lies on the path of migratory birds, and with the persistent smuggling of poultry into Taiwan, he would not rule out the possibility of an onslaught of the high pathogenic A(H5N1) avian flu virus.

He said the most urgent task now is stepping up overall monitoring, strengthening the monitoring and sampling stations at the observation posts set up in Chiayi and the outlying island of Penghu, and asking the poultry industry to establish high nets to guard against the fowl coming in contact with one another. "The government will provide subsidies if necessary, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: REFERENDUMS MUST BE CARRIED OUT IN LINE WITH LAW: KMT WHIP

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang (KMT) fully supports the holding of referendums in Taiwan but insists that any referendum must be carried out in line with the Referendum Law, a KMT party whip at the Legislative Yuan said Monday.

KMT Legislator Huang Ter-fu said that the KMT will not intentionally boycott the referendum promoted by President Chen Shui-bian which is being referred to by the administration as a "peace referendum, " but he added that the party is opposed to the "illegal" referendum that is "being strategically merged" into the March 20 presidential election.

Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, also a KMT stalwart, said last week that referendums are a right of the people as stated in the Republic of China Constitution, but added that a referendum must be held in accordance with the Referendum Law.

KMT leaders have said recently that Article 17 of the Referendum Law, which was passed late last year, empowers the president to call a referendum when the nation faces an obvious and immediate threat. Such a condition, however, does not currently exist for the holding of a "defensive referendum, "they said.

If the government insists on holding a referendum in tandem with the March 20 presidential election, Huang said, the KMT will then call for the Central Election Committee to maintain its neutrality in election affairs and allow the voters to cast their referendum votes on ballots separate from those for the presidential election.
Meanwhile, another KMT party whip, Liao Feng-teh, said that the KMT supports both referendums and the new 10 major national construction projects which were put forth by the Executive Yuan.
Liao urged the ruling Democratic Progressive Party not to misuse the two issues as campaign schemes in the run-up to the presidential election.
Liao said that he has learned that many voters have decided that on the March 20 election day, they will either not accept a referendum ballot or not mark a choice on the ballot.

Huang and Liao made the remarks on the first day of the new Legislative Yuan session, which is expected to become a battlefield for the ruling DPP and the opposition parties in the run-up to the presidential election, with the referendum and the budget plan on the new 10 major construction projects being the core issues of debate.

President Chen Shui-bian announced in mid-January that a "peace referendum" would be held on the day of the presidential election to ask voters whether Taiwan should further beef up its anti-missile defenses if Beijing refuses to withdraw the hundreds of ballistic missiles aimed at Taiwan and whether a mechanism should be established for negotiations with Beijing over a framework for peaceful cross-Taiwan Strait interaction.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Manila Bulletin: Manila Bulltin celebrates its 104th Anniversary today
The Manila Bulletin, the nation's leading newspaper, marks its 104th anniversary today, vowing to continue its pledge of providing accurate and objective information to the Filipino public.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Macapagal, Poe camps doubt Honasan plot
OPPOSITION candidates belittled the alleged military intelligence report claiming a reported plot to oust movie actor Fernando Poe Jr. in the event he wins the presidency.
The Philippine Star: Palace refuses to counter FPJ's attack on GMA
After repeatedly questioning Fernando Poe Jr.'squalifications to seek the presidency, Malacanang yesterday avoided getting into a word war with the political neophyte.
The Manila Times: AFP has 7,000'ghost'soldiers
Top officials of the Department of National Defense and the Armed Forces are raking no less than P100 million a month by drawing the salaries and benefits of 7,000 fictitious soldiers whose names appear on the military's roster, a highly reliable source told The Times on Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Feb. 2, or the 12th day of the first month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1535: The Argentine city of Buenos Aires is founded by Spanish explorer Pedro de Mendoz.
1556: An earthquake rocks the provinces of Shensi, Henan and Shansi in mainland China, killing an estimated 830,000 people.
1665: A British fleet captures New Amsterdam, the center of the Dutch colony in North America and the flourishing trading settlement on the island of Manhattan, renaming it New York in honor of the Duke of York.
1848: Mexico, according to a treaty signed after the U.S.-Mexico War, cedes Texas, New Mexico and California to the United States.
1878: Greece declares war on Turkey.
1913: The world's biggest railroad station, New York's Grand Central Station, is formally opened.
1915: Germany begins U-boat blockades of British waters, while the United States warns Germany against attacking American ships.
1926: Valery Giscard d'Estaing, French president from 1974 to 1981, is born.
1943: German troops surrender to the Soviet Union in Stalingrad.
1946: Taipei's Yuanshan Zoo is opened.
1953: The U.S. government announces it will no longer block Chinese Nationalist troops in their raids against mainland Chinese troops stationed along the mainland coastline during the period of the Nationalist-Communist struggle.
1967: Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle is elected president of Nicaragua.
1970: China Airlines launches ROC-U.S. flight services with its inaugural flight, by a Boeing 707, to San Francisco.
1970: British philosopher and Nobel Prize-winner Bertrand Russel dies at the age of 98.
1972: Protesters in Dublin burn down the British Embassy in an act of revenge for the "Bloody Sunday" shooting in Londonderry the previous weekend in which British troops killed 13 Catholic youths and wounded another 17.
1975: Gen. Gamad Shumaimari, chief of the general staff of the armed forces of Saudi Arabia, arrives in Taipei for a 10-day visit.
1979: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini returns from 14 years in exile in Paris to rule Iran. He succeeded the Shah of Iran who fled to Egypt 15 days prior to Khomeini's return after failing to resist mounting opposition masterminded by Khomeini.
1986: Oscar Arias Sanchez is elected president of Costa Rica.
1989: A coup in Paraguay topples President Alfredo Stroessner who ruled the South American country for 35 years.
1989: The last of the Soviet troops withdraw from Afghanistan, ending a nine-year occupation of the country by Communist forces.
1994: Rafael Caldera is sworn in as president of Venezuela.
1994: The Republic of China and Burkina Faso announce the restoration of diplomatic relations, which were suspended for 21 years.
1998: A Cebu Pacific Air DC-9 crashes into a mountainside 65 kilometers northeast of Cagayan de Oro airport in the Philippines, killing all 104 people on board.
2000: The U.S. House of Representatives passes the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act, a bill aimed at strengthening military ties with Taiwan, despite warnings from Beijing and the White House.
2001: Exiled mainland Chinese-born Nobel laureate writer Gao Xingjiang meets with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If there were a sure way of getting rich, even though one had to be a groom and keep horses, I would be willing to pursue it. But as there is really no sure way of getting rich, I prefer to follow the pursuits congenial to me."

DOC.HEADLINE: WHO OFFICIAL URGES COUNTRIES NOT TO OVERREACT REGARDING BIRD FLU FEARS
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Feb. 2 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: As the bird flu epidemic continues to spread across Asia, a World Health Organization official on Monday called for affected countries not to overreact regarding fears the disease may now be transmitted from person to person.
The official, who is responsible for the WHO global influenza program, made the remarks while responding to questions raised by the Central News Agency.

Although those countries that have been facing bird flu outbreaks should make efforts to prevent the spread of the disease, he said, it is not necessary for them to overreact regarding the possibility of human-to-human transmission of avian flu.
He made the comments a day after the WHO said that two sisters in Vietnam who died of bird flu last month probably caught the virus from their brother -- the first cases of human-to-human infection.

Pointing out that the H5N1 virus has been transmitted among fowl over a period of time and that more than a thousand people have been exposed to the virus, the official said the fact that only a few people have been infected demonstrates that the disease is not easily transmitted to humans.

The official noted that the WHO's five-level global alert mechanism for the bird flu has been maintained at the zero level, meaning there is no global epidemic. He said the WHO's investigations have shown there have been no further cases of human-to-human transmission of the disease.

Although the WHO will not rule out the possibility, the official said that currently there is no scientific evidence to confirm that bird flu will become an epidemic in which the disease is transmitted among humans.

DOC.HEADLINE: SERIOUS CONSEQUENCES IF BIRD FLU VIRUS COMBINES WITH HUMAN FLU VIRUS

TEXT.P: Renowned AIDS specialist David Ho warned in Beijing Monday that if the bird flu virus genetically combines with the human influenza virus to create a new virus, the consequences could be serious.
Ho said that the H5N1 avian flu virus, which is more pathogenic than the H5N2 virus, can be transmitted from fowl to humans, but added that the possibility of human-to-human transmission is very low.

However, if the H5N1 virus combines with the H5N2 human influenza virus to create a new H5N2 virus, this might trigger large-scale human-to-human transmissions, Ho said during an interview with reporters from the Hong Kong-based daily Wen Wei Po. He said that such a situation would be extremely serious as no people would be immune to the new virus.
He added that a major, large-scale outbreak of influenza occurs about once every 30 years. The most serious outbreak occurred in 1918, with some 40 million people dying from the disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKERS TO VISIT NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 2 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A group of lawmakers from Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will visit New York later this week to meet with scholars at major U.S. think tanks, including the National Committee on American Foreign Policy, Chinese community sources said Monday.
The group, including Legislators John Chang and Sun Guo-hua, is scheduled to arrive in New York Thursday, the sources said.

The KMT lawmakers are expected to exchange views with American academics on cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Taiwan's plan to hold a referendum on Beijing's military threat alongside the March 20 presidential election and other related topics, the sources said.
The group will also meet with representatives of the Chinese community during its stay in New York. It will wrap up the visit and leave for home Feb. 7.

DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: 2 Blasts Kill 56 at N.Iraq Celebrations.
A pair of suicide bombers infiltrated holiday celebrations at the northern Iraq officies of the nation's two main Kurdish political parties and blew themselves up, killing at least 56 people and injuring hundreds in nearly simultaneous strikes.
