DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HELPS GRENADA IMPROVE MEDICAL FACILITIES
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Feb. 3 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China donated US$100,000 to Grenada Monday to help the Caribbean nation improve its medical facilities, according to officials of the ROC Embassy in Grenada.
Ambassador to Grenada Jiang Li-shang delivered the donation on behalf of the ROC government to Grenada Minister of Health Ann Antoine at a ceremony held at the minister's office.
After receiving the donation, Antoine thanked the ROC government for the generous donation, which she said will greatly benefit the people of her country.
Jiang said that the ROC is pleased to help care for the health of Grenada's people and that the donation represents the deep friendship that exists between the two countries.
He expressed the hope that bilateral ties will be further enhanced through exchanges and cooperation between both the governments and people of the two nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES PEOPLE TO FIGHT AVIAN FLU WITH CONFIDENCE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian called on the public Tuesday to join hands with the government in warding off avian flu and to be confident that the country can ride out the crisis unscathed.

Speaking at a weekly meeting of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), the president, who is also the DPP chairman, said Taiwan is the only country in the region which has not been affected by the avian flu caused by the H5N1 virus.
In light of the high volume of travel between Taiwan and neighboring states that have reported bird flu cases, the government and the people should work together to prevent an invasion of the virus.

In addition to a clampdown on the smuggling of poultry, the health and agricultural authorities should keep a close eye on local poultry farms and set up a rapid communication mechanism to relay information about the disease, the president went on.

Citing the country's successful fight against severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) early last year, the president said the lessons drawn from dealing with that epidemic will be useful in combating the avian flu.
"United together, I am confident we can weather the crisis, " the president said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PORTLAND MISSION VISITS KAOHSIUNG CITY COUNCIL

TEXT.P: A 45-member delegation from Portland, Oregon, paid a visit Tuesday to the Kaohsiung city council.

Led by Portland Deputy Mayor Randy Leonard, the U.S. visitors were warmly greeted by Council Speaker Tsai Chien-hsing, city councilors and municipal government officials. Kaohsiung and Portland maintain close and cordial twin-city ties, with more and more two-way exchanges every year.

Tsai said the city council fully supports these bilateral activities and he added that the port city is seeking to sharpen its competitiveness by developing a wide range of projects, ranging from an improved traffic network to cultural affairs, in an attempt to increase its international presence.

He expressed the hope that enhanced two-way exchanges and activities will help create a mutually beneficial situation for both cities, particularly on the tourist and cultural fronts, and that he can visit Portland soon.

The council speaker also thanked Portland for the assistance the city extended to Taiwan when the island was struck by a devastating earthquake Sept. 21, 1999 and by outbreaks of the potentially deadly severe acute respiratory syndrome in the first half of last year.

Describing themselves as deeply impressed by the warmth and hospitality of the people of Kaohsiung -- the largest city in southern Taiwan -- the U.S. guests also said they are very interested in the traditional celebrations currently being displayed in the streets to mark Lantern Festival, which falls on Feb. 5.
The city's vigor and its people's vivacity and friendliness are the major attractions for foreign visitors, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SWISS VICE MINISTER VISITS HSINCHU SCIENCE-BASED INDUSTRIAL PARK

TEXT.P: Switzerland's vice minister of international economic affairs and financial markets, David Syz, visited the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park Tuesday to explore opportunities for technological cooperation between Taiwan and Switzerland.
Syz, traveling at the head of a seven-member trade delegation, was accompanied by Jost Feer, director of the Trade Office of Swiss Industries in Taipei.
In addition to holding talks with Swiss and local enterprises operating in the industrial complex, Syz also toured the Industrial Technology Research Institute.
He said he was deeply impressed by the vigorous development of the information technology industry in Taiwan's high-tech stronghold, park administration officials said.
Syz and his delegation were scheduled to depart Taiwan later that evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESCRIPTION FLU DRUG SALES UP IN SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: Singapore may be free of the deadly bird flu, but many Singaporeans have been buying prescription flu drugs as an added protection, especially those who have to travel to affected countries.

Experts say prescription flu drugs like Tamiflu can protect healthy people from the bird flu, as well as prevent lethal complications for flu victims. As a result, the Raffles Medical Group of 60 clinics has seen a tenfold increase in demand for Tamiflu in the past month.
Tamiflu does not come cheap, costing about US$2.80 per pill. And unlike a flu vaccine, which can last a year, Tamiflu is only effective during the period of consumption.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO REGISTER HIS ELECTION CANDIDACY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will register his candidacy for the March 20 presidential election Wednesday, a spokesman for his campaign headquarters said Tuesday.
Chen is scheduled to arrive at the Central Election Commission (CEC) at 11 a.m. in the company of representatives from Taiwan's four major ethnic groups, the spokesman said.
"The arrangement is aimed at signifying harmony among the four major ethnic groups -- Minnan (Taiwanese) , Hakka, mainlanders and Aborigines," the spokesman said.

Chen's top five campaign aides, including Premier Yu Shyi-kun, Taipei County Magistrate Su Tzen-chang and Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, will also accompany Chen on his candidacy registration, the spokesman said.
The aides will call a joint news conference at the campaign headquarters prior to Chen's registration to expound on the gist of Chen's platform for his re-election bid, the spokesman went on.

The upcoming election will be a race between the "pan-blue alliance" of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) and the "pan-green" camp, which comprises the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and other pro-independence political groups.

KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong announced earlier this year that they will team up to challenge Chen's re-election bid. Lien reportedly will register his candidacy Wednesday afternoon.

Candidacy registration lasts from Jan. 31 through Feb. 6. The CEC is scheduled to sponsor televised campaign forums for the candidates between Feb. 21 and March 19 and eligible voter rosters will be available for public viewing March 2-4. The election will take place March 20 and the results will be formally published by March 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISTRICT COURT TO IMPLEMENT CHILD CUSTODY RULING ON BRAZILIAN BOY

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung District Court will use force to take a boy at the center of an international custody battle away from his Taiwanese uncle and send him home to his legal guardian in Brazil if the uncle fails to hand over the boy voluntarily by Feb. 5, a judge said Tuesday.

Liao Cheng-hsiung, a judge at the district court's civil suit execution department, said the representative of the boy's Brazilian legal guardian is scheduled to lead a judge and local police officers to take the boy away from his Taiwanese uncle's home Feb. 6.
Liao said the court hopes that Wu Hou-yen will voluntarily hand over Iruan Wu Ergui to his legal guardian's representative in Taiwan by the Feb. 5 deadline to avoid further unnecessary trouble.
Since the Supreme Court has meted out a final verdict that the boy's guardianship belongs to his Brazilian grandmother, Rosa Ergui, Liao said he hopes Wu will respect the court ruling.
Rosa Ergui has commissioned Brazil's representative to Taiwan, Paulo A.P. Pinto, to take Iruan, who is better known as Wu Yi-hua in Taiwan, back to Brazil on her behalf.

Iruan was born out of wedlock in Brazil in July 1995 to a Brazilian mother and a Taiwanese father. His mother died six years ago and his grandmother was appointed his legal guardian. He was brought to Taiwan in March 2001 by his father, who died a couple of weeks later. Wu, the boy's uncle, refused to allow the child to leave for home, and the boy has since been living in the southern Taiwan county of Kaohsiung and is now a second-grader at a local elementary school.
His grandmother eventually resorted to legal action to regain custody of her grandson when it became clear that Wu would not let her take the child back to Brazil in 2001.
Wu said over the weekend that he hopes Ergui will come to Taiwan to take the boy back in person.
"I'll feel at ease only when I can hand over my nephew to his Brazilian grandmother in person," said Wu.
However, the grandmother said earlier that she would not come to come to Taiwan again because she wants to avoid the media harassment, which she feels is bad for the boy.

According to Taiwan regulations, if Wu refuses to comply with the court order, he can be fined between NT$30,000 and NT$300,000 (US$890-US$8,902) and if he still refuses to hand over the boy, the court can keep fining him. If Wu continues to hold out, the court will ultimately order the police to implement the transfer of custody.
A support group has been formed in Kaohsiung County that has called for donations of NT$10 (US$0.296) per person to help Wu pay for the fines and support for the boy.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLANNED REFERENDUM FAVORABLE FOR CROSS-STRAIT TIES: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's planned referendum will be favorable for the future development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said Tuesday.

Explaining a statement made by President Chen Shui-bian earlier that day on the "peace referendum" to be held March 20 to coincide with the presidential election, Tsai said that the two questions to be put to the vote in the referendum show that the government is trying to actively settle the differences between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait by peaceful means.
She told the foreign diplomats gathered at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs that Beijing should respect the collective will demonstrated in the referendum.
According to Chen's statement, the two referendum questions are as follows:

-- "The people of Taiwan demand that the Taiwan Strait issue be resolved through peaceful means. Should mainland China refuse to withdraw the missiles it has targeted at Taiwan and openly renounce the use of force against us, would you agree that the government should acquire more advanced anti-missile weapons to strengthen Taiwan's self-defense capabilities?"

-- "Would you agree that our government should engage in negotiation with mainland China on the establishment of a peace and stability framework for cross-strait interaction in order to build consensus and for the welfare of the peoples of both sides?"

Referring to Chen's proposal for establishing liaison offices on each side of the strait by the two sides, Tsai said that her office does not rule out the possibility that representatives of the proposed liaison offices will be assigned by the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) of Taiwan and the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) of mainland China, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIAL HEADS MISSION FOR U.S. NATIONAL PRAYER BREAKFAST

TEXT.P: Senior Presidential Advisor Peng Ming-min, traveling at the head of a Taiwan delegation, left Tuesday for Washington, D.C., where he will take part in the 2004 U.S. National Prayer Breakfast slated for Thursday.

The delegation also includes Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Kau Ying-mao, lawmakers Chen Tan-sun and Parris Chang of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and opposition Kuomintang lawmakers John Chang and Sun Guo-hua, as well as representatives from the academic spectrum and the private sector.

In addition to participating in the Feb. 5. breakfast, in which delegation members will meet U.S. government officials and their counterparts from around the world, they will also meet local political figures, think tank members and Chinese community leaders to exchange views on U.S.-Taiwan relations and other issues of mutual concern.

Dismissing speculation that the trip by Kau and Chen might have something to do with Taiwan's planned March 20 referendum, Richard Shih, a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said the vice minister will simply attend the annual gathering and stressed that it has nothing to do with the referendum issue.

Both Kau and Chen were members of a propaganda mission recently organized by the National Security Council to explain to the United States the purpose and contents of the March 20 referendum called by President Chen Shui-bian, while Parris Chang was a leader of a similar mission aimed at European countries.

Chen claimed prior to his departure from Chiang Kai-shek International Airport that his trip is totally irrelevant to the referendum issue and added that no one has instructed them to publicize the issue in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN TO START CAMPAIGN TO RAISE AWARENESS ABOUT REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will start a publicity campaign to raise public awareness about the forthcoming referendum now that President Chen Shui-bian has activated the referendum process Tuesday by signing a letter listing the reasons for calling a referendum.

Lin Chia-lung, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan, said the letter was delivered to the Executive Yuan and that the Executive Yuan will publish the letter on the front pages of seven local newspapers Wednesday.

The letter will be discussed at a Cabinet meeting that same day, and is expected to be approved immediately. It will then be referred to the Central Election Committee for implementation of the referendum.

Lin said the Executive Yuan has already worked out a position paper on the referendum, which will be presented to the Cabinet meeting for approval before being published and delivered to the country's 7 million households by mid-February.
In addition, the Executive Yuan will air several commercials on local television stations, beginning mid-February, to stress the legality and necessity of the referendum.

The voters will be asked two questions in the referendum. The first will be: "The People of Taiwan demand that the Taiwan Strait issue be resolved through peaceful means. Should mainland China (the PRC) refuse to withdraw the missiles it has targeted at Taiwan and to openly renounce the use of force against us, would you agree that the government should acquire more advanced anti-missile weapons to strengthen Taiwan's self-defense capabilities?"

The second question will be: "Would you agree that our government should engage in negotiation with mainland China on the establishment of a peace and stability framework for cross-strait interaction in order to build consensus and for the welfare of the peoples of both sides?"

DOC.HEADLINE: CHRISTMAS MAY BE MADE NATIONAL HOLIDAY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that he will think about reinstating Dec. 25 as national holiday, although in celebration of Christmas rather than its original purpose of marking the Republic of China's Constitution Day.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with a group of foreign Catholic missionaries who have contributed the prime of their lives to serving the people of Taiwan.
The holiday was canceled after the government adjusted the work-week and national holiday schedules a few years ago.

Chen said he is aware that many Catholic devotees are discontented with the cancellation of the Dec. 25 holiday. "We'll further discuss this issue in hope of forging a national consensus. I'll be glad to see the proposal receive the support of a majority of local citizens," he added.

Noting that the Catholic church has long played an important role in Taiwan's development and modernization, Chen said he appreciates the devoted services of the large number of foreign Catholic missionaries to the people of Taiwan over the decades.

In addition, Chen said, many Catholic priests have helped promote Taiwan's cultural exchanges with other countries as well as assist in the preservation and dissemination of Taiwan's cultural legacies, including publishing important dictionaries, translating the Bible and preserving the languages and cultures of Taiwan's aboriginal tribes.

Chen further said he admires Pope John Paul II's efforts to promote world peace. "I fully support the pope's appeal in his 2004 World Peace Day message that leaders of countries around the world are obligated to promote peace and that a new world order should be based on concern, justice and morals," he added.

The president said he believes that promoting a culture of peace and creating a goodwill and reconciliatory environment are crucial to maintaining peace across the Taiwan Strait and ensuring regional stability and prosperity. He assured the Catholic missionaries that he will lead Taiwan along the "road of democracy and peace."
During the meeting, Chen also promised that the Cabinet will use its reserve funds to pay for the NT$10,000 service fee for each foreign missionary who applies for permanent residency in Taiwan.
"Money is not a problem. The government should pay the charge to show its gratitude for foreign clergymen who have dedicated themselves to working for Taiwan throughout the years," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Bush bets America agrees with his fiscal priorities.
President Bush on Monday unveiled a budget with cuts in domestic programs but big increases for the military, showing himself a gambler willing to bet his re-election that he made the correct fiscal choices.
Mr. Bush's calculation is that voters will care far more about protecting the nation from another terrorist attack than about cuts to popular programs, or, for that matter, the record-high deficit.
Wall Street Journal: Bush unveils budget package of $2.4 Trillion.
Preparing the way for his re-election bid, President Bush proposed a $2.4 trillion budget that promises to sharply slash the deficit over the coming five years but relies on some fiscal sleight of hand in an effort to reach his goal.
The budget reflects the president's top political priorities -- taxes and security -- at the expense of other domestic programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET MULLING EXPANSION AT SCIENCE PARK IN CENTRAL TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i said Tuesday that he has instructed the National Science Council (NSC) to consider acquiring extra land for planned expansion at the Central Science-based Industrial Park in Taichung.
Lin made the announcement while giving a speech at a meeting with officials from the central coordination office of the Executive Yuan in Taichung City.

Pointing out that the existing 153 hectares of land in the industrial park have already been allocated as a result of strong demand from companies operating within the compound, Lin said he has asked the NSC to study the feasibility of acquiring an additional 130 nearby hectares of land from the Taiwan Sugar Corporation and the private sector to satisfy fresh demand amid booming business prospects.
Lin attributed the situation to the recovering domestic economy that has been particularly noticeable in the real estate market of Taichung City.
Taiwan's economic growth rate is estimated to top 5 percent for the whole of this year, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: EYE SPECIALISTS SAY TAKING FLU MEDICINE MAY CAUSE GLAUCOMA

TEXT.P: Eye specialists in Singapore said Monday that medicines which alleviate flu symptoms might put some people at risk of glaucoma or blindness.
Experts from the National Eye Centre said any medicine which causes the sudden dilation of the pupil can cause glaucoma.
"These medicines usually work by constricting the blood vessels in the nose and preventing your nose from running, " said Steve Seah, senior consultant at the center.

"One of the side-effects is the dilation of the pupil. Those at risk from the disease will suffer a build-up of fluid pressure in the eye when their pupils dilate, and this leads to glaucoma, " he explained.
"Every year, glaucoma affects 12 to 13 people in every 100,000. Chinese people are three times more likely to get it than those of other races," Seah said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3RD GROUP OF DIPLOMATIC CONSCRIPTS TO LEAVE FOR OVERSEAS SERVICE

TEXT.P: A group of conscripts who will work with the Republic of China's diplomatic missions abroad as an alternative to their mandatory military service will soon take up their overseas posts, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday.
The 41 "diplomatic conscripts" have completed the necessary professional training for work at Taiwan's agricultural and fishery missions in various countries, the official said.
According to the official, 18 will be sent to work in African countries, 20 will go to Central and South America and three will be assigned to Asia-Pacific countries.
They will be the third group of "diplomatic conscripts" since Taiwan began to include diplomatic work in the alternative military service choice items in 2002.
"We hope they will help boost our friendship with the people of their host countries and upgrade the agricultural technology of our diplomatic allies," the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO DE-SALINATION PLANTS PLANNED FOR PENGHU TO EASE WATER SHORTAGE

TEXT.P: The central government is planning to build two de-salination plants on Penghu Island during the next two years to ease a water shortage that has been a problem for several years.

The decision was made during a meeting held last week by a commission under the Executive Yuan chaired by Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i. Officials attending the meeting discussed issues pertaining to water, power and medical resources supplies for the outlying island off Taiwan's southwest coast.

The decision was finalized after officials from the Taiwan Provincial Water Company gave a briefing about the present situation on Penghu, which has been hit by a severe drought over the past two years, with its reservoirs now nearly dry.

Construction plans for the two de-salination plants, one capable of containing 2,500 tons of water and the other 3,000 tons, is slated to be completed in mid-2005 and 2006 as a means of securing a long- term water supply for local residents.

It was also decided that current shipments of fresh water from Taiwan to Penghu will be maintained until August of this year in the face of the slim possibility of abundant rainfall in the coming months.
Penghu and the rest of the country, particularly the north, have been troubled by a continued dry spell since 2002. Conserving water has become an urgent matter for the public and the government.
In line with government measures, the island county of Penghu has been under the second phase of water restrictions since May 10, 2003.

According to a set of water restriction measures worked out by a national anti-drought task force in March last year, the second phase comprises a 20 percent cutback in water supply to heavy users such as car washes, saunas and swimming pools.

To prevent a further deterioration in providing water to the general public in northern regions, the second phase of water limits are slated to kick off in Taipei, Taoyuan and Hsinchu areas on Feb. 6.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROMISE IS TIMELESS, SAYS PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that if he is re-elected in March, he will continue to honor his "four noes plus one" pledge and safeguard Taiwan's present status quo, including its sovereign status and peace with mainland China.

Chen made the pledge at a news conference held at the Presidential Office where he expounded in detail the reasons behind his decision to call a referendum on mainland China's missile threat to coincide with the March 20 presidential election. The news conference attracted more than 100 journalists from home and abroad.
During the question-and-answer session, Chen was asked if he is re-elected, will he continue his "four noes plus one" pledge outlined in his 2000 inaugural speech or will he forsake those promises?
In response, Chen said a promise is a promise. "A promise is timeless, and I'll never lightly back off my promise," he stressed.

Over the past four years, Chen said he has faithfully honored his "four noes plus one" pledge which includes no change to Taiwan's national title and flag and no holding of an independence vs. unification referendum.
If re-elected, Chen said he will definitely repeat the "four noes plus one" pledge in his inaugural speech.

Chen, who is running a tight race with the opposition "pan-blue alliance" ticket of Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong, said if he wins the mandate for another four years, he will continue to promote political reform, economic reform, social reform, judicial reform and education reform based on the current achievements.
"We'll also do whatever we can to protect Taiwan's sovereign status quo, democratic status quo, economic prosperity status quo and the peaceful status quo in the Taiwan Strait," Chen said.
Stressing that Taiwan would not like to see its status quo be changed unilaterally, Chen said his administration will push for constitutional reform on the principle of no change to the status quo.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DIPS ON TAIPEI FOREX

A total of US$817 million changed hands.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY TO WASHINGTON REITERATES HIS INTENTION TO RESIGN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 2 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Representative to the United States Chen Chien-jen on Monday reiterated his intention to resign from his current post and expressed the hope that the government will send another official to replace him as soon as possible.
The envoy made the comments while responding to questions raised regarding his intended resignation at a meeting with Chinese-language media in Washington, D.C.
Although he had tried to hand in his resignation following his recent consultations in Taipei in early January, Chen said that President Chen Shui-bian asked for him to stay on.

Pointing out that he has been determined to resign from the post as Taiwan's top official in the United States, the ROC diplomat said that he will spare no effort to do his job until the last day of his service in his current post.
He also emphasized that his intended resignation is purely due to personal and family reasons, and that he has no plans to serve in government agencies in the future.

Asked whether he will consider accepting President Chen's offer to continue serving the next government if the president wins the presidential election set for March 20, the representative said that he will not accept the offer.
The representative also said that he has long considered resigning from his current job and that he has not changed his mind.

Saying that he has long considered resigning from the various posts which he has held for the last 37 years, the representative said that he believes that he has served the nation and the people rather than any individual or political party.
No one is irreplaceable, said the envoy, adding that he hopes to see the government send a suitable official to replace him as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TAIEX Index futures for March fell 73 points to finish at 6,262, with 454 contract transactions, while June futures lost 96 points to close at 6,280, with 18 contracts traded.
September futures fell 88 points to finish at 6,260, with 3 contract transactions, while December futures decreased 72 points to finish at 6,270, with 3 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,330 for February, 6,335 for March, 6,376 for June, 6,348 for September, and 6,342 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
February TE futures lost 3.55 points to finish at 260.15, with 3,416 contract transactions, while March TE futures fell 3.65 points to close at 260.15, with 44 contracts traded.

February TF futures moved down 5.2 points to finish at 937.8, with 7,115 contract transactions, while March TF futures lost 4.8 points to close at 938, with 76 contracts traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY READIED TO HELP IN BIRD FLU PREVENTION EFFORTS: MND

TEXT.P: Taiwan's armed forces have been readied to help in the government's bird flu prevention efforts, military spokesman Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng said Tuesday.

Minister of National Defense Tang Yiau-min has already instructed that the disease-prevention mechanisms applied during the onslaught of SARS last year be activated in efforts to prevent the spread of avian flu to the Taiwan population, Huang said.

The military made a significant contribution in the battle against SARS last year, including dispatching military personnel to hospitals to help out with health care affairs, opening military hospital beds to civilian patients, and supporting anti-virus bio-research, Huang said.
He added that the military-run P4 Laboratory, the only P4 lab in Taiwan, has also been a stronghold in SARS research in Taiwan.

The P4 lab, which was closed in late 2003 after an in-lab researcher contracted SARS while handling a sample of the virus, can be reopened at anytime after it successfully passes a Department of Health check, Huang noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Feb. 3, or the 13th day of the first month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1468: Johann Gutenberg, a German goldsmith who developed the letterpress printing method and oil-based inks, dies in obscurity. His "Mazarin Bible" (1455) is believed to be the first book printed with such type.
1488: Portuguese explorer Bartolomeu Diaz, after rounding the Cape of Good Hope, lands on Africa's eastern coast. He is the first European to land on African soil.
1830: Greece is declared independent under the protection of Britain, France, and Russia at a London conference.
1867: Prince Mutsuhito becomes Emperor Meiji at the age of 14. His reign in Japan lasted until 1912.
1913: The 16th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution is ratified, giving the government the power to impose and collect taxes on income.
1919: The League of Nations holds its first meeting in Paris with U.S. President Woodrow Wilson presiding.
1924: Woodrow Wilson, the 28th president of the United States and winner of the Nobel Peace Prize in 1919, dies at the age of 67.
1930: Ho Chi Minh establishes the Vietnamese Communist Party in Hong Kong.
1931: An earthquake jolts Hawks Bay in New Zealand, killing 256 people.
1943: British bombers pound the German city of Hamburg.
1945: U.S. troops recover Manila in the Philippines from Japanese forces during World War II.
1960: British Prime Minister Harold Macmillan tells the astonished white politicians in the Cape Town parliament that they should accept racial equality.
1966: The unmanned Soviet spaceship Luna IX lands on the moon and sends signals back to Earth.
1969: Yasser Arafat is elected as the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization.
1973: Fighting in Vietnam comes to a halt when a cease-fire goes into effect.
1974: Dr. Arthur A. Kimball, director of the International Training Section of the U.S. Agency for International Development, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: The Indian Ocean satellite communications ground station in Taiwan begins operations, providing improved telephone service to Europe and Africa.
1974: The ROC's agricultural technical cooperation with Honduras is extended for two years.
1977: China Steel Corp.'s Kaohsiung mill begins operations.
1978: The European Economic Community and Communist China initial their first trade agreement.
1989: P.W. Botha resigns as chief of South Africa's ruling party.
1989: A military coup topples strongman Alfredo Stroessner in Paraguay, ending his eight successive presidential terms and 35 years of rule.
1992: A fight breaks out in a camp for Vietnamese boat refugees in Hong Kong, resulting in 18 deaths.
1994: U.S. President Bill Clinton announces the lifting of the United States' trade embargo against Vietnam.
1996: An earthquake rocks Lijiang in southwestern China, killing more than 302 people.
2000: An A300-600R airbus of China Airlines, carrying 225 passengers, departs Taipei for Manila, formally resuming direct air links between Taiwan and the Philippines after they had been suspended for four months.
2001: One hundred and fifty practitioners and supporters of Zhong Gong, a form of Chinese kung fu which emphasizes the use of inner strength to toughen one's body, stage a parade around Guam to call for the release of founder Zhang Hongbao.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Living upon the poorest fare with cold water for drink and with my bent arms for a pillow, I could yet find pleasure in such a life, whereas riches and honors acquired through the sacrifice of what is right would be to me as unreal as a mirage."

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG COUNTY FRUITS MAKE INROADS INTO FOREIGN MARKETS

TEXT.P: The southern Taiwan county of Kaohsiung has succeeded in tapping overseas fruit markets through the concerted efforts of the county government, fruit growers and trading companies, agricultural sources said Wednesday.
Kaohsiung County exported 87,000 tons of various kinds of fruits last year, including bananas, guavas, mangos, lichees, dates, papayas and bell fruit, the sources said.
Major overseas markets for Kaohsiung County fruits included Japan, Hong Kong, Singapore, Canada, the United States and mainland China's Shanghai City.

In January of this year, Kaohsiung County, one of Taiwan's major fruit production areas, exported 70 tons of guavas to Canada, stimulating a rise in domestic retail prices of the fruit. Market sources said the price of guavas has risen from NT$8 per kilogram to NT$20 in the past two weeks, while the retail price of high quality guavas has surged to NT$30.

Kaohsiung County is a major guava production base, with more than 3,000 hectares of guava orchards turning out about 90,000 tons of guavas annually. Thanks to assistance from the Council of Agriculture, the quality of Kaohsiung County-grown guavas has improved significantly in recent years, local government officials said.

The group is made up of undergraduate and graduate students from National Taiwan University, National Tsinghua University, National Sun Yat-sen University, Fu Jen Catholic University and Soochow University. Most of the students are visiting mainland China for the first time.
The group, sponsored by the Ten Outstanding Young Persons' Foundation, will also visit Shanghai and Hangzhou during the trip, as well as engage in exchanges with mainland university students.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER WARNS ABOUT NEGATIVE ECONOMIC IMPACTS FROM AVIAN FLU

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun urged his Cabinet members to do their best to achieve the economic target of a 5 percent expansion this year, and in the same breath he warned them to ward off the avian flu which might disrupt the economic growth.

He made the comment at a weekly Cabinet meeting in which Ho Mei-yueh, the vice chairwoman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development reported that the economy expanded by 3.15 percent in the last year and all economic indexes showed a strong upward trend is taking place this year.
The unemployment rate stood at 4.99 percent in 2003, which is 0.18 percent lower than the previous year and is expected to dip to 4.6 percent or even 4.5 percent this year, Ho said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEAN COMMISSIONER TO BE HONORED BY FU JEN UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: European Commissioner for education and culture Viviane Reding will receive an honorary doctoral degree in literature Thursday at Fu Jen Catholic University for her outstanding promotion of cultural affairs in Europe.

Reding, a member of the European Commission (EC) since 1999, was born in Luxembourg in 1951. Formerly a veteran journalist, she devoted much of her life to culture, education, training, youth, audiovisual affairs, sports and civil society.
Reding once served as chairperson of the EP - (European Parliament-) Taiwan Friendship Group and has maintained a good relationship with the Taiwan authorities over a long period of time.
She has frequently spoken out at the EC to support Taiwan's efforts to join world bodies, such as the International Monetary Fund and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

The prominent woman politician also played a significant role in pushing the European Union to set up a representative office last year in Taiwan as a means of improving bilateral ties and bolstering two-way exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICERS VISIT INVESTIGATION BUREAU

TEXT.P: Officers of the Japanese Coast Guard recently visited the Investigation Bureau (IB) under the Ministry of Justice and exchanged views on combating international narco-trafficking with their Taiwanese counterparts, IB officials said Wednesday.
The visiting Japanese officers were specially interested in Taiwan's crackdown on amphetamine manufacturing plants, the officials said.
Taiwan has been increasing international cooperation in combating drug trafficking, including exchanges of information, the officials said.

They attributed the seizure of 30 kilograms of high-grade heroin smuggled from Thailand Tuesday at Keelung Harbor and the arrest of two suspects involved in the smuggling to international cooperation, in addition to concerted efforts by domestic law enforcement agencies.

The seized heroin, with an estimated street value of nearly NT$700 million (US$21.6 million) , was hidden under planking on the bottom of a container supposedly full of porcelain vases aboard a freighter at Keelung Harbor.

Following a tip-off via "international cooperation channels" a year ago, law enforcement officers were able to apprehend the smugglers despite the fact that they repeatedly changed the shipping schedule, they noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE FAMILY TO WAIT FOR COURT TO IMPLEMENT CHILD CUSTODY RULING

TEXT.P: The Taiwanese uncle of a Taiwanese-Brazilian boy at the center of an international custody battle said Wednesday he will wait for the court to implement its ruling on the child's guardianship.

Wu Hou-yen made the remarks after the Kaohsiung District Court said a day earlier it will use force to take Iruan Wu Ergui away from his Taiwanese uncle Feb. 6 and send him home to his legal guardian in Brazil if the uncle fails to hand over the boy voluntarily by Feb. 5.

Wu said he and his family and members of a support group formed last year to help Iruan, better known as Wu Yi-hua in Taiwan, will stay at home Feb. 6 to wait for law enforcement officers to implement the court ruling.

According to the district court, the representative of the boy's Brazilian legal guardian is scheduled to lead a judge and local police officers to Wu's home in the southern Taiwan county of Kaohsiung at 10 a.m. Feb. 6.
Taiwan's Supreme Court meted out a final verdict last November that the boy's guardianship belongs to his Brazilian grandmother, Rosa Ergui.
Rosa Ergui has commissioned Brazil's representative to Taiwan, Paulo A.P. Pinto, to take Iruan back to Brazil on her behalf.

Iruan was born out of wedlock in Brazil in July 1995 to a Brazilian mother and a Taiwanese father. His mother died six years ago and his grandmother was appointed his legal guardian. He was brought to Taiwan in March 2001 by his father, who died a couple of weeks later. Wu, the boy's uncle, refused to allow the child to leave for home, and the boy has since been living in Kaohsiung and is now a second-grader at a local elementary school.
His grandmother eventually resorted to legal action to regain custody of her grandson when it became clear that Wu would not let her take the child back to Brazil in 2001.

According to Taiwan regulations, if Wu refuses to comply with the court order, he can be fined between NT$30,000 and NT$300,000 (US$890-US$8,902) and if he still refuses to hand over the boy, the court can keep fining him. If Wu continues to hold out, the court will ultimately order the police to implement the transfer of custody.
A support group has been formed in Kaohsiung County that has called for donations of NT$10 (US$0.296) per person to help Wu pay for the fines and support for the boy.

A spokesman for the support group said Wednesday that the support group will cooperate with the Brazilian office of the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation and the Taiwanese Chamber of Commerce in Brazil in helping Iruan after the boy returns there.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES TWO REFERENDUM QUESTIONS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet approved at its weekly meeting Wednesday the two questions to be put forth for the nation's first-ever referendum to coincide with the March 20 presidential election.
The two questions were listed in a letter sent by President Chen Shui-bian a day earlier detailing his rationale for holding the referendum.

Quoting Chen's letter, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said at a news conference held after the Cabinet meeting that Beijing's repression of Taiwan in the international arena and its deployment of hundreds of missiles against the island constitute a threat that jeopardizes the country's sovereignty and that the danger justifies a presidential call for a referendum under the country's newly enacted Referendum Law.
Yu said the upcoming referendum will mark a further step forward in Taiwan's democratic development as it will allow all eligible voters to decide major national policy issues.
"A referendum is the most direct, evident and effective embodiment of democracy. We'll write a new chapter in our political history by holding the referendum," Yu said.
He said the Cabinet will direct all relevant government agencies to administer referendum affairs based on the principles of "simplicity, convenience, prudence and impartiality."
In order to prevent Beijing attacking Taiwan, the president said in his letter, the referendum will ask the following two questions:

-- "The people of Taiwan demand that the Taiwan Strait issue be resolved through peaceful means. Should mainland China refuse to withdraw the missiles it has targeted at Taiwan and openly renounce the use of force against us, would you agree that the government should acquire more advanced anti-missile weapons to strengthen Taiwan's self-defense capabilities?"

-- "Would you agree that our government should engage in negotiations with mainland China on the establishment of a peace and stability framework for cross-strait interactions to build consensus and for the welfare of the peoples of both sides?"
Yu said the Cabinet will launch a publicity campaign to help local people better understand the gist of the planned referendum.
"We'll make every possible effort to ensure that the historic referendum proceeds smoothly," Yu said.

As part of the campaign, the Ministry of the Interior will distribute 8.5 million pamphlets to local households expounding on the gist and background of the referendum questions and all relevant technical details.
The ministry will also produce two TV commercials to help local voters better understand the content and values of the first-ever nationwide referendum.
Minister of the Interior Yu Cheng-hsien said all the publicity pamphlets and TV commercials will be ready for distribution and broadcast by Feb. 10.

: New York Times: Kerry rolls on in presidential bid, Edwards takes South Carolina; Clark claims win in Oklahoma.
Senator John Kerry rolled to substantial victories in the Democratic presidential contests in Missouri, Delaware, Arizona, New Mexico and North Dakota last night, but Senator John Edwards won handily in South Carolina, allowing him to portray the contest as a battle with Mr. Kerry and keep the race alive at least through February.
Wall Street Journal: Wins lift Kerry, but nomination remains in play.
Sen. John Kerry swept five of seven states holding presidential nominating contests, but wins in South Carolina by John Edwards and Oklahoma by Wesley Clark left the Democratic front-runner in a lengthened fight that prevents him from immediately targeting President Bush.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN, SOONG REGISTER AS CANDIDATES IN PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong, registered with the Central Election Commission (CEC) Wednesday as candidates in the March 20 presidential election, with Lien running for the president and Soong for vice president.

Accompanied by their wives and supporters, the two handed in their completed registration forms and a deposit of NT$15 million (US$450,450) which will be impounded if they fail to garnered five percent of the ballots cast.

CEC Chairman Huang Shih-cheng, who greeted President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu at the ground floor gate of the CEC office earlier in the day when the two registered as candidates, greeted Lien and Soong at the third floor of the commission's office where the registration papers were to be filed.

After handing in the registration, Lien told his supporters outside the CEC building that it is time to end the nightmare of President Chen's four year rule. He vowed to live up to his supporters' expectations by wining the March 20 election.
Soong called the president's 10 campaign promises for the future proof that Chen hasn't measured up to the job of leading the nation in the past.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPOREANS MAKE OVER 300 CALLS TO AMBULANCE HOT LINE OVER BIRD FLU

TEXT.P: As avian flu has been giving many Singaporeans the jitters, the city-state's 993 ambulance hotline has received more than 300 bird-flu related calls over the past two weeks, with all of them being false alarms.

Singapore's Health Ministry recently expanded its 993 ambulance hotline, which was set up last year to handle SARS cases, to also ferry those who think they may have bird flu to Tan Tock Seng Hospital.
The ambulance service provider says it can handle up to 130 dispatches each day, and extra resources from the civil defense can be activated if needed.
The call center currently can handle up to 500 legitimate calls per day, but it can be scaled up to handle as many as 20,000 calls a day if required.

DOC.HEADLINE: FLEXTRONICS HOLDS PROCUREMENT SEMINAR IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Flextronics -- the world's No. 1 electronics manufacturing services (EMS) provider -- hosted a procurement seminar Wednesday at the Taipei International Convention Center.

Senior manager Thomas Atkinson, who is in charge of procurement of consumer electronics goods, presided over the seminar, in which more than 200 representatives from Taiwan-based enterprises took part.

Hailing the fine quality and cheap prices of Taiwan-made hi-tech products, Atkinson expressed the hope for closer and enhanced cooperation with Taiwan companies as part of Flextronics' global efforts to provide efficient and professional services to their high-end clients across the world, such as IBM, Dell, Apple, Motorola, Ericsson, Palm PDA, HP and Microsoft Xbox.

Atkinson stressed that high quality was the most important element to be able to become a supplier of Flextronics's global supply chain. While in Taiwan, he has talked about cooperative issues with various prominent local firms, including BenQ, Primax Electronics and Mustek Systems since his arrival on Feb. 1.

Flextronics believes in Taiwan's hi-tech clout and the island should do its best to maintain its edge in the face of robust competition from mainland China, he said, giving his assurances that Flextronics is set to increase cooperation with Taiwan-based companies.

The Singapore-based Flextronics is the world's leading electronics manufacturing services (EMS) provider focusing on delivering operational services to technology companies. It maintains operations in 29 countries and has an annual business turnover of over US$13.4 billion.
The Taiwan-based Hon Hai Precision Machinery -- the country's top manufacturing company -- is the world's third-largest EMS provider. (By Flor Wang) ENDTIEM/mw

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO QUIT PARTY POST IF ELECTED PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan reaffirmed his commitment Wednesday to quit his party post if he wins the March 20 presidential election.

Lien, who has teamed up with People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong to challenge President Chen Shui-bian's re-election bid, made the reaffirmation when he was asked by the media whether his previous promise to quit the KMT chairmanship remains valid and how the KMT-PFP coalition, more commonly known as the "pan-blue alliance," will operate provided the Lien-Soong ticket claims victory in the upcoming election.
Lien said he would not continue serving as KMT chairman if he wins the presidency.

"If I win the election and my current party chairmanship tenure expires, I won't seek re-election as KMT chairman. I hope to cultivate a new generation of party elites to lead the KMT to an even brighter future," Lien said.

Noting that he personally takes the KMT's loss of power four years ago as a "blessing, " Lien said the painful defeat has forced the party to make self-reflections and undergo sweeping intraparty reforms and restructuring.

"We have reinvented ourselves, shedding old burdens and streamlining our bloated party apparatus, " Lien said, claiming that the KMT has transformed itself into a "lean and mean" organization with a transparent, efficient and democratic operational framework.

And if he wins the presidency, Lien said, he will cultivate younger members to take over the party's helm. "I hope the KMT will be able to continue moving forward on the basis of its current achievements under new leadership with new thinking and new working styles to face even tougher challenges in the future," he added.

As for the "pan-blue alliance's" future operations, Lien said he basically hopes to see the two parties merge into a large political force. "I think such a development will benefit both our two parties and our country as a whole."
Nevertheless, Lien admitted that the merger proposal is only his personal view. "The realization of the proposal is still subject to many subjective and objective factors," he noted.

As a matter of fact, Lien said, the "pan-blue alliance" has crafted many viable cooperative mechanisms. "If we win the election, the alliance will form a professional and competent team to take over national administration work," he added.

Lien's remarks were seen as a rebuttal to allegations by some detractors that once the Lien-Soong ticket wins, their two parties will engage in a power struggle which they said could bring misfortune to the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOME-RAISED CHICKENS COULD BE OPEN TO AVIAN FLU: HEALTH DEPARTMENT

TEXT.P: An official of the Department of Health (DOH) has advised people against raising their own chickens in an attempt to avoid coming into contact with avian flu.

Shih Wen-yi, deputy director-general of the health department's Center for Disease Control, spoke amid reports that some people who want to eat chicken and eggs are thinking of raising the birds themselves to avoid buying chickens in the market that could be infected with the virus that spreads avian flu.

Although Taiwan is an avian flu-free country, the emergence of H5N2, a less lethal form of the H5N1 avian flu virus, in chicken and duck farms in southern Taiwan has forced the culling of tens of thousands of fowl.
Reports that the death toll from the illness in Asia has risen to 13 has also contributed to a sharp decrease in demand for chicken and related products in local poultry markets.
Shih said that if people raising chickens do not effectively isolate their birds from wild birds, their chickens could still come into contact with infected birds.
"Don't thing you're smart and can raise healthy chickens, " Shih said.
He pointed out that professional chicken farms have nets to prevent wild birds from entering their facilities. They also have the ability to keep their chicken coops clean of droppings, he added.
If chickens raised by private individuals do contact bird flu from an outside animal, he said, the possibility exists of furthering the rate of mutation of the virus that causes the malady.
He also said that pet birds are safe if they have not come into contact with other fowl and there is no need to destroy them.
Chen Lung-hung, director of the health department's Bureau of Food Sanitation, also tried to soothe public jitters Wednesday about the safety of eating chicken and eggs.
He said that as long as consumers choose products that have the "CAS" seal indicating that the foodstuff in question has been inspected by health authorities, there is nothing to fear.
It is also better to buy eggs with cleaned shells so there will be no chance of contamination, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI REGISTERS RECORD LOW TEMPERATURES IN JANUARY

TEXT.P: Taipei recorded its coldest January in seven years, with an average temperature of just 15.4 degrees Celsius, according to the latest tallies released Wednesday by the Department of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DBAS) under the Taipei city government.

DBAS officials said average temperatures in Taiwan have shown an upward trend for a long time, but recorded a reverse last year, with the average temperature in Taipei recorded as 23.5 degrees last year, down 0.3 degrees from the 23.8 degrees recorded the previous year.
Due to the onslaught of a series of cold fronts, the average temperature dropped to just 15.4 degrees in Taipei, setting a new low in seven years, they said.

Taipei has also suffered from water shortages in recent years, the officials noted, pointing out that Taipei received just 1,192.5 millimeters of rainfall last year, lower than the 1,346.4 millimeters recorded the previous year and the lowest on record in 52 years.

The tallies show that the figure is only 51.59 percent of the average rainfall of 2,311.6 millimeters over the past decade. Rainfall in Taipei in every month of last year was lower than that of the average monthly rainfall over the past decade, with 1.7 millimeters in December 2003 the lowest of all.

In terms of the number of what the DBAS described as "rainy days, " except for 134 days in 1963, rainy days in Taipei over the past five decades exceeded 150, but the figure dropped to 136 days in 2002, and 127 days in 2003, setting a new low.

Water reserves at the Feitsui Reservoir, which supplies water to the greater Taipei area, are not satisfactory, the officials added. They said that the average water level at the reservoir was 146.47 meters last year representing only 15.58 million cubic meters of waters, the second-lowest figure recorded for years.

DOC.HEADLINE: FESTO OPENS ENGINEERING CENTER IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Germany-based Festo -- the world's second-largest pneumatics automation company -- inaugurated an engineering center in Taiwan Wednesday.

The center, located at the Engineering Department under the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) in northern Hsinchu County, was set up by Festo with assistance from the Department of Industrial Technology under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , according to Tsai Hsin-yuan, head of the ITRI'S engineering department.
According to Tsai, Festo and the ITRI signed a memorandum of understanding in December last year to forge and boost two-way cooperation.

The pact is expected to boost the government's efforts to promote the domestic hi-tech sector, particularly at a time when the MOEA is in full gear advocating its "two-trillion, two-star" program aimed at making Taiwan a key hub of various forms of core high-technology, Tsai said.

The opening of Festo's Taiwan engineering center is proof of Taiwan's competitiveness in technological strength, manpower and government assistance, Tsai said, pointing out that the German company chose Taiwan to set up the center after finding that Taiwan outperforms mainland China, Japan, Singapore and South Korea in all these fields.
The company is likely to set up a research and development center in Taiwan in the future, he added.

"Didactic, " which is Festo's unit of learning systems for automation and technology -- will launch an iCIM (Internet Computer Integrated Manufacturing) program jointly with the ITRI to recruit and train professional new blood for Taiwan.
According to Festo (Taiwan) General Manager Liang Chen-chuan, Festo has funneled NT$50 million (about US$1.5 million) into the engineering center.

In the initial stages, Festo will station six engineers from Germany and six from Taiwan at the facility to focus on the study and development of compressed air automation components related to the semiconductor and opto-electronics industries, Liang explained.
With support from Taiwan's government, academic and industrial sectors, Festo's engineering center is poised to help Taiwan companies in related industries upgrade their production levels, he said.

Festo, the world's oldest manufacturer of automation with pneumatic components and systems, was set up in 1925. Its annual business revenue totals about US$45 billion and its service network encompasses 176 countries around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: REFERENDUM CALLED BY PRESIDENT IS DOUBLY WRONG: KMT CHIEF

TEXT.P: The referendum called by President Chen Shui-bian is the result of a double-barreled mistake, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan, who will compete against Chen in the March 20 presidential election, claimed Wednesday.

The Referendum Law is seriously flawed in authorizing the president to initiate a referendum in case of emergency and President Chen Shui-bian has committed a mistake in using this power in a situation not intended by the law, Lien said in an interview with a group of media.

The president's power to call a referendum in case of emergency was included in the Referendum Law at the insistence of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) . It is part of the president's right to address emergencies provided for in the Constitution and should not be included in the Referendum Law, which is of a much lower echelon than the Constitution in the legal system, according to Lien.

Furthermore, the power awarded to the president by the Referendum Law to call a referendum should be invoked only when the country is threatened by outside forces that might damage its sovereignty. However, the president has abused this power by organizing a referendum that is not designed to deal with any emergency at all, Lien argued.

Instead of cautioning the president about his mistakes, the Executive Yuan and other related government agencies have turned a blind eye to the controversy surrounding the referendum, which is why many county chiefs are bridling at working with the central government to implement the referendum, Lien claimed.

The consequences of the referendum will be far-reaching and both the KMT and its political ally the People First Party will have to wait until the referendum's political implications sink in to figure out a way to address them, Lien went on.

The president's insistence on pushing ahead with the referendum has created an uproar on the international stage because it is considered by many of Taiwan's neighbors as a provocative act. Worst of all, it strains Taiwan's ties with the United States, which is the country's most important supporter, said Lien.

The United States, preoccupied with the problems in Iraq and North Korea, need Beijing's cooperation and does not want to see Taiwan divert its attention by causing problems with mainland China. To be a considerate friend, the president should take into account the U.S. position and stop the referendum, Lien said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Â£4bn shambles of unreliable new trains.
The generation of sophisticated new trains introduced in the biggest replacement programme seen in Britain are badly designed and frequently break down.
Financial Times: Ryanair chief blasts EU ruling.
Ryanair launched a blistering attack on the European Commission yesterday, describing Brussels' landmark ban on airport subsidies granted to the Irish no-frills carrier as a "disaster" for consumers, low-cost airlines and publicly-owned airports.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN TO GRANT VISA-FREE STATUS FOR HONG KONG PEOPLE

TEXT.P: Japan has decided to grant visa-free status for Hong Kong people after years of talks, a government official said Wednesday.

Donald Tsang, chief secretary for administration, said that under the new arrangement effective April 1, Hong Kong citizens holding Special Administration Region (SAR) passports may visit Japan for up to 90 days without a visa.
Tsang made the announcement after meetings in Tokyo with Japanese Minister of Foreign Affairs Yoriko Kawaguchi and other officials.
"Visa-free access for HKSAR passport-holders is the result of several years of discussions between Hong Kong and Japanese officials since 1997," he said.
Including Japan, 129 countries and territories have now agreed to grant HKSAR passport-holders visa-free status.
Last year, about 480,000 Hong Kong residents visited Japan, making Hong Kong one of the top five sources of visitors to the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG TO HELP HANOI TREAT AVIAN FLU

TEXT.P: Hong Kong is sending a team of experts to Hanoi to help doctors there treat avian flu in humans, officials of the Department of Health said Wednesday.
At the request of the Vietnamese Ministry of Health, the department has assembled a team of four experts to assist the country, which is being threatened by the H5N1 virus, the officials noted.
The clinical team, composed of experts from the University of Hong Kong, the Chinese University of Hong Kong and the Hospital Authority, is to leave for Hanoi Thursday, they added.

In Hanoi, the team will provide support in establishing clinical protocols for the management of patients with flu-like illness or community-acquired pneumonia; development of diagnostic algorithms for flu-like illnesses; specific hospital treatment protocols for suspected and confirmed H5N1 patients; and training in flu infection control measures.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY FORESEES NO SETBACKS IN EXCHANGES WITH FRANCE
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Feb. 3 (CNA) (By Lo Yuan-shao and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Representative to France Chiou Jong-nan said Tuesday that the cancellation of visits to Paris by two senior Taiwan officials will not affect exchanges and cooperation between the two countries.
Chiou made the remarks before presiding over the presentation of the 2004 Taiwan-France Science and Technology Award at the Institut du France.

Taiwan's National Science Council Chairman Wei Che-ho was originally scheduled to travel to Paris to present the award, but he canceled his travel plan after French President Jacques Chirac publicly opposed Taiwan's decision to hold a referendum on mainland China's missile threat to coincide with the March 20 presidential election.

For the same reason, Taiwan's top culture administrator -- Council for Cultural Affairs Chairwoman Tchen Yu-chiou -- also canceled her trip to Paris to present an annual Taiwan-France culture award on Monday.
As a result, Chiou presented the culture and science awards, respectively, on behalf of Tchen and Wei.
Chiou said the two officials will still visit Paris later this year, stressing that the recent incident will not affect Taiwan-France exchanges and cooperation in the long run.

In comments made during a visit to France by mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao in late January, Chirac described Taiwan's referendum plan as a "grave error" and said the referendum initiative could destabilize the Asia-Pacific region.
Chiou said Chirac's "ingratiating manner" toward mainland China has been harshly criticized by the French news media and many political analysts.

Despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties, Chiou said, Taiwan-French cultural and economic exchanges have been growing steadily. Nearly all France's luxury fashion brands have set up marketing footholds in Taiwan as they cannot ignore Taiwan's consumers' strong purchasing power and their quest for high-quality goods, Chiou said.
Many French culture officials and members of the diplomatic corps in Paris attended the eighth Taiwan-France Culture Award presentation ceremony to express their support for Taiwan, Chiou said.
The World Culture Hall in Paris received the 2004 culture award for its efforts to introduce Taiwan's achievements in arts and culture to France over the past decade.

Meanwhile, Patrice Tran Ba Huy, an ear, nose and throat physician who heads a neurobiology laboratory jointly founded by Paris' Seventh University and Fifth University and the French National Science Research Center, received the fifth Taiwan-France Science and Technology Award for his contributions in promoting bilateral research cooperation.

More than 10 ear, nose and throat doctors from various Taiwan hospitals have received training at his laboratory since 1989 and he plans to organize a group of French scholars to visit Taiwan this year to discuss new cooperative programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE AIRLINES KICKS OFF NON-STOP FLIGHTS TO LOS ANGELES

TEXT.P: A Singapore Airlines (SIA) Airbus A340-500 took off Tuesday from Changi Airport for Los Angeles, marking the start of the longest commercial flight in aviation history.

SIA's new non-stop flight service will save passengers one to two hours in travel time. Later this year, the airline will kick off non-stop flights between Singapore and New York, saving passengers up to six hours in travel time.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO DISTRIBUTE 8.5 MILLION CAMPAIGN LEAFLETS ON REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior will distribute 8.5 million campaign pamphlets to prepare for Taiwan's first referendum to be held alongside the March 20 presidential election.

Minister of the Interior Yu Cheng-hsien made the announcement at a press conference presided over by Premier Yu Shyi-kun after the Executive Yuan approved Wednesday the two questions to be put to the referendum vote.
The premier asked all related government agencies to adopt the principles of "simplicity, convenience, exercise of caution and fairness" to ensure that the referendum is a success.

Accompanying the premier and interior minister at the press conference were Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i, Secretary-General of the Executive Yuan Liu Shih-fang, Minister without Portfolio Hsu Chi-hsiung, Foreign Affairs Minister Eugene Chien, Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen and Deputy National Defense Minister Lin Chong-pin.
The interior minister said his ministry is busy printing the referendum campaign pamphlets and producing two TV clips on the referendum, which should be ready by Feb. 10.
He said the ministry will distribute the pamphlets to each household so that the public will understand more about the gist of the "peace referendum."
The questions that the president sent to the Executive Yuan for approval concern the strengthening of national defense and cross-strait negotiation on an equal footing.

The first question is designed to tell the public that Taiwan needs to enhance its anti-missile capability in the face of the missile threat from mainland China, while the second expresses the keen desire of the Taiwan people to resume stalled cross-strait talks and urge Beijing to conduct talks on the establishment of a cross-strait consultation framework, exchanges on an equal footing, a political relationship based on mutual respect and avoidance of military conflicts.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARAGUAYAN AMBASSADOR PRESENTS CREDENTIALS

TEXT.P: New Paraguayan Ambassador Ramon Antreo Diaz Pereira presented his credentials to President Chen Shui-bian in a ceremony at the Presidential Office Wednesday.
Chen extended a warm welcome to Diaz upon his arrival to take up his Taipei assignment.
Noting that the ROC and Paraguay have maintained diplomatic ties since 1957, Chen said the bilateral relationship is based on the shared values of freedom and democracy.
"Geographic distance has not hindered our friendship and cooperation because we have a shared belief in freedom and democracy," Chen said.

Chen also expressed his gratitude for the actions of Paraguayan President Nicanor Duarte, who has on many international occasions spoken out for Taiwan's cause, including its bid to regain a seat in the United Nations.

For his part, Diaz said he feels honored to be able to work in Taipei. During his tenure, Diaz went on, he will do his utmost to further boost exchanges and cooperation between Taiwan and Paraguay in various fields.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE SEIZE 30 KG OF HEROIN AT KEELUNG HARBOR

TEXT.P: Law enforcement officers seized 30 kilograms of high-purity heroin that had been smuggled in a container from Thailand to Keelung Harbor, northern Taiwan, and arrested two suspects, Investigation Bureau (IB) officials announced Wednesday.

Tipped off that a drug ring was attempting to smuggle the drugs in a shipping container, the IB formed a squad that swooped on a container supposedly full of porcelain vases aboard a freighter at Keelung Harbor Tuesday.

Law enforcement officers went over the container twice without finding anything before they found the blocks of heroin, which they estimated to have a market value of nearly NT$700 million (US$21.6 million), hidden under planking at the bottom of the container.
They then arrested two suspects involved in the smuggling operations, Chiang Nien-chu, 51, and Lin Lung-kuang, 48.

The raid followed a tip-off via "international cooperation channels" a year ago that the two suspects were going to smuggle in a large quantity of drugs in a container around Chinese New Year and they were able to apprehend the smugglers despite the fact that they repeatedly changed the shipping schedule.
Judging from the size of the haul, the police did not rule out the possibility that other suspects may have been involved in the operation.

IB officials stressed that they are stepping up information exchanges with other nations to crack down on drug trafficking operations and that this cooperation contributed to the Keelung bust, one of the largest in northern Taiwan.
They also said that as of the end of last December, the IB was holding 2,905.125 kg of confiscated drugs in its warehouses.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar moved up against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, gaining NT$0.015 to close at NT$33.288.
A total of US$716 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$33.283 and was traded between NT$33.230 and NT$33.350.

DOC.HEADLINE: FERRY SERVICE BETWEEN KINMEN, XIAMEN ENHANCED

TEXT.P: The "mini three links" maintained between Taiwan-held Kinmen Island and Xiamen Port in mainland China's Fujian Province has entered a new era, with each side now operating three round-trip passenger ferries per day.

The new arrangement kicked off Feb. 3 after Kinmen county officials and representatives from the Xiamen port authorities and a ferry company agreed upon the new schedule during a meeting Jan. 27 in Xiamen.

Kinmen Tourism Bureau Director Chen Chao-chin said the mini links -- direct transport and trade services set up in January 2001 between the islands of Kinmen and Matsu and the Fujian ports of Xiamen and Mawei -- served a total of 21,377 passengers during the first year. The figure rose to 53,681 in 2002 and to 160,103 in 2003.

A 25-day special package designed to transport a large number of mainland-based Taiwan businessmen on the route during the Jan. 9-Feb. 2 period surrounding the Chinese New Year holiday season serviced a total of 22,582 passengers, Chen said, pointing out that the jump in traveler numbers pushed the two sides to hold talks on stepping up the ferry services based on the existing framework.

To begin with, the Kinmen-Xiamen ferry service was irregular without a fixed timetable. It started to provide a two-weekly service on a regular basis in May 2002 and this was increased to a three- and a four-weekly regular round trip service recently, Chen reported.

The enhanced service now allows passengers to travel between the two sides within just one day, making it the most economical and time-saving travel option for the many Taiwan businessmen who have to travel often between Taiwan and mainland.

Claiming that the ferry timetables will be adjusted every month to better serve the passengers, he said the Kinmen county government is optimistic about the business prospects, as the central government in Taipei is expected to ease its current rules to permit more people to use the links in the near future, probably starting from March 1.
At present, only Kinmen and Matsu residents and Taiwan businessmen and their families based in Fujian Province are allowed to use the direct links to travel between the two sides.

Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng has demanded that the central government deploy more coast guard vessels in Kinmen in order to help strengthen sea traffic security and reduce smuggling in surrounding waters.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REGISTERS FOR ELECTION CANDIDACY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and his running mate, Vice President Annette Lu, registered for re-election candidacy in the March 20 election Wednesday.

In an arrangement designed to signify ethnic harmony, the president and vice president were accompanied by the representatives of Taiwan's four major ethnic groups -- Minnan (Taiwanese) , Hakka, aborigines and "mainlanders" -- people who arrived in Taiwan from mainland China after 1949 -- as well as several prominent women, when they arrived at the Central Election Commission (CEC) to a warm greeting from CEC Chairman Huang Shih-cheng.
They submitted their registration forms and posted a deposit bond of NT$15 million (US$450,450) according to the regulations under the Election and Recall Law of the President and Vice President.
After completing the registration procedure, the president also shouted out "believe in Taiwan, insist on reforms, " as well as "victory for referendum and fighting for re-election."

Chen's supporters had installed two giant "A-bian" -- Chen's nickname -- dolls outside the CEC building in the morning and wielded batons to cheer him on, while officials of an alliance distributed pamphlets urging voters to spoil their ballot papers to boycott the election, claiming that the campaign expenditures of both Chen and his rival, Lien Chan of the opposition Kuomintang, have already topped the ceiling stipulated under the election law.
Lien and his running mate, People First Party Chairman James Soong, registered at the CEC later in the day.
Chen shook hands with each of his supporters as he left the CEC amid chants of "a peaceful referendum and successful re-election" by his supporters.
Prior to their registration at the CEC, the president and the vice president painted a vision of Taiwan at a press conference held at their campaign headquarters.

They were accompanied by top campaign aides, including Chang Chun-hsiung, secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party; Taipei County Magistrate Su Tseng-chang; Presidential Office Secretary-general Chiou I-jen; and Ke Chien-ming, DPP party whip in the Legislative Yuan.
With just 45 days to go until the March 20 presidential election and the nation's first-ever referendum, the president said that this is a time for democracy to go forward.

He noted that Taiwan completed its first popular presidential election in 1996 in the shadow of a missile threat from mainland China, and the first political power transfer in the 2000 presidential election.
Chen said he is confident that the Taiwan people will vote in the referendum "based on the conviction of believing in Taiwan and insisting on reforms."

He stressed that the ballots cast March 20 will not only signify Taiwan's democracy and peace in the Taiwan Strait. More importantly, the Taiwan people will continue to pursue sustainable economic development and high-quality life under the two pillars of "peace" and "democracy," he added.
"This is the mission of A-bian and the commitment of the DPP toward the people," the president said.

He also said that during a recent rehearsal for a "one-million-hand-in-hand" campaign scheduled for Feb. 28 -- Peace Memorial Day -- he was moved to see that everyone, irrespective of race or gender, held hands, with each person's 10 fingers signifying the vision of what he called his "10 future Taiwan."

The future Taiwan will have peace, democracy, economic prosperity, justice, progress, harmony, clean politics, sustainable development, voluntarism and dynamism, adding that the vision will be created by the DPP and the Taiwan people together.

Just as the party's campaign theme is "Yes! Taiwan! , " the president said "dreams will come true if you believe in Taiwan and insist on reforms, " and that Taiwan will surely become a "beautiful and successful exclamation mark in the 21st century."

John Edwards (N.C.) easily won in South Carolina and retired Army Gen. Wesley K. Clark claimed a narrow victory in Oklahoma.
