DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SOCIETY CALLS FOR EFFORTS TO FACILITATE ELECTION DEBATES

TEXT.P: The liberal Taipei Society on Wednesday called for Taiwan's two rival political camps to facilitate the holding of televised presidential election debates, a ritual which is likely to hit a snag in the run-up to the 2004 presidential election.

Differences and disputes between the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) have caused negotiations over the holding of televised presidential election debates to be postponed to Feb. 8.

The Taipei Society, founded by a group of liberal scholars, will not sit idly by and let any camp strategically maneuver to undermine the holding of televised debates between the two presidential candidates, Taipei Society Chairman Hung Yu-hung said.

The Taipei Society does not exclude the possibility of publicizing the negotiation process and the minutes of the meetings between the DPP and the "pan-blue alliance" to let the Taiwan public know exactly which party is being difficult and uncooperative, Hung said.

He said that although the Taipei Society will remain neutral and not take sides during the election season, the group is not restricting its members from making known their opinions on affairs and events surrounding the March 20 presidential election.

Meanwhile, the Central Election Commission (CEC) has arranged for the holding of presidential campaign forums on Feb. 21, March 6 and March 13, respectively, to allow presidential candidates -- President Chen Shui-bian and KMT Chairman Lien Chan -- to voice their policy initiatives. Similar forums for vice presidential candidates, namely Annette Lu and PFP Chairman James Soong, was scheduled to take place Feb. 28, according to the CEC.
Each of the forums is set to be 70 minutes long and to be telecast live nationwide, an official from the commission said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stocks futures market were lower on Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for February moved down 24 points to close at 6,235, with 20,372 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for March fell 20 points to finish at 6,242, with 434 contract transactions, while June futures lost 29 points to close at 6,255, with 2 contracts traded.
September futures fell 11 points to finish at 6,271, with 2 contracts traded. No transactions were reported for December futures.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 10.84 points to close at 6,241.39.
The bourse opened at 6,271.54 and fluctuated between 6,297.92 and 6,233.88 during trading.

A total of 5.59 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$117.08 billion (US$3.52 billion) , compared with the previous trading session which saw 5.95 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$113.46 billion (US$3.41 billion).
Three of the eight major stock categories posted gains, with construction stocks moving up the most at 2.3 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 0.4 percent, and cement stocks at 0.2 percent.

The other major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff shares moving down the most at 1 percent, followed by textile issues at 0.8 percent, bank and insurance shares and electrical stocks, both at 0.4 percent, and plastics and chemical stocks at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 411 to 365, with 179 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOMB THREAT SUSPECT TRACKED DOWN IN LESS THAN 20 HOURS

TEXT.P: Police have tracked down the individual suspected of threatening on Tuesday to bomb nine organizations, police sources said.
The police nabbed the suspect at his residence in Nankang at around 3 a.m. Wednesday, 18 hours after he allegedly made the first threatening call, the sources said.

Chu Tsung-yun, 46, was arrested on charges of intimidating the public. The police found in his room several paper notes carrying the telephone numbers of the organizations that he threatened with bombs or planned to call, Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) officials said.
Chu first called the People First Party legislative caucus at 9:20 a.m. Tuesday, telling the opposition lawmakers that "someone is going to plant a bomb at the Legislative Yuan building."

Between 9: 20 a.m. and 11: 50 a.m., Chu made nine calls to prominent organizations in Taipei, including the Taipei City Hall, the United Daily News, the IBM Building, the Taipei 101 skyscraper, and SOGO Department Store, claiming that either "someone is going to plant a bomb" or "a suicide car will ram into your building at around noon, " the CIB officials said.

Discovering no bomb-making devices or materials at his home, CIB investigators suspect that Chu, who has a master's degree from a Baptist seminary, probably has mental problems as they found bags of medication on his table.
Chang Si-liang, director-general of the National Police Administration, praised the CIB investigators' excellent performance in tracking down the suspect in such a short time.
Chang said the suspect had taken all members of society hostage by making the bomb threats. Chu's deeds were not only disruptive to social order, but also "immoral," he said.

Commenting on Chu's case, CIB Commissioner Hou You-yi called for people who intend to commit similar crimes "not to test the law, " saying that law enforcement authorities are confident that any violators will be brought to justice without delay.

Hou also said that investigators have ruled out the possibility of Chu being the "rice bomber" who planted explosive devices at several locations around Taipei late last year and a bomb that exploded in a train car traveling between Taipei and Hsinchu several days ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUAKE ROCKS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A magnitude 6.0 earthquake on the Richter scale occurred at 11:24 a.m. Wednesday in the waters off Hualian, eastern Taiwan, with no immediate reports of casualties or property damage, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said.
The quake's epicenter was 76 kilometers southeast of Hualien, according to the CWB.
The temblor, which was felt around Taiwan, had an intensity of 4.0 in Hualien and Taitung, and an intensity of 3.0 in Ilan, Changhua and Nantou, the CWB said.
It had an intensity of 2.0 in Taipei, Hsinchu, Miaoli, Taichung, Yunlin, Chiayi, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Pingtung, and an intensity of 1.0 in Taoyuan and on the outlying island of Penghu.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Feb. 4, or the 14th day of the first month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1789: George Washington is elected as the first president of the United States.
1793: France abolishes slavery in all its te0ritories.
1810: Tsar Alexander I of Russia refuses to grant Napoleon I his sister Anna's hand in marriage. The Russian tsar's plans to liberalize the government were forestalled by wars with Napoleon I.
1899: Fighting breaks out in the newest U.S. protectorate, the Philippines, which declared itself a republic the previous month.
1902: Charles Lindbergh, the American aviator who made the first solo flight over the Atlantic Ocean, is born.
1904: The Russo-Japanese war breaks out.
1906: The New York Police Department adopts fingerprint lifting methods to collect evidence in criminal cases.
1922: China signs an agreement with Japan in Washington, D.C. to settle the Shantung dispute.
1938: Joachim von Ribbentrop becomes foreign minister of Germany while Hitler assumes the office of war minister.
1945: Leaders of the United States, Britain, and the Soviet Union meet in Yalta, USSR and reach the so-called "Yalta secret agreement." According to the pact, Soviet troops enter the war against Japan on the condition that its former land rights in China, taken by Japan in 1904, are to be restored later.
1948: Ceylon (now Sri Lanka) gains independence from Britain.
1949: Taiwan Provincial Governor Chen Cheng publicizes the practice of the Farm Rental Reduction Program, which was put into force on April 12 of the same year.
1966: An All Nippon Airway plane crashes at Tokyo's Haneda airport, killing all 133 people aboard.
1969: Liao Ho-shu, Communist China's charge d'affaires in the Netherlands, arrives in the United States and requests political asylum.
1973: The Asian Relations Association opens its Japan office in Tokyo.
1976: Dr. Raymond Jallow, senior vice president of the United California Bank, Los Angeles, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1976: A disastrous earthquake measuring 7.5 on the Richter scale jolts Guatemala, claiming more than 22,000 lives.
1976: Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs H.K. Yang decorates Dr. Tare Takemi, president of the Japan Medical Association, with the Order of Brilliant Star with Special Cordon.
1978: Junius Jayawardene becomes the first president of Sri Lanka.
1978: Fan Yuan-yen, the defecting Communist Chinese pilot who flew a MiG-19 to Taiwan the previous July, writes an open letter to the United Nations condemning human rights violations by the Beijing regime.
1980: Abolhassan Bani-Sadr becomes the first elected president of Iran. He is expected to follow the line of the country's de facto ruler, religious leader Ayatollah Khomeini.
1986: Twelve political dissidents jailed in Taiwan for the Formosa magazine incident are released on parole. The incident occurred in 1979 when political dissidents clashed with police while celebrating the anniversary of the publication of the magazine.
1988: The Executive Yuan passes a bill allowing high school graduates to study abroad.
1992: The Republic of China's Fair Trade Law goes into effect.
1997: Two military helicopters collide in mid-air in a storm in northern Israel, killing 73 Israeli soldiers.
1998: A strong earthquake measuring 6.1 on the Richter scale hits northern Afghanistan, killing 4,000 and leaving more than 15,000 homeless.
2000: Three Indonesian workers at the sixth naphtha cracking plant owned by Taiwan Plastic Corp. are killed in an accident while cleaning gas pipelines.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "I am not the one born with understanding. I am only the one who has given himself to the study of antiquity and is diligent in seeking for understanding in such studies."

TEXT.P: Thousands of Singaporeans lined up at lottery outlets Thursday ahead of the draw for the S$10-million (US$5.7-million) TOTO HongBao Jackpot.

To cope with the large numbers of people wanting to buy lottery tickets on the auspicious 15th day of the Lunar New Year, Singapore Pools is keeping several of its outlets around the island open later than usual.
TOTO counters will close at 6 p.m. Thursday, with the draw to be held half an hour later.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIVIC GROUPS TO HELP AVIAN FLU SUFFERERS IN THAILAND, VIETNAM

TEXT.P: Various civic groups have jointly launched a campaign to extend assistance to avian flu sufferers in Thailand and Vietnam, an official of a charity organization involved in the campaign said Thursday.

Chen Chun-liang, executive director of the Eden Social Welfare Foundation, said that his organization and various other civic religious groups have donated a total of NT$200,000 (US$6,000) as the first step toward initiating the relief campaign.
He called on the public to join the charity campaign, which will deliver US$50 to each household of relatives of Taiwanese peoples' spouses in Thailand and Vietnam who fall victim to avian flu.
Chen said that the groups have set a goal of raising NT$1 million in the initial stage of the campaign and are expected to further expand their fund-raising activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LIGHTS LANTERN TO KICK OFF LANTERN FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian lit the leading lantern Thursday at the Taiwan Lantern Festival in Panchiao, Taipei County.
Chen and Taipei County Magistrate Su Tseng-chang jointly switched on the 22.5-meter-high monkey-shaped lantern, which was illuminated by more than 10,000 bulbs.

The president claimed credit for staging the country's 15th Lantern Festival in Panchiao, saying the main festival used to be held in Taipei City but after he was elected president in 2000, he moved the festival to other places on the island, including twice in Kaohsiung, once in Taichung, and this year in Panchiao.
The festival opening, staged in the square in front of the Panchiao Railway Station, drew more than 10,000 visitors.
The festival originated in the Chinese tradition of displaying lanterns in various shapes, sizes and colors on the 15th day of the first month of the lunar calendar.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PASSPORTS ALLOWED FOR TRAVEL TO MAINLAND CHINA VIA KINMEN, MATSU

TEXT.P: From March 1, people from Taiwan proper or the outlying island of Penghu will be able to travel on passports instead of entry and departure permits when traveling between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait via the outlying outposts of Kinmen and Matsu, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Thursday.

Those eligible to travel on the routes will include Taiwan businessmen who have legally registered with the government to do business on the mainland, along with their employees and dependents, veterans born in mainland China's Fujian Province and their dependents, those who are engaged in direct cross-strait transportation links and leaders of trade and economic activities, as well as others who are allowed to use the route on a case-by-case basis.

But the MAC officials said that those who have registered their domicile as Kinmen or Matsu for over six months will still have to present entry and departure permits for travel to and from the mainland.
Those who have no permission from the Ministry of the Interior will be barred from traveling to the mainland via Kinmen and Matsu, MAC officials added.

The officials stressed that since the "mini-three links" -- direct trade, transport and postal links -- were established between Kinmen and Matsu and Fujian Province in January 2001, the government has made four overviews and has revised related regulations four times.
"The MAC will continue to make necessary reviews and adjustments in view of the implementation of the mini links and the development of cross-strait interaction," they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP WILL NOT MERGE WITH KMT BEFORE YEAR-END LEGISLATIVE ELECTION

TEXT.P: James Soong, chairman of the opposition People First Party, said Thursday that his party "will only cooperate, but will not merge with" its ally the Kuomintang (KMT) before the year-end legislative election.
Soong made the remarks while on the campaign trail around several townships in Taichung, central Taiwan, in response to remarks by KMT Chairman Lien Chan the previous day.

Lien, who formed a ticket with Soong to challenge President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu in the March 20 presidential election, said Wednesday that if elected president, he will quit the party chairmanship in order to allow the nurturing and grooming of new leaders.

Lien also expressed hope that the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and its two splinter parties, the PFP and the New Party, can move toward a merger, saying that this would have positive significance for the nation and its politics.
Soong said that the first task will be to form a coalition government if he and Lien are elected in the March 20 election.

"If elected, the top priority will be to form a strong coalition government, resume social order, stimulate the economy and resume cross-strait dialogue so that the people regain their confidence in the government and the international community resumes confidence in Taiwan," he said.

"The KMT and the PFP will only talk about cooperation before the year-end legislative election, and will not talk about a merger, " Soong went on, adding that "whether or not the two will merge will be up to the party members."
Meanwhile, high-ranking KMT officials shared Soong's remarks Thursday that the KMT and the PFP will only talk about cooperation before the presidential election.

Legislative Yuan President and KMT Vice Chairman Wang Jin-pyng said that the two parties know the importance of unity and are now focusing on stumping for Lien and Soong, adding that the question of merging the two parties should be left until after the presidential election.

On Lien's remarks about passing the baton to the next leader if elected and the "pan blue alliance" merges, Tseng Yung-chuan, a top campaign aide for the Lien-Soong ticket, also said that "there has been no talk on the issue within the KMT."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD HOLD ON TO ITS STATEHOOD: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that Taiwan should hold fast to its statehood and that no foreign country or individual can unilaterally decide the future of Taiwan after the March 20 referendum.

Speaking at a seminar on cultural affairs organized by the Association of Community Radio Stations in Paochung, in central Taiwan's Yunlin County, Chen said that holding the referendum will allow the international community to know the Taiwan people's collective will.

The achievements made by Taiwan in the field of democratic reforms, ranging from the lifting of martial law, lifting the ban on organizing political parties and restrictions on media operations, to the election of the president by popular vote, were not obtained by chance but by a long and hard fight by the people, Chen said.
The referendum is the last step in completing Taiwan's democratization, the president claimed.
He encouraged the public to "vote for Taiwan" in the upcoming national referendum, which will be Taiwan's first, and to jointly write a new chapter of Taiwan's history.
The two questions that will be put to the referendum vote initiated by Chen are as follows:

-- "The people of Taiwan demand that the Taiwan Strait issue be resolved through peaceful means. Should mainland China refuse to withdraw the missiles it has targeted at Taiwan and openly renounce the use of force against us, would you agree that the government should acquire more advanced anti-missile weapons to strengthen Taiwan's self-defense capabilities?"

-- "Would you agree that our government should engage in negotiation with mainland China on the establishment of a peace and stability framework for cross-strait interaction in order to build consensus and for the welfare of the peoples of both sides?"

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE-BRAZILIAN BOY TO RETURN TO BRAZIL FRIDAY

TEXT.P: The curtain will finally fall on a three-year-old international custody battle over a Taiwanese-Brazilian boy Friday with his return to his legal guardian in Brazil, judicial sources said Thursday.
The Kaohsiung District Court said Brazil's representative to Taiwan, Paulo A.P. Pinto, has traveled from Taipei to Kaohsiung in preparation for taking Iruan Wu Ergui back to Brazil.

Pinto is scheduled to visit the home of Iruan's Taiwanese uncle in Kaohsiung County's Chieting township in southern Taiwan at 10 a.m. Friday in the company of a district court judge and local police officers.

The district court said earlier this week that it will use force to implement the court ruling on the child's guardianship Feb. 6 if his Taiwanese uncle, Wu Hou-yen, fails to hand over the boy voluntarily by midnight on Feb. 5.
Wu said Thursday that he and the boy will stay at home Friday to wait for the court to implement its custody ruling.

If all goes smoothly, Iruan will leave Kaohsiung for Hong Kong Friday evening escorted by Pinto, who has been commissioned by the boy's grandmother -- his legal guardian -- to bring Iruan home. They will then take a flight from Hong Kong to Brazil via the South African city of Johannesburg.

Iruan, who is better known as Wu Yi-hua in Taiwan, was born out of wedlock in Brazil in July 1995 to a Brazilian mother and a Taiwanese father. His mother died six years ago and his grandmother was appointed his legal guardian. He was brought to Taiwan in March 2001 by his father, who died a couple of weeks later. The boy's uncle refused to allow the child to leave for home and the boy has since been living in Kaohsiung and is now a second-grader at a local elementary school.
His grandmother eventually resorted to legal action to regain custody of her grandson when it became clear that Wu would not let her take the child back to Brazil in 2001.
Taiwan's Supreme Court meted out a final verdict last November that the boy's guardianship belongs to his Brazilian grandmother, Rosa Ergui.

Iruan's classmates held a farewell party for the 9-year-old boy Thursday. His teacher and all of his classmates gave him gifts. Many of them, including Iruan himself, broke down in tears when they sang "Auld Lang Syne, " the famous song of fellowship by Scottish poet Robert Burns.
Meanwhile, President Chen Shui-bian wrote a message to Iruan Thursday in his weekly Internet newsletter exhorting him to obey the law and return home to his legal guardian in Brazil.
"Everyone must obey the law and even I, the head of state of the Republic of China, must obey the court's ruling, " Chen said in his message.
A letter, reputedly written by Iruan, was sent to Chen before the Chinese New Year asking for Chen's help to allow him to stay in Taiwan.

A private support group has been formed in Kaohsiung County to help Iruan and a spokesman said Thursday that the group will cooperate with the Brazilian office of the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation and the Taiwanese Chamber of Commerce in Brazil in helping Iruan after the boy returns there.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINES

TEXT.P: New York Times: C.I.A. director to defend assessments of Iraqi weapons.

After months of silence, George J. Tenet, the director of central intelligence, has decided to mount a strong public defense of the prewar judgments made by American intelligence agencies about Iraq and its illicit weapons stockpiles.

An intelligence official said that Tenet will seek "to correct some of the misperceptions and downright inaccuracies concerning what the intelligence community reported and didn't report regarding Iraq in a speech scheduled at Georgetown University Thursday.
Wall Street Journal: Democrats weigh the risks of a long fight for nomination.
Some Democrats fear that candidates will use up cash battling each other instead of Bush.

The costs could escalate in three ways. The candidates might turn toward nasty personal attacks. To stand out from the pack, the contenders might adopt more extreme views on contentious issues such as trade and jobs, which would hurt them in the general election. And the cost of campaigning now could deplete the nominee's coffers before the real engagement with Bush begins.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRODUCTION VALUE OF IT HARDWARE ESTIMATED TO HIT NEW HIGH FOR 2004

TEXT.P: The production value of Taiwan's information technology (IT) hardware will post a record high of US$68.4 billion for 2004, a spokesman for the semi-official Institute for Information Industry (III) predicted Thursday.
Chen Wen-tang, a manager at the III's Market Intelligence Center, made the forecast on the local industry's trends at a news conference.

Claiming that Taiwan's IT hardware sector is expected to continue bottoming out of a low since 2002 and to set an all-time high in its output value this year, Chen said the upward trends are a result of an improved economy around the world.

According to Chen, the domestic IT hardware sector recorded a new high of US$57.1 billion in its output value for the whole of last year, with various industries in the sector, including the desktop computer, notebook, motherboard, server, LCD and digital camera manufacturers, also setting highs in both production value and output volume.
Apart from the IT hardware sector, Taiwan's cellular phone and telecommunications industries also notched up encouraging results, he reported.

The mobile phone industry registered new highs in the fourth quarter of last year in both production value and output amount, with double-digit increases, he said. However, he added that the pace of the growth rate is likely to slow this year on the grounds that demand from mainland China might fall and that the number of foreign orders might drop.
He forecast that Taiwan will produce about 55 million cellular phones in 2004, representing a growth rate of about 30 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAYSIAN GETS 5-YEAR PRISON TERM FOR DRUG TRAFFICKING

TEXT.P: A Malaysian was sentenced to five years in prison Thursday for attempting to smuggle contraband drugs into Taiwan last May.
Sim Lee Ping was convicted of attempting to smuggle 991.23 grams of ketamine into Taiwan, the Taiwan High Court said in its verdict.
Customs inspectors discovered the drug hidden in Sim's luggage when she arrived at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Taiwan's main gateway, in May 2003.
The high court verdict said Sim's behavior would have affected Taiwan's public order and health if the drugs had not been seized before they could flow into the local market.
As Sim is a Malaysian citizen, the verdict said, she should be deported after serving her time in prison or being given an amnesty.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS CALL FOR PROPERLY ORGANIZED PRESIDENTIAL DEBATES

TEXT.P: Two scholars called Thursday for the establishment of a permanent organization to set up presidential election debates and other election debates.

In a seminar organized by the Central News Agency and presided over by Liu Chih-tsung, CNA editor in chief, to discuss a Feb. 8 debate between Chen Shui-bian and Lien Chan, the two presidential candidates, Hu You-wei, director of the Graduate Institute of Mass Communication of National Taiwan Normal University, claimed that election debates, especially presidential election debates, are more a source of valuable political and social education for the general public than a chance for individual candidates to woo voters.

However, impartial organization of such debates is a difficult job and only those who have the trust of all candidates can bring different candidates together in such an event, he said. Since this job becomes necessary every four years with the presidential election, that is why the United States set up a Commission on Presidential Debates in 1987 that has produced every presidential and vice presidential election debate since 1988.
With funding from private donations, the commission considers itself a social education institute that organizes seminars on elections and publishes the results of its studies regularly.

Public debate is vital for voters, since the people who put questions to the candidates in the debates are not chosen from campaign teams, so that the public might get some "real" information rather than propaganda, and will get to know the candidates from their political points of view, Hu said.
The voters can also compare the different candidates' ideas, he went on.
Any organization set up for this task should be non-partisan, impartial and non-profit, according to Hu.

Ku Chung-hua, former president of the Taipei Society and a professor at National Chengchi University, said it is a duty rather than a right for candidates to air their points of view in public debate.

At present, presidential debates are produced by an ad hoc umbrella organization consisting of the Taipei Society, the Public Television Service, four national newspapers. This situation might not change in the foreseeable future, although a different organization for presidential debate would be helpful in perfecting the rules for such debates, according to Ku.

Tsao Wan-ling, a researcher at the Public Television Service, said the current organizer of presidential debates staged a successful debate between the candidates for Taipei city mayor in 2002 and has accumulated valuable experience.

With the presidential election only about a month away, Tsao said, it is too late to talk about the establishment of a permanent organization for the 2004 election debate but the idea may be worth studying after the March 20 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, JAPAN COOPERATE IN BUSTING CROSS-BORDER DRUG TRAFFICKING RING

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) said Thursday it has cooperated with Japanese law enforcement officers in busting a cross-border drug trafficking ring attempting to smuggle 113 kilograms of amphetamines from mainland China to Japan.

With information provided by MJIB agents, Japanese law enforcement officers managed to arrest two masterminds of the trafficking ring in Yokohama Tuesday and seized the large quantity of amphetamines hidden in a container, MJIB officials said, adding that the seizure was worth an estimated NT$1.9 billion at street value.
The two arrested suspects were identified as Liu Fang-cheng, a 49-year old man from Taiwan's Chiayi County, and Takeshi Sakai, a naturalized Japanese man of Taiwan origin.

MJIB officials said the ring had traffickers in mainland China, Hong Kong and Taiwan with the aim of smuggling mainland China- and Hong Kong-produced amphetamines to Japan in the guise of legitimate chemical products.

The MJIB informed Japanese law enforcement authorities of all relevant information in early January, the officials said, and a joint investigative team formed by the MJIB, Japanese police authorities, as well as Tokyo and Yokohama customs officers, kept close tabs on the ring's activities.

Japanese law enforcement officers then discovered a suspicious container delivered from the southern mainland Chinese port city of Shenzhen to Yokohama Jan. 27. They arrested Liu and Sakai when the duo were claiming the container Feb. 3 and later uncovered the contraband drugs hidden in the container.
Over the past month, some 20 MJIB agents have been mobilized to investigate the case, the officials said, adding that Japan mobilized more than 80 investigators.

"The two sides have held many rounds of videoconferences to discuss various technical details and Japan sent liaison officers to Taiwan to work out various investigative plans, " an MJIB official said, adding that the case set a good model for international cooperation in drug busting.
Japanese law enforcement authorities announced the raid on the drug trafficking ring simultaneously with the MJIB. It was the largest drug seizure in Japan in two years.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES URGED TO DEBATE OPENLY TO ALLOW SCRUTINY

TEXT.P: A scholar said Thursday that the presidential candidates should get used to open debate so that their views on public policies can be subject to the scrutiny of the voters.

Ku Chung-hua, a professor from National Chengchi University, made the remarks at a forum on how to establish a permanent organization to handle presidential debate. The forum was presided over by Liu Chih-tsung, editor-in-chief of the Central New Agency.

Ku is a former president of the Taipei Society, a group comprised of liberal scholars, which will be one of the sponsors of a proposed televised debate between President Chen Shui-bian and his rival, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, who are competing in the March 20 presidential election.
Ku lamented that Taiwan has not formed the habit of debating public policy, citing the current difficulty in setting up a date for the televised debate between the two rival camps as an example.

He noted that Western education attaches great importance to dialogue and open communication, while the East tends to stress that a ruler need not talk too much, so that much of his policy is shrouded in secrecy.

"Taiwan's political figures need to be re-educated, " Ku said, adding that "taking part in debates is an obligation. If you want support from the voters, you should allow yourself to be subjected to public scrutiny."

Other scholars and pundits participating in the CNA forum included Hu Yu-wei, director of the Graduate Institute of Mass Communication of National Taiwan Normal University, Deputy Secretary-General Chen Cheng-hsiu of the Association of Terrestrial Television Networks, Tsao Wan-lin, a researcher at the Public Television Service Foundation, and Lu Tung-hsi, an executive member of the Association of Taiwan Journalists.
The proposed televised presidential election debate will be jointly sponsored by the Taipei Society, the Public Television Service Foundation, and four other major newspapers.
Meanwhile, Ku said that an alliance comprised of 11 local TV media groups is also trying to organize another televised presidential election debate.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSUMER PRICE INDEX FOR JANUARY RISES

TEXT.P: The consumer price index (CPI) for January stood at 100.5 points, an increase of 0.79 percentage points over the December level, the Cabinet-level Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Thursday.
The growth was the first since June last year, DGBAS officials said, adding that the January CPI also represents a slight increase of 0.01 percentage points over the year-earlier level.

Although the officials attributed the rise to higher product and service prices during the Chinese New Year holiday season late last month, they claimed that deflation is out of the question amid noticeable signs of an improved domestic economy fueled by an economic upturn in the international market.

Dismissing public concerns as to whether an outbreak of avian flu in many Asian countries will cast a shadow over Taiwan's rebounding economy, the officials said that an effective containment of the disease will in fact boost the economy.

At the same time, Taiwan's wholesale price index for January was 104.63 points, up by 1.05 percentage points over the December ratio and up by 2.39 percentage points over the level posted in the same of a year ago, according to the DGBAS report.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DELEGATION TO U.S. NATIONAL PRAYER BREAKFAST KEEPS LOW PROFILE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 5 (CNA) (By Lin Wen-chi and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China delegation attending the 2004 U.S. National Prayer Breakfast in Washington, D.C. has kept a low profile amid the current low ebb in bilateral relations over Taiwan's planned referendum.

The mission, headed by Peng Ming-min, a senior advisor to President Chen Shui-bian, arrived in the U.S. capital Tuesday. Its members include Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Michael Ying-mao Kau, Legislator Chen Tang-san, Professor Joanne J.L. Chiu and Chia Hsin Cement Co. Chairman Nelson A.P. Chang.

The delegation first paid a visit to the Republican National Committee Wednesday and then held a lunch meeting with members of the Taiwan Caucus -- a pro-Taiwan subgroup in the U.S. House of Representatives.

Later in the day, the group met with scholars at the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), a noted think tank. After the meeting, Peng and Kau told Taiwan reporters stationed in Washington that they had exchanged views with CSIS research fellows on the referendum plan and other issues of mutual concern. However, they declined to elaborate on the content of their talks and Peng said only that the two sides exchanged views candidly.
Chiu said that the people of Taiwan have been denied a voice in the international community since the ROC left the United Nations in 1971.

"The planned referendum to coincide with the March 20 presidential election will offer the Taiwan people an opportunity to express their opinions on relations with mainland China in the world arena, " Chiu said. "Therefore, we believe that the nation's first-ever referendum bears historic significance."

The delegation was scheduled to hold a similar closed-door meeting with researchers from another U.S. think tank, the Brookings Institute, after attending the prayer breakfast Thursday. The group will also visit the Democratic National Committee and meet with two influential U.S. congressional members and various Chinese community representatives before wrapping up its U.S. visit.

The National Prayer Breakfast is an annual religious gathering attended by thousands of dignitaries, including the U.S. president, senior U.S. officials and congressional members, as well as diplomats and religious leaders from various countries. The purpose of the gathering is to promote world peace and conciliation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO GIVE ADMINISTRATIVE REPORTS TO LEGISLATIVE YUAN

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun will give his administrative reports to the Legislative Yuan when it opens for a new session Friday.

The premier will point out that to achieve the "green silicon island" goal as envisioned by President Chen Shui-bian, the government will make the bettering of the economy and continued political and financial reforms as the main focus this year, according to an advanced copy of his reports sent to the Legislative Yuan.

The government will also nurture talented people, promote research, development and innovation, global logistics programs and quality of life through the implementation of its five-year, NT$500 billion (US$15.06 billion) 10 new major construction projects plan, the report said.

As cross-strait relations are special factors that will affect Taiwan's development, the government will promote a positive development in cross-strait relations, and will take into consideration national dignity, security and reciprocal exchanges to promote cross-strait reconciliation, active cooperation and a lasting peace, it said.
Regarding national defense, the report said the government will continue to upgrade the military's combat readiness and promote the recruitment of volunteers.

On the diplomatic front, the government will strengthen substantive relations with the United States and Japan, promote active participation of international organizations, raise the national profile in the world, join hands with private organizations to promote international cooperation and continue to provide humanitarian assistance to the social and economic development of diplomatic allies, the report said.

On economic development, Taiwan's economy was beginning to rebound in early 2003, but because of the U.S.-led war against Iraq and the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome in the first part of the year, which resulted in a negative impact to the economy, Taiwan's economy recorded a negative growth in the second quarter.

But the report said that starting from the next half of 2003, Taiwan's exports improved in line with a global economic rebound. The nation's economy has flashed a healthy green light ever since July 2003, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL GAIN 32 PERCENT OF GLOBAL DVD RECORDER MARKET: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's production of DVD (digital video discs) recorders is expected to hold a second-highest 32 percent market share globally in 2004, according to forecasts made by the Topology Research Institute.

The ratio represents an output level of 15.2 million units out of an estimated global production of 47.5 million, the institute predicted, pointing out that Taiwan will only trail Japan. It also predicted that the world's total output volume may top 110 million units in 2007.
Taiwan made about 4.05 million DVD recorders in 2003, accounting for some 16.2 percent in the international market with a scale of 25 million units, the institute reported.

Business opportunities provided by the hi-tech device, now already a common household appliance, are tremendous, as manufacturers are actively seeking to produce new generations of the item, a senior researcher at the institute said.

Falling prices for DVD recorders are expected to push many Japanese companies to look for foreign outsourcers to manufacture for them in search of greater profit, and Taiwan-based makers and the general public may benefit from the situation, he explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA DISMISSES REPORTS ABOUT NEW JAPANESE CONCERNS OVER REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: Japan has not again expressed concern about Taiwan's planned referendum scheduled for next month, a spokesman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Thursday.
Richard Shih made the remarks in response to a media report that said a spokesman from the Japanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs again expressed worries about cross-strait tensions the previous day.

Hatsuhisa Takashima said that the basic stance of the Japanese government is that it is concerned about Taiwan's referendum, and not the questions to be put to a vote, according to the mass-circulation United Daily News. The spokesman also said that since both the United States and Japan are concerned about the issue, Taiwan should exercise caution, the report added.
Shih said that Taiwan's representative office in Japan has checked with the Japanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and it had denied the reports.

Shih added that Japan has only sent Katsuhisa Uchida, director of the Interchange Association's Taipei Office, to call on Chiou I-jen, secretary-general of the Presidential Office Dec. 29, to express concern about the planned referendum along with the presidential election on March 20.

Shih said the spokesman of the Japanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs had only said in a routine news conference Wednesday that both the United States and Japan hope that there would be dialogue, not rivalry, between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, and that Taiwan should deal with the referendum with caution.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER YU EXPRESSES THREE WISHES ON LANTERN FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun expressed three wishes Thursday on Lantern Festival, including the smooth proceeding of Taiwan's first-ever referendum to coincide with the March 20 presidential election.
Yu expressed his wishes during a lunch meeting with a group of reporters covering Cabinet-related news events.
As Thursday happened to be Lantern Festival, Yu took advantage of the occasion to extend his best wishes to all local people.

"Local people traditionally eat round, sweet rice dumplings known as 'yuan siao' in Chinese on Lantern Festival to symbolize family reunion and good fortune. I wish all fellow countrymen a happy Lantern Festival and a prosperous life throughout the year," Yu said.
He further said a pair of wild magpies have made a home in a four-storey tree at the courtyard of his official residence since last November.
"I took it as a harbinger of good things to come. For instance, our economy has bottomed out of its year-long recession and is now on a steady upward swing," Yu said.
The premier is scheduled to deliver an administrative report at the Legislative Yuan Friday, which also marks the opening of the legislature's new session.
Yu said he hopes his report at the opposition-control legislature will proceed smoothly.

He also outlined his "yuan siao three wishes," -- the legislature passes several important bills, including the statute on the management of a financial reconstruction fund, the three "sunshine bills" for the establishment of clean politics and the Executive Yuan restructuring bill, during its new session; the legislature passes the budget bill for the 10 New Major Construction Projects; and the island's historic referendum on mainland China's missile threat turns out to be a success.
In order to prevent Beijing from attacking Taiwan, President Chen Shui-bian has decided to call a referendum to ask local voters the following two questions:

-- "The people of Taiwan demand that the Taiwan Strait issue be resolved through peaceful means. Should mainland China refuse to withdraw the missiles it has targeted at Taiwan and openly renounce the use of force against us, would you agree that the government should acquire more advanced anti-missile weapons to strengthen Taiwan's self-defense capabilities?"

-- "Would you agree that our government should engage in negotiations with mainland China on the establishment of a peace and stability framework for cross-strait interactions to build consensus and for the welfare of the peoples of both sides?"

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR MACAU TO OPEN NEW ROUTE TO SERVE TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN

TEXT.P: Air Macau is slated to open a new route between Taiwan and Shenzhen in mainland China's Guangdong province via Macau on March 9 to serve a host of Taiwan businessmen traveling between Taiwan and mainland China, according to a spokesman for the aviation company.

Air Macau has planned a two weekly flights from Taipei or Kaohsiung to Shenzhen via Macau and vice versa for the initial stages, the spokesman said, adding that the service is mainly aimed at business travelers between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The flight will take only two hours and 55 minutes and passengers can get on buses provided by the Macau airport to go directly to Shenzhen or Dongguan without waiting in line at immigration and customs.

Air Macau also will provide entry visa services at its counters at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport and Kaohsiung Hsiaokang Airport for Taiwan passengers. Those who check in at Air Macau counters at the two airports and apply for a new entrance permit by the mainland authorities will have their travel documents processed when arriving at the Macau airport.
This will help save three days of normal processing time for Taiwan passengers heading for mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OVERSEAS CHICKEN SALES TAKE FLIGHT AFTER OUTBREAKS OF AVIAN FLU

TEXT.P: Taiwan's poultry products have been selling well in Asian markets in recent weeks due to the outbreaks of avian flu in major Asian chicken exporting countries, a Council of Agriculture (COA) official said Thursday.

At a time when poultry farms in most of the countries in Southeast and East Asia have fallen to the scourge of bird flu, caused by the H5N1 virus, Taiwan's chicken products exports have picked up after several years of sluggishness.

Thailand and mainland China have been two major exporters of chicken meat on the world market. Both of these countries have reported cases of avian flu. Taiwan has been exporting relatively much less chicken meat over the past years, not because of inferior quality, but because the price has been about three times higher than that for the same products from Thailand and mainland China, COA officials said.

According to the Republic of China Chicken Farm Association, Indonesia recently placed an order for 430 metric tons of Taiwan chicken meat. The shipment is expected to be made next week after the food safety and quarantine process is completed, association chairman Wu Chuan-ching said.
The association has also recently received orders from Japan and Hong Kong for six containers of chicken meat, according to Wu.

Exports to these two places, however, are not expected to be made in the near future as authorities in Japan and Hong Kong have imposed a ban on poultry products from Taiwan since early January in the light of reports that several Taiwan chicken farms destroyed more than 60,000 birds on suspicion of an outbreak of a less virulent bird flu virus called H5N2, Wu said.
Meanwhile, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Thursday that Taiwan chicken meat is safe and tasty and that the public can eat as much of it as they want without worry.
Yu, nevertheless, reminded people to stay alert against smuggling of unknown poultry products into Taiwan and to safeguard against wild birds that might be a source of H5N1 or H5N2.

In related news, Vice COA Chairman Lee Jen-chyuan said that a price stabilization mechanism on chicken meat began Thursday to help the domestic chicken market at a time when Taiwan, as well as most of Asia, are under threat of bird flu.
Under the price stabilization program, the COA will spend NT$20 million to promote Taiwan chicken meat in both domestic and overseas markets, Lee said.
The COA will also purchase chicken meat whenever the wholesale price declines to 95 percent of production costs or lower, Lee said.

He added that currently, the government has a farm product price stabilization fund totaling NT$76.5 billion. It is estimated that it would need at most NT$5 billion if the COA were to be forced to purchase all chicken meat to stabilize domestic chicken prices, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PROMOTING TIES WITH U.S. ON ALL FRONTS: MOFA SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs in promoting Taiwan's relations with the United States on all fronts and is explaining clearly the island's stances on relevant issues, Richard R.C. Shih, the ministry's spokesman, said Thursday.

Shih made the comments while responding to media questions raised regarding U.S. Senator John Kerry's suggestion of using the framework of "one country, two systems" to solve cross-Taiwan Strait problems.

Media reports have said that Kerry, a leading figure in the race for the U.S. Democratic presidential nomination, has long considered taking a hard line in dealing with the Taiwan question, as evidenced by the fact that he has visited mainland China several times but has never been to Taiwan.
The senator also said in a recent campaign debate that the "one country, two systems" model should be used to solve disputes between Taiwan and mainland China.

Asked whether Taiwan-U.S. relations will be harmed if Kerry wins the U.S. Democratic candidacy and eventually the U.S. presidential election set for November this year, Shih said that the foreign ministry's job in to enhance Taipei-Washington relations on all fronts and that it will spare no effort to clearly communicate Taiwan's important stances to all important political figures in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE ARREST GROUP PROVIDING TEST-TAKERS, QUESTIONS IN ADVANCE

TEXT.P: Four Taiwan citizens were arrested Thursday for providing people to take tests for international IT certifications and professional licenses in place of other persons who paid, the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) reported.

Tung Pei-chang, Hsu Ching-ping, Hsiung Chih-yuan and a man surnamed Chang were arrested in Taipei, Taoyuan, Taichung, respectively, on charges of fraud and violating the Copyright Law, CIB officials said.

The group was discovered to have been soliciting customers via the Internet, including the sites Test4U.net, TaipeiITtest.net and OPASScertification.net. They were offering advance test questions and people could who sit for international IT certification and professional license tests -- tests of Prometric or Pearson VUE -- in place of customers who would pay NT$10,000 for each subject, CIB officials said.

In their online advertisement, the group members boasted that their advance test questions were obtained first-hand from Prometric or Pearson VUE tests held in Hong Kong, Singapore, Beijing, the United States and Canada.
The group also has paid test-takers who will be coming from Canada, Macau, mainland China and Taiwan, according to CIB investigators.

After preliminary investigations, the CIB officials discovered that more than 300 people in Taiwan have obtained IT certifications, including that from Microsoft and other professional licensing and certifications, through the help of the group.
Group members, including Hsu, an engineer with an electronics company in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, have netted at least NT$5 million by engaging in the scheme, investigators said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR PEOPLE TO BUILD ANTI-VIRUS NETWORK

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Thursday called for the people of Taiwan to build an effective anti-virus network following the nation's successful containment of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) last year.
Chen made the appeal in an article, entitled "Building an Anti-Virus Network," posted in his Internet Newsletter on Thursday.

Pointing out that Taiwan has not been placed by the World Health Organization (WHO) or the World Animal Health Organization on their lists of bird flu affected areas, the president said that he believes Taiwan can do even better in preventing disease this year following an outstanding performance in fighting against SARS last year.

Despite the fact that outbreaks of avian flu have affected ten Asian countries, including mainland China, South Korea, Vietnam, Japan and Thailand, the president said, Taiwan has only witnessed a few cases of low pathogenic H5N1 bird flu virus infection among fowl.

He urged the people of Taiwan not to overreact to the bird flu outbreaks, saying that if they take proper health and sanitation precautions as well as avoid contact with fowl, this will help limit the bird flu threat.

The president pointed out that at a meeting held in Thailand last week, representatives from Asian countries, including Taiwan, and international organizations, including the WHO and the U.N. Food and Agricultural Organization, agreed that both the SARS and bird flu threats are without boundaries and that countries in the same region should cooperate in dealing with the issue.
Chen said that the Executive Yuan has already instructed the relevant government agencies to be well-prepared to fight against bird flu.
He also said that the government has decided to adopt strict measures to fight against fowl and animal smuggling in efforts to prevent bird flu outbreaks from spreading to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN SENDS EMAIL RESPONSE TO TAIWANESE-BRAZILIAN BOY IRUAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian, in his response letter to Taiwanese-Brazilian boy Iruan Wu Ergui on Thursday, exhorted Iruan to be courageous in facing the facts, saying that even he himself as president, "must obey the law."

In the president's letter to Iruan posted in Chen's Internet Newsletter, Chen said that his heart goes out to Iruan, better known as Yi-hua in Taiwan, considering that at such a young age, the boy must face such a trying fate and a tremendously difficult choice.

President Chen said that he shares the feelings of most of the Taiwan people that Yi-hua should be allowed to stay in Taiwan to live happily with his Taiwanese uncle and his family, but added that the boy must return to Brazil as both the Brazilian and Taiwanese courts have ruled.
"Even I, as a president, must respect the court ruling, " Chen said to Yi-hua.

Chen told Yi-hua in the letter that he is not alone because all the people of Taiwan support him and consider him "a son of Taiwan." Chen exhorted Yi-hua to be a good student and love and respect all his Brazilian family members after he returns to Brazil. "You are always welcome to return to Taiwan," Chen added.

The eight-year-old Iruan Wu Ergui, who has been at the center of an international custody battle, had been scheduled to be returned to his Brazilian grandmother, his legal guardian, before Jan. 16 as ordered by the Kaohsiung District Court.

After Yi-hua's uncle, Wu Hou-yen, failed to return the boy by the deadline, the Kaohsiung District Court declared on Wednesday that it will use force to take Iruan Wu Ergui away from Wu's residence Friday and send him home to his legal guardian in Brazil if the uncle fails to hand over the boy voluntarily by Thursday.

It has been learned that Yi-hua's Brazilian grandmother, Rosa Ergui, has authorized Paulo A.P. Pinto, Brazil's de facto ambassador to Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries, to take the boy home to Brazil on her behalf.

According to sources from the Kaohsiung District Court, Pinto is scheduled to arrive at the court first thing Friday morning and then accompany the Kaohsiung judges and police, who will "implement the court order forcibly" to take Yi-hua away.
It was learned that Pinto will accompany Iruan on a "homecoming" flight scheduled to depart Friday afternoon and Grandmother Rosa will be waiting at the airport of Porto Alegre, Brazil, Saturday.
In response to the Kaohsiung District Court remarks Wednesday, Yi-hua's uncle said that he will wait for the court to implement its ruling on the child's guardianship.

Yi-hua, who is now a second grader at a primary school in Kaohsiung County, was born in Brazil to a Brazilian mother and a Taiwanese sailor father. His mother died six years ago, and Yi-hua was brought to Taiwan in March 2002 by his father, who died a couple of weeks later. Since then, the boy has been living with his uncle in Kaohsiung.

His grandmother, who is the child's legal guardian, decided to take legal action to regain custody after Wu refused to let her take the boy home to Brazil in 2001. She finally won her case when Taiwan's Supreme Court rejected an appeal by the Wu family last November.

The Kaohsiung District Court in southern Taiwan served notice to the Wu family last Dec. 25, demanding that Wu return Iruan to Rosa Ergui within 20 days. Wu then went into hiding with his entire family and Iruan.
The family reemerged Jan. 15 in Chiehting Township, Kaohsiung County, where they staged a press conference in the company of a lawyer, a legislator and more than 30 supporters.
At the press conference, members of the Wu family fell to their knees, appealing to the Kaohsiung judges to postpone the implementation of the court order.

A spokesman for the support group said Wednesday that the group will cooperate with the Brazilian office of the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation and the Taiwanese Chamber of Commerce in Brazil in helping Iruan after the boy returns to the South American country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 5, or the 15th day of the first month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1596: Japanese Shogun Hideyoshi Toyotomi puts 26 Catholic converts to death in Nagasaki after he banned Christianity earlier in the year.
1792: Tippo of Mysore, India is defeated and cedes half of Mysore to the British.
1788: Sir Robert Peel, British prime minister and founder of the Metropolitan Police, is born.
1900: Adlai Stevenson, American statesman and ambassador whose liberal views caused him trouble during the McCarthy witch hunts, is born.
1914: Andreas Papandreou, Greek prime minister, is born.
1917: Mexico becomes a federated republic of 28 states.
1922: The first issue of the U.S. magazine Reader's Digest rolls off the presses.
1924: French automaker Renault launches an epoch-marking car safari in the Sahara.
1929: The Nationalist government changes the name of Fengtien province to Liaoning province.
1945: Gen. Douglas MacArthur and U.S. troops enter Manila. On Oct. 20, 1944, MacArthur and his forces landed on the Philippine island of Leyte, fulfilling his pledge to return to the Philippines.
1955: U.S. President Dwight Einsenhower instructs the Seventh Fleet to assist Nationalist troops in withdrawing from the island of Tachen, opposite mainland China's Chechiang province.
1959: The Republic of China's Executive Yuan adopts a resolution to open Hualien port in eastern Taiwan as an international port.
1959: The Ilan branch of Taiwan's East-West Highway is formally opened to traffic.
1962: A total solar eclipse occurs in the morning.
1962: President Charles de Gaulle of France calls for independence for Algeria.
1971: U.S. Apollo 14 astronauts land on the moon.
1974: Thirteen-year-old Mats Wermelin of Sweden scores all 272 points in a basketball game.
1976: A major earthquake rocks Guatemala, killing nearly 23,000 people.
1977: Brazilian soccer star Pele arrives in Taiwan for a three-day visit.
1990: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev indicates that the Communist Party must abandon its monopoly on power.
1990: Rafael Calderon Fournier wins the presidential election in Costa Rica.
1996: Rene Preval succeeds Jean-Bertrand Aristide in a peaceful transfer of power in Haiti.
1997: Switzerland's three banking giants announce the creation of a 100 million Swiss franc Holocaust memorial fund.
1999: Marshall Islands President Imata Kabua and his wife Hiromi Kabua arrive in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1999: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou awards a plaque to popular movie star Andy Lau in honor of his appointment as "Taipei Rapid Transit Ambassador," which includes the right to travel on the Taipei MRT for free for the rest of his life.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When three men meet together, one of them who is anxious to learn can always learn something from the other two. He can profit by the good example of the one and avoid the bad example of the other."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DELEGATION ATTENDS U.S. NATIONAL PRAYER BREAKFAST
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 5 (CNA) (By W.C. Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A five-member Republic of China delegation headed by Peng Ming-min, senior advisor to President Chen Shui-bien, attended the 2004 U.S. National Prayer Breakfast held Thursday at the Hilton Hotel in Washington, D.C.

With the presence of U.S. President George W. Bush at the gathering to pray for the nation's destiny, about four thousand dignitaries, including many senior U.S. administration officials, members of Congress, as well as diplomats and religious leaders from various countries around the world, participated.
The members of the ROC delegation included Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Kau Ying-mao, Legislator Chen Tang-san, professor Joanne J.L. Chiu and Chia Hsin Cement Co. chairman Nelson A.P. Chang.

ROC Representative to the United States Chen Chien-jen as well as the representative of the opposition Kuomintang and the People First Party to Washington, Jason C.S. Yuan, also attended the gathering.
The National Prayer Breakfast is an annual religious gathering aimed at promoting world peace and reconciliation.

The ROC delegation, which arrived in Washington Tuesday, paid a visit Wednesday to the Republican National Committee and met with members of the Taiwan Caucus -- a pro-Taiwan group in the U.S. House of Representatives, as well as scholars at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a renowned think tank in the U.S. capital.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNCLE FAILS TO TURN OVER TAIWANESE-BRAZILIAN BOY IRUAN

TEXT.P: The Taiwanese-Brazilian boy who has been at the center of an international custody battle and who was set to be taken back to Brazil to his legal guardian, was not turned over to authorities by his Taiwanese uncle Friday morning as scheduled, taking all parties concerned by surprise.

Iruan Wu Ergui's uncle, Wu Hou-yen, faced Kaohsiung District Court Judge Liao Cheng-hsiung, Brazil's representative to Taiwan Paulo A.P. Pinto, and local police officers alone when they arrived at his residence in Chieting township, Kaoshiung County, at 10: 15 a.m. to pick up the boy as scheduled with the consent of Wu in advance. Pinto has been authorized by Iruan's Brazilian grandmother to bring the boy back to Brazil.

Wu insisted that Iruan's Brazilian grandmother Rosa Leocadia Silva Ergui should come to Taiwan to take Iruan -- born out of wedlock in Brazil to a Brazilian mother and a Taiwanese father. He said he will only hand Iruan over when the boy's grandmother comes to get him.
Wu had said Thursday that he and the boy would stay at home Friday to wait for the court to implement its custody ruling.
The scheduled handover of the boy Friday was expected to be the last episode in the international custody battle that has dragged on for three years.

Iruan's mother died six years ago and his grandmother was appointed as his legal guardian. He was brought to Taiwan in March 2001 by his father, who died a couple of weeks later. The boy's uncle refused to allow Iruan to be returned to Brazil, and the boy has since been living in Kaohsiung and attending a local elementary school.
His grandmother eventually resorted to legal action to regain custody of her grandson when it became clear that Wu would not let her take the child back to Brazil in 2001.
Taiwan's Supreme Court made a final ruling last November, saying the boy's Brazilian grandmother is his legal guardian.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Massachusetts Grants Gays Right to Marry.
The highest court in Massachusetts, clarifying its stand on gay unions, ruled that same-sex couples were entitled to marry, beginning as May 17.
