DOC.HEADLINE: SUPPORTERS CANNOT DICTATE TERMS TO PRESIDENT: CHEN SHUI-BIAN

TEXT.P: Calling himself a president serving all the people, President Chen Shui-bian said Friday he won't be held hostage by any businessman.

In an interview with the local SET TV, the president was asked about news reports that one of his ardent supporters, Chang Yung-fa, the founder of the Evergreen transportation group, has switched his support to Chen's rival in the presidential race because of his displeasure with the president's mainland China policy.

Without mentioning his name, the president said he appreciated a certain tycoon's support in the past, but donors' financial support would not influence his administration's policy, which is formulated to serve the national interest, the interest of all the people.

He suggested that this businessman wants an immediate opening of direct transportation links with mainland China, "but this is against the interests of the country and might damage the security of the country; therefore, I have to say 'no, sorry. I can't help but say no, even if that means I lose your support.'"
"If I listen to your 'orders' because you are my good friend, I will become a puppet. Then the country won't need a president; just let a few businessmen rule the country," said Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOINT CENTER SET UP IN KAOHSIUNG, PINGTUNG TO COMBAT BIRD FLU

TEXT.P: A center to fight the spread of avian flu was jointly set up Friday by the authorities of Kaohsiung City, Kaohsiung County and Pingtung County in southern Taiwan.

Kaohsiung City Mayor Frank Hsieh, Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing and Pingtung County Magistrate Su Chia-chuan will serve as leaders of the joint center to fight against the disease. Infections in birds by the less virulent H5N2 virus have been reported in southern Chiayi and central Changhua counties.

Based on a similar set of mechanisms established last year to contain the outbreak of the potentially deadly severe acute respiratory syndrome, officials of the three local governments in charge of tourism, public health and agriculture will also take part in the task force.
Hsieh said they have full confidence that their collective mission will be a success in view of last year's good cooperation and results.

In addition to stepping up inspection and monitoring of local poultry farms, Hsieh said they will also ask the coast guard patrol authorities to increase surveillance against smuggling along the coasts in the region.
He also urged the public not to panic because the virulent H5N1 bird flu virus has not been found in Taiwan and that it is safe to eat chicken and eggs if they are well cooked.
The H5N1 bird flu has been reported in about 10 countries in Asia, including Thailand, Vietnam, Indonesia, South Korea, Cambodia, Laos and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES LEGISLATURE TO SPEED UP PASSAGE OF IMPORTANT BILLS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun urged the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan Friday to speed up screening of important bills to facilitate national development on all fronts.
Yu made the appeal while delivering an administrative report to the legislature which opened its new session Friday.

Noting that the legislature only passed 26 of the 126 Cabinet-drafted bills, or 20.6 percent of the total, in its previous session ending in mid-January, Yu said he is worried about the legislative delay's adverse impact on national reform and development. Altogether, Yu said, a total of 318 Cabinet-drafted bills are still pending legislative approval.

Yu said he most hopes the legislature can pass the bill concerning the Cabinet's 10 new major construction projects aimed at upgrading Taiwan's overall national competitiveness as well as "sunshine bills" designed to prevent shady money and gangster links with politics and facilitate establishment of clean politics during its current session.
"I hope legislative caucuses of all political groups will rationally discuss key points of various bills and refrain from irrational boycott or stonewalling of the passage of major bills," Yu said.

As this was Yu's last administrative report the legislature before the May 20 presidential inauguration, Yu took advantage of the occasion to tout the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration's achievements over the past four years.

Yu said when the DPP took power in May 2000, it inherited a public debt of more than NT$2.4 trillion. "Over the years, we have overcome many tough challenges and completed many difficult reforms. And now the spring has come. Our economy has regained momentum," he added.
The premier also took the opportunity to call on local voters to support the nation's first-ever referendum to coincide with the March 20 presidential election.

"I hope every voter will cast their ballots to demonstrate to the world that we are masters of this beautiful island through the upcoming referendum," Yu said, adding that the historic referendum will help strengthen and consolidate Taiwan's young democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAN-PURPLE ALLIANCE PUTS FORTH VIRTUAL PRESIDENTIAL TICKET

TEXT.P: The Alliance of Fairness and Justice, also known as the "pan-purple alliance" in contrast to Taiwan's two major political forces -- the "pan-green camp" and the "pan-blue alliance" -- presented its virtual presidential ticket Friday.

Representatives of the alliance unveiled posters featuring images of the group's virtual presidential and vice presidential candidates known as Lin Hsiu-mei and Chang Chih-ching in front of the Central Election Commission (CEC) to signify the group's determination to offer voters an alternative platform in the hotly contested presidential election.

Friday marked the final day of candidacy registration for the March 20 presidential election. The "pan-purple alliance" could only present a virtual ticket because the time for independent hopefuls to seek the required number of endorsements from citizens expired a month ago.

Chien Hsi-chieh, the alliance's convener, said the virtual presidential ticket will campaign on a platform characterized by six appeals -- tax reform, economic reform, gender equality, education reform, peaceful cross-Taiwan Strait relations and equitable distribution of welfare resources.
"Our policy initiatives are all designed for the benefit of ordinary citizens, not any specific political group," Chien stressed.

Chien said the alliance, which groups 12 associations of the underprivileged and labor rights activists, is extremely dissatisfied with policies presented by the two major political camps, which he said favor large business groups or vested interests rather than working-class or salaried people.

Starting next week, Chien said, the alliance will regularly publicize comments or critiques on policy initiatives advocated by the pan-green and pan-blue presidential candidates as well as on their often negative campaign tactics.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" has fielded a ticket of Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong to challenge the re-election bid of the pan-green ticket of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu in the upcoming election. Both teams registered their candidacy Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPOREANS RUSH TO PULAU UBIN TO BUY CHICKENS AND DUCKS

TEXT.P: Many Singaporeans rushed down to Pulau Ubin on Thursday to try and buy the kampung chickens and ducks ahead of their removal following the government's implementation of a ban on poultry farms there as a precaution against bird flu.

The visitors wanted to beat the Poultry Merchants' Association and the government to the kampung chickens and ducks. Quite a few of the chickens and ducks were sold ahead of the Friday deadline for removal of the birds. Some latecomers had to go home empty-handed.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACAU MISSION STUDIES INVESTMENT CLIMATE ON KINMEN

TEXT.P: A seven-member mission from Macau paid a visit Friday to Kinmen to look for investment and business opportunities on the outlying island.
The delegation, formed by representatives from Macau's shipping and tourism businesses, was warmly greeted by Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng.

Lee warmly welcomed Macau investment on Kinmen and expressed his optimism about the island's business environment and future development, citing a central government plan to enlarge the existing "mini three links" -- direct trade and transportation services set up in Jan. 2001 between Taiwan-held Kinmen and Matsu islands and the Fujian ports of Xiamen and Mawei.

Lee said he strongly recommended Macau businesses to invest in building five-star tourist hotels on Kinmen because the central government in Taipei is to relax its current rules on the "mini three links" starting from March 1, making trips between the two sides easier for a larger number of people.

Business opportunities to be brought about by the "mini three links" will be abundant, the Kinmen County magistrate claimed. "There will be no retrogression in developing the 'mini three links' on the island, " he said, pointing to a growing number of travelers as an example.

The "mini three links" was used by 21,377 people in 2001, with the figure rising to 53,681 in 2002 and to 160,103 in 2003, he said. During the 25-day period from Jan. 9 to Feb. 2 surrounding the recent Chinese New Year holiday season, the links serviced a total of 22,582 passengers, he said.

After visiting facilities related to the "mini three links, " the visitors said that Kinmen's tourist and traffic sectors could be ripe with business and investment possibilities should the "mini three links" be effectively enhanced. They said that Kinmen could be developed into a second Macau if gambling were legalized for the frontline island.

From the beginning of next month, the present "mini three links" will be also available for residents on Taiwan proper and on the island county of Penghu as well as for Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China outside Fujian province.
For the time being, only Taiwan businessmen and their families based in Fujian and residents on the islands of Kinmen and Matsu are permitted to travel between the two sides via the links.
In line with the eased rules, ferry services between Kinmen and Xiamen have been increased from Feb. 3, with each side now operating three round trips per day to better serve passengers.

The improved ferry service now allows travelers between the two sides to come and go in just one day, making it the most economical and time-saving travel option for the many Taiwan businessmen who have to travel often between Taiwan and the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Savers miss out as mortgage rates rise again.
Mortgage lenders pounced on the decision by the bank of England to lift base rates and many leading banks passed on the increase to borrowers in full within minutes of the announcement yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: At least 30 killed in explosion in Moscow subway
An explosion ripped through a subway car in the Moscow metro during rush hour Friday morning, killing at least 30 people.
The explosion occurred in the second car of a subway train after it pulled away from the Avtozavodskaya station, heading northwest to Paveletskaya station on the city's busy circle line.
Wall Street Journal: Tenet says CIA didn't call Iraq 'imminent' threat
CIA Director George Tenet, defending his agency's conduct before the Iraq war, said in a speech that analysts never told President Bush Iraqi weapons posed an "imminent" threat to the U.S. and argued that the failure to find weapons of mass destruction there doesn't mean Baghdad lacked the will or means to make them.
The unusual and widely anticipated speech, delivered at Georgetown University, seemed sure to set up a debate with congressional investigators who are finishing a tough critique of the Central Intelligence Agency's performance in assessing the threat posed by Baghdad.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIALS WILL BE PUNISHED FOR BOYCOTTING REFERENDUM: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Officials who refuse to implement the country's first national referendum will risk losing their jobs or be reprimanded, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday.

In answering questions from a lawmaker at the Legislative Yuan, Yu cited Lee Yi-yang, director-general of the Central Personnel Administration as saying that the law provides that officials who refuse to follow their superiors' orders, such as the president's decree to implement the referendum, would face punishment ranging from reprimands to removal from their jobs depending on the situation.
Yu stressed that the administration is carrying out the referendum in accordance with the law, and any official who boycotts the referendum will be disciplined.
Country magistrates who were elected would be referred to the Committee on the Discipline of Public Functionaries if they boycott the referendum, the premier said.

Huang Shih-cheng, chairman of the Central Election Commission, echoed the premier's view, saying that the Referendum Law has been properly enacted and promulgated. Officials refusing to implement the referendum called in accordance with the Referendum Law will be punished; even elected county magistrates will not be exempted, he said.

Calling the referendum illegal, the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party were once threatening to disrupt the president's plan by urging their country magistrates to refuse to implement the referendum.
The two parties control 12 out of 23 counties and cities in Taiwan among them, in addition to Taipei City.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DONATES FUNDS TO RENOVATE PARAGUAYAN POLICE FACILITIES
DOC.DATELINE: Panama, Feb. 5 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has donated funds to help Paraguay, the ROC's only diplomatic ally in South America, to build a new barracks for its national cavalry police corps and renovate its crime-fighting facilities.
The new police barracks in the Paraguayan capital of Asuncion were inaugurated Thursday in a ceremony attended by many senior Paraguayan officials and ROC Ambassador Yen Ping-fan.

Paraguayan President Oscar Nicanor Duarte, Vice President Luis Alberto Castiglioni and many other senior officials attended the inaugural ceremony, indicating that the Paraguay government attaches great importance to the event, Yen said.

Addressing the ceremony, Paraguay police chief Juan Humberto Nunez expressed his gratitude for the ROC's generous aid to help his country renovate police facilities for the sake of maintaining law and order and protecting people's safety.

In addition to financially supporting the construction of the new cavalry police barracks, the ROC has also earmarked funds to help Paraguay purchase police vehicles, bulletproof vests and establish a police patrol network.

Moreover, the ROC has donated funds for the Paraguayan cavalry police corps to purchase 100 horses and other equipment to improve its crime-fighting capabilities. Yen said he believes that with the Taiwan-donated facilities, public order in Asuncion and its nearby areas will improve greatly in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Nation: Virus poses global threat. WHO, FAO warn that disease could spread across the world without targeted vaccination of poultry
BIRD FLU, which has killed 16 people in Asia, is not under control and could spread to other regions without the right preventative measures, experts from three international agencies said yesterday. (Francis Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA TO ARRANGE FOR UNCLE TO ACCOMPANY BOY BACK TO BRAZIL

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday that it will help arrange for the uncle of a Taiwanese-Brazilian orphan at the center of an international custody battle to accompany the boy on his journey home to his legal guardian in Brazil.
Javier Hou, director of the MOFA's Central and South American Affairs Department, made the remarks after Wu Hou-yen defied a court order to give Iruan Wu Ergui up earlier in the day.

Hou said the Taiwan Catholic Mission Foundation (TCMF) , a non-government charity organization, has agreed to offer funds for Wu to accompany Iruan on the flight to Brazil to live with his Brazilian maternal grandmother -- the 8-year-old's legal guardian.
According to Ho, TCMF Chief Executive Officer Ou Chin-jen has arrived in Brazil to meet with the boy's Brazilian family, including his grandmother, to seek their consent to Wu's visit.

"Ou hopes to arrange face-to-face talks in Brazil between Iruan's Taiwanese and Brazilian family members, " Ho said, adding that such talks are expected to help reduce the uncle's defiance of a Taiwan court order to return the boy to his legal guardian.
Ho said a trip to Brazil will also enable Wu to see for himself the boy's future living environment.

Iruan's grandmother, Rosa Leocadia Da Silva Ergui, has commissioned Brazil's representative in Taiwan, Paulo A.P. Pinto, to take the boy back to Brazil on her behalf after Taiwan's judicial authorities confirmed her guardianship of the boy last November.
Pinto was originally scheduled to escort the boy back to Brazil via Hong Kong and Johannesburg Friday.

Accompanied by a Kaohsiung District Court judge, Pinto arrived at Wu's home in Kaohsiung County's Chiehting township in southern Taiwan Friday morning to pick up the boy. Much to his disappointment, only Wu greeted them, but the boy was not there.
Wu claimed that he had not received the court's previous notice demanding that he hand over the boy voluntarily by Feb. 5.
The judge, Liao Cheng-hsiung, immediately issued Wu with a new notice ordering him to turn over the boy by 10 a.m. Feb. 9. If he fails to do so, he will be taken into custody, Liao said.
In response, Wu said he wanted to accompany Iruan back to Brazil in person to return the boy.
Opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lin Yi-shih said he supported Wu's stance. "The child is not an object. You cannot package him and send him away," Lin said.

Iruan, who is better known as Wu Yi-hua in Taiwan, was born out of wedlock in Brazil in July 1995 to aBrazilian mother and a Taiwanese father. His mother died six years ago and his grandmother was appointed his legal guardian. He was brought to Taiwan in March 2001 by his father, who died a couple of weeks later. The boy's uncle refused to allow the child to leave for home, and the boy has since been living in Kaohsiung and is now a second-grader at a local elementary school.
His grandmother eventually resorted to legal action to regain custody of her grandson when it became clear that Wu would not let her take the child back to Brazil in 2001.

A support group has been formed in Kaohsiung County to help the Wu family in the custody battle. A spokesman for the support group said earlier this week that the group will cooperate with the Brazilian office of the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation and the Taiwanese Chamber of Commerce in Brazil to help Iruan after the boy gets home.

DOC.HEADLINE: ON-LINE TAIWAN AGRICULTURAL EXPORT SYSTEM LAUNCHED

TEXT.P: An on-line system for exporting agricultural products -- Taiwan AgExporter -- was launched Friday to establish a transaction platform between foreign buyers and Taiwan agricultural product suppliers.

The network, http://trade.coa.gov.tw, was set up by the Council of Agriculture (COA) and jointly sponsored by the Institute for Information Industry, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council and a monthly published by the COA.

Deputy COA Chairman Lee Chien-chuan said while browsing the Website that the purpose of the site is to introduce Taiwan's agricultural products to the world in the hope that "Taiwan farmers can catch a ride on the international marketing train."
The site mainly targets foreign buyers and domestic agricultural product suppliers and is in Chinese, Japanese and English.

It covers 12 categories and 75 items of excellent agricultural products. Domestic suppliers can register as members free of charge and can have independent account numbers and handle mail inquiries from prospective buyers.
Foreign buyers can take advantage of the Japanese and English versions to browse related information and find interested suppliers and products.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPENSATION TO BE PAID OUT FOR AVIAN FLU VICTIMS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The government will provide compensation of NT$5 million (US$154,700) to the families of anyone who dies from avian flu after eating cooked chicken, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday.
The premier made the remarks at a general interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan.

Opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Legislator Chen Chien-ming raised the proposal that the government should provide compensation of NT$3 million to "help allay public jitters" about consuming chicken and related products.

Chen made the suggestion amid reports of more human deaths in Asia from avian flu. The reports, combined with the emergence of the H5N2 virus -- a less virulent form of the H5N1 strain -- in several domestic poultry farms, have resulted in the culling of tens of thousands of chickens and ducks.
However, Yu said that the compensation figure will be NT$5 million.
The premier also said that the government will make the best possible preparations against a domestic outbreak of the disease.
Meanwhile, legislators from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) suggested several measures to help fight the disease.

KMT Legislator Yang Li-huang said that the government should take action against smuggled vaccines, establish a system of poultry marking to guarantee quality, and not allow health officials to "intimidate" consumers and infringe on the interests of poultry farmers.

She said that she was informed by some chicken farmers that the government subsidy for every culled animal is NT$100 per head, lower than the market price of NT$150, which might lead to unscrupulous people repacking condemned poultry for public sale.
She therefore suggested raising the subsidy to nearly the market value of the poultry.

In addition, she suggested that the government "give full compensation" to the chicken farmers who have temporarily closed their farms and that the compensation should last for at least six months to help them cut their losses.

PFP Legislator Kao Ming-chien claimed that the public has no need to worry, because the virus type found in local poultry is less dangerous than the strain sweeping other countries in Asia. In addition, the government has put in practice several measures to contain the disease, he said.

Officials from the Department of Health and and Council of Agriculture also said that they have provided poultry farmers with free flu shots since last October and have continued to monitor their health to reduce the possibility of person-to-person avian flu transmission.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG CUSTOMS SEIZE LARGE HAULS OF SMUGGLED GOODS

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung customs authorities seized over 1,000 smuggled products worth more than NT$119 million (about US$3.6 million) during the second half of last year, according to tallies released by the Kaohsiung Customs Bureau under the Ministry of Finance.

The statistics, published Thursday, show that Kaohsiung customs agents confiscated 1,011 smuggled products worth a total of more than NT$119 million during the last six months of 2003, the bulk of which -- 122 products with an estimated market value of NT$47.1 million -- were untaxed foreign cigarettes and liquor, much of which came from mainland China.
Bureau officials said that smugglers usually hide their contraband in containers or on fishing vessels and try to sneak them into Taiwan at remote spots along the coastline.

DOC.HEADLINE: 11 SINGAPOREANS SHARE IN JACKPOT LOTTERY WIN

TEXT.P: Eleven people had the right lottery numbers to win a share of the jackpot in Singapore's Toto Hongbao Draw of S$10 million (US$5.7 million) Thursday evening.
Each of the winners will take home over S$900,000. This year's draw also saw over 220,000 winners of smaller cash prizes.

Singaporeans had lined up by the thousands at lottery outlets around the city-state Thursday, with the outlets staying open to 6 p.m. to accommodate the large number of people wishing to purchase tickets. The draw was held at 6:30 p.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, gaining NT$0.010 to close at NT$33.295.
A total of US$734 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$33.302 and was traded between NT$33.318 and NT$33.276.

DOC.HEADLINE: STABLE CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES AT VARIOUS LEVELS: MAC

TEXT.P: There are stable exchanges on various levels between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, although cross-strait relations could experience ups and downs at times, the nation's top mainland China policy planner said Friday.

Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , made the remarks after she was asked about the state of cross-strait relations by Legislator Chen Chien-ming of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) at a legislative interpellation session.
Chen asked Tsai to define the current cross-strait relations as one of four states -- positive, stable, stalled or tense.

"Both sides of the Taiwan Strait have stable exchanges on various levels, " Tsai said, adding however that there are "ups and downs" when communicating on sensitive issues because of the international situation.

She also denied that the four new measures regarding the interests of Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China announced last week by President Chen Shui-bian, who is seeking re-election, had anything to do with his seeking to boost his re-election chances.

The four measures cover the expansion of the current direct shipping links joining the country's two frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu, with the Fujian Province ports of Xiamen and Fuzhou, subject to Beijing's agreement.

The president also promised to enlarge the planned one-way charter cargo fights from Taiwan to the mainland to two-way charter flights and to allow mainland Chinese carriers to provide the service as well as domestic ones.

He also promised to allow Taiwan businessmen to claim national health insurance payment if they seek treatment in hospitals opened by Taiwan businessmen or medical facilities designated by Taiwan's Department of Health on the mainland.
The last of the four measurers is to increase government subsidies to Taiwan schools on the mainland to about NT$30,000 (US$900) per student.
"They are part of the measures mulled when the MAC revised the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and Mainland Area late last year," Tsai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH LAUNCHES BLOOD DONATION CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) launched a campaign Friday enlisting central government officials to donate blood to help relieve a serious blood shortage facing the country.

A vehicle equipped with facilities for blood donation will travel around various government agencies, including the Central Bank of China, the Ministry of Justice, the Ministry of National Defense, the Ministry of Education and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs over the next week until Feb. 12 to prompt their staff members to donate blood.

DOH Vice Minister Lee Lung-teng took the lead by donating a bag of blood early Friday when the blood wagon arrived at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex near the DOH building in downtown Taipei.

Quoting remarks made by President Chen Shui-bian earlier this week, Lee said blood donating is both an act of self-interest and of altruism that can help boost social harmony. "Let us be happy blood donors," Lee said.
Shortly afterwards, Yang Pao-yu, wife of Premier Yu Shyi-kun, headed the spouses of 14 Cabinet members to the venue to donate blood.
Later in the day, the vehicle arrived at the Executive Yuan building, where many staff members rolled up their sleeves to donate blood.

Chang Ing-ell, chief executive officer of the non-profit Chinese Blood Services Foundation, said nearly all major domestic blood banks are in dire shortage of various types of blood at the moment, particularly blood types A, B and O.
Taiwan needs about 5,700 bags of blood per day, Chang said, adding that current blood stocks fall below the required seven-day safety supply level.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN ANNOUNCES CONTROLS ON IMPORTS OF LIVE POULTRY

TEXT.P: The county government of the outlying island of Kinmen announced Friday that all imports of live poultry, frozen poultry and related products will be controlled and screened during a nearly 11-month period beginning Friday as part of the local's government's efforts to ward off a spread of avian flu.

In the face of an escalating number of reported infections of the virulent H5N1 avian flu virus in 10 Asian countries, with more than a dozen people having already died of the disease, Kinmen, which is located some 24 kilometers off mainland China's coast and relies heavily on imports for its daily necessities, decided Friday to step up food safety and animal quarantine checks, county government officials said.

Beginning Friday, all in-bound shipments of live poultry, frozen poultry or cold ready-to-serve meat products will be controlled, county government officials said, adding that such shipments will not be allowed in without import-permit documents and papers proving that the products are come from farms that have not been affected with any epidemic or diseases over the past three months.
The controls will remain in place until Dec. 31, the officials said.

In related news, officers from the Kinmen Police Department captured 17 live chickens and ducks on a beach near Kuningtou in northwestern Kinmen that were believed to have been abandoned by smugglers while escaping a coast guard patrol.

The captured birds were handed over to authorities from the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine (BAPHIQ) under the Council of Agriculture, Kinmen Office, for bird flu virus examination.
BAPHIQ authorities destroyed the smuggled poultry after taking samples from them.
On Dec. 9 last year, six live red-faced ducks were caught by Kinmen authorities on a beach in Hsiyuan in northeastern Kinmen during an anti-smuggling operation, BAPHIQ officials said.
The six ducks, believed to have come from mainland China, were destroyed after the BAPHIQ officials took samples of the animals and sent the samples to a laboratory on Taiwan proper for examination.
The BAPHIQ lab researchers confirmed later in the month that the deadly H5N1 virus was present in one of the six ducks.
Chen Yu-hsin, head of the BAPHIQ Department of Animal Health Inspection and Quarantine, said that the H5N1 virus can be passed from animals to humans.
According to officials from the BAPHIQ Kinmen Office, no cases of the virus have been discovered on any of Kinmen's 28 poultry farms.

DOC.HEADLINE: PALAU OFFICIALS TO PRESIDE OVER EMBASSY RELOCATION TEA PARTY

TEXT.P: Two Palau officials will come to Taiwan to attend a party to celebrate the relocation of the island nation's embassy to a foreign mission building complex in Tienmou, suburban Taipei, next week, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday.
MOFA officials said that Temmy L. Shmull, minister of state, and Elbuchel Sadang, minister of finance, will preside over the tea party scheduled for next Monday.
The officials noted that since Taiwan and Palau established relations Dec. 1999, they have maintained close and friendly ties.

On the medical cooperation front, Taiwan has donated medical equipment to prevent the spread of dengue fever at the request of Palau, while in the area of agricultural cooperation, Taiwan has set up agricultural missions for the last 18 years and regularly offers training classes and field demonstrations, as well as providing guidance to Palau farmers.
Taiwan tourists also made 28,000 visits to Palau last year, making it the largest source of tourists for the West Pacific island state, they added.

They noted that Palau has been a staunch supporter of Taiwan's bid to enter such international organizations as the United Nations, the World Health Organization and the Pacific Island Forum in recent years, making it one of Taiwan's major diplomatic allies.

The market has been thoroughly cleaned and disinfected and trading resumed early Friday.
The authorities banned the selling of chickens from mainland China and local farms last week as the virus was spreading fast on the mainland.
To date, Hong Kong has found no local H5 avian flu virus.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUDGE ORDERS UNCLE ARRESTED IF IRUAN NOT HANDED OVER BY FEB. 9

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung District Court Judge Liao Cheng-hsiung on Friday ordered the arrest of Wu Huo-yen if Wu does not hand over his Taiwanese-Brazilian nephew to the boy's legal guardian before Feb. 9.

Judge Liao and Brazil's representative to Taiwan, Paulo A.P. Pinto went to the Wu residence at about 10: 15 a.m. Friday to pick up the eight-year-old Iruan Wu Ergui as scheduled but found him not to be at home. Only the uncle met them at the residence located in Chiehting rural township in the southern county of Kaohsiung.
Pinto has been commissioned by Iruan Wu Ergui's Brazilian grandmother, the boy's legal guardian, to bring Iruan back to Brazil.
Liao said Wu faces arrest if he doesn't hand over Iruan, better known as Wu Yi-hua in Taiwan, by 10 a.m. next Monday.

When Liao, Pinto and police officers arrived at Wu's residence, Wu insisted that Iruan's Brazilian grandmother Rosa Leocadia Silva Ergui should come to Taiwan to take Iruan -- born out of wedlock in Brazil to a Brazilian mother and a Taiwanese father. He said he will only hand Iruan over when the boy's grandmother comes to get him.

He added that his older brother, Wu Teng-shu, Iruan's Taiwanese father, who died in 2001 several weeks after he brought Iruan back to Taiwan, said before his death that he wanted Iruan to stay and live in Taiwan.

Iruan's Brazilian mother died six years ago, and after the boy's father died, his grandmother was appointed as his legal guardian. However, the boy's uncle refused to let Iruan be taken back to Brazil, and he has been living in Kaohsiung and attending a local elementary school there since 2001.

Taiwan's Supreme Court last November rejected an appeal by the Wu family to keep the boy in Taiwan and upheld a Kaohsiung District Court ruling that the boy be handed over and taken back to Brazil to live with his grandmother.
Wu had promised Thursday that he and the boy would stay at home Friday to wait for the court to implement its custody ruling.
The scheduled handing over of the boy Friday was expected to be the last episode in the international custody battle that has dragged on for three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTER MUM ON REPORTS ABOUT MAINLAND ARREST OF TAIWAN SPIES

TEXT.P: Minister of National Defense Tang Yiau-min declined to make any comments Friday on media reports that mainland China has busted a large Taiwan intelligence network by secretly arresting a number of Taiwanese spies in a raid.
According to the reports, the intelligence network had been arduously established by Taiwan's military intelligence agents posted in mainland China's Nanjing Military Region for many years.

As it was the largest spy ring raid since mainland China executed a senior officer of the People's Liberation Army in 1998 after he was convicted of spying for Taiwan, the reports said, the latest mass arrest has drawn much attention in mainland society.
Before attending a Legislative Yuan plenary session, many reporters repeatedly asked Tang about his views on the reported mainland arrests of Taiwanese intelligence agents.
In response, Tang said intelligence gathering is important work for protecting the nation's security.

"And it's a norm in democratic countries around the world to refrain from making any comments on espionage cases, " Tang said, adding that he hopes local people will support intelligence work and all personnel involved in the operations.
As intelligence agents work under dangerous, difficult and stressful conditions, Tang said, they need tangible and intangible support.

"For the sake of protecting our intelligence operators' safety, we have traditionally not issued any comments on espionage cases. And I hope both news media and ordinary citizens can support this practice," Tang said.

According to media reports, Col. Lee Yun-pu from the Military Intelligence Bureau under Taiwan's Ministry of National Defense and several other Taiwan intelligence workers under Lee's leadership and a senior mainland army officer were arrested by mainland Chinese authorities earlier this month.
The reports said Lee was responsible for collecting intelligence about mainland China's Second Artillery Corps and its East China Sea Fleet and activities in the Nanjing Military Region.

According to the reports, Lee had managed to develop an intelligence network under the guise of a science and technology firm to spy on the Second Artillery Corps' missile base in Loping in Jiangxi Province, where hundreds of missiles aimed at Taiwan are deployed. The reports said Lee's arrest could deal a severe blow to Taiwan's intelligence work in mainland China.

Meanwhile, a military source who spoke on condition of anonymity said he thinks that mainland China's latest raid was a retaliatory move against Taiwan's arrests of several people on charges of spying for Beijing late last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CITIZENSHIP SEEKERS MAY SOON BE REQUIRED TO TAKE MANDARIN TESTS

TEXT.P: Foreigners seeking Republic of China citizenship may soon be required to pass tests demonstrating they have at least a basic level of Mandarin Chinese proficiency if a draft revision to the Nationality Law is passed into law.

According to the draft revision crafted by a legal committee within the Ministry of the Interior (MOI), foreigners should at least be able to speak basic Mandarin Chinese and have a basic knowledge of the rights and obligations of an ROC citizen before being naturalized.
The draft revision must first be approved by the Cabinet before being sent to the Legislative Yuan for possible passage into law.
The draft revision stipulates that the Ministry of the Interior will be responsible for mapping out the regulations concerning the tests, fees and related matters.
MOI officials noted that many countries require that foreigners demonstrate a basic proficiency in the national language before being granted citizenship.

They said the revision is aimed at motivating foreigners to study Mandarin Chinese and helping them to adapt more quickly to life in Taiwan, as well as at encouraging foreign spouses of ROC citizens to take part in the language classes subsidized by the Ministry of the Education to enable them to better raise and educate their own children.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP CAMPAIGN AIDES TO MEET TO DISCUSS PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION DEBATE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's top campaign aide and Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan's will meet Sunday to discuss matters related to the holding of a televised debate between the two candidates in the run-up to the March 20 presidential election.
Wu Nan-jen, spokesman for President Chen's campaign headquarters, said that both sides have decided to send officials to attend the discussion arranged by the Public Television Service Foundation.

Taipei County Magistrate Su Tseng-chang, top campaign aide of President Chen, will represent Chen, while Su's counterpart, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, will represent Lien in the discussion to be held in a Taipei hotel.
The televised debate between Chen and Lien will be jointly sponsored by four major newspapers, the Public Television Service Foundation and the Taipei Society, a group comprised of liberal scholars.
It has been learned that an alliance comprised of 11 local TV media groups is also trying to organize another televised debate between the two presidential candidates.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. OBLIGED TO ASSIST TAIWAN IN SELF-DEFENSE: SCHRIVER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 7 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States is obliged to assist Taiwan in defending its national security even though the two countries don't have a defense treaty, a U.S. State Department official said Friday.

Randall G. Schriver, deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asia and Pacific affairs, made the remarks while testifying at a hearing held by the U.S.-China Economic and Security Commission, which was set up by the U.S. Congress in 2000 to regularly review the impact of U.S.-China economic and trade relations on U.S. national security as well as on the effective execution of the Taiwan Relations Act.

During the hearing, Patrick Mulloy, a commission member, said it seems to him that Taiwan doesn't perceive the military threat from mainland China because it has so far not purchased any weapons the Bush administration offered to sell some three years ago. He also said the United States doesn't have formal obligation to defend Taiwan.

In reply, Schriver said although the United States does not have a defense treaty with Taiwan, it has obligations to help Taiwan in self-defense under the Taiwan Relations Act-- the U.S. law that regulates relations with Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties.

"The Taiwan Relations Act not only talks about providing weapons for sufficient self-defense, there's two other operative elements: one, we have an obligation to maintain the capacity to resist force if asked to do so; and number two, if there is a threat to the people on Taiwan, the president would consult with Congress to determine appropriate action," Schriver said, adding: "That's not a defense treaty, but there are some very important obligations there."
Schriver also said he doesn't think that Taiwan doesn't see mainland China's threat.

"I don't think it's that Taiwan doesn't see a threat or they don't agree with us on the threat. I think it's a bit more complicated than that. But they are having some difficulties with how they make the resourcing decisions and how they make discreet decisions along the way to address the threat. But I think there is an appreciation of the threat among the military and among the leadership there," he explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN VOWS TO BRING FINANCIAL CRIMINALS TO JUSTICE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed his determination Saturday to terminate corrupt "black gold" politics and bring to justice all fugitive major financial criminals.
Chen made the vow while attending a campaign rally in the central county of Taichung for his re-election bid.
Chen told his supporters that he will never back off his promise to wipe out money and gangster influence in politics rampant in the previous Kuomintang era.
He also pledged to bring to justice all those who were involved in serious financial crimes even if they have fled abroad.
Describing himself as a president to serve all people, Chen said he won't be held hostage by any businessman.

Chen said while he appreciates support from local business groups, he cannot be dictated to by any of them in policy formulation. "National policy must serve national interest or the interest of all the people, not special interest groups," he said.

Meanwhile, Chen said, the nation's economy has bottomed out of a recession and is now on a steady upward track. He assured his supporters that if re-elected, he will continue carrying out sweeping economic and financial reforms, boosting economic growth and driving down the unemployment rate.

DOC.HEADLINE: LU URGES MEDIA TO ARRANGE FOR VICE PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES DEBATE

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday that President Chen Shui-bian has authorized her to arrange a debate with the opposition "pan-blue alliance's" vice presidential candidate ahead of the March 20 presidential election, if necessary.
Lu made the remarks at a news conference introducing her new book on her vision for Taiwan's future development.
Lu said she hopes local news media can help push for a televised debate between her and her counterpart from the "pan-blue alliance" -- People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong.

Lu said she has yet to figure out the agenda to be debated with Soong. "Journalists, scholars and social activists are all welcomed to offer their advice about the subjects for the debate as well as the format and other technical details," she added.

The top campaign aides from the two rival camps -- the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the pan-blue alliance of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the PFP -- will meet Sunday to work out details for a televised debate between the two presidential candidates -- President Chen and KMT Chairman Lien Chan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-RAISED HOGS FREE OF H5 AND H7 AVIAN FLU VIRUSES: COA

TEXT.P: Taiwan-raised hogs are free of the H5 and H7 avian flu viruses, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said Saturday.

The COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine (BAPHIQ) made the remarks after the World Health Organization (WHO) warned that once hogs are infected with an avian flu virus, the possibility of humans being infected will increase.
BAPHIQ Deputy Director Yeh Ying said the bureau began monitoring local hogs for influenza in July 1998.
"Over the past six years, we have never discovered the H5 or H7 avian flu viruses in locally raised hogs," Yeh said.

In 2003, he said, the bureau examined 1,326 hog serum samples and 1,680 samples of excretion from hog lungs, noses and tracheas collected from six pork markets and 68 hog farms in Taiwan and 18 hog ranches on the frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu.
"We only found common pig influenza viruses in those samples, " Yeh explained.
As local poultry farmers usually do not raise hogs, Yeh said, the possibility of locally raised hogs becoming infected with an avian virus is relatively low.

According to foreign wire service reports, a Vietnamese official said earlier in the day that bird flu viruses had been found in several pigs raised in his country. Several people in Vietnam and some other Asian countries have died from avian flu infections.

Taiwan has so far only discovered the less virulent H5N2 strain of the avian flu virus in some poultry farms and is free of the more virulent H5N1 strain. The H5N2 strain cannot infect humans while the H5N1 can.
Yeh said the bureau will step up monitoring of local chicken and duck farms amid the current avian flu outbreaks in Asia.

Meanwhile, COA sources said Saturday that a total of 120,000 chickens raised at six poultry farms in the central county of Nantou will be culled Sunday after some of its chickens were tested positive for H5N2.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER HOPES CANDIDATES CAN STATE CROSS-STRAIT POLICIES CLEARLY

TEXT.P: An official of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Saturday expressed the hope that the two rival camps in the presidential campaign can clearly state their cross-strait policies in a televised debate in the run-up to the March 20 election.

Chen Chung-hsin, director of DPP's China Affairs Department, was responding to earlier remarks by James Soong, chairman of the People First Party (PFP), who accused the ruling party of trying to brand him as being in same league with mainland China. Soong is Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan's running mate for the upcoming presidential election.
Chen said that the DPP has taken the view that Taiwan should be made the top priority and that it is questioning the attitude of the PFP.

He noted that several PFP legislators, while reviewing revisions to the Statute Governing the Relations between the People on Taiwan Area and the Mainland late last year, had different views regarding placing restrictions on mainland spouses of Taiwan residents in terms of obtaining citizenship, and that they want the government to allow direct cross-strait links even without cross-strait consultations.
Meanwhile, a top aide from the Lien-Soong presidential campaign office said Saturday that he hopes the presidential candidates could start to debate on real issues soon.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who will represent the Lien-Soong ticket in discussions Sunday with his counterpart from President Chen's campaign team, said that polls have shown that the public is most concerned about the economy, adding that he hopes the debate can focus on this issue.
Ma said the focus of the Sunday meeting will be whether to include the referendum issue in the debate or whether the issue of the economy should come first in the planned televised debate.

Ma noted that recent polls show that 70 percent of the people believe that economic issues most need to be addressed by the presidential candidates, adding that the Lien-Soong ticket will not ignore such concerns.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADVOCATES OF LINKS WITH MAINLAND CHINA IGNORE NATIONAL SECURITY: LEE

TEXT.P: Taiwan entrepreneurs who advocate direct trade and transportation links with mainland China have not considered the question of the nation's security, former President Lee Teng-hui said Saturday.
Lee made the remarks while addressing the opening of classes at a school named after him.

Lee again targeted entrepreneurs such as Chang Yung-fa, head of the shipping giant Evergreen Group, who switched his support from President Chen Shui-bian to his rival in the upcoming presidential election, Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, because of the current administration's continued ban on direct trade and transportation links with the mainland.

The former president said these businesspeople "act as if they're going to die if there are no direct cross-strait links, " adding that he cannot understand why they wouldn't think about the nation's security.
He said that the ban on direct cross-strait links means that national security has been placed ahead of the interests of the businesspeople.
Meanwhile, an Evergreen Group spokesman declined to comment on Lee's remarks about no consideration of the nation's security.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-CHINA CONFLICT TO REMAIN NO MATTER WHO WINS ELECTION: LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: The conflict between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will remain in place no matter who wins the Republic of China's presidency in the March 20 election, an independent lawmaker said Saturday.

Speaking at a seminar on Taiwan's national identity problems in the face of mainland China's rise as an economic powerhouse, Legislator Sisy Chen said the cross-strait conflict will not come to an end simply because President Chen Shui-bian wins re-election or because opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan claims victory in the upcoming election.

Sisy Chen, who once served as spokeswoman of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) before it came to power in May 2000 and who is now Lien's top campaign adviser, said Taiwan's national identity plight will also not evaporate overnight with the end of the presidential election.

Since 1992 when the two sides of the Taiwan Strait reached a verbal agreement that mainland China and Taiwan are both part of "China" despite their contention over the definition of "China, " Sisy Chen said, the biggest change in local society has been the significant increase in the number of people who identify themselves with Taiwan rather than with mainland China.
"The results of many opinion polls show that only about 9 percent of local people still identify themselves as Chinese, " Sisy Chen said. "This is a far cry from the figures seen in the early 1990s."

The outspoken lawmaker claimed that the upcoming presidential election will offer a historic opportunity for local voters to choose either an across-the-board conflict or an unpleasant compromise with mainland China.

In her view, Sisy Chen said, if the opposition "pan-blue alliance" ticket of KMT Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong wins, Taiwan and mainland China will still have conflicts from time to time. But she added that those conflicts will not be related to sovereignty issues.
If the ruling DPP ticket of President Chen and Vice President Annette Lu is re-elected, Sisy Chen claimed, the Taiwan-mainland China conflicts will be about sovereignty in nature.
Should that be the case, Sisy Chen said, the conflicts won't originate in Taiwan, but rather from mainland China's internal political pressure or Beijing's own interests.

Commenting on Sisy Chen's analysis, DPP Legislator Chen Chung-hsin, who also heads the DPP's China affairs department, said it's an exaggeration to describe the upcoming election as a "historic choice."

"Even if the DPP is defeated in the race, it can still stage a comeback in the future. If the DPP wins, it will be able to further consolidate its power base in the future and will have to squarely face up to the thorny 'one China' issue," Chen Chung-hsin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG OFFICIALS TO DISCUSS DEMOCRATIC ISSUES WITH BEIJING

TEXT.P: Hong Kong officials are flying to Beijing Sunday to discuss democratic issues with officials and legal experts in the mainland Chinese capital.
Members of the Constitutional Development Task Force will discuss issues related to the constitutional development in Hong Kong with the mainland authorities, the government announced Saturdayday.

Led by Chief Secretary for Administration Donald Tsang, the task force will meet with the Hong Kong & Macau Affairs Office and the Legislative Affairs Commission of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress on Feb. 9 and 10. It will also meet with mainland legal experts during the Beijing visit.
Hong Kong Secretary for Justice Elsie Leung and Secretary for Constitutional Affairs Stephen Lam will also head to Beijing.
The task force has been set up by Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa to collect local views on democratic issues including the introduction of a referendum for the chief executive in 2007.
The democratic camp in Hong Kong has strongly pushed for the introduction of referendums following the protest last July 1 against the proposed draft amendments to Hong Kong's national security law.
The Hong Kong government has said that it needs to discuss the issue with Beijing before adopting any constitutional changes. (Stanley Cheung)

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG TO STEP UP MONITORING OF PIG FARMS FOR BIRD FLU VIRUS

TEXT.P: The Hong Kong authorities will step up efforts in monitoring pig farms following reports saying that the bird flu virus was found in several pigs in Vietnam.

Director of the Agriculture, Fisheries & Conservation Thomas Chan said Saturday that inspections of pig farms may be stepped up from once a month to once every two weeks while more samples will be taken for bird flu tests to strengthen monitoring.
Speaking on a radio talk show, Chan said that none of the 2,000 or so samples taken from pigs last year tested positive for bird flu virus.
A Vietnamese official had earlier said that bird flu virus had been found in several pigs. (Stanley Cheung)

DOC.HEADLINE: ETHNIC EQUALITY ALLIANCE TO MONITOR 2-28 ACTIVITIES OF RIVAL CAMPS

TEXT.P: A group formed by cultural and literary figures to promote ethnic equality said Saturday that it will send observers to monitor the 2-28 Peace Memorial Day activities of the two rival camps in the runup to the March 20 presidential election.

Ku Yi-ling, a liaison officer of the Ethnic Equality Alliance, made the remarks after both the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomingtang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) scheduled large-scale activities for Feb. 28.

The DPP will hold a "one-million-hand-in-hand" campaign on that day, with people around the island joining hands to form a giant human chain. The "pan-blue alliance" will also stage large-scale activities to drum up support for its March 20 presidential election bid.

Ku said the alliance held a meeting Friday during which the participants focused discussions on the activities set for the 2-28 Peace Memorial Day which commemorates the tragedy that took place on Feb. 28, 1947, and during the ensuing "white terror" period when hundreds of local elites were killed.

The participants decided to abort its planned 2-28 walk in reminiscence of the event and replace it with other activities. They also decided to form an observation team, with the team to be divided into groups of two or three people to monitor the large-scale rally scheduled by the "pan green" camp of the DPP and its allies, as well as the "pan blue alliance's" rally, Ku said.
"The observers will monitor the two camps to see if they mobilize any one ethnic group against another ethnic group," she added.
She also said that the alliance has defined itself as a "whistle blower" and that it will from now on observe and evaluate the two rival camps each week.

The alliance wants to avoid giving scores to each of the two camps as it wants to remain objective, but the members of the alliance will list the personnel and practices of the two camps that it deems as good or bad and give explanations as to why it thinks the offense have violated decorum.

She said that the alliance has chosen the approach of monitoring the two camps mainly because they want them to "exercise self-restraint" and avoid "using sensational or radical words to try to appeal to the voters."

"The alliance will not take sides, " she stressed, adding that the alliance earlier sent letters to both camps urging them to give a substantial explanation about their policies regarding ethnic groups.

Participating in the alliance's Friday meeting were famous director Hou Hsiao-hsien, writers Chu Tien-hsin and Lo Yi-chun, and convener Chien Hsi-chieh of the "pan-purple alliance" which advocates the rights of the minority and disadvantaged groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUDICIAL YUAN ACCEPTS RESIGNATIONS OF 4 JUDGES OVER ADULTERY SCANDALS

TEXT.P: The Judicial Yuan has accepted the resignations of four judges who were involved in two separate fiction-like adultery scandals, the Taipei District Court said Saturday.
A court spokesman said the approval of the four judges' resignations is part of the Judicial Yuan's efforts to protect the image of the judiciary.

According to media reports, a married Taipei District Court judge surnamed Chang fell in love with a married female judge surnamed Lei from the Hsinchu District Court while they were taking part in a short-term study program in the United States two years ago. Both of their spouses are prosecutors.

Lei gave birth to a daughter last year. Her husband secretly had the girl undergo a DNA test after noticing that she hardly resembled him in appearance. The test results revealed that the girl was not related to him by blood. The husband reportedly became so distraught that he planned to leave the judicial profession. He stated the reason in his resignation letter. But he later accepted his colleagues' advice and decided to stay in his post.
With assistance from lawyers, the prosecutor and his wife are negotiating how to resolve their marital and child custody issues, judicial sources said.

Meanwhile, the sources said, Chang has kept a low profile since his extramarital affair with Lei was exposed in the resignation letter. He reportedly will respect his wife's wishes regarding the fate of their marriage.

In the other adultery case, a married Taipei District Court chief judge surnamed Chen became involved in an affair with a junior female judge under his guidance. The unmarried judge gave birth to a child last September.

As none of the spouses of those involved in the two adultery cases have filed criminal suits against any party, the district court spokesman said, the four judges should not be regarded as having committed any crime.

Nevertheless, the spokesman said, the district court's disciplinary committee will hold a meeting next week to mete out punishment to the three judges under its jurisdiction even though the Judicial Yuan has already approved their resignations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 7, or the 17th day of the first month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1478: Sir Thomas More, English Lord Chancellor who was executed by Henry VIII for refusing to deny the Pope's authority, is born.
1685: King Charles II, king of England, Scotland, and Ireland known as the "merry monarch" who reigned during the Restoration, dies at the age of 55.
1792: Austria and Prussia sign a military pact against France.
1812: Charles Dickens, the great English novelist who wrote a number of well-loved classics like "Oliver Twist" and "David Copperfield," is born.
1816: Italian missionary Giovanni Lantrua of Triora is executed by the Chinese.
1870: Alfred Adler, Austrian psychoanalyst who introduced the concept of the inferiority complex, is born.
1885: Sinclair Lewis, U.S. novelist and Nobel Prize winner who wrote "Main Street," is born.
1886: George Walker, an English carpenter, strikes gold in the Transvaal in South Africa while building a cottage for a prospector.
1948: Liaoning Province falls into the hands of Communist Chinese troops.
1950: Vietnam splits in two, with the Soviet Union recognizing the provisional government of Ho Chi Minh and the United States and Britain endorsing the French-backed government of Emperor Bao Dai.
1955: Republic of China government troops begin to evacuate the Tachen Islands.
1960: Israeli archaeologists unearth a number of Dead Sea Scrolls.
1968: The ROC's Ministry of Education agrees to the establishment of National Central University in Chungli, Taoyuan County.
1971: Switzerland grants women the right to vote.
1973: Former Kaohsiung City Mayor Yang Chin-hu and his wife are arrested for suspected involvement in a bribery case during his term in office.
1974: Grenada gains independence, with Eric Gairy as its first prime minister.
1976: Emanuel O. Gardiner, Liberian deputy minister of planning and economic affairs, and Lafayette Kwie Johnson Jr., assistant minister of the Ministry of Industry, Commerce, and Transportation, arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1982: Luis Alberto Monge becomes president of Costa Rica.
1985: The Executive Yuan approves the project to make Yushan into a National Park.
1986 Self-styled "President for Life" Jean Claude "Baby-Doc" Duvalier flees Haiti with his loot, bound for exile in France in the face of a national uprising.
1986: Both Ferdinand E. Marcos and his chief election opponent, Corazon Aquino, claim victory in the Philippine presidential election. The National Assembly would later rule that Marcos won the election.
1990: The Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party votes for a package of reforms that will end its monopoly on power.
1991: In its most daring daylight raid to date, the Irish Republican Army fires three mortar bombs at British Prime Minister John Major's residence at No. 10 Downing Street.
1992: Ministers of Europe formally sign the Maastricht Treaty of the European Union.
1996: A Boeing 757 passenger jetliner on its way from the Dominican Republic to Frankfurt crashes into the Atlantic Ocean, killing all 189 aboard.
1999: Crown Prince Abdullah becomes the king of Jordan following King Hussein's death from cancer.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Perfectly honest men I do not expect to see; if I could only meet with scrupulous men I would be satisfied. But in a state of society in which men must pretend to possess what they really do not possess; pretend to have plenty, when they have really nothing; and pretend to be in affluence when they are in actual want -- in such a state of society, it is difficult to be even a scrupulous man."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS UNDERPINNED DESPITE BIRD FLU OUTBREAK IN ASIA

TEXT.P: Taiwan stocks will be well underpinned by the country's optimistic economic outlook, despite outbreaks of avian flu in many Asian countries that have caused their stock markets to plunge, according to an analysis by an investment and trust company.
Amid this wave of stock market falls, the domestic bourse has experienced the smallest drop of 3.3 percent, an analyst of Hsbcggsset Management (Taiwan) Ltd. said.

In addition to the main reason that the virulent H5N1 avian flu virus has not been found in Taiwan, the analyst pointed to a string of strong economic fundamentals as the underpinner for the stock market, such as a lowered jobless rate of 4.58 percent for December last year and a yellow-red light, indicating a booming economy according to the government's five-color economic gauge -- the first in four years.
Amid a rebounding domestic economy, the middle- and long-term prospects of Taiwan's stock market are positive, the analyst said, advising investors to be cautiously optimistic about its development.

The analyst suggested that investors should pay attention to shares of stable commodities and stocks that will benefit from an appreciating local currency at a time when international oil prices are going up and the new Taiwan dollar is gaining in value against the U.S. dollar.

Since the recent outbreak of the H5N1 bird flu in about 10 Asian countries and areas, including Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, South Korea, Vietnam, Japan, Hong Kong and mainland China, the stock markets in those countries have plummeted under strong profit-taking pressure.

Thai stocks suffered the largest fall of 19.1 percent, with its benchmark SET index dropping from a high of 802 points Jan. 13 to its lowest level of 649 points Feb. 3. The SET index rebounded 13.1 percentage points in the following two days, backed by a noticeably improved economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: FEITSUI WATER SUPPLY MAY REMAIN NORMAL UNTIL MAY: RESERVOIR OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Water supplies from the Feitsui Reservoir -- Taipei's main source of water -- to normal and household users are expected to remain normal until May if the present wet weather continues this week, reservoir authority officials said Sunday.

If rain continues in northern Taiwan Monday, the water level of the Feitsui Reservoir is expected to rise to 160 meters -- an average level for normal water supplies in previous years except for 2003 -- a development that will obviate the need to continue the second-phase water conservation measures that have began Feb. 6, Feitsui Reservoir Administration head Kang Shih-fang said.

Rainfall in the catchment area of Feitsui, which is located in Taipei's southern suburb of Hsintien, reached its highest level this year Sunday, remarkably increasing Feitsui's water levels and temporarily easing the grip of a water shortage in the Taipei area as aresult of scarce rainfall over the past year, Kang said.

Sunday's downpour, plus the intermittent rain in the catchment area since Feb. 1 has led reservoir authorities to believe that the water level, which stood at 157.3 meters as of 2 p.m. Sunday, will return to the 160-meter level Monday.
Reservoir authorities were optimistic that the Feitsui Reservoir will offer normal water supplies for ordinary and household users until May, Kang added.

In accordance with an announcement made by the Water Resource Agency under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, a second-phase water conservation measuren has been imposed since Feb. 6 in five cities and counties in northern Taiwan -- Taipei City, Taipei County, Taoyuan County, Hsinchu City and Hsinchu County.
The restrictions were aimed at large-volume water users such as car washers, saunas, spas and swimming pools. By Deborah Kuo)

Aimd mounting questions about the administra- tion's case for war, President Bush created a bipartisan commission to investigate problems with the prewar intelligence on Iraq. But he put off a final report from the panel until well after the November presidential election. By Lu-sheng Chu)

The United States and its major economic allies were locked in a battle Friday over the best polices to pursue to deal with the slumping dollar and Americas soaring budget and trade deficits.

The Manila Bulletin: Funds assured for elections.
House Speaker Jose de Venecia allayed yesterday the concern of the opposition that there would be no funds for the May 10 elections as a result of the reenactment of the 2003 national budget, saying the government has"substantial savings"to finance this year's polls.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Comelec chairman Abalos won't quit.
COMMISSION on Elections Chairman Benjamin Abalos is hanging tough despite a survey showing that only 25 percent of registered voters had "much trust" and a "dominant" 32 percent had "little trust" in him.
The Philippine Star: Human rights, reforms top CPP talks agenda.
Government peace negotiators are flying to Norway today to resume peace talks with communist rebel leaders to end 35 years of the Marxist insurgency.

A vote on whether to indict National Archives Director Ricardo Manapat for allegedly forging documents relating to Fernando Poe Jr.'s presidential candidacy has split the Senate along party lines.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST TELEVISED PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION DEBATE SET FOR FEB. 14

TEXT.P: Top campaign aides from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) decided in a second round of negotiations Sunday that the first televised presidential election debate will be held Feb. 14.

After ironing out differences between the rival sides, the top campaign aides -- led by Taipei County Magistrate Su Tseng-chang of the DPP camp and Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou on the KMT side -- decided that two televised presidential election debates will be held during the run-up to the March 20 election, with the first being held Feb. 14 and the second Feb. 21.
The two sides decided that the candidates -- President Chen Shui-bian and KMT Chairman Lien Chan -- will debate issues and affairs related to the general state of the nation.

They also decided that the two sides must respect and follow the rules to be established by the debate organizers, who will be made up of representatives from the Public Television Service Foundation, the China Times daily, the United Daily News, the Liberty Times daily and the Taiwan Daily News.

The organizing body will choose a host to preside over the debates and announce the rules of the debates, and several questioners who will raise questions to the two candidates during the debates based on the principles of "fairness, professionalism and diversity."

The second debate will be held in place of a televised presidential campaign forum that has been arranged by the Central Election Commission on that date to allow Chen and Lien to voice their policy initiatives and campaign platforms.
It will be the first time in Republic of China history that presidential candidates will engage in televised election debates in the run-up to a presidential election.

Candidates of the 2002 Taipei city mayoral election took part in a televised debate organized by the Public Television Service Foundation, marking the first televised debate in Taiwan's election history.
Last week, a group of scholars called for the establishment of a permanent organization to set up presidential election debates and other election debates.

Hu You-wei, director of the Graduate Institute of Mass Communication of National Taiwan Normal University, claimed that election debates, especially presidential election debates, are more a source of valuable political and social education for the general public than a chance for individual candidates to woo voters.

"Public debate is vital for voters, since the people who put questions to the candidates in the debates are not chosen from campaign teams, so that the public might get some "real" information rather than propaganda, and will get to know the candidates from their political points of view, according to Hu.
The voters can also compare the different candidates' ideas, he went on.

Ku Chung-hua, former president of the liberal Taipei Society and a professor at National Chengchi University, said it is a duty rather than a right for candidates to air their points of view in public debate.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL GETS ENGINE MAINTENANCE CONTRACT FROM ROYAL BRUNEI AIRLINES

TEXT.P: Taipei-based China Airlines (CAL) has recently gained a contract from Royal Brunei Airlines (RBA) to repair and maintain engines for its fleet, according to a CAL spokesman.

Under the terms of the three-year contract, worth about US$25 million, CAL -- Taiwan's largest carrier -- will take charge of repairing and maintaining the PW4056 and PW4060 engines of RBA's six Boeing 767 airplanes, the spokesman said, noting CAL won the contract amid strong foreign competition.

According to the CAL official, CAL is also in charge of similar operations for Hong Kong's Dragonair Ltd., mainland China's Air China and Shanghai Airlines, Taiwan's Mandarin Airlines and the B737 airplanes used by the air force, earning an annual income of more than US$40 million.

RBA, set up in 1974, now operates six B767-300ER, one B757-200 and two A319 jets. It serves routes to 23 destinations in Asia, Australia, the Middle East and Europe, including three weekly fights to Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTMENT MEETS GOVERNMENT TARGET: MOEA

TEXT.P: Capital funneled by the private sector into major investment plans led by the government in 2003 totaled NT$724.8 billion (US$ 21.7 billion), exceeding the official target of NT$724.5 billion, a spokesman for the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Sunday.

Amid an optimistic outlook for the domestic economy, private-sector investment is expected to increase 1.2-fold over the 2003 level to hit around NT$870 billion for the whole of this year, the official said.

As of the end of January, an additional NT$204.1 billion was channeled into various major government investment projects, the official reported, adding that the ministry will continue to trace capital promised to enter in January in another 261 investment cases worth a total of NT$129.465 billion.

The MOEA attracted total promised investment worth NT$223.68 billion for 453 investment cases at the 2003 Business Alliance Conference -- a high-profile international investment promotion conference held in October last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSPECTS FOR CROSS-STRAIT TOURISM OPTIMISTIC DESPITE CURRENT LOW

TEXT.P: The prospects for cross-Taiwan Strait tourist travel are bright despite the fact that a series of events have had an adverse impact on the sector in recent years, business sources said Sunday.

Taiwan travelers paid a total of more than 2.73 million visits to mainland China last year, down by over 930,000 visits compared with the 2002 level, the sources reported. However, they pointed out that about 50 percent of all outbound passengers were headed for mainland China, an indication that the mainland has become the number one destination for Taiwan travelers.

Taiwan-based travel agencies, dedicated both to outbound and inbound tourism, have been mired in sluggishness due to a spate of incidents, ranging from the 2001 terrorist attacks on the United States to last year's outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome around the world, as well as the recent bird flu in Asia, they said.
They said, however, that they are confident that the domestic tourist industry will undoubtedly regain its vigor and continue to grow in the near future after the present woes come to an end.

The growth will be the result of various key advantages enjoyed by Taiwan in regard to the mainland, such as cultural and linguistic similarities, as well as low costs on the mainland, they explained.

Despite the current low, the mainland's position as Taiwan's leading outbound tourist destination has not changed, they added, noting that more than 2,000 tourist agencies based in Taiwan operate mainland-bound trips.
On the other hand, tourists from the mainland are expected to allow to visit Taiwan sooner or later if the government changes its policy on tourist arrivals from the mainland, they said.

An influx of mainland tourists would help inject a new lease on life into the domestic tourism sector, which is gearing up to upgrade service quality in line with the government's goal to double the number of tourist arrivals by 2008.

In a concerted effort along with the government, many large business groups as well as small- and medium-sized enterprises have invested in the domestic tourist and resort sectors in view of the many business opportunities seen arising from a booming domestic travel and an improved traffic network across the island, they said.

They forecast optimistically that cross-strait tourist travel is full of hope, with bilateral exchanges and cooperation set to increase every day. A rebounding economy coupled with a better political atmosphere will greatly benefit tourism exchanges between the two sides, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO ORGANIZE TRADE MISSION TO VISIT LATIN AMERICA

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs is organizing a trade mission that will visit Latin America from late March to early April, BOFT officials said Sunday.
The mission is scheduled to leave Taiwan March 20 for Mexico, Colombia, Peru and Argentina and will return home April 4, the officials said.

Mexico is Taiwan's largest market in Latin America, with exports of US$887 million-worth of goods from Taiwan in 2003, while Colombia, Argentina and Peru rank fourth, sixth and seventh, respectively, with exports of US$115 million to US$128 million, the officials noted.
Given that the imports of the four nations from Taiwan accounted for less than 1 percent of their totals, the officials said, there exist many opportunities to explore.
The mission will hold business talks with local enterprises and visit local business groups during the visit, they added.
