Senator John Kerry romped to two more big victories in the Democratic presidential battle on Saturday night, overwhelming Howard Dean in two of his one-time strongholds, Washington and Michigan, and solidifying his position as the favorite to win his party's nomination.
Wall Street Journal: Kerry surges to victory In Washington, MichiganJohn.
Kerry scored commanding victories in caucuses in Washington state and Michigan on Saturday, tightening his claim to the Democratic presidential nomination.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DEFENDS DECISION TO CALL REFERENDUM
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Feb. 7 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian defended his decision to call a referendum in an interview with the Los Angeles Times last Friday, describing it as a vital next step for Taiwan's emerging democracy.
The paper published the main content of Chen's hour-long interview Saturday on its front page under the title "Taiwan Leader Defends Vote."

According to the paper, Chen rejected international concerns that the proposed referendum is a provocation that endangers the uneasy peace in the Taiwan Strait. He also characterized Beijing's denunciation of the referendum as part of a broader attempt during the last 17 years to intimidate Taiwan's 23 million people as they move along the path of democracy.
Chen is placing two questions in votes for the planned referendum on March 20 to coincide with the presidential election that are as follows:

-- "The people of Taiwan demand that the Taiwan Strait issue be resolved through peaceful means. Should mainland China refuse to withdraw the missiles it has targeted at Taiwan and openly renounce the use of force against us, would you agree that the government should acquire more advanced anti-missile weapons to strengthen Taiwan's self-defense capabilities?"

-- "Would you agree that our government should engage in negotiation with mainland China on the establishment of a peace and stability framework for cross-strait interaction in order to build consensus and for the welfare of the peoples of both sides?"

Chen said that he appreciates the concerns from the international community, particularly the U.S. government and President Bush, and he gave his assurance that the Taiwan issue should not be a liability or a burden to the United States.
If re-elected March 20, Chen pledged to maintain the status quo and a permanent peace across the Taiwan Strait.

Referring to his plan to draft a new constitution for Taiwan by 2006, Chen said that it will be conducted on the basis of the status quo and will involve a series of internal issues aimed mainly at improving government efficiency.

The paper also published an interview with opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan, who will challenge Chen in the upcoming presidential race, in which Lien criticized Chen for taking Taiwan down a dangerous path by calling the referendum and thereby antagonizing Beijing.
Lien said that if he is elected, he will begin a dialogue with Beijing "as soon as the atmosphere is right."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HOLDS UP ROSY ECONOMIC PICTURE FOR 2004

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun held up a rosy economic picture for the country Sunday and canvassed the people of Ilan -- his home county -- for support for President Chen Shui-bian's bid for re-election.
Speaking to a group of Ilan residents in Taipei City, Yu said that the magpie, which is a symbol of good news in local tradition, has appeared in terms of the economy.
The country's economy is moving toward its 5 percent growth target for this year and might reach 6 percent or even 7 percent, according to some international economic institutes.
However, the economic momentum might be interrupted if the people do not choose the right person to lead the country in the March 20 elections, Yu said.

He also played down the impact on the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) of the recent disclosure that the DPP has received political donations from a fugitive business tycoon, claiming that the party's image remains intact despite the disclosure.
The DPP has never profited from donations from businessmen and does not let businessmen dictate policy, Yu claimed, adding that the voters are well aware of this.

The fugitive businessman in question -- Chen Yu-hao, who fled Taiwan to mainland China leaving behind a debt-laden business group -- revealed his political donations to DPP politicians in an attempt to disrupt legal action taken by his local creditors, mainly banks, to auction off his Taiwan concerns. This only underlines the DPP government's determination to weed out corrupt businessmen who try to buy the government's favors, according to Yu.

The premier said that one of Chen's firms bought a large piece of land in Taoyuan County four years before the land was earmarked by the government for the construction of a thermal generation station.
But the DPP government pulled the plug on Chen's scheme for making huge illegal profits when it put the construction of the power plant to public tender.

The public bidding saved taxpayers NT$150 billion (US$4.52 billion) but left Chen's business group unable to repay its NT$60 billion (US$1.8 billion) debt to local banks, the premier explained, adding that this is why Chen is trying to scuttle President Chen Shui-bian's re-election bid by revealing his political donations to the president and other DPP politicians.

Ironically, Yu said, Chen has made it onto the list of the top ten biggest tax-payers in mainland China, which he said reinforces the suspicion that he illegally transferred funds from his Taiwan concerns to his firms on the mainland.
The fugitive's anger at the DPP government only highlights the fact that the government has got it right in ridding the country of dishonest businessmen, Yu claimed.

Chen, who is hiding on the mainland after being listed by the government as one of Taiwan's top-ten fugitives, claimed in an open letter Feb. 2 that he was politically persecuted by the government despite his lavish donations to DPP politicians, including the president.

The president's aides admitted afterward that the president got NT$10 million in donations from Chen You-hao in the 2000 presidential campaign but pointed out in the same breath that the business tycoon also donated NT$100 million (US$301,431) to the opposition Kuomintang.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Feb. 8, or the 18th day of the first month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1517: Spanish explorer Capt. Francisco Hernandez de Cordoba sets sail from Cuba and later "discovers" Mexico.
1587: Mary, Queen of Scots, who had been found guilty of plotting to assassinate England's Queen Elizabeth I, is beheaded.
1725: Peter the Great of Russia dies. He would be succeeded by his wife Catherine.
1902: The eruption of a volcano on the French island of Martinique in the Lesser Antilles kills more than 26,000 people.
1904: Japanese warships launch a surprise night attack against Lushun (Port Arthur) in northern China, destroying three Russian warships and causing the outbreak of the Russo-Japanese War.
1906: A strong typhoon hits Tahiti in the South Pacific, killing about 10,000 people.
1910: The Boy Scouts of America organization, a cousin to the movement founded by Sir Robert Baden-Powell in Britain two years earlier, is inaugurated.
1924: The gas chamber as a method of execution is used for the first time in Carson City, Nevada, when Gee Jon, a Chinese gang member, is put to death.
1926: American archaeologists discover relics from the Mayan civilization in the jungles of Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula near the Caribbean coast.
1931: More than 3,000 miners are killed in an accident at the Fushun mine run by a Japanese company of the Southern Manchuria Railway in Liaoning province, northeastern China.
1931: James Dean, the U.S. film actor and cult hero who died at the age of 24 in a road accident while driving his Spider convertible, is born.
1946: A provisional people's council is set up in Soviet-occupied North Korea, with Kim Il Sung serving as chairman.
1949: The National Central Library moves to Taiwan from the Chinese mainland.
1954: More than 14,000 Communist Chinese prisoners of war in Korea who refuse to return to the Chinese mainland begin to undergo job training in Tahu, Siahu, and Yangmei in Taiwan.
1955: Nikolai Bulganin becomes premier of the Soviet Union, replacing Georgi Malenkov.
1962: The U.S. military council is set up in South Vietnam.
1963: President Abdel-Karim Kassem of Iraq is overthrown and killed in a military coup.
1964: Princess Irene of Holland renounces her right to the throne in order to marry Spanish Prince Carlos Hugo of Bourbon-Parma.
1965: British Health Minister Kenneth Robinson announces that cigarette ads will be banned from television.
1966: The Republic of Vietnam and the United States issue the Declaration of Honolulu, outlining their aims for Vietnam.
1974: Dr. George L.B. Pratt, director of the Office of Education and Manpower, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1974: Chinese investors in Taiwan and Gulf Oil Corporation officials agree on the establishment of a joint company to produce low-density polyethylene.
1976: Foreign Minister Shen Chang-huan decorates Dr. Harry Bodan Shields, visiting vice minister of foreign affairs of the Republic of Nicaragua, with the Grand Cordon of the Order of Brilliant Star.
1976: Guatemalan Ambassador Agustin Donis Kesler calls on Foreign Minister Shen Chang-huan to thank the government for helping earthquake victims.
1980: Louis Vorster, new ambassador of the Republic of South Africa, presents his credentials to President Chiang Ching-kuo.
1984: Athletes from the Republic of China re-enter the Olympic Games, taking part in the 1984 Winter Olympic Games in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia under the name "Chinese Taipei."
1995: The U.S. liaison office in Vietnam begins business operations, marking the first step in the return to normal relations between the two countries.
2000: President Lee Teng-hui says the ROC and the Vatican should join hands to strive for freedom and democracy for the enslaved people in mainland China and other parts of the world.
2001: Chen Li-fu, a member of the presidium of the opposition Kuomintang Central Advisory Committee, dies at the age of 103.
2001: Two reporters from mainland China's Xinhua News Agency who have been granted permission to be stationed in Taiwan arrive in Taipei, marking a new milestone for news exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are, perhaps, men who propound theories they themselves do not understand. That is a thing I never do. I read and learn everything and, choosing that which is excellent, I adopt it; I see everything and take note of what I see: that is, perhaps, next to having a great understanding."

Moscow, Feb.9 [CNA] The Moscow Times:Fiery Metro Explosion Kills at Least 39.
A fiery explosion tore through a crowded metro car traveling between the Avtozavodskaya and Paveletskaya stations on Friday, killing at least 39 people, police said.
There were indications Sunday, however, that the initial death toll might be much higher.
President Vladimir Putin blamed the blast on Chechen rebels and suggested that it was an attempt to put pressure on him ahead of the March 14 presid -ential election, which he is expected to win.

DOC.HEADLINE: WRA TO DECIDE FEB. 17 WHETHER TO LIFT WATER RESTRICTIONS

TEXT.P: The Water Resources Agency (WRA) said Monday it will hold a drought-fighting meeting Feb. 17 to decide whether to lift the second-phase water restrictions that have been in place in five northern Taiwan cities and counties since Feb. 6.
Thanks to heavy rainfall over the weekend, a WRA spokesman said, water levels at all the major reservoirs in northern Taiwan have risen significantly.
As of Monday morning, the spokesman said, water storage in the Feitsui Reservoir -- the primary source of water supply in the greater Taipei area -- had reached 70 percent of capacity.
On Sunday alone, the spokesman said, the reservoir's water level rose 1.68 meters, marking an increase of 9.39 million cubic meters in its water storage.
"Given the situation, there is room for considering a lifting of the second-phase water restrictions in Taipei City and Taipei County," the spokesman said.

The second-phase water restrictions mainly target large-volume water consumers, such as car washes, saunas, spas, swimming pools and manufacturing firms. The measures include cutting water supply to them by 5 percent to 20 percent.

As to water supply in the three other northern districts, the spokesman said, the current water restrictions in Taoyuan County, Hsinchu City and Hsinchu County will have to remain in place because the amounts of water in the major reservoirs in the regions, including the Shihmen Reservoir and the Paoshan Reservoir, still fall below the minimum safety levels.

Unless the three districts receive substantial rainfall in the coming days, the spokesman said, the second-phase water restrictions in Taoyuan County, Hsinchu City and Hsinchu County are not expected to be lifted in the foreseeable future.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUNSHINE LAWS MAY CLEAR LEGISLATURE BEFORE PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: Sunshine laws designed to regulate political donations to political parties might clear the Legislative Yuan before the March 20 presidential election, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said Monday.

In an interview with the CNA, Wang said the sunshine laws have been thrust into the limelight after allegations emerged recently about donations made by controversial businessmen to political parties, and a consensus among different parties coalesced about regulations governing the raising of campaign funds.

With the presidential election only 40 days away, Wang, who is campaign manager for opposition Kuomintang chairman Lien Chan and his running mate, People First Party Chairman James Soong, said the main vote-getting strategy is to inform the public of the vision a Lien-Soong victory will bring to the country.
The campaign team for Lien and Soong are trying hard to convince the people that they are the candidates who can fulfill their promises.

In anticipation of more unexpected incidents cropping up in the lead-up to election day, Wang said his team is working hard to prevent vote-buying and election-fixing and is well-prepared to control any damage caused by unexpected crises.

He welcome planned televised debates between Lien and President Chen Shui-bian, saying they will help the public understand the candidates' points of view on various issues. However, he said it is not necessary for debates between their running mates, who are not supposed to air any ideas other than those espoused by the presidential candidates themselves.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REITERATES CALLS FOR NEW CONSTITUTION VIA REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reiterated his call for the writing of a new constitution for the country by 2006 through referendum.

Speaking to a group of lawyers supporting his March 20 bid for re-election, the president repeated his claims that the Constitution is out of date and that it is impossible to adapt it to the situation through amendments, especially as the revision process provided for at present is so difficult.

In order to give the country a well-conceived constitution for its sustained development, the president said, he will put a draft constitution to referendum Dec. 10, 2006, and put it into practice by May 20, 2008, when he finishes his second term, should he win re-election.
Chen said a new constitution will be one of his most valuable legacies for the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT-PFP ISSUES FOREIGN POLICY WHITE PAPER

TEXT.P: The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) said in a white paper on foreign policy that they will promote diplomacy with a pragmatic and professional approach, vowing that "we can do it better."

KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong unveiled the white paper in a post-Chinese New Year tea party hosted for foreign diplomatic officials stationed in Taiwan. Lien, with Soong as his running mate, will run against President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu in the March 20 presidential election.

Lien said the "pan-blue alliance" foreign policy will be "credible, stable and pragmatic, " while Soong said that the presidential election will be a turning point in Taiwan's history and expressed the hope that the diplomatic officials will convey to their home countries the alliance's stance on cross-strait and international relations.
"The KMT and the PFP will bring Taiwan back onto the right path, and the people on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will need time to resolve their differences," Soong said.
"The KMT and the PFP will have no timetable" for changing cross-strait relations and the stance of the KMT-PFP will be "say yes to peace, say no to war."
The white paper criticizes the incumbent government's foreign policy as "unpragmatic" and "unprofessional."

In comparison, it says that the KMT and the PFP have seven clear goals -- to enhance security, cement sovereignty, promote peace, revive the economy, establish mutually beneficial and reciprocal relations, promote democracy and humanitarian concerns.

The white paper states that if elected March 20, the new government's top priorities will include strengthening the nation's sovereignty, seeking active participation in international organizations, promoting global security and establishing lasting peace, participating in international affairs and making good use of international assistance to raise the profile of Taiwan around the world.

The priorities will also include effective distribution of foreign resources to strengthen regional cooperation, good coordination of foreign affairs, and the grooming of talented people to serve in foreign diplomatic areas, the white paper says.

The white paper also says that with Taiwan's difficult diplomatic situation, it has to make good use of the "second track" dialogue channel, meaning that think tanks, academic figures, non-government organizations, or government officials acting in their private capacities, must take part in communication mechanisms that can complement the government's contacts with countries with which Taiwan does not maintain diplomatic relations.

KMT official Su Chi said that although the diplomatic goals of the "pan-blue alliance" are similar to those of the ruling party, the alliance's "pragmatic" and "professional" approach is far superior.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIAN WORKERS ALLOWED TO EXTEND WORK PERMITS TO MAY 1

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) announced Monday that Indonesian workers whose employment contracts expire during the period between Feb. 2-May 1 can extend their work permits until May 1.

The measure is aimed at ensuring that the interests of both the Indonesian workers and their Taiwan employers are not affected while the CLA works with the Indonesian government to lift a freeze on the introduction of new Indonesian workers, CLA officials said.

Kuo Fang-yu, director-general of the CLA Employment and Vocational Training Administration, said that employers who are entitled to employ foreign workers can apply for extensions of employment contracts for Indonesian workers whose permits expire during the period and who want to remain in Taiwan.
He estimated that the measure will benefit some 6,000 Indonesian workers.

At the invitation of the Indonesian government, CLA Chairwoman Chen Chu recently visited Jakarta and held talks with Indonesian Minister of Manpower and Transmigration Jacob Nuwawea on Indonesian expatriates working in Taiwan, on their high absconding rate and on other relevant affairs.

The CLA imposed the freeze in August 2002 in retaliation for the high rate of absconding and working illegally by Indonesian workers in Taiwan, as well as the excessively high brokerage fees charged by Indonesian labor brokers.
According to CLA tallies, some 73,000 Indonesian workers are working in Taiwan at present.
Taiwan is working to sign a memorandum on labor affairs with Indonesia in the near future to facilitate bilateral cooperation, CLA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOB STOPS COURT FROM TAKING TAIWANESE-BRAZILIAN CHILD

TEXT.P: Police sent by the Kaohsiung District Court failed in their attempts to hand a Taiwanese-Brazilian boy at the center of a custody dispute over to Brazil's representative to Taiwan Monday evening.
As of press time, the police were still trying to convince the boy's Taiwanese uncle to hand over the boy voluntarily.

Liao Cheng-hsiung, a Kaohsiung District Court judge who ordered the police to take Iruan Wu Ergui away from his Taiwanese uncle Wu Ho-yen and return him to his rightful and legal guardian, said Wu called in a huge mob of relatives and sympathizers to prevent police from taking the eight-year-old boy away.
The mob surrounded the police station at Chieting, a rural township in Kaohsiung County, to prevent police from carrying out their duty.

Liao, who was at the scene to see to it that the boy was returned to his grandmother, the child's legal guardian, said he has asked for police reinforcements to help implement the court's order, although he was still hoping it could be done without resorting to force.

Meanwhile, Brazilian representative to Taiwan Paulo A. Pereira Pinto was waiting at the Kaohsiung District Court, having already missed a 5 p.m. flight from Kaohsiung to Hong Kong on which he had booked two seats to escort the boy home to Brazil.
It was the third time Pereira had gone to the Kaohsiung District Court to pick up the boy due to Wu's continued refusal to give up the boy.
Iruan Wu Ergui was born to Brazilian mother Marisa Tavares Ergui and Taiwanese father Wu Teng-shu in 1995 in Brazil.
The mother died in 1998, and the child's grandmother, Rosa Leocadia Da Silva Ergui, was named as the boy's guardian with Wu Teng-shu's approval in 2000.

Wu Teng-shu took the boy from his grandmother's home at Porto Alegre, Rio Grande do Sul to his hometown of Chieting on March 15, 2001, for a short visit, but he died unexpectedly March 29 in Chieting.

Wu Teng-shu's younger brother, Wu Ho-yen decided to take the law into his own hands and refused to let the child leave, triggering a desperate legal battle for Iruan's custody with the boy's distraught grandmother.
Wu lost and was ordered by the court to hand over the boy to Pereira, who is looking after the interests of the child's grandmother in Taiwan.

The court has threatened to detain Wu if he fails to hand in the boy but Wu has refused to budge. Instead, he tried to seek public sympathy for his efforts to keep the boy in Taiwan and even wrote a letter to President Shui-bian for help in a desperate attempt to reverse the court's order.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECOND-PHASE WATER RESTRICTIONS COULD BE LIFTED: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu said Monday that if the water level of Shihmen Reservoir reaches 225 meters, or seven meters more than the current level, the ministry will consider lifting a second phase of water restrictions.
Lin made the remarks when he inspected the reservoir in Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan.

Lin said that if the water level reaches 225 meters, it will bring tremendous relief to the drought and that the second-phase water restrictions imposed in northern Taiwan since Feb. 6 could be lifted, although related details will still have to be worked out at a drought-fighting meeting scheduled for Feb. 17.

Thanks to several consecutive days of rain, the rainfall received by the reservoir has accumulated to 151.20 millimeters since Feb. 1, higher than the 146.47 millimeter monthly average. The water level had also risen to 217.73 meters from 214.35 meters before the latest bout of rain.

Lee Tie-min, director of the Water Resource Agency of northern Taiwan, briefed Lin about the condition of Shihmen reservoir, saying that barring any unexpected circumstances, there will be an additional 100 millimeters of rain in February, which will bring the water in the reservoir to 100 million cubic meters. At present, the reservoir holds 64.3 million cubic meters.

The second-phase water restrictions have been in place in five cities and counties in northern Taiwan since Feb. 6, mainly targeting large-volume water consumers such as car washes, saunas, spas, swimming pools and manufacturing firms. The restrictions include cutting water supplies to these users by 5 percent to 20 percent.

Meanwhile, with the rain of recent days, the Water Resource Agency has authorized the Taipei Water Department to decide whether to adjust the second-phase water restrictions depending on the situation of the water level at Feitsui Reservoir -- the prime source of water for the greater Taipei area.
The rain has also brought plentiful water to Yungheshan and Paoshan reservoirs, which supply water to the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park and households in the Hsinchu area.
Although the second-phase restrictions are still in place, Taiwan Water Supply Corp. officials said that there will be no water supply problems for industrial and household use until the end of May.

Jenyitan and Lantan reservoirs, which supply water to Chiayi in southern Taiwan, also reported daily water accumulation of between 50,000 and 60,000 tons of waters for three consecutive days, which means there will be no supply problems from that source before the end of May.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN IS OPEN TO PUBLIC DEBATES ON REFERENDUM QUESTIONS

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will respect whatever decision is made by the Central Election Commission (CEC) on whether there should be public debates about the questions to be asked in the upcoming referendum, an Executive Yuan spokesman said Monday.

Lin Chia-lung said although the Referendum Law doesn't require public debates proceeding the referendum initiated by the president, as it does for a referendum initiated by others, the Executive Yuan will not oppose such debates in light of the fact that they could help raise public awareness about the referendum, which will be the first national referendum in the country.

However, Lin said, the referendum scheduled for March 20 to coincide with the presidential election should not be postponed because of public debates, the Executive Yuan will respect the CEC's decision and hopes it will balance the president's power to call a referendum against the public's right to understand the referendum through debates.

The Referendum Law obliges the CEC, which is charged with the implementation of referendums, to stage at least five public debates for nationwide referendums with the purpose of educating the public on the pros and cons of the issues.

Since the law is unclear whether the public debates rule applies to a referendum called by the president, CEC members have been divided over whether to hold debates because of the logistical problems of organizing five debates around the country in the short period before March 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES PLEDGE TO HOLD CLEAN ELECTION

TEXT.P: The presidential and vice presidential candidates from the two rival political camps signed promissory notes Monday to signify their determination to hold a clean election and keep political contributions transparent.

President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu signed their promissory notes during a meeting with representatives of the National Clean Election Promotion Association (NCEPA) at the headquarters of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Chen said a clean election is not only a common wish but also an integral part of the code of practice of a mature democracy. "Only a clean election can thwart corrupt 'black gold' politics," he noted.
In the past, Chen claimed, Taiwan's authoritarian rulers indulged the involvement of gangsters and shady money in political elections in order to maintain its political dominance.

Even though authoritarian rule ended following the power transition in May 2000, Chen said, the "black gold" political mechanism did not collapse with the Kuomintang's (KMT's) defeat in the 2000 presidential election.

Against that backdrop, Chen said, his administration has spared no effort in the past four years to promote financial, judicial, legislative and political reform with an ultimate goal of establishing clean politics and wiping out shady political links with gangsters and moneyed interests.

"Our efforts have achieved initial results on some fronts, but there is still room for improvement in several other fields, " Chen said, adding that a clean election is crucial to the campaign for clean politics in the future.
Chen said he fully supports the clean election promotion association's cause and is more than willing to pledge support for its goal.

For his part, NCEPA President Chai Sung-lin said he hopes the March 20 election will be a high-quality race in which the candidates refrain from negative campaign tactics, from instigating ethnic disharmony and from polluting the environment, as well as establish transparency in their political contributions and refrain from wasting money.
In addition to signing the clean election promissory note, Chen and Lu also signed a promissory note on the transparency of political contributions.

According to the note, Chen and Lu agreed to publicize political donations received by themselves and their campaign headquarters in the run-up to the election. They are required to publicize detailed reports about the donations on Feb. 20 and March 13.

Later in the day, Chai and other NCEPA representatives also met with the opposition "pan-blue alliance" presidential and vice presidential candidates -- KMT Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong.

Lien and Soong also signed the clean election and political donations transparency promissory notes, pledging to abide by the clean election principles outlined by the association and keep their political donations transparent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FUTURES EXCHANGE SIGNS AGREEMENT WITH TOKYO COMMODITY EXCHANGE

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Futures Exchange (TaiFex) signed a memorandum of understanding on bilateral cooperation with the Tokyo Commodity Exchange (TOCOM) Monday, according to TaiFex officials.

TaiFex Chairman Wang Teh-san and TOCOM Chairman Tadayoshi Nakazawa signed the memorandum in Tokyo on behalf of each side. TOCOM has become the fourth international partner of the TaiFex, the official said.
After the signing ceremony, the two sides began to arrange for the first working meeting, and will continue to map out areas of cooperation.

Wang expressed the hope that the signing of the memorandum will establish an exchange framework, adding that since the TaiFex is working on new commodities, the TOCOM's experience can be a valuable reference.

In line with its internationalization policy, the TaiFex is actively promoted strategic cooperation with foreign commodity exchanges and signed memorandums of understanding with the Korean Futures Exchange, the Tokyo International Financial Futures Exchange, and the Chicago Board of Trade between Nov. 2002 and Aug. 2003.

The Taiwan Futures Exchange, formally launched in July 1998, has seen its transactions grow significantly. It averaged 128,000 transactions per day last year, or three-fold from 2002, becoming one of the fastest growing markets in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: RELIEF FUND TO FARMERS TO INCREASE TO NT$100 BILLION NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) said Monday that an additional NT$23.5 billion (US$707.83 million) budget will be appropriated to a relief fund next year to compensate for the losses of farmers incurred by imported agricultural products following the nation's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO).
With the additional budget, the COA officials said that the total will be NT$100 billion.

The officials made the remarks in response to a three-point proposal by opposition parties to step up care of farmers and fishermen. The gist of the proposal is to increase the relief fund to NT$100 billion within one year, with farmers and fishermen being able to get loans at 2 percent interest rates from farmers and fishermen's associations, as well as to raise the purchase price of rice to NT$23 per kilogram and to raise the subsidy for fuel for fishing vessels.
Regarding the proposal to raise the price of rice, the COA said that the government's purchases follow a specific formula.

The officials said the current purchase price is enough to safeguard farmers' incomes, adding that if the purchase price is increased too dramatically, it will run against the WTO's principle of diminished government subsidies and will be detrimental to the adjustment of the nation's rice industry.

On the opposition parties' proposal that the loan interest rate be cut to 2 percent, they said that starting from Feb. 1, the rates of loans from an agricultural industry development fund have already dropped to 2 percent from 2.5 percent, while the interest rates of loans from a special fund to stimulate the farmers' and fishermen's associations has dropped to 1.5 percent from 2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANTED U.S. MURDER SUSPECT SURRENDERS TO TAIWAN POLICE

TEXT.P: A wanted U.S. murder suspect has turned himself in to the Pingtung County Police Bureau in southern Taiwan, the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) said Monday.

According to CIB officials, W. A. Kimmick, who has been wanted by a U.S. Vermont state court on a second-degree murder charge, surrendered to Pingtung police authorities Sunday evening after his friend told him that Taiwan's police had set up an islandwide dragnet to arrest him.
Kimmick arrived in Taiwan Jan. 25 via an EVA Airways flight after allegedly killing his wife, CIB officials said.

The CIB began to search for Kimmick after the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan, which represents U.S. interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, sought its assistance in arresting him earlier this month, the officials said.
The U.S. Federal Investigation Bureau will send staff members to Taiwan in the near future to escort Kimmick back home to stand trial, the officials said.

TEXT.P: New York Times: Bush states his case early.

U.S. President George W. Bush's TV interview at "Meet the Press" was to frame the election on his capacity to make the tough, unpopular decisions that he thinks are in the best interests of the national security and economic health of the United States.
Bush discussed his decision to take the nation to war with Iraq, trying to make a larger case for his presidency and his sincerity.
Wall Street Journal: As Democrat adds to wins, President defends policies in rare TV appearance

President George W. Bush and Sen. John Kerry of Massachusetts this weekend began framing a 2004 presidential-election debate with starkly divergent approaches to the economy, the war in Iraq and their own records of military service.

Bush, facing criticism from Democrats and battered by policy setbacks such as the rising cost of his Medicare drug plan and the failure to find weapons of mass destruction in Iraq, took the rare step of submitting to an hourlong, televised Oval Office interview.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CONSULTS WITH WTO MEMBERS ON TRADE INTERESTS ON EU ENLARGEMENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's permanent mission to the World Trade Organization (WTO) recently invited key members of the organization to hold a consultation meeting to deal with the possible impact made by the enlargement of the European Union (EU) on their trade interests.
Ten European countries, including Hungary, Poland, Slovenia, Malta, Cyprus, the Czech Republic, Latvia, Lithuania, Estonia, and Slovakia, will become new EU members May 1 this year.

Facing the new trade situation and relevant issues after the EU's enlargement, the countries attending the meeting also discussed matters regarding how to obtain maximum trade interests from the EU in the future, according to sources close to the mission.
The sources said that the new EU member states are expected to adjust the level of their import tariffs to that of the EU's and that such an adjustment will impact export countries' interests.

Statistics show that annual trade between Taiwan and the 10 new EU members amount to US$1.5 billion and that the island particularly maintains close trade relations with Hungary, Poland and the Czech Republic.

It is expected that through consultations among delegates from Australia, Canada, Japan, Singapore, South Korea and the United States, the major WTO members will be able to work out a strategy to deal with future negotiations with the EU in seeking compensation for their trade interests.

According to the rules of the General Agreement of Tariffs and Trade -- the predecessor to the WTO -- the EU has to hold talks with those export countries that might be affected by the increase of import tariffs of new EU nations.

Officials from the United States, Japan, Canada and South Korea stationed in Brussels recently held an informal consultation meeting with their EU counterparts on relevant issues, a Taiwan trade official in Geneva said. However, Taiwan did not attend the gathering.
A customs tariff document released by the EU at the end of January shows that up to 3,000 Taiwan-made products exported to the new 10 EU members will be affected after the EU enlargement.

DOC.HEADLINE: VETS POSTED AT POULTRY WHOLESALE MARKETS TO MONITOR QUALITY

TEXT.P: Veterinarians have been posted at the country's three major poultry wholesale markets as part of the government's efforts to prevent the spread of avian flu, sources from the Council of Agriculture (COA) reported Monday.
The COA has contracted 300 vets to work at the three major poultry wholesale markets in northern, central and southern Taiwan. Avian flu has killed 19 people in Vietnam and Thailand.

The vets, who will take turns being stationed at the three wholesale markets, located in Taipei City, Taichung City and Fengshan City, will examine live birds between 10 p.m. and 11 a.m. each day to make sure that the birds are safe for consumption, said COA Vice Chairman Hu Fu-hsiung.
Hu said the COA animal health inspection offices around the country are also inspecting poultry farms islandwide on a regular basis.
Because of avian flu, a number of poultry farms in southern and central Taiwan have destroyed some 100,000 chickens and ducks since early January this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP DEFENDS POLICY OF BANNING ENGLISH TEACHING IN KINDERGARTENS

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Monday defended the Ministry of Education's (MOE's) decision to ban English teaching in kindergartens and nursery schools from the start of the next school year.
DPP Legislator Tsai Huang-lang said at a press conference held at the Legislative Yuan that the MOE's decision is aimed at streamlining and improving the learning environment for Taiwan's very young.
The move received the approval of both DPP and opposition lawmakers, Tsai said, adding that Taipei City has taken the lead in implementing the measure Feb. 1.

Tsai made the remarks in the wake of an announcement by Minister of Education Huang Jung-tsun a day earlier that all kindergartens and nursery schools around Taiwan will be prohibited from offering instruction in English.
The MOE announcement has triggered a wave of protest from school operators and parents.

Meanwhile, Wu Tsai-shun, director-general of the MOE's Department of Elementary Education, said that all forms of English teaching at kindergartens or nursery schools, regardless of whether they are legally registered, should be prohibited as the practice runs counter to the basic educational principles for very young children.

For normal and healthy development, very young children should first be taught in their mother tongue, then Mandarin Chinese, and then a foreign language, Wu said. He added that the purpose of the MOE's ban on English teaching is for the healthy physical and mental development of the preschool children.
Wu said many illegal cram schools or after-school study centers have solicited "customers" by offering bilingual or "full English" instruction at excessively high prices.

He noted that the Ministry of Education will first make the English ban policy better known among kindergartens, nursery schools, as well as children's cram schools and after-school study centers before actually implementing the ban at the start of the next school year.

Meanwhile, Taipei City Government announced Monday that in accordance with the Ministry of Education policy, all kindergartens, nursery schools and children's cram schools, numbering over 1,000, are now prohibited from offering any form of instruction in English.
Violators could face fines or have their licenses revoked, city government officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN 11,0000 FOREIGN WORKERS REMAIN UNACCOUNTED FOR: NPA

TEXT.P: More than 11,000 foreign laborers had absconded from their jobs as of the end of last year, with Vietnamese forming the bulk of runaway alien workers, the National Police Administration (NPA) reported Monday.
According to NPA statistics, the number of foreign workers abandoning their jobs stood at 11,125 at the end of last year. Among them, 3,983 were from Vietnam and 3,706 were from Indonesia.

By gender, NPA officials said, female Indonesian workers were the most likely to run away, with 3,303 remaining unaccounted for at the end of 2003; followed by Vietnamese women laborers at 2,819, and Philippine women workers at 1,721.
Among male workers, Thai citizens formed the largest national group of laborers fleeing their jobs with 1,246, followed by Vietnamese men at 1,164.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stocks futures market were higher on Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for February moved up 105 points to close at 6,470, with 28,973 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for March rose 100 points to finish at 6,475, with 712 contract transactions, while June futures gained 80 points to close at 6,480, with 39 contracts traded.
September futures increased 85 points to close at 6,475, with 4 contracts traded. No transactions were reported for December futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,365 for February, 6,375 for March, 6,400 for June, 6,390 for September, and 6,385 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
February TE futures increased 4.05 points to finish at 266.25, with 3,739 contract transactions, while March TE futures rose 4.35 points to close at 266.5, with 113 contracts traded.
June TE futures gained 3 points to finish at 266, with only one contract changing hands, while December TE futures increased 4.8 points to close at 270, with 2 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for September TE futures.
February TF futures moved up 27.4 points to finish at 981.2, with 12,052 contract transactions, while March TF futures rose 23 points to close at 981, with 290 contracts traded.
June TF futures increased 15.4 points to finish at 970, with 3 contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 109.74 points to close at 6,463.09.
The bourse opened at 6,442.84 and fluctuated between 6,475.38 and 6,422.62 during trading.

A total of 8.52 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$167.64 billion (US$5.05 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 7.28 billion stocks changed hands on a market turnover of NT$148.46 billion (US$4.46 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories posted losses, with plastics and chemical shares moving down 0.3 percent.

The other major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff shares moving up the most at 5.3 percent, followed by textile issues at 3.8 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 3.1 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.9 percent, cement stocks at 1.8 percent, electrical shares at 1.7 percent, and construction stocks at 0.7 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 606 to 215, with 137 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK PRICES UP BY 109.74 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Monday, with the weighted index moving up 109.74 points to close at 6,463.09.
Market turnover amounted to NT$167.64 billion (US$5.05 billion).

DOC.TEXT:
The Manila Bulletin: DENR offers to remove posters. The Commission on Elections (Comelec) was asked yesterday by the Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENR) to deputize environment officials and employees to remove campaign materials nailed or tied to trees and other plants not designated as common poster areas.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Gov't wants peace with Reds by May. WITH THE resumption Monday of the long-stalled peace talks in the Norwegian capital of Oslo, the government wants to sign a final agreement with communist rebels before the May 10 elections.
The Philippine Star: Peace pact before polls? The government wants to sign a peace agreement to settle the 35-year-old communist rebellion before the May 10 general elections, but the rebels said this was highly unlikely.
The Manila Times: Angara to defy Drilon. The Senate Committee on Revision of Codes and Laws will implement its recommendations on the Manapat report, defying the ruling of Senate President Franklin Drilon that the Senate did not approve it Friday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Feb. 9, or the 19th day of the first month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1775: Hostilities between Britain and the American colony of Massachusetts become imminent as the British Parliament announces the state is in rebellion and approves new laws to control the situation.
1799: The U.S. Navy draws first blood in a war with France.
1801: France signs the Peace of Luneville with Austria, dissolving the Holy Roman Empire.
1825: John Quincy Adams, an American politician who helped formulate the Monroe Doctrine and who advocated antislavery measures, is elected the sixth president of the United States, defeating Andrew Jackson.
1830: Explorer Charles Stuart discovers the source of Australia's longest river, the Murray.
1881: Feodor Mikhailovich Dostoevski, Russian writer who wrote such great novels as "Crime and Punishment," "The Idiot," "The Possessed," and "The Brother Karamazov," dies at the age of 60.
1899: The Boxer Uprising breaks out in China. Sparked by popular discontent with internal misgovernment and anti-foreign sentiment aroused by unequal treaties, the boxers lay siege to the foreign legion in Peking, where a combined force of Japanese, French, British, Russians, and American troops held out for over a month.
1921: The Living Buddha of Outer Mongolia proclaims "independence" after Mongolian and Russian communists gain control of Outer Mongolia. They established the Mongolian People's Republic in 1924, after the Living Buddha died.
1942: Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek visits India after assuming office as supreme commander of the China Theater of War on Jan. 2, 1942.
1945: Mia Farrow, the American actress who first made her name in the television series Peyton Place and went on to make many films, notably comedies with Wooden Allen, is born.
1955: The U.S. Senate approves the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty by a vote 64-6.
1957: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China advocates independence for the Ryukyus. China and Japan both claimed the Ryukyus until 1874, when the Ching court signed a treaty recognizing Japanese rule. After Japan's defeat in World War II, the U.S. took over the Ryukyus. In 1953, the U.S. returned the islands north of Okinawa to Japan. Okinawa and the southern Ryukyus were returned in 1972.
1962: The Taiwan Stocks Exchange formally begins operations.
1964: Beatlemania hits the United States as 73 million Americans watch four lads from Liverpool appear on the Ed Sullivan Show.
1973: H.E. Hisham Muhiuddin Nazer, state minister of Saudi Arabia, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1974: Six winners of the Second Cathay Children's Music Contest leave Taipei for Hong Kong to attend the Arts Festival.
1981: General Wojciech Jaruzelski, Poland's defense minister, becomes prime minister and chief of the Polish Communist Party.
1993: President Francois Mitterrand visits Vietnam, ending Vietnam's isolation in the international community. He was the first Western head of state to visit the communist country since 1966.
1994: President Lee Teng-hui leaves for the Philippines, Indonesia, and Thailand on an eight-day visit.
1999: A 352-page collection of news photographs depicting historic moments in ROC diplomacy over the past six decades is published by the Central News Agency, which was founded in 1924.
1999: The Republic of the Marshall Islands opens an embassy in the Republic of China, heralding a new era in relations between the two countries.
2000: The Taiwan Stock Exchange performs well on the first trading session after the Chinese New Year holiday, with the market's weighted price index breaking the 10,000 point level at the close.
2001: Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) Deputy Director-General Francis K.H. Liang, leaves Taipei for Beijing to attend a senior officials meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Why should one be too severe? When a man reforms and comes to me for advice, I accept his present reformation without inquiring what his past life has been. I am satisfied if I find that, for the present, he has really reformed, without being able to guarantee that he will not relapse again. But why should one be too severe?"

DOC.HEADLINE: REFERENDUM RESULTS TO BE BINDING: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Tuesday that the results of the nation's first-ever referendum, to be held March 20 in conjunction with the presidential election, will be legally binding.
Yu made the remarks during a general interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan.

At the session, opposition People First Party Legislator Feng Ting-kuo asked Yu how the government will react if the results of the referendum show that a majority of the voters disagree with the proposal to negotiate with Beijing on the establishment of a mechanism for peaceful interaction or that a majority of the voters are opposed to the government purchasing more anti-missile weapons.
In response, Yu said the Cabinet will definitely respect the referendum results which have an undisputable binding force under the Referendum Act.
Expressing dissatisfaction with Yu's answer, Feng repeatedly pushed Yu to give an unequivocal reply. However, the premier said he couldn't answer hypothetical questions.
Yu said he hopes all eligible voters will support the referendum and express their opinions on the two referendum questions through their ballots.
He further said that after the referendum results come out, he will gladly explain the government's stance on the results if Legislator Feng asks him again.

During the legislative session, Feng also asked Minister of National Defense Tang Yiau-min how his ministry will respond if the referendum results show that the majority of voters oppose missile procurement.

In reply, Tang said that while national defense is a common duty of all his fellow countrymen, it is also a professional affair. "We don't like to see political meddling with defense affairs," he added.
Last Wednesday, the Cabinet approved the two questions initiated by President Chen Shui-bian to be put to the people in the upcoming referendum:

-- "The people of Taiwan demand that the Taiwan Strait issue be resolved through peaceful means. If mainland China refuses to withdraw the missiles it has targeted at Taiwan and to openly renounce the use of force against us, do you agree that the government should acquire more advanced anti-missile weapons to strengthen Taiwan's self-defense capabilities?"

-- "Do you agree that our government should engage in negotiations with mainland China on the establishment of a peace and stability framework for cross-strait interactions to build consensus and for the welfare of the people of both sides?"

During the Tuesday legislative session, Yu also reiterated the legality and constitutionality of the upcoming referendum, saying that the Referendum Act endows President Chen the right to decide the timing and content of a national referendum in terms of the nation's diplomatic and defense situations.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPRESENTATIVE TO ESCORT TAIWANESE-BRAZILIAN BOY HOME FEB. 11

TEXT.P: After a long and turbulent day, the Kaohsiung family of the Taiwanese-Brazilian boy at the center of an international custody battle finally handed the child over to Brazil's representative to Taiwan midnight Monday, allowing the child to be returned to his legal guardian in Brazil.

Representative Paulo A.P. Pinto, who has been commissioned by Iruan Wu Ergui's Brazilian grandmother Rosa Leocadia Silva Eugui to bring him home, is scheduled to escort the 8-year-old back to Brazil Wednesday. Iruan will also be accompanied by his Taiwanese aunt during the journey back to Brazil.
Iruan Wu Ergui, born to Brazilian mother Marisa Tavares Ergui and Taiwanese father Wu Teng-shu in 1995 in Brazil, has been living in Taiwan for the past three years.

At the Kaohsiung District Court, Judge Liao Cheng-hsiung handed the boy over to Pinto just before midnight Monday. Iruan's uncle and aunt, their lawyer, and Kaohsiung County Legislator Lin Yi-shih were all present. By that time, Iruan had fallen asleep after a long and difficult ordeal the preceeding day.

On Monday morning, the judge issued a warrant for the arrest of Iruan's Taiwanese uncle Wu Huo-yen over Wu's failure to hand the boy over before the deadline set by the court. A mob of relatives and sympathizers then swamped the Wu residence in Chiehting township, Kaohsiung County, to prevent the police from taking the boy away. Iruan screamed and kicked when the police came and tried to separate him from his relatives.
Pinto, who arrived in Kaohsiung late Sunday evening and proceeded to the Kaohsiung District Court Monday morning to pick up the boy, was also at the scene.

Judge Liao, who was also present to see to it that the boy was handed over, said he asked for police reinforcements to help carry out the court's order, although he added that he still hoped it could be done without resorting to force.

Finding no more room for maneuvering in light of the judge's determination, the Wu family finally gave in and came to an agreement with the judge and Pinto, allowing the Brazilian representative to take Iruan Wu Ergui home to Brazil.
Iruan's mother died in 1998, and the child's grandmother, Rosa Ergui, was named as the boy's guardian with Wu Teng-shu's approval in 2000.

Wu Teng-shu took the boy from his grandmother's home at Porto Alegre, Rio Grande do Sul, to his hometown of Chiehting on March 15, 2001, for a short visit, but he died unexpectedly March 29 in Chiehting. Iruan's uncle refused to let the boy be taken back to Brazil, so he has been living in Kaohsiung ever since.

Taiwan's Supreme Court last November rejected an appeal by the Wu family to keep the boy in Taiwan and upheld a Kaohsiung District Court ruling that the boy be handed over and taken back to Brazil to live with his grandmother.

Los Angeles Times: Bush Concedes Flaws in Iraq Weapons Data.
U.S.President Bush conceded for the first time that he relied on flawed assumptions and inaccurate information in launching the Iraq war, but he denied having intentionally misled the American people.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL ELECTION COMMISSION ISSUES PROCLAMATION FOR REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission issued Tuesday a proclamation formally announcing the referendum called by President Chen Shui-bian on the nation's defense and talks with mainland China.
The referendum will be held March 20 by secret vote, the proclamation says.
The president is placing two questions to votes for the planned referendum to coincide with the presidential election:

-- "The people of Taiwan demand that the Taiwan Strait issue be resolved through peaceful means. Should mainland China refuse to withdraw the missiles it has targeted at Taiwan and openly renounce the use of force against us, would you agree that the government should acquire more advanced anti-missile weapons to strengthen Taiwan's self-defense capabilities?"

-- "Would you agree that our government should engage in negotiation with mainland China on the establishment of a peace and stability framework for cross-strait interaction in order to build consensus and for the welfare of the peoples of both sides?"

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN LEADING LIEN BY 0.9% IN SURVEY: DPP

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian was leading opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan by 0.9 percent in the latest survey carried out by Chen's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), Chen's campaign manager Wu Nei-jen said Tuesday.

Chen, who was lagging behind Lien last April, has caught up with Lien and has taken the lead, according to Wu, who played down the negative impact brought by recent allegations made by a tarnished business tycoon that he donated money to the president in the 2000 presidential campaign.
According to Wu, the survey shows the DPP leads the KMT in terms of cleanliness, which is favorable for the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: KIRIBATI PRESIDENT TO REPAY TAIWAN WITH GOODWILL

TEXT.P: Visiting Kiribati President Anote Tong said Tuesday that his country is not wealthy and cannot afford to return Taiwan's friendship with anything more than goodwill.
Tong said that his country is worried about global warming, which could raise sea levels and submerge much of Kiribati's territory, which is made up mainly of low-lying coral atolls.

However, he said his country is rich in fish stocks and has issued fishing licenses to Taiwan's fishing boats. He expressed hope that foreign countries can create jobs for Kiribati's people by fishing in its territorial waters.
This is Tong's second visit to Taiwan. He last came in 1982. Kiribati forged diplomatic ties with Taiwan last Nov. 7 and Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien paid a visit last month.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATIZATION OF STATE-RUN ENTERPRISES TO CONTINUE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that his administration will continue to promote the privatization of state-run enterprises.

Speaking at a gathering of owners of gas stations affiliated with the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) , Chen said that under a privatization program initiated by his administration more than three years ago, the overall performance of state-run enterprises has been improving, with the loss-making ones becoming profitable and the money-making ones earning even greater profits.
For instance, he noted, China Shipbuilding Corp. recorded profits of NT$520 million (US$15.4 million) for 2003 and NT$300 million for 2002 as opposed to the NT$4.5 billion it lost in 2000.
Tang Eng Iron Works Corp., another state-run company, which registered a deficit of NT$5.6 billion in 2000, earned NT$200 million and NT$1.47 billion in 2002 and 2003, respectively.
"We should not be satisfied with these achievements, " Chen said, adding that the reforms should be continued.

Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu, CPC Chairman Kuo Chin-tsai and Executive Director of the Commission of National Corporations Wu Fong-sheng were also present at the rally, which attracted more than 1,000 gas station owners.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL POLE VAULT INVITATIONAL TOURNAMENT TO BE HELD IN NANTOU

TEXT.P: The 2004 Nantou Cup International Pole Vault Invitational Tournament will be held in Tsao Tun, in the central county of Nantou Feb. 19-20, organizers of the event said Tuesday.

A total of 29 athletes from 11 countries -- the United States, Russia, Canada, Poland, Australia, New Zealand, South Korea, Japan, Thailand, Kazakhstan and Taiwan -- will participate in the annual tournament, the 11th of its kind, the officials noted.
The competition will be divided into men's and women's groups, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIST FORECASTS TAIWAN ECONOMIC GROWTH RATE OF 6 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth rate for 2004 will be between 5 percent and 6 percent, a well-known foreign economist predicted Tuesday in Taipei.
John Calverley, chief economist and strategist for American Express Bank, London, made the forecast while releasing the results of his latest research to the domestic press.

Although Calverley said demand from Taiwan's domestic market will remain sluggish this year, he forecast that Taiwan's economy will still manage a growth rate from 5 percent to 6 percent, mainly as a result of a mildly rebounding U.S. economy.

That increase rate will be much better than the 2003 level of 3.1 percent, thanks to the robust information industry-related sectors, Calverley said. However, he made it clear that enterprises based in Taiwan still have an overwhelming need to restructure.

At the same time, mainland China will achieve a growth rate of 8.4 precent, followed by India with 7 percent, Thailand with 6.8 percent, Singapore with 5.9 percent, Hong Kong with 5 percent, the Philippines with 4.7 percent and Indonesia with 4.6 percent, he predicted, adding that a booming export sector will be the major engine behind the expansion.
Calverley was also optimistic about the stock markets of Asian countries, including Japan.

He predicted that stock markets in the region will continue to pick up, with Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore expected to post the best performance on the grounds that the prices of their shares are at a relatively low level.
With its economy gradually regaining momentum, the United States might move to lift its interest rates in June for the first time following many years mired in recession, he said.
He also said a weaker U.S. dollar will help the current economic upward trend in that country to last longer, while mainland China might allow the renminbi to appreciate this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU STEPS UP AVIAN FLU PREVENTION DRIVE FOR FOREIGN LABORERS

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu city government urged manpower agents and employers Tuesday to step up avian flu prevention publicity for their foreign laborers.
Hsinchu City, which hosts Taiwan's high-tech heartland -- the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park -- has more than 9,200 foreign workers, most of whom come from Southeast Asian nations.

As many Southeast Asian nations, including Thailand and Vietnam, have been gripped by avian flu outbreaks, the Hsinchu city government has stepped up a publicity campaign to advise foreign laborers to refrain from coming into contact with fowl or wild birds during visits home and to monitor their health after they return to Taiwan.
The city government also urged manpower agents and employers to advise their foreign employees to cancel or postpone visits home for the time being because of concern over the avian flu.

Manpower agents should also ask their counterparts in labor exporting countries to intensify pre-departure health checkups and avian flu prevention publicity for foreign citizens intending to work in Taiwan, the city government said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND UNVEILS 2004 MILITARY TRAINING DRILL SCHEDULE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) unveiled a detailed schedule for its military training exercises for 2004 Tuesday, with large-scale live-fire training drills mostly concentrated between April and November.

Wang Kuo-chiang, an MND department chief in charge of military training affairs, said the arrangement was mainly based on the demand of combat units and had nothing to do with the upcoming presidential election or the escalating tension across the Taiwan Strait over Taiwan's referendum plan.

"The exercise schedule has long been crafted in terms of the requirements of strengthening combined services combat capabilities," Wang said, adding that the military training schedule has neither been delayed for the sake of the March 20 presidential election nor increased over Beijing's intimidation against Taiwan's plan to hold a referendum in conjunction with the presidential election.

Wang further said that training drills on the Taiwan-held frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu, both of which lie closer to mainland China than to Taiwan, will proceed as scheduled and will not be affected by President Chen Shui-bian's recent proposal to set up "demilitarized zones" between Taiwan and mainland China in order to ensure permanent cross-strait peace.
Stressing that Chen's "demilitarized zones" initiative remains on the drawing board, Wang said the military's combat training and preparedness will not be affected by the proposal.

Noting that this year's training programs have been designed in line with the principles of maintaining cross-strait stability, preventing war, maintaining electronic warfare supremacy and beefing up combined services combat capabilities, Wang said a total of 42 training drills in four major categories -- live-fire war games, mobilization, nuclear and chemical warfare preparedness and general combat skill training -- will be conducted during the year.
According to Wang, many of the training drills will integrate forces from various military regions, with the chief of the general staff's headquarters commanding all maneuvers.

With the aim of reinforcing the armed forces' ability to attack maritime targets from frontline islands and their air defense capabilities, Wang said the number of combined services training exercises has been raised this year.

Meanwhile, Wang went on, the Hangkuang Exercise -- the largest training drill of the year -- will be conducted in three stages. The first stage, to be held in the second half of April, will focus on tactical training; the second stage, to be held in mid-June, will focus on computerized war games; and the third-stage, to be held from late June through November, will focus on amphibious live-fire war games in waters and air space surrounding Taiwan.
In addition, Wang said, a total of 10 rounds of combined services training drills will be held on the islands of Kinmen, Matsu, Penghu, Tungyin and Wuchiu.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HOPES POLITICAL DONATION BILL WILL PASS LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that he hopes a political donation bill will pass its third reading in the legislature by the end of this month.

Chen, who concurrently serves as chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), made the remarks when he attended a regular DPP Central Standing Committee meeting during which participants discussed the three "sunshine bills" -- a political donation bill, a political party bill, and a lobbying bill -- as well as their progress in the Legislative Yuan and related matters.

The president claimed that the three bills will clean up politics, saying that they will regulate normal development and competition among political parties and curb shady links between political figures and rich business tycoons.
"All political lobbying and maneuvering will be made thoroughly transparent, open and normal under the sunshine bills, " according to Chen.
The president said that for over three years, the DPP government has tried to promote financial, judicial and legislative reforms.
"This has been aimed at achieving eventual political reforms so that Taiwan politics will embrace the sunshine and there will be no place left for corrupt `black gold' politics," Chen said.
The president stressed that the integrity of political figures must come under the most rigorous scrutiny and that political donations must be bound by the law.
He said that he will ask the DPP legislators to promote the "political donation bill" so that it can pass its third reading by the end of this month.
He also expressed hope that the political party bill and the lobbying bill will cleared the legislature by the end of the current session.

Chen noted that he and Vice President Annette Lu, when meeting with representatives of the National Clean Election Promotion Association the previous day, signed promissory notes to ensure a clean election and to make the political donations they receive transparent.
Last week, the president vowed to pull out all the stops to promote the clearing of the political donation bill in the shortest possible time.

He also said that if the bill does not pass the third reading before the March 20 presidential election, he and all DPP members will follow the norms set up by the Cabinet's version of the political donation bill and will accept outside monitoring.

He expressed the desire to lead the way so that it will have a positive effect to the future development of political parties and transparency and positive competition between political parties, so that the public will realize and support the sincerity of the reforms promoted by the DPP.

The sunshine bills were cast into the limelight recently when fugitive business tycoon Chen You-hau, who is on the nation's top 10 most wanted list for embezzlement, accused the DPP of cutting the ground from under his feet by taking his political donations before the 2000 presidential election but indicting him after they won the election.

Chen's revelation took some by surprise, as the DPP has always claimed to have integrity and has tried to distance itself from money politics. Both the opposition Kuomintang and the DPP admitted that they did receive donations from Chen, who fled to mainland China to avoid his creditors after his business went bankrupt.
However, the two parties claim they did nothing wrong because there are no legal precedents for political donations.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUTHORITIES VOW TO MAKE EPZS DIVERSIFIED COMPOUNDS

TEXT.P: The government will endeavor to make the country's economic processing zones better equipped to lure both traditional and hi-tech companies to set up shop in their compounds, a spokesman for the Economic Processing Zone Administration (EPZA) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Tuesday.

In the face of rapid developments, Taiwan's economic processing zones (EPZs) -- once the backbone of the country's economic lifeline -- will be made into a diversified environment to attract various sorts of industries, the spokesman said.

EPZs, which used to accommodate only labor-intensive and manufacturing businesses, will also be able to court hi-tech and capital-intensive groups in the future, shifting from compounds that focus on production, processing and assembly to those that are also attractive to the warehousing, distribution, trade and information technology service-oriented and value-added industries, he said.

In an effort to achieve that aim, the EPZA will set different levels at which the various industries can operate in the EPZs, including a lowered threshold for research and development spending for hi-tech companies, he explained, pointing out that this will help both high-technology and traditional businesses to retain their capital and operations in Taiwan.

The EPZs may also be approved to operate as "free trade port zones" to help domestic businesses based there to go international, with assistance from the EPZA to help them with global marketing, distribution and brand-building.

DOC.HEADLINE: INNSBRUCK MAYOR ARRIVES FOR VISIT

TEXT.P: Hilde Zach, the mayor of the Austrian city of Innsbruck, arrived in Taipei Tuesday for a six-day visit at the invitation of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

During her stay, Zach will meet Chen Chu, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu and other government officials, MOFA officials said.
The main purpose of Zach's visit is to gain a better understanding of Taiwan's development in the political, economic, cultural and tourism fields.
She will also tour Taroko National Park, the National Palace Museum and other economic and cultural establishments prior to her departure on Feb. 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: POULTRY FARMS TO BE FENCED TO PREVENT BIRD FLU

TEXT.P: The government will help domestic poultry farmers to erect five-meter fences around their farms in an attempt to prevent migratory birds which might carry the lethal avian flu virus from mingling with their stocks.

Lee Ching-lung, chairman of the Council of Agriculture, pointed out to the Legislative Yuan that Taiwan straddles a route used by birds migrating from south to north and is therefore vulnerable to any diseases they might carry.
Since almost all of Taiwan's neighboring states have fallen under the grip of the avian flu, the island has gone out of its way to prevent an invasion of the H5N1 virus that causes avian flu.

However, he assured the public that there have been no recorded human cases of the less virulent H5N2 strain of avian flu that has been found in some domestic poultry. This low pathogenic virus exists only in the digestive tracts of poultry and can be easily destroyed through cooking, so it safe for consumers to eat thoroughly-cooked poultry.

Lee denied reports that his council is importing 3 million avian flu vaccines for chickens and ducks, saying that such a move would be a drop in the ocean compared to the hundreds of millions of fowls raised in Taiwan.
