DOC.HEADLINE: MAC EASES RULES TO FACILITATE STAYS BY MAINLAND SPOUSES, FAMILIES

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) has approved a set of draft revisions to the existing rules regarding short-term stays by mainland Chinese spouses and their families, an MAC official said Tuesday.

The set of draft adjustments put forward by the Ministry of the Interior were approved by the MAC during a Monday meeting, Vice Chairman Johnnason Liu said, adding that the changes will provide a more efficient mechanism by which the authorities can better handle immigration, entry and departure by people from mainland China amid growing exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
According to Liu, the major revisions approved by the MAC are as follows:
-- parents of mainland spouses who have already acquired residence permits are permitted to visit Taiwan if their children suffer a serious disease or major injury that threatens their lives here;

-- mainland spouses of foreign nationals who work in Taiwan will be issued with multiple entry visas to facilitate their entry and departure, but will still be required to interviewed by immigration officials;
-- mainland spouses with records of overstaying their visas in Taiwan will not be allowed to re-enter Taiwan for a longer period of time and will face heavier punishments; and

-- crew members from mainland China working aboard foreign ships will be permitted to stay in Taiwan with transit permission -- the same treatment granted to their fellow countrymen employed by aircraft of foreign nationalities.
The MAC is Taiwan's top government agency in charge of policy planning with regard to mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEN DEBATES TO BE HELD ON TWO REFERENDUM QUESTIONS

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission will organize 10 public debates on the two issues to be put to a referendum on March 20, according to a decision made by the commission on Monday.

The debates, five for each of the two issues, will pit the Executive Yuan, which is charged with the implementation of the referendum, against opposition groups in the Legislative Yuan, or civil groups that oppose the ideas of the Executive Yuan. In case there are no such groups, the debates will be changed into a presentation of the opinions of the Executive Yuan.
The Executive Yuan claimed earlier Monday that it will respect whatever decision is made by the election commission on the debate as long as it won't postpone the March 20 vote.

The election commission also backed the Executive Yuan's decision to distribute to voters the ballots for the referendum, with one for each question, along with the ballots for the presidential election on election day. Even if the ballots are dropped into the wrong box, they will be counted as valid.
The two questions to be asked in the referendum are:

-- "The people of Taiwan demand that the Taiwan Strait issue be resolved through peaceful means. Should mainland China refuse to withdraw the missiles it has targeted at Taiwan and openly renounce the use of force against us, would you agree that the government should acquire more advanced anti-missile weapons to strengthen Taiwan's self-defense capabilities?"

-- "Would you agree that our government should engage in negotiation with mainland China on the establishment of a peace and stability framework for cross-strait interactions in order to build consensus and for the welfare of the peoples of both sides?"

DOC.HEADLINE: EXTRA POLICE TO BE DEPLOYED WHEN TAIWANESE-BRAZILIAN BOY LEAVES TAIWAN

TEXT.P: More police will be deployed to Kaohsiung's international airport when a Taiwanese-Brazilian boy at the center of an international custody battle embarks on his long journey back to his legal guardian in Brazil Wednesday, Kaohsiung aviation police said.

Nine-year-old Iruan Wu Ergui will be accompanied by Brazil's representative to Taiwan Paulo A. Pereira Pinto, who has been appointed by the boy's grandmother, Rosa Leocadia da Silva Ergui, to bring the boy home. They will board a China Airlines flight Wednesday afternoon from Kaohsiung to Hong Kong.

Police said that they are expecting a lot of media reporters as well as the boy's Taiwan family members and friends to show up at the airport to see the boy off, so that they are deploying more police force to maintain order.

The boy and the Brazilian representative will take the 12:50 p.m. China Airlines to fly to Hong Kong first, and transfer to a South African Airlines flight to Johannesburg. They will then take a Brazilian Airlines flight to San Paulo Friday morning Taiwan time, and then take a domestic flight to the boy's grandmother's home at Porto Alegre, Rio Grande do Sul.
China Airlines officials said that they have not received any instructions from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs or requests from the Brazilian side regarding giving the boy any special treatment.
The officials said that the China Airlines flight is a regular one, and there will be more than 200 passengers on board Wednesday, most of whom are Taiwanese businessmen operating on mainland China.

Kaohsiung District Court had asked Wu Huo-yen, the uncle of Iruan Wu Ergui, who is known in Taiwan by his Chinese name of Wu Yi-hua, to turn over the boy Monday. But as the uncle refused to cooperate, police were mobilized in the afternoon to carry out the task. In the ensuing clashes between police and Wu's family members and friends, the boy became intermittently distraught and confused.
Only after long hours of negotiation did the boy's uncle finally sign the document turning over the child to the Brazilian representative, ending the boy's nearly three years of living in Taiwan.
Iruan Wu Ergui was born out of wedlock to a Brazilian mother and a Taiwanese father, Wu Teng-shu, in 1995 in Brazil.
The mother died in 1998 and the child's grandmother was named as the boy's guardian with Wu Teng-shu's approval.
Wu took the boy back to his hometown of Chieting in Kaohsiung County on March 15, 2001, for a short visit, but he died unexpectedly March 29.
The boy's uncle then decided to take the boy and refused to let him go, saying that his older brother had asked him to take care of the boy, who is now a second-grader of Chieting Elementary School.
Meanwhile, the boy's grandmother filed a lawsuit for the custody of the boy, and Taiwan's supreme court ruled late last year to return the boy to his rightful guardian.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAIDEN FLIGHTS FROM INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT IN TAICHUNG SLATED FOR MARCH

TEXT.P: Maiden charter flights from Taiwan's third international airport in Taichung are slated for early next month, according to a spokesman for the Taichung Chamber of Commerce.

Chiang Shao-chi, secretary-general of the Taichung Chamber of Commerce, which is in charge of arranging the charter flights, said that China Airlines and Far East Air Transport Corp. have organized three charter flights to Tokyo, Puget Island and Palau on March 5 from the airport located in Chingchuankang, which was formerly an air force base.

According to Chiang, public response to the special tourist charter flights has been warm, as the number of applicants wishing to travel on board the charter planes has exceeded the 360 seats of their capacities. Would-be travelers will be decided by a draw in the middle of this month, he added.

The keen response is an indication that the airport will be highly welcomed by residents living in central Taiwan, as it will help them save time by sparing a trip to northern Chiang Kai-shek International Airport near Taipei or southern Kaohsiung Hsiaokang Airport for outbound travel, he noted.

The airport, which remains under its first phase of construction for the time being, will only handle outbound charter flights in the initial stag. The second phase of its expansion is slated to be completed for 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT URGES PEOPLE TO SUPPORT PLANNED REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: Support for the proposed referendum by the people of Taiwan is key in helping address the issue of cross-strait relations in a peaceful manner, Vice President Annette Lu said on Tuesday.
The vice president made the comments while attending an activity in Taoyuan honoring Lu's ancestors.
The ruling Democratic Progress Party (DPP) government has decided to hold a referendum on the day of the presidential election set for March 20.

Pointing out that mainland China's missiles aimed at Taiwan will increase from the current nearly 500 to 650 by 2005, Lu called for the public to pay more attention to the issue by urging them to support the March 20 referendum called by President Chen Shui-bian.

Chen announced Jan. 16 in a pre-taped TV broadcast to the nation that he would ask the people to decide in the forthcoming referendum whether Taiwan should further strengthen its missile defense capabilities and whether it should try to work out a mechanism of peaceful interaction with mainland China.

For Beijing to understand the feeling of the people of Taiwan and their concern for future generations, all the people in Taiwan should support the referendum, the vice president said, adding that Beijing might consider that the people of Taiwan do not support their nation if the referendum fails, and such a failure would endanger Taiwan's security and interests.
Lu also said a peaceful cross-strait relationship can only be achieved with a second term for herself and the president, as well as the support of the people for the referendum.
Meanwhile, Lu warned that Taiwan business people in mainland China should be vigilant and not to fall into traps set by Beijing to attract them to do business there.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRILLS ON FRONTLINE ISLANDS WILL BE HELD AS USUAL: DEFENSE MINISTRY

TEXT.P: Routine military exercises and drills on the frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu this year will be held as scheduled, Ministry of National Defense spokesman said Tuesday.

Maj. Gen. Huang Shey-sheng said at a news conference that the idea of establishing "demilitarized zones" across the Taiwan Strait as recently advocated by President Chen Shui-bian is "only an idea" that needs detailed planning and support before being put into practice.
Noting that such demilitarized zones do not yet exist, Huang said scheduled war games on Kinmen and Matsu will not be affected by the president's idea and will be held as scheduled.

In his first news conference with members of the media from home and abroad this year held Feb. 3, President Chen said that to avoid military conflicts, demilitarized zones should be established across the Taiwan Strait, including the removal of combat personnel, equipment and deployed missiles, to create a "buffer zone in terms of time and space."

President Chen also called for the signing of a cross Taiwan Strait "peaceful interaction" accord and appealed for a prohibition on the use of military and economic blockades. He also advocated having representatives from both sides stationed in each other's capital cities to facilitate negotiations.

Seconding Huang's remarks, Maj. Gen. Wang Kuo-chiang, a defense ministry official in charge of combat training affairs, said that there must be training drills so long as the nation maintains a military and such exercises scheduled to be held on outlying islands should not be scrapped.
The defense ministry called a news conference Tuesday to make known the timetable for this year's military exercises.

Wang said that the training drills are scheduled to be held between April and November this year and denied allegations that the exercises have been increased in number and delayed due to exacerbated tensions across the Taiwan Strait and the March 20 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. NOT OPPOSED TO REFERENDUM: DPP LEGISLATOR

TEXT.P: The United States is not opposed to Taiwan's planned referendum on March 20, although it will continue to observe what Taiwan does after the nationwide vote, a legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Tuesday upon returning from a trip to the United States.

Legislator Parris Chang held a press conference on the results of his U.S. mission, undertaken with members of the Legislature's Foreign Affairs Committee, to better understand the sentiments of U.S. officials regarding the upcoming referendum in Taiwan.

Chang said that recent remarks by Republic of China representative to the U.S. Chen Chien-jen to the Legislative Yuan had been misreported by Taiwan media. Reports had said that Chen had said that relations with the United States were in unprecedentedly bad shape, when in fact what he only said that relations were "unprecedented." Chang said that no U.S. officials he spoke with felt that relations were in bad shape.

'The U.S. did have some questions about Taiwan's referendum at first, although the overall relationship is good," Chang said. "After weeks of bilateral communications and the announcement of the questions to be on the referendum, the U.S. response has been very positive," he added.
The U.S. feels that the referendum is an internal affair for Taiwan, Chang said.
Chang said that the United States is concerned about the referendum mainly because it will surely have to intervene if mainland China uses forces against Taiwan.
He also criticized the "pan-blue alliance" for claiming that the United States will punish Taiwan for holding the referendum, asking why the United States would oppose the referendum.
He said that the U.S. is concerned about Taiwan's referendum, but believes that it is a democratic country and will decide by itself what to do.
"The U.S. will continue to observe Taiwan, listen to what it says and observe its deeds and will not oppose the referendum, " Chang said.

He said that what the United States cares about is not the two questions on the referendum, but what President Chen will do after winning re-election, including whether his inaugural speech will continue to mention the "four noes plus one" -- which include no referendum regarding the nation's future status as to whether to declare independence or unification with mainland China -- and the writing of a new constitution.
After President Chen wins re-election, he will continue to communicate with the United States, Chang said.

Meanwhile, other legislators, including John Chang and Sun Kuo-hua of the Kuomintang, who went with Chang to call on U.S. State Department officials, congressmen and scholars in the United States, said that the United States still is seriously concerned about Taiwan's planned referendum, and has not accepted or endorsed the referendum.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SUSPENDS SECOND-PHASE WATER RESTRICTIONS

TEXT.P: Thanks to abundant rainfall over the weekend, the Taipei City Government suspended imposing second-phase water restrictions in the greater Taipei area Tuesday.
A city government spokesman said the second-phase water restrictions in areas that rely on the Taipei Water Department for water would be suspended immediately.

"The decision was made on the fact that the water level at the Feitsui Reservoir has rebounded to 160 meters, " the spokesman said, adding that water supply for household consumption will not be a problem until May when northern Taiwan will enter its "plum rains" monsoon season.

The second-phase water restrictions have been in place in five northern Taiwan cities and counties since Feb. 6, mainly targeting large-volume water consumers, such as car washes, saunas, spas, swimming pools and manufacturing firms. The measures include cutting water supply to these users by 5 percent to 20 percent.

The suspension of second-phase water restrictions will be valid for Taipei City and most parts of Taipei County, while the restrictions will remain in place in Taoyuan County, Hsinchu City and Hsinchu County as reservoirs in the three districts didn't receive as much rainfall as the Feitsui Reservoir over the past week.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN DECORATES PARAGUAYAN VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian decorated Paraguayan Vice President Luis Alberto Castiglioni Tuesday with one of the nation's highest commendations in recognition of Castiglioni's contribution toward cementing bilateral ties between the Republic of China and Paraguay.

In a ceremony held at the Presidential Office, Chen conferred the Order of Propitious Cloud with Grand Cordon on Castiglioni in recognition of the Paraguayan vice president's efforts that have helped accelerate friendly and reciprocal exchanges between the two countries.

On hand to witness the event were Vice President Annette Lu, as well as Castiglioni's wife, Paraguayan Finance Minister Dinoisio Borda, Paraguayan Ambassador to the ROC Ramon Antero Diaz Pereira and ROC Foreign Affairs Minister Eugene Chien.
During the ceremony, Chen offered his congratulations again to Paraguayan President Oscar Nicanor Duarte and Castiglioni for winning the 2003 presidential election.
Chen also asked Castiglioni to relay his appreciation to President Duarte for boldly speaking out in support of the Republic of China in the U.N. Assembly.

For his part, Catiglioni said that since President Duarte took office, he has mapped out useful and resourceful policies on domestic affairs as well as foreign relations, including continued support for Taiwan in its bid to join the United Nations and other international organizations.
On behalf of the Paraguayan government and people, Castiglioni expressed his support for Taiwan's holding of a referendum next month on the issue of Beijing's deployment of missiles aimed at Taiwan.

"Referendums -- which are a basic right of the people and in line with democratic values -- should by no means be restricted because of external suppression or military intimidation," Castiglioni said.

Castiglioni also expressed his gratitude to the ROC government for its assistance to Paraguay in many areas, as well as his admiration for Taiwan for its accelerated democratization and economic prosperity.

The Paraguayan vice president, at the head of a 10-member entourage, arrived in Taipei Monday for a six-day official visit. During the visit, Castiglioni and his party will meet with officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Government Information Office and the Central Election Commission. He will also tour a high-technology industrial park in northern Taiwan and the Taroko Gorge National Park in eastern Taiwan.

The ROC government has donated funds to help Paraguay, the ROC's only diplomatic ally in South America, to build a new barracks for its national cavalry police corps and to upgrade its crime-fighting equipment and facilities.
Both Paraguayan President Duarte and Vice President Castiglioni attended a ceremony last Thursday marking the inauguration of the new police barracks located in the Paraguayan capital of Asuncion.

In addition to financially supporting the construction of the new cavalry police barracks, the ROC government has also earmarked funds to help Paraguay purchase police vehicles and bulletproof vests and to establish a police patrol network.
Moreover, the ROC has donated funds for the Paraguayan cavalry police corps to purchase 100 horses and other equipment to improve its crime-fighting capabilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Feb. 10, or the 20th day of the first month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1763: The Treaty of Paris is signed, ending seven years of war and heralding Britain's emergence as the leading world power. Britain gained both Canada and Florida and established dominance in the East.
1840: Queen Victoria of Britain and Ireland and empress of India, whose sense of duty and strict moral code had great influence on 19th-century British society, marries her first cousin, Prince Albert.
1846: British forces defeat Sikhs at Sobranhan, India.
1890: Boris Pasternak, the Russian author famed for his prize-winning novel "Doctor Zhivago," is born.
1894: Harold Macmillan, British statesman and Conservative prime minister, is born.
1904: The Russo-Japanese war breaks out after Japan formally declares war on Russia.
1923: William Rontgen, the German physicist who discovered X-rays and developed X-ray photography, thereby revolutionizing medical diagnosis, dies in Munich at the age of 77.
1939: Haikuo falls after Japanese troops land on Hainan Island in southern China.
1946: In the first Jakarta (Batavia) meeting between the two sides, the Netherlands government bows to the inevitable and agrees to let Indonesia become independent, on the condition that Indonesia forms a confederation of states.
1955: Thousands of armed South African police begin evicting 60,000 black people from their homes in Sophiatown near Johannesburg, with bulldozers flattening the township in their wake.
1955: All 14,483 residents of the Republic of China-held Tachen Islands near mainland China's Chekiang Province are evacuated to Taiwan.
1962: In an historic exchange, captured U.S. spy-plane pilot Gary Powers starts walking to freedom from the communist side of a Berlin bridge, while the highest-ranking Russian spy ever caught, KGB Colonel Rudolf Abel, sets off from the American side.
1964: The government of the ROC recalls its envoy from France and announces the severance of diplomatic relations with the European country.
1964: More than 80 people die as HMAS Voyager, a destroyer of the Royal Australian Navy, sinks after a collision with HMAS Melbourne.
1974: An all-star women's basketball team leaves Taipei for a tour of the United States.
1976: Work begins on an elevated road across the North Gate area of Taipei, in a move designed to relieve traffic congestion.
1980: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces severance of diplomatic relations with Colombia.
1981: King Juan Carlos names Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo as prime minister of Spain.
1981: The 32 new ROC Control Yuan members are sworn in.
1982: President Chiang Ching-kuo sends a congratulatory message to President-elect Luis Alberto Monge Alvarez of the Republic of Costa Rica.
1985: The ROC Ministry of Finance orders the 10th Credit Cooperative of Taipei to stop transactions for three days for violating operating regulations.
1996: On the Japanese island of Hokkaido, a landslide crushes a highway tunnel, killing 20 people.
1998: Former French Foreign Minister Maurice Schumann dies. He is considered a founding father of the European Union.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui and Marshall Islands President Imata Kabua sign a joint communique reaffirming their commitment to further expanding bilateral cooperation.
2001: Fan Liqing and Zhen Binhua, the first two mainland Chinese reporters allowed to be stationed in Taiwan, cover their first story, with themselves being the center of attention among the local press.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Is moral life something remote or difficult? If a man only wishes to live a moral life -- there and then his life becomes moral."

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF FALSE ALARMS DOWN IN SINGAPORE, BUT SCDF STILL CONCERNED

TEXT.P: The Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) emergency ambulance service responded to some 79,000 calls in 2003, or a 5-percent increase over the year-earlier level, according to SCDF figures released Tuesday.
SCDF Commissioner James Tan said while releasing the figures that although the number of false alarms fell 15 percent, the issue still remains a cause for concern for the SCDF.
The number of emergency calls increased by some 8 percent over the previous year's figure, while the number of non-emergency calls was down by 28 percent.
The SCDF responded to some 4,500 calls in 2003, or a drop of about 8 percent over the year-earlier figure. It was also the lowest figure in 15 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PLAYS DOWN CONCERNS ABOUT RIOTS OVER REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: No riots surrounding the March 20 referendum will take place unless someone incites them for their own political reasons, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said in Hsinchu City, northern Taiwan Wednesday.

In an attempt to allay public concerns about the referendum called by President Chen Shui-bian, Yu said Taiwan people are used to elections after having taken part in many of them over the last five decades. It is impossible that the referendum, which would be the first national one, might result in riots unless some people instigate them deliberately.

He made the remarks in response to critics' claims that the Referendum, which is to take place along with the presidential election on March 20, has not been properly prepared and might lead to chaos, even riots.
In a Cabinet meeting earlier in the day, the premier warned opposition parties that have questioned the legal basis for the referendum not to try to disrupt the referendum by obstructing it.

The premier said at the Cabinet meeting in Taipei that the country has successfully carried out multiple elections at the same time before, the last time in 1989 when residents went to the polls to elect lawmakers, deputies to the Taiwan Provincial Council and to their own county councils.
In those elections, ballots for difference elections were given to voters at the same time, and the results were tallied before midnight after the election stations were closed, said the premier.
If multiple elections could be held before, there is no reason why the upcoming referendum can't be held simultaneously with the presidential election, the premier said.
The spokesman for the Executive Yuan, Lin Chia-lung, also dismissed the possibility of rioting as "sensational claims" concocted with the aim to scare the people.
He reiterated his claim Tuesday that the results of the presidential election as well as the referendum will be known before 9:30 p.m. on March 20.
Meanwhile, a Kuomintang whip at the Legislative Yuan, Liao Feng-teh, said Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers will make a motion to urge the Executive Yuan to consider ballots cast in the wrong boxes invalid.

Liao said it will save time in counting the votes in the presidential election and avoid the results of the presidential election having to be reversed by ballots found in boxes not intended for them, which might cast into doubt the results of the election.

He blamed the Executive Yuan and the DPP for disregarding the warnings of the KMT as absurd that riots might be prompted by the ill-thought out voting procedures and by suggesting that the KMT has a political axe to grind in raising the alarm.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARAGUAYAN VICE PRESIDENT VISITS TZU CHI FOUNDATION

TEXT.P: Visiting Paraguayan Vice President Luis Alberto Castiglioni visited the headquarters of the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation in Hualien, eastern Taiwan Wednesday, and lauded the charity organization for its contributions to the world.

In a meeting with Master Cheng Yen, founder of the Tzu Chi Foundation, Castiglioni said that he has been deeply impressed by the charity and relief activities conducted by Tzu Chi followers around the world and admires the spirit they have demonstrated in carrying out their four main missions -- charity, medicine, culture and education by crossing national, racial and religious boundaries.
At the invitation by Master Cheng Yen, Castiglioni promised that he will make contacts with Tzu Chi followers in Paraguay and help them carry out their missions after returning home.

In addition to conducting regular charity activities and emergency relief, the Tzu Chi Foundation's Paraguay Chapter has built five elementary schools for aboriginal people in remote areas of the South American nation, donated medical equipment and materials to Asuncion University Hospital and other clinics to improve their health care capabilities since it was established in 1996.
At the head of a 10-member entourage, Castiglioni arrived in Taipei Monday for a six-day official visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS NO PLANS TO HALT POULTRY IMPORTS FROM U. S.: COA

TEXT.P: Taiwan has no plans to stop poultry imports from the United States and it is holding talks with 14 countries and areas in the hope of seeking their permission to allow in Taiwan poultry again, Council of Agriculture (COA) Vice Chairman Hu Fu-hsiung said Wednesday.

The COA has no plans to ban U.S. poultry imports at present because the H7 bird flu virus discovered in that country is less virulent, similar to the H5N2 virus found in Taiwan which causes no danger to human lives, Hu said.
Hu, however, pointed out that 14 countries and areas have banned poultry shipments from Taiwan, despite the fact that the island remains free from the virulent H5N1 virus bird flu.

Hu added that COA officials have launched negotiations with those countries and areas in an effort to persuade them to re-open their markets for Taiwan's poultry products on the grounds that Taiwan chicken raisers have received many orders from Hong Kong buyers and other countries at a time when their countries are troubled by the virulent H5N1 avian flu.

According to the COA vice chairman, the 14 countries and areas are Japan, Hong Kong, Russia, Singapore, South Korea, Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia, Switzerland, Brazil, Paraguay, the Czech Republic, Poland and Iran.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Moscow, Feb. 11 [CNA] The Moscow Times: Girl, 9, Stabbed to Death in St. Pete.
A group of teenagers in St. Petersburg stabbed a 9-year-old Tajik girl to death and beat her father and 11-year-old cousin in a brutal attack that prompted calls Tuesday for tougher action against racially motivated crime.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOME 100 CASES OF ABUSE OF ELDERLY REPORTED IN SINGAPORE EACH YEAR

TEXT.P: About 100 cases of abuse of the elderly are reported to the Ministry of Community Development and Sports in Singapore every year.

Speaking at a conference on preventing abuse of the elderly Tuesday, Minister of State for Community Development and Sports Chan Soo Sen pointed out that the government thinks the actual figure may be higher as many cases are probably not reported.
He said abuse of the elderly is a sensitive issue that not many people want to talk about, adding that many people perceive it as an internal family matter.
Many cases only come to light when social service workers conduct unrelated checks, such as those concerning financial assistance for the elderly, he noted.
Most victims are over 80-years-old, and their abusers are often relatives or caregivers.
Sen urged parents to set a good example for their children by treating their elders well, as "nothing escapes their watchful eyes".

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT COOPERATION ON DISEASE PREVENTION IS POSSIBLE: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Cross-Taiwan Strait cooperation on disease prevention can be done through international exchanges in the region, an official of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said Wednesday.

COA Vice Chairman Hu Fu-hsiung made the remarks in response to an appeal made by a mainland Chinese official for concerted efforts from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to contain the spread of avian flu that has affected 10 countries and areas in Asia.

Zhang Mingqing, spokesman for Beijing's Taiwan Affairs Office, said at a regular news conference that at a time when virulent bird flu has been found in both Taiwan and the mainland, the two sides should step up cooperation to stop the spread of the disease.

International cooperation is very important to disease prevention and control, particularly in containing the spread of the virulent H5N1 strain of bird flu virus which has affected many Asian nations, including the mainland, Hu said.
Taiwan should not feel free from the threat of the virus even though only the non-lethal strain -- H5N2 -- has been found in Taiwan, he noted.

The government has been trying to prevent the H5N1 strain from spreading to Taiwan by increasing surveillance and cracking down on smuggling from the mainland, in addition to other quarantine measures, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONGERS BECOMING DISSATISFIED WITH BEIJING RULE: MAC REPORT

TEXT.P: Beijing's strong interference in Hong Kong's political affairs has created resentment among Hong Kong people against its rule, a report issued Wednesday by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) showed.

Citing the results of public opinion surveys conducted by two universities based in Hong Kong, the MAC said in the report that Beijing's hard-line position toward the political system and development in the former British colony has provoked dissatisfaction among Hong Kong residents. A small number of local people do, however, express satisfaction with Beijing's policy in Hong Kong, it added.

According to the MAC, the core issue is Beijing's tough stance with regard to Hong Kong people's desire for a direct vote to elect a chief executive and members of the Legislative Council of the special administrative region starting from 2007.

In the face of increased public calls for greater political reform and an enhanced democratic progress, incumbent Chief Executive Tung Chee Hwa has replied that the Hong Kong government will first set up a special panel to consult Beijing before making a move so as to gain an understanding of Hong Kong people's views.

At the same time, Beijing's high-profile response and moves aimed at underscoring its sovereignty over the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR) , such as turning a blind eye to grave international concerns over Hong Kong's political development, have pushed many Hong Kong people to air their discontentment.
Results of the two recent surveys have demonstrated that the number of Hong Kong people satisfied with Beijing's policy has dropped, the MAC said.

The MAC pointed out that this is an important development worth more attention from the Taiwan authorities and the international community, as it indicates that Beijing's strong meddling in Hong Kong political affairs will have a negative impact on interactions between the HKSAR and Beijing.
The MAC is Taiwan's top government agency in charge of policy-planning toward mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINES

TEXT.P: New York Times: Kerry sweeps to 2 victories as Clark drops out of race.

Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts had victories in the Tennessee and Virginia primaries on Tuesday, solidifying his position as the perhaps unstoppable front-runner for the Democratic nomination and dealing a serious blow to his two Southern rivals.
Senator John Edwards of North Carolina and Gen. Wesley K. Clark finished far behind. General Clark abandoned the race for the nomination.
Wall Street Journal: Kerry easily beats foes in the South.

Massachusetts Sen. John Kerry handily won Democratic primaries in Tennessee and Virginia, beating two Southern rivals and rebutting critics' claims that the New Englander can't draw votes in a region that hasn't been hospitable to his party in recent years.
Kerry has now won 12 of the 14 contests held so far, scoring big wins in every region of the country and making his lead over the narrowing field all the more prohibitive.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF EMPLOYEES IN ECONOMIC PROCESSING ZONES UP IN JANUARY

TEXT.P: With the gradual economic rebound, the number of employees at Taiwan's various economic processing zones reached 67,480 in January, the Economic Processing Zone Administration (EPZA) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Wednesday.
The number represented an increase of 3,902 from the same month last year, EPZA officials said.
The officials said that Nantzu Economic Processing Zone in Kaohsiung recorded the largest contingent of employee at 37,640.

They said that manufacturers that are adding employees are mostly in the high-tech industry, especially the high-precision instrument industry. That sector's employee numbers rose by 520 compared with the same month last year.
The electronic and electrical engineering industries in the economic processing zones employ the largest number of people, more than 50,800, the administration added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO STEP UP MOVES TO COMBAT AVIAN FLU: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun instructed relevant government agencies Wednesday to step up preventive measures to avert an invasion of the virulent H5N1 strain of avian flu into Taiwan from neighboring countries.

To achieve this aim, culls must be fully carried out at all affected poultry farms and all preventive measures, such as vaccinations, surveillance and care, must be further enhanced to keep Taiwan free from the H5N1 virus, Yu said.

The premier gave the instruction at a weekly Cabinet meeting in which officials from the Council of Agriculture (COA) and the Department of Health (DOH) reported on their mission to combat the spread of bird flu caused by the less virulent H5N2 virus strain among domestic poultry farms.

According to COA officials, the H5N2 virus has been found on poultry farms in southern Tainan and Chiayi counties and in central Changhua, Nantou and Yunlin counties, as well as in northern Miaoli and Taoyuan counties.

All chickens and ducks on these poultry farms were culled and those farms must undergo a four-month disinfection program and be subject to testing to ensure that they are totally safe before they will be given permission to resume operations, the COA officials reported, adding that they have also strengthened monitoring, checkups and quarantine control in cooperation with immigration and customs authorities.
According to DOH officials, exchanges of bird flu virus data with the various agricultural authorities have already been started and inoculations have begun on local poultry farms.

About 10 countries and areas in Asia have reported H5N1 bird flu cases, including Japan, South Korea, Vietnam, Thailand, Indonesia, mainland China and Hong Kong. The H5N2 virus found in Taiwan causes no immediate risk to human lives, as long as poultry and eggs are well cooked.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AMBASSADOR TO HOLY SEE HOSTS RECEPTION
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Feb. 10 (CNA) (By Tony Fang & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Ambassador to the Holy See Tou Chou-seng hosted a reception in Rome Tuesday to celebrate his assumption of his new post at the Holy See.
The reception brought together senior officials of the Holy See and ambassadors posted to the Vatican, all of whom welcomed Tou.
Tou is the ROC's 12th ambassador to the Vatican. He arrived in Rome Jan. 19 and presented his credentials Jan. 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRA TO LAUNCH HIGH-QUALITY SKIN-CARE PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) is trying to diversify into yet another field to help boost its revenues, this time launching a range of skin-care products on the eve of Feb. 14 -- Valentine's Day.

The TRA, which re-launched its popular lunch boxes for passengers nostalgic for the old days of rail travel to great success and has also marketed wine laced with gold powder, is scheduled to present its high-quality skin-care products using state-of-the-art nanotechnology, according to TRA officials.
TRA officials said that from Feb. 12-14, it will sell its new products at Taipei, Taichung and Kaohsiung stations.
The six-item skin-care set will sell for NT$8,800 (US$265.86) and will have a limited circulation of only 500 sets.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE-BRAZILIAN BOY GOES HOME AT LAST

TEXT.P: Blessed by many well wishers, a Taiwanese-Brazilian boy at the center of a bitter three-year international custody battle left Taiwan Wednesday for the long journey home to his legal guardian -- his grandmother in Brazil.

Wu Huo-yen, the uncle of nine-year-old Iruan Wu Ergui -- who is better known in Taiwan by his Chinese name Wu Yi-hua -- as well as members of Wu's family, went to Kaohsiung's Hsiaokang International Airport to bid the boy farewell after keeping him in Taiwan for nearly three years.
Despite extra aviation police deployed to maintain order, the Wu family and friends, as well as a multitude of reporters, caused chaos and pandemonium at the departure scene.

Wu, who had kept Iruan at his home in Kaohsiung County's Chieting township since Iruan's father -- Wu's older brother -- died unexpectedly in March 2001, could not hide his sadness and sense of loss when he gave his sincere blessing to the boy.

Wu, who had refused to return the boy until the last moment, said tearfully earlier that he felt sorry for the child as well as his deceased brother, to whom he claimed to have promised on his deathbed that he would take care of the boy.

China Airlines (CAL) officials presented a model of one of their planes to the boy to bid him godspeed at the boarding gate, but when Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials tried to present a digital camera to the boy so that he could e-mail pictures back to Taiwan, the Wus refused to allow Iruan to have it, to show their displeasure at the MOFA for not being allowed to keep the boy.

Iruan took a 12: 50 p.m. CAL flight to Hong Kong, where he transferred to a South African Airlines flight to Johannesburg before taking a Brazilian airline flight to Sao Paulo Friday morning Taipei time. He will then take a Brazilian domestic flight to his grandmother's home at Porto Alegre, Rio Grande do Sul.

Iruan left accompanied by his aunt, a lawyer, Brazil's representative to Taiwan Paulo A. Pereira Pinto, an assistant to Legislator Lin Yi-shih of the opposition Kuomintang, a Brazilian Taiwanese, and an official of the Taiwan Catholic Mission Foundation.

Liao Hsiu-shan, acting executive director of the Taiwan Catholic Mission Foundation, said that the journey to Brazil will take about 44 hours, and that the foundation will sponsor all the travel expenses of the people accompanying Iruan.

The MOFA will assist at all transit stops along the way, Liao said, adding that he hopes this will help mend fences over the bitter custody battle between the boy's grandmother and uncle, as well as promoting the friendship between the two countries.
Pereira, on behalf of the Brazilian government, thanked the Taiwan District Court for its efforts in implementing the boy's return and said there are no complaints about the procedure.

Wu was ordered by the Kaohsiung District Court to turn over the boy Monday, but as he refused to cooperate, the court sent extra police to carry out the task. Pictures of a distraught and crying Iruan, jammed between policemen, reporters and Wu's family members to obstruct the officials, touched hearts and sparked anger in Taiwan when broadcast live on television.
Wu said that the MOFA has promised that it will help the boy to return to Taiwan.

The boy's aunt and a lawyer will discuss with Iruan's grandmother, Rosa Leocadia da Silva Ergui, Iruan's future communications with Taiwan, as well as the possibility of his visiting the Wus, according to Wu.
Iruan was born out of wedlock to a Brazilian mother and a Taiwanese father, Wu Teng-shu, in 1995 in Brazil.
The mother died in 1998 and the child's grandmother was named as the boy's guardian with Wu Teng-shu's approval.
Wu took the boy back for a short visit to his hometown of Chieting on March 15, 2001, but he died unexpectedly March 29.
The boy's uncle then decided to take the boy and refused to let him go. Iruan went to the Chieting Primary School, where he reached second grade.
The boy's grandmother filed a lawsuit to regain custody of the boy, and Taiwan's supreme court ruled late last year that Iruan should return to his rightful guardian.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA OPENS SPECIAL ON-LINE REPORTING ON PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: In order to provide instant information about the 2004 presidential election, the CNA opened a section on its Website devoted exclusively to election affairs Wednesday, called "Express."
"Express" will include political analyses, reporting on elections, election-related news, news pictures and file photos of previous presidential elections.
Through "Express, " CNA will also cooperate with the Public Television Service to broadcast the debates between the presidential candidates on Feb. 14 and Feb. 21.
On election day, "Express" will report on the election results from the Central Election Commission, the campaign headquarters of the Democratic Progressive Party and of the Kuomintang.
Internet surfers can select video or audio news on the presidential election through the video-on-demand service provided by CNA on its Website.
The URL of "Express" is http://www.cna.com.tw/2004president/.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS URGE TAIWAN BUSINESSES NOT TO SPECULATE ON RENMINBI

TEXT.P: Despite widespread market speculation that mainland China's currency is set to appreciate soon in the face of an increasingly weaker U.S. dollar, Taiwan businesses should be wary over the possible impact of this rather than speculate on the renminbi, local scholars warned Wednesday.

Kao Chang, a professor at National Dong Hwa University, called on Taiwan-based companies to refrain from speculating on the value of the renminbi because the possibility of its appreciation remains unclear in the short term.

Pointing out that the mainland currency has come under strong market pressure to gain in value mainly due to a continued depreciating greenback, Kao said it is hard to forecast at present whether or not it actually will appreciate in the near future.
The situation will become clearer in March or April, when the mainland's central bank reassesses the renminbi's value at its regular quarterly meeting, according to Kao.

The only thing which seems clear for the time being is that the renminbi will appreciate gradually in order to avoid a negative impact on the mainland's economy, he added, pointing out that on the other hand, businesses based in Taiwan should also pay greater heed to the possible benefits or disadvantages brought about by an appreciating renminbi.

On the plus side, he went on, a stronger renminbi will promote greater capital flight from the mainland, leading to more and more economic, financial, investment and tourism exchanges with Taiwan, Kao said.

Although this might not benefit mainland-headquartered Taiwan companies dedicated to the export business, he explained that they will be in turn compensated if their production materials are imported from other countries.

On the negative side, the new Taiwan dollar will also face mounting pressure to appreciate if renminbi gains in value, he added. He warned Taiwan businesses not to hold excessive amounts of renminbi for profiteering, as the mainland still heavily restricts exchanges of foreign currencies and deals harshly with black market dealing and speculation.

Sun Ming-teh, an assistant researcher at the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research cited mainland officials as saying that the question of the renminbi's appreciation will depend on the mainland's economic situation.

Under the present circumstances, there is little reason to believe that the renminbi will appreciate in the near term, as the mainland's exports are expected to slow this year compared to its performance last year, Sun explained.
Should the mainland bow to pressure from the United States to allow its currency to go up in value, this will also create an impact on other Asian countries, including Taiwan, he claimed.

Despite the fact that industrial levels in Taiwan and mainland China remain imbalanced, it is very likely that Taiwan industries will also be adversely affected by an appreciating renminbi before they realize any benefits, he forecast.

DOC.HEADLINE: NORTHERN THAI RESIDENTS GIVE UP OPIUM PRODUCTION FOR TAIWAN TEA
DOC.DATELINE: Chiang Rai, northern Thailand, Feb. 11 (CNA) (By Francis Kuo & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Some residents in northern Thailand areas bordering Burma have sought a "second spring" in business by shifting from cultivating opium poppies to growing Taiwan tea.

The Golden Triangle, notorious as a stronghold of opium production, is now also covered by labyrinth of tea plantations that represent a new cash cow for the northern Thai residents, many of whom are of Han Chinese descent.
The locals are at present celebrating their tea harvest during the World Tea Festival of Feb. 6-15 in Chiang Rai, which is sponsored by Thailand's Ministry of Agricultural Cooperation.

Native groups from neighboring mainland China, Laos and Burma, as well as Thailand, have put their tea harvests and products up for display and sale, backed by performances of folk dances and singing each night of the festival.

Addressing the opening of the World Tea Festival, Minister of Agricultural Cooperation Somsak Thepsutin said that there are approximately 38,400 acres of tea plantations around Thailand. Of this total, about half, or 18,000 acres, are centered around Chiang Rai Province.

Of all the tea production in Chiang Rai, the best species and production are oolong tea originating from Taiwan, Somsak said, adding that the quality and flavor of Chiang Rai oolong is about to catch up with that produced in Taiwan.
Currently, five villages in Chiang Rai are concentrating on tea production and export, sending their produce to the United States, Europe and Taiwan, Somsak said.

According to Chen Huan-tang, a tea grower and merchant from Taipei who has been invited by the Chiang Rai authorities to be one of the judges at a tea-tasting competition at the festival, the oolong tea from Thailand is fast catching up with the oolong from Taiwan. "Taiwan oolong will face cut-throat competition in world markets before long, " Chen predicted.

Lai Jen-fang, secretary-general of the Taiwan Tea Producers Association, who is another judge at the festival, said that once tea drinking becomes a major habit in Thailand, tea products from Taiwan will find a good business niche in the Southeast Asian country.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar moved down against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, giving up NT$0.046 to close at NT$33.149.
A total of US$1.39 billion changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$33.201 and slid to a low of NT$33.110.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN WARNS BEIJING AGAINST INTERFERING WITH TAIWAN ELECTION

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan warned Beijing Wednesday against interfering with Taiwan's presidential election slated for March 20.

Lien called for the Beijing authorities to refrain from tampering with the election, saying that previous such moves show that Beijing gained nothing after mounting military threats toward Taiwan in the run-up to major elections.
Noting that the election is a time for the Taiwan people to demonstrate their democratic power in a sovereign state, Lien said the last thing he wants to see is tampering on the part of Beijing.

Past experience shows that after Beijing launched military threats toward Taiwan, including firing missiles and holding live-ammunition war games in the Taiwan Strait in the run-up to previous presidential elections, Taiwan voters were angered rather than intimidated by Beijing's scheming to alter the election results, Lien noted.

Lien made the remarks during a ceremony to mark the establishment of a national headquarters for supporters of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" presidential ticket of Lien and People First Party Chairman James Soong.

Meanwhile, Lien appealed to his rival, President Chen Shui-bian, who is seeking re-election, not to bring in an ill harvest by accusing the Lien-Soong ticket of benefiting from support by the Chinese communists and Taiwanese businessmen operating in mainland China.
Lien called for Chen not to stigmatize the "pan-blue alliance" people as either criminals or communists.

Quoting what he said were recent analyses by several foreign media bodies, Lien claimed that Taiwan's voters have already made their choices and predicted that there will be a new leadership in Taiwan after March 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUDGET FOR MARCH 20 REFERENDUM WILL EXCEED NT$300 MILLION: CEC

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) confirmed Wednesday that the budget for Taiwan's first-ever referendum on March 20 will be NT$300.88 million (US$9.09 million).

As some cities and counties have complained that they cannot begin preparatory work for the referendum, the CEC said that it has asked the Executive Yuan to appropriate the money to finance the referendum scheduled to coincide with the presidential election.

After the Executive Yuan appropriates the money, the CEC will immediately distribute it to local election commissions that will then have to act according to the law and prepare for the referendum on two questions -- whether Taiwan should enhance its anti-missile capability and whether it should open talks with Beijing for establishing a mechanism for cross-strait interaction.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MISERY INDEX UP SLIGHTLY IN 2003

TEXT.P: Taipei City's misery index in 2003 was slightly higher than the previous year and unemployment set a new five-year high, according to the latest tallies released Wednesday by the city government's Department of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DBAS).

The misery index is defined by a combination of price increase rates and employment rates, and an increase in both figures means that the lives of average citizens are getting more difficult, although DBAS officials said that the increase is small and that the public might not feel acute pain.
The officials noted that Taipei's misery index was 4.46 percent in 2003, with a price index of negative 0.14 percent and an unemployment level of 4.6 percent.

They noted that unemployment has remained unchanged over the past two years, although the price increase rose to negative 0.14 percent in 2003 from negative 0.28 percent in 2002. The slight increase of the 2003 misery index is a result of this increase.
However, they observed that, buoyed by the global economic recovery and the government's job stimulus project, the unemployment situation is getting better.

An analysis of the reasons for the unemployment shows that the unemployment ratio of first-time job seekers to the total jobless population dropped slightly. In comparison, the ratio of non-first-time job seekers rose.
The number of people put out of work as a result of closures or downsizing increased to 24,000 in 2003, setting a new high since 1998, according to the DBAS figures.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING CALLS FOR CROSS-STRAIT COOPERATION ON BIRD FLU CONTAINMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Feb. 11 (CNA) (By Tseng Chun-liang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Beijing authorities called Wednesday for concerted efforts from Taiwan and mainland China to contain the spread of avian flu, which has affected 10 countries and areas in Asia and has killed at least 19 people in Vietnam and Thailand.

At a regular press conference, Zhang Mingqing, spokesman for Beijing's Taiwan Affairs Office, claimed that at a time when "virulent" bird flu has been found in both Taiwan and on the mainland, both sides should step up bilateral cooperation in efforts to ward off the communicable disease.
In fact, the virulent H5N1 strain of the disease that has affected much of Asia, including the mainland, has not been found in Taiwan.

Zhang called for the establishment of a disease-reporting channel across the Taiwan Strait. He also urged that the two sides to speed up exchanges on bird flu prevention. Efforts would include early holding of academic seminars or teleconferences that would pave the way for cross-strait exchanges on medication, medical knowledge and related vaccination materials on bird flu prevention and control.

Zhang said that during a special meeting called by the State Council Feb. 1, Beijing's leaders issued "precise" directives that the mainland should step up cooperation with Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau on efforts to prevent and control virulent avian flu viruses.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 33.95 points to close at 6,454.39.
The bourse opened at 6,518.16 and fluctuated between 6,518.16 and 6,440.3 during trading.

A total of 8.65 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$170.34 billion (US$5.14 billion) , compared with the previous trading session which saw 8.91 billion stocks changed hands on a market turnover of NT$164.84 billion (US$4.97 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories posted gains, with foodstuff shares moving up the most at 0.2 percent, followed by bank and insurance stocks at 0.1 percent.

The other major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 2.3 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 2.1 percent, construction stocks at 1.8 percent, electrical shares at 0.8 percent, textile issues at 0.7 percent, and plastics and chemical shares at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 518 to 313, with 125 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 33.95 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Wednesday, with the weighted index moving down 33.95 points to close at 6,454.39.
Market turnover amounted to NT$170.34 billion (US$5.14 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPOREAN ARRESTED AT CKS AIRPORT FOR DRUG TRAFFICKING

TEXT.P: A Singaporean man was arrested at Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport -- Taiwan's main gateway -- late Tuesday on charges of drug trafficking, aviation police said Wednesday.
The detainee, identified as Chua Ek Hwee, was charged with attempting to smuggle 3,699 grams of high-grade heroin into Taiwan, police said.

Initial investigations showed that Hwee first flew from Bangkok to Hong Kong where he transferred to another plane bound for CKS Airport. The detour was designed to avoid intensive security checks as passenger and cargo planes from Thailand are subject to more stringent inspection for possible drug trafficking, police said.
Experienced security and customs officers discovered 127 bricks of heroin about the size of cell phone batteries hidden in Hwee's luggage and took him into custody, police said.
They said there is no previous record of Hwee being arrested by the CKS Aviation Police Bureau.
"We believe that he is just a trafficker, " a police officer said, adding that law enforcement authorities will search for any accomplices he may have in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO NEED TO AMEND THE TRA: STATE DEPT. OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 10 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A senior U.S. State Department official said Tuesday that he sees no need to amend the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) since the current act is efficient, sufficient and practical.

Randall G. Schriver, deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asia affairs, made the comments in response to media questions regarding a suggestion Monday by an assistant of a U.S. congressman that some improvements should be made in the act's contents.

An assistant of Rep. Henry J. Hyde, chairman of the U.S. House of Representatives' Committee on International Relations, said that the TRA was enacted 25 years ago and that there is a need to make the act more efficient for the coming 25 years by making certain amendments. Hyde was one of the key members of the U.S. Congress in pushing the introduction of the act.

Meanwhile, an assistant of Tom Lantos, vice chairman of the committee, said that although the United States is committed to helping in Taiwan's self-defense since this is part of the obligations stated in the TRA, this commitment is not an open check for the island to do whatever it wants to do.

He also said that some U.S. congressmen are dissatisfied with President George W. Bush's criticism of President Chen Shui-bian's planned referendum expressed during mainland Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao's visit to Washington, D.C., last month.

Well-placed sources in Washington have said that assistants of U.S. congressmen who are responsible for East Asian affairs gathered Monday to discuss the Congress's concerns for 2004 and that some of them consider that this April, which marks the TRA's 25th anniversary, is the right time to review the act.

Saying that he will express his opinion after listening to suggestion of the congressmen's assistants, Schriver pointed out that he considers the current TRA to be sufficient and practical and not in need of amendments.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Feb. 11, or the 21st day of the first month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1810: French Emperor Napoleon I, a brilliant military strategist whose military and political might gripped Continental Europe, marries Marie-Louise, daughter of the first emperor of Austria, Francis I.
1847: Thomas Alva Edison, the American who invented the incandescent light bulb and patented more than a thousand other inventions, is born. He patented his motion picture projector on his birthday in 1909.
1889: A constitution is granted in Japan with a two-chamber Diet, with the Emperor retaining extensive powers.
1920: The League of Nations convenes its first council meeting in London.
1922: A treaty for securing China's independence and maintaining an "open door" is signed in Washington by nine powers.
1929: Pope Pius XI and the Italian government of Benito Mussolini sign the Lateran Treaty, which gives Vatican City the status of an independent sovereign state.
1944: American war planes strike heavy blows against Japanese positions in the Marshall Islands.
1945: The Yalta Conference ends with an agreement for the establishment of the United Nations as well as plans for the defeat of Germany.
1946: U.S. Secretary of State James Byrnes makes public the Yalta Secret Agreement. With victory in the war with Germany virtually assured, the three allied leaders, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Winston Churchill, and Joseph Stalin, met on Feb. 4, 1945 at a secret meeting in the Black Sea resort of Yalta to map out Europe's future.
1964: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with France.
1967: Military rule is imposed in Beijing.
1968: Communist troops execute 300 civilians in South Vietnam during fighting for the city of Hue.
1970: Japan successfully launches its first satellite into orbit.
1970: The Taiwan Provincial Bureau of Mines is established with Tien Wei-wu serving as the first director-general.
1971: The United States and the Soviet Union sign a treaty in Washington banning underwater nuclear testing.
1973: Lic. Raimundo Guerrero, president of the Mexican Chapter of the World Anti-Communist League, arrives in Taipei for a brief visit.
1974: Archbishop Domenico Enrici, roving ambassador of the Holy See, arrives in Taipei on an inspection tour. He had served in the Apostolic Internunciature in Taipei 20 years earlier.
1974: Nineteen top Chinese golfers, including Melbourne World Cup Champions Lu Liang-huan and M.N. Hsieh, leave for Manila for the Asian circuit.
1974: U.S. Army Assistant Secretary Eugene E. Berg and a party of 2 arrive in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1975: For the first time in its 300 year history, Britain's Conservative Party names a woman as its leader when Margaret Thatcher defeats four rivals to succeed Edward Heath.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives the visiting Dr. N. B. Sommer, the first vice president of U.S. Cyanamid Corporation, and W. A. Liffers, the Pacific area general manager.
1979: Islamic revolutionaries take control of Iran's government after the shah, Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, fled Iran the previous month after strikes, riots, and mass demonstrations against his rule.
1990: South Africa's Nelson Mandela is freed after being imprisoned for 27 years for his anti-apartheid activities.
1991: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev sends a letter to government leaders of the Warsaw Pact nations proposing that the military structure be disbanded by April 1.
1994: Japanese Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa and U.S. President Bill Clinton fail to reach a critical trade deal.
2000: Liu Shao-tang, publisher of the Chinese-language monthly Biographical Literature, dies at the age of 80 after a long illness.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the knowledge of letters and arts, I may perhaps compare myself with other men. But as for the character of a good and wise man who carries out in his personal conduct what he professes -- that is something which I have not yet attained."
