DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO DONATE 2,500 TONS OF RICE TO HELP IRANIAN QUAKE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Taiwan will donate 2,500 tons of rice to help victims of a magnitude-6.7 earthquake that rocked the historic Iranian city of Bam late last December, the Council of Agriculture (COA) announced Thursday.

The rice will be delivered to Iran in mid-February for distribution to earthquake victims in Bam through the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation -- Taiwan's largest charity which has sent volunteers to assist in post-disaster relief work in the southeastern Iranian city since early January, COA officials said.
The aid program is expected to meet the rice needs of more than 80,000 quake victims in Bam for the coming three months, the officials said.
"We also hope that the donation of rice can help boost friendship between the Iranian and Taiwanese people and upgrade Taiwan's image in the international arena," a COA food administrator said.

Despite the absence of formal diplomatic relations between the two countries, the Republic of China government has donated US$100,000 in post-quake relief aid to Iran, in addition to sending a 61-member rescue team to assist in relief operations immediately after the Dec. 26 earthquake.

The ROC Red Cross Society also collected 30 tons of relief goods, including jackets, blankets, wool socks and wool hats, as well as various types of winter garments, for Iranian quake victims. The goods were delivered by a China Airlines cargo plan in early January.
More than 26,000 Bam residents were killed and at least 30,000 others injured in the earthquake.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE GOVERNMENT PLANNING TO GRANT UNIVERSITIES MORE AUTONOMY

TEXT.P: The Singapore government is planning to give local universities more autonomy, including allowing them to decide on all fee increases and admission criteria for themselves.

Currently, National University of Singapore (NUS) and Nanyang Technology University (NTU) have to ask the government for permission each time they want to raise tuition fees. And during economic downturns, the government has frozen fees to help students cope.
Deputy Prime Minister Tony Tan said that "this greater autonomy won't come all at once. It'll be phased in."
"And for those undergraduates who are wondering, university tuition fees are not going up this year," he added.

Acting Education Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam pointed out that some British universities, which are heavily regulated by the government, have become bogged down by bureaucracy and fallen behind their U.S. counterparts which are far more independent.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT SIGNS JOINT STATEMENT WITH PARAGUAYAN COUNTERPART

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu and her Paraguayan counterpart Alberto Castiglioni signed a joint statement Thursday pledging to further promote relations between the two countries.

In the joint statement, Lu and Castiglioni reiterated that both the people and governments of the Republic of China and Paraguay will continue to work for the development, peace and security of the world.
The two countries will also continue to heighten bilateral ties and mutual understanding by promoting cooperation in the economic, financial, technological and international fields.

The ROC government will do its best to organize a trade and investment mission to visit Paraguay in the near future, while the Paraguayan government will take measures and offer incentives to facilitate Taiwan investment in the South American nation.

The ROC government also thanked Paraguay for the support and assistance it has extended to Taiwan in the international arena, including Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations and other international organizations.
Castiglioni arrived in Taipei Monday for a six-day official visit at the head of a 10-member entourage.

DOC.HEADLINE: KIRIBATI PRESIDENT FETED WITH HAKKA DISHES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian hosted visiting Kiribati President Anote Tong to a banquet of delicious Hakka dishes Thursday at a resort villa in northern Hsinchu County.
The state banquet, featuring Hakka food ranging from steamed fish to wild herbs, was prepared with rare and fine products originating from the nearby mountains.

Thanking Tong for his visit to the Republic of China, Chen voiced his hope that Kiribati will support Taiwan's efforts to take part in international activities, including its bid to enter the United Nations and the World Health Organization.

Hsinchu County Magistrate Cheng Yung-chin said it is a great honor for local residents that a state banquet could be held for a second time in Hsinchu County, where the Hakka people form a sizeable portion of the county's population.
Traveling at the head of a delegation composed of various Cabinet members, Tong and his wife arrived in Taiwan Feb. 10 for a five-day visit.

Tong was accorded a 21-gun military salute at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei following his arrival. The Kiribati president also met Vice President Annette Lu and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, as well as other high-ranking government officials, during the welcoming ceremony.
It is Tong's first visit to the ROC since he assumed the presidency in July 2003. Tong first visited Taiwan in 1982 in his capacity as a ministerial-level official.

The ROC and the world's largest coral reef nation in the South Pacific forged diplomatic ties in November last year. The move prompted Beijing to dismantle a satellite tracking facility it had built on Kiribati's main island.
Various trade promotion groups, a legislative mission composed of aboriginal lawmakers and Foreign Affairs Minister Eugene Chien have visited Kiribati since the two countries set up formal relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE FILES SUIT AGAINST OPPOSITION FIGURES

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office filed a complaint with the Prosecutor's Office at the Taipei District Court Thursday, accusing opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong and five lawmakers of libel.
Chiou I-jen, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, rang the bell at the Prosecutor's Office, symbolizing the filing of the complaint.
Chiou charged Soong and the other defendants with insulting the public office by describing the Presidential Office as a "black gold political center."

Soong, legislators Lee Chuan-chiao, Huang Chao-sun, Chu Feng-chi, Lin Yu-fang and Liu Wen-hsiung accused the Presidential Office of corruption, citing a recent allegation by Chen You-hao, a fugitive business tycoon who is wanted in Taiwan for embezzlement, against the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

In three open letters to President Chen Shui-bian, who also serves as DPP chairman, Chen You-hao accused the ruling party of cutting the ground from under his feet by taking his political donations before the 2000 presidential election but indicting him after its candidate won the election.

In a tit-for-tat exchange of libel accusations, Chang Hsien-yao, director of the PFP Policy Center, filed a complaint with the Prosecutor's Office later that same day, accusing Chiou of lodging a false accusation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PREPARED TO PREVENT BEIJING MEDDLING IN ELECTION: CABINET AIDE

TEXT.P: Taiwan is fully prepared to prevent all possible meddling from Beijing aimed at rigging Taiwan's first referendum, to be held on the same day as the presidential election slated for March 20, Executive Yuan spokesman Lin Chia-lung said Thursday.

According to the Cabinet spokesman, all relevant government authorities will heighten their alert levels to fend off any type of irregularities involved in the historic referendum, particularly those schemed up by the Chinese communists.

Lin gave his assurances that national security, police and intelligence authorities have been on high alert in the face of rampant rumors that the Beijing regime is very likely to attempt to influence the coming referendum and presidential race.

He called on the public to stay calm and urged the opposition parties to refrain from smearing the referendum. Accusations such as that the referendum will create riots only reflects their fear and ignorance, he claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATES 7,000 TONS OF RICE TO MONGOLIA

TEXT.P: A shipment of 7,000 tons of rice donated by World Vision Taiwan to Mongolia was transported to Ulan Bator in January and will be distributed to needy Mongolian families by the end of this month, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials said Thursday.
The donation will benefit around 45,000 households in Mongolia, which is suffering a food shortage due to natural disasters over the past few years, the officials said.
Based on humanitarian concerns, they added, the MOFA plans to donate another 2,000 tons of rice to the country.
The shipment of the new donation is slated for April and will be distributed by the end of May, they said.

Furthermore, 300 Mongolian workers have been selected to receive a two-month vocational training course in Ulan Bator, after which they will be entitled to apply for permission to work in Taiwan, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2003 BUSINESS REVENUE OF HSIP TOTALS OVER NT$850 BILLION

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park (HSIP) in northern Taiwan registered an annual business revenue of NT$857.8 billion (about US$27 billion) for 2003, the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park Administration reported Thursday.
The figure represents a 22 percent increase over the 2002 level, according to the report issued by the administration.

As of the end of last year, a total of 101,832 workers were employed by the 370 companies based in the park --- Taiwan's high-technology stronghold, the report shows. The two numbers reflect rises of 10.4 percent and 3.2 percent, respectively, over their year-earlier levels.

In terms of annual growth rate registered by the six leading hi-tech industries that form the backbone of the HSIP, the opto-electronic industry posted the largest increase rate of 57 percent year-on-year, with business turnover worth NT$94.3 billion.

Biotechnology came second with a growth rate of 30 percent, contributing business valued at NT$1.84 billion, followed by the IC industry with a 24 percent increase rate representing business worth NT$564.5 billion.

The computer and peripherals industry recorded the fourth-largest growth rate of 11 percent, with business worth NT$134.8 billion. The precision machinery industry ranked fifth, with a 7 percent increase rate, notching up business worth NT$5.8 million, ahead of the telecommunications industry.

The six major industries chalked up a combined business volume of NT$857.8 billion for 2003, with the figure expected to top NT$1.3 trillion in 2004 amid strong signs of an improved economy, administration officials said.
Per-capita production value averaged NT$8.43 million last year, up by 23 percent compared to the 2002 level, the report indicates.

The computer and peripherals industry posted the highest per-capita output value of NT$109.7 million, followed by the IC industry with NT$99.9 million, the telecommunications industry with NT$81.9 million, the precision machinery industry with NT$61.1 billion, the opto-electronics industry with NT$48.8 billion and the biotechnology industry with NT$22.4 billion.

The HSIP's import and export trade totaled NT$612.6 billion in 2003, an annual expansion rate of 15.9 percent. Hong Kong, mainland China, the United States, Japan and South Korea were the park's top five markets. Exports amounted to NT$390.8 billion, while imports hit around NT$221.8 billion, up by 4 percent and down by 11.1 percent, respectively, compared with the 2002 levels.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. NOT OPPOSED TO TAIWAN REFERENDUM: ROC SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: United States Secretary of State Colin Powell's remarks on Taiwan's referendum show that the United States does not support, nor it is opposed to, the "peace referendum" scheduled for March 20 alongside the presidential election, a government spokesman said Thursday.

Executive Yuan spokesman Lin Chia-lung, made the remarks in response to Powell's testifying at the House International Relations Committee a day earlier, during which he said that "we don't really see a need" for the referendum, but Taiwan is a democratic place, and if they choose to have a referendum, they can have a referendum.

Powell also said that he had urged the European Union not to lift an embargo on arms sale to mainland China at a sensitive time when the mainland still has many missiles targeting Taiwan and Taiwan is scheduled to put to a referendum vote the question of increasing its anti-missile capability.
"This means that the U.S. does not want to say anything that will affect Taiwan's presidential election," Lin said, adding that this is Washington's long-standing position.
"The government thanks the U.S. for respecting Taiwan's democratic development, and not opposing its first nationwide referendum," Lin said.

"The government will continue to communicate with international friends on the motive and purpose of promoting the peace referendum," Lin said, explaining that "the referendum will not have anything to do with the nation's status regarding independence versus unification with mainland China and that it will not seek to change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait."

Lin said that the world might have differing views on the referendum, but from Taiwan's point of view, its sovereignty and security are in clear and immediate danger, which is why the government has decided to hold the national referendum according to the recently passed Referendum Law.

Lin also said that the government appreciates Powell's words on the mainland's missile threat to Taiwan and his opposition to the E.U.'s lifting of the arms embargo, which he said shows that "the U.S. understands that a lifting of the arms embargo on China will have a possible effect on the security and stability in the Asia-Pacific region."

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEAN TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER MAY ENCOURAGE BEIJING TO INVADE TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The transfer of European technology to mainland China could encourage Beijing to invade Taiwan, Vice President Annette Lu warned Thursday.

Receiving the mayor of the Austrian city of Innsbruck, Hilde Zach, at the Presidential Office, Lu told her guest that Beijing has not only tried to isolate Taiwan diplomatically but also has been increasing its military buildup against Taiwan.
Beijing has deployed around 500 missiles targeting Taiwan and the number of missiles deployed is expected to increase to 650 next year, Lu said.

Noting that the European Union adopted a resolution to ban arms sales to mainland China after the Tiananmen massacre of 1989, the vice president said it is worrisome that the leaders of France and Germany are reportedly seeking to lift the ban following years of seduction by Beijing with commercial interests.

She expressed concern that European advanced technology will be transferred to the mainland, adding that if this is the case, it will be helpful for Beijing's military buildup and therefore will encourage it to invade Taiwan.

Taiwan is not a part of the People's Republic of China and has maintained substantive relations with almost all countries around the world, although most of them do not have diplomatic relations with Taiwan, she went on.

Taiwan has never ceased its efforts to participate in international activities and has made great contributions to global development even though it is denied by many international organizations, she added.

She described Beijing as a "real international terrorist" by imposing a missile threat against Taiwan and preparing to invade Taiwan at any time, adding that this is why President Chen Shui-bian called a "peace referendum" for March 20 alongside the presidential election.
European nations should not join Beijing in opposing Taiwan's planned referendum, she said.

Zach arrived in Taipei Tuesday for a six-day visit at the invitation of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. She hopes to gain a better understanding of Taiwan's development in the political, economic, cultural and tourism fields.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZU-CHI BUDDHIST HOSPITAL INKS COOPERATIVE PACT WITH U.S. FIRM

TEXT.P: Tzu-Chi Buddhist General Hospital in the eastern Taiwan county of Hualien signed a cooperative contract with a U.S. firm Thursday on the development of cancer-fighting drugs based on a plant extract.

Han Hung-chi, director of Tzu-Chi Hospital's cancer research laboratory, said his research team has discovered a substance in Chinese thorowax root, whose scientific name is Dupleurum Scorzonerifolium, that can stem growth of cancerous cells.
Han said his team will cooperate with Seattle-based Phenogenomics Co. in using Chinese thorowax root extracts to develop cancer-fighting drugs.
According to Han, the Chinese thorowax root is usually grown in such southern mainland Chinese provinces as Hubei, Sichuan and Anhui.

Han said his team has completed an analysis of the Chinese thorowax root extract's chemical structure. "We are applying for patent rights to the extract in Taiwan, the United States, Japan, Europe and mainland China," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PRESIDENT WILLING TO TESTIFY IN COURT OVER SLUSH FUND CASE

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui said Thursday that if he is subpoenaed by judicial authorities to testify in a case regarding alleged misappropriation of national security funds during his term in office, he will definitely be willing to attend the court hearing.

Lee made the remarks after the Taipei District Court confirmed earlier in the day that it has decided to summon 16 witnesses, including the former president, for questioning about the alleged embezzlement of money from secret accounts of the National Security Bureau (NSB) -- Taiwan's top intelligence agency -- during Lee's presidency.
The case centers on the alleged misappropriation of NT$250 million (US$7.5 million) from secret NSB accounts. Prosecutors indicted two former NSB officials in connection with the case last November.
"I didn't do anything wrong. Why should I dodge a court subpoena to testify as a witness in the investigation of the case? " Lee said in response to a press inquiry.

Huang Chun-ming, a Taipei District Court chief judge, said the list of witnesses also includes former Minister of Foreign Affairs Jason Hu, who is now mayor of Taichung City, as well as former Lee associates, business leaders and retired security officials.
A date for the former president's court appearance has not been decided yet, Huang added.
Lee testified in court as a witness last November over a snowballing land deal scandal involving one of his closest confidants -- Liu Tai-ying, the disgraced former China Development Group chairman.
One of the defendants in the NSB case -- the former NSB chief accountant, Hsu Ping-chiang -- has been detained and prosecutors are asking for a 15-year prison sentence for him.

The other suspect, former NSB chief cashier Liu Kuan-chun, fled the island in 2000 and his whereabouts are unknown, although a media report claimed that he is living in Canada. Prosecutors have asked for a 12-year sentence for Liu.

DOC.HEADLINE: MERGING DOMESTIC AIR CARRIER TREMENDOUS TASK: CAA

TEXT.P: Although merging the four air carriers currently plying domestic routes will be a tremendous task, the government has decided not to play a leadership role in the matter but will remain on the sidelines, a government official said Thursday.

Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) Director-General Chang Kuo-cheng made the remarks after calling a meeting with representatives from the four aviation companies to discuss and exchange opinions on the issue.

Claiming that it will be enormously difficult to merge the four carriers, Chang said the CAA has decided not to get involved in the matter. The main purpose of the meeting was to gain an understanding of the opinions of the carriers and the CAA has no concrete plans on the matter, he noted.

Mandarin Airlines General Manager Lo Ta-hsin, who is also chairman of the Taipei Transport Aircraft Association, noted that all four carriers -- Mandarin Airlines, Trans Asia Airways, UNI Airways Corp. and Far East Air Transport Corp. (FEAT) -- are operating in the red.

Although Lo disclosed that all four companies share a common view that a merger might be better for them, he acknowledged that the task will be very difficult because of their varied business and market strategies, not to mention the fact that their respective fleets are composed of different types of planes -- the biggest problem affecting the much-discussed merger.
Rumors of a possible merger were circulating as far back as three or four years ago but very little progress has been seen, despite the fact that no strong opposition has arisen from those involved.

Pointing out that the four airlines remain sharply divided over the question of which company should be the acquirer, Lo suggested inviting foreign experts to help settle the issue in conjunction with government assistance and incentives.

FEAT General Manager Chen Mei-wen contended that the issue is far too complex for the CAA to deal with. He opined that the best way to achieve the merger would be for Mandarin Airlines and UNI Airways to pull out of the market and join their respective parent companies -- China Airlines and EVA Airways Corporation -- which operate international routes.
Such a move would leave just two carriers to ply the domestic routes, he argued.
Representatives of FEAT and UNI Airways expressed reservations about the merger plan.

However, a UNI Airways official stressed that his company has succeeded in trimming its losses in recent years by launching special tourism packages and he predicted that the carrier should be able to operate profitably in the near future.

All four carriers have been increasingly troubled over the past few years due to various key factors, such as the high-speed railway system under construction -- completion of which is slated for next year -- flight ticket price hikes and an improved road traffic network.

Last year, the domestic air traffic market was dealt a heavy blow when the potentially deadly severe acute respiratory syndrome broke out in spring, reversing previous optimistic prospects that Trans Asia would register profits and leaving all four carriers operating at a loss.

UNI Airways recorded losses of more than NT$800 million (about US$25 million) , followed by Mandarin Airlines with over NT$300 million in losses, FEAT with losses of NT$200 million and Trans Asia at NT$70 million in the red.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, THAILAND UNIVERSITIES SIGN COOPERATIVE PACT
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Feb. 12 (CNA) (By F. C. Kuo and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) of Taiwan and Thailand's Chulalongkorn University agreed on a cooperative accord Thursday, with presidents from the two prominent universities inking the pact in Bangkok.

NCKU President Kao Chiang and Chulalongkorn University President Tatchai Sumitra signed a memorandum of understanding. Under the terms of the accord, the two sides will step up two-way academic cooperation and exchanges of visits by professors and students as part of their efforts to pursue a greater international standing.

Kao and Sumitra agreed to strengthen bilateral exchanges of short-term visits by professors and students for research purposes. Kao said his university is willing to offer free housing and tuition for students from Chulalongkorn while encouraged NCKU students to seek advanced studies in Thailand.

Kao also met Buddagarn Rudchatorn, vice president of the Economic School, and hailed Chulalongkorn's performance following a briefing by Rudchatorn about their teaching methods and facilities. The NCKU president highly praised Chulalongkorn's globalization, proof of which can be seen in its all-English speaking environment and a noticeable number of foreign students.
Most of the foreign students at Chulalongkorn are from Japan and European countries. No Taiwan student is enrolled in the Thai University.

Kao and four other NCKU professors also paid a visit later the same day to the Asian Institute of Technology in Bangkok, while they are slated to call at Mahidol University and National Thammasat University Friday before flying back to Taiwan after concluding a three-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA STEEL TO UPGRADE PRODUCTS TO MEET COMPETITION: OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: China Steel Corp. said Thursday that it will strive to produce superior products to counter increased competition from mainland Chinese steel manufacturers.
Mainland China has often been referred to as the "world's factory for manufacturing" and its steel-producing sector has seen rapid increased growth in its production capacity.

Although China Steel in Taiwan is enjoying good profits at the moment, company officials acknowledge that world steel prices are bound to move toward more cut-throat competition and China Steel is expecting this to adversely affect profits, company officials said.
"We have to look for other ways to boost our revenues, " the officials added.
China Steel is planning to increase research and development, the officials said, hoping that the high-value added products will find a niche in the ever-more competitive global market.

In addition, China Steel must also expand the production capacity of its higher quality goods, they said, as well as establish a marketing network for these products, especially in downstream industries. The company will also have to tap other markets, including mainland China, in the future.
China Steel sold around 10 million tons of steel products last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ILLEGAL DRUGS SEIZED IN 2003 UP 200 PERCENT OVER PREVIOUS YEAR: NPA

TEXT.P: The amount of contraband drugs seized by law enforcement authorities in 2003 surged 200 percent compared with the year before, the National Police Administration (NPA) reported Thursday.
According to NPA tallies, 2,339.86 kilograms of drugs were seized in 2003, marking an increase of 1,559.98 kilograms, or 200 percent, from the 779.88 kilograms found in 2002.
NPA officials attributed the sharp rise mainly to the increase in seized second- and third-grade drugs.

In comparison, the amount of confiscated first-grade drugs, such as heroin, cocaine, opium and morphine, declined from 442.65 kilograms in 2002 to 262.37 kilograms in 2003. Heroin seizures alone decreased 176.14 kilograms.

Seizures of second-grade drugs, such as amphetamines and MDMA, zoomed from 288.16 kilograms in 2002 to 1,647.9 kilograms last year, while third-grade drug seizures also jumped from 75.98 kilograms to 429.59 kilograms because of a substantial rise in ketamine seizures.
The NPA statistics also showed that 25,491 drug trafficking cases were uncovered last year, down 121 cases from that registered in 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZU CHI URGED TO HELP RECRUIT RETIRED TEACHERS TO TEACH ABROAD

TEXT.P: The Republic of China representative to the Philippines has urged Taiwan's largest charity -- the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation -- to encourage retired Taiwan elementary and high school teachers to teach abroad.
Wu Hsin-hsing, a scholar-turned-diplomat, made the appeal during a courtesy call at the Tzu Chi's branch office in Manila Wednesday afternoon.
To the best of his understanding, Wu said, Taiwan has many retired elementary and high school teachers who are concurrently Tzu Chi members.

"As many Chinese schools in Southeast Asian countries face a shortage of teaching staff, I hope Tzu Chi can help recruit retired schoolteachers to teach in overseas Chinese schools," Wu said. "I believe it's an effective way to help disseminate Chinese cultural legacies and values."

According to Wu, the Chinese community in the Philippines has traditionally attached great importance to Chinese-language education and has offered much support to Chinese schools in various parts of the country.

"There are now more than 140 Chinese schools in the Philippines, with over 100,000 teachers and students," Wu said, adding that most of them, particularly those in rural areas, face difficulties due to ashortage of qualified teachers.
Perhaps, Wu said, Tzu Chi can help resolve the issue by recruiting its retired teachers-turned-volunteers to teach at Chinese schools in the Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 17.44 points to close at 6,436.95.
The bourse opened at 6,505.53 and fluctuated between 6,578.82 and 6,397.34 during trading.

A total of 9.9 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$202.66 billion (US$6.12 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 8.65 billion stocks changed hands on a market turnover of NT$170.34 billion (US$5.14 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories posted gains, with electrical shares and bank and insurance stocks both moving up 0.5 percent. Plastics and chemical shares remained unchanged.

The other major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff shares moving down the most at 5.2 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 3.9 percent, cement stocks and textile issues, both at 3.1 percent, and construction stocks at 2.9 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 624 to 211, with 122 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION INVITED TO DEBATE AGAINST CABINET OVER REFERENDUM QUESTIONS

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) has asked the three opposition parties in the Legislative Yuan whether they intend to represent the "opposed" side against the administration in the 10 scheduled public debates on the two referendum questions.

The debates, five for each of the two questions, will pit the Executive Yuan, which is charged with implementing the referendum, against the opposition parties in the Legislative Yuan or civil groups that oppose the Executive Yuan's views.
In the event that there are no "opposed" groups, the scheduled debates will be transformed into a presentation of the Executive Yuan's views.

The CEC has asked the Executive Yuan and any "opposed" groups to recommend between one and five people to represent them for the debates, adding that the opposition political parties will have to provide their list of recommended representatives by Monday at the latest.
The 10 debates have been scheduled to be held between Feb. 20 and March 19, according to the CEC's plan.
The two questions to be asked in the March 20 referendum are:

-- "The people of the Taiwan demand that the Taiwan Strait issue be resolved through peaceful means. Should mainland China refuse to withdraw the missiles it has targeted at Taiwan and openly renounce the use of force against us, do you agree that the government should acquire more advanced anti-missile weapons to strengthen Taiwan's self-defense capabilities?"

-- "Do you agree that our government should engage in negotiation with mainland China on the establishment of a peace and a stability framework for cross-strait interactions in order to build consensus and for the welfare of the peoples of both sides."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 12, or the 22nd day of the first month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1809: Abraham Lincoln, the U.S. president who was assassinated a few days after the end of the American Civil War, is born.
1851: Fortune hunters rush to the town of Bathurst in the Blue Mountains of New South Wales, Australia, in search of gold.
1895: Japan scores an impressive victory at Weihaiwei in northern China when Japanese forces quickly breach Chinese defenses and sink most of its northern navy in the war between the Ching court and Japan which broke out in 1894.
1899: Germany purchases the Marianas Islands, the Caroline Islands, and Palau from Spain.
1908: The first global Grand Prix is inaugurated at Times Square in New York.
1912: Henry Pu Yi abdicates as emperor of China, ending the rule of the Manchu dynasty.
1941: A group of researchers led by Howard Florey of Australia and Ernst Chain of Germany develop a method of extracting and purifying small amounts of penicillin, which was first used by physicians to treat a human a day later when the drug was given to a British policeman suffering from blood poisoning.
1960: The Council of Grand Justices of the Judicial Yuan announces that the total membership of the Republic of China National Assembly, under the period of national emergency, shall be 1,576.
1964: Japanese Premier Shigeru Yoshida arrives in the ROC to confer with President Chiang Kai-shek.
1970: Express trains collide north of Hsinchu, in northern Taiwan, killing 10 and injuring 47.
1974: Chang Kwang-shih, ROC vice minister of economic affairs, returns from Saudi Arabia, where he signed a memorandum of economic coorperation.
1974: Soviet Nobel Prize winner Alexander Solzhenitsyn is arrested in Moscow and exiled the following day.
1974: Raimundo Guerrero, chairman of the World Anti-Communist League, arrives in Taipei for a visit.
1975: The people of South Korea vote to adopt a new constitution that gives the president almost unlimited power and permits him to serve an unlimited number of terms.
1976: Six hundred members of the ROC's National Federation of Industries Association, National Federation of Businesses Association, and the Industrial and Business Association meet and pledge to support government economic policy.
1976: The first Sino-Japanese exhibition of modern painting opens, with more than 52 works by contemporary Japanese artists on display.
1980: Hong Kong's subway is formally inaugurated.
1987: The U.S. Air Force successfully launches "Titan 3B" missiles into orbit above the North and South Poles.
1992: Mongolia's new non-communist constitution takes effect.
1996: Yasser Arafat becomes the first president of Palestine.
1996: Faced with threatening military maneuvers undertaken by Beijing, the ROC Executive Yuan sets up a temporary policymaking task force to closely follow developments and coordinate the actions of various agencies to respond to the situation.
1997: Hwang Jang Yop, a confidant of North Korean leader Kim Jong Il, defects in Beijing and seeks asylum in South Korea.
1999: The U.S. Senate votes against removing President Bill Clinton from office in the Monica Lewinsky scandal.
2000: Taiwan doctor Chen Chiu-huang wins the 2000 award of the Foundation de Enterprise Montblanc de la Culture of Britain.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Extravagance leads to excess; thrift to meanness; but it is better to be mean than to be guilty of excess."

DOC.HEADLINE: UNCLE OF TAIWANESE-BRAZILIAN BOY WORRIED ABOUT HANDOVER PROCEDURE

TEXT.P: The uncle of a Taiwanese-Brazilian boy who was handed over to his Brazilian grandmother Friday in Brazil was worried very much about the boy after learning from news reports that the boy was separated from his Taiwanese relatives who accompanied him to Brazil.

Wu Huo-yen said in his Chieting home, Kaohsiung County, he is trying to contact his wife, Lee Su-hua, who was escorting the boy, Iruan Wu Ergui, to Porto Alegre, Brazil, to see that the boy was handed over to his Brazilian grandmother, Rosa Leocadia Da Silva, properly, and to see why she was not allowed to accompany the boy after he was sent back to the home of his grandmother.

Iruan Wu Ergui has been at the center of a three-year legal fight between Wu Huo-yen and Rosa Leocadia Da Silva. Wu Huo-yen lost the custody suit and was forced to hand the boy back to his Brazilian grandmother.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER NOT TO ALLOW SEPARATE REFERENDUM AND PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun vowed Friday not to allow local governments to hold the referendum and the presidential election separately, saying any official who dares to do this will be putting their jobs on the line.

Answering questions from an opposition People First Party lawmaker, the premier said his administration won't allow a referendum separate from the presidential election to be held even if they are held on March 20 simultaneously.

The premier said the Central Election Committee (CEC) has accepted the Executive Yuan's idea of holding the two votes together at the same time and place, although the ballots are to be cast into different boxes. Officials who failed to follow the CEC's guidelines in carrying out the referendum and the presidential election will be called to account.

Three additional workers will be needed at each polling station and an extra NT$84 million will be needed because voters must pick up their ballots for the referendum only after they have cast ballots for the presidential election, as suggested by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), the premier said.

The premier made the comments in the Legislative Yuan in answering questions about news reports that two local governments are contemplating holding the two votes at separate locations in light of their different nature and their different qualifications for voters.
In order to ensure the success of the first national referendum, the Executive Yuan has laid down every detail for the implementation of the vote and has left nothing to chance the premier added.

As a valid referendum would require a turnout of more than 50 percent, the Executive Yuan has gone out of its way to turn the voters out for the referendum and has insisted to have it held piggyback with the presidential election.

Meanwhile, the opposition, mainly the KMT and People First Party, claimed the referendum is not based on legal grounds. They have gone out their way to stop the referendum, or prevent it from boosting President Chen Shui-bian's chance of wining a second term.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE, EGYPT SIGN ECONOMIC AND TECHNICAL COOPERATION AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: Singaporean Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong and his Egyptian counterpart Atef Ebeid on Thursday witnessed the signing of an economic and technical cooperation agreement between the two countries.
Goh is currently on an official visit to the Middle Eastern country.
During their meeting, Ebeid described Singapore as a model for economic progress and said Egypt would like to tap Singapore's experience in higher education and port and industrial park management.

Briefing reporters on the talks between the leaders, Goh's press secretary said Singapore will help organize an investment seminar. Goh said he thinks the Middle East offers many opportunities as countries in the region strive to diversify their economies beyond oil.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN TO EXPOUND ON HIS VISION FOR THE FUTURE IN LIVE TV DEBATE: AIDE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will expound on his vision for the nation's future development as well as initiatives for major policy issues in Saturday's televised debate with his challenger Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan, an aide said Friday.

Legislator Lo Wen-jia, who concurrently serves as convener of a task force in charge of preparations for Chen's two live TV debates with Lien on Feb. 14 and Feb. 21, said Chen will adopt a "business as usual" attitude toward the upcoming televised debate.
"Chen will explain his vision and policy initiatives in a natural and sincere manner," Lo said.
While the March 20 presidential election will be the third of its kind in Taiwan, it will be the first time that presidential candidates will have conducted a live TV debate.

In the previous two direct presidential elections in 1996 and 2000, candidates only conducted televised campaign forums organized by the Central Election Commission (CEC) , in which hopefuls only outlined their own policy platforms.
Back in 2000, Lo recalled that Chen, a lawyer-turned-politician, did not rehearse before the CEC-organized televised campaign forums.
"So this time around, Chen has also not rehearsed before this weekend's live TV debate," Lo said.
It will mark the first-ever face-to-face debate between Chen and Lien.
The debate, organized by Public Television Service (PTS) , will start at 2 p.m. In addition to PTS, nearly all other major domestic TV and radio stations will broadcast the debate live.

PTS Chairman Wu Feng-shan will chair the debate, while five people will pose questions to the two contenders. The five are Huang Kun-yen, a microbiologist who is now chairman of the Ministry of Education's Medical Education Commission; Chu Ching-yi, an Academia Sinica academician; Lin Ching-ping, chief executive of the private Judicial Reform Promotion Association; Wang Jung-chang, spokesman for the "pan-purple alliance, " which is dedicated to promoting fairness and social justice; and Wang Yeh-li, a Tung Hai University political science professor.

DOC.HEADLINE: OSAKA PREFECTURE COUNCIL MISSION VISITS KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: A 12-member delegation composed of a pro-Taiwan group from the council of Japan's Osaka Prefecture and Chinese community representatives paid a visit Friday to Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh.

The delegation led by the group's leader, Michio Kawaai, was warmly greeted by Hsieh at the Kaohsiung City Government offices, where the two sides held talks to exchange views on a wide range of issues, ranging from elections and political contributions to fiscal matters.
Hsieh expressed the hope for a closer and enhanced relationship between Kaohsiung and Osaka to push for more exchanges between Taiwan and Japan.

Kawaai passed on a letter from Osaka Prefecture Governor Fusae Ohta to Hsieh and echoed Hsieh's words by agreeing that two-way visits and activities between Kaohsiung and Osaka should be further strengthened on a broad range of issues. The Kaohsiung City Council and Osaka Prefecture Council formed sisterhood ties in October 2001.

In addition to Taiwan's upcoming presidential election on March 20, Kawaai said his group is also interested in getting to know Taiwan's natural beauty and urban development during their four-day visit. He added that they will tour top tourists spots such as Sun Moon Lake in central Nantou County and Alishan in southern Chiayi County.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SAYS WAGERING ON PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION WILL NOT BE TOLERATED

TEXT.P: The government does not condone gambling on the outcome of the March 20 presidential election and such activities will be stopped when they are uncovered, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday.

Saying that betting on the election could have some effect on the outcome, Yu said the government, especially the ministries of the interior and justice, will do all they can to stop gambling on the candidates.

Lawmaker Lo Chih-ming of the Taiwan Solidarity Union asked the premier to comment on reports that 1.4 million people in the seven counties in southern Taiwan have placed bets in favor of the opposition Kuomintang candidate Lien Chan.
This, if true, is alarming, Lo said, because the seven counties have been bastions of support for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in the past.
Minister of the Interior Yu Cheng-hsien said he had heard about betting on the presidential election but was not aware of such a large number of people being involved, Lo quoted him as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: FATHER OF TAIWANESE DETAINED IN MAINLAND CHINA APPEALS FOR HELP

TEXT.P: The father of a Taiwanese businessman detained in mainland China under suspicion of being a spy appealed for government help Friday in seeking the release of his son.
Chang Shih-chang, the father of Chang Hsu-min, said at his home in Tungshi, Taichung County, that his son "could not" work as a spy for Taiwan as accused by mainland authorities.

Chang Shih-chang said his family has been farming in Taichung for generations and that his son grew fruit in Lishan, Nantou County, after finishing his military service. He then began working as a travel agent, organizing tours for visitors to Thailand and Singapore.
About a year ago, the 27-year-old went to Putian, in southern China's Fujian Province, to act as a matchmaker, where he lived with his Taiwanese girlfriend Yu Shih-ping.
He last returned to Taiwan during the Chinese New Year but failed to communicate with his family in Taiwan upon returning to the mainland after the holiday.

Chang Shih-chang appealed to the Straits Exchange Foundation Feb. 10 for help in locating his son, but learned the next day from news reports that he and his girlfriend had been arrested on the mainland for spying.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY TWO-THIRDS OF PEOPLE SATISFIED WITH SOCIAL ORDER: POLICE

TEXT.P: Nearly two-thirds of Taiwan people are satisfied with social order, officials of the National Police Administration (NPA) said Friday.

According to polls conducted by two private polling companies commissioned by the NPA on the condition of social order for the fourth quarter of last year, the officials said 64.9 percent of respondents said that they were satisfied, up 0.2 percentage points over the previous quarter's level and one percentage point higher than that of a year ago.
The polling took place Jan. 1-9 with a total of 21,195 samples randomly selected by telephone in 23 cities and counties around Taiwan. The poll had a margin of error of less than 3.5 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, KIRIBATI PRESIDENTS SIGN JOINT COMMUNIQUE ON COOPERATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and visiting Kiribati President Anote Tong signed a joint communique Friday, pledging to promote peace based on parity and reciprocality and to step up two-way cooperation.

Chen and Tong inked the document at the Presidential Office, with the two heads of state promising to settle regional and international disputes through peaceful means such as dialogue and negotiations in line with principles of equality and fairness.
Chen and Tong also vowed to enhance and upgrade bilateral cooperative ventures based on their current cordial relations.

Praising Taiwan's remarkable developments on the economic, political and social fronts, Tong thanked Chen for the warm reception that the Republic of China government and its people have extended to him and invited Chen to visit his island nation located in the South Pacific.
Tong also wished Chen success in his re-election bid on March 20 and expressed his hope that he could visit Taiwan again to take part in Chen's inauguration in May.

Tong left Taiwan for Kiribati later the same day. Prior to his departure, the Kiribati president was accorded a farewell ceremony at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei. The previous day, Tong and his entourage were treated to a state banquet featuring Hakka food at a resort villa in northern Hsinchu County.
Traveling at the head of a Cabinet-level delegation, Tong and his wife arrived in Taiwan Feb. 9 for a five-day visit. It was Tong's first visit Taiwan after he assumed the presidency in July 2003.
While here, Chen and Tong discussed and exchanged views on issues of mutual concern and international situations.
The two countries set up diplomatic ties in November 2003, making Kiribati the 27th nation in the world to officially recognize the ROC.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES MUST ADDRESS QUESTIONS IN DEBATE: ALLIANCE

TEXT.P: The convener of an alliance comprised mainly of underprivileged and social welfare groups on Friday urged the two presidential candidates not to dodge questions in the first televised debate in more than five decades in Taiwan.

Chien Hsi-chieh of the "pan-purple alliance" made the remarks about the first of the two televised presidential debates between President Chen Shui-bian and his challenger, Lien Chan, chairman of the Kuomintang Saturday afternoon. The second debate will be held Feb. 21.

Chien noted that Wang Jung-chang, a spokesman for the alliance, will be one of the five representatives to ask questions at the debate, and he said the Wang will surely be the voice of the people to reflect the views of the general public.
He also urged the two candidates not to dodge questions.

Observers have welcomed the first televised debate between the two presidential candidates, saying that the public is tired of the negative campaigning and mudslinging that has taken place so far. They said the debates will serve to help undecided voters cast their votes in the March 20 presidential election.
He said that although Wang is only allowed to ask two questions, the questions will be a gauge at to whether the two candidates have really responded to the needs of the people.

He was also positive about the selection of the five representatives to ask questions in Saturday's debate, which will also include a researcher from the nation's highest research institute, Academic Sinica, an official of a private judicial reform group, a university professor, and an official from the Ministry of the Education.
He said the five are basically neutral, and favor neither the incumbent president nor his challenger.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINES

TEXT.P: New York Times: U.S. may support Israeli approach on leaving Gaza.
The Bush administration, has indicated that it may support Israel' s new proposal for a unilateral withdrawal from parts of Gaza and the West Bank.

A senior American official said that the administration is "taking a close look" at its Middle East policy, and that the president would send three senior aides to Israel next week to get questions answered before the proposal was endorsed.
Wall Street Journal: China rethinks the peg tying Yuan and Dollar.
Pressures building within China's hard-charging economy are driving Beijing to re-examine the Chinese currency's iron-like tether to the U.S. dollar.
The U.S., the European Union and other trading partners have urged China to let the yuan float, contending that the currency is undervalued and fueling a predatory export boom.
But it is internal economic concerns -- not outside political pressures which have led the communist leadership "to gradually perfect" the exchange-rate mechanism.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE TO TEST BIRD FLU BATTLE PLAN

TEXT.P: Singapore's bird flu contingency plan will be tested next week, with the government staging an emergency exercise in which healthy chickens will be culled.

To make sure Singapore is ready to deal with the bird flu if the disease ever finds it way to the island, some 5,000 healthy chickens from one of the poultry farms in the Lim Chu Kang area will be culled next Wednesday.
The government, which has purchased the chickens, will go through all the steps of the bird flu battle plan. It will use an internationally approved method to cull the chickens.
Batches of 10 chickens will be placed in heavy duty plastic bags and then gassed with carbon dioxide. The process, which lasts about five minutes, is painless for the chickens.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT BIDS FAREWELL TO KIRIBATI PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian bade farewell Friday to visiting Kiribati President Anote Tong with a military ceremony at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.
A 21-gun military salute was accorded to Tong and the national anthems of the two countries were played during the ceremony.

Tong, his wife and the members of his entourage then said goodbye to Chen and his wife, as well as high-ranking government officials and foreign ambassadors and envoys posted to the Republic of China, after wrapping up a five-day visit.
The previous day, Tong was feted with a state banquet featuring Hakka food in northern Hsinchu County, with dishes ranging from steamed fish to fresh wild herbs originating from nearby mountains.
The Hakka people form a significant segment of the population in Hsinchu County.
It was Tong's first visit to the ROC since he assumed the presidency in July 2003. He first visited Taiwan in 1982 in his capacity as a ministerial-level official.
A few days earlier, Chen described Tong's state visit as a propitious sign for Taiwan at the beginning of a new year.
The two countries set up diplomatic relations in November last year, prompting Beijing to close a satellite tracking establishment it had constructed on Kiribati's main island.
Two-way exchanges between the two diplomatic allies have been stepped up since then and officials of the two countries have exchanged a number of visits.
Several trade promotion groups, a parliamentary delegation composed of aboriginal lawmakers, and Foreign Affairs Minister Eugene Chien, have visited Kiribati, located in the South Pacific.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION DEBATE TO BE AIRED SIMULTANEOUSLY ON HAKKA TV

TEXT.P: The first of two televised debates between the two presidential candidates will be broadcast simultaneously Saturday in the Hakka language and in Mandarin.

Channel 17 will provide simultaneous translation of the two-hour debate between President Chen Shui-bian and Chairman Lien Chan of the opposition Kuomintang Saturday afternoon between 2 p.m. and 4 p.m. to serve the Hakka community, who account for 20 percent of Taiwan's 23 million people.

Yeh Chu-lan, chairman of the Council for Hakka Affairs, said that prior to the establishment in July last year of the Hakka-language TV channel that will air Taiwan's first-ever debate between presidential candidates, non-Mandarin-speaking Hakka people were shut out of the world of TV communication.

Yeh noted that because of the government's Mandarin-speaking campaign of the past, the Hakka language is fast disappearing and among Hakka people between the ages of 13 and 29, only 36.3 percent can still speak fluent Hakka, while the figure is only 11.7 percent among those under 13.
At the same time, however, there are many elderly Hakka people who are unable to understand Mandarin, Yeh said.
The situation made some initial improvement after the council began promoting Hakka-related activities and launched the Hakka TV channel, Yeh said.

Council officials said that the launch of the channel has enabled younger Hakka people to learn more about the language and its culture, while older members of the community can now enjoy television in their own tongue, which they had not been able to do previously.
The channel has also enhanced the understanding among non-Hakka people of the beauty of Hakka culture and has provided an opportunity to learn the language, the officials said.

The first simultaneous Hakka broadcast of the presidential candidate debate will also allow elderly Hakka voters who do not speak Mandarin to participate in this major democratic event in Taiwan's history, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS REVENUE AT SCIENCE PARK IN CENTRAL TAIWAN TO HIT NT$120 B.

TEXT.P: Production value of the Central Taiwan Science-based Industrial Park in Taichung is expected to hit around NT$120 billion (about US$3.6 billion) in 2006, fueled by ongoing expansion as a result of the rebounding economy, park authorities said Friday.

Yang Wen-ker, a deputy director of the preparatory committee for the park's development, said that the 153 hectares of available land in the park's first-phase compound has been allocated following robust demand from companies based there and that an expansion has been mulled to meet further demand.

For the time being, an additional 86 hectares of land in the second-phase compound will become available in June for plant construction, while efforts to court investment for land development at its compound in Huwei, in neighboring Yunlin County, will also kick off in the near future, as an environmental impact assessment has recently gained approval, Yang said.

Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i told the Cabinet-level National Science Council last week in a meeting with officials from the central coordination office of the Executive Yuan that to consider acquiring extra land for a planned expansion at the hi-tech industrial park in central Taiwan.

The Central Taiwan Science-based Industrial Park will eventually occupy a total of 430 hectares of land. Since its inception more than a year ago, 38 companies -- mainly in the hi-tech sector -- have been approved to open shop in the compound, channeling more than NT$430 billion in investment into the park.
The output value of the park is expected to reach NT$120 billion by 2006 after companies operating there start mass production, Yang predicted.

At the same time, the production value of the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park (HSIP) in northern Taiwan has been estimated to top NT$1.3 trillion for 2004, based on the fact that its business revenue amounted to NT$857.8 billion for 2003, up by 22 percent over its 2002 level.
The HSIP -- Taiwan's most representative industrial park -- is the first one of its kind designed solely to house hi-tech companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIKEABLE PERSONALITY TOP ATTRACTION FOR HI-TECH SINGLES: POLL

TEXT.P: A likeable personality and being "easy to communicate with" are the two personality traits that wealthy young singles in the high-technology sector consider most attractive when seeking relationships, according to the results of an opinion poll.
The poll, conducted by the 104 Job Bank, also found that "shared values" is important to those polled.
Being beautiful or handsome is not so important for a date who might potentially become a spouse, according to the respondents to the poll conducted days before Valentine's Day on Feb. 14.
Financial strength and religious affiliation are two issues considered least important, according to the results of the poll.

The poll found that 56 percent of Taiwan's hi-tech professionals are currently single. Of them, 55.2 percent rely on "dating arrangements" made by friends or relatives for getting to know a member of the opposite sex, while 54.9 percent opt for parties.

The poll also found that 38.2 percent of the respondents are not opposed to "office affairs" or picking up dates at their workplaces. Some 32.3 percent surf the Internet for friends and only 4 percent said they would choose to marry a foreign girl introduced by marriage service companies.

On the careers of potential spouses, over half of the respondents said this is not an important factor. Some 22 percent said teachers would be a good choice and 21 percent said civil servants would be preferable. Nineteen percent said it would be excellent if spouses had the same career, the poll found.

On how to sharpen their competitiveness in the "love arena, " 70 percent said broadening their social circle is the best way, followed by improving communication techniques (66 percent) , changing appearance and developing a sense of style (44 percent) and shifting to a less time-consuming job (23 percent), the poll found.
The poll, conducted Feb. 4-6 via the Internet, received 1,426 valid responses and had a margin of error of 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENTS SHOULD BE INVOLVED IN CROSS-STRAIT DISEASE CONTROL: MAC

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Friday that government authorities should be involved in cross-Taiwan Strait efforts to prevent and control communicable diseases, if such bilateral efforts are undertaken.

MAC Vice Chairman Huang Chieh-cheng welcomed Friday Beijing's calls two days earlier for cross-strait cooperation in efforts to contain the spread of avian flu, but said that private groups would find it difficult to implement any such efforts without government assistance.

Huang said that the MAC welcomes all efforts that contribute to enhancing the welfare of the people of both sides of the Taiwan Strait and called for the Beijing authorities to come to the negotiating table for talks over bird flu prevention and control, as well as any other health issue.

Zhang Mingqing, spokesman for Beijing's Taiwan Affairs Office, said at a regular press conference Wednesday that Taiwan and mainland China should make concerted efforts to contain the spread of avian flu that has affected 10 countries and areas in Asia.

Zhang said that at a time when the "virulent" form of bird flu has been found in both Taiwan and on the mainland, both sides should step up bilateral cooperation in efforts to ward off the communicable disease.
In fact, while the H5N1 strain of avian flu has been found on the mainland, it has not been found in Taiwan.

Zhang called for the establishment of a disease-reporting channel across the Taiwan Strait. He also urged that the two sides to speed up exchanges on bird flu prevention. Efforts would include the holding of academic seminars or teleconferences that would pave the way for cross-strait exchanges on medication, medical knowledge and related vaccination materials for bird flu prevention and control.

Meanwhile, Huang also called for the Beijing authorities to save themselves the effort of trying to tamper with Taiwan's presidential election by constantly releasing reports on Taiwanese citizens being arrested on the mainland for spying.

The spate of reports of Taiwanese being arrested on charges of collecting intelligence for the Taiwan authorities has led the MAC to believe that Beijing is using this as a scheme to alter the process and results of Taiwan's presidential election slated for March 20, Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN AUTHORITIES CONVENE DISEASE-PREVENTION MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Kinmen, Feb. 13 (CNA) (By K.Y. Ni and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Kinmen county government convened a disease-prevention meeting Friday aimed at strengthening the outlying island's ability to ward off communicable diseases that could threaten the health of either humans or animals.

Presiding over the meeting, Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng said that in the face of an escalating number of reported infections of the virulent H5N1 avian flu virus in 10 Asian countries, Kinmen, which is located some 24 kilometers off mainland China's coast and relies heavily on imports for its daily necessities, will have to step up food safety and animal quarantine checks.

Although Kinmen has not reported any cases of the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) that wreaked havoc in Asia, particularly in Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China, last year and no avian flu so far this year, this does not mean that those diseases will never take Kinmen hostage, Lee said.

The meeting decided that officials from the Kinmen bureaus of health, education and social affairs should take turns to report on health controls, particularly temperature-taking among schoolchildren, to the Kinmen county government once each week.

The meeting also decided that Yang Chun-jen, director of the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine (BAPHIQ) under the Council of Agriculture, Kinmen Office, should report to the county government once per week on efforts as regards bird flu prevention and control.

Separated from mainland China's Fujian Province by only a narrow channel, Kinmen suffered a foot-and-mouth disease outbreak among its cattle some five years ago. The disease is believed to have been brought into Kinmen via livestock smuggled from the mainland.
On Dec. 9 last year, six live red-faced ducks were caught by Kinmen authorities on a beach in Hsiyuan in northeastern Kinmen during an anti-smuggling operation, BAPHIQ officials said.

The ducks, also believed to have been smuggled from the mainland, were destroyed after BAPHIQ officials took samples from the animals and discovered that the deadly H5N1 virus was present in one of the six ducks, prompting the county government to announce Feb. 6 that all imports of live poultry, frozen poultry and related products will be controlled and screened during a nearly 11-month period beginning that day as part of the local government's efforts to ward off a spread of avian flu.

DOC.HEADLINE: G-10 GROUP MEETS WITH SPECIAL PRODUCTS UNION AHEAD OF DOHA RESUMPTION

TEXT.P: Taiwan and other members of the G-10 Group are actively seeking cooperation with other groups within the World Trade Organization (WTO) to consolidate their common positions when the Doha Round trade talks resume.
The G-10 Group members are Taiwan, Bulgaria, Israel, Iceland, Japan, Mauritius, Norway, Switzerland, South Korea and Liechtenstein.
It is expected that the Doha Round of trade negotiations will be resumed next month with agriculture to be a key topic of the discussions.

According to sources close to Taiwan's permanent mission to the WTO, the G-10 Group met with a 42-country "Special Products Union" for the first time at a meeting held Thursday to express its hope of forming a common front to gain the maximum benefits for themselves in the Doha trade negotiations.

Yen Ching-chang, Taiwan's permanent representative to the WTO, suggested at the meeting that agricultural experts from the two groups study the feasibility of establishing cooperation between the two sides.

Explaining the current situation of Taiwan's agricultural sector and the island's stance for the negotiations, Yen said the G-10 Group should unite with the "Special Products Union" in order to form a stronger group in the upcoming trade talks.

Sources also revealed that the G-10 countries are also planning to meet with their rivals in the agricultural negotiations -- namely the United States and the European Union -- in the hopes that Washington and Brussels can gain a better understanding of the G-10 Group's goals and concerns regarding future agricultural talks.

Claiming that their "special products" should be given special protection and treatment, the "Special Products Union" is an organization of developing countries, while the G-10 Group is keen on issues regarding market access and non-trade concerns. The group also considers that sensitive products should be better protected. (B C.H. Lu and P.C. Tang)

DOC.HEADLINE: MIAOLI DECIDES TO SEPARATE ELECTION, REFERENDUM POLLING STATIONS

TEXT.P: The northern county of Miaoli has decided to separate polling stations for the presidential election and the referendum vote, both of which are scheduled to be held March 20, local government sources reported Friday.

Ku Chen-ching, chairman of the Miaoli County Election Commission, said the commission decided to let Miaoli voters cast their ballots for the presidential election and the referendum at different polling stations based on the notion that different laws apply to the two events.
Ku said the move is aimed at reducing any risks, simplifying the procedures for casting ballots, and allowing the voting to be carried out smoothly.

He said that his commission reached consensus with its counterpart in the south-central county of Yunlin Thursday and that the Yunlin commission will soon announce its decision to have separate polling stations.
Ku said that if the move to separate the polling stations is not accepted by the Central Election Commission (CEC), he will take full responsibility.

Meanwhile, Chen Wu-hsiung, chairman of the Yunlin County Election Commission, said around noon that his commission has not yet decided whether to adopt a policy different from the CEC regulations by separating its polling stations for the presidential vote and the referendum.

Commenting on Miaoli county's plans to separate the polling stations, CEC Chairman Huang Shih-cheng said Friday that all local governments should follow the regulations put forth by the CEC with regard to election and voting affairs.
Premier Yu Shyi-kun called for all relevant local government authorities to observe the CEC regulations in the upcoming presidential election and Taiwan's first-ever referendum.
Any local governments or civil servants that violate the CEC regulations will be dealt with squarely and will be legally responsible for their actions, Yu added.

The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party urged the Miaoli County to immediately withdraw its plan for separate polling stations, saying that the plan risks causing social and political chaos and that it will increase election costs.

The DPP legislative caucus members also called for the opposition "pan-blue alliance" not to instigate local governments to oppose to the central government and in turn harvest ill-gotten political gains from the elections.
Meanwhile, Wang Jin-pyng, president of the Legislative Yuan, said separating the presidential election polling stations from the referendum voting stations is a policy that is "absolutely correct."

Wang, also a campaign manager for the opposition "pan-blue alliance" ticket of Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong, said the CEC should be enlightened by Miaoli County's move and follow suit.
"I believe that the policy will be supported and recognized by the majority of the Taiwan voters," Wang said.

Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, also a senior campaign aide of the opposition "pan-blue alliance, " said that he fully understands why the Miaoli election commission has opted for separate polling stations. He said having separate polling stations can help to keep disputes and controversy to the lowest possible level.
Ma, however, declined to say whether Taipei City will follow suit.

1973: Minister of Economic Affairs Y. S. Sun of the ROC leaves for Bangkok to attend a meeting of the board of trustees of the Asian Institute of Technology and meet with Thai government officials.
1975: The ROC Cabinet decides to ban activities of the Christian Unification Church on the grounds that it has been violating the customs of the Chinese people.
1975: The Sino-Guatemalan and the Sino-Dominican technical cooperation agreements are approved by the ROC Cabinet.
1984: The Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party elects Constantin Ustinovich Chernenko as its secretary-general.

DOC.HEADLINE: BITTER CUSTODY DISPUTE OVER IRUAN WU ENDS WITH RECONCILIATION
DOC.DATELINE: Canoas, Brazil, Feb. 13 (CNA) (By S.Y. Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A long and bitter dispute over custody of a Taiwanese-Brazilian boy has finally been ended with a conciliation between his relatives from the two countries.

Iruan Ergui Wu, an 8-year-old Taiwanese-Brazilian orphan, accompanied by some of his Taiwanese relatives and a Taiwanese lawyer, arrived in Canoas Friday and was immediately handed over to his grandmother, Rosa Leocadia de Silva Ergui.

The custody dispute happened after the boy's mother died when he was three and his Taiwanese father, a fishing boat captain, also passed away just few days after he took the boy back to the island to visit relatives in March 2001.

Although the boy then lived with his uncle's family in Taiwan, the island's highest court decided that the boy should be sent to his Brazilian grandmother. The grandmother had been granted custody by a court in Brazil long ago.

According to the reconciliation of the boy's Taiwanese and Brazilian relatives who met with each other Friday at the Martin Luther Lutheran Community School in the city, they agreed that the boy will be allowed to continue learning Chinese as well as being allowed to have an one-day meeting with his Taiwanese relatives before they leave for Taiwan.
The boy went to the school's kindergarten before he went to Taiwan with his father and it is expected that he will resume classes at the same school next month.
The relatives also agreed to have further discussions on issues regarding the boy's possible return to Taiwan for a visit as well a service for his late father.
But the boy's Taiwanese relatives now said that it's all up to the boy to decide if he wants to return to Taiwan for a visit next year or a bit later.
