DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ENCOURAGES TAIWANESE-BRAZILIAN BOY TO BE STRONG AND BRAVE
DOC.DATELINE: Canoas, Brazil, Feb. 13 (CNA) (By S.Y. Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has sent a letter to Iruan Ergui Wu, the 8-year-old Taiwanese-Brazilian orphan who was at the center of an international custody dispute, to encourage him to be strong and brave in facing his new life in Brazil.
On behalf of the president, Chou Kuo-rey, Taiwan's representative to Brazil, passed on the letter to the boy Friday.
The president also reminded the boy to remember that he will always have good wishes and the blessing of the people of Taiwan.

"I know that Taiwan and Brazil have lovely people and beautiful landscapes and I also know that your relatives in both countries are concerned about you, " Chen said in the three-page letter, adding that, "I hope you become a bridge between these two beautiful countries."
Saying that life is made up of many meetings and partings and that life's changes are just like changes in of nature, the president told the boy that growing up entails experiencing various things.

He also encouraged the boy to courageously challenge the difficulties he might face in the future, saying that a brave man can create his own destiny and that everyone should be the author of his own fate.
After ending a bitter custody dispute between his Taiwanese and Brazilian relatives, the boy arrived in Canoas Friday to start his new life with his grandmother, Rosa Leocadia de Silva Ergui.

The dispute occurred after the boy's Brazilian mother died when he was three and his Taiwanese father, a fishing boat captain, also died only a few days after he took the boy back to Taiwan to visit relatives in March 2001.

Despite the fact that the boy then lived with the family of his uncle, Wu Huo-yen, in Taiwan, the island's highest court decided that the boy should be handed over to his Brazilian grandmother. The grandmother had been awarded custody in a court in Brazil long ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN PROMOTES AT LEAST 50 YEARS OF CROSS-STRAIT PEACE

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan on Saturday advocated the establishment of a peaceful cross-Taiwan Strait relationship and the pursuit of peace across the strait for at least 50 years.

The sole challenger to President Chen Shui-bian's re-election bid in the March 20 election made the remarks in the first of two televised debates between presidential candidates in Taiwan' history. The second debate will be next Saturday.
"In this way both sides of the Taiwan Strait could base exchanges on the principles of equality and cooperation to achieve a win-win situation," Lien said.
Lien also appealed to voters to give him a chance to return to the helm of the nation.

"For those who have obtained power but have shown that they are incapable of ruling, or have even make the country corrupt - along with the leaders - the voters need to give the ruling party a chance to reflect on what they have done, " Lien said, indicating that the way for this to happen would be for the people to vote out the current administration.

Lien also said that the people should "let the KMT that failed [in the 2000 presidential race] again serve the people" since the party had gone through " excruciating soul-searching and self-examination."

Lien also said that an ideal government leader should take responsibility, and "not blame international factors because of poor domestic economic performance, not to put the blame on the legislature for internal political instability, and not to blame the KMT and People First Party (PFP) for stalled cross-strait relations." PFP Chairman James Soong is Lien's running mate.

"If there is no difference whether you are present or not, why should people select you as a president? " Lien asked, meaning that the president's blame of others is as if he were not even present to take responsibility.

Lien promised to establish a government of integrity and efficiency if elected to regain the faith and trust of the people, saying that the Lien-Soong ticket will not be the resurrection of the old guard, but "the beginning of a new era."
Lien also urged both sides of the Taiwan Strait to put aside disputes on sovereignty to seek development and prosperity on both sides.

Lien said that President Chen had said in his inaugural speech that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should deal with the issue of a future "one China, " but recently he had advocated "one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait, " and the writing of a new constitution as well as giving Taiwan its "correct name."
Lien criticized Chen for being "inconsistent" and "foundering along the way" in cross-strait policy.
Lien stressed that his basic stance will be to put aside disputes on sovereignty between the two sides and jointly enhance bilateral exchanges to promote economic development.

"If one has to talk about 'one China, ' then the 'one China' will be the Republic of China, the country where we were born, and where we grow and that which we love the most, not a sneaking 'one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait.'"

He also vowed to promote ethnic harmony, and language equality if elected, so that all ethnic groups in Taiwan will be first-class citizens and no ethnic groups will be superior or inferior to other ones.
"The government should also take good care of aboriginal people, as they are the underprivileged, " and their jobs and health care require the government's attention.
In the earlier question-and-answer session, Lien vowed not to interfere in the personnel arrangements in heading state-controlled enterprises.
He said that the heads of the state-owned enterprises will only take professionalism into consideration, and he will likewise.
Lien also expressed his views on the nation's Constitution, tax policy, the rising national debt as well as education reform.
Lien said that before the present Constitution is reconsidered, one must respect it, as it is the basic law.

But as to what kind of system the country should adopt, a presidential system, or a cabinet one with the premier as its highest national leader, or dual leadership system could be left for future discussion.
On the widening gap between the rich and the poor, Lien said that the incumbent government should take the greatest responsibility.
He said that the income of the top category used to be four or five times that of the lowest category in the past, but after the new administration took office, the ratio has jumped to six fold.

Questioned about the rising debt of the nation, Lien said that he was sure that tax revenues will grow dramatically if there is an annual 5 percent economic growth rate. He would also advocate the adjustment of the tax system, upgrade the efficiency in implementing the budget, commission the private sector for government works, and streamline government organizations.
"After all these are done, I believe that the national budget could be balanced in six years," Lien said,

Lien also said that the premium 18 percent interest rate for the deposits of military personnel, civil servants and teachers have their historical background, but that laborers, fishermen and farmers should also be taken care of.
Lien denied that the KMT and PFP have obstructed judicial reforms, saying that the two parties have worked together to promote the revision of civil, criminal and administrative laws.
He also said that the litigation period should be shortened to 180 days, and the correct verdict should be increased to 90 percent, as well as the establishment of an independent prosecutor.
He also described the controversial "education reform" as a "fiasco, " because there are no comprehensive considerations and too much rashness in promoting lofty ideals.
He promised to increase education expenditures if elected to help the poor and nurture more talented people.

On the multiple options to enter universities, Lien advocated that 30 percent of entries be selected through a screening and recommendation system, while 70 percent be through a joint entrance examination system.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL DEBATE A VICTORY FOR DEMOCRACY: SCHOLARS

TEXT.P: The first presidential debate held Saturday between President Chen Shui-bian, who is seeking reelection in the March 20 presidential election, and his challenger, chairman of the Kuomintang, Lien Chan, was a victory for democracy, scholars said.

Ku Chung-hua, a professor in sociology at National Chengchih University, said that both Chen and Lien showed a democratic manner in the debate not only in the way they spoke but also in their body language.
The debate, which was the first of its kind ever held in Taiwan, has set a milestone in the country's democratic development, he noted.

Echoing Ku's comment, Chu Yun-peng, a professor in economics at National Central University, said that the two participants in the debate did appropriately express the sentiments of their respective supporters on national issues.
Chen Yu-wen, president of the Taiwan Debate Society, said that the televised debate set a good example for electoral campaigns in Taiwan and had given the general public a good lesson on democracy.

However, Chien Hsi-chieh, convener of the "pan-purple alliance, " which is composed mainly of underprivileged and social, welfare groups, criticized the two participants of the debate for avoiding replying concretely to some questions, although he admitted that the cross-fire of words was a success in terms of its smooth process.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-DONATED RICE DELIVERED TO IRAN

TEXT.P: The 2,500 tons of rice donated by the Republic of China government was delivered to Iran from the Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan Saturday by an Iranian cargo ship.
The rice was donated by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture to help victims of a magnitude-6.7 earthquake that rocked the historic Iranian city of Bam late last December.

The Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation -- Taiwan's largest charity which has sent volunteers to assist in post-disaster relief work in the southeastern Iranian city since early January, arranged for the delivery of the rice. Fifteen Tzu Chi volunteers assisted in loading the rice onto the Iranian freighter.
A Tzu Chi spokesman said its volunteers in Bam will also assist in distributing the rice to earthquake victims when the rice arrives in Iran in early March.
The aid program is expected to meet the rice needs of more than 80,000 quake victims in Bam for the coming three months, the spokesman said.

Despite the absence of formal diplomatic relations between the two countries, the Republic of China government has donated US$100,000 in post-quake relief aid to Iran, in addition to sending a 61-member rescue team to assist in relief operations immediately after the Dec. 26 earthquake.

The ROC Red Cross Society also collected 30 tons of relief goods, including jackets, blankets, wool socks and wool hats, as well as various types of winter garments, for Iranian quake victims. The goods were delivered by a China Airlines cargo plan in early January.
More than 26,000 Bam residents were killed and at least 30,000 others injured in the earthquake.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINES

TEXT.P: New York Times: Bush acts against critics on guard records and 9/11.

U.S. President Bush moved on Friday night to try to stem potentially damaging election-year questions about his military record and whether the White House mishandled intelligence threats before the Sept. 11 attacks.

The White House said it had decided to rele ase all documents from the president's National Guard files and, within hours, disclosed that Bush would appear before a commission investigating the terrorist attacks.
Wall Street Journal: Friday deadline passes for AT&T wireless bids.

As the deadline for bids to buy AT&T Wireless Services Inc. came and went late Friday, Cingular Wireless submitted a bid that was significantly higher than its original $30 billion offer, according to people familiar with the situation. Cingular's bid was believed to be roughly $34 billion.
Also on Friday, NTT DoCoMo Inc.'s board ruled out a bid for the company, but is still involved in the process since it owns 17.1% of AT&T Wireless.

Cingular has been seen as the early front-runner, already putting in an informal $30 billion, all-cash bid for AT&T Wireless. A decision by Vodafone on whether to pursue AT&T Wireless has been complicated by its 45% ownership stake in Verizon Wireless, which it would have to divest before acquiring AT&T Wireless.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Cabinet chaos over curbs on new Europeans.
Prime Minister Tony Blair has abandoned attempts to deter East European workers from entering Britain after a week of turmoil, confusion and Cabinet splits over immigration policy.
Financial Times: 10m facing extra NI bill after tax blunder.
More than 10m people - a quarter of the working-age population - are to be asked by the Inland Revenue if they are willing to pay hundreds of pounds in extra National Insurance contributions, because of a blunder that jeopardises their right to the full basic state pension.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN SAYS REFORMS MUST CONTINUE WITH HIS REELECTION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Saturday urged continued reforms and another four years of mandate for him in the first televised presidential debate in Taiwan's history.

Chen opened his allotted eight-minute speech in the more than two-hour debate against his sole challenger, Lien Chan, chairman of the Kuomintang, by wishing all couples around the world the best on Valentine's Day.
He also said that, "As a national leader, I have the responsibility toward this land, the 23 million people on Taiwan and their future offspring.
"To better the nation's economy and its major reforms so that Taiwan can become a normal, complete, great and beautiful country is also my responsibility," the president said.
He then shifted gears and began to lash out at the corruption of the past regimes to contrast the difference between the new and old administrations.

"For the past five decades, it has been clear that the rampant corruption of 'black gold' politics, the mixing together of the nation and the party, and an unjust judicial system have gradually undermined the nation's foundation," he said.

He asked the voters to think back -- would it have been possible if there had been no political changeover four years ago to have a neutral military and uncover a secret slush fund under the National Security Bureau?

Chen also said that because of the political changeover, those people who became embroiled in embezzlement scandals, instead of fleeing the country, might still be surrounding Lien and his running mate, James Soong, chairman of the People First Party.
"We sincerely hope that people believe in Taiwan and insist on reforms," the president stressed.

"We take reforms as religion, but some have the habit of making them something only to talk about and not to do -- this is something that we cannot countenance, " the president said, adding that a privileged few have made abnormal loans to hollow out banks to the tune of NT$2.5 trillion (US$75.528 billion).
The opposition parties are not helping; in fact, they are actually obstructing the reforms, the president continued.

He pointed to the financial reconstruction fund -- created to help write off the bad debt -- which has until now been unable to clear the legislature because of opposition resistance. He also said that the opposition parties are opposed to reform that would halve the number of seats in the Legislative Yuan from the current 225, and are also against the regulation of ill-gotten assets of political parties and sunshine bills.
"We really can't understand why a person would be opposed to the reforms, " he said. "How can we better the economy by opposing the reforms?" he asked.

He said that instead of people huddling together and cursing the president if they are in a tough situation, they should encouraged those who are without jobs to stand up for a fresh start, which he said is the major difference between himself and Lien.

Chen said that people born into adversity harbor the fairest ideals, and that this is the spirit of Taiwan, knowing that "we can have unlimited possibilities in limited conditions and the worst environment."

Chen reaffirmed his belief in Taiwan and his insistence on reforms, and appealed to voters to give him and his running mate, Annette Lu, another four years, saying, "We have conviction and are also most resistant to pressure."

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION CANDIDATE LIEN URGES ELECTORATE TO VOTE FOR CHANGE

TEXT.P: Taiwan needs a change and needs a national leader with a steady, reliable and sincere character to lead it to a safe, secure and peaceful environment, the opposition "pan-blue alliance's" presidential candidate said Saturday.

Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan made the call in his opening remarks in a televised debate with his sole contender in the March 20 presidential election -- President Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Lien, a former vice president, said the upcoming election is not just aimed at choosing a president, a ruling party or a governing team. "The most important thing is to choose an attitude," he noted.

Claiming that Taiwan has lagged far behind many other Asian countries in economic globalization and liberalization under Chen's leadership over the past four years, Lien said it's high time for Taiwan to change its leadership.
In the face of a quickly changing international environment, Lien said Taiwan needs a clean, effective, efficient and competent governing team to survive fierce global competition.

Stressing that the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) has crafted many feasible and forward-looking policy initiatives, Lien said he hopes people will vote for him and his running mate, PFP Chairman James Soong, in the upcoming election to usher in a second transition of political power and a new era in Taiwan's development.
"We must vote for a change. A leadership change will bring new opportunities and new hopes. We should not miss the chance, " Lien said in his opening remarks in the two-hour debate.
Lien also criticized Chen for his frequent policy flips-flops, citing as examples an abrupt suspension of the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant and a later resumption of the project under pressure.
"We need a steady and sincere national leader, not a president who often changes his policies," Lien said.
In his speech, Lien also ridiculed Chen for his inclination to blame the "pan-blue alliance"-controlled Legislative Yuan for flawed policy enforcement or delays in implementing his reform agenda.

"A national leader should seek ways out in difficult situations. You can't always pass the buck for your administration's failures, " Lien said, adding that the legislature can never boycott a capable administrative team's operations.

The live TV debate was the first of its kind ever held in Taiwan. The event was jointly organized by Public Television Service (PTS), the Taipei Society, the China Times, the United Daily News, the Liberty Times and the Taiwan Daily.
In addition to the PTS, 11 other local TV stations and five radio stations broadcast the debate live.
The debate started with each candidate delivering an eight-minute speech on their vision for the nation's future and major policy initiatives.
Their opening remarks were followed by a question-and-answer session, with five representatives from various walks of life posing questions to the two.

The five were Huang Kun-yen of the Medical Education Committee under the Ministry of Education, Chu Ching-yi of the nation's highest research institute, Academia Sinica, Lin Ching-ping, executive director of a private judicial reform committee, Wang Jung-chang, spokesman of the "pan-purple alliance, " which is comprised mainly of underprivileged and social welfare groups, and political professor Wang Yeh-li of Tunghai University.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST OF TWO TELEVISED PRESIDENTIAL DEBATES OPENS

TEXT.P: The first of two televised debates in more than half of a century in Taiwan was held Saturday between the two men running for president.
Wu Feng-shan, chairman of the Public Television Service, one of the sponsors, presided over the debate that began at 2 p.m.
President Chen Shui-bian, who is seeking re-election in the March 20 presidential election, and his challenger, chairman of the Kuomintang, Lien Chan, each opened with an eight-minute speech.
Five representatives from various walks of life posed questions to the two.

The five were Huang Kun-yen of the Medical Education Committee under the Ministry of Education, Chu Ching-yi of the nation's highest research institute, Academia Sinica, Lin Ching-ping, executive director of a private judicial reform committee, Wang Jung-chang, spokesman of the "pan-purple alliance, " which is comprised mainly of underprivileged and social welfare groups, and political professor Wang Yeh-li of Tunghai University.

Wu said that to maintain neutrality and objectivity, the sponsors and the media were not allowed to take part in the question-and-answer session. The five representatives were recommended and selected using this guideline. They were chosen to represent the areas of medical education, the economy, judicial reforms, social welfare and politics.
After the question-and-answer session, the candidates put five questions to each other after an intermission of 15 minutes. The candidates concluded with another eight-minute speech.
The Public Television Service aired the debate live and cooperated with Chunghwa Telecom who provided a live Web feed.
Four terrestrial TV stations and several news stations also broadcasted the debate live. The debate also aired simultaneously on Channel 17, which is a Hakka-language channel.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PRESS OFFICER IN CHICAGO EXPLAINS PURPOSE OF PLANNED REFERENDUM
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 13 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A Republic of China press officer stationed in Chicago recently sent a letter to the Chicago Herald to explain the purpose of Taiwan's planned referendum, saying that the referendum is to further promote the island's democracy.
President Chen Shui-bian and his ruling Democratic Progressive Party government have decided to hold a referendum in conjunction with the presidential election set for this March 20.

The president also announced Jan. 16 in a pre-taped TV broadcast to the nation that he will ask the people of Taiwan to decide in the proposed referendum whether the nation should further strengthen its anti-missile defense capabilities in response to mainland China's ever-increasing missile deployment and whether it should try to work out a peace interaction mechanism with mainland China.

In his letter published by the newspaper Thursday, Ben Shao, director of the information division of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Chicago, said that the 23 million people of Taiwan, who are on the front line facing a potential cross-Taiwan Strait conflict, prefer to maintain the current status quo as much as anyone in the world.
Shao also stated in the letter that to solicit other nations' pressure against Taiwan's proposed referendum, Beijing is deliberately misinterpreting its purpose.

"The nature of Taiwan's coming referendum, the first in its history, is not provocative, as China labels it, but reactive to China's aggressive stance," the director explained, adding that, "The world should urge China to back off terrorizing Taiwan.
"After all, the purpose of the referendum is simply to expand and deepen Taiwan's young democracy, " the official concluded in the letter.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES CONDUCT HISTORIC LIVE TV DEBATE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and his sole challenger Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan conducted a televised debate Saturday.
Public Television Service (PTS) Chairman Wu Feng-shan, who chaired the debate, said in opening remarks that the event marks a big step forward in Taiwan's political development.

"We are grateful for the two presidential hopefuls' participation iin the debate. It may be a small step for both of you, but it's a giant step in our country's development," Wu said. The event marked the first time that the nation's presidential candidates have ever conducted live TV debates.
It was the first of two televised debates to be held ahead of the March 20 presidential election. The second debate is scheduled to take place Feb. 21.

The first debate was jointly organized by PTS, the Taipei Society, the China Times, the Liberty Times, the United Daily News, and the Taiwan Daily. Meanwhile, 11 local television stations and five radio stations broadcast the debate live. The debate was also broadcast live on the Internet.

The debate started at 2 p.m. and lasted for two hours. Five people posed 10 questions to the two contenders. The five were Huang Kun-yen, a microbiologist who is now chairman of the Ministry of Education's Medical Education Commission; Chu Ching-yi, an Academia Sinica academician; Lin Ching-ping, chief executive of the private Judicial Reform Promotion Association; Wang Jung-chang, spokesman for the "pan-purple alliance, " which is dedicated to promoting fairness and social justice; and Wang Yeh-li, a Tung Hai University political science professor.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Feb. 14, or the 24th day of the first month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1766: Thomas R. Malthus, the British economist who wrote "An Essay on the Principle of Population," is born. His 1798 work argues that populations tend to increase faster than food supplies unless the increase is checked by moral restraints or by war, famine, or disease.
1779: Captain James Cook, the British navigator and explorer who commanded three major voyages of "discovery," charting and "naming" many islands in the Pacific Ocean, is killed by a native's spear in Hawaii.
1797: British naval forces under Admiral John Jervis and Captain Horatio Nelson defeat the Spanish fleet off Portugal's Cape St. Vincent.
1859: Oregon becomes the 33rd state of the United States.
1893: Hawaii is annexed to the United States by a treaty.
1912: Arizona becomes the 48th state of the United States.
1924: Thomas John Watson, the U.S. industrialist who worked for the National Cash Register Company (now NCR Corporation) for 15 years, is made president of a company that later becomes International Business Machines Corporation (IBM).
1933: The League of Nations refuses to recognize the Japanese puppet regime known as "Manchukuo." To deflect world condemnation of their hegemony, the Japanese invaders of northern China installed the Manchukuo regime in 1932. This "land of the Manchu" proved to be no more than another stepping stone for the extension of Japanese aggression.
1939: The German battleship Bismarck is launched.
1950: The Chinese communist regime and the Soviet Union sign the "Sino-Soviet Friendly Alliance and Mutual Assistance Treaty" in Moscow.
1956: Soviet President Nikita Khrushchev denounces the policies of Joseph Stalin at the 20th Congress of the Soviet Communist Party.
1962: General Hu Chung-nan, strategic adviser to President Chiang Kai-shek, dies in Taipei at the age of 68.
1972: Mexico establishes diplomatic relations with mainland China.
1972: The Soviet Union launches its Luna 20 spacecraft to the moon.
1972: Washington relaxes trade restrictions against Beijing, putting it on the same basis as Moscow.
1973: Walter Benche Medina, newly-appointed ambassador of El Salvador, arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
1974: A six-member Jordanian trade mission led by S.A. Matouk, president of the Amman Chamber of Commerce, arrives in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1974: Commissioner W. Stanley Cottrill, international secretary of the Salvation Army International Headquarters, leaves Taipei after a three-day visit.
1975: The Marinas Islands in the Pacific becomes a territory of the United States.
1977: Shih Wei-liang, a noted Republic of China musician, dies in Taipei at the age of 54.
1989: Ayatollah Khomeini, Iran's religious leader, issues a "fatwa," or death sentence, against British writer Salman Rushdie for what he deemed to be blasphemy in the author's book "The Satanic Verses," sending him into years of hiding.
1999: Former Nixon White House aide John Ehrlichman dies at the age of 73. He served 18 months in prison for his role in the Watergate cover-up.
2000: President Lee Teng-hui confers the Order of the Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on Cor Boonstra, president of Royal Philips Electronics, in recognition of his company's contribution to Taiwan's economic development.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian says that he will visit Beijing and invite mainland Chinese leaders to visit Taipei if he wins the March 18 election.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Earnestness without judgment becomes pedantry; caution without judgment becomes timidity; courage without judgment leads to crime; uprightness without judgment makes men tyrannical."

DOC.TEXT:
The Manila Bulletin: P13-B drugs seized in 6 months. Interior and Local Government Secretary Jose Lina Jr., Dangerous Drugs Board (DDB) chairman, reported yesterday that the government has seized more than P13 billion worth of "shabu" and ephedrine in six months of antinarcotics operations.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: SC: We're not cowed by Poe's supporters. ASSERTING its role as the last bulwark of democracy, the Supreme Court said Sunday that it was not at all cowed by supporters of Fernando Poe Jr., who had warned of civil unrest should the SC rule against the opposition bet.
The Philippine Star: Gringo: Coup unnecessary. Opposition Sen. Gregorio "Gringo" Honasan said here yesterday any attempt by the military to destabilize the government and seize power at this time would be "totally unnecessary."
The Manila Times: Doubts grip FPJ allies. Local officials, especially those running in the May election, are reluctant to openly campaign for Fernando Poe Jr., Koalisyon ng Nagkakaisang Pilipino standard-bearer, and the rest of his ticket until the Supreme Court settles with finality the issue over Poe's citizenship.

DOC.TEXT:
Bangkok Post: Weekend toll: 3 dead, 6 wounded.
Four more people were attacked yesterday, capping off a weekend of bloody violence in South. (Francis Kuo)

DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Gunmen Raid Iraqi Police Post.
Masked men stormed an Iraqi police station,hurling grenades and pumping out machine-gun fire in a daylight street battle that killed at least 22 people and freed dozens of prisoners.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE FORMS TASK FORCE TO STUDY H5N1 STRAIN OF BIRD FLU VIRUS

TEXT.P: Singapore has formed a task force to carry out research into the H5N1 strain of the bird flu virus which has claimed several lives in Asia.
Health Minister Khaw Boon Wan said Sunday that conducting early research on the virus will greatly improve Singapore's ability to control a bird flu outbreak if it occurs.

Singapore's rapid response to the SARS outbreak was due to its early efforts to develop life sciences research, Khaw said, noting that soon after the outbreak, the Genome Institute managed to develop a method to detect the SARS virus.
"Had SARS occurred in Singapore a few years before we started the Life Science effort, I think our response would have been different," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE, JORDAN ON TRACK TO SIGN FTA BY JULY

TEXT.P: Singapore and Jordan are on track to sign a bilateral free trade agreement (FTA) by July of this year.
Both sides said this after visiting Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong met with Jordanian Prime Minister Faisal Al-Fayez in the Jordian capital of Amman on Sundday.
Goh is in Jordan on the second leg of his trip to the Middle East. It is the Singapore prime minister's first visit to Jordan.
Goh first proposed an FTA with Jordan in a letter to Jordanian King Abdullah II last June.
The two sides also discussed ways to strengthen their economic partnership, with Jordan keen to see more investments from Singaporean companies.
Jordan, which wants to become a technological and business hub in the Arab world, has been keen to model its development on Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A four-member parliamentary delegation will arrive in Taipei Tuesday for a six-day visit, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials said Monday.
The officials said that the delegation will be headed by Ernst Hinsken, chairman of the German parliament's Tourism Committee.

During the visit, the German lawmakers will visit the Legislative Yuan, the MOFA, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council and the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.
They will also tour cultural establishments and tourist spots around Taiwan before departing Feb. 22.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS ELECT CONVENERS OF LEGISLATIVE COMMITTEES

TEXT.P: Legislators elected the 36 conveners of the Legislative Yuan's 12 standing committees Monday, with three elected for each committee.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party won the lion's share of 13 seats, followed by 10 seats for the opposition Kuomintang, eight seats for the People First Party, three for the Taiwan Solidarity Union and the remaining two seats for independents.
The four parties and the independents have agreed to divide the seats between them largely in proportion to the number of seats they hold in the legislature.
The conveners serve as the chairmen of the committees.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN TO HEAD TO TAITUNG TO WOO ABORIGINAL VOTERS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is scheduled to head to the eastern county of Taitung Monday afternoon in an attempt to woo aboriginal voters from around Taiwan.
Some 10,000 representatives of various aboriginal tribes from around the island are expected to turn out to listen to Chen speak at a campaign rally at the Taitung Seaside Park Monday evening.
Under the slogan of seeking unity among Taiwan's ethnic groups, Chen is expected to speak about his aboriginal policies if re-elected for a second term.

This will mark the first large-scale campaign rally that Chen presides over among Taiwan's aboriginal citizens, most of whom were previously considered to be supporters of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) which ruled Taiwan for five decades until 2000.
Prior to the rally, Chen is scheduled to visit elders of the Puyuma Tribe, one of the major indigenous groups in eastern Taiwan, to seek their support.
Chen is also expected to meet with Tseng Wen-ke, a former stalwart of the opposition KMT who maintains solid connections with Taitung locals.

He is also slated to meet with Chen Chien-hsien, who is the chief secretary of Taitung County Assembly Speaker Wu Chun-li, currently the head of a supporters group for the "pan-blue alliance" presidential ticket of Lien Chan and James Soong.
The president's meetings with Tseng and Chen are considered to be another strategic move aimed at swaying supporters from the rival camp.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SARS RESPONSE LEVEL DOWNGRADED TO ZERO

TEXT.P: Taiwan's epidemic prevention mobilization level against severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) was downgraded to Level "Zero" from "A" Monday, according to an official of the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health (DOH).

CDC Deputy Director-General Shih Wen-yi said that the SARS Contingency Committee Task Force Group under the Executive Yuan decided to lower the mobilization level at its 17th meeting as no new SARS cases have been reported around the world since the world's most recent SARS patient was discharged from hospital Jan. 30.
The task force also decided to reduce the frequency of its regular meetings on prevention and control of the potentially deadly disease from twice per month to once per month, Shih went on.

However, he added that passengers from mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau should have their temperatures taken upon arrival and that middle and elementary schools, kindergartens and nurseries around the nation should continue to take their students' temperatures every day.
The DOH has classified four levels of SARS precaution -- Zero, A, B and C -- with C as the most stringent grade.
The task force raised the SARS precaution level from zero to "B" Dec. 17 after a military medical researcher was confirmed to have come down with the disease.

It downgraded the level back to "A" Jan. 1 after the patient, a 44-year-old researcher with the Institute of Preventive Medicine under the National Defense Medicine College, was released Dec. 30 from a Taipei hospital after receiving treatment for 13 days in an isolation ward.
The SARS response level was maintained at "A" because the status of a reported SARS case in the southern mainland Chinese city of Guangzhou remained unclear.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGAL COMPLAINTS FLY IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Two Kaohsiung city councilors filed complaints of vote-buying with prosecutors against KMT presidential candidate Lien Chan Monday, only to be accused of filing false charges by the chief of Lien's local campaign office.

Councilors Chao Tien-lin and Kang Yu-cheng lodged their complaint with the Prosecutor's Office at the Kaohsiung District Court, claiming that Lien attempted to buy votes Saturday by offering roses, chocolate and free meals to those who attended a campaign rally in the southern port city.
The value of the gifts issued to each of the attendees, estimated at about NT$200, exceeds the NT$30 ceiling for election campaign gifts and thereby constitutes vote-buying.
Their complaint was greeted by a complaint of false charges lodged by Lin Shiang-nung, chief of Lien's Kaohsiung campaign office.
Lin said the two councilors were barking up the wrong tree because the rally was neither a campaign activity nor a rally called by the KMT.

Rather, it was a activity organized by a private group to celebrate Valentine's Day, although it was held at Lien's Kaohsiung campaign office and tandem bicycle, as those ridden by attendees in the activity, is the logo of Lien's presidential campaign.
Lin's claims were supported by Wu Chang-sheng, the chief of a little-known private group called the Middle Voters Alliance, which organized the activity.

Waving invoices for the roses and candies handed out, Wu said the activity had nothing to do with the presidential campaign and claimed that the gifts -- a NT$28 rose and a NT$10 candy -- offered to each couple in the activity was worth less than NT$40.
The activity featured 99 couples riding tandems to symbolize their long-lasting love, as the Chinese pronunciation of 99 is similar to that of the term "long-lasting," according to Wu.

DOC.HEADLINE: KUOMINTANG CHAIRMAN MEETS FORMER DPP HEAD OVER TRIMMING LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan met Monday with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) former chairman, Lin I-hsiung, and the two agreed to accelerate the pace of action to halve the number of lawmakers, according to KMT sources.

The KMT sources said that Lien told Lin at the meeting that he fully supports a quicker move to downsize the Legislative Yuan. However, the KMT chairman also pointed out that the important task must be carried out in compliance with standard procedures. Lien was quoted as stressing that common ground must first be built between the opposition and ruling parties to clear the way.
For his part, Lin gave his assurance that the DPP will give its full backing to such legislation, as long as the KMT initiates the much discussed proposal in the Legislative Yuan.

According to the KMT sources, Lien immediately instructed Tseng Yung-chuan, secretary-general of the KMT's Central Policy Committee, to promote this mission at the Legislative Yuan and he asked Lin to help coordinate DPP lawmakers over the issue.
It was Lin's second visit to Lien in recent months to seek the prime opposition party's cooperation in downsizing the legislature -- a major constitutional reform long sought by the DPP.

Lin also talked with Lien about his dream of building Taiwan into a nuclear-free homeland by halting the ongoing construction of the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant at Kungliao township in northern Taipei County.

In response, Lien replied that the project was already approved with budget allocated by the Legislative Yuan. He said that the KMT and its political ally, the People First Party, strongly believe that the building of the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant must be carried out in order to make it possible to dismantle the first, second and third nuclear power plants in other parts of the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: REFERENDUM VALUE SUPERSEDES PRESIDENTIAL RACE OUTCOME: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: The value of holding the nation's first-ever referendum supersedes the outcome of the upcoming presidential election, a scholar claimed Monday.
Hsiao Hsin-huang, an Academia Sinica research fellow and a national policy adviser to President Chen Shui-bian, noted that referendum is a "new thing" in Taiwan's political history.

Saying that it is not the norm in a mature democracy to oppose a new thing before learning of its true essence, Hsiao said he hopes the major political parties will neither boycott nor manipulate the referendum simply for electoral purposes.

Hsiao made the appeal at a news conference where he unveiled a list of 1,000 scholars who have shown explicit support for Chen's decision to call a referendum alongside the March 20 presidential election in line with Article 17 of the newly passed Referendum Act.
Hsiao launched a campaign Feb. 6 to collect the signatures in support of the upcoming referendum, which the opposition "pan-blue alliance" has been threatening to boycott.
"The signature campaign has so far received the support of more than 4,000 people from various walks of life, " Hsiao said, adding that the campaign will continue.
He stressed that support for the upcoming referendum should not be regarded as "unconditional support" for any particular political party.

The two questions to be put to referendum March 20 are: Should the government buy new anti-missile systems to counter Beijing's increasing build-up of missiles targeting Taiwan? And should the government open talks with Beijing to establish a peaceful and stable framework for cross-Taiwan Strait interaction?

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO, NATIONAL GEOGRAPHIC COOPERATE ON TAIWAN DOCUMENTARY

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) and National Geographic Channel International (NGCI) announced Monday that they will cooperate on a documentary production project and invited documentary makers to take part in the selection contest.
Lee Cher-jean, GIO deputy director-general, and Bryan Smith, NGCI executive vice president, jointly announced the cooperative venture.

Lee said the unprecedented cooperation project is aimed at nurturing Taiwan documentary filmmaking talent. The project will see four documentaries made, three of which will be filmed in Taiwan, while the fourth can be filmed in other parts of Asia.

Lee said that Taiwan's rich landscape and pluralistic society will be aired to 145 countries worldwide through the noted TV channel and he added that the project will allow Taiwan's documentary production techniques and abilities to be enhanced.

Filmmakers interested in taking part in the one-hour documentary contest will have to submit proposals before April 5. Submitters whose proposals pass the first screening will be interviewed and will be invited to take part in a workshop May 3-4.
The four successful production companies will be announced in June and the NGCI will sign production contracts with them.

Under the production supervision of an NGCI-GIO board, the four films will be produced for airing in 2005 and will provide an opportunity for Taiwan production companies to join the ranks of internationally renowned filmmakers.

To qualify for the project, production companies must be established under the laws of Taiwan and at least half of their key production personnel must be Republic of China nationals or permanent residents of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBERS OF PATENTS, TRADEMARKS UP: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY OFFICE

TEXT.P: The number of patents and trademarks approved last year by the Intellectual Property Office (IPO) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) were up substantially from their 2002 levels, a spokesman for the IPO said Monday.

According to the IPO official, 65,512 patent applications were approved in 2003, up by 4,100 from the 2002 level of 61,402. The number of new models grew by 82, while the number of new designs dropped by 90, he added.

At the same time, the number of trademark registrations totaled 65,943, up by 4,214 compared to the year-earlier level, he said, pointing out that 21,996 of the total were re-registrations, a marked 23 percent increase from the previous year's level of 17,896.

The official attributed the rises to noticeable signs of an improved economy, a situation which he said has prompted many companies to re-register their trademarks to protect their business interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: REFERENDUM IS STRATEGY FOR DEALING WITH BEIJING: VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Monday that President Chen Shui-bian's call for a referendum March 20 alongside the presidential election is a strategy for dealing with Beijing.

Speaking at rallies in southern Taiwan's Pingtung County of supporters of the Chen-Lu ticket, who are seeking re-election in the upcoming presidential race, Lu said that the referendum is aimed at making the people aware of Beijing's missile threat against Taiwan and thus increasing their anti-missile sentiment on the one hand, while seeking to hold "peaceful talks" with Beijing on the other.
Lu claimed that if Chen had not called the referendum, a majority of Taiwan people might not have noticed that Beijing has deployed nearly 500 missiles targeting Taiwan.
The referendum will also help obtain international support for asking Beijing to dismantle the missiles, she continued.
"Taiwan is not a part of China," Lu stressed, adding that it is a maritime country and that she will suggest that the Executive Yuan establish a ministry of oceanic affairs.
Beijing opposes Taiwan's planned referendum because it is afraid Hong Kong and Tibet will follow in Taiwan's footsteps, according to the vice president.

Chen has placed two questions to be voted on in the referendum: Should the government buy new anti-missile systems to counter Beijing's increasing build-up of missiles targeting Taiwan? And should the government open talks with Beijing to establish a peaceful and stable framework for cross-Taiwan Strait interaction?

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTOR PROBES ALLEGED SEXUAL ATTACK INVOLVING FORMER LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: A prosecutor began Monday to investigate sexual attack allegations involving a former lawmaker and his Filipino housemaid, but a Filipino official in Taipei said the alleged victim would prefer not to sue her employer.
Pai Chih-chung, a prosecutor with the Shilin District Court in Taipei City, said he will summon former lawmaker Elmer Fung's Filipino maid, even though she has already flown back to Manila.

The prosecutor charged with the investigation into the case said a transcript of questioning conducted by police with the Filipino woman, the alleged victim in the case, is not clear enough and that more information is needed.

Although local media said Fung settled the case out of court by paying the woman "hush money, " the prosecutor said sexual attack is a type of crime that prosecutors are obliged to look into, regardless of the victim's opinion.

Meanwhile the Manila Economic and Cultural Office (MECO) in Taipei, which was accused by local human rights groups of trying to hush up the case by hastily sending the woman home, defended its handling of the case, arguing that the woman chose to fly home as soon as possible rather than sue Fung.

The MECO said in a statement that they received a phone call from the alleged victim Jan. 23, in which she complained that she had been sexually attacked by her Taiwanese employer. A worker from MECO immediately took the woman to MacKay Memorial Hospital for treatment before logging a complaint with the Chungshan Police Station in Taipei City in preparation for legal action against the employer.
The woman, whose name was withheld, was then lodged by MECO pending the legal process. MECO also retained a lawyer specialized in industrial disputes to tell the woman about her legal rights.

However, the young woman changed her mind after talking with Fung's wife on the phone. She insisted on withdrawing the complaint, claiming that it resulted from "misunderstandings" and said she wanted to return to the Philippines as soon as possible.
MECO put her on a flight to Manila Jan. 29.
A MECO official refused to confirm local news report that Fung and his family paid the woman NT$800,000 (US$24,167) as hush money, but he admitted that money probably changed hands in the settlement.
He also said he did not know whether the young woman will come to Taipei to answer prosecutor's questions. "It's up to the woman to decide after taking account of Taiwan's laws," he said.
Fung is presently in mainland China, where he denied the allegations in an interview with a local television station, claiming that it is a ploy concocted by his political rivals to ruin him.

TEXT.P: New York Times: U.S. aides hint Afghan voting may be put off.
The Bush administration has begun suggesting that Afghanistan's elections scheduled for June may have to be postponed because of security problems and the failure to register enough voters.

Administration officials said in recent days that security conditions remained dangerous or at least uncertain in a third of the country, hampering registration so badly that only 8 percent of eligible Afghan voters have been enrolled. Among women, only 2 percent have registered. The United Nations has said at least 70 percent of eligible voters should be register ed for the elections to be considered successful.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE AUNT LEAVES BRAZIL FOR HOME WITH REGRET, UNEASE

TEXT.P: With a bit of regret and sadness, the Taiwanese aunt of an 8-year-old Taiwanese-Brazilian orphan left Brazil for home Sunday without being able to say goodbye to the boy before her departure.

Lee Su-hua, who accompanied Iruan Ergui Wu on his return to his legal guardian in Brazil last Thursday after losing a three-year-old international custody battle, said she felt deep regret for having been denied access to the boy during her stay in Canoas, a small town on the outskirts of Port Alegre in southeastern Brazil where Iruan's Brazilian maternal grandmother lives.

"The boy's grandmother and guardian, Rosa Leocadia da Silva Ergui, backed off an earlier promise and would not let me bid farewell to Yi-hua (Iruan's Chinese name) before I left Canoas, " Lee said after her arrival at Sao Paulo.

Lee was accompanied by her lawyer Wu Chiu-li and Chou Kuo-rey, Taiwan's representative to Brazil, on the flight from Canoas to Sao Paulo for a transit stop on her way back to Taiwan via Johannesburg and Hong Kong.
Wu said she could not understand why Ergui would not allow them to meet with Iruan before their departure.

"We had no chance of seeing for ourselves the environment where Iruan will live in the future because Ergui did not invite us to visit her home. We have no way of understanding Iruan's interaction with his Brazilian family or his grandmother's way of dealing with him. We cannot say we were leaving for home with ease," Wu said.
As to how Iruan's Taiwanese relatives will continue to be concerned about the boy's life and education in Brazil, Wu said a detailed plan will be unveiled later.

Iruan was born to a Brazilian mother and a Taiwanese father, Wu Teng-shu, in 1995 in Brazil. The mother died in 1998 and the child's grandmother was named as the boy's guardian with Wu Teng-shu's approval.

Wu took the boy for a short visit to his hometown of Chiehting in southern Taiwan March 15, 2001, but he died unexpectedly two weeks later. The boy's uncle then decided to take the boy and refused to let him go. The child attended the Chiehting Primary School, where he reached second grade.
The boy's grandmother filed a lawsuit to regain custody of the boy, and Taiwan's Supreme Court ruled late last year that Iruan should return to his rightful guardian.
Iruan will from now on live in Brazil with his 48-year-old grandmother, his 83-year-old great-grandmother, a 16-year-old aunt and his 13-year-old half-brother.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO PROMOTE TUNA TO EUROPEAN, AMERICAN AND DOMESTIC MARKETS

TEXT.P: Taiwan Deep Sea Tuna Boatowners and Exporters Association officials said Monday that they are adjusting their strategy and will now promote tuna products to European, American and domestic markets.
In the past, tuna catches were mostly destined for Japan.
The officials said Taiwan's current tuna fishing fleet is made up of more than 600 vessels, and Chiencheng Fishing Harbor in Kaohsiung, sothern Taiwan, is their major port.
Taiwan's annual tuna catch is around 400,000 tons, ranking first in the world, and bringing in more than NT$40 billion (US$1.2 billion) each year.
To encourage local people to eat tuna and to diversify the market, the association has begun to plan a series of promotional activities, hoping to increase domestic consumption.

They noted that tuna caught by deep sea tuna vessels are kept at ultra low temperatures of 50 or 60 degree Celsius below zero, which they said can best preserve the freshness and delicious taste of the fish.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRADUATES MORE WORRIED ABOUT JOBS THAN FOLLOWING ELECTION: POLL

TEXT.P: Even though the presidential election is just over a month away and campaigning is getting more frenzied, a survey has shown that more than 60 percent of this year's graduates are more concerned with finding a job.

According to the results of a poll made public on Sunday by the executive research Web site www.1111.com.tw, nearly half of this year's 450,000 graduates from universities, colleges and senior high schools do not pay attention to current political issues but 64.75 percent of them are concerned about whether they will be able to find a job after leaving school this summer.
Some 53 percent of the would-be graduates responding to the poll said they will immediately enter the job market in June -- the equivalent of at least 270,000 new job seekers.
Around 60 percent of them said they have started to look for work, while 60 percent said that they have taken language and computer courses to sharpen their competitiveness, the poll indicated.
Sixty-seven percent said they would use the Internet to look for work, followed by 48 percent who will use newspapers and 39 percent who will use government-run agencies or Web sites.
This year's graduates hope for an average monthly salary of NT$25,194, higher than the average level of NT$22,763 that business owners are willing to pay.

The poll also found that more than 80 percent of employers attach the most importance to new job seekers' communication abilities, professional knowledge and ability to adapt. Computer skills and language proficiency come second.
The survey was carried out Feb. 6-14. It recovered 1,386 valid questionnaires, and had a margin of error of 2.63 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET WARNS LOCAL CHIEFS NOT TO CHANGE VOTING FORMAT

TEXT.P: The Cabinet reiterated Monday that local governments are prohibited from arbitrarily changing the voting format for the March 20 presidential election and referendum.

Cabinet spokesman Lin Chia-lung made the reaffirmation after several city and county government chiefs said they planned to modify the inside of polling stations in their constituencies for the upcoming election and referendum to avoid confusion.
"Such worries are not necessary and the central government cannot tolerate any inconsistence in the handling of electoral affairs," Lin said.

According to the Election and Recall Law, Lin said, city and county election commissions must abide by the Central Election Commission's regulations and should not unilaterally change the voting format inside polling stations.

Noting that the Cabinet would not like to see the phenomenon of "one country, multiple systems" in local governments' handling of electoral affairs, Lin said local governments should refrain from complicating the simple electoral process by making a fuss over trivial technical issues.
Lin also urged local government chiefs to have confidence in grassroots election workers and voters.
On the upcoming election day, each voter will cast three ballots into three different boxes -- one for electing the president and two for answering the two referendum questions.

Lin said it won't be the first time for local voters to cast multiple ballots in a single polling setting. Over the past more than two decades, Lin said, Taiwan simultaneously held elections for three different kinds of public functionaries in 1977, 1986, 1989 and 1998.

"On those four occasions, each eligible voter received three different ballots at the same time, marked them at the same place and then cast them into different boxes. All of those elections were conducted smoothly. I simply cannot understand why some local government chiefs would doubt voters' wisdom this time around and plan to set up separate polling stations for the presidential election and the referendum," Lin said.

Stressing that Taiwan has come a long way in its democratic development, Lin said election administrators and ordinary voters have accumulated abundant experience in voting affairs. "Opposition politicians should step up preparations for the nation's first-ever referendum and stop any technical boycott against the event, " he added.
The two questions to be asked in the March 20 referendum are:

-- "The people of Taiwan demand that the Taiwan Strait issue be resolved through peaceful means. Should mainland China refuse to withdraw the missiles it has targeted at Taiwan and openly renounce the use of force against us, do you agree that the government should acquire more advanced anti-missile weapons to strengthen Taiwan's self-defense capabilities?"

-- "Do you agree that our government should engage in negotiation with mainland China on the establishment of a peace and a stability framework for cross-strait interaction in order to build consensus and for the welfare of the peoples of both sides."

DOC.HEADLINE: SOME ROC AGRICULTURAL MISSION MEMBERS, DEPENDENTS EVACUATED IN HAITI

TEXT.P: Some members of the Republic of China's agricultural missions in Haiti and their dependents have been evacuated to Port-Au-Prince, capital of the Caribbean country after an eruption of battles between rebels and loyalists to President Jean-Bertrand Aristide.

Richard Shih, a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Monday that for safety reasons, some ROC agricultural mission members and their dependents have been evacuated to Port-au-Prince, but ROC Ambassador Hsieh Hsin-ping and embassy staff are staying at their posts.
Shih stressed that the foreign ministry has mapped out contingency plans and will keep in touch with Haiti's foreign and agriculture ministries.
The Haitian government has also promised that it will protect the safety of the members of Taiwan's agricultural mission and the staff of the ROC Embassy, Shih said.

Shih stressed that the situation with Haiti and Liberia is different. The ROC severed diplomatic ties with Liberia last October after its opposition forces overthrew the government to take the helm of the nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN ACCUSE MAINLAND AUTHORITIES OF CONDONING CRIMES

TEXT.P: Several Taiwan businessmen condemned mainland Chinese authorities Monday for apparently condoning crimes against citizens of Taiwan who have invested and are doing business on the mainland.
The Taiwan businessmen spoke of their tribulations at a news conference held at the Legislative Yuan called by Legislator Chang Ching-fang of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

They alleged that mainland China is a country rife with obscure laws and where many well-intended Taiwan business people have seen their investments stolen or confiscated. They appealed to the Communist Chinese government to address cases involving Taiwan citizens with fairness and impartiality.

At the news conference, Lin Chih-sheng said that he invested a great deal of money in 1993 to build four schools in Chengdu, the capital city of the southwest province of Sichuan. Before 2000, the authorities in Chengdu declared the buildings illegal and confiscated them all.

Then, Lin said, one day in 2001 several gangsters came to his home and tried to kidnap him. He escaped and reported the incident to local public security authorities who decided that the way to protect him was to detain him for 15 days.

Lin said he then fled from Chengdu to Xiamen in the southern province of Fujian in 2002 and from Xiamen he paid human traffickers to have him smuggled to the Republic of China-held island of Kinmen, where he then managed to return to Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Pao Yang-bo said he invested some NT$200 million in real estate development in the central Chinese municipality of Chongqing in 1996. The investment was entirely stolen by a group of locals. He filed a lawsuit against the group and won; however, the court has until now not executed the judgment and his holding remain out of reach.

Kao Wei-pang said that he invested and operated a manufacturing plant in Yenjiao of the northern Chinese province of Hebei. One of his local employees forged Kao's signature on guarantee documents that were used to fraudulently obtain a large loan.
Kao said that the incident happened over five years ago but the suspect is still at large while the bank continues to press him to repay the money that was embezzled.

Voicing support for the Taiwanese businessmen, Legislator Chang said that more than 1,000 Taiwan citizens have filed appeals to the Mainland Affairs Council for help over incidents of being conned, kidnapped or arrested in mainland China.

Noting that the actual number of Taiwan citizens who have been taken advantage of in mainland China but did not speak out may exceed 3,000, Chang called for the mainland Chinese authorities to demonstrate some respect for the law and help do justice to the Taiwan business people who have made numerous contributions to society on the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTRY DENIES REPORT ABOUT HUGE AID OFFER TO KIRIBATI

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) categorically denied a media report Monday that the Republic of China promised huge cash aid in exchange for Kiribati's diplomatic recognition.

MOFA spokesman Richard Shih made the denial after a U.S. newspaper -- the Baltimore Sun -- reported a day earlier that the establishment of ROC-Kiribati diplomatic ties last November was probably a result of "checkbook diplomacy."

The paper quoted the Kiribati president's brother as claiming that Taiwan had attempted to offer financial assistance to candidates during the Pacific island nation's presidential election last summer. The brother was also quoted as having revealed that Taiwan might have offered US$8 million in aid to Kiribati annually in exchange for the establishment of bilateral diplomatic relations.

"The report is absolutely not true and totally unfounded, " Shih said in response to questioning by local media. "We have forged diplomatic ties with Kiribati in line with our consistent diplomatic policy of fostering relations with all democratic countries around the world and assisting diplomatic allies in their national development within the scope of Taiwan's financial capability."
Shih pointed out that Kiribati's decision to establish diplomatic ties with Taiwan was not made solely by its president, Anote Tong.

"It was instead a decision made by the Kiribati Cabinet after a lengthy, comprehensive debate based on their national interest," Shih said, adding that since the two countries have become diplomatic allies, Taiwan is certainly willing to help Kiribati develop its economy on the principle of reciprocity.

Asked how much money Taiwan will donate in aid to Kiribati per year, Shih said there is no agreement on a fixed aid amount. In the memorandum of understanding signed by the two sides on the establishment of diplomatic ties, Shih said, Taiwan promised to provide Kiribati with assistance in agricultural, fishery, economic and cultural development after a careful evaluation of Kiribati's needs and the ROC's own budget resources.

Kiribati became the 27th nation to recognize Taiwan last November. The move angered mainland China, which promptly cut relations with Kiribati and dismantled a satellite tracking station it had maintained on the Pacific island nation's main island.
Kiribati President Tong has said on many occasions that his government recognized Taiwan because the Taiwanese can better help his country develop its economy.

Tong made his first state visit to Taiwan last week, where he signed a joint communique with President Chen Shui-bian reaffirming their commitment to further boosting bilateral exchanges and cooperation for mutual benefits.

Located on the equator in the Pacific Ocean, halfway between Hawaii and Australia, Kiribati is the world's largest coral reef nation, with a sprawling exclusive economic zone. It is heavily dependent on revenue from fishing licenses. Over the years, Taiwan's deep-sea fishing vessels have paid a huge amount in licensing fees to Kiribati, thereby contributing to its economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Feb. 16, or the 26th day of the first month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1473: Nicolaus Copernicus, Polish astronomer, is born. He advanced the theory that the earth and other planets revolve around the sun, discrediting the Ptolemaic model of the universe.
1659: A new way of paying money without using either coinage or a letter of credit is first used in England when Mr. Nicholas Vanacker signs a "cheque" to a creditor.
1884: Robert J. Flaherty, U.S. explorer and filmmaker, is born. His works, including "Nanook of the North," were the world's first major documentaries.
1906: British labor representatives meet in London to establish the Labour Party.
1918: Lithuania, which is located in Northern Europe, proclaims its independence from Russia.
1931: The Control Yuan of the Republic of China is formally established.
1937: The synthetic material nylon, which was developed by the U.S. chemist Wallace Carothers, is patented.
1942: Kim Jong Il, North Korean leader, is born.
1944: Allied aircraft bomb a Japanese naval base at Truk in the Caroline Islands, destroying some 200 planes.
1945: The United States starts massive air raids on Tokyo as U.S. forces capture Bataan in the Philippines during World War II.
1959: Fidel Castro becomes the leader of Cuba at the age of 32.
1960: The USS Triton begins an underwater voyage around the world, becoming the first nuclear submarine to undertake such a journey.
1968: A China Air Transportation plane flying from Hong Kong to Taipei crashes in Linkuo, killing 21 and injuring 43.
1970: The Directorate General of Posts starts nighttime business operations.
1973: Robert E. Page, vice president of United Press International, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1973: The Republic of China revalues the New Taiwan dollar upward by 5 percent against the U.S. dollar. The new exchange rate is NT$38 to US$1.
1976: A new radar control system is inaugurated at Kaohsiung International Airport in southern Taiwan.
1976: Yu Hao-chang, former ROC Army commander in chief, returns to Taipei after more than a year of medical treatment in the United States.
1983: The Dutch airline Martinair inaugurates flight services to Taiwan, marking the first air link between the Netherlands and the Republic of China.
1986: A China Airlines Boeing 737 plane crashes near Makung, in Taiwan's Penghu Islands, killing all 13 aboard.
1992: OPEC member countries agree to cut oil output by 1 million barrels a day.
1994: An earthquake claims 134 lives and injures at least 550 in southern Sumatra in Indonesia.
1994: The Helenic Republic (Greece) declares an embargo on the Macedonian Republic in a conflict over the use of the name Macedonia. The two countries later reached an agreement on the use of the formal name "Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia" for the latter's entry into the United Nations.
1998: A China Airlines Airbus A-300 plane returning from Bali crashes near Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, killing all 116 aboard and six people on the ground.
2000: Two destroyers of the Republic of China, the Loyang and Suiyang, are decommissioned after more than two decades of active service.
2000: The ruling Kuomintang formally files a lawsuit against independent presidential candidate and former KMT Secretary-General James Soong, accusing him of embezzling party funds.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The common people should be educated in what they ought to do; not to ask why they should do it."
