The Manila Bulletin: AFP help to Comelec assured President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo assured yesterday that the Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP) remains firmly committed to help the Commission on Elections (Comelec) ensure an honest, orderly, and peaceful elections on May 10 and will never allow itself to be dragged into partisan politics.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: 2 new poll execs want Poe barred THE two new appointees to the Commission on Elections Monday asked the Supreme Court to disqualify actor Fernando Poe Jr. from the presidential race on the ground that he was not a natural-born Filipino citizen.
The Philippine Star: I'm a natural-born Filipino, FPJ tells SC Movie actor Fernando Poe Jr. told the Supreme Court yesterday that he is a natural-born Filipino citizen and is therefore qualified to seek the presidency.
The Manila Times: GMA 'buys' loyalty of mayors -- Padilla PRESIDENT Arroyo has started to "buy" the loyalty of mayors in Central Luzon with fund distribution to ensure her victory in the May 10 election, a ranking opposition lawmaker said on Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Bangkok Post: Bird flu scare / Virus re-ermerges in nine provinces.
Bird flu disease has re-emerged in poutlry in nine provinces with officials blaming unregulated movement of fighting rooters for the second wave of the epidemic. (Francis Kuo).

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Kerry Takes Hits in Debate.
John Edwards jabbed John F. Kerry over his views on trade and spending in a debate in Milwaukee,presenting his most aggressive challenge to him since the Massachusetts sentar emerged as the front-runner for the Democratic presidential nomination.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PRESIDENT CANVASSES VOTES FOR INCUMBENT PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui urged the public Tuesday to vote for President Chen Shui-bian and to vote "yes" to both questions in the first national referendum scheduled for March 20.

At a news conference to launch the Chinese translation of his Japanese-language book "Bushido, " the ex-president did not forget to beat the drum for Chen's re-election bid and suggested that Chen's rival in the 2004 race, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan, is a proxy of mainland China and unqualified to run for public office in Taiwan.

Lee said that as a U.S.-educated economist with a doctorate he is fully qualified to say that Chen has done marvelously in terms of the economy, especially in forcing local banks to cut their bad loan ratio from 8.04 percent three years ago to 4.5 percent this year.
He said the country needs a young leader and that Chen is its best choice, adding that he feels the country is blessed to have a "brilliant" leader like Chen.
In the preface to his book, Lee says he was not really surprised when Chen defeated Lien to win the 2000 presidential election.

However, the KMT, which Lee led from 1988 to 2000, could not come to terms with the fact that it had lost power. The party has gone out its way in its attempts to oust Chen and poses a threat to the country's burgeoning democracy, Lee said.

This, he went on, is why he could not quit politics after stepping down from the presidency. He said he would come out to unite the country's pro-democracy forces to back Chen and his Democratic Progressive Party.

In "Bushido, " Lee blames the Japanese authorities for what he calls "dishonesty and cowardice, " especially in its dealing with Beijing, which flies in the face of bushido, or the tradition code of the Japanese warrior, the samurai.

Lee said Japan is afraid of mainland China and therefore its government dares not dispute Beijing's criticism of the Japanese prime minister's visits to a shrine honoring Japanese war dead, including those executed by allies for war crimes.
Furthermore, Lee said, Japan caved in to Beijing's pressure to speak out against Taiwan's referendum. "Japan should be ashamed of its cowardice," Lee said at the news conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ENVOY TO FILE COMPLIANT TO BRAZIL OVER IRUAN WU ERGUI

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative to Brazil will file a written compliant with the Brazil government over a recent ruling by a Brazilian children's court over the fate of an orphaned Taiwanese-Brazilian boy.

Chou Kuo-juei said he will issue the complaint to the Brazilian authorities to protest the court decision banning the Taiwan family of Iruan Wu Ergui from saying goodbye to him, saying the ban damaged their right to visit the eight-year-old boy.

Breaking an earlier promise, Rosa Leocadia da Silva Ergui -- the Brazilian grandmother and legal guardian of Iruan -- acceded to the court's ruling and refused to allow Lee Su-hua -- the boy's Taiwanese aunt -- to bid farewell to him before she left Brazil after accompanying him from Taiwan.

According to officials of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), the two families reached an agreement Feb. 14 that the boy and his aunt could meet the following day during a lunch gathering planned to be held at a ranch owned by a Taiwan businessman at Canoas, a small town near Porto Alegre in southern Brazil, where the boy was born and his maternal grandmother lives.

Although officials of the Taiwan Representative Office and child experts tried hard to change da Silva Ergui's decision to abide by the court ruling, Lee and other members of Iruan's Taiwanese family failed to see the boy prior to their departure, the MOFA officials said.

The Taiwan envoy also paid a visit to the Brazilian court prosecutor, who was reluctant to change the court's decision as it was based on the premise of protecting the boy's best interests, the MOFA officials said.

Iruan, who has been at the center of a bitter three-year custody battle between his Taiwan and Brazilian families, returned to Brazil last Thursday after his Taiwanese uncle yielded to a Taiwan court ruling that the boy must be returned to his Brazilian grandmother. His aunt and a Taiwanese lawyer accompanied him on his trip to Brazil.

The boy visited Taiwan at the age of five with his Taiwanese father, who was captain of a Taiwanese fishing boat, but his father died suddenly in his hometown in southern Kaohsiung County. His Brazilian mother had passed away before he came back to Taiwan. The boy's uncle then refused to allow Iruan to return to Brazil, despite a desperate journey to Taiwan by his grandmother, who was recognized by the Taiwan court, the Brazilian court and the boy's father himself as Iruan's legal guardian.

DOC.HEADLINE: REFERENDUM WILL NOT BRING DISASTER: VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu offered her opinion recently in an interview with Cable Television of Hong Kong that Taiwan's planned referendum will not bring disaster to the Taiwan Strait.

Lu said that the referendum called by President Chen Shui-bian to coincide with the March 20 presidential election is aimed at seeking to establish a stable and peaceful framework for cross-strait interaction.

Only "dancing blindly in tune with Beijing's opposition to the referendum" will bring disaster to the Taiwan Strait, she claimed, adding that Beijing opposes the referendum because it is afraid Hong Kong, Macau, Xinjiang and Tibet will follow in Taiwan's footsteps.

Chen has put two questions to be voted on in the referendum: Should the government buy new anti-missile systems to counter Beijing's increasing build-up of missiles targeting Taiwan? And should the government open talks with Beijing to establish a peaceful and stable framework for cross-Taiwan Strait interaction?

DOC.HEADLINE: 2002 OUTPUT VALUE OF PUBLISHING INDUSTRY TOPS NT$43 BILLION

TEXT.P: The output value of Taiwan's publishing industry in 2002 totaled about NT$43 billion (US$1.3 billion) , up slightly by 1.48 percent over the 2000 level of NT$42.39 billion, according to the results of an investigation released Tuesday by the Government Information Office (GIO).

Citing statistics provided by the International Standard Book Numbering (ISBN) system, there were a total of 2,385 publishing companies based in Taiwan as of the end of 2002, the poll found, more than 80 percent of which were registered under the name of a private
individual, while over 12 percent belonged to a business group.

About 36,758 new books published in 2002 in Taiwan were registered with the International ISBN Agency, with children's books and motivational books forming the bulk, although reference books and children's' books notched up the largest sales value.

More than 77 percent of traditional bookstores and 57 percent of chain bookstores acknowledged a drop in business of over 20 percent, which they attributed to the economic recession in recent years and an exodus of local residents, according to the investigation results.
At the same time, complex bookstores and stores specialized in computer books as well as those located near bus or train stations performed better in business revenues.

However, the results also found that Taiwan-based publishers are not fully prepared for globalization, a situation that will hinder their efforts to edge into the huge mainland Chinese market and other Chinese-language book markets, despite the fact that books published in Taiwan are of better quality than those published in other Chinese-speaking countries and areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: THERE WILL BE NO ELECTION FRAUD: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun claimed Tuesday that there will be "no election fraud" and said that the government will do its best to curb vote-buying in the run-up to the March 20 presidential election.
Yu made the remarks in reply to questions raised by lawmakers in an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan.
Neither the Executive Yuan nor the Central Election Commission will commit irregularities, nor will they allow others to do so, Yu claimed.
The premier also said he will continue to carry out reforms initiated by President Chen Shui-bian if re-assigned after the presidential election.
Yu said that he is confident that Chen will win re-election and that it is up to Chen whether he will continue to serve in the government.
If he leaves the government, Yu said he will work for the underprivileged as a volunteer.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD SEIZES LARGE HAUL OF SMUGGLED CIGARETTES

TEXT.P: Coast guard officers seized a large haul of untaxed foreign cigarettes worth around NT$4 million (US$120,845) in waters off Ilan, northeastern Taiwan, early Tuesday.
Tipped off recently that a smuggling ring would use a fishing vessel and a sampan to try to smuggle untaxed foreign cigarettes into Taiwan, coast guard officers were put on alert.
At around 3 a.m. Tuesday, they spotted a fishing vessel and a sampan loading and unloading goods and ordered them to stop for an inspection.
After the cigarettes were found on the two vessels, the fishing ship's captain, surnamed Lin, and the six crew members were all taken back to Suao, Ilan, for further questioning.
The seven men were later turned over to the Ilan District Court on charges of violating Taiwan's tobacco and wine regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Cingular's $40.7 billion offer wins bidding for AT&T Wireless.
Cingular Wireless, the second-largest wireless telephone operator in the United States, made a stunning last-minute bid to win an auction for AT&T Wireless, executives close to the talks said early Tuesday.
It had appeared early on Monday night, that AT&T Wireless, the third-largest cellphone operator in the United States, appeared to be leaning toward a buyout offer from the Vodafone Group of Britain.
The auction appeared to turn yesterday when Vodafone indicated that it would be willing to raise its $38 billion cash bid, while Cingular Wireless, which had been the favorite to win the auction, refused to increase its offer. But early on Tuesday, it was announced that Cingular has boosted its bid to $40.7 billion.
Wall Street Journal: Cingular wins AT&T wireless, beating out U.K.'s Vodafone.
Cingular Wireless won the bidding war for AT&T Wireless Services Inc. with a cash offer of $15 a share, or about $40.5 billion, for the U.S.'s third-largest cellular operator, according to people familiar with the matter.
Cingular's victory caps a long weekend of competitive bidding by Vodafone Group PLC, Britain's largest mobile-phone operator, which was also vying to buy Cingular by bidding at least $14 a share.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEM MEETS WITH VISITING PARAGUAYAN SENATORS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian met with a delegation from the Paraguayan Senate Tuesday, saying the group's visit will help boost bilateral relations and encourage Taiwanese business people to invest in the South American country.
The Paraguay senatorial delegation, headed by Senate Speaker Carlos Mateo Balmelli, arrived in Taipei Monday for a weeklong visit.
Chen said relations between the Republic of China and Paraguay have been cordial since the two countries forged diplomatic ties in 1957.
Last year, Chen said, Taiwan lawmakers formed a Taiwan-Paraguayan parliamentary amity association for further boost bilateral parliamentary exchanges and cooperation.

For his part, Mateo said his mission wants to take advantage of the current visit to express Paraguay's gratitude for Taiwan's financial aid for renovating his country's parliament building. The renovation project was completed last summer.
Mateo said he and his colleagues will do their utmost to further promote cooperation between the two countries in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIVE PRESIDENTIAL DEBATE QUESTIONERS CHOSEN

TEXT.P: Five questioners were selected Tuesday to put questions to candidates in a Feb. 21 presidential debate.
The five, selected by the two candidates' campaign workers from a shortlist prepared by the Public Television Service, which is co-sponsoring the televised debate, will cover different fields.

Chang Wu-euh, director of the Institute of China Research, Tamkang University, will raise questions about Taiwan's ties with mainland China, while Cheng Jui-yau, a researcher at the Institute of International Relations, National Chengchi University, will raise questions in the field of national defense and diplomacy.

In the fields of women's affairs and education, the questioner will be Huang Chang-ling, an associate professor of political science at the National Taiwan University and the vice chairwoman of the Awakening Foundation, a women's rights group.

Sun Ta-chuan, a former vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Indigenous People's Affairs, will question the candidates about their policies regarding improving harmony among different ethnic groups, and Chen Tain-Jy, president of the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, will question them on their economic policies.
In the debate, the second and final of its kind, President Chen Shui-bian will face off against his only rival in the race, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO MAKE TAIWAN INTO TOP DESIGN HUB

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presided Tuesday over the opening of the Taiwan Design Center (TDC) , which coincided with the inauguration of the second phase of the Nankang Software Industrial Park in suburban Taipei.

Praising the center's opening as a milestone in the history of Taiwan's design industry, which is in full gear to establish a greater international presence and standing with its value-added services, Chen claimed that the center is a crystallization of Taiwan's potential for creativity.

He urged the public to seek new horizons to achieve sustainable progress, as Taiwan is faced with robust competition from around the world, and he expressed his strong belief that there is no turning back from the road ahead.

"A bright future will only wait for a Taiwan that is moving up relentlessly, " Chen said, adding that "the center will play a leadership role in helping turn Taiwan into a front-runner in the current knowledge-based era featuring ideas, quality and speed in a global race."

TDC Secretary-General Chang Kuang-min said the center will assist Taiwan companies with their image building and professional talent, ranging from product design to diversified design applications, to help them better tap the world market with a finely tuned brand name.
At the same time, the center will also help promote transnational exchanges to help upgrade the value and awareness of Taiwan-made fine products by cultivating world-class design manpower, he added.
According to Chang, a joint venture between the center and the Institute for Information Industry and the Industrial Technology Research Institute was also set to kick off on the same day.
The alliance has a plan to create business for more than 4,000 product items that are newly designed and have been developed with a taste and flavor of Taiwan over the past four years, he revealed.

On the other hand, they will also try to seek foreign companies wishing to open design units in Taiwan for their goods, a development which is expected to push the output value of such business in Taiwan to NT$30 billion in 2007, a more than two-fold increase over last year's level of NT$14.5 billion, he said.

In cooperation with the Taiwan External Trade Development Council, the TDC will help work out brand names for 100 companies based in Taiwan by the end of 2007, he went on, adding that they are confident that 20 of these will have become well-known marks in the global market by that time.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABIDE BY THE LAW AND ELECTION AND REFERENDUM WILL GO SMOOTHLY: PREMIER

TEXT.P: As long as both presidential candidates abide by the law, the upcoming referendum and presidential election will be implemented smoothly, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Tuesday.

Answering questions from Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Lin Kuo-hua, the premier admitted that some people have suggested that holding the election and the referendum simultaneously on March 20 might lead to riots, but he said that this won't happen unless there are persons who deliberately instigate such events for their own political gains.
The premier urged all candidates in the presidential race to ensure that their campaign workers do not create disturbances.
If any candidate deliberately incites riots, this would be something independent of whether the referendum was carried out separately from the presidential election, he said.
Lin warned the premier that someone was behind the complaints of some election officials to hold the referendum and the presidential election together.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO FORM SPECIAL TASK FORCE ON BEIJING TIES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed his commitment Tuesday to forming a special task force to promote peace with mainland China if he is successful in the March 20 presidential election.

"The task force will begin operations immediately after the presidential poll to promote the establishment of a framework for peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait, " Chen said at a weekly meeting of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) Central Standing Committee in his capacity as party chairman.
Chen, who is seeking re-election, further said that Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh has agreed to serve as a co-convener of the task force.

More than half of the team members would come from the private sector, including representatives from the business, cultural and academic fields, Chen said, adding that the roster will not be unveiled until after the presidential poll to prevent opposition parties from "distorting" his goodwill in fostering cross-strait rapprochement into an election campaign ploy.

Noting that the DPP has consistently called for resolving cross-strait disputes through negotiations on an equal footing, Chen said his administration has also put the question: "Should the government start negotiations with mainland China on the establishment of a peaceful and stable framework for cross-strait interaction" on the nation's first-ever national referendum, to be held alongside the upcoming presidential election.
If he is re-elected, Chen said, he will address four major categories of cross-strait issues under the principle of "maintaining permanent peace."

The four categories will include establishing a consultative mechanism for peaceful and stable interaction, promoting exchanges on the principles of parity and reciprocity, forging cross-strait political ties and preventing cross-strait military conflict.

Chen described the referendum as important, claiming that if the results show that a majority of local people want to beef up Taiwan's anti-missile defense capability and forge a cross-strait interactive framework, his administration will have a mandate to negotiate with Beijing and the mainland Chinese leadership will have to "seriously consider" Taiwan's call for negotiations on an equal footing.

Against this backdrop, Chen went on, the referendum will not only be a step toward consolidating and strengthening Taiwan's young democracy but will also be a strategy to realize the goals of "cross-strait reconciliation, active cooperation and permanent peace."

Saying that the referendum will allow the people of Taiwan to decide on major policy issues, Chen said every eligible voter should cast his or her ballot in the referendum to write a new chapter in Taiwan's political history.
Addressing a campaign rally in downtown Taipei earlier in the day, Chen claimed that if voter turnout in the referendum is below 50 percent, it will be a loss for Taiwan and a boon for the mainland.

"We should not let such a grim scenario or nightmare happen. Every voter should answer the two referendum questions to express to the world and to the mainland our desire for peace and our commitment to safeguarding our present status quo," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI COMPUTER ASSOCIATION SIGNS MOU WITH BEIJING COUNTERPART

TEXT.P: To promote the cooperation and development between game software industries on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the Taipei Computer Association signed a memorandum of understanding with the Beijing Game and Education Software Branch Association.

The memorandum on digital entertainment industry exchanges and cooperation was signed by Zhao Jinmeng, secretary-general of the Beijing Game and Education Software Branch Association and Lin Chi-ching, adviser to the Taipei Computer Association.
Taipei Computer Association officials said that initially, discussions and cooperation on product standards will take place to allow greater access to the markets of each side.
Both sides will also hold conferences on the technology, products and markets in the game industry to promote information exchanges and cooperation of the industries.

Both sides will also cooperate to hold a game industry exhibition to promote the development of the Mandarin Chinese game industry, as well as game competitions on both sides of the Taiwan Strait to help promote healthy entertainment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PROVIDES HUMANITARIAN AID TO MALAWI, SWAZILAND

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs has helped a private group to extend humanitarian assistance to two Republic of China's allies in Africa -- Swaziland and Malawi.

Chang Pei-chi, director of the foreign ministry's Department of African Affairs, said that an 18-member delegation from the District 3490 Rotary International of Taiwan visited the remote regions in Malawi to distribute 7,500 packs of corn powder Feb. 15-18.

The delegation went to Swaziland Feb. 22-25 to distribute another 5,000 packs of corn powder, Chang said. With all the packs emblazoned with the ROC national flag, it will help propagate the love from the people of Taiwan, he added.

He said that Malawi and Swaziland are long-time allies of Taiwan. In view of the food shortage in certain regions of the two countries, the foreign ministry wants to help private groups to provide humanitarian assistance, hoping to relieve food shortage as well as enhance bilateral friendships.
Meanwhile, Chang also said that the foreign ministry has turned over a private donation from Taiwan to Sao Tome and Principe, another ROC ally in western Africa.

Chang said that Lee Kong-wen, chairman of O-TA Precision Industry, who was invited by President Chen Shui-bian to a state dinner in honor of visiting Sao Tome and Principe President Fradique De Menezes Feb. 7 during which he was deeply moved by the speeches by the two leaders and decided to donate NT$2 million (US$60,422) to the country as a fund for the prevention of malaria.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECENT FOREIGN INVESTMENT ACCOUNTS FOR 23 PERCENT OF TAIEX VALUE

TEXT.P: A total of NT$447.8 billion (US$13.53 billion) worth of foreign capital has been channeled into the domestic stock market since the start of this year until Feb. 13, according to statistics compiled by the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX).

That makes the total value of Taiwan stocks held by foreign investors at NT$3.24 trillion, accounting for 22.64 percent of the overall value of the domestic bourse and representing a growth of NT$93.2 billion from the level recorded on Jan. 30, according to TAIEX tallies.
During the period between Jan. 1 and Feb. 13, a total of about NT$339 billion worth of Taiwan stocks held by foreign investors were sold, resulting in a net buy of NT$108.76 billion.

Meanwhile, the results of a public opinion survey carried out by the Focus Survey Research Corporation shows that more than 60 percent of stock investors are optimistic that the domestic bourse will continue to rise this year, with its benchmark weighted index standing around 7,000 points, while some 52 percent of the general public are confident of this year's business conditions.

In terms of the respondents' political affiliation, nearly 78 percent of the backers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party are looking forward to a better business climate this year, while 52.7 percent and 56.8 percent of the supporters of the New Party and the People First Party hold the same view, respectively.

But only 42.5 percent of the prime opposition Kuomintang's supporters are positive about this year's business climate, a stark contrast to a high 85.3 percent posted by backers of the Taiwan Solidarity Union, the survey discovers.

In terms of educational background, more than 70 percent of university and college graduates believe that business conditions will turn for the better in the months ahead, while only 44 percent of people with a junior high school diploma do not think so.
The poll, commissioned by Taiwan Thinktank, was taken Feb. 12-13 and collected 1,042 valid responses. It had a margin of error of 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.002 to close at NT$33.107.
A total of US$915 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$33.118, and was traded between NT$33.075 and NT$33.131.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALL ROC NATIONALS SAFE IN HAITI: DIPLOMAT

TEXT.P: Fighting in Haiti has been confined to only several locations and all 46 Republic of China's nationals in the Caribbean country are safe, a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Tuesday.

Richard Shih said that the latest reports from the ROC's embassy in Haiti indicates that the government of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide as well as the lives of the general public have not been affected.

Rebels attacked the police headquarters in the central Haitian city of Hinche Monday, killing the chief of police and his bodyguard. The rebels have been joined in their 11-day insurrection by exiled Haitian fighters, according to wire reports.
Shih said that the most serious fighting has so far erupted in Gonaives, the fourth-largest city and the stronghold of the rebel forces, but this has not affected the normal life of local citizens.

Shih also said that President Aristide has initially agreed to accept mediation of the Caribbean Community. Judging from the situation, the unrest will not affect the Aristide government or the diplomatic relations between the ROC and Haiti.
He stressed that for safety reasons, some members and dependents of the ROC agricultural mission have been evacuated to Port au Prince, the capital of the Caribbean nation.
But the head and major members of the agricultural mission are staying at their posts. The staff of the ROC embassy as well as ROC nationals are all safe, he stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: MASTERMINDS OF CROSS-BORDER CAR THEFT RING BUSTED

TEXT.P: The Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) on Tuesday arrested two men in northern Taiwan believed to be the masterminds behind a cross-border car theft ring that used rigorous techniques to steal, ship and then sell the vehicles in Southeast Asia.

After months of investigations, CIB investigators, backed up by local police from Taoyuan County and Taipei City, raided the homes of Chou Cheng-hsu in Taoyuan and Cheng Fu-hsiang in Taipei late Monday night and arrested the pair on charges of fraud and theft.

CIB investigators say they possess evidence showing that Chou, 26, and Cheng, 42, have operated a ring that steals new Mercedes-Benz, BMW and Toyota Camry cars in Taiwan and then ships the stolen vehicles to southeast Asia for sale.
The arrest of the pair should help police stem the trade in cross-border car theft and sales, officials said.

CIB officials discovered that members of the group have incorporated a tight network where division of labor is key. For example, the individuals responsible for stealing, loading containers, shipping and overseas sales do not know each other, investigators said.
CIB officials said they will investigate further to gain a better understanding of the ring's operations and bring all of those involved to justice.
The investigators also said that Chou was involved in a series of fraudulent withdrawals from automatic teller machines islandwide during the Oct. 10 National Day holiday last year.

In August 2003, the CIB successfully had 12 stolen new Toyota Camry cars shipped back to Taiwan from Singapore through the joint efforts of police, customs and immigration authorities from the two countries.
The CIB was tipped off in early July 2003 that a car theft ring was planning to ship stolen cars to Thailand and Cambodia via Singapore for sale.

After scrutinizing a large stack of container loading documents, shipping firms' data and customs clearance reports, investigators uncovered two containers holding eight new Camrys at a container terminal at Keelung Harbor in late July last year.
Through a further analysis of relevant documents, they concluded that three other containers holding 12 stolen cars had been shipped to Singapore's Keepel Port.
The CIB asked Singaporean customs to assist in intercepting the containers. CIB and local customs officers then traveled to Singapore to arrange for shipment of the cars back to Taiwan.
According to CIB investigations, the 20 new Camrys were stolen in Tainan, Taichung, Hsinchu and Taoyuan between July 4 and July 9 last year.
Reports also said that many Mercedes-Benz were stolen from the roads of Taiwan and then packed into containers heading to mainland China.

One report recalled the ordeal of a man in Taiwan who had a bit too much drink one night. Instead of driving home, he parked his black Mercedes S320 to sleep it off. He later awoke to find himself inside his car, which was inside a container headed to the mainland's Fujian Province.

Another report told of a wealthy Taiwan businessman going to Chengdu, the capital city of the southwestern province of Sichuan, where he spotted a Mercedes that looked exactly like the one that was stolen from him in Taiwan. He was shocked to find that, in fact, the car thieves had not even bothered to remove the licence plate - it was the man's car.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAMES SOONG ANNOUNCES BOYCOTT OF PLANNED REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong said Tuesday that he will not vote in the upcoming referendum even though his party and the Kuomintang (KMT) have not reached a consensus on the issue.
The PFP leader made the remarks while responding to media questions raised regarding the referendum during a campaign tour in Ilan County.
President Chen Shui-bian of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has decided to hold a referendum in conjunction with the presidential election set for March 20.

The president also announced Jan. 16 in a pre-taped TV broadcast to the nation that he will ask the people of Taiwan to decide in the planned referendum whether the nation should further strengthen its defensive capabilities in response to mainland Chinese ever-increasing missiles deployment and whether it should try to work out an interaction mechanism to establish peace and stability with the mainland.

Pointing out that the proposed referendum is illegal, Soong, also the vice president candidate for the 2004 presidential campaign, said that since it is an unlawful referendum, his personal position is not to cast a vote.

Saying that it is not only illegal but inappropriate to hold a referendum on the same day as the presidential election, Soong reiterated that his party and the KMT have never been opposed to the referendum and that the two parties pushed for passage of the Referendum Law at the Legislative Yuan.

The so-called "defensive" referendum was designated as a last resort of the people of Taiwan to prevent the island's status quo from being changed unilaterally, he said; therefore, since there is no obvious danger that the island might face, the KMT and PFP are worried about the DPP's decision to hold such referendum.

Admitting that the KMT and PFP may reach a consensus in dealing with the upcoming referendum, Soong said that he personally will not vote in the referendum since rejecting to cast a vote is also a kind of vote to express one's choice and opinion.

Daniel Y.J. Hwang, spokesman for the PFP, also said that according to the law, the referendum will be invalid if more than half of the voters do not vote in the referendum, demonstrating that refusing to vote is also an option for the people.

While calling for the public to support KMT Chairman Lien Chan and Soong in the presidential campaign, Hwang said that the KMT and PFP will respect the voters' choices on issues regarding whether they vote in the referendum or not.

Meanwhile, Tsai Cheng-yuan, spokesman of the KMT-PFP headquarters for the presidential campaign, said Tuesday that considering the nation's stability, the KMT and PFP will not take any radical action on election day. He also said that he did not want to reveal what the two parties will do on that day.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTRY MUM ON U.S. NAVAL SHIPS STOPPING AT MAINLAND PORTS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense confirmed Tuesday that two United States Navy ships will visit Shanghai and Hong Kong between late February and early March, but would not comment on the military activities.

Defense ministry spokesman Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng was responding to reports that the USS Blue Ridge, the flagship of the U.S. Seventh Fleet, will arrive in Shanghai next week for a five-day visit, while the aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk will visit Hong Kong in early March for five days.

The mass-circulated United Daily News quoted observers as saying that the aircraft carrier's visit to Hong Kong will come at a sensitive time in the run-up to Taiwan's March 20 presidential election and is expected to help stabilize the situation.
Huang confirmed that the USS Blue Ridge will visit Shanghai Feb. 24, but said that this will only be a routine military exchange between the two sides.

Huang would not comment on whether the presence of the two U.S. Navy ships have anything to do with tensions between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait because of a referendum called by President Chen Shui-bian to be held alongside the March 20 presidential election in Taiwan. Chen is seeking re-election.
"The defense ministry will not comment on the U.S. military activities and there are no unusual military maneuvers in mainland China," Huang said.
During the two previous presidential elections in Taiwan, the United States also sent aircraft carriers to monitor waters near the Taiwan Strait.
In late February 2000, or one month before Taiwan's presidential election, the Kitty Hawk left its home port in Japan for the Taiwan Strait.

During the Taiwan Strait crisis in 1996, when mainland China lobbed missiles in the waters north of Taiwan, the United States also sent the aircraft carriers Nimitz and Independence to waters near the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEDIA CELEBRITY HOPES TO LEAD PRIVATE GROUP IN REFERENDUM DEBATES

TEXT.P: Influential media personality Jaw Shao-kang has decided to lead a group of "private individuals" to challenge the administration in the 10 scheduled debates on the referendum to be held on the same day as the March 20 presidential election.

Jaw, a noted television talk show host and chairman of UFO Radio, asked for the public to sign a document of endorsement for himself, independent Legislator Sisy Chen and writer Li Ao to become representatives of the "opposition" side in the 10 government-sponsored debates.
Formerly Jaw was a Kuomintang legislator and a head of the Environmental Protection Administration,

Once 1,547 legitimate voters endorse the trio, the three can be considered legal representatives of the private sector in the debates, although Chen is actually a legislator. The group's participation in the debates is allowed only in the event that none of the opposition parties in the Legislative Yuan step forward to take part in the debates, according to regulations of the Central Election Commission (CEC), the sponsor of the debates.

As of noon Tuesday, all four legislative caucuses of the opposition parties had turned down the CEC's invitation to assign debaters to represent the opposition; in effect, to prosecute the referendum in the debates.

According to CEC regulations, if the Legislative Yuan fails to put forward a list of names to represent the prosecution side by Monday and no other private group applies before Feb. 20 to take part in the debates, or to take the "con" side, the 10 debates will instead be presentations of the Executive Yuan's views regarding the referendum and its two questions.

Appealing for people to come forward and endorse his efforts to organize a private sector opposition debate team, Jaw said some people must step forward to challenge the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the debates to prevent Taiwan's first-ever referendum from becoming a one-sided story.

Jaw said he is not an anti-referendum extremist, but said that he, Chen and Li share the thoughts of U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell and consider the questions to be asked on the March 20 referendum, proposed by President Chen Shui-bian, to be "odd."
"We think the referendum questions are peculiar, prompting us to decide to step forward," Jaw noted.

The two referendum questions are whether Taiwan should strengthen its anti-missile defense capability if mainland China refuses to remove its deployed missiles aimed at the island, and whether the government should engage in negotiations with Beijing for the establishment of a mechanism for peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait.

Meanwhile, military spokesman Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng said Friday that the Ministry of National Defense will follow the decisions that are made by the Executive Yuan pertaining to the referendum debates.
Huang said the defense ministry has no opinions on who will be appointed by the Executive Yuan from the ministry as debaters representing the defense side of the vote.

Referring to reports that Vice Minister of National Defense Lin Chong-pin and several other officials from the Ministry of National Defense have been appointed by the Executive Yuan to represent the DPP in the referendum debates, Huang said that to the best of his knowledge, Lin had not been contacted by Executive Yuan officials about the debates as of noon Tuesday.
Reports said that other administration officials who have been appointed include Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen and Straits Exchange Foundation Vice Chairman Shi Hwei-yow.

Executive Yuan spokesman Lin Chia-lung said Tuesday that it is a pity that all the opposition parties in the Legislative Yuan have rejected the administration's invitation to take part in the referendum debates, prompting the CEC to invite people from the private sector to take part.

TAIEX Index futures for March rose 46 points to finish at 6,620, with 18,660 contract transactions, while June futures gained 55 points to close at 6,640, with 24 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,571 for February, 6,574 for March, 6,585 for June, 6,596 for September, and 6,614 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were generally higher.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC CONTINUES TO COMMUNICATE WITH MIAOLI OVER REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) will continue to communicate with Miaoli County election officials over the national referendum scheduled to be held on the day of the presidential election March 20, CEC Chairman Huang Shih-cheng said Tuesday.

Huang declined to comment on the decision reportedly made by the Miaoli County Election Commission Monday that the Miaoli officials will submit a proposal to the Executive Yuan requiring the CEC to either allow for the separation of polling stations for the presidential election and the referendum vote, or cancel the referendum altogether.

Huang said the CEC has not been informed by the Miaoli County Election Commission yet about its opinions on the referendum, adding that the CEC will continue to communicate with the local government on the issue.

Members of the Miaoli County Election Commission passed a resolution unanimously Monday requiring the Executive Yuan to either separate the presidential election polling stations from the referendum voting stations or cancel the referendum outright to avoid confusion or trouble from occurring on election day.

Miaoli County Election Commission Chairman Ku Chen-ching said that he does not exclude the possibility of stepping down from his post if the Executive Yuan refuses to adopt Miaoli County's suggestion while his commission insists on sticking to its resolution.

Ku said last Friday that the Miaoli County Election Commission has decided to let Miaoli voters cast their ballots for the presidential election and the referendum at different polling stations based on the notion that different laws apply to the two events.
Ku said the move is aimed at reducing any risks, simplifying the procedures for casting ballots, and allowing the voting to be carried out smoothly.
Ku said that if the move to separate the polling stations is not accepted by the central government, he will take full responsibility.

Commenting on Miaoli County's plans to separate the polling stations, Huang said last Friday that all local governments should follow the regulations put forth by the CEC with regard to election and voting affairs.
Premier Yu Shyi-Kun also called for all relevant local government authorities last Friday to observe the CEC regulations in the upcoming presidential election and Taiwan's first-ever referendum.
"Any local governments or civil servants that violate the CEC regulations will be dealt with squarely and will be legally responsible for their actions," Yu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE, MALAYSIA TO HOLD JOINT MOCK EMERGENCY EXERCISE

TEXT.P: Two government agencies from Singapore and Malaysia will hold a joint mock emergency exercise Feb. 19 in which an accident involving the leakage of chemical gas will be simulated.
The exercise, organized by Singapore's National Environment Agency (NEA) and Johor's Department of Environment (DOE) , will be held from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. at the 2nd Link at Tuas.
According to an NEA spokeswoman, the objective of the biennial exercise is to "test the operational effectiveness of the emergency response plan developed by the two agencies."
Officers from the police and civil defense departments, Maritime and Port Authority, Police Coast Guard, and Immigration & Checkpoints Authority will be involved in the exercise.
The exercise will simulate an accident involving a prime mover carrying two 4-ton demountable tanks containing 99.9 percent anhydrous ammonia on the 2nd Link and traveling towards Singapore.

The NEA says only the left lane on both sides of the 2nd Link near the exercise area will be open to traffic during the exercise. The agency has also advised the public and motorists not to be alarmed and to closely follow the directions of traffic police at the site of the exercise.

DOC.HEADLINE: ILLEGAL BABY TRADE OPERATING JUST A FERRY RIDE FROM SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: In Singapore, while some childless couples try modern medicine to have a child, others turn to criminal gangs.

In this region, there is an illegal baby trade operating just a ferry ride from Singapore. Indonesian officials frown upon the illegal adoption racket, and those caught can be jailed up to nine years.
However, the illegal trade is thriving, with the main figures of organized baby smuggling rings remaining at large.

Orphanages are often the first stop for children of parents who can't afford to raise a young one because of severe financial hardship. But some babies born out of wedlock do not end up at orphanages. They end up in the illegal adoption trade.
The baby smugglers haven't gone unnoticed by the Indonesian and Malaysian police, with both sides now working to solve this problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMERICAN FUGITIVE REPATRIATED

TEXT.P: An American fugitive who was wanted by United States law enforcement authorities was repatriated Wednesday night, according to officials of the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB).
The officials said that W.A. Kimmick, an electronic engineer who was charged with second-degree murder by a circuit court in Vermont for killing his wife in January.
The CIB found that Kimmick fled to Taiwan on a Eva Airways flight Jan. 25 after receiving a request for help from the U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation through Interpol.

Kimmick surrendered to a police station in Pingtung, southern Taiwan Feb. 8 on the suggestion of his friend with whom he had stayed since his arrival in Taiwan and was transferred to a foreign detainees' center in Shanhsia, northern Taiwan on the same day.
Kimmick was delivered to U.S. FBI agents on Wednesday night aboard a Continental Airlines flight at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PRESIDENT SUMMONED IN CASE INVOLVING NATIONAL SECURITY BUREAU

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui was summoned to appear before a court on April 14 as a witness in the trial of the former accounting director of the National Security Bureau (NSB), according to the Taipei District Court.

Lee will be the last in a series of witnesses to be questioned in the case. Fifteen other high-profile witnesses will be questioned in the trial before April 14, including the president's former personal secretary Su Chih-cheng, former Foreign Minister Jason Hu, former NSB Director Ting Yu-chou, former chairman of the China Development Industrial Bank Liu Tai-ying and businessman Ying Yen-liang.
The case stems from the country's US$10.5 million financial aid to South Africa's ruling party, the African National Congress, in 1994.

As president of the country at the time, Lee ordered the NSB to pay the aid in advance with money from a slush fund kept by it and asked the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to repay the money to the NSB in 1999.

However, for still unknown reasons, the repayment was routed to the Taiwan Research Institute, a private think tank led by Liu Tai-ying. Liu also took some US$150,000 from the repayment to line his own pockets.
Lee became chairman of the Taiwan Research Institute after his term as president was over in 2000. Liu was the president of the Taiwan Research Institute.
The whole case is still under investigation, but the former NSB chief accountant Hsu Ping-chiang and the former NSB chief cashier Liu Kuan-chun were indicted on Nov. 17, 2003 for corruption.

Liu Kuan-chun fled the country on Sept. 3, 2000 before the case came to light, making away with NT$190 million from the slush fund. Therefore Hsu is the only person to come to trial in the case thus far.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO TRANSFORM TAOYUAN INTO AIR TRANSPORT HUB: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The government plans to transform Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan, into an air transportation hub, President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday.

Speaking at a meeting with some 400 representatives of businesses established in eight industrial parks in Taoyuan, Chen said that one-fourth of the proposed budget of NT$500 billion (US$15.1 billion) for the 10 new major projects for the next five years will be used in construction of the county's transportation facilities, including a rapid transit system linking the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport with the mass transit system of Chungli City.
In addition, he continued, the construction projects for an air cargo park and a passenger transportation center have been contracted.
Once these projects are finished, Chen said, Taoyuan will become an air transportation city.

Together with the high-speed railway, which will be inaugurated by the end of next year, Taoyuan will help Taiwan become a "city-state," making every place in the country accessible within one day, he added.

Chen also touted the economic achievements of his administration, including the improvement of financial institutions' operations, the economic recovery, the increase of investment in the country and the sharpening of the nation's international competitiveness.
Taiwan's economy will take off again in light of the booming housing industry and stock market over the recent months, the president affirmed.
He encouraged domestic enterprises to join the government's efforts to construct the nation for the sake of the people's welfare.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO REVISING RULES TO OFFER HANDSOMER REWARD FOR FILM-MAKERS

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) is reviewing the current rules to provide greater financial backing to domestic film-makers to underpin the ailing domestic industry, a spokesman for the GIO said Wednesday.

The new measures, worked out as six sub-plans contained in "Challenge 2008" -- a six-year, national development plan initiated by the Executive Yuan early last year -- were put forward at a weekly Cabinet meeting held earlier the same day.

The set of incentives is expected to inject a new lease on life to the domestic industry, allowing Taiwan-based film-makers who have made a mark in leading international film festivals or have received awards to receive government financial assistance to help their work, the spokesman said.

In essence, a Taiwan-made film, no matter whether it is purely a domestic production or a transnational joint venture that has gained prominent awards at international film festivals, will get government subsidies of up to a total of NT$100 million (US$3 million) with their new work. The concept for the film, however, must be submitted for approval from the GIO within two years.
Premier Yu Shyi-kun highly praised the new plan, saying that it will effectively encourage domestic film-makers to create new works.

DOC.HEADLINE: REFERENDUM DEBATES GET FIRST GROUP OF CHALLENGERS

TEXT.P: A group ready to challenge the government's referendum obtained the required signatures Wednesday to take part in a series of debates on the issue, independent legislator and talk show host Sisy Chen said.
As an outspoken critic of President Chen Shui-bian, she challenged him to defend his call for a referendum in person in the public debates.

One day after Sisy Chen and another well-known television talk show host, Jaw Shau-kong, announced that they and three others will team up to challenge the legality of the referendum in 10 debates organized by the Central Election Commission (CEC) over the two referendum questions, they collected the signatures of more than 2,400 individuals, nearly twice the 1,500 sponsors needed to participate in the debates.

Sisy Chen, who has denounced the referendum as illegal, unnecessary and flirting with conflict from neighboring states, volunteered to serve as a member on the opposition side in the debates after the CEC failed to find any team to debate against the affirmative side, which is made up of government officials and pro-referendum scholars.

At a news conference announcing having secured the requisite number of signatures to form an opposition debate team, Sisy Chen named specific people she said her team would most like to face off with: President Chen, Vice President Annette Lu, Minister of National Defense Tang Yiau-min, Chairperson of the Mainland Affairs Council Tsai Ing-wen and Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh.

Tang and Tsai were named to the government team because the two questions to be asked in the referendum fall within the scope of their offices. Hsieh was probably named because he is considered one of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's big guns and is known for his debating skills.

Sisy Chen also named several people that she said had no place in the debates since they are in charge of implementing the referendum: Premier Yu Shyi-kun, Minister of the Interior Yu Cheng-hsien and spokesman for the Executive Yuan Lin Chia-lung.

Jaw, a former lawmaker and the host of a popular television talk show, also appeared at the news conference and said that he jumped at the chance to be on the opposition debate team. "I can't stand democracy without dissenting opinions," he said.
Jaw, who was defeated by Chen for mayor of Taipei City in 1994, has been considered a sympathizer for Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, Chen's only rival in the presidential race.

Lien's strategy has been to keep a lid on the controversy surrounding the referendum as much as possible out of concerns that if the questions are to be publicly debated, this would have the unfortunate effect of drawing attention away from the presidential race and focus attention on the referendum, which has been a rallying point for the president's campaign.

Until Sisy Chen and Jaw got the needed signatures to be in the debate, no opposing political party had come forward to take part and the debates were to have been transformed into one-sided information sessions conducted by the Executive Yuan. Sisy Chen and Jaw's move put the referendum back on the front burner of public debate.

Jaw, however, brushed aside journalists' questions that his participation in the debates might be harmful to Lien's campaign. "Why should I concern myself about Lien's campaign? Am I my brother's keeper? " he asked.
"I just want to debunk the president's claims surrounding this ill- conceived referendum. It has nothing to do with Lien. Lien's party has no right to tell me to shut up," he said.
Several little-known social activist groups also hope to field a team to participate in the referendum debates, but as yet have not secured the needed signatures for inclusion.
The deadline for the signature drive is Friday.

The CEC plans to organized five debates for each of the two questions to be on the referendum, with five people defending and five opposing each of the two questions, meaning that each team will be limited to 10 people.
If more than 10 people are qualified to be on the opposition team, the final group will be determined by negotiations or by drawing lots if needed.

Writer Li Ao appeared the previous day as part of the opposition debating team but was not at the news conference on Wednesday. The other members of the team are still being considered, and a final list has been tentatively scheduled for release on Feb. 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: OKINAWA DELEGATION VISITS KAOHSIUNG COUNTY MAGISTRATE

TEXT.P: A 25-member delegation from Okinawa visited Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing Wednesday.

The delegates were warmly greeted by Yang, who gave a briefing about his county's industrial development and investment climate on various key fronts to the Japanese visitors without forgetting to mention that the county is also rich in farm produce.

Kaohsiung County has been actively promoting high technologies and working to boost environmental protection awareness, Yang said, adding that the county has solid infrastructure for the movement of goods and people, pointing to the fact that it takes only about 30 minutes by car to get from various key points in the county to Kaohsiung International Airport or Kaohsiung Port.

There are two American schools and one Japanese school in the greater Kaohsiung area, which give Kaohsiung County a sound environment for school-age children of hi-tech experts willing to work in the county, Yang said.

At the same time, construction of the research building at the county's environmental technology industrial park is slated for June next year, Yang announced. Investors setting up shop in the compound will be provided with handsome incentives and preferential loans, he said.

According to Yang, Kaohsiung County has courted capital worth more than NT$130 billion (US$3.93 billion) in investment projects. What the county needs now is technology and manpower, he noted, expressing his hope for a trade and investment partnership between Okinawa and his county.

In response to Yang's invitation, the chief delegate of the Okinawa mission said that his group members are very interested in two-way cooperative ventures and that they welcome the Kaohsiung County magistrate to visit Okinawa in April. Noting that Okinawa has a free trade zone, he said tourism, health care and environmentally friendly sectors are its key income sources.
Members of the delegation included officials of the Okinawa Prefecture Government, university professors and environmental protection specialists.

DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Kerry holds off push by Edwards in primary vote in Wisconsin.
The U.S. Democratic presidential nomination battle turned into a two-man contest on Tuesday as Senator John Kerry narrowly defeated Senator John Edwards in the Wisconsin primary. Howard Dean suffered a dismal third-place showing that Democrats said would effectively end his campaign.
The finish by Edwards startled Democrats here, as well as those in the Kerry and Edwards camps, who had been looking for Kerry to post another decisive victory in Wisconsin, based on his performance so far this year.
Wall Street Journal: Cingular deal will reshape industry.
The huge acquisition deal that the U.S. wireless industry had been anticipating for more than two years has reshaped the industry.
If regulators approve the deal without forcing Cingular to shed substantial assets, it would create the largest U.S. wireless company, with more than 46 million customers. Cingular's coverage will extend to 97 out of the nation's top 100 markets. With AT&T Wireless, Cingular will have enough spectrum -- the invisible airwaves used to carry wireless calls -- to bring the masses anything from basic cellphone calls to Web surfing.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR GENERATIONS OF FIRST FAMILY TO ATTEND HUMAN CHAIN CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: The four generations of the first family will take part in an islandwide human chain campaign scheduled for Feb. 28, the nation's Peace Memorial Day, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) caucus in the Taipei city council said Wednesday.

DPP council whip Lee Chien-chang said that the first family members will include first lady Wu Shu-chen, President Chen Shui-bian's mother Chen Li Sheng, first daughter Chen Hsin-yu, her husband Chao Chien-ming, and their son Chao Yi-an.

Lee made the announcement as he unveiled the road map for the Taipei City section of the "one million hand-in-hand" campaign, a length of 16.1 kilometers that will meander from Nankang Road to Mingchuan West Road.
Lee said that members of the first family will gather at the 2-28 Peace Memorial Park, the command post of the campaign, to join others for the colossal human chain.

Lee said that DPP officials, elected officials, private civic groups, businesses, and medical groups will line up along the road and that around 40,000 have registered to take part, not including those expected to show up on the day.

Lee said that around 4,000 people will gather at the 2-28 Peace Memorial Park for a rehearsal before the main event, which will take place at 2: 28 p.m., and that the members of the first family and three generations of Taipei County Magistrate Su Tseng-chang's family will hold hands.
DPP Deputy Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan urged all those interested to take part.
Lee said that participants who can round up five generations of their families will be invited to the Presidential Office for tea.

He also urged the participants to bring mobile phones, cameras and radios with them so that they can listen to a national broadcast and take the pictures of their family members joining hands. The pictures will be gathered on a Web site, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC FORMS MECHANISM TO COPE WITH CEPA

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Wednesday it has forged a special consultative mechanism with Taiwan business people operating in Hong Kong and Macau to cope with challenges from th Closer Economic Partnership Arrangement (CEPA).

Chang Yung-shan, director of the MAC's Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Department, said since mainland China implemented the CEPA to strengthen its economic partnerships with Hong Kong and Macau at the beginning of this year, trade and investment between Taiwan and Hong Kong have been affected slightly.
To address the new challenges, Chang said, his department has forged a new mechanism to facilitate contacts with Hong Kong- and Macau-based Taiwanese business people.

"We'll continue monitoring the CEPA development and working out feasible measures to cope with any impact that may arise from the new economic partnerships between mainland China and the two former Western colonies," Chang said.
In addition to the CEPA development, Chang said preventing transmission of avian flu and severe acute respiratory syndromes (SARS) viruses is also on the MAC's priority work agenda.

Chang said trade and investment between Taiwan and Hong Kong declined in 2003 as compared with the year-earlier level mainly because some Taiwanese businessmen adopted a wait-and-see attitude ahead of the implementation of the CEPA.

In 2003, Taiwan-Hong Kong trade amounted to US$30.1 billion, down 7.79 percent from 2002. Taiwan exports to Hong Kong declined 8.19 percent while its imports from the former British colony dropped 0.75 percent.

In contrast, Chang said, indirect trade between Taiwan and mainland China via Hong Kong increased last year. In the first 11 months, cross-Taiwan Strait trade via Hong Kong totaled US$12.72 billion, up 15.95 percent from the same period of 2002. Of the amount, Taiwan exports to the mainland via Hong Kong reached US$10.77 billion, up 14.32 percent; while Taiwan imports from the mainland via Hong Kong increased US$25.85 percent to US$1.95 billion.

Meanwhile, Chang said, Taiwan businessmen invested US$640 million in Hong Kong in 2003, down 283.86 percent from 2002; while Hong Kong investment in Taiwan also declined 32.33 percent to US$44 million.
Taiwan's investment in Hong Kong focused on banking and insurance and electronics, while Hong Kong's investment in Taiwan centered on wholesaling and retailing business.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOMB HOAXER NABBED

TEXT.P: A man who made a hoax bomb call to the Hsinchu Railway Station Feb. 8 was nabbed late Tuesday at his home in Miaoli, northern Taiwan.

Lo Wei-wen admitted to police that he made the hoax call warning that there was a bomb on a train from Hsinchu to Taichung Feb. 8. He made the call while waiting in vain at the Hsinchu railway station for his estranged girl friend.

Since suspicious devices had already been found twice on the train this year -- once Jan. 5 and again Feb. 2 -- rail officials took the warning seriously and stopped five Hsinchu-Taichung trains for inspection. Although nothing was found, the inspection snarled rail traffic all over northern Taiwan.

Police traced the hoax call to Lo's cellphone and arrested him, but to their disappointment, found he is not the bomber who has left explosive devices in eight places in Taipei City since last November. That bomber has been nicknamed the "rice bomber" because of his habit of leaving statements on his devices protesting the country's rice imports.

None of the devices, which lack fuses, pose any real danger to the public but police are alarmed nevertheless, as the devices are quite sophisticated and show that their maker has the skills to made a real bomb.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEAD OF MIAOLI ELECTION COMMISSION RESIGNS OVER REFERENDUM ISSUE

TEXT.P: The head of the Miaoli Election Commission announced his resignation Wednesday after days of rows over his proposal to separate polling stations for the March 20 presidential election and referendum.

Miaoli County Election Commission Chairman Ku Cheng-ching said that based on his experience in dealing with local elections, he had proposed to the Central Election Commission (CEC) that the ballots for the referendum and the presidential election be cast at different stations to avoid confusion, adding that the proposal was based on the notion that different laws apply to the two events.
He said the move was aimed at "reducing any risks, simplifying the procedures for casting ballots and allowing the voting to be carried out smoothly."
But he said that his proposal was ignored and that he was repeatedly bullied and intimidated by people protesting his proposal, adding that some even came to his office to call him names.
Ku became choked with emotion several times while delivering his resignation statement and at one point appeared to be on the point of collapse.
After he recovered, he expressed the hope that the government will respect the basic rights of everyone and that every voter will face the election in a rational manner.

Meanwhile, Executive Yuan spokesman Lin Chia-lung said that the Executive Yuan will "respect the wishes of individual election officials" and that the CEC is monitoring the local election commissions and will handle related matters.
The CEC said that it is dealing with the matter according to the law, and that the vacancy left by Ku will be filled by a suitable person.

Voters will get three ballots on election day -- one for the presidential election and the other two for the referendum questions concerning strengthening Taiwan's anti-missile capability and the re-opening of cross-Taiwan Strait talks. The government wants the three ballots to be cast at the same station and has said that even votes placed in the wrong ballot boxes will be counted.

DOC.HEADLINE: LARGE AMOUNT OF CONTRABAND MAINLAND CHINESE MEDICINE SEIZED

TEXT.P: Customs officers reported Wednesday that a large amount of contraband mainland Chinese medicine had been seized a day earlier at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport's cargo terminal.
The contraband included balms, anti-impotence pills, powdered heart disease medicine and herbal extracts, packed in 11 boxes.
Customs officers said that although the medicine can be obtained easily in mainland China, they are banned from entering Taiwan because none of it has passed Cabinet-level Department of Health tests.
Much of the haul is expensive on the mainland market, the customs officers said, adding that the total seizures are worth an estimated NT$10 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIVIC, INDUSTRIAL WATER SUPPLIES TO BE SECURED: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun instructed relevant government agencies Wednesday to continue monitoring the water resources situation across Taiwan to secure sufficient water use for the general public and industry.
Yu issued the instruction during a weekly Cabinet meeting after hearing a briefing by officials from the Water Resources Agency (WRA) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

The MOEA formally announced a day earlier that the second-phase water restrictions imposed from Feb. 6 in five cities and counties in northern Taiwan -- Taipei City, Taipei County, Taoyuan City, Hsinchu City and Hsinchu County -- had been lifted, thanks to recent rainfall brought by several cold fronts since the Chinese New Year holiday season in late January.
The second-phase water restrictions comprised a 20-percent cutback in water supplies to heavy users such as car washes, swimming pools and saunas.
The water level at the Feitsui Reservoir in Taipei County has rebounded to about 160 meters -- a normal level for this time of year.

Yu, however, called on the public to continue conserving water, even though adequate water use has been secured through late May, because the possibility of a dry spell has not yet been totally ruled out.

As it was decided that about 65,000 hectares of farmland and rice paddies in northern regions will lie fallow in the coming months in line with the central government's water conservation program, the premier also demanded that the MOEA, the Council of Agriculture and regional irrigation associations take charge of the issue to fully protect farmers' interests.
Taiwan, especially the northern region, has been hit hard by a water shortage over the past two years due to an extreme scarcity of rainfall.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY GOVERNMENT LIFTS TEMPERATURE-TAKING MEASURES

TEXT.P: Temperature-taking measures that had been in place at agencies under the jurisdiction of the Taipei city government and Taipei municipal hospitals were formally lifted Tuesday.

The Taipei city government's decision was made after the Cabinet-level Department of Health announced on Monday that Taiwan's epidemic prevention mobilization level against severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) had been downgraded to level "Zero" from level "A."

The DOH has classified four levels of SARS precautions -- Zero, A, B and C -- with C as the most stringent grade. The level was lowered because no new SARS cases have been reported around the world since the world's most recent SARS patient was discharged from a hospital in the southern mainland Chinese city of Guangzhou Jan. 30.

The city government's Department of Health said that because of the DOH's announcement, people entering city government agencies and municipal hospitals are no longer required to have their temperature taken and are not required to wear surgical masks when entering hospitals, although it advised those with fever to wear a mask.
However, health officials said that although the vigilance level against SARS is lower, the public must remain on guard against avian influenza.

The officials said that they were happy that a wave of flu expected after Chinese New Year failed to occur, but added that under the threat of reported avian flu cases in Asia, they will continue to ask those who work in schools, hospices and hospitals to monitor their temperatures daily.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO BECOME MEDICAL EDUCATION, RESEARCH CENTER: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that Taiwan will become a medical education and research hub in Asia and a major medical technology and services exporting country with the inauguration of a new biomedical industry park.

Chen made the remarks at a ceremony marking the start of preparations for construction of the biomedical industry park in the northern Taiwan county of Hsinchu, which hosts Taiwan's high-tech center -- the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park.
The new Hsinchu biomedical industry park will pool the resources of the public and private sectors to boost development in biomedicine and relevant medical technologies, Chen said.

"With concerted efforts of the government, academia and the business community, I'm convinced that Taiwan will emerge as a regional medical education and research center, as well as a major exporter of medical technology and services, " Chen said.
Noting that biomedical industry as become a new focus of development in many advanced countries in recent years, Chen said Taiwan cannot afford to lag behind in this field.
He added that his administration has listed the new biomedical industry park as one of the "Ten New Major Construction Projects" aimed at upgrading Taiwan's overall national competitiveness.
The new park will be located on 38.3-hectares of land near the high-speed railway's Chupei station, currently under construction.

At Wednesday's ceremony, the Bureau of Taiwan High Speed Rail under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications handed over control of the land to National Taiwan University (NTU) , which will be responsible for planning and management of the new biomedical park.
NTU President Chen Wei-chao said Japan's Nomura Research Institute has been commissioned to draw up a construction blueprint for the NT$20 billion project.
"Construction of infrastructure and other public facilities inside the park is scheduled to get underway in the second half of 2005 and the park will begin operations in 2008," Chen Wei-chao said.
He said the new park will house a research-oriented medical center to serve as the park's research and development driving force.

When the park is inaugurated in 2008, Chen said, Taiwan's biomedical industry production will increase by 20 percent annually in the first five years and will create more than 10,000 jobs for well-trained professionals, particularly those with tertiary academic degrees.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECOND CIVIC GROUP TO OPPOSE REFERENDUM QUESTIONS IN TV DEBATES

TEXT.P: Another civic group has expressed the desire to represent those who are opposed to the March 20 referendum in 10 scheduled television debates on the two referendum questions concerning the nation's anti-missile capability and the reopening of cross-strait talks.

Lo Chi-chiang, president of the Chinese Speech and Debate Association, said that his "Citizen Right View Alliance" is soliciting signatures and is expected to collect enough names before Friday to gain approval from the Central Election Commission (CEC) to take part in the debates.

Lo's announcement came on the heels of announcements by several TV personalities, including independent Legislator Sisy Chen, former legislator and TV and radio station host Jaw Shau-kong and writer Li Ao, that they also wish to challenge the "yea" team formed by the Executive Yuan, which is in charge of implementing the referendum.

The CEC invited the private sector to form a team to represent referendum opponents after no opposition political parties in the Legislative Yuan expressed any desire to represent the opposition side before the dateline expired Monday.
Lo said "referendum is a right of the people, although they should cast their ballots only after careful consideration."

According to Lo, the three TV celebrities' desire to take part in the debate seems likely to end up as rivalry between the "pan green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, and the "pan blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party.

"I don't want to see the debate turning into rivalry between political camps rather than discussion of the issues, " Lo said, adding that his aim is to call to public attention whether Taiwan actually needs to purchase anti-missile systems.

According to the rules of the CEC, the "yea" and "nay" sides must each recommend one to five people to take part in the debate. If both civic groups intend to take part in the debate, they will have to coordinate between themselves on which ones will take part in which debate.
If the coordination falls through, then the representatives will be decided through the drawing of lots.

Lo stressed that as his pitch is different from that of the TV celebrities, who want to highlight the absurdity of what they call the "illegal" referendum called by President Chen Shui-bian, his alliance will not merge with Jaw's team, although it is possible that they will have to coordinate on procedural arrangements.
The debates will be held between Feb. 20 and March 19, according to the CEC plan.
The two questions to be asked in the March 20 referendum alongside the presidential election are:

-- Should mainland China refuse to withdraw the missile it has targeted at Taiwan and openly renounce the use of force against us, do you agree that the government should acquire more advanced anti-missile weapons to strengthen Taiwan's self-defense capabilities?

-- Do you agree that our government should engage in negotiation with mainland China over the establishment of a peace and stability framework for cross-strait interaction in order to build a consensus and for the welfare of the people of both sides?
