DOC.HEADLINE: SEVEN STATE-RUN CORPORATIONS POST BETTER PROFITS IN JANUARY

TEXT.P: Seven state-run companies posted combined profits of NT$2.348 billion (US$71 million) in January, up by NT$1.231 billion over the target set by the government, according to statistics compiled by the Commission of National Corporation (CNC) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

Of the seven national corporations -- Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) , Taiwan Provincial Water Company, Taiwan Sugar Corporation, Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) , Tang Eng Iron Works Corp., Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. (AIDC) and China Shipbuilding Corp -- Taiwan Sugar and AIDC were operating in the red, recording losses of NT$105 million and NT$143 million, respectively.

Taipower registered the largest pre-tax earnings of NT$1.556 billion last month, up by NT$756 million over the government-set objective. Taiwan Provincial Water Company recorded profits of NT$155 million, in contrast to an early estimated loss of NT$17 million. The CPC earned an additional NT$242 million as a result of rising oil prices on the international market.

CNC Chairman Wu Feng-sheng attributed the profits notched up by Taipower and Taiwan Provincial Water Company to the global economic upturn, which has boosted the manufacturing sector, resulting in stronger demand for water and power.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND ISSUES POSITION PAPER ON REFERENDUM QUESTIONS

TEXT.P: Minister of National Defense Tang Yiau-min confirmed Wednesday that the Ministry of National Defense (MND) has issued a position paper on its anti-missile forces build-up plan in preparation for Taiwan's first-ever referendum.

Tang made the confirmation at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's National Defense Committee where opposition People First Party Legislator Ku Chung-lien unveiled an MND position paper saying the ministry has been working on an anti-missile battery deployment plan since 1997 and will begin to implement a Patriot anti-missile battery procurement project in 2005.

The MND position paper makes it clear, Ku pointed out, that no matter what the results of the March 20 referendum will be, the ministry's plan to purchase advanced anti-missile weaponry systems will not be affected.
"Against this backdrop, do we really need to hold a referendum alongside the March 20 presidential election?" Ku asked.

Tang did not answer Ku's question directly, saying only that the MND has explained its stance "based on professionalism." Tang also refrained from revealing to whom copies of the position paper have been distributed.

In the upcoming referendum, the electorate will be asked whether Taiwan should acquire more missiles to defend itself against military threats from mainland China and whether the island should enter talks with Beijing for the establishment of a framework for peaceful interaction.
The MND position paper points out that mainland China's missile threats have existed for a long time and that the mainland has so far refused to renounce the option of using force against Taiwan.

According to the position paper, the mainland now has more than 100 strategic ballistic missiles armed with nuclear warheads that can strike any country in the world. In the future, the position paper says, the mainland's strategic missiles, which are of various configurations and types, including Dongfeng 3, 4, 5, 5A, 21, 21A and 31, will be able to be fired from any waters around the globe.

In addition, the position paper says, the mainland has deployed about 500 tactical ballistic missiles of four types -- Dongfeng 11, 11A, 15 and 15A -- along its southeastern coast opposite Taiwan. Each mainland tactical missile is armed with multiple highly explosive warheads. These tactical missiles can not only strike any area of Taiwan but can also hit major U.S. military bases in South Korea, Okinawa and elsewhere in Japan.

Noting that the mainland's annual tactical missile output ranges between 50 and 75 units, the position paper predicts that the number of tactical missiles deployed in coastal mainland provinces will exceed 600 by 2005.

The position paper further says that the mainland's tactical missiles are mobile and tightly guarded and require only a short preparatory time prior to launch. Their accuracy rate has been largely increased with the installation of satellite positioning systems.
In the face of the intensified missile build-up, the position paper says, Taiwan must beef up its anti-missile defense capabilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

The bourse opened at 6,656.1 and fluctuated between 6,661.13 and 6,586.74 during trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: POWER CONSUMPTION UP BY 5.4 PERCENT FOR 2003

TEXT.P: Amid a gradual economic recovery, power consumption in Taiwan increased by 5.4 percent in 2003 over the year-earlier level, according to statistics released Wednesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) under the Executive Yuan.

DGBAS officials said that in 2001, amid a global economic slump, Taiwan's power consumption increased by only 0.9 percent over the previous year, compared with an increase of 8.1 percent for 2000. The increase in 2001 was Taiwan's lowest in nearly a decade.
Over the past decade, the growth in Taiwan's power consumption each year has for the most part hovered between 5.3 percent and 9 percent.

The economic recovery over the past two years has been reflected in a gradual rise in power consumption, with year-on-year increases of 5.3 percent and 5.4 percent for 2002 and 2003, respectively, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTER DENIES REPORT ABOUT ARMS PROCUREMENT BUDGET

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) denied a media report Wednesday that the ministry will put forward a NT$500 billion (US$15.11 billion) arms procurement budget plan for deliberation by the Cabinet before the March 20 presidential election.
Defense Minister Tang Yiau-min made the denial at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's National Defense Committee.

During the session, opposition Kuomintang Legislator Chiang Chi-wen asked Tang whether the MND really will finalize the special arms purchase budget plan ahead of the election as a local newspaper has reported.
In reply, Tang said the report is absolutely not true. "You can wait and see whether we present the reported budget proposal to the Cabinet before the election," he added.

The China Times quoted unidentified sources as reporting Wednesday that the MND has ordered the Navy and the Army to finalize their budget plans for purchasing eight submarines, 12 P3-C anti-submarine aircraft and three Patriot anti-missile batteries as soon as possible so that the ministry can refer a comprehensive budget plan to the Cabinet on March 18.
Tang dismissed the report as sheer speculation, stressing that arms procurement must follow institutionalized procedures.

"The MND has established standard operational rules, and arms procurement budget planning must follow the rules without any exceptions, " Tang said, adding that he himself is unlikely to abuse his power to interfere with arms procurement budget planning procedures.
To the best of his understanding, Tang said, preparations for purchasing the stated weaponry systems have not yet reached the budget evaluation stage.
According to the unconfirmed newspaper report, procurement of the submarines, anti-submarine aircraft and Patriot anti-missile systems will cost about NT$520 billion.

The Bush administration already agreed to sell eight conventional submarines, 12 P3-C anti-submarine aircraft and three advanced Patriot anti-missile batteries to Taiwan in 2001. However, none of the deals have been completed partly because of the huge amount of funds needed for the procurement.

In Taiwan's first-ever nationwide referendum to be held alongside the upcoming presidential poll, the electorate will be asked whether Taiwan should acquire more missiles to defend itself against military threats from mainland China and whether the island should enter talks with Beijing for the establishment of a framework for peaceful interaction..

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Feb. 18, or the 28th day of first month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1517: Mary Tudor, the English queen known as "Bloody Mary" because of her relentless persecution of Protestants, is born.
1546: Martin Luther, German theologian and the 16th century Protestant reformation leader who confirmed the Augsburg Confession in 1530, effectively establishing the Lutheran Church, dies in Eisleben, Germany, at the age of 63.
1564: Michelangelo Buonarotti, Italian sculptor, painter, architect, poet, and the most brilliant representative of the Italian Renaissance who created some of the greatest works of all time, including his marble sculpture "David," the paintings on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel, and the plans for St. Peter's Cathedral, dies in Rome at the age of 89.
1678: John Bunyan, English preacher and writer celebrated for his "Pilgrim's Progress," the allegorical tale of a Christian's journey from the City of Destruction to the Celestial City, publishes the first part of his masterpiece.
1685: La Salle, a French explorer, sets up the first European settlement in Texas.
1745: Alessandro Volta, Italian physicist who invented the electric battery, is born. The volt is named in his honor.
1855: Nicholas I, the czar of Russia who suppressed the December Movement and led his country into the Crimean War, dies at the age of 59.
1915: German submarines start a maritime blockade of Great Britain.
1930: Clyde William Tombaugh, a US astronomer, is the first to see Pluto, realizing it is the Sun's ninth and smallest planet, at the Lowell Observatory in Flagstaff, Arizona.
1932: Japan announces that the "Manchukuo" regime will be installed in northeastern China. The "land of the Manchu" (Manchuria) proved to be no more than another stepping-stone for the expansion of Japanese aggression.
1943: Madame Chiang Kai-shek addresses a joint session of the US House and Senate.
1945: The battle for Iwo Jima starts in the Pacific.
1951: Prime Minister Tran Van Huu announces the formation of a new government in Vietnam.
1960: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Mexico, Paraguay, Peru and Uruguay agree to establish the Latin American Free Trade Association.
1965: The West African nation of Gambia proclaims independence.
1967: Robert Julius Oppenheimer, the American physicist known as the father of the A-bomb, dies at the age of 65.
1972: The Supreme Court of California abolishes the death penalty.
1974: Jorge Cervantes-Pinzon, outgoing charge d'affaires from Colombia, leaves Taipei for home.
1976: C.C. Yang, ROC economic affairs vice minister, and S.M. Osman, secretary-general of the Afro-Asian Rural Reconstruction Organization, sign an agreement on technical cooperation.
1984: McDonald's, the Chicago-based fast-food chain, opens its first branch in Taiwan.
1986: The Asian Development Bank votes to admit mainland China.
1988: Boris Yeltsin is ousted from the ruling Communist Party Politburo in Moscow.
1991: The US assault ship Tripoli and the guided missile cruiser Princeton are damaged by mines in the Persian Gulf during the Gulf War.
1992: A delegation from the US President's Export Council arrives in Taipei to promote bilateral trade.
1994: Lin Wen-chiang, a mainland Chinese hijacker, commandeers a Southwest Airlines passenger plane from the mainland to Taiwan.
1998: Mya Than Tint, one of Burma's most renowned and admired writers, dies at the age of 69.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man may have abilities as admirable as our Lord of Chou (the Chinese equivalent of Moses or Solomon), but if he is proud and mean, you need not consider the other qualities of his mind."

DOC.HEADLINE: SEAN CONNERY REPORTEDLY COMING TO TAIWAN FOR HUMAN CHAIN RALLY

TEXT.P: Scottish movie star Sean Connery is reportedly coming to Taiwan later this month to take part in an islandwide human-chain activity symbolizing determination and esprit de corps in protecting Taiwan through peace.

Academy Award-winning actor Connery will come to Taiwan to join the "one million hand-in-hand" campaign that will kick off in front of the Presidential Office at 2:28 p.m. on Feb. 28, according to Wang Hsien-chi, a deputy executive director of the campaign.

Connery will be one of the foreign guests of President Chen Shui-bian during the rally, marking the second meeting between them since last November when they met in Panama City for Panama's centennial celebrations, Wang said.

During that celebration, Connery, who represented Great Britain at the centennial, took the initiative in asking a Central American country's ambassador to Panama to arrange for a meeting with President Chen.
During their meeting, Connery was quoted as having said he is a fan of President Chen.

For his part, President Chen said he is a loyal Sean Connery fan. "You have numerous fans in Taiwan and are welcome to visit any time," Chen told Connery, who starred as the charismatic spy "007" in several James Bond films, including "Dr. No" (1962) , "Goldfinger" (1964) and "Diamonds Are Forever" (1971).
Connery is expected to announce his Taiwan itinerary at a press conference in Tokyo Feb. 26, according to a report by the China Times daily in Taipei.

The "one million hand-in-hand" activity will take place on 2-28 Memorial Day, with people from around the island joining hands to form a colossal human chain and shouting "Taiwan yes, China no! " at 2:28 p.m.
The campaign is widely believed to be aimed at drumming up support for President Chen Shui-bian in his bid for re-election. Taiwan's presidential election is set for March 20.

Meanwhile, Wu Nai-jen, President Chen and Vice President Annette Lu's campaign manager, said that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has no clear ideas about Connery's visit to Taiwan, which is believed being sponsored by the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union, a DPP ally.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Pakistan and India to begin peace talks.
India and Pakistan agreed on a promising timetable to hold peace talks on prickly issues including Kashmir, to end years of hostility and mistrust.
The Lianhe Zaobao: AVA culls 5,000 chickens as part of bird flu readiness exercise.
Singapore's bird flu contingency plan has been put to the test on Wednesday. A total of 5,000 healthy chickens were slaughtered to make sure everything goes according to plan if there is ever an outbreak of the deadly virus.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Edwards Takes a Close Second in Wisconsin.
John F. Kerry scratched out a victory in the Wisconsin primary, but John Edwards finished close enough to emerge as a serious challenger to the Democratic front-runner and to extend the race to California and other big states on March 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Nation: Royal mission / Princess comforts South.
The Royal Highness Princess Maha Chakri Sirindhorn yesterday conpleted the second day of a three-day visit to the three southernmost provinces to boost morale in the predominantly Muslim region that has been rocked by sporadic violence in recent months. (Francis Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: MEN WITH ERECTILE DYSFUNCTION STILL PREFER SPONTANEOUS SEX: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Globally, one in every two men above the age of 40 have erectile dysfunction, and Singapore is no exception.
A National University Hospital survey on men with erectile dysfunction revealed that most prefer sex to be spontaneous and dislike having to plan when they are going to have sex.
Doctors said a major reason men with erectile dysfunction do not seek help is the "macho" factor. "The male ego is very delicate, "one doctor said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL ADVISER MAKES PITCH FOR DIRECT LINKS WITH MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: An economic adviser to the president made a pitch for closer economic exchanges and direct transportation links with mainland China in an interview with the CNA Thursday.

Chen Tain-jy, president of the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research and an economic adviser to President Chen Shui-bian, said direct transportation links with the mainland might have impact on Taiwan's economy in the short term but would benefit the country in the long term. The long-term benefits, he claimed, would outweigh the short-term shortcomings.
Taiwan has stripped itself of the chance to boost its economy by resisting direct transportation links with the mainland and its huge market of 1.2 billion people.
As to public concerns about national security should direct air links be opened with the mainland, Chen said this could be addressed with proper planning.
By the same token, he said he favors the idea of allowing Taiwanese firms doing business on the mainland to list their stocks on the Taipei Stock Exchange.
Instead of draining off capital, allowing these firms to float their stocks in Taiwan would encourage them to funnel their profits back to Taiwan, he said.
This would also give the government a valuable tool in controlling these firms by obliging them to made public their financial status as is required for any public company.

Direct transportation links would also contribute to the government's efforts to develop the island into a research and development center, because these centers cannot work alone but rely on close interaction with their companies' manufacturing bases on the mainland. Such interaction, he said, would only be possible with the presence of direct links.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO JOIN 2006 PISA TEST

TEXT.P: Taiwan has decided to join the 2006 PISA test, an international program for student assessment, Ministry of Education officials said Thursday.

The officials said that the government has assigned the Cabinet-level National Science Council as the only window for foreign communications on the test and will send a representative to participate in the first meeting of national project managers for the 2006 PISA test to be held March 1-5 in Athens.
The PISA test was first set up by the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) in 2000 with the participation of 28 countries, 24 of which were OECD member nations.
The 2000 PISA test focused on assessing the reading ability of 15-year-old students who had completed basic compulsory education courses in that same year.
The second PISA test was held in 2003, with 45 countries participating. That test was designed to assess the mathematic ability of the students of the participating nations.
The PISA 2006 test will be centered around science subjects, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILLING TO SHARE E-CUSTOMS EXPERIENCE: WTO ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Feb. 19 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's permanent representative to the World Trade Organization (WTO) vowed Thursday to share with other member states its rich experience in cross-boarder transport, a key issue that will be discussed in a new round of the Doha talks.

Yen Ching-chang made the remarks during an informal meeting at the WTO headquarters that brought together representatives of WTO member countries that also are members of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to exchange views and opinions on issues related to a resumption of the Doha talks slated for late March.

Yen reiterated that Taiwan fully backs multilateral trade talk mechanisms under the framework of the WTO and a re-opening of the 2001 WTO conference in Doha, Qatar. The so-called Singapore issue -- market opening, regulatory affairs, improvement in transparency in government procurement and simplified procedures for cross-border transportation -- were touched upon at one of its follow-up meetings.

As cross-broader transportation has been the only one of the four topics in the Singapore issue accepted by the APEC members at the WTO for discussion, Yen said Taiwan is very willing to share its experience in paperless customs clearance with other WTO members in the coming Doha round of talks, to help forge consensus among the WTO to achieve free transportation across borders.
According to Yen, Taiwan and Australia have made noticeable progress in reducing import and export costs and in boosting economic activity since their implementation of a system of e-customs.

Chile's WTO envoy, who chaired the meeting, gave a positive response to Yen's proposal and said he will push for discussions on the issue at WTO expert-level meetings. He contended that future APEC ministerial-level meetings should include WTO envoys in order to bolster bilateral exchanges between the two organizations.
Chile will be the host country of this year's APEC annual conference, with a trade ministers' meeting planned for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: BREAKTHROUGH MADE BY PARTIES NEGOTIATING OVER POLITICAL DONATION BILL

TEXT.P: A breakthrough was made by the various parties in the Legislative Yuan involved in negotiations over a political donation bill, after all the parties agreed that political donations should be prohibited in non-election times.

The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union, which opposed limiting donations to election time only, eventually agreed with the opposition People First Party that donations should not be allowed unless an election is in the offing.

The consensus will be put into record by various political factions in the legislature either Friday or Monday, which will lay the groundwork for passage of the whole bill before the end of this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC RELAXES RESTRICTIONS ON MINI-DIRECT LINKS

TEXT.P: Restrictions on people who wish to visit mainland China via the frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu will be relaxed slightly from March 1, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Thursday.

MAC Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tong said the council has decided to allow Taiwan businessmen working on the mainland to use the direct shipping links between the Taiwan-controlled islands of Kinmen and Matsu, and the mainland ports of Xiamen and Mawei.
Usually, these links are reserved for Taiwanese businessmen working only in the mainland's Fujian Province.
Furthermore, the mainland spouses of Taiwan people living in Penghu County, as well as veterans born in Fujian, will also be allowed to go to the mainland via Kinmen or Matsu.
Allowing more people to use the links will help boost the economy of the two frontline islands, said Chen.

Kinmen and Matsu, which are only a few kilometers from the mainland coastline, used to be heavily armed garrisons and their economies depended heavily on the troops posted there. But the two islands have lost their strategic importance because of the mainland's rapid buildup of missiles, and the Taiwan authorities have reduced the number of military personnel assigned there, which has taken a heavy toll on the economies of the two islands.
In order to address this, the MAC three years ago began allowing the two islands to operate direct shipping links with the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW IRIS-SUPPORTED LENS IMPLANT FOR MYOPICS AVAILABLE IN SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: In Singapore, people suffering from severe myopia can now look forward to a new iris-supported lens implant to restore perfect vision.
The implant is made of a special polymer-based material which is very similar to the one used in cataract lens implants. And according to doctors, it can pretty much be left in the eye permanently.
The lens is inserted into the eye and clipped onto the iris at two points. The procedure only takes about 40 minutes and costs S$2,500 (US$1,470) per eye. The price includes the S$900 lens implant.
So far, five people have received the implant in Singapore, which has one of the highest myopia rates in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC MIGHT REDESIGN NT$500 BILL

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) is studying whether to redesign the NT$500 bill in order to make it less easily confused with the NT$100 bill, which is a similar color, CBC Governor Perng Fai-nan said Thursday.

Perng made the remarks at the Finance Committee of the Legislative Yuan in which legislators expressed concern about the color of the NT$100 bill, which is red, and the NT$500 bill, which is reddish brown. According to the legislators, this could result in people mistaking one for the other.
Perng said that if the two bills are found to be easily confused, the CBC will launch a series of advertisements to teach the public, especially the elderly, how to differentiate the two.
He said that the CBC might change the color of the NT$500 bill and will also strengthen the bill's anti-counterfeiting features.
Perng offered no timetable for any design change.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MORE RESTRAINED BUT CONTINUES TIRADE AGAINST PRESIDENT: SEF

TEXT.P: Although mainland China has adopted a more restrained manner in the run-up to Taiwan's March 20 presidential election than it had prior to the country's previous two direct elections, it has continued its tirade against President Chen Shui-bian and the referendum to be held in tandem with the election, an official of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Thursday.

SEF Deputy Secretary-General Yen Wan-chin made the comments when he attended a seminar on the mainland China factor in Taiwan's presidential election sponsored by the Institute for National Policy Research, a private think tank.

"Beijing has learned from its experience in the past two presidential elections in Taiwan, " Yen said, referring to its test-firing of missiles near Taiwan waters in 1996 and then-Premier Zhu Rongji's intimidating talk in 2000, both of which whipped up antagonism in Taiwan and boosted support for former President Lee Teng-hui and later, Chen.
To avoid repeating the same mistakes and turning resentment of Beijing into a booster for Chen, Yen said, the mainland has been keeping a low profile.
High-ranking officials from the Taiwan Affairs Office under Beijing's State Council have refrained from giving their views, and even limited talks have been kept low-profile.

But Yen pointed out Beijing has been unable to suppress the urge to criticize, estimating that between Jan. 1 and Feb. 15, there were 53 media reports opposing Taiwan's referendum, and 47 criticisms of Chen.

He said that if the Beijing leadership cannot directly interfere with the election, it will use indirect pressure to sway voters, citing the recent arrests of alleged Taiwan spies on the mainland as an example.

Yen said that a greater majority of the estimated 1 million Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland support the "pan-blue alliance" of the opposition Kuomintang and the People First Party, but added that "the number should not exceed more than 70 percent."

However, several scholars said in the seminar that the election will hinge on the mainstream views of the people and that the effect of Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland will be very limited.
With the election campaign moving into high gear, reports about Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland could play a role in the race surface.
The scholars said they do not believe that Taiwan businessmen working on the mainland will give priority to returning to Taiwan to vote over their own economic interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PREMIER URGES JAPANESE CARMAKER TO BUY MORE TAIWAN-MADE PARTS

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i paid a visit Thursday to the Honda Taiwan Co., a business wholly owned by the Japanese carmaker Honda Motor Co., in southern Taiwan's Pingtung County, and suggested to the management that they buy more Taiwan-made spare parts.

Lin, accompanied by Pingtung County Magistrate Su Chia-chuan and officials of the Executive Yuan's Southern Coordination Office, was warmly welcomed by the plant workers and the Japanese management led by Honda Taiwan President Teruo Fujisaki.

Wishing the Honda Taiwan great success, Lin called on the management to purchase more Taiwan-produced parts and components to help it bring down production costs and raise the annual output from the current level of 12,000 units to its designated target of 30,000.
Lin also expressed hope that Honda will set up a research and development (R&D) center in Taiwan to provide customers with the best service.
According to the vice premier, Taiwan's exports of automobile parts and components are worth more than NT$100 billion (about US$3 billion) every year.

In response to Lin's remarks, Fujisaki said Honda Taiwan plans to sponsor an investment seminar in April in cooperation with the Pingtung county government and the Economic Processing Zone Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, in order to meet Taiwan-based parts and components makers.
Fujisaki claimed that the mother company in Japan will consider opening a R&D center in Taiwan and promised to step up on-the-job training for the Pingtung plant workers.
Honda Taiwan Co., with capital of about NT$3.6 billion, is located on a 57,000-ping (about 18.8 hectares) landlot and employs more than 850 workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER TAIWAN COMFORT WOMEN APPEAL AGAINST JAPANESE COURT RULING

TEXT.P: Seven Taiwanese women who were forced into sexual slavery for the Japanese Imperial Army during World War Two appealed against a Japanese court ruling in Tokyo Wednesday. The court upheld a lower court decision to throw out their claims for damages from the Japanese government, according to a private group in Taipei that advocates the rights of such women.
The Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation said a Japanese lawyer has appealed, on behalf ofthe seven Taiwanese women, to the Japanese Supreme Court against the Feb. 9ruling by the Tokyo High Court.

The foundation said in a news release Thursday that two of the nine former so-called "comfort women" who filed the suit with the Tokyo District Court July 14, 1999, have since died. The rest are all in their 70's and 80's and are hoping they will see the Japanese government apologize and admit its cruelty to them.
The Japanese forced more than 200,000 Asian women to serve as sex slaves for their soldiers between 1938 and 1945, including at least 1,200 from Taiwan.
The Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation began to locate these women in 1992 and has found 43, most of whom are now in fragile health.

Although the Japanese government has steadfastly refused to admit any responsibility for the women, it set up a private foundation in 1995 to compensate them with 2 million yen per person. However, some of the Taiwanese comfort women have refused to take the compensation as it does not come directly from the government and demand an apology from the government.
Aided by human rights groups in Taiwan and Japan, they went to Tokyo to file their claim for damages with the Tokyo District Court on July 14, 1999.
The period for applying for compensation from the private group expired May 1, 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CONFIDENT OF INTEGRITY OF HIS ADMINISTRATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that he has full confidence in the integrity of his administration.
Chen made the remarks in a radio interview on the UFO network with Chou Yu-ko, a noted talk show host.
In the radio program, titled "UFO Breakfast, " Chen said he regrets that the opposition parties have frequently made false accusations of corruption against some members of his ruling team.
"There has so far been no concrete evidence to show that any member of my administration has committed any wrongdoing. Otherwise, I would not have the face to seek a second term," Chen claimed.
While he welcomes criticism of his administration, Chen said he hopes critics will present solid evidence to back up their "wrongdoing" accusations against individual members of his team.

During his tenure as Taipei mayor from 1994 through 1998, Chen recalled, his team at that time was subject to extremely stringent supervision by the city council. "In those years, opposition parties also criticized my team. But they were unable to produce convincing evidence to show that any member was involved in any irregularities."
Chen said he is proud of the dedication and integrity of all the members of his current administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Junk food under attack by fat tax.
Plans seen by The Times for the new tax follow the discovery that the number of obese people had risen from less than 10 per cent of the population in the 1980s to more than 20 per cent in 2001.
Financial Times: Straw backtracks over bribery.
Bribery by UK companies operating abroad is being curbed by "education rather than prosecution" after the government retreated from the strict enforcement of laws introduced just two years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Advocacy groups allowed to raise unlimited funds.
The Federal Election Commission said on Wednesday that advocacy groups that were established to get around fund-raising restrictions in the new campaign finance law could continue to spend unlimited contributions for television commercials and other communications, though they must do so under far more restrictive rules.
Wall Street Journal: Dividend-tax cut is causing more errors on 1099 forms.
Nine months after Congress voted to slash the tax rate on dividends, that act of largess has turned into a major headache for financial companies and taxpayers.
The tax law approved in May cut the top tax rate on many dividends to 15% from as high as 38.6%, a move designed to bolster the stock market and stimulate the economy. But the tax break, retroactive to January 2003, doesn't apply across the board to all the dividends that investors receive.
As a result, brokerage firms and mutual-fund companies are having a harder-than-usual time telling customers exactly how much of their dividend income qualifies for the lower rate.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA HAILS E.U. DECISION TO MAINTAIN ARMS EMBARGO AGAINST BEIJING

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday it welcomes the passage of a resolution by the European Parliament last week demanding that the European Union (E.U.) maintain its arms embargo against mainland China.

The European Parliament, the E.U.'s legislative arm, unanimously passed the resolution Feb. 10 asking the European Commission -- the E.U. executive body -- not to lift the ban on arms exports to mainland China without its prior approval.
"We welcome the European Parliament's move, " said Wang Yu-yuan, director of MOFA's European Affairs Department.

According to Wang, the European Parliament already passed a similar resolution last December. As some E.U. member states, including France and Germany, have been advocating lifting of the arms ban imposed in 1989, the European Parliament voted against such a proposal again last week.
Given this development, Wang said, the E. U. is not expected to bring up the topic again in the near future. Nevertheless, Wang said, MOFA will continue to monitor developments on this issue.

The European Union imposed the arms export ban against mainland China after Beijing conducted an armed crackdown on pro-democracy students at Tiananmen Square in 1989. While Germany and France have been pushed for the lifting of the ban with a view to facilitating their acquisition of lucrative business contracts in mainland China, Wang said the European Parliament doesn't support such a move because it is still dissatisfied with Beijing's human rights record.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL BANK SAYS RECOVERING ECONOMY WILL NOT SPARK INFLATION

TEXT.P: A rebounding economy in Taiwan and the rest of the world will not spur inflationary pressure at home, according to a recent report by Taiwan's Central Bank of China (CBC).

Despite a robust economic recovery, Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) is expected to increase by 0.38 percent for the whole of 2004, a contrast to a negative annual growth rate of 0.28 percent registered in 2003, the CBC estimated in the report, which was submitted to the Finance Committee under the Legislative Yuan.

The CBC based its supposition on the fact that major countries will continue to maintain a loose monetary policy and that competition in retail businesses will remain fierce, producing no further inflationary pressure, even though the domestic economy is regaining momentum following the containment of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) last year.

The Taiwan's economy was hit hard by the SARS outbreaks in the first half of last year. Local demand, fueled mainly by an economic upturn and the launch of government-funded public construction projects, has increasingly become stronger.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, gaining NT$0.079 to close at NT$33.179.
A total of US$936 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$33.250 and was traded between NT$33.140 and NT$33.316.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE UNIVERSITY STUDENTS ARRESTED FOR DRUG TRAFFICKING VIA MAIL

TEXT.P: Three university students were arrested Thursday for alleged involvement in cross-border drug trafficking by mail, the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) said.

The mastermind was a 23-year-old male student at a local private university, surnamed Cheng, who was arrested upon his arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport -- Taiwan's main gateway -- after a leisure trip to Canada, MJIB officials said.
Cheng, who will graduate this summer, was accused of having sent more than 10 kilograms of marijuana from Canada to seven locations in Taipei City and Taipei County by air between Feb. 9 and Feb. 16.

The marijuana was packed into 45 parcels and mailed to Cheng's two accomplices -- two female college students surnamed Chen and Hsiung. The two accomplices were nabbed in Taipei City shortly after Cheng's arrest.

Cheng told investigators that he and his accomplices met some foreigners at pubs in Taipei last year. "They asked us to help transport marijuana and ecstasy pills by offering us free trips to Canada and other foreign destinations," he said, adding that he then traveled to Canada early this month to help deliver the drugs for his foreign friends.

MJIB agents reminded local college students that marijuana is a second-grade contraband drug. Those transporting or selling marijuana may be given a minimum seven-year prison term or life imprisonment.

DOC.HEADLINE: VAC DENIES EXERTING INFLUENCE ON VETERANS OVER REFERENDUM ISSUE

TEXT.P: The head of the Veterans Affairs Commission (VAC) denied Thursday that his commission has told retired servicemen to participate in the upcoming referendum on orders from the Executive Yuan.

VAC Chairman Teng Tsu-lin said at a meeting at the Legislative Yuan Defense Committee that the Veterans Affairs Commission is completely neutral and the Executive Yuan has not asked the VAC to promote participation in the referendum among the country's retired servicemen.
Teng also denied that the VAC has used administrative resources to drum up support for President Chen Shui-bian to facilitate his re-election.

Teng made the remarks in response to questions raised by opposition People First Party (PFP) legislators Chin Hui-chu and Ku Chung-lien about rumors of the VAC's intention of tampering with the retired servicemen's voting decisions ahead of the March 20 presidential election and referendum.

The PFP lawmakers also expressed concern that the aged retired servicemen -- most of them having come to Taiwan before 1950 after the Republic of China government moved its seat from the mainland to Taiwan -- would have trouble casting three ballots without some confusion.
In this regard, Teng said that he is confident that the retired servicemen, despite being elderly, will have no problems and will choose wisely.
"Our veterans have a great deal of common sense and they are well informed from watching TV and reading newspapers," Teng added.
Meanwhile, Teng said, the government is not suspending monthly retirement pensions to those retired soldiers who have traveled to the mainland and settled there.

He said the government is continuing paying retirement pensions to the 5,514 retired ROC soldiers who are now living on the mainland but have not applied for resident status or a passport from the People's Republic of China.

The Examination Yuan passed a new regulation recently stipulating that retired military servicemen, civil servants and school teachers will have to receive their retirement pensions in one lump sum rather than by monthly payments if they reside on the mainland.
If they don't apply for a lump-sum payment, they may risk having their retirement pensions withheld, according to the Examination Yuan regulation.

The VAC has assigned personnel to the mainland on a yearly basis to check whether the 5,000-odd retired soldiers now residing on the mainland have received Beijing-issued ID cards, Teng said, adding that the VAC was relieved to find that none of them had accepted the PRC papers of identification.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF NARCOTICS SEIZED UP 2.7 TIMES LAST YEAR

TEXT.P: The number of narcotics seized totaled more than 8,500 kilograms last year, up 2.7 fold from the previous year, statistics compiled by the Department of Health (DOH) showed Thursday.
DOH officials said that not only the size of the narcotics haul had increased sharply, but the types had become more varied, and the use of marijuana grew by nearly 10 fold, DOH officials said.
Among the drugs seized last year, amphetamines accounted for half, followed by ketamine, heroin, ecstasy and marijuana.

Li Jih-heng, director-general of the DOH's National Bureau of Controlled Drugs, said that both ketamine and marijuana are popular substances in parties and clubs, adding that ketamine seized last year surpassed that of heroin, and marijuana seized totaled 121 kilograms, or 9.9 fold or 11 kilograms in 2002.
"The changes of the two drugs [ketamine and marijuana] will provide police with information on how they are supplied," Li said.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORST DAYS OVER SAYS CONFIDENT PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Thursday said that the most difficult and worst days are over for the country and that Taiwan's economy is improving.
The president made the comments in an interview with local radio station UFO.
Chen said that he is confident he will win a second term in the upcoming presidential election on March 20 and that his presidential campaign will pick up steam in the last 30 days of the campaign.

While indicating that this year's presidential election is not an election of "two rotten apples, " Chen said that his position on issues regarding the nation's status, reforms, and the elimination of corruption are different from that of Lien Chan, the presidential candidate of the opposition Kuomintang.

He further said that Taiwan will be in danger if its leader does not know what the sovereignty of the nation is or does not insist on the maintenance of national sovereignty to avoid it from being changed.
Noting that reform is his belief, the president said that he has long insisted on eliminating corruption and crime as well as respecting the will of the people of Taiwan.
Although confident of victory, the president said that he is not being careless with his campaign. He said that the contest may be decided by a razor-thin margin of only 3 to 5 percent of the vote.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDEPENDENCE A MOOT POINT AS TAIWAN ALREADY HAS SOVEREIGNTY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reiterated Thursday that Taiwan need not declare independence because it is already an independent, sovereign country no matter whether it is called "Taiwan" or the "Republic of China."
Chen made the remarks in a radio interview with Chou Yu-ko, a noted talk show host. The one-hour interview was broadcast live on UFO Network from 8 a.m. to 9 a.m.
During the talk show known as "UFO Breakfast," Chou asked Chen if he is re-elected in the March 20 presidential election, will he declare Taiwan independence?
In response, Chen said those who have asked him this question do not seem to have full confidence in Taiwan's sovereign status.
"Only those who lack confidence in our national sovereignty will feel a need to declare Taiwan independence," Chen said. "For me, such an issue is non-existent."
Chen said his Democratic Progressive Party administration has insisted that Taiwan is an independent, sovereign state regardless of its official designation.

"No matter whether we are called 'Taiwan' or the 'Republic of China, ' we are a country and I'm the top leader of this country. I'm now the ROC's 10th-term president and I'm now running for re-election to become our country's 11th-term president," Chen explained.
If he is re-elected in the March 20 presidential election, Chen said he will continue to honor the "four noes plus one" pledge outlined in his 2000 inaugural address.

"For me, a promise is timeless. I won't retreat from the 'four noes plus one' pledge in my 2004 inaugural speech, " Chen said firmly. The now famous pledge includes no change of Taiwan's national title and flag as well as no holding of a referendum on the "independence vs. referendum" issue.

As to his earlier advocacy of writing a new constitution for Taiwan in 2006, Chen said he will definitely carry out Taiwan's constitutional reform with no change in the status quo as the guiding principle.

In the interview, Chen also defended his decision to hold the nation's first-ever referendum alongside the upcoming presidential election, stressing that the two referendum questions will offer the electorate an opportunity to express their opinions about major policy issues.

In the March 20 referendum, the voters will be asked whether Taiwan should acquire more anti-missile defense capabilities to defend itself against military threats from mainland China and whether the island should enter into talks with Beijing for the establishment of a framework for peaceful interaction.

Even though the results of the referendum may be self-evident, Chen said the referendum will serve to reaffirm Taiwan's commitment to pursuing permanent peace with mainland China and to remind Beijing that it must negotiate a viable interactive framework with Taiwan because its "one China" principle is unacceptable.

Chen also said he sees no fault in Minister of National Defense Tang Yiau-min's remarks a day earlier that even if less than half of the electorate vote against purchasing more missiles in the upcoming referendum, the Ministry of National Defense will go ahead with its arms procurement plans.

"What we need to buy to beef up our defense capabilities includes many kinds of weapons, not just missiles, " Chen argued, adding that he had extensive discussions with Tang and other government officials before deciding on the referendum questions.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, PFP COULD ANNOUNCE THEIR REFERENDUM VOTING INTENTIONS THURSDAY

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) could announce their decision on Thursday regarding whether to vote in the historic referendum set for the day of the presidential election March 20, a well-placed source said Thursday.

The source said that the two parties have held consultations since PFP Chairman James Soong stated Feb. 17 that even though his party and the KMT had not reached a consensus on the issue, he personally would not vote in the referendum because he said it is "illegal."
President Chen Shui-bian has called for the people of Taiwan to support the referendum.

The two questions to be put to the people in the referendum are whether Taiwan should further strengthen its defense capabilities if mainland China refuses to remove its missiles aimed at Taiwan, and whether the government should negotiate with Beijing for the establishment of an interaction mechanism for peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait.

Sources close to the KMT and PFP said that the two parties still consider the March 20 referendum illegal and think they should explain the legal reasons why voters have the right to refuse to vote in the referendum.

Nevertheless, the sources said that it is impossible that the KMT and PFP will openly call for the people to refuse to cast their ballots in the referendum because some influential members in the two parties still view the issue differently, and because the two parties are concerned about incurring criticism if they urge the public not to vote.

Soong has confirmed that only a few differences remain between leading members of the KMT and the PFP on the referendum issue, expressing the hope that the two parties can reach a consensus on the issue as soon as possible.
Noting that according to the law, the referendum results will be invalid if more than half of Taiwan's voters don't vote, Soong said that not casting a ballot is also a form of voting.
However, Wang Ching-ping, president of the Legislative Yuan and a leading figure at the KMT-PFP campaign headquarters, has said that he will vote in the referendum.

DOC.HEADLINE: COUNTERFEIT LEATHER GOODS SEIZED

TEXT.P: Customs officials announced Thursday that they seized 44 boxes of counterfeit brand name leather goods worth tens of millions of new Taiwan dollar a day earlier.

The counterfeit LV, Gucci, Prada, Puma leather goods, including shoes and handbags, were produced in mainland China and shipped to Taipei via Hong Kong on Cathay Pacific Airways and Air Macau flights.

Customs officials said that they will step up crackdown on counterfeit goods to ensure that local consumers get the genuine brand name goods that they pay for and to let the international community know that Taiwan will not tolerate the sale of counterfeit goods.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 19, or the 29th day of the first month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1473: Nicolaus Copernicus, the Polish astronomer who advanced the theory that the Earth rotates daily on its axis and, with the other planets in the solar system, revolves around the Sun, is born.
1800: Napoleon Bonaparte proclaims himself First Consul of the newly established French dictatorship.
1861: Tsar Alexander II signs a proclamation setting free 20 million serfs, almost a third of Russia's population.
1878: Thomas Edison, the U.S. inventor who once described genius as "1 percent inspiration and 99 percent perspiration," is granted a patent for his phonograph.
1909: Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th U.S. president, who won the 1906 Nobel Peace Prize for his mediation in the Russo-Japanese War and was an avid big-game hunter, calls for a world conference on conservation.
1915: A French-British fleet begins shelling Turkish fortifications along the strategic Dardenelles waterway in a bid to defeat Turkey and reopen the critical Black Sea supply route to Russia.
1927: The Chinese Nationalists extract a reduction of concessions from Britain at Hankow and Kiukiang.
1932: The United States refuses to recognize the Japanese puppet state of "Manchukuo" (State of Manchuria).
1934: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National Military Council of the Republic of China, launches the "New Life Movement" in Nanchang, Kiangsi Province.
1942: Japanese forces invade Bali in Indonesia and make their first raid on the Australian mainland when they bomb the Northern Territories port of Darwin.
1945: U.S. forces launch an invasion of the island of Iwo Jima, killing most of the 22,000 occupying Japanese troops and eventually taking the Pacific island on March 26 at the cost of 6,821 American lives.
1951: Andre Gide, the French writer who won the 1947 Nobel Prize for literature and was noted for his diaries and novels such as "The Immoralist" and "Lafcadio's Adventures," dies at the age of 82.
1953: The ROC and the Kingdom of Spain sign the Sino-Spanish Friendship Treaty in Madrid.
1955: The Southeast Asian Treaty Organization (SEATO) is established, with eight countries participating.
1958: The ROC Navy sinks three Chinese communist warships and damages three others in a battle off the Min River estuary.
1959: Britain, Greece and Turkey guarantee the independence of the island of Cyprus.
1963: U.S. President John F. Kennedy announces that the Soviet Union has agreed to pull out several thousand of its troops from Cuba by March 15.
1964: The Sungshan International Airport terminal in Taipei is inaugurated.
1972: Japan establishes diplomatic relations with the Mongolian People's Republic.
1973: Guatemalan Vice Foreign Minister Ing Afredo Obiols Gomez leaves for home after a weeklong tour of Taiwan.
1974: The presiding bishop of the American Episcopal Church, the Most Rev. John Hines, arrives for the Thanksgiving and Holy Communion Service on the 20th founding anniversary of the Taiwan Episcopal Church.
1976: Four Beijing opera stars leave Taipei for Hong Kong to participate in the Hong Kong Festival of Arts.
1977: Representatives of the disabled celebrate their first "Torch-Light Day" at the Taipei New Park.
1985: A Spanish Airlines Boeing passenger plane crashes in a mountainous area, killing 142 people aboard.
1990: The Liberal Democratic Party under Toshiki Kaifu wins the general election in Japan.
1991: Boris Yeltsin, president of the Russian Federation, urges Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev to resign, accusing him of sacrificing reform for "absolute personal power."
1997: Mainland China's paramount leader Deng Xiaoping, who ruled from 1978 until his retirement from his last official post in 1990, dies in Beijing at the age of 93.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who educates himself for three years without improvement is seldom to be found."

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC HEAD TRYING TO PERSUADE ELECTION OFFICIAL NOT TO RESIGN

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) will continue in its efforts to persuade Provincial Election Commission Chairman Chen Lung-chi not to resign, CEC Chairman Huang Shih-cheng said Friday.

Chen announced his decision to step down from the chairmanship Thursday out of "concerns about not being able to accomplish the challenging tasks regarding ballot procedures and other voting affairs related to the referendum" to be held in tandem with the presidential election on March 20.

Chen is the highest-ranking government official in charge of election affairs to submit a resignation notice since the Executive Yuan began carrying out relevant measures pertaining to the referendum earlier this month.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Huang said he and other CEC officials are communicating further with Chen, as well as with Miaoli County Election Commission Chairman Ku Cheng-ching, who offered to resign two days before, in an attempt to retain the two election officials.
Ku announced his resignation Wednesday after days of wrangling over his proposal to separate referendum polling stations and those for the presidential election.

Ku made the proposal to the CEC for separate stations as a means of avoiding confusion, based on the notion that different laws apply to the two events. He said the move was aimed at "reducing any risks, simplifying the procedures for casting ballots, and allowing the voting to be carried out smoothly."
However, Ku said, his proposal was ignored, and he was repeatedly bullied and intimidated by people opposed to his proposal, adding that some even came to his office to call him names.

At the Legislative Yuan Friday, CEC head Huang also noted that the CEC has its set policy and is dealing with the matter according to the law. He said that vacancies created by those who resign will be filled by suitable individuals.

According to the CEC policy, voters will get three ballots on election day -- one for the presidential election and another two for the referendum questions. The two referendum questions concern whether Taiwan should strengthen its anti-missile defenses if mainland China refuses to remove its missiles aimed at the island, and whether the government should negotiate with Beijing for the establishment of an interaction mechanism for peace across the Taiwan Strait.
The administration wants the three ballots to be cast at the same polling stations, and it has said that even votes placed in the wrong ballot boxes will be counted.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP AND TSU TO LINK TAIWAN WITH HUMAN CHAIN ON FEB. 28

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) will mobilize their followers to form a human link from Keelung to Pingtung on Feb. 28 to mark Peace Day, according to DPP Deputy Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan Friday.

The chain will start from Hopintao, or peace island, in Keelung, northern Taiwan, and wind through the island to a small village called Changlung, meaning prosperity, in Pingtung the southern-most county of Taiwan, Lee said.
Hundreds of thousands of people around the island have already promised to form this 480-kilometer chain on Feb. 28 to highlight their desire for peace and prosperity.

Former president Lee Teng-hui, who helped come up with the activity, will join hands with President Chen Shui-bian to form a section of the chain in Miaoli County, northern Taiwan, according to Lee Ying-yuan.
President Chen might also greet the participants in other counties such as Keelung and Hsinchu, Lee went on.

Lee Teng-hui's wife, Tseng Wen-hui, Chen's wife, Wu Shu-chen, as well as government leaders from Vice President Annette Lu on down will also take part in forming the chain in various places around the island, said Lee Ying-yuan.
The organizers will stage a rally in Oluanpi, the island's southern-most tip, on Feb. 28 night, Lee said.
He reminded the participants to be sure to carry cell phones with them to call in more friends to join the activity, radios to pass the time, cameras to take photos, and chairs to sit on.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO PROMINENT FIGURES ISSUE JOINT APPEAL FOR LEGISLATIVE REFORM

TEXT.P: Two prominent personalities issued a joint statement Friday urging the two presidential tickets to push lawmakers to pass a constitutional reform bill ahead of the March 20 election to pave the way for halving the number of legislative seats.

Lin Yi-hsiung, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), and Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, also urged the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan in their joint statement not to close its current session before passing the reform bill.

The two widely respected celebrities further called on the general public to endorse their joint appeal. Lee, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, is scheduled to unveil progress in their signature campaign at the end of this month.

Lin said at a news conference that reform should not be just a political slogan, but rather require concrete actions. Since the two presidential tickets -- President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu of the DPP and the opposition "pan-blue alliance" ticket of Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong -- have recently reaffirmed their commitments to promoting political reforms, Lin said he and Lee want to remind them to deliver on their solemn promises with concrete actions.

Three years ago, Lin recalled, all major domestic political parties already vowed to pass a constitutional reform bill to pave the way for cutting the number of seats in the legislature during this session. Such a promise has received wide recognition in local society, he added.

"Although the legislative caucuses of various political parties, including the dominating KMT, presented various constitutional reform bills regarding downsizing the legislature last December, they have so far not taken any action to deal with those bills, " Lin lamented. "The delay has made me wonder whether the presentation of those bills was just a political ploy."
Lin further said he will seek endorsements of ordinary citizens to push local politicians to honor their promise and substantiate legislative reform.
According to the nation's Constitution, the Legislative Yuan should have 225 seats. To halve the number requires revision to this provision.

DOC.HEADLINE: DGBAS FORECASTS 2004 ECONOMIC GROWTH RATE AT 4.74 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan will post an economic growth rate of 4.74 percent for the whole of 2004, while its first-quarter economic growth rate will hit 5.16 percent, the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Friday.
The DGBAS made the forecast on the grounds that the domestic economy expanded by 5.17 percent for the fourth quarter of last year, an encouraging quarterly performance in recent years.

According to the DGBAS statistics, Taiwan's economy grew substantially by 3.24 percent for 2003, with its gross domestic product reaching US$295.9 billion and the per-capita income standing at US$13,157.

If the budgets for the 10 new public construction projects submitted by the Cabinet are approved by the Legislative Yuan in the second half of this year, the country's economy will further expand by at least 0.5 percent for 2004, brining the annual economic growth rate to top 5 percent, DGBAS officials said.

But the officials pointed out that an annual economic growth rate above 5 percent can be obtained only when the possibilities of various uncertainties are fully ruled out, such as a reappearance of severe acute respiratory syndrome, a deterioration of the situation with bird flu, a strong appreciation of mainland Chinese currency and high interest rates.

Private-sector consumption and demand will be the major driving forces to account for 4.2 percent in this year's economic expansion of 4.74 percent, the officials explained, adding that consumption from the private sector will rise by 3.71 percent for 2004, up from last year's 0.85 percent.
Private-sector investment is also estimated to post a growth rate of 14.5 percent, a jump from a negative growth rate of 0.7 percent recorded in the previous year, they elaborated.

The mission members include Panama's minister of industry and commerce, leaders of the commercial and industrial sectors and other government officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: STARTING SALARIES AVERAGE NT$23,700 FOR NEW JOB SEEKERS: POLL

TEXT.P: Starting salaries for first-time job seekers in the industrial and service sectors average about NT$23,700 (US$715) this year, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) reported Friday.

Citing the results of a recent investigation conducted early this year, CLA officials said that starting salaries for new job seekers in the industrial sector hit around NT$23,800, while new workers in the service sector receive an average monthly salary of some NT$23,600.

Although companies, fueled by stronger demand for manpower as a result of a recovering economy, have released a larger number of jobs in recent months, the officials noted that monthly salaries for job seekers remain at similar levels compared to those posted in July last year.

For instance, service-related medical-care professions provide an average starting salary of NT$25,000, while beverage and food companies and restaurants offer a starting salary at around NT$20,000. Beginners in the financial, stocks and futures companies are better salaried with an average monthly pay of around NT$29,000.

The survey, discovers, however, that new workers in public utilities such as power and water plants, as well as railway, postal, tobacco-related and energy businesses get starting pay of more than NT$30,000 per month, with those working at air and sea ports leading others by enjoying a salary of up to NT$50,000.

The survey also finds that a higher educational background is a guarantee of a better salary. Monthly incomes of graduate school students average at nearly NT$28,000, while those of four-year university graduates average more than NT$26,000, ahead of the monthly average of NT$23,000 for two-year college students and NT$20,000 for senior high school students.
The gap in men's and women's monthly incomes is slight at 3 percent, an improvement from a difference of 5.91 percent recorded in 2000, it points out.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE TV PERSONALITIES SUBMIT SIGNATURES TO DEBATE REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: Taipei, Feb. 20 (CAN) Three TV personalities -- the head of a local radio station, a legislator and a university professor -- applied to the Central Election Commission (CEC) Friday for permission to represent the opposition side in a series of 10 televised debates with the government on the March 20 referendum.

Jaw Shau-kong, chairman of the UFO Network, independent Legislator Sisy Chen and National Taiwan University Professor Tim T.Y. Ting submitted the signatures of more than 100,000 people who support their bid to debate the two referendum questions -- whether Taiwan should strengthen its defenses and whether it should open cross-strait talks on a peace and stability framework -- to be voted on in the referendum that will be held alongside the presidential election.
The number of signatures far exceeded the minimum threshold of 1,547 names set by the CEC for each question.

As more than one team has expressed an interest in serving as the "nay" side to the government's "aye" team, the final debating teams will be decided by a drawing of lots if the various hopefuls cannot coordinate among themselves.

To get around this, Jaw said, his team has artificially bulked up the size of the teams from the maximum five to 20 people to ensure that his teams have the best chance of success in a draw situation.

The list includes many UFO Network hosts, as well as writer Li Ao, lawyer and former CEC member Wang Ching-feng, Former Chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party Hsu Hsin-liang and former Control Yuan Member Yeh Yao-peng.

But Sisy Chen said that in view of the fact that the government has changed its recommended debate team list, the opposition should have the same opportunity. "In other words, the final list of our team is yet to be finalized," she added.
The 10 live TV debates must all be held by March 19.
Under the referendum rules, the CEC must hold five debates for each of the two questions. Each debating team can have between one and five members, with an equal number on each side.

The CEC first invited opposition political parties to serve as the "nay" side but neither the Kuomintang nor its ally, the People First Party, were interested, pointing out that they agree with the content of the referendum and are only opposed to the referendum on the grounds that they believe it has been illegally called by President Chen Shui-bian. They also fear that continued talk on the referendum will shift the focus of their election campaign theme of improving the economy.
The CEC therefore had to open the debate to civic groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTROVERSY SURROUNDING REFERENDUM BEARS OUT ITS NECESSITY: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: The controversy in Taiwan surrounding the upcoming referendum proves the necessity to sort out differences among the people through just such a nation-wide vote, Tamkang University professor Juan Ming said Friday.

In a forum held by CNA to discuss issues regarding the 2004 presidential election and Taiwan's ties with mainland China, Juan played down public concerns that the forthcoming referendum has strained the country's ties with both the United States and mainland China, claiming that the three parties enjoy the stablest relations since 1979.
Juan said the ties between the United States and mainland China have never been as good as they are now because both sides have make clear their bottom lines in dealing with each other.

Similarly, Taiwan's ties with both the United States and mainland China are better and this stability serves the interests of Beijing, which needs peace while it is concentrating on economic development.

However, Juan also said that Beijing is obviously trying to stop Taiwan from holding the referendum by making its concerns known to the United States. Taiwan can easily allay Washington's concerns over the referendum by convincing the United States that the island is not flirting with the idea of Taiwan independence.

In addition to Juan, the forum, chaired by CNA Editor in Chief Liu Chih-tsung, brought together Chiang Li-hsin, a professor with Fo Guang University, Chang Wu-ueh, a professor at Tamkang University, and Byron Weng, a professor at National Chi Nan University.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRAMEWORK NEEDED FOR CROSS-STRAIT TALKS, ECON. COOPERATION: SCHOLARS

TEXT.P: A framework for cross-Taiwan Strait talks and economic cooperation should be established, a scholar specialized in mainland Chinese studies said Friday.

Speaking at a seminar organized by CNA on the 2004 presidential election in Taiwan and cross-strait ties, Chang Wu-ueh, a professor at the Graduate Institute of China Studies of Tamkang University, said that cross-strait trade and exchanges of personnel are increasing, although there still exist disputes over the sovereignty between the two sides.

Regardless of who is elected as the next-term president of the Republic of China, Chang suggested the governments of the two sides shelve their political differences and take a pragmatic attitude toward seeking a framework for bilateral trade and exchanges for the sake of their own interests and that of the international community.

Beijing's concerns over Taiwan's planned March 20 referendum, which will be held alongside the presidential election, are centered on the impact that it could bring to the new leadership of Chinese President Hu Jintao and Premier Wen Jiabao, who are seeking to gradually consolidate power with stability, Chang noted.
The Beijing leadership is also concerned that Taiwan's democratic development could bear on the situations in Hong Kong and the mainland as well, he added.

Beijing hopes to spend the first two decades of this century developing its own economy and seeking an opportunity for unification with Taiwan in the process of building the strength of the country, Chang stressed.
Taiwan's democratic development would interrupt Beijing's long-term strategy for dealing with the island, he went on.

The forum, chaired by CNA Editor in Chief Liu Chih-tsung, was also attended by Professor Byron Weng of National Chi Nan University, Professor Juan Ming of Tamkang University and Chiang Li-hsin of Fo Guang University.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINES

TEXT.P: New York Times: Pending avote, some Iraqis press for a larger governing council.

As prospects for early elections faded, several ral Iraqi leaders said Thursday that they wanted the American-appointed Iraqi Governing Council to remain in place after the United States transferred power back to the people on June 30. Plans are already under way to expand the council, they added.

The leaders, including representatives from the major ethnic and religious groups and members of the council, said a consensus had emerged to increase the current council of 25 people to as many as 125, and to keep it in power until United Nations-assisted elections could be held in early 2005.

The move to extend the council's rule represented another complication in the Bush administration's vision for a quick transfer of power. As late as this week, American officials were still clinging to an agreement, signed with Iraqi leaders in November, that called for the council to be replaced on June 30 and for a new Iraqi government to be selected by nationwide caucuses.
Wall Street Journal: Searching for Hussein's billions, U.S. finds little outside Iraq.

Last March, at the start of the military invasion of Iraq, the Bush Administration announced a parallel "financial offensive" against Saddam Hussein. Treasury Secretary John Snow declared, "We are directing a world-wide hunt for the blood money that Hussein and his cronies have stolen from the Iraqi people."

But after nearly a year, the hunt for money to be used for Iraqi reconstruction appears to have largely stalled. The U.S. has recovered almost nothing of the billions Mr. Hussein and his family supposedly squirreled away.
The U.S. military scored an early success last year by seizing nearly a billion dollars in cash inside Iraq. But Mr. Hussein's alleged assets outside the country have proven far more elusive.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WILL NOT JEOPARDIZE SECURITY FOR DIRECT LINKS WITH MAINLAND

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday in Tainan County, southern Taiwan, that he will not open direct transportation links with mainland China if doing so would threaten the country's security.

Telling a group of his supporters that national security and the country's dignity are his greatest concerns, he claimed that direct transportation links could endanger both, which is why he has not open these links until now despite the advocacy of many people.

Noting that the country has done all it can to bring the unemployment rate down to 4.58 percent by the end of last year, Chen said this achievement could be easily ruined by transportation links with the mainland, which he claimed would bring in mainland workers and encourage local people to visit the mainland and spend their money there.
He also urged his supporters to cast their ballots in the March 20 presidential election and the referendum, which he described as a valuable chance for the Taiwan people to say "no" to Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW WHARVES TO OPEN AT TAINAN PORT

TEXT.P: Two new wharves built jointly by the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau and the Chi Mei Corporation at Anping Port in southern Tainan City are expected to begin operations in the near future, a bureau spokesman announced Friday.

The spokesman made the announcement after a 5,000-ton ship owned by Chi Mei returned from Thailand and made a trial docking at one of the wharves. He said ships weighing up to 20,000 tons will be able to use the two wharves after operations begin in earnest.

The new wharves will greatly benefit Anping Port -- once an important business hub in southern Taiwan -- the spokesman said. In addition to Chi Mei, other Tainan-based business groups such as President Enterprise and Great Wall Enterprise are also interested in using the port facilities, he pointed out.

with Tehran to grant a Japanese consortium rights to develop Iran' huge Azadegan oil field.

DOC.HEADLINE: 61% OF TAIWAN PEOPLE USE INTERNET: SURVEY

TEXT.P: The number of Taiwan people who use the Internet had reached 12.64 million as of the end of January, accounting for 61 percent of the island's total population, according to a report released Friday by the Taiwan Network Information Center (TWNIC).
Among the Internet users, the report said, 9.03 million people used broadband equipment.
The report further said that 4.62 million local households used the Internet, accounting for 72 percent of total households, 51.15 percent of which used broadband equipment.
The TWNIC report was based on a survey of 3,197 family members of local telephone subscribing households. The survey was conducted between Jan. 6 and Feb. 8, with a margin of error of 1.25 percent.
According to the Cabinet's "e-Taiwan" project, the government wants to promote broadband Internet services to 6 million local households.

Major TWNIC survey findings include that the 16-25 age group formed the bulk of local Internet users, with male users outnumbering female users. The most popular time for surfing the Internet ranged between 8 p.m. and 11 p.m.
