A majority of teachers in the remote southern provices have stopped work amid widespread rumours of looming violence and anonymous flyers threatening their lives. (Francis Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PRESIDES OVER GROUNDBREAKING FOR ORCHID PARK IN TAINAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presided Friday over the groundbreaking of an orchid biotechnology park in southern Tainan County, praising locally cultivated fine orchids as a symbol of Taiwan's refined agriculture.

Claiming that Taiwan orchids will become the world's top class flower due to its high quality and production volume, Chen said the government fully supports the industry, which has been included by the Executive Yuan in its "Challenge 2008" six-year national development plan.

The president also talked about the government's financial reform efforts, stressing that it has helped write off bad loans worth more than NT$1.2 trillion (about US$37 billion) for the credit divisions of farmers's and fishermen's associations all over the country.
Scores of representatives of the horticultural sectors from Japan, Holland and New Zealand also took part in the ceremony.

According to Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih, globalization is one of the critical strategies for Taiwan's agriculture in the face of strong competition from mainland China. Success for the orchid biotechnology park will set an example for other sectors, he said.

The 200-hectare park will be one of the world's leading orchid cultivation facilities and will provide a major fillip for Taiwan's production, marketing, research and sales of the popular flower in the international market, Su said.

Construction of the park's first-phase 23-hectare compound will be completed in early March to serve as the venue for an Asia-Pacific exhibition slated to open March 6. The building of a 34-hectare second-phase compound will also start shortly, he added.

The biggest difference between an orchid biotechnology park and an agricultural special zone, Su explained, is that the former is a specially designed complex devoted to the whole process of orchid cultivation, ranging from cultivation to overseas sales, while an agricultural special zone focuses only on production.
Currently, some 67 hectares of farmland in southern Tainan County are devoted to orchid planting, producing 30 percent of Taiwan's orchids.
The Executive Yuan plans to earmark more than NT$2 billion (about US$61 million) in subsidies for the five-phase development plan of the park to help promote the business.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJORITY OF POLL RESPONDENTS SAY BEIJING TRYING TO SWAY ELECTION

TEXT.P: More than half of the people surveyed in a recent poll believe mainland China is trying to sway Taiwan's March 20 presidential election, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) official said Friday.

Tsai Huang-lan, DPP whip at the Legislative Yuan, revealed the survey results Friday at a press conference. The poll was conducted Feb. 12-13 by Focus Survey Research at the commission of the private Taiwan Thinktank, with 1,042 effective samples collected and a margin of error of 3.04 percent.
The survey results show that 51.4 percent of those polled said that Beijing is trying to sway the presidential election, compared with 21.1 percent who disagreed.
Tsai said that if foreign forces intervene in the election, it will affect Taiwan's competition edge.

The results also show that 57.8 percent of the respondents believe that business tycoons who flock to invest in the mainland leaving huge debts in Taiwan will have a "very serious" impact on Taiwan's economy, and 18.6 percent said they will have a "serious" impact.

On who, as a national leader, will be more capable of improving the situation, 27.4 percent named President Chen Shui-bian, compared with 22.8 percent who named his election rival, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan.
"This shows that President Chen is more capable of solving the problem," Tsai claimed.

The survey also found that 20.2 percent of the respondents believe that former Tuntex Group Chairman Chen You-hau, one of the country's 10 most-wanted fugitives, who fled Taiwan after embezzling the group's money, will be removed from the wanted list if Lien is elected president, compared with 58.4 percent who said they do not believe such a possibility.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE LAWMAKERS TO VISIT TAIWAN TO OBSERVE PRESIDENTIAL POLL
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 20 (CNA) (By Amy Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Japanese lawmakers will travel to Taiwan in several groups in the coming weeks to observe the March 20 presidential election, the Republic of China representative office in Tokyo said Friday.

Two independent Diet members -- Yoshihiro Kawagami and Tetsushi Sakamoto -- concluded a three-day fact-finding visit to Taiwan Thursday, an official with the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Japan said, adding that three other Diet members will make a similar trip to Taipei next week.
The official said the final week before the presidential poll will be a peak period for Japanese dietmen visiting Taiwan to observe the hotly contested election.

According to the official, the Japanese media has given prominent coverage to Taiwan's presidential election and its first-ever referendum to be held on the same day. Asahi Television, for instance, will broadcast an interview with President Chen Shui-bian, who is seeking re-election, within the next day or two.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPECIAL WEAPONRY PROCUREMENT PLAN NOT EXPECTED TO BE FINALIZED SOON

TEXT.P: Special budget plans for Taiwan's additional procurement of advanced weapons systems, including submarines, are not expected to be finalized before May 20, Minister of National Defense Tang Yiau-min said Friday.

Tang said a final revision of the analysis of weapons systems on the Ministry of National Defense's (MND's) shopping list is expected to be submitted by the MND to the Legislative Yuan in early March, while the investment guidelines are expected to take another two months to complete, making it impossible for the special arms-purchasing budget plans to be passed by the legislature before May 20, the day the next president is sworn into office.

Tang made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan to discount media speculation that the government is pressing to allow the special arms budget plans to clear the legislative floor before March 20 in an attempt to get a nod from Washington to Taiwan's holding a referendum on election day.

During an interview with the local radio program "UFO Breakfast" a day earlier, President Chen Shui-bian Chen said he sees no fault in Tang's remarks Wednesday that even if more than half of the electorate vote against purchasing more missiles in the upcoming referendum, the MND will go ahead with its arms procurement plans.

"What we need to buy to beef up our defense capabilities includes many kinds of weapons, not just missiles, " Chen argued, adding that he had extensive discussions with Tang and other government officials before deciding on the referendum questions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, NEW ZEALAND INK WORKING HOLIDAY SCHEME AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan and New Zealand signed an agreement Friday to allow young people from both countries to take temporary work while on holiday in each other's country.

Shih Ting, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New Zealand, and Charles Finny, director of the New Zealand Commerce and Industry Office in Taipei, signed the arrangement on behalf of their respective governments.

Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien noted during the signing ceremony that the substantive bilateral trade exchanges between Taiwan and New Zealand grew by 22 percent last year, a year in which New Zealanders made 54,000 visits to Taiwan, while Taiwanese made around 25,000 visits to New Zealand. Both countries also hold regular bilateral trade and economic meetings.

Shih pointed out that New Zealand broached the idea during a Taiwan-New Zealand trade consultation conference in May 2001. New Zealand Prime Minister Helen Clarke also agreed that the two countries should increase economic and cultural exchanges when she was interviewed by a Taipei monthly magazine.

Shih noted that related government agencies reached consensus after lengthy discussions on various aspects of the project. The two governments then worked out and finalized the scheme after two years of coordination.
Shih said the scheme has become a major channel of bilateral youth exchanges around the world and he cited similar schemes in the neighboring countries of Japan and South Korea as an example.

He noted that Japan signed agreements on a similar scheme with Australia, New Zealand, Canada, France and South Korea, while South Korea also operate similar schemes with Australia, New Zealand, Canada and Japan, with initial good results.

Statistics in Japan and South Korea show that Japanese and South Korean young people going to New Zealand have so far outnumbered New Zealanders going to Japan and South Korea for working holidays, and that most Japanese and South Korean youths who have participated in the scheme have come away with positive views of the program.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said that according to the terms of the agreement, the representative offices in each country can issue visas to 400 young people each year who meet the qualifications for enrollment in the program.

Applicants must be aged between 18 and 30, and their main purpose of travel must be for vacation. The work they undertake will only be to allow them to earn some spending money during their stays and working will not be the main purpose of their entry.
MOFA officials said that New Zealand is the first country that Taiwan had signed such an agreement with, while Taiwan is the 18th country with which New Zealand has signed similar agreements.

The scheme will based on the principle of reciprocity, so that youths from both countries can have a chance to understand first-hand the society, culture and people of other country, establish lasting friendships and strengthen long-term substantive bilateral relations through private contacts.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION CAMPAIGN TO FORMALLY KICK OFF SATURDAY

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) issued a gazette Friday announcing that the campaign period for the March 20 presidential and vice presidential election will officially kick off Saturday.
According to the gazette, the official campaign period will last until March 19 and the daily campaign hours will be from 7 a.m. to 10 p.m.
The CEC also formally announced that there will be two presidential and vice presidential tickets for the electorate to choose between.

In the two-way race, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan will team up with People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong to challenge the re-election bid of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

In fact, the two rival camps have been carrying out election campaign activities for a long time and according to the results of various public opinion polls, the two tickets are running neck and neck.

According to a survey of 2,535 eligible voters conducted by the China Times between Feb. 16 and Feb. 19, Lien would win 43 percent of the vote against 40 percent for Chen if the election were to take place the following day.

The Chinese-language paper claimed that although Lien has maintained a roughly 3 percentage point lead over Chen in recent surveys, this was the first time support for the president had risen to above 40 percent, which indicates that the race is too close to call.
With just 30 days to go before the vote, about 17 percent of those interviewed were still undecided. The poll allowed for a 2 percent margin of error.

Despite trailing in most opinion polls, Chen said in a radio interview broadcast live Thursday that he is confident he will win the election by between 300,000 and 500,000 votes, which would be a majority of roughly 3 percent to 5 percent.

Chen predicted that the outcome will be similar to the race four years ago, when he defeated Lien and Soong, a former KMT secretary-general who mounted a maverick presidential bid, in a tight three-way election, ending more than five decades of KMT rule in Taiwan.
This time around, however, Lien and Soong have formed a joint presidential ticket to challenge Chen's re-election bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE SAMPAN SINKS AFTER RAMMING PENGHU FISHING BOAT
DOC.DATELINE: Kinmen, Feb. 20 (CNA) (By K.Y. Ni and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A mainland Chinese sampan sank in Republic of China waters near Kinmen after ramming a Penghu-based fishing boat in thick fog Friday morning.

The motor-driven sampan, named the Minlongyu 4052 from Fujian Province, collided with the Penghu-registered 99-ton fishing boat "Sheng-Hung-Chuan" in waters near Kinmen's Peiting Isle and capsized shortly before it sank. The only two crew members of the vessel -- father and son Kang Ahquan, 54 and Kang Ahzhi, 26 -- were rescued by the crew of the vessel they hit, the Sheng-Hung-Chuan.
According to the skipper of the Sheng-Hung-Chuan, Chang Tsai-ling, he did not see the sampan on his radar and the fog was so thick that his crew members did not see the sampan.

Chang said they were totally unaware of the presence of the mainland sampan until they heard a huge "bang" as the two vessels collided. He added that as soon as he saw the two mainlanders fall into the water, he instructed three of his crew to jump overboard to their rescue.

Chang said that he radioed the Kinmen fishing broadcasting station for help after discovering that the senior Kang had suffered injuries to his chest. Both the Kangs were transported to a Kinmen hospital soon afterward, Chang said.
Authorities from the Kinmen Coast Guard have begun investigating the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE SEIZE 4 KG KETAMINE

TEXT.P: Four kilograms of ketamine were seized late Thursday in a raid in the southern city of Kaohsiung, police authorities reported Friday.

Police had been tipped off that a major dealer identified as Kuo Chun-cheng, 33, was smuggling raw materials from abroad and processing them into ketamine at a time when the price of ketamine had been driven up because of a stepped up police crackdown. Kuo then sold on the processed drugs to lower-stream dealers in central and southern Taiwan.

Kuo, who police described as being well-versed in legal regulations on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, imported the various controlled substances via fishing boats and made frequent trips back and forth between Taiwan and the mainland.
Seeking to expand the source of his raw materials, Kuo recently began traveling Southeast Asian countries such as Burma and Thailand in search of supplies.
After a stakeout operation lasting more than three months, the police found that Kuo was using a tea shop in Kaohsiung City as a front for his operation.

During the raid, the police failed to apprehend Kuo, who is believed to have fled after finding out about the tipoff, but they found four kilograms of ketamine, fumigation equipment, electronic scales and counterfeit bills at the scene.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 15.98 points to close at 6,665.54.

The other major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 1.8 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares at 1.1 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 0.8 percent, foodstuff shares at 0.5 percent, textile issues at 0.3 percent, and construction stocks at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 466 to 316, with 183 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE, MALAYSIA CARRY OUT CHEMICAL EMERGENCY EXERCISE

TEXT.P: Singapore and Malaysia successfully completed an emergency exercise Thursday aimed at dealing with chemical accidents.
It was the fourth such exercise jointly held by Singapore's National Environment Agency (NEA) and Johor's Department of Environment.
The exercise simulated a chemical spill from a prime mover carrying ammonia across the Tuas Second Link to Singapore.
Foong Chee Leong, the head of the NEA's pollution control, said the exercise was aimed at testing the two countries' emergency operational readiness.

The Emergency Response Plan is designed to enable emergency response agencies from Singapore and Malaysia to react quickly and effectively to minimize the impact of hazardous chemical accidents on the Second Link.
The road transportation of hazardous chemicals is restricted to the Second Link. Last year, about 60,000 tons of hazardous chemicals moved between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 20, or the first day of the second month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1437: James I, King of Scotland, is assassinated by a group of nobles seeking to place a rival on the throne. He was 42.
1694: Voltaire, French philosopher, writer and moralist who waged a lifelong campaign against intolerance and injustice, is born.
1707: Aurangzeb, the sixth and perhaps last of the great Mogul emperors of India, dies at the age of 88. He seized the throne at Agra from his father, Shah Jahan, 49 years earlier, killing two of his brothers and jailing the third to secure his succession.
1811: Austria declares itself bankrupt.
1904: Alexei Kosygin, Soviet prime minister from 1964 to 1980, is born.
1915: The Panama-Pacific Exhibition, in celebration of the opening of the Panama Canal between the Atlantic and Pacific oceans, opens in San Francisco.
1916: The Battle of Verdun begins after Chief of the German General Staff Falkenhayn chooses to attack the French city of Verdun, despite his belief that France will defend it to the last man.
1919: Afghan head of state Habibullah Khan is assassinated. He was succeeded by one of his sons, Amanullah Khan.
1922: Hong Kong police fire on striking workers, killing two and severely injuring seven.
1933: The U.S. House of Representatives passes an act to abolish the law prohibiting the consumption of alcohol in the United States.
1938: British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden resigns in protest against Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's policy of appeasement of Italy's Fascist dictator Benito Mussolini and German's Nazi dictator Adolf Hitler.
1942: Portugal protests to Japan after Japanese troops invade Portuguese Timor.
1946: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China declares the Yalta Secret Agreement not binding in the case of China.
1952: A meeting on the Treaty of Peace between the Republic of China and Japan is held in Taipei.
1960: The third plenary session of the first ROC National Assembly opens in Taipei.
1962: Astronaut John Glenn circles the Earth three times in less than five hours, becoming the first U.S. citizen to orbit the planet.
1966: Chester William Nimitz, admiral of the U.S. Pacific Fleet during World War II, who halted Japanese expansion and ultimately destroyed the Japanese fleet with a strategy based largely on the use of aircraft carriers, dies at the age of 81.
1967: President Sukarno surrenders all executive power to General Suharto, keeping only the title of president of Indonesia.
1971: Major-General Idi Amin Dada heads the new government of Uganda as president after the Uganda Army overthrows Apollo Milton Obote.
1972: Radio telephone service between Taipei and Madrid is inaugurated.
1974: A six-member South Korean Parliamentary Mission led by Oh Joon Suk arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1976: International Monetary Fund experts and representatives of the ROC Ministry of Finance begin their annual meeting with ROC Vice Minister Wang Shao-yu and the IMF Asia Department's consultant Andreas Abadjis as co-chairs.
1976: Gen. Wego Chiang, president of the Armed Forces University, and 30 foreign cadets studying war techniques in the ROC visit the offshore island of Kinmen.
1979: Mount Sinira erupts in Indonesia, claiming 175 lives.
1988: Torrential flooding in Rio de Janeiro leaves 500 dead and 10,000 homeless.
1997: Washington refuses to recognize the World Trade Organization's authority in its dispute with the European Union over trade with Cuba.
2000: ROC opposition Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian stresses that only political party rotation can maintain Taiwan's administrative neutrality and achieve independence of the government's judicial branch.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who is not in office in the government of a country, should never give advice as to its policy."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT CONFIDENT OF WINNING RE-ELECTION
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 21 (CNA) (By C.C. Huang and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that he is confident he and Vice President Annette Lu will win a second term in the March 20 presidential election, although he admitted that the campaign is very tough.
The president made the comments in an interview with the Japanese Asahi TV Station. The content of the interview was broadcast by the station's "News Station" program Friday night.

Describing the election campaign as very tough and saying that the contest may be decided by a razor-thin margin of only 3 percent to 5 percent of the vote, Chen said that nevertheless, he and Lu will certainly win the campaign.
Mainland China wants to use force to change Taiwan's status quo, the president said in the interview, adding that the island should have the right and opportunity to say "no" to the mainland.

Chen also hopes that the people of Taiwan will be able to decide the definitive version of the Constitution by holding another referendum by 2006. Saying that Taiwan's first referendum, to be held concurrently with the presidential election March 20, is aimed at maintaining the country's status quo as well as protecting the nation's sovereignty, democratic development and economic prosperity, the president said that it is also designed to maintain the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo.
Saying that Taiwan has the same goals as those of Japan, the United States and France, the president said that all Taiwan wants is to maintain the status quo.
Before televising the interview, the program also introduced Chen as the leader of the 23 million people of Taiwan and the person who makes the mainland the most nervous.
Analyzing the reasons for Beijing's nervousness, the program said the mainland is worried that Chen's actions will lead Taiwan to independence if he wins a second term.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMANIAN TRADE MISSION TO VISIT TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Feb. 20 (CNA) (By M.S. Huang and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A Panamanian trade mission headed by First Vice President Arturo Vallarino and Trade and Industrial Minister Joaquin Jacome, is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Sunday for a six-day visit.
The mission consists of 43 representatives from various sectors including agriculture, livestock, the seafood industry and the hotel business.

The members of the mission have expressed hope that the signing of a free trade agreement (FTA) between the two countries will help them further promote their products and services as well as seeking business opportunities when they visit the island.

President Chen Shui-bian and his Panamanian counterpart, Mireya Moscoso, signed the FTA in Taipei -- the first such accord that Taiwan has ever signed with a trading partner -- Aug. 21 last year. The two presidents then exchanged notes on the signing to complete the process in Panama last November.

DOC.TEXT: The Japan Times: Annan calls polls impossible in Iraq until power transfer; U.N. promises to help form new goverment. UNITED NATIONS U.N. Secretary General Kofi Annan on Thursday sided with the United States, saying elections in Iraq before the political transfer of power on June 30 are not feasible.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER VISITS 3 SOUTHERN AFRICAN COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: ROC Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu has made a three-leg tour of three southern African countries over the past week to meet with their government officials and help Taiwanese business people resolve problems.

Lin arrived in Swaziland Feb. 15 to attend an annual ROC-Swaziland economic cooperation conference. During the meeting, officials from the two sides agreed to strengthen cooperation in trade, investment and technological development as well as in AIDS prevention.

Lin later told Taiwanese business people operating in Swaziland that the Swazi prime minister has agreed to help resolve their problems, including simplifying customs clearance procedures for exports.

Lin also visited Lesotho and South Africa after the Swaziland trip. During his meeting with officials of the two countries, Lin asked them to help resolve difficulties faced by Taiwan investors in the two countries, including value-added taxes on raw materials, rising labor wages and dramatic currency exchange rate fluctuations.
Lin wrapped up his southern African tour and left Johannesburg for home late Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Ex-CEO Arraigned in Fraud at Enron.
Former Enron Corp. Chief Executive Jeffrey K. Skilling was taken to court in handcuffs to face charges on 35 counts of fraud, insider trading and conspiracy in connection with one of the biggest corporate scandals in recent American history.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN WILL NOT VOTE IN REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman and presidential candidate Lien Chan said Saturday that he will not vote in Taiwan's first-ever referendum, to be held alongside the March 20 presidential election.

Lien, in the second and last live televised debate between him and President Chen Shui-bian, said that he respects the people's right to take part in the referendum but will not himself cast his ballots on the questions concerning the strengthening of the nation's defenses and the opening of cross-strait dialogue because the referendum is "illegal" and "controversial."

Lien was responding to questions by Chen as to why the KMT is boycotting the referendum when the KMT-led camp passed its version of the Referendum Law -- the brainchild of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party -- when he acted according to the law in calling for the referendum.

Lien said that the Article 17 of the Referendum Law only empowers the president to call for such a referendum when the nation is threatened by outside forces so that its sovereignty is at risk of being changed and claimed that neither of these conditions exist at present.

Lien pointed out that mainland China's missiles were deployed against Taiwan when Chen pledged his "four noes plus one, " promises -- which included no referendum on the nation's status -- in his 2000 inaugural speech.

The referendum is also "controversial, " Lien said, claiming that with only 30 days to go to the presidential election, the public is not capable to make such major decisions in such a short time. He also questioned the legality of the referendum and claimed that it is no more than a ploy to boost Chen's election campaign.
He said that this is a gross violation of the law by the president, which is "very discouraging for all those who have promoted the referendum system."

Lien told Chen that the spirit of the Referendum Law is clear and that except for Article 17, the referendum is the right of the people and not that of the president. He urged the president "to rein himself in before the brink of the precipice."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Pakistani said to have given Libya uranium.
The network led by the Pakistani nuclear scientist Abdul Qadeer Khan shipped partly enriched uranium directly to Libya aboard a Pakistani airplane in 2001, providing the fuel stock in addition to the designs and technology to make a nuclear bomb, according to a report by Malaysian investigators released Friday.
The report provides a wealth of evidence that businessmen and engineers from Turkey, Germany, Switzerland and Britain, as well as Dubai and Malaysia, were closely involved in recent years in Libya's clandestine nuclear program. It is based primarily on the Malaysian authorities' interrogation of B.S.A. Tahir, 44, a key middleman in Dr. Khan's global nuclear trading network.
Wall Street Journal: Prosecutors rest their case in trial of Martha Stewart.
The U.S. government rested its case against Martha Stewart and her stockbroker Friday, after a critical prosecution witness wavered slightly about testimony that had damaged the homemaking mogul.
But whether the jury will hear from Ms. Stewart, or even deliberate on one of the charges against her, will remain a mystery until next week.
U.S. District Judge Miriam Goldman Cedarbaum said she would rule Monday on a motion by Ms. Stewart's attorney Robert Morvillo to dismiss a charge of securities fraud in the case. That count accuses Ms. Stewart of deceiving investors in her own company, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia Inc., by announcing her sale of shares in Im Clone Systems Inc. was proper.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD JOIN INTERNATIONAL COMMUNITY: KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang chairman and presidential candidate Lien Chan said Saturday that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should think seriously about letting Taiwan join the international community and take part in related activities.
Lien, the sole challenger to President Chen Shui-bian in the March 20 election, made the remarks during the second and the last of two live televised debates with Chen prior to the election.

During a question-and-answer session, Lien was asked by Cheng Duan-yao, a researcher of the Institute of International Relations of National Chengchi University, how to make a breakthrough in the diplomatic plight faced by the nation with the emergence of mainland China and the gradual erosion of Taiwan's economic edge, which has resulted in the stalled or even dwindling number of diplomatic allies.

Lien was asked how, if his interpretation of "one China" is the Republic of China, can break the common perception among the international community of "one China" as meaning the People's Republic of China.

Lien stressed that under the concept of "one China means the Republic of China, " both sides engaged in seven or eight years of dialogue -- although the dialogue stalled after former President Lee Teng-hui's "special state-to-state" rhetoric of 1999 -- and that a lot of substantive results were produced during the period.

He criticized Chen's administration for losses on the diplomatic front over the years, saying that even the United States, which Taiwan has relied upon heavily, has had misgivings about the referendum called by Chen alongside the presidential election.
He said that if elected, he would cement ties with countries with which Taiwan has diplomatic relations, and enhance substantive relations with those countries which are close to Taiwan.
He also said that friendly relations between nations should be based on mutual trust, not on a series of "surprises" -- a dig at the frequent flip-flops of the current government.
He said that "Taiwan can contribute a lot to the international community, " adding that "its performance in every way should be respected by the world."

He said that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should think seriously about a mechanism that would allow Taiwan to join the international community, and added that both sides should simultaneously join international organizations and take part in related activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS STRAIT TALKS SHOULD BE HELD ON BASIS OF MUTUAL RESPECT: LIEN

TEXT.P: Presidential candidate Lien Chan urged the two sides of the Taiwan Strait Saturday to establish a dialogue mechanism based on mutual respect.
The chairman of the opposition Kuomintang made the appeal during the second and final of two live televised debates between him and President Chen Shui-bian prior to the March 20 election.

Lien was asked by Chen why he still insists on the so-called "one China, " when the international community sees "China" as meaning the People's Republic of China, of which Taiwan is a part, while the previous KMT administration's long advocation of "one China" has led Taiwan to become an international pariah.

However, Lien countered by saying that according to the Republic of China Constitution, "China" means the Republic of China, which is what Chen pledged his allegiance to during his inauguration May 20, 2000.

Lien said the so-called "1992 consensus, " which the KMT believes was reached between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in 1992, was based on the concept of "one China, different interpretations" and not as "one country, two systems" as construed by Chen.

Lien said that cross-strait relations should start from a position of mutual respect and that both sides should put aside their political differences and start dialogue, leaving a solution to the "one China" issue for the future. Between now and that time, both sides still need to establish a dialogue mechanism, he said.
In a question-and-answer session earlier, Lien also spoke about the three-stage National Unification Guidelines set out by the former KMT administration.
He noted that nearly 13 years has passed since the unveiling of the guidelines, a period in which the nation's environment has undergone tremendous changes, which leaves a lot of room for discussion.
He promised that if elected, he will "invite all political parties to promote a supra-party national development conference to forge a new consensus."
He stressed that both sides of the strait should treat each other based on the principles of "equality and mutual respect."

He also defended the mainland China policy of the old KMT administration, saying that between 1988 and 1995, the two sides conducted two meetings between Ku Chen-Fu and Wang Daohan, the top negotiators for the two sides, and nearly 30 cross-strait consultations, which he said resulted in many substantive agreements.

"During the same period, Taiwan continued to develop and make diplomatic breakthroughs, while its society was orderly and prosperous, " Lien claimed, adding that "this shows that cross-strait development and Taiwan's development had no conflicts with what we advocated."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO MAKING PEACE WITH BEIJING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that if he is re-elected in the upcoming presidential election, he hopes to shake hands and make peace with mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao.

"Ah Bian's biggest hope is that one day in the next four years, I can shake hands with President Hu Jintao and reconcile," Chen said in a televised debate with opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, who is the sole challenger to Chen's re-election bid.
Chen also said in his concluding speech of a two-hour debate with Lien that he wants to post a permanent representative to Beijing before May 20, when the next presidential term begins.

Although his plan to hold a referendum alongside the March 20 presidential election has drawn broadsides from Beijing, Chen claimed that his referendum will lend the authority of public opinion to negotiations with the mainland.
"That is why we are confident we can begin positive talks and sign agreements with the mainland if I'm re-elected," Chen said.

In Taiwan's first-ever referendum, voters will be asked whether Taiwan should acquire more anti-missile defense capabilities to defend itself against military threats from mainland China and whether the island should enter into talks with Beijing for the establishment of a framework for peaceful interaction.

In the two-hour debate, Chen portrayed himself as the defender of Taiwan's sovereignty against the mainland, which sees the island as a breakaway province that must be brought to heel, by force if necessary. He attacked Lien's stance on the mainland, saying that Taiwan is an independent country and not a mere "appendage" to the mainland.
"The problem is that during the KMT's long rule, they insisted on 'one China'. This is why Taiwan is an international outcast today, " Chen said.
He also accused Lien of having a wishy-washy policy with regard to the mainland. "Lien doesn't believe in himself. He doesn't believe in Taiwan," he said.
Chen also criticized a position backed by Lien's running mate, People First Party Chairman James Soong, who has said Taiwan and the mainland can exist under the same "one-China roof."
"If we're all under a one-China roof, is Taiwan the carpet or the tile?" Chen asked.
The wide-ranging debate also touched on women's issues, the economy, defense, ethnic harmony and equality. But Taiwan's relationship with the mainland was a major point.

In the debate, Chen argued that Lien's economic development initiatives would allow the mainland to swallow Taiwan, which is just 160 kilometers off the mainland coast, while claiming that his own policies would protect the island from becoming marginalized.
"Taiwan isn't a springboard to China. It's the center of Asia, " Chen claimed.
He also repeated his now famous "four noes plus one" pledge that he will not make any changes to the status quo of cross-Taiwan Strait relations as long as the mainland does not attack.
"Our push for democratic reforms isn't a push for an independence timetable," he said.

In his eight-minute conclusion at the end of the debate, Chen said that if he is re-elected, he will make every possible effort to have Taiwan admitted into the World Health Organization within two years.

He also reaffirmed his commitment to safeguarding Taiwan's sovereign status, expanding its diplomatic frontiers and continuing sweeping reforms, including government restructuring, legislative reform, judicial reform, financial reform and social reform.

Most important is to prevent a revival of corrupt "black gold" politics, Chen said, adding that during his second term, he will push for the passage of major "sunshine bills" to facilitate clean politics and push the KMT to return its ill-gotten party assets to the national coffers.
In his opening remarks delivered prior to the question-and-answer session, Chen said his administration has had to deal with many "old ills" left unresolved by the previous KMT administration.

Against this backdrop, he claimed that if the Lien-Soong ticket wins the upcoming poll, it would usher in a return of "black gold" politics. "It would be like buying a new television set that has an old 'black gold' image tube installed. That would be a nightmare for our country," he said.

Chen also took advantage of the debate to urge the electorate to vote on the referendum to demonstrate to the world Taiwan's determination to safeguard its security with peace, rather than war with mainland China. The referendum results will also push Beijing to respect Taiwan people's desire for forging a viable mechanism for peaceful cross-strait interaction.
The debate was the second and final one of its kind before the presidnetial poll. The first live TV debate between the two contenders was held a week ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PROPOSES MORE DEBATES WITH HIS ELECTION CHALLENGER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian proposed more debates Saturday with his sole election challenger, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan.

Chen, who is seeking reelection in the March 20 presidential election, presented his proposal in the second and final televised debate with Lien that was held at the studios of the Public Television Service. The first debate took place Feb. 14.
Chen said that he hopes to have a third and even fourth round of debate with Lien.

He reiterated his proposal at a press conference held after the debate, claiming that "many groups expect the two presidential candidates to hold more debates on their policies and assertions with regard to national issues."
He urged media outlets to help promote his proposal and make it a reality.
Neither Lien nor his campaign headquarters commented on Chen's proposal.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL PURSUE VALUE-ADDED INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT: KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan said Saturday that the nation must follow the path of developing industry through value-added products.
Lien made the remarks in the second and final TV television debate between himself and President Chen Shui-bian prior to the March 20 presidential election.

Asked about Taiwan's industry, which is undergoing a tremendous transformation because the traditional sectors are flocking out of the country while the hi-tech sector is facing a bottleneck, Lien said the direction is clear-cut. He noted that the manufacturing sector used to be the prime mover of the nation's development, but with the changing environment, the country has to move from "made in Taiwan" to "value added in Taiwan or value added by Taiwan."

He said that the previous KMT administration promoted the idea of an Asia-Pacific operations center project, but the project was derailed because of the "go slow, no haste" policy advocated by former President Lee Teng-hui.

He said the idea of Taiwan as a gateway must be maintained and added that from this idea, Taiwan could become an assets management, logistics, investment, design, and research and development center in Asia and the world.

Lien also said that in addition to the industrial and manufacturing sectors, the service sector also has rich potential, adding that a service sector based on knowledge must be promoted, while assistance should be given to small- and medium-sized enterprises, as well as to conventional industries, to help them create their own brands.
Agricultural policy, he said, must be based on technology to create superior agriculture. The government should also take care of farmers and promote tourism agriculture, Lien said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEAN CONNERY HAS NO INTENTION OF VISITING TAIWAN: AGENT

TEXT.P: Scottish movie star Sean Connery has no plans to visit Taiwan, according to an e-mailed statement to CNA by Connery's public relations agent.
"He (Connery) is not now, nor was he ever, planning a trip either to Tokyo or to Taiwan," Nancy Seltzer said in her statement.

Wang Hsien-chi, a deputy executive director of the "one million hand-in-hand" campaign, told domestic media last Thursday that Connery would come to Taiwan to take part in the islandwide human-chain event that will take place Feb. 28 to demonstrate the Taiwan people's determination and esprit de corps in protecting the country by peaceful means.
Connery had been "expected to announce" his Taiwan itinerary at a press conference in Tokyo Feb. 26, according to a report by the Taipei-based China Times.
In fact, Connery will be attending the Academy Awards Feb. 29, the head of the California-based Nancy Seltzer and Associates noted.
In response to Seltzer's statement, Wang said he had nothing to say about the issue and that it is regrettable that Connery will not come to Taiwan.
He declined to reveal his information sources, but admitted that he had excited many people with his claim that Connery would visit Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION CAMPAIGNING KICKS OFF WITH LIVE TV DEBATE

TEXT.P: The presidential election campaign officially kicked off Saturday, 28 days before the March 20 presidential poll.

The Central Election Commission (CEC) had issued a gazette Friday introducing the profiles of the two contending presidential tickets -- opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan teaming up with People First Party Chairman James Soong to challenge the re-election bid of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.

According to the CEC gazette, candidates may hold campaign rallies from 7 a.m. to 10 p.m. Anyone running over the limit will face fines of NT$50,000 to NT$500,000 (US$1,500-US$15,000) . Candidates in major local elections are often willing to pay the fines in order to stage raucous late-night rallies with blaring airhorns and laser light shows.

The CEC is scheduled to finalize the compilation of the electorate roster at the end of this month and will publish the roster between March 2 and March 4. Eligible voters can ask for corrections of the roster within a specified period of time. The CEC will formally announce March 16 the exact number of voters eligible to cast ballots in the 11th-term presidential poll.

According to the CEC schedule, a bulletin detailing the locations of all polling stations will be issued before March 4. The CEC is also scheduled to complete ballot printing and distribution of election bulletins and voting notices by March 17.

Although the official campaign period began Saturday, the two rival camps -- the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP -- have been mobilizing for months.

With just four weeks to go before the election, most opinion polls show that about a fifth of eligible voters remain undecided. The two candidates are now fighting very hard to win over the swing voters in what seems certain to be a tight race.
Government data shows that some 16.4 million people are eligible to vote, an increase of about 1 million from the 2000 election.

In addition to electing the president and vice president, voters will also cast two additional ballots for two questions put forth in the nation's first-ever referendum to be held alongside the presidential poll. The questions are whether Taiwan should buy more anti-missile batteries in the face of mainland China's intensified military threat and whether Taiwan should negotate a mechanism with Beijing for peaceful interaction.

The DPP launched an "Action 100" campaign program Saturday in connection with the opening of the official campaign period. The program is aimed at helping the electorate become familiar with the voting procedure, as voters might not know how to cast their referendum votes.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DRIFTS FURTHER AWAY FROM PEOPLE: KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, the sole challenger of President Chen Shui-bian in the March 20 election, accused Chen Saturday of drifting away from the people, claiming that even his close allies have turned away from him.
Lien made his claims while delivering his opening statement in the second and final of two live television debates between the two candidates.

After offering a greeting in mandarin Chinese, Taiwanese, Hakka and aboriginal languages, Lien wasted no time in claiming that since the beginning of the presidential campaign, Chen has engaged in a series of smear strategies.

"Why all this mudslinging? " Lien asked. "This is because the election is drawing near, but (Chen's) performance sheet over the past four years is so lackluster that he simply cannot face the voters and has to shift the focus from his poor performance."

According to Lien, this is not his feeling alone, and he cited blistering attacks from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) by Chang Chun-hung, a DPP heavyweight, the previous day, as well as passages in a recently published book by former National Security Bureau Ting Yu-chou, to bolster his claim that Chen is an inexperienced national leader and that his administration lacks talented people.
He then pointed out what he claimed are four major flaws of Chen.

"Mr. Chen is constrained by his ideology, so that he cannot rationally analyse many major issues, " Lien claimed, citing the suspension of construction work on the partially finished Fourth Nuclear Power Plant in late October 2000 as an example. Chen only budged and agreed to resume construction in early 2001 under tremendous pressure from the dominant opposition parties in the legislature.

"The temporary suspension cost the government an additional NT$93 billion (US$2.8 billion), domestic investment has shed NT$450 billion every year and the plummeting stock market has caused incalculable losses," according to Lien, who added that this proves "a wrong policy is even worse than corruption."

Lien further claimed that Chen "is ignorant of the international situation" so that he has insisted on holding his referendum on enhancing anti-missile capability and resuming cross-Taiwan strait talks despite misgivings by Taiwan's closest friends, including the United States, Japan, France and even the Vatican. l

Lien quoted U.S. President George W. Bush, who said that "the comments and actions made by the leader of Taiwan indicate that he may be willing to make decisions unilaterally to change the status quo, which we oppose." According to Lien, Taiwan has never before been in this plight in its dealings with foreign relations.

Chen is "helpless" in dealing with cross-strait relations, so that four years after he advocated the promotion of direct trade, postal and transportation between the two sides, the links still have not gone anywhere, Lien went on.

"Chen has also drifted further away from the people, " Lien continued, claiming that social division has become more acute during his rule and adding that recently, a mother took her own life as well as those of her three young daughters because she could not repay a NT$200,000 debt.

"Under Chen's rule, Taiwan set a record high 3,053 suicides annually, " Lien said, adding that the tragic number is even higher than the number of victims of the devastating earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999.
He also claimed that social order has worsened, saying that media reports have said that 1 million households were burglarized last year, resulting in estimated losses of more than NT$100 billion.
He concluded by saying with emotion that his ancestors have lived in Taiwan for 10 generations and that he wants to work for a better Taiwan with hope if elected.
He painted his vision of Taiwan as a place of "ethnic harmony." He said that if elected, he will also work to mend fences with foreign friends and allies based on the credibility lost under Chen.
Lien also promised to develop the nation's economy and address the jobless question, rising debts and the widening gap between rich and poor.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT EXPOUNDS VISION FOR TAIWAN IN LIVE TV DEBATE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian outlined his vision for Taiwan's future Saturday in a second live TV debate with his sole challenger in the March 20 presidential election, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan.

In his eight-minute conclusion at the end of the debate, Chen said that if he is re-elected, he will make every possible effort to have Taiwan admitted into the World Health Organization within two years.
He also reaffirmed his commitment to safeguarding Taiwan's sovereign status and expanding its diplomatic frontiers.
Stressing that Taiwan is an independent sovereign country, Chen said any change to the present status quo must be approved by the people of Taiwan through referendum.
He further pledged to do whatever he can to normalize relations across the Taiwan Strait, including establishing a viable mechanism for peaceful bilateral interaction.

"If I'm re-elected, we'll have an envoy stationed in Beijing shortly after the May 20 presidential inauguration, " Chen claimed confidently, adding that he will make all-out efforts to promote cross-strait reconciliation and rapprochement during his second term.

The president also said he will promote Taiwan's constitutional reforms on the "four noes plus one" pledge outlined in his 2000 inaugural speech. The "four noes plus one" pledge refers to no change to Taiwan's official title or flag, as well as no holding of a referendum on the independence versus unification issue.

His remarks were seen as a response to opposition accusations that his plan for constitutional reform, such as formulating a new constitution for Taiwan in 2006, is a timetable for pursuing de jure Taiwan independence.
"The ultimate goal of our constitutional reform plan is to make Taiwan a normal, complete and great country," Chen asserted.

Key points of his constitutional reform plan include modifying Taiwan's current five-branch central government system to a three-branch one, halving the number of legislative seats and implementing a new "single seat, two ballots" system for legislative elections.

The two-hour debate was the second and final of the two live TV debates between the two presidential candidates to be held before the March 20 presidential poll. The first debate was held last Saturday.
The wide-ranging debate also touched on women's issues, the economy and defense. But Taiwan's relationship with mainland China was a major point.

The debate followed the same format adopted in the first one a week ago. At the beginning, each candidate delivered an eight-minute opening speech, followed by a question-and-answer session in which five questioners took turn asked the two candidates various issues. Each questioner asked two questions. After a 15-minute intermission, the candidates asked each other five questions before ending with an eight-minute conclusion.

The five questioners were Chang Wu-euh, director of the Graduate Institute of China Studies, Tamkang University; Cheng Duan-yau, a researcher at the Institute of International Relations, National Chengchi University; Huang Chang-ling, an associate professor of policial science at the National Taiwan University; Sun Ta-chuan, a former vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Indigenous Peoples's Affairs; and Chen Tain-jy, president of the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research.

The debate was co-sponsored by Public Television Service (PTS) and several other news organizations. In addition to PTS, nearly all major local TV and radio stations broadcast the debate live. PTS also cooperated with Chunghwa Telecom to provide a live Web feed.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECOND TV PRESIDENTIAL DEBATE HELD

TEXT.P: The second and final live televised debate between President Chen Shui-bian and his sole challenger in the March 20 election, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, was held in Taipei Saturday.

Chen arrived at the studios of the Public Television Service (PTS) channel, co-sponsor and the venue of the two debates without his wife, who accompanied him to the last debate held Feb. 14. Lien, accompanied by his wife Lien Fang Yu, arrived a little later.
The two candidates shook hands and took the podium for the two-hour debate shortly after 2 p.m.

PBS Chairman Wu Feng-shan, who moderated the debate, urged the two presidential candidates after the first debate to heed public opinion, meaning that they should "focus more on stating their own views instead of engaging in debates and should not dodge questions or give vague or ambivalent answers."

The two-hour debate was divided into two parts. In the first part, each candidate gave an eight-minute opening statement, followed by a question-and-answer session. After a 15-minute intermission, the candidates asked each other five questions before ending with an eight-minute conclusion.

The five questioners, each of whom asked two questions, came from the academic field and their questions covered the economy, national defense, cross-Taiwan Strait relations, politics, ethnic groups and women's policies.

The five questioners were Chang Wu-euh, director of the Graduate Institute of China Studies, Tamkang University; Cheng Duan-yau, a researcher at the Institute of International Relations, National Chengchi University; Huang Chang-ling, an associate professor of policial science at the National Taiwan University; Sun Ta-chuan, a former vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Indigenous Peoples's Affairs; and Chen Tain-jy, president of the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research.
PTS aired the debate live and cooperated with Chunghwa Telecom, which provided a live Web feed.
Four terrestrial TV stations and several cable news stations also broadcast the debate live, including Channel 17, which is a Hakka-language channel.

Observers had hoped that the live TV broadcast of the first-ever public debates between presidential candidates in more than five decades would help undecided voters to select a candidate for whom to vote.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT URGES PUBLIC TO VOTE IN REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu urged the public Saturday to vote in the March 20 referendum and claimed that "soft and gentle power" can dissolve violence and create harmony.
Lu made the remarks while attending the opening ceremony of the First Presidential Cup of the Tai Chi Chuan Championship held in Taipei County.

Emphasizing that the referendum is designed to show the public's desire for peace, the vice president claimed that it is not just a re-election ploy. The referendum will ask voters if Taiwan should build up its anti-missile defenses and if the government should set up a mechanism for cross-Taiwan Strait interaction.
Lu expressed hope that the people should become their own masters and understand that Taiwan is "a place full of love and peace."
Turning to what she called "soft national power, " Lu said that such power is based on love and peace -- just like Tai Chi Chuan's theory of using soft power against violence.
Soft national power is also aimed at promoting freedom, democracy, human rights and high-technology, she added without elaborating.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE PM PROPOSES DIALOGUE BETWEEN MID-EAST, ASIAN COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong said countries in the Middle East and Asia could begin dialogue to build links between their regions as early as next year.
Goh was speaking to Singapore journalists at a news conference at the end of visit to the Middle East.

Goh, who had proposed the dialogue to Egypt, Jordan and Bahrain, said Singapore could host the first round of talks and that it is time for the Middle East and Asia to start looking at each other and not only the West.
He said such dialogue could involve government leaders, academics and journalists, with topics ranging from culture to politics.
Goh said that while there has been contact between countries on a bilateral basis, it is quite minimal between regions.
Goh said that the proposed dialogue will not be a formal summit but will bring people together for a better understanding of both regions.
He added that his idea received strong support from the Middle Eastern leaders he met.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
[Turkish Daily News]: Iran votes; Urged by prayer leaders to "slap American in the face".
Iranians voted on Friday in a disputed parliamentary election set to tighten hard-liners grip on power and end President Mohammad Khatami's faltering reform drive.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE PM TO REMAIN IN CABINET AFTER STEPPING DOWN

TEXT.P: Singapore's Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong has confirmed he will stay on in the Cabinet after he steps down.
Goh was speaking to Singapore journalists at a news conference at the end of a visit to the Middle East.
However, he said it will up to the next prime minister to decide what his exact position will be.
Goh said he would wait for Singapore's first quarter economic results before he makes his decision as to when he will step down.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Make your windows safe, or risk a fine.
An alarming rise in incidents of windows crashing to the ground from high-rise flats in Singapore has spurred the authorities to change the law and make it a must for home owners to have their windows checked and made safe.
The Lianhe Zaobao: High rise flat owners in Singapore will need to pay to get their windows inspected
In Singapore, all high rise flat owners will have to have their windows inspected and certified by accredited contractors to make sure they are secure and won't fall off and injure passers-by.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Feb. 21, or the second day of the second month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:

1795: Holland surrenders Ceylon (now Sri Lanka) to Britain.
1858: Edwin Holmes of Boston installs the first electric burglar alarm.
1866: August von Wasserman, the German bacteriologist who invented a test to detect syphilis, is born.
1911: The United States and Japan sign a treaty limiting the flow of Japanese workers into the United States.
1916: Massed German artillery begin a furious bombardment of a crucial 13-kilometer sector of the French line at Verdun in the middle of the Western Front.
1917: Modern China's founding father Dr. Sun Yat-sen completes "The Fundamental Knowledge in Democracy," a book dealing with the procedures of parliamentary rule.
1944: General Hideki Tojo, prime minister of Japan, replaces Field Marshall Hajime Sugiyama as chief of the Imperial Army general staff.
1957: Israel defies a U.N. resolution and holds on to the Gaza Strip.
1963: Moscow warns Washington that an American attack on Cuba would mean world war.
1969: King Hassan of Morocco is granted a patent by the U.S. Patents Office for his device to monitor the function of the human heart.
1970: A cargo plane belonging to Taiwan's Far East Air Transport Corp. crashes on top of Fushoushan in suburban Taipei, killing its two pilots.
1972: U.S. President Richard Nixon visits mainland China.
1973: Forty-six manufacturers attend the second European Industrial Machinery Exhibition in Taipei.
1973: Lt. Gen. Robert R. Williams, acting commander of the U.S. Army, Pacific, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: Swaziland Vice Prime Minister Z.A. Khumalo arrives in Taipei for a week-long tour.
1974: The Buenos Aires University Club rugby team, champions of South America, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1975: The Taiwan Shipbuilding Corporation begins construction of a fifth 100,000-ton tanker for the Chinese Petroleum Corporation.
1986: Mainland Chinese air force pilot Chen Baozhong defects to South Korea in a MiG-19 fighter.
1986: Shigechiyo Izumi, the world's oldest man, dies in Japan at the age of 120.
1989: Czech writer Vaclav Havel is imprisoned for initiating a demonstration. Havel later became president of Czechoslovakia.
1990: Hun Sen, premier of Cambodia, holds peace talks with his rival, Prince Ranaridh Sihanouk, in Bangkok.

Confucius' lesson of the day: "Appearance of high spirits without integrity, of dullness without humility, of simplicity without honesty -- of such men I really do not know what to say."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER YU EXPLAINS ADVANTAGES OF HI-TECH IN TAIWAN TO MEETING IN U.S.

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun on Sunday encouraged individuals from around the world who are talented in high-technology to work in Taiwan and spoke of the advantages of investment in the island by hi-tech companies.

Yu spoke via a teleconference Sunday to participants at a meeting in Silicon Valley, California, organized to inform them of the Republic of China government's efforts to facilitate the upgrading of Taiwan's industry and its emphasis on technology in the economy.
Yu quoted a 2003 World Economic Forum (WEF) report as indicating that Taiwan's competitiveness in the scientific-technology sector ranked third worldwide and topped all Asian countries.

The ranking illustrates that despite diplomatic shortcomings, Taiwan has secured sustainable growth and has sharpened its international competitiveness, thanks to concerted efforts by both the government and the private sector, Yu said.

Yu said that facing increasing globalization and competitiveness from industrially advanced countries, Taiwan must first free itself from contract-manufacturing constraints and then secure positions in industries of creativity, cross-border business operations and marketing- and service-oriented businesses.

He added that Taiwan authorities have picked electronics, telecommunications, information services, bio-technology and nanotechnology as the five core industries to be developed in a new nationwide industrial development plan.

Under the plan, many new "star" industries are expected to become established in Taiwan, with leading foreign companies investing in Taiwan and making the island their research and development hub, Yu said.

Yu also said that production from the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, Taiwan's "Silicon Valley, " is expected to top NT$1 trillion (US$30 billion) this year, while the island's semiconductor manufacturing industry is also estimated to churn out products worth another NT$1 trillion.

Production from Taiwan's TFT LCD manufacturing companies as a whole is also estimated to exceed that of South Korea's output this year to make Taiwan the largest maker of TFT LCDs in the world, Yu noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DRAGNET CAPTURES 68 ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS IN LATEST OPERATION

TEXT.P: The third phase of an ongoing operation to crack down on people smuggling netted 68 illegal mainland Chinese, an Executive Yuan task force reported Sunday.
Fifteen Taiwan citizens who were helping the people traffickers, commonly referred to as "snakeheads," were also apprehended.

The latest "Snakehead Hungting" operation was conducted in a five-hour islandwide sweep that began at 10 p.m. Saturday by a joint force headed by the Executive Yuan to hunt down people smugglers and manned by agents from the Coast Guard Administration and the Criminal Investigation Bureau.
Since the operation began on Nov. 1, 2003, 873 illegal mainland Chinese and 236 Taiwan accomplices have been taken into custody, said a spokesman for the task force.

The spokesman said that in accordance with Article 79 of the Statute Governing Relations Between People from the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area passed by the Legislative Yuan last year, the masterminds of cross-strait human trafficking operations face jail terms of up to five years and fines of up to NT$10 million if convicted.
Owners of boats used for human trafficking could have their shipping rights suspended, licenses revoked or their vessels confiscated, the spokesman said.
He added that Taiwan people involved in human trafficking will be arrested and held according to relevant statutes.

Executive Yuan task force officials urged the general public to help law enforcement authorities thwart cross-strait human trafficking by informing police at 110 or by calling the Coast Guard Administration at 118 if they see any suspicious individuals.
