DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 80 PERCENT OF WHITE-COLLAR WORKERS SEEKING BETTER JOB: POLL

TEXT.P: More than 80 percent of Taiwan's white-collar workers hope to find a new job with better pay and a higher position, according to the results of a survey made public on Sunday by a executive research Web site.

The poll carried out by www. 1111. com. tw. shows that as many as 81.38 percent of domestic white-collar employees polled are considering seeking a new job with better salary and more promising career prospects. Some 80 percent of them hold middle-range posts at their companies, while 57.45 percent are ranking officials.
In addition to better pay, the respondents to the survey also cited personal career plans and looking for good employers as the main reasons, according to the poll results.
About 39 percent said that good luck is important in finding a new job, while professional skills as well as good manners and communication abilities come in second and third, respectively.
The survey also points out that younger people tend to change their jobs frequently because they think it is an indication of their stronger competitiveness in the workplace.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS FAVOR APPRECIATION OF NEW TAIWAN DOLLAR

TEXT.P: In the face of continued price hikes in staple commodities in the international market, Taiwan's central bank should consider allowing the local currency to appreciate rather than just interfering in its value, scholars said over the weekend.

Schive Chi and Yeh Wang-an, both well-known economists who also serve as advisory members to the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, opined that the Central Bank of China (CBC) should allow the new Taiwan dollar to gain in value adequately against the U. S. dollar to help local companies better run their businesses.

If the price of major import products, such as oil and steel, continues to rise, it will result in a greater difficulty for many Taiwan-based enterprises in their operations, as the pressure from the domestic market pushing up the price of imported goods has reduced while export prices of domestic products also have begun to fall, they said.

Under such circumstances, the CBC should permit the local currency to appreciate at an adequate time in order to help ease operation pressure on domestic business, they contended, adding that it is a better strategy than interfering in the market trying to stop its appreciation.

Rising import product prices and falling prices for locally-made goods is an indication that the domestic economy has not substantially improved, they explained, pointing to the fact that the local currency has effectively devalued compared to other currencies. A weak new Taiwan dollar has put many domestic companies in a very difficult business condition, they argued.

Meanwhile, sources of the domestic banking industry forecast that the new Taiwan dollar will drop to 33.3 against the U. S. dollar this week, mainly because of a devaluated Japanese yen. The Japanese yen lost in value against the U. S. dollar to stand at 109 by the end of last week, a level lower than the much anticipated range between 105 and 108.
The local currency ended at 33.22 against the greenback last Friday, a fall of NT$0.09 compared to its week-earlier level.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOT VOTING IN REFERENDUM IS A WIN FOR MAINLAND CHINA: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged his countrymen Sunday to be sure to vote in the country's first national referendum on March 20, saying that not doing so would be tantamount to handing a victory to mainland China.

Speaking to a group of his supporters in Taipei City, the president called on the people to show their resentment towards Beijing's military threat against Taiwan, claiming that the number of Beijing's missiles targeting Taiwan increases at the rate of one every six days.

He criticize his only rival in the presidential race, Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan, as "selfish" by branding the referendum illegal and vowing in Saturday's presidential debate that he would not participate in the referendum voting.
Chen said Lien has set a bad example for the country by taking the law into his own hands and determining on his own that the referendum is illegal.
The power to declare the referendum legal or not is held by the Council of Grand Justices, Chen said, adding that Lien is usurping the power of the Grand Justices by declaring the referendum illegal.

He also criticized Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou for trying to carry out the referendum in a way different from that stipulated by the Executive Yuan, saying the mayor is trying to create chaos within the government.

The Executive Yuan has ordered that voters be given three ballots at polling stations: one for the presidential election and two for each of the referendum questions. Voters are to then mark the ballots and place them in each of the three boxes marked accordingly.

Mayor Ma has decided that in Taipei, voters will only be given a ballot to vote for president upon entering polling stations. After voters have marked this ballot and deposited it in the box for presidential election ballots, the voters will then be able to pick up the other two ballots for the referendum.

"If the mayor can refuse to abide by the central government's decree on the excuse that it is not legal, the city's residents can follow suit and refuse to comply with the decisions of the mayor, " the president said.

Meanwhile, a campaign worker for Lien explained Sunday that the KMT presidential candidate was speaking of his personal view rather than the party's line when he said the previous day that he would not vote in the March 20 referendum, which he said is not based on law.

Huang Teh-fu, who is in charge of public opinion surveys for Lien's presidential campaign, said the official policy of the KMT and People First Party (PFP) , the KMT's ally in the presidential race, remains, " Vote for Lien in the presidential election, but decide for yourself whether to vote in the referendum."
"That means we respect the voters' decisions on the referendum rather than calling for them to follow Lien's example," Huang said.
Both Lien and his running mate, PFP Chairman James Soong, have said they would not vote in the referendum, saying that it is illegal.

However, their chief campaign manager, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, said he will vote in the referendum but Mayor Ma was unwilling to commit, saying that as the vote is supposed to be secret, he prefers to keep his cards close to his chest.
In Hsinchuang, Taipei County, Ma also said that his camp will not try to influence followers of the party to take a position on the referendum.

But he defended the way Taipei is to implement the referendum, saying that the method for voting was reached by a non-partisan subcommittee of the city's election commission, which is simpler and less likely to cause confusion than the way worked out by the Executive Yuan.
The election commission's greatest concern is that the referendum vote goes smoothly, not to have a referendum that produces an outcome favorable to any political party.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Aristide to Share Power in Haiti; International Talks Aim to Defuse Crisis.
Embattled Haitian president Jean-Bertrand Aristide agreed Saturday to share power with longtime political rivals as the U.S. government led talks to resolve an armed rebellion that has paralyzed the country and left dozens dead in the past 17 days.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIAYI BRIDGE BUILDER BUILDS 306TH BRIDGE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Jen Lien Bridge across a steep valley of Mt. Tuli in the southern county of Chiayi was inaugurated and officially opened to public traffic Sunday, marking the 306th bridge that the renowned Chiayi Philanthropy Group has built around Taiwan.

Volunteers of the Chiayi Philanthropy Group (CPG) -- founded by philanthropist and Ramon Magsaysay Award winner Ho Ming-teh -- spent three months and only about NT$1.8 million (US$55,900) to built the 35-meter steel wire bridge connecting the Chuchi rural township and Mt. Tuli, a scenic attraction but hard to reach without a bridge.

According to Liu Ning-ching, an abbot of a temple in Chuchi, the bridge was built in three months and is 2.5 meters wide. The single arch cable bridge has been overwhelmingly welcomed by mountain climbers who would otherwise walk nearly 10 hours to reach Mt. Dooli.
Tons of cable and cement were transported to the building site little by little by a makeshift mini cable car suspended on ropes and as were the bridge building volunteers, Liu said.

Huang Yi-rong, one of the construction supervisors, tripped and slipped down the valley one day and was critically injured. It took several hours for other volunteers to carry him to a Chuchi hospital, where he underwent a six-hour operation.
Huang, however, recovered in a miraculously speedy period, allowing him to return to the building location to work a week later, according to Liu.
CPG founder Ho Ming-teh, winner of the 1995 Ramon Magsaysay Award for community leadership, died at the age of 77 in early 1998 shortly after the Chinese New Year.

Ho received the Ramon Magsaysay Award for his selfless dedication to "improving rural Taiwan through good deeds and sturdy bridges, " making him the ninth Republic of China citizen to receive the prestigious award, named after a popular Philippine president who died in a plane crash in 1957.

Ho, a devout Buddhist, and his followers built their first bridge in June 1971 after a flood took the lives of two young brothers on their way to school. Since then, more than 200,000 supporters have contributed to the Ho-founded CPG, either financially or in the form of volunteer labor in the construction of the bridges.
Over the past 32 years, the group has built a total of 305 bridges in remote rural areas of central and southern Taiwan, with the just-completed Jen Lien Bridge being the 306th.
The bridges built by the group, ranging from six meters to 160 meters in length, have all stood firm since their completion, strong enough to brave the typhoons that sweep over Taiwan each year.

DOC.HEADLINE: 60 PERCENT OF TAIWAN BUSINESSES TO EXPAND OPERATIONS THIS YEAR: POLL

TEXT.P: Believing that Taiwan's business climate is picking up, some 60 percent of the companies in Taiwan will expand their operations this year, according to an opinion poll released Sunday.

A total of 60.93 percent of Taiwan's companies responding to the survey conducted by the 1111 Human Resource Bank said they will continue expanding their business operations and enlarging the number of people on the payroll.
Only about 10 percent of the companies surveyed said they will reduce the number of their personnel, the poll conducted between Jan. 30 and Feb. 15 found.
Meanwhile, a total 52.69 percent of the companies that responded said pay raises for every staff member is expected this year on the premise that the business environment is gaining momentum.

Of the companies surveyed, supermarket chain Carrefour, for example, has announced that it will need 450 more people this year to work at its stores islandwide, while hardware chain B&Q is planning to enlarge its staff by 5 percent to 10 percent this year.

Of the different areas in the business sector, computer and electronics companies and stocks and securities firms continue to top Taiwan companies seeking new employees, although many Taiwan computer and electronics companies have relocated part of their manufacturing operations to mainland China in recent years, according to Wu Jui-ying, a 1111 vice president and spokesperson.
The 1111 Human Resource Bank conducted the poll via Internet, fax and telephone interviews. It obtain valid responses from 300 companies.

In another poll conducted during the same period, the 1111 Human Resource Bank found that 37 percent of Taiwan's salaried workers succeeded in finding a new job and had began to work at a new company after the Chinese New Year holiday.
The poll, with 1,777 valid responses, found that job seekers spent an average of 1.6 months to successfully find new employment.

The poll also found that the number of job seekers was about twice that before Chinese New Year, while the number of vacancies that were made available by different companies also increased substantially since the end of January.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIWAN DOLLAR MAY FALL TO 33.3 AGAINST GREENBACK THIS WEEK

TEXT.P: The trend of the new Taiwan dollar toward appreciation against the U. S. dollar may suffer a short-term setback this week, prompted mainly by a depreciating Japanese yen, sources in the banking industry said Sunday.

The sources forecast that the new Taiwan dollar may continue to drop to 33.3 against the U.S dollar this week as a result of the Japanese yen's recent depreciation against the greenback. The Japanese yen lost in value against the U. S. dollar and stood at 109 as of last Friday, a level lower than the much-anticipated range between 105 and 108.
Fueled by pressure from a devalued Japanese yen, the local currency closed at 33.22 against the U. S. dollar last Friday, down by NT$0.09 from its week-earlier level of 33.13.
Moreover, the sources pointed out that the new Taiwan dollar will continue a depreciating trend this week because of a weaker Japanese yen and a sluggish market demand for the U. S. dollar.

Due to a huge influx of foreign capital and a robust anticipation that Asian currencies will pick up in value against the U. S. dollar, the new Taiwan dollar had experienced two rounds of noticeable appreciation against the U. S. currency following the Chinese New Year holiday season in late January.

Many local businesses have sold large amounts of U. S. dollars over the past few weeks in exchange for a rising new Taiwan dollar, with the daily trading volume amounting to over US$1 billion in the Taipei foreign exchange market.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST FREE TRADE PORT ZONE MAY BEGIN OPERATIONS IN SUMMER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first-ever free trade port zone is expected to begin operations this summer, according to the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

The Ministry of Transportation and Communications has conducted initial screening of the free trade port zone projects put forward by the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau and the Keelung Harbor Bureau, CEPD officials said Saturday, adding that they will submit the projects to the Executive Yuan on Feb. 25 and on March 1 for final approval.

The opening of such special zones in which products and capital are allowed to move freely will help boost Taiwan's bid to develop into a business operations center in the Asia-Pacific region and a global business management hub, the officials said.

For the time being, six economic processing zones located mainly in central and southern Taichung, Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties, as well as the Taichung Harbor Bureau, Hualien Harbor Bureau, Tainan city and county and the Industrial Development Bureau have applied to set up such free trade port zones in areas under their respective jurisdictions, the officials pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN AND LU MAKE PUBLIC DETAILS OF CAMPAIGN DONATIONS

TEXT.P: One day before a bill comes before the Legislative Yuan limiting when individuals running for office can receive donations, President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu released information Sunday on the amount and nature of the money so far donated to them for their re-election bid,
The campaign headquarters of the incumbent president and vice president announced that it has received 68,829 donations totaling NT$279.90 million (US$8.42 million) thus far.

Wu Nei-jen, the campaign manager for Chen and Lu said at a news conference that 105, or NT$15.25 million, has come from for-profit institutions; seven, or NT$1.71 million, from non-profit institutions; and NT$7.19 million from an unspecified political party.
The president and vice president had promised a private group pushing for a clean and fair campaign that they would make public the details of the donations they have received.
This information will be provided on the Web site of the campaign headquarters as agreed to by Chen and Lu to the private group.

Chen's rival in the presidential race, Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan, didn't followed suit Sunday, although Lien and his running mate, People First Party Chairman James Soong, had made a similar promise.
However, Chang Che-sheng, a KMT official in charge of raising funds for the campaign, told journalists that his party had raised about NT$200 million from some 30,000 donors by the end of last year.

The donations that the party received this year have yet to be determined, he said, but all of them have been recorded clearly and were made in accordance with regulations that no more than NT$3 million come from a single company and no more than NT$200,000 from a single person.

Chang said his party will not make public the list of its donors on its Web site out of concerns that the individuals could be harassed by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, which is in a tight race with the KMT for the presidency.

Meanwhile, the political parties at the Legislative Yuan are expected to endorse a political donations bill Monday. After negotiations, the parties all agreed that people campaigning for public office can receive donations only during the officially designated campaign period, according to a lawmaker from the People First Party (PFP).

At the insistence of the PFP, an article in the bill that would have allowed those running for public office to take in limited donations outside of the official campaigning period was tossed out, PFP Legislator Lee Yung-ping said.
With this thorny issue sorted out, Lee said, the bill might be enacted before the March 20 presidential election, unless other controversies crop up.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY

Confucius' lesson of the day: "In education, study always as if you have not yet reached your goal and as though apprehensive of losing it."

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL LAUREATE REAFFIRMS PROMISE TO WORK FOR CROSS-STRAIT PEACE

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh said Monday he would still be willing to head a panel to promote peaceful cross-Taiwan Strait interaction even if the opposition "pan-blue alliance" won the presidency in the upcoming election.
Lee, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, made the remarks at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Science, Technology and Information Committee.

During the session, Legislator Chiu Yung-jen of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) asked Lee whether he has accepted President Chen Shui-bian's invitation to serve as a co-convener of a special panel to push for the establishment of a viable mechanism for cross-strait peaceful interaction.

"Yes, I have accepted the president's invitation, " Lee said. "Nevertheless, I have also expressed my hope that this will not be used as a presidential campaign tool to be played up and that the special panel will not begin operations until after the March 20 presidential election. Otherwise, I think it might trigger extremely complicated effects."

At the same session, opposition People First Party (PFP) Legislator Pang Chien-kuo asked Lee whether he will still be willing to head a similar task force to boost cross-strait peaceful interaction if the "pan-blue alliance" ticket of Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong wins the election.
"I'll be willing to take up such a post if Lien invites me, " Lee said.
Asked whether he would come forward to endorse either of the two presidential tickets, Lee said he would be willing to reveal his choice if he is asked.
"But I have not yet made up my mind. I'm still studying the platforms and visions outlined by the two rival camps. When I come to a conclusion, I would be willing to express my opinion," Lee said.
Many observers said they believed that Lee's public support for Chen on the eve of the 2000 preisential election had contributed to Chen's upset win in that race with a narrow margin.
Last Thursday, President Chen said in a radio interview that if he is re-elected, he will immediately form a special panel to work for the establishment of a cross-strait interactive mechanism.

"And both Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh and a respected business executive have agreed to jointly head the special panel, " Chen said, adding that he would withhold the tycoon's name to save the tycoon any unnecessary trouble ahead of the hotly contested presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN HEADS TO OFFSHORE PENGHU TO WOO VOTERS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is scheduled to arrive on the island of Penghu, located some 72 nautical miles from the southern port city of Kaohsiung, at noon Monday to woo Penghu voters 26 days ahead of the March 20 presidential election.

Topping Chen's whirlwind itinerary in Penghu is a speech he is to deliver at the Penghu Cross-Sea Bridge at 12: 30 p.m. to appeal to Penghu voters to take part in the "one million hand-in-hand" activity slated to be held Feb. 28 islandwide. The activity is meant to symbolize determination and esprit de corps in protecting Taiwan through peace, according to Chen Kuang-fu, head of Chen's campaign headquarters in Penghu.

The "one million hand-in-hand" activity, seen by many as aimed at drumming up support for Chen in his bid for re-election, will take place on 2-28 Peace Memorial Day, with people from around the country joining hands to form a colossal human chain and shouting "Taiwan yes, China no! " at 2:28 p.m.
After Chen delivers his speech in Penghu, he is scheduled to pay his respects to the gods and goddesses at two local temples and ask for their blessing in his re-election bid.
Chen is also scheduled to visit the Department of Health-run Penghu Hospital to officially inaugurate a new building at the largest hospital in Penghu.
At around 8: 30 p.m., Chen is scheduled to attend a rally in Makung City, where some 10,000 of the president's supporters are expected to turn out for the gathering.
The president will fly back to Taipei Monday night, according to campaign organizers.

The Manila Bulletin: People assured of stable prices. The government assured yesterday the people that prices of basic goods will remain stable despite the trend of increasing commodity prices in the world market.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Bro. Eddie musters big force at Luneta. TENS of thousands gathered at Rizal Park in Manila Sunday for the proclamation rally of Bangon Pilipinas standard-bearer evangelist Eduardo "Bro. Eddie" Villanueva, organizers claimed. Police estimated the crowd at 2.8 million.

In Singapore, bird flu, foreign competition and flexi wages were some of the issues raised by residents of Tampines Changkat during Environment Minister Lim Swee Say's visit to their ward. While listening to their concerns, Mr Lim reassured residents that the new flexi-wage system is crucial in making wages more responsive to economic changes.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT ECONOMIC POLICY ADJUSTMENT TO FOCUS ON FINANCIAL SECTOR

TEXT.P: The adjustment of policies regarding cross-Taiwan Strait trade and economic relations will focus on the financial sector, the head of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Monday.

MAC Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said in a meeting with business leaders that the basic legal framework has been prepared for the adjustment after an amendment to the Statute Governing the Relations between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area cleared the legislature last year.
The MAC, Taiwan's top mainland policy planner, is presently elaborating relevant policies, which she said are expected to be made public in the near future.

The government has permitted direct cross-strait remittances, allowed offshore banking units to provide financial services to Taiwan businesses in mainland China and approved nine domestic banks to set up representative offices on the mainland, she noted, adding that the next step is to deal with upgrading the nine banks' representative offices to branch level.
The government will do its job in this regard after the March 20 presidential election, Tsai added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM DENIES TRYING TO LURE SEAN CONNERY WITH HIGH APPEARANCE FEE

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien denied Monday that his ministry tried to lure Scottish actor Sir Sean Connery to attend a local political activity organized to mark Feb. 28 Peace Day with a large appearance fee.
Answering an opposition lawmaker's question, Chien admitted that his ministry did approach the actor, well-known for his on-screen role as James Bond, over the possibility of him visiting Taiwan.

Noting the actor has expressed personal sympathy for President Chen Shui-bian, Chien said his ministry contacted Sir Sean through its offices in Los Angeles and London before the end of last year, in the hope that his appearance in Taiwan would boost the country's diplomacy. The ministry did not receive a reply.

He denied that his ministry offered Sir Sean a high appearance fee for his attendance at an activity organized by former President Lee Teng-hui and endorsed by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to mark the country's Feb. 28 Peace Day.

In the activity, participants will form a 480-kilometer chain winding the entire length of Taiwan. The organizers had claimed that Sir Sean would join them Feb. 28 but this was immediately denied by a spokesman for the actor.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO RETRY ENTERING WHO: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan will repeat its attempts to enter the World Health Organization (WHO) as an observer, an official from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Monday.

Tung Kuo-you, director of the International Organizations Department under the MOFA told the Legislative Yuan that Taiwan will apply for WHO observer status as a health entity rather than a country, given the fact that only a few WHO members recognize the island as a country.
MOFA will enlist the help of the country's legislature and private sector in its efforts, Tung said.

Tung said the MOFA's overseas offices are trying hard to win support from their host countries for Taiwan's WHO bid, on the grounds that it is unfair to exclude Taiwan from the world health body and is detrimental to the WHO's efforts to control disease around the world.

Taiwan has tried to secure access to the WHO since 1997 and made a strong case for its bid during the WHO's last annual meeting in May, 2003, thanks to the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome in Asia that drove home the fact that no country can be excluded in the world's fight against epidemics.

Many prominent WHO members expressed sympathy for Taiwan's bids at the time, but the World Health Assembly -- the WHO governing body -- turned down Taiwan's request because of Beijing's vociferous protests.

DOC.TEXT: The Japan Times: Ari- stide accepts plan backed by U.S. to share Haiti power. President Jean-Bertrand Aristide agteed to a U.S. backed peace plan to share power with political opponents,but his rivals resisted , saying he must step down for there to be peace in Haiti.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFULS RUNNING NECK-AND-NECK: POLL

TEXT.P: The two presidential hopefuls are in a neck-and-neck race, with the difference in their popularity rates less than 1 percent, according to the results of a poll released Monday by the Taiwan Thinktank.

The survey, conducted by Focus Survey Research and commissioned by Taiwan Thinktank, shows President Chen Shui-bian -- who is seeking re-election along with his running-mate, Vice President Annette Lu -- enjoying a popularity rating of 36.6 percent, only 0.6 percentage points behind the 37.2 percent obtained by the ticket formed by opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and his running-mate, People First Party Chairman James Soong.

In comparison with poll results released a week earlier, the popularity rating of the Chen-Lu ticket increased by 4.5 percentage points from 32.1 percent, while that of the Lien-Soong ticket also surged by 1.6 percentage points from 35.7 percent, with the percentage of undecided respondents down from 32.2 percent to 26.2 percent.
The survey, with a total of 1,047 valid samples, had an error margin of 2.99 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: At Least 8 Killed in Bombing Outside Iraqi Police Station.
The attack killed at least eight Iraqi officers just as Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld arrived in the country, according to a military spokeswoman.
The Wall Street Journal: Electronics Makers Play Defense.
Many consumer-electronics makers are maneuvering to make sure Microsoft doesn't dictate key technical standards for their industry. They are trying to dilute the software titan's power by making their products compatible with rival software.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST LADY INSISTS NO LAW-BREAKING IN STOCK TRADING

TEXT.P: First lady Wu Shu-chen said Monday that President Chen Shui-bian's public apology for her stock trading activities does not imply that she has broken any rules in conducting her transactions.

Speaking at a news conference to introduce a newly published picture book of her high-profile European tour last July that took her to Germany and the Holy See, Wu said she has honestly reported her stock trading records in accordance with regulations set by the watchdog Control Yuan.
"Anybody who scrutinizes my reports will see that I have never been involved in any insider trading, nor have I committed any irregularities in my stock trading activities," Wu said.
The wheelchair-bound first lady reportedly has taken up stock trading as a hobby. However, her trading has come under fire in recent weeks as the presidential race has hotted up.

During last Saturday's televised debate between Chen and opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan -- the sole challenger to his re-election bid -- Lien claimed that in the United States, the first lady's stock trading activities would be tantamount to political suicide. Lien said he had promised to put his family assets into a blind trust if he wins the presidency and that he wanted to know Chen's opinion about his wife's stock trading.

In response, Chen pointed out that he had already made a public pledge to put his family assets into trust after the March 20 presidential election and that his wife will take a break in her stock trading activities prior to the poll.

Chen further said that even though his wife has not committed any wrongdoing or insider trading, he agreed that such activities are inappropriate for her at this time. "And for this, I'm willing to apologize," Chen said in the live TV debate.
At Monday's news conference, Wu said Chen's apology was mainly aimed at stopping the controversy surrounding the issue.

"The president's apology should not be interpreted as implying that I have done anything illegal. And if I really had broken any rule, I would be willing to receive punishment in accordance with the law, " Wu said, adding that she would respect her husband's decision and stop trading in the run-up to the poll.

During the news conference, Wu also called Oscar-winning movie star Sean Connery her idol and said she felt sorry that the Scottish megastar will not be joining a human-chain rally in Taiwan this weekend in protest against mainland China's missile threat. Wu said she had been watching Sean Connery as James Bond since she was in elementary school.

Organizers of the peace protest claimed last week that Connery planned to attend the Feb. 28 event, but Connery's agent later said the actor had never planned to be part of the human-chain demonstration that's supposed to stretch the length of Taiwan -- more than 300 kilometers.
The Feb. 28 "one-million-persons-hand-in-hand" rally is supposed to urge mainland China to redeploy nearly 500 ballistic missiles pointed at Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Wu said she would be willing to visit the mainland in her capacity as the Republic of China first lady, "but only if Beijing were to recognize my capacity as the ROC's first lady, " Wu said.

Wu, who has been confined to a wheelchair since being run over by a truck in 1985, has conducted several high-profile overseas tours over the past four years, including visits to the United States, France, Germany, the Czech Republic and the Holy See.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESTRICTIONS EASED ON TOURISTS FROM MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese who do not live in mainland China will be allowed to tour Taiwan individually after a panel under the Executive Yuan decided Monday to abolish the requirement that such people arrive in and leave Taiwan in groups.
The panel made the decision after setting a goal of attracting 3.2 million foreign visitors -- including 200,000 mainlanders -- this year.
At present, only mainlanders living outside the mainland are allowed to tour Taiwan and only as part of a tour group. They are forbidden from moving around alone during their stay in the country.
About 170,000 overseas mainlanders visited Taiwan in 2002 for sightseeing, but the number plunged to 130,000 in 2003 mainly because of the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome in Taiwan.
The panel set up to boost local tourism decided to ease the requirements in the hope that the move will help boost the number of mainland visitors to the level of 200,000 this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO PROMOTE TALKS ON TAIWAN-SOUTH KOREA AIRLINKS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that he will continue to promote talks on the resumption of Taiwan-South Korea airlinks based on the principles of reciprocity and mutual benefit.
Receiving visiting Kyungnam University President Pak Chae Gyu of South Korea at the Presidential Office, Chen noted that Taiwan and South Korea maintain close trade and economic relations.

Two-way trade between the two countries amounted to US$13 billion last year, with a surplus of US$4 billion in favor of South Korea, Chen said, adding that South Korea is Taiwan's fifth-largest trading partner.

Given that commercial and tourist travel between Taiwan and South Korea is increasing, the present system of charter flights between the two countries is not the normal way to meet increasing flight service demands, Chen told his guest.
Air transport links between Taiwan and South Korea have been suspended since 1992, when Seoul switched its diplomatic ties from Taipei to Beijing.
During the meeting, Chen and Pak also exchanged views on the situation in the Taiwan Strait and the Korean peninsula. Pak is a former South Korean minister of unification.

Chen said that he has presented a proposal for establishing a framework for cross-strait peaceful and stable interaction after the March 20 presidential election, and he expressed hope that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can hold talks based on the principle of peace on four major issues -- the establishment of a negotiation mechanism, exchanges based on equality and reciprocity, the establishment of a political relationship and the prevention of military conflicts.
Pak should have a great deal of practical experience in dealing with North Korea, which is worthy of note by Taiwan, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC TO COUNT PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION BALLOTS BEFORE REFERENDUM VOTES

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) said Monday it will not begin to count the referendum ballots until after the outcome of the March 20 presidential election has been announced.

Fielding questions at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Interior Affairs Committee, CEC Chairman Huang Shih-cheng said the CEC has decided to complete vote-counting for the election before calculating the ballots cast for the two referendum questions.
Huang said the arrangement is designed to avoid unnecessary confusion and to speed up the presidential ballot-counting.

"We'll first focus on counting the election ballots. In the process, we'll sort out any presidential ballots mistakenly placed into referendum ballot boxes. By so doing, we believe we will be able to announce the election results by 8 p.m. on election day, " Huang told lawmakers.
In the 2000 presidential election, the CEC managed to announce the final result at 7:26 p.m. on election day.
This time around, voters will not only elect the president but will also cast two additional ballots on two referendum questions.
Huang said election workers at polling stations around the country will not begin to count referendum ballots until after the election outcome has been announced.

The two referendum questions are whether Taiwan should purchase more anti-missile batteries in the face of mainland China's intensified missile build-up against Taiwan and whether Taiwan should negotiate with Beijing a viable mechanism for peaceful interaction. The questions will be printed on two separate ballots.

DOC.HEADLINE: JANUARY UNEMPLOYMENT RATE DIPS TO TWO-AND-A-HALF-YEAR LOW

TEXT.P: The unemployment rate dipped to a two-and-a-half-year low of 4.53 percent in January, according to statistics compiled by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) under the Executive Yuan.

The rate is expected to decline to between 4.7 percent and 4.8 percent for the whole year in light of the fact that economic growth for 2004 is estimated at 4.74 percent, a DGBAS official said Monday.

If the Executive Yuan's ongoing program to create temporary jobs can be extended for another six months, the rate will be cut by another 0.1 percent to between 4.6 percent and 4.7 percent, or even 4.5 percent if economic growth is better than expected, the official said.
The NT$20 billion (US$601.59 million) job-creation program will expire at the end of the June and the Council of Labor Affairs is seeking an extra NT$7 billion or NT$8 billion to extend the program.

With an unemployment rate of 4.53 percent, the official said, Taiwan fares better than Hong Kong, the United States and Japan which have jobless rates of 7.3 percent, 4.5 percent and 4.9 percent, respectively, but fares worse than South Korea and Britain, whose unemployment rates stand at 3.1 percent.
For 2003, the economic grew by 3.24 percent and the unemployment rate stood at 4.99 percent, according to the official.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY, SECURITY UNITS HEIGHTEN ALERT AHEAD OF ELECTION

TEXT.P: Both the Ministry of National Defense (MND) and the National Security Bureau (NSB) said Monday they have heightened their levels of alert in order to ensure that the March 20 presidential election and the nation's first-ever referendum will be held smoothly.
The MND and the NSB made the remarks in separate reports delivered at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Legal Affairs Committee.

The MND said in its report that it has designated election day as a period for special combat preparedness, while the NSB said it has joined forces with other intelligence agencies to form a special task force to collect foreign comments on the election and referendum, monitor interference by mainland China with electoral affairs and collect information about any event that might affect the security of the presidential and vice presidential candidates.
In the run-up to the election, the MND said, military units will keep close watch on the mainland's military activities, particularly movements of its missile and submarine forces.
According to the MND report, the military has drawn up various response options and has conducted training exercises to cope with possible "abnormal" mainland military actions.

The NSB said it has also prepared a package of crisis management programs to deal with any emergencies, including electoral affairs disputes, massive protests, terrorist attacks, threats to candidates' personal safety, and mainland saber-rattling.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST LADY MIGHT VISIT MAINLAND CHINA IF RECOGNIZED BY BEIJING

TEXT.P: First lady Wu Shu-chen said Monday that if Beijing were to recognize her position as the Republic of China's first lady, she would consider visiting mainland China.
Wu made the remarks at the Presidential Office during the launch of an illustrated book that chronicles her high-profile European visit which took her to Germany and the Holy See last July.
Joseph Wu, vice secretary-general to President Chen Shui-bian, Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Kao Ying-mau and National Palace Museum Director Tu Cheng-sheng also attended the ceremony.
Asked by the media if she is willing to help Chen to visit the mainland, she said that if the mainland recognizes her as the first lady, then that could be a possibility.
"If Taiwan is denigrated into the position of a local government under Beijing, I would not accept the situation," she said.
Wu noted Taiwan's difficult diplomatic plight and said that in her first lady position, her job is to serve the Taiwan people.
Wu said that during her several overseas visits, she realized that Taiwan's diplomatic work could be better.
"One must have confidence in oneself, " Wu said, adding that Taiwan should not be described as small since compared with some other countries, Taiwan is not so small.
"Both the education level of the people and the nation's per capita income are at the global forefront, " Wu said, adding that one must respect oneself if one wants respect from others.
"Taiwan must stand up for itself, otherwise no-one else will help, even if they want to," she said.

Wu, who has been confined to a wheelchair since being run over by a truck in 1985, added that if diplomacy were not a consideration, she would most like to visit Japan to see the cherry blossoms, as it is a short journey.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOB-CREATION PROJECT MAY BE EXTENDED UNTIL END OF YEAR

TEXT.P: The government is considering extending its job-creation program for another six months to the end of the year, Liu San-chi, director-general of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, said Monday.
Liu made the remarks while fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan concerning unemployment.

Liu said that the jobless rate was 4.99 percent last year, and it is estimated that it will drop to 4.5 percent at best this year. With the changing industrial structure and businesses becoming larger, he said that it may be impossible to cut the employment rate to below 4.5 percent.
As the job-creation project is only scheduled to run until June, legislators also expressed concern that the jobless rate could rise again after the project stops.

Liu said that the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) is planning to extend the project to the end of the year, saying that this will incur an additional cost of NT$7 billion to NT$8 billion (US$211.48 million to US$241.69 million) to the government, which he said could be financed from the employment stabilization fund, and that financing will not be a problem.
CLA officials also said that the council is now mapping out related measures to help those who are jobless for an extended period.
They said that they will initially use NT$400 million to help the long-term jobless by subsidizing employers so that they can learn some working skills during a specific period of time.
They stressed that the measure aims to provide substantive assistance to the jobless for their future employment, and not as a subsidy " for a post," or to reduce the labor cost of the employers.
They also said that when providing subsidies to employers, it will take into consideration the "training and substantive assistance extended to the hired laborers."

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADE DEVELOPMENT COUNCIL INKS COOPERATION PACT WITH PANAMA

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) concluded a cooperation pact with Panama Monday with the purpose of stepping up commercial exchanges.

The pact was signed in Taipei by TAITRA Chairman Hsu Chih-jen and visiting Panama Minister of Commerce and Industry Joaquin Jacome, and witnessed by visiting Panama First Vice President Arturo Vallarino.
This is the second accord of its kind after Panama signed a cooperation pact with TAITRA's forerunner the China External Trade Development Council in 2002.
Panama is an important trading partner for Taiwan in Central America and the first country that has signed a free trade agreement with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: REAL NUMBER OF SEXUAL ABUSE CASES INVOLVING FOREIGN LABORERS ELUSIVE

TEXT.P: A center for the prevention of domestic violence and sexual abuse in Taipei said Monday that it received nine reports of sexual abuse concerning foreign laborers last year, but admitted that many cases may have gone unreported.
Center officials made the remarks after a private women's group claimed that 16 percent of all Taipei's foreign laborers had been sexually abused.

The officials said that among the nine reported cases concerning foreign laborers, three were forced molestations and six were forced intercourse. All of the cases have been handled according to the law, the officials said.
The claim of 16 percent made by the Taipei Association for the Promotion of Women's Rights would need to be supported with proof before such a figure could be taken as fact, officials said.

The officials said, "There is indeed a high percentage of sexual abuse cases that go unreported, " and that if a private group learns of a foreign labor who has been sexually abused, it must encourage the victim to get assistance from the center or report the incident to the police.

They said that aid services for foreigners are the same as those for local woman and provide help based on the needs of the individuals. Victims will receive 24-hour companionship for the physical examination, questioning and appearance in court, legal assistance, physiological counseling, emotional support, economic assistance and shelter.

The official spoke amid a recent controversy over a former legislator who allegedly sexually abused his Filipina maid. The case is still unresolved as the former lawmaker has denied the allegation while the maid has returned to the Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTION COMMISSION MAY HAVE TO DRAW LOTS FOR DEBATE PARTICIPANTS

TEXT.P: There are far too many civic groups wishing to debate against the upcoming referendum in a series of public, government-sponsored meetings, and unless the groups can decide among themselves who will attend the debates, participants will have to be selected by drawing lots, the Central Election Commission (CEC) said Monday.

CEC officials said that they will invite the representatives of all civic groups to meet Tuesday to try and work out a solution. If a compromise cannot be reached, then a drawing of lots will be necessary to decide who will be able to face off with government representatives.

The officials said, "We are racing against time to screen the signatures of the civic groups who wish to participate in the upcoming debates." At least 1,547 signatures are needed for a non-political group to qualify to take part in the debates. Officials are faced with the daunting task of trying to verify the endorsement signatures of 48 groups.

Among the 48 groups, 25 groups have registered to challenge the government's views on the first question concerning the enhancing of the nation's anti-missile defense capability in the face of the missile threat of mainland China, and 23 groups have registered to debate on the second question concerning the reopening of cross-strait talks to establish a peace and stability framework between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
All 23 groups for the second question have also registered to debate the first question.

As there will be only 10 public debates, five for each of the two questions, with one representative from the "affirmative" and "negative" sides attending each debate, coordination is necessary before drawing lots to decide who will participate in the debates.
Those who qualify will be announced Wednesday, the officials said.
The public debates on the March 20 referendum, held in tandem with the presidential election, will start Feb. 29 and run for three consecutive Sundays.
There will be four debates on Feb. 29 and March 7 and two debates March 14.
Meanwhile, one of the civic groups demanded Monday that the CEC protect those who have different viewpoints and give them a chance to take part in the debate.

Kao Cheng-yen, acting convener of the small Green Party and one of the representatives who passed the screening to be eligible, said, "If the CEC insists on drawing lots to decide who can debate, then the Green Party will not rule out the possibility of mobilizing people to protest."

Kao was most discontent that TV talk show personality Jaw Shau-kong, chairman of the radio station UFO Network; independent Legislator Sisy Chen; and writer Li Ao, have submitted 21 groups so that they could have a better chance in the draw if it comes to that. Jaw's group was the first to express the desire to serve on the "nay" side. He has said that his group wants to show that the two questions are absurd and that President Chen Shui-bian has illegally called the referendum.
"Jaw has dominated the media, does he also want to dominate the speech forum?" Kao asked.
Kao said that he has asked the CEC to give priority to those groups who have different views.
He also disputed Jaw's allegation that "proxy" negative side representatives may come forward to reduce the chances of his group being selected, saying, "We are the genuine nay side."

Kao said that those who are against the referendum have no right to serve as the "opposition" side, saying that his group will only question the content and reasons of the referendum questions, and will not question "the legality of the referendum."

A total of US$812 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$33.450 and dipped to a low of NT$33.281 during the session.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH-SPEED RAIL TO REDUCE AIR, NORMAL RAIL PASSENGERS BY 60,000 DAILY

TEXT.P: After the high-speed railway begins operations in October 2005, the number of passengers traveling by air or normal rail may drop by more than 60,000 per day, Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san said Monday.

Lin made the remarks at the Transportation Committee at the Legislative Yuan on the impact of the first high-speed railway connecting Taipei and Kaohsiung in 90 minutes on regular railway and air transportation services.

Lin said that it is expected that around 149,000 people daily will make use of the 345-kilometer high-speed railway and that 17,000 of these will be passengers who now travel by air between southern and northern Taiwan and 50,000 passengers who now travel by regular rail.

"The government and the operators have to cooperate with each other, " he said, adding that, "Air carriers and the Taiwan Railway Administration must engage in growth management on the one hand and transformation on the other to face the new competition."

He said that rail transportation in major stops in western Taiwan will suffer most from competition from the high-speed rail. It is estimated that major rail stops will lose between 70 percent and 80 percent of their current passengers, while minor rail stops will lose between 5 percent and 40 percent of regular passengers.

As to how to handle the situation, he said that rail transportation in western Taiwan could make adjustments and focus on mid- and short-distance travel and make long-haul transportation secondary. While in eastern Taiwan, rail transport could focus on mid- and long-distance transportation and make short-haul transportation secondary.

Furthermore, the Taiwan Rail Administration could add commuter stations and electric cars along the rail lines of major cities, so that Taiwan Rail could double as a rapid transport operator in metropolises.

Lin also said that air transportation in western Taiwan could be cut by between 50 percent and 70 percent, and his ministry will suggest that air carriers adjust their flight routes to shit focus to eastern Taiwan or outlying islands.

The ministry will also suggest that air carriers promote international charter services and cooperate with other international carriers so that the remaining fleet can be rented overseas and their operations ensured.
The ministry will also coordinate with air carriers to share limited air resources and reduce operating costs in the hope that air carriers can expand through mergers.
Meanwhile, Legislator Lee Hung-chun of the opposition People First Party questioned the future operations of the high-speed rail amid the higher-than-estimated expenditure.

To this, N. H. Ho, director-general of the Bureau of Taiwan High Speed Rail under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, said that it is estimated that the construction of the high-speed rail will be NT$50 billion (US$1.61 billion) more than originally estimated, which he said was reasonable considering the fact that it is a long-term, major construction project.
Ho noted that the construction work of the high-speed rail is 98 percent complete, and the cost is NT$22.5 billion more than the original calculation.
It is estimated that after electrical engineering and other works are completed, the total cost will be NT$513.3 billion. The overruns will be financed by the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp.
Lee questioned the increased budget, which he said increased operational risks because of insufficient government management.

Ho explained that the increase is mainly due to the new Taiwan dollar exchange rate. When the construction contract was signed, the exchange rates between the new Taiwan dollar and the U.S. dollar was 28: 1; now it has risen to over 33: 1. A station that was constructed above ground instead of underground as originally planned also added costs.
"As the high-speed rail system is a long-term, major construction project, the increase of its budget by 10 percent is quite reasonable," he said.

The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Monday are as follows:

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stocks futures market were higher on Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for March moved up 7 points to close at 6,703, with 28,061 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for April rose 11 points to finish at 6,711, with 135 contract transactions, while June futures increased 30 points to close at 6,795, with 30 contracts traded.
September futures gained 9 points to finish at 6,740, with 3 contract transactions, while December futures moved up 5 points to close at 6,740, with only one contract traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,696 for March, 6,700 for April, 6,725 for June, 6,731 for September, and 6,735 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
March TE futures decreased 1 point to finish at 273, with 10,239 contract transactions, while April TE futures lost 1.25 points to close at 274, with 71 contracts traded.
June TE futures fell 2.15 points to finish at 274, with 5 contract transactions, while September TE futures moved up 0.6 points to close at 274, with 2 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
March TF futures gained 7.8 points to finish at 1,061.4, with 11,290 contract transactions, while April TF futures rose 8 points to close at 1,061, with 26 contracts traded.
June TF futures decreased 7.4 points to finish at 1,049, with 5 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN MEETS WITH PANAMANIAN 1ST VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday he hopes that commercial exchanges between the Republic of China and Panama can grow substantially after their bilateral free trade agreement took effect at the beginning of this year.

Chen made the comments while meeting with Panamanian First Vice President Arturo Vallarino who arrived in Taipei Sunday at the head of a large commerce and industry delegation for a six-day official visit.
"We welcome your visit, " Chen told his guests. "I believe your visit will contribute to the promotion of trade and economic cooperation between our two countries."
Chen said he exchanged the instruments of ratification of the ROC-Panama free trade agreement with Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso during his state visit to Panama last November.

"Now that the agreement is in effect, I hope the provisions of the pact can be fully substantiated to facilitate bilateral trade, investment and technological cooperation for the mutual benefit of both sides," Chen said.
For his part, Vallarino said he will take advantage of his current visit to help lay an even more solid foundation for future Taiwan-Panamanian commercial exchanges and economic cooperation.
Also present at the meeting were ROC Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Lung-yuan and Panamanian Ambassador to the ROC Jose Antonio Dominguez.

During his visit, Vallarino will meet with senior ROC officials and business leaders to explore possible cooperative projects in various fields. Vallarino is being accompanied by more than 50 Panamanian officials and senior industry executives on his current visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and then fluctuated on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 0.35 points to close at 6,665.89.
The bourse opened at 6,686.67 and fluctuated between 6,695.45 and 6,607.36 during trading.

A total of 7.13 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$154.42 billion (US$4.64 billion) . a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 8 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$174.54 billion (US$5.26 billion).

Half of the eight major stock categories posted gains, with pulp and paper issues moving up the most at 4.6 percent, followed by construction stocks at 1.9 percent, bank and insurance shares at 0.6 percent, and cement stocks at 0.5 percent.

The other major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff shares moving down the most at 2 percent, followed by textile issues at 0.9 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 0.7 percent, and electrical shares at 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 440 to 388, with 138 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENGHU COAST GUARD SEIZES SMUGGLED MAINLAND RICE

TEXT.P: Coast guard officers seized a small haul of rice being smuggled from mainland China aboard a Penghu fishing boat late Sunday night, officials from the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) southern Taiwan operations reported Monday.

During an anti-smuggling operation amid the threat of avian flu, members of the CGA 72 Squadron searched the Penghu-registered "Ho-Man-Sheng" at around 10: 45 p.m. as the vessel was preparing to dock at Waian fishing port to the west of Makung, the capital of Penghu County. Penghu is located some 72 nautical miles off the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung.
The coast guard officers discovered a total of 210 kilograms of rice contained in nine sacks hidden in the cabin of the fishing boat.

The skipper of the "Ho-Man-Sheng, " surnamed Tseng, said he and his two crew members, surnamed Hsu and Lu, bought the rice from an unnamed mainland fishing boat in the Taiwan Strait earlier Sunday for "private household consumption."
The three men were brought in for further questioning, while the "Ho-Man-Sheng" was temporarily held at the Waian fishing port.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Feb. 23, or the fourth day of the second month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1743: Meyer Rothschild, a German banker who founded a bank at
Frankfurt am Main, is born. His sons, most notably Salomon and Nathan Meyer, established branches of the bank throughout Europe.
1792: Sir Joshua Reynold, British painter and first president of
the Royal Academy, dies at the age of 69. He is considered one of the most important figures in the history of English painting.
1836: The siege of the Alamo begins in San Antonio, Texas. The siege ended March 6 with all the Texans killed by Mexican troops.
1848: John Quincy Adams, the sixth president of the United
States, who helped formulate the Monroe Doctrine, dies at the age of 81.
1863: British explorers John Speke and J.A. Grant announce that they have "discovered" Lake Victoria to be the source of the Nile.
1898: Emile Zola, the French writer and critic who was a leading
proponent of naturalism in fiction, is imprisoned for the publication of his letter "J'accuse, " which accused the French government of anti-Semistism and of wrongly imprisoning Captain Alfred Dreyfus.
1905: Paul P. Harris, a lawyer in Chicago, establishes Rotary International. There are now about 24,500 Rotary clubs in 167 countries, with about 1.1 million members.
1906: Johann Hoch is imprisoned in Chicago for murdering six of
his 13 wives.
1924: Thomas Woodrow Wilson, the 28th president of the United
States and the winner of the 1919 Nobel Peace Prize, dies at the age of 68. His administration was marked by World War I and the introduction of prohibition.
1933: Japanese forces occupy Chinese territory north of the Great
Wall of China.
1942: Australia, Britain, New Zealand and the United States sign
the Master Mutual Aid Agreement.
1942: A Japanese submarine shells an oil refinery near Santa
Barbara, California.
1944: Joseph Stalin dissolves the Chechen republic and forces 1
million Chechens into exile, accusing them of collaboration with Nazi Germany.
1945: U.S. Marines plant the Stars and Stripes on Mount Suribachi of Iwo Jima, a strategic island 750 miles from Tokyo, after 74 days of bombardment and four days of a bitter ground battle.
1955: The first meeting of the Southeast Asian Treaty
Organization (SEATO) is held in Bangkok, Thailand.
1957: Republic of China Major-General Chiang Wei-kuo weds Helene B. Chiu in Tokyo, Japan.
1958: Taiwan's first Cobalt 60 medical instrument for treating
cancer arrives in Keelung from the United States.
1960: The ROC establishes diplomatic relations with Cameroon.
1969: Chang Chun-li, chairman of the China Democratic Socialist
Party, dies in San Francisco at the age of 83.
1970: British Guinea ends its association with Britain and sets
up the Republic of Guyana.
1976: The Association of East Asian Relations and Japan's
Interchange Association open a two-day economic and trade conference.
1990: Prince Sihanouk returns to Cambodia after 11 years in
exile.
1991: The National Unification Council holds its fifth meeting
and passes the Guidelines for National Unification, which are now the highest directives governing the ROC's mainland policy. Its long-term goal is to establish a democratic, free and equitably prosperous China.
1991: Thailand's Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhaven is arrested
after the armed forces seize power in a bloodless coup.
1995: U.S. President Bill Clinton voices support for a united Canada in a speech to Canada's parliament.
1997: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes an amendment to Article 4
of the February 28 Incident Disposition and Compensation Act, stipulating that February 28, named "Peace Memorial Day," be deemed a national holiday.
2000: The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang
adopts a proposal that Adolfo Sun should succeed Kuo Kang to become the ROC's ambassador to the Dominican Republic.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "How toweringly high and surpassingly great in moral grandeur was the way by which the ancient Emperors Shun and Yu came to the government of the Empire, and yet they themselves were unconscious of it."

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO DRUG TRAFFICKERS NABBED AT KAOHSIUNG AIRPORT

TEXT.P: Two men were arrested at Kaohsiung International Airport in southern Taiwan Tuesday for attempting to smuggle heroin into the country from Cambodia.
The Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) said the two men, identified as Cheng Chi-shuan, 54, and Kang Yo-chih, 41, concealed the 700 grams of heroin in locally produced Long Life cigarette cartons.
This marked the first time that the CIB has ever uncovered contraband drugs hidden in Long Life cigarette packs, an investigator said.

According to initial investigations, the two traffickers bought the Long Life cigarettes at the airport's duty-free shop when they left for Cambodia Feb. 16. Before their return, they concealed the high-grade heroin in four Long Life cigarette cartons.
The CIB official said they believe there is a drug ring involved behind the scenes. "We are carrying out investigations to find the ringleader and other members," he added.

According to the official, the CIB has been tipped off that some drug traffickers are trying to take advantage of the current presidential campaign period to intensify their smuggling operations as police are busy with maintaining domestic law and order and preventing entry of illegal mainland Chinese immigrants ahead of the March 20 election.
"In fact, the CIB will not relax its vigilance against drug trafficking despite its heavy pre-election work load, " the official said.
