DOC.HEADLINE: BIGGER VENUE TO BE BUILT FOR ASIAN AEROSPACE

TEXT.P: Singapore Deputy Prime Minister Tony Tan announced Monday night that the government has decided to build a larger, better-equipped exhibition center in Changi North.

Tan, who opened the Asian AEROSPACE 2004, said the air show is getting a new home in 2008. In four years' time, a piece of barren land will be transformed into a new venue to house the exhibition center for Singapore's premier air show.

The site of the proposed venue is three kilometers from the current Changi Exhibition Centre and opposite Changi Airport's runway. The Changi Exhibition Centre will host its last Asian Aerospace in 2006.
Tan said the new venue will have the most modern facilities available for exhibitors to show off their hardware and services.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOOKIE NABBED FOR TAKING ON-LINE WAGERS ON PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: A bookmaker and his wife were nabbed Tuesday in Hsinchuang, Taipei County, for taking on-line wagers on the March 20 presidential election, according to police.
In the first crackdown of this type, police said the man, identified only by his surname of Pan, his wife and a technician were arrested for running the on-line business.
Police said Pan set up the Web site www.votelotto.com to solicit bets on the outcome of the election.
It was unclear how many bets they had taken or what odds they were offering, according to police.
Betting, like other forms of gambling, is illegal in Taiwan, and betting on elections is especially rare.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEADING ELECTION RACE: DPP OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is running ahead his sole challenger in the March 20 presidential election -- opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan -- in his bid for re-election, an official of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) claimed Tuesday.

Chen Chun-lin, director of the DPP's Public Opinion Survey Center, said in a press conference held after the party's weekly Central Executive Committee meeting that Chen is leading Lien by a narrow margin, according to the results of two recent polls conducted by his party.

The ticket of Chen and his running mate -- Vice President Annette Lu -- obtained a popularity rating of 38.1 percent against 36.4 percent for the ticket formed by Lien and his running mate -- People First Party Chairman James Soong -- in a survey conducted Feb. 20, Chen Chun-lin said, adding that the poll, with 1,169 valid samples, had a margin of error of 2.9 percent.

Another poll carried out Feb. 21 with 1,293 valid samples showed that the Chen-Lu ticket enjoyed a popularity rating of 38.9 percent against 37.5 percent for the Lien-Soong ticket, Chen Chun-lin continued, noting that the survey had an error margin of 2.8 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONVENERS OF LEGISLATIVE CONSTITUTION-AMENDING COMMITTEE TO MEET

TEXT.P: Eleven conveners of the Constitution-amending Committee in the Legislative Yuan are scheduled to meet Wednesday to set in motion reforms of the Legislative Yuan.

Legislator Ker Chien-ming, the whip for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) caucus at the legislature, said Tuesday that his party is pushing for the downsizing of the Legislative Yuan by decreasing its 225 seats by half.

However, whether this can be done, preferably before the March 20 presidential election, depends on the cooperation of the two major opposition parties -- the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP), Ker added.
Noting that both the KMT and the PFP have agreed that the number of lawmakers should be decreased, Ker urged the two opposition parties to follow through on their words.
However, KMT Lawmaker Huang Teh-fu said the DPP's call for a quick passage of a constitutional amendment does not mean it is any more enthusiastic about parliamentary reform than the KMT.

Legislator Hsu Yuan-kuo, a PFP convener on the Constitution-amending Committee was also reserved about the DPP's call for the passage of a constitutional amendment before March 20, saying it would be too hasty to address such a complicated issue in such a short time, in light of the many differences between the ruling and opposition parties on the issue.
"Pass (a bill) in haste, repent at leisure." Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR MISSIONS FROM NORTH AMERICA TO VISIT TAIWAN IN MARCH: MOFA

TEXT.P: Four missions from North America will visit Taiwan in March, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday.
Victor Chin, director-general of the MOFA's North American Affairs Department, said that Mayor Donald Woolcott of Oxford County, Canada, will visit Taiwan at the head of a delegation March 12-19.
The main purpose of the visit is to conduct cultural exchanges with Tamshui township in northern Taipei County, which has sisterhood ties with Oxford County, Chin noted.

Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee of the United States will head a 15-member trade mission to Taiwan March 13-16, Chin went on, adding that the deputy governor of North Dakota will visit Taiwan at the head of an 18-member delegation from March 20-25.
The fourth mission to visit in March will be a 10-member delegation organized by the World Affairs Council of Houston, but its itinerary has not yet been fixed, Chin continued.
No U.S. congressmen have confirmed that they will visit Taiwan in March to witness the country's March 20 presidential election, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AGRICULTURAL MISSION FAMILIES EVACUATED FROM HAITI

TEXT.P: The families of Taiwan agricultural mission workers based in Haiti will be evacuated in stages to neighboring Dominican Republic starting from Wednesday, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday.
Javier Ho, director-general of the MOFA's Central and South American Affairs, made the announcement at a news briefing.

According to Ho, the families will be evacuated in line with a contingency plan worked out late last week by the Republic of China Embassy in Haiti and the ministry in response to recent riots in the Caribbean nation.

No Taiwan agricultural technicians remain in northern Haiti, where about 300 rebel militants are struggling to topple the Haitian government, Ho said. He pointed out, however, that some of them are still scattered throughout central regions and stressed that they are allowed to leave at any time should the local situation deteriorate.
Ho also said that Haiti's riots are not expected to affect its relations with Taiwan and that the MOFA's contingency plan has taken into account the worst-case scenario in Haiti.

There are about 40 ROC nationals in Haiti, including a very small number of overseas Chinese and families of ROC outposts stationed there, Ho said, adding that the situation in Port-au-Prince, Haiti's capital, remained calm.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-DEVELOPED HYBRID CAR UNVEILED

TEXT.P: The government-financed Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, unveiled Tuesday a hybrid car powered by an internal combustion engine and an electric motor.

Tsai Hsin-yuan, director of the Mechanical Engineering Department of the ITRI, said the vehicle thrusts the country to the forefront of worldwide efforts to come up with more fuel-efficient and cleaner vehicles.

The vehicle, which runs on an energy-efficient mini-engine developed by the ITRI Mechanical Engineering Department, can reach a maximum speed of 100 kilometers per hour despite its relative small torque, and can run for 25 kilometers on one liter of gasoline, making it much more efficient than most motorcycles on the streets, said Tsai.

Although the car still depends heavily on fuel, especially when running at high speed, it turns waste energy produced by the internal combustion engine into electricity that is stored in a battery, which powers the vehicle when it is moving at low speed.
The battery can power the vehicle for 80,000 kilometers on a single charge, said Tsai.
The advantages of the vehicle are its low emission and fuel economy. It consumes only about 60 percent of the fuel of a conventional car of the same size.
Since the battery is recharged automatically when the car is running at high speed, the range of the car is greater than other electric vehicles, he said.
Tsai predicted that hybrid vehicles will play a major role in short-distance travel within and between cities and that Taiwan will eventually need some 400,000 such cars a year.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING INTENDS TO CHANGE CROSS-STRAIT STATUS QUO: JAPANESE LAWMAKER
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 24 (CNA) (By Huang Chin-chin & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: A Japanese lawmaker accused Beijing Tuesday of intending to change the status quo in the Taiwan Strait through military intimidation.

Questioning the Japanese government's expression of concern over Taiwan's March 20 referendum, Hirosato Nakatsugawa, a member of the Japanese Diet, noted at the parliament's budget committee that it is Beijing that has deployed missiles targeting Taiwan with the intention of changing the cross-strait status quo.

Katsuhisa Uchida, director of the Taipei Office of Japan's Interchange Association -- Japan's de facto ambassador to Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic relations between the two countries -- expressed Japan's concern over Taiwan's referendum in a Dec. 29 meeting with Chiou I-jen, secretary-general of the Presidential Office.
Nakatsugawa urged the Japanese government to let the people of Taiwan decide their own internal affairs.

Fielding questions raised by Nakatsugawa, Japanese Minister of Foreign Affairs Yoriko Kawaguchi said that Japan opposes any use of force by Beijing against Taiwan and hopes that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will settle their disputes through peaceful talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: JANUARY EXPORT ORDER VALUE HITS HISTORIC MONTHLY HIGH

TEXT.P: The value of export orders received by Taiwan companies in January hit an all-time monthly high of US$13.94 billion, up by US$910 million, or an annual 7.05 percent growth rate, compared to the year-earlier level, according to statistics released by the government Tuesday.

The tallies, announced by the Statistics Department under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , show that the order value for electronic products grew by US$680 million year-on-year last month, representing an annual increase rate of 28.72 percent.

The combined value of orders for precision instruments, fueled by robust demand for digital cameras and LCDs (liquid crystal displays), rose by US$230 million, reflecting a remarkable 80.14 percent growth rate, while foreign orders placed with Taiwan-based makers of telecommunications devices and notebook computers picked up by US$210 million in value, or an annual growth rate of 7.98 percent.
In terms of the origin of the foreign orders, the United States, Hong Kong, Japan and European countries were the prime buyers of Taiwan-made hi-tech goods in January, the statistics indicate.

However, purchase value by the United States posted an annual growth rate of 0.24 percent, or some US$9 million. At the same time, orders from Hong Kong increased by US$250 million in value, up by 9.23 percent from the previous-year level, while Japanese buyers also bought more US$90 million-worth of locally manufactured electronics goods.
Meanwhile, orders from countries in Europe rose by US$240 million in value, marking an 11.91 percent annual increase rate.

Taiwan's industrial production index stood at 126.64 points in January, down a slight 1.06 percent from the level recorded in the same month of a year ago, mainly because of fewer work days last month due to the Chinese New Year holiday season, according to the statistics.
MOEA officials forecast that the index will register a higher growth rate for February thanks to continued strong demand both at home and abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINES

TEXT.P: New York Times: C.I.A was given data on hijacker long before 9/11.

American investigators were given the first name and telephone number of one of the Sept. 11 hijackers two and a half years before the attacks on New York and Washington, but the United States appears to have failed to pursue the lead aggressively, American and German officials say.

The information -- the earliest known signal that the United States received about any of the hijackers -- has now become an important element of an independent commission's investigation into the events of Sept. 11, 2001, officials said Monday. It is considered particularly significant because it may have represented a missed opportunity for American officials to penetrate the Qaeda terror cell in Germany that was at the heart of the plot. And it came roughly 16 months before the hijacker showed up at flight schools in the United States.
Wall Street Journal: Drug industry's big push into technology falls short.
Some leading chemists are calling the effort of pharmaceutical companies an expensive fiasco by applying machines in creasing chemical combinations at once and tested them out with robots.

They said that machines churned out chemical after chemical that didn't produce useful results. And chemicals that seemed promising often turned out to have big flaws that traditional testing might have caught earlier on. Some drugs couldn't dissolve in water or be turned into pills, for example.

Critics believe these problems help explain the pharmaceutical industry's drought of new products. Last year, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved only 21 new drugs, marking a steady decline since a peak of 53 in 1996. Many of the world's largest drug companies failed to win U.S. approval for a single new drug in 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEGOTIATIONS CALLED FOR TO HELP TAIWAN CHICKEN EXPORTS TO U.S.

TEXT.P: In the face of required market opening for foreign chicken imports next year in compliance with World Trade Organization (WTO) rules, Taiwan should step up the pace of its negotiations with other countries to help boost domestic chicken exports, business sources said Tuesday.

To achieve this aim, the government should move to complete such talks by the end of this year, especially with the United States, to help bolster outbound shipments of chicken starting from next year, said Chen Tuan-fang, chairman of the Taiwan Electric Slaughterhouse Association.

Chen said Taiwan should try to sell chicken to the United States now, as the domestic price of chicken has dropped. Taiwan could also consider barter trade -- exchanging chicken legs with U.S. chicken breasts -- he suggested, to seek to reduce the gap resulting from the current unilateral imports of U.S. chicken to Taiwan.
Prices of Taiwan-produced chicken used to be more expensive due to higher production costs, making it difficult for Taiwan to sell its chicken to the United States.

Cho Pai-hung, secretary-general of the Taiwan Slaughterhouse Association, said that Taiwan and the United States have agreed to hold six rounds of consultations to discuss shipments of Taiwan chicken to the United States.

With three rounds of the talks already having been held, the two sides have another three meetings to go, Cho said, pointing out that the fourth meeting was originally slated to open following the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday in late January but was postponed as a result of the recent outbreaks of avian flu in Asia.

Cho said the previous three meetings represent initial marked progress in Taiwan's efforts to edge into the U.S. chicken market, in contradiction to a wide assumption that it is impossible for Taiwan-produced chicken to break into the U.S. market, whose annual output scale amounts to about 18 million tons, much higher than Taiwan's 400,000 tons.

In order to abide with WTO rules, Taiwan must fully open its chicken market in 2005 without enjoying a quota treatment prior to its market opening. In the 1998-2003 period, Taiwan allowed entry of 90,000 tons of chicken, and plans to import 45,000 tons this year alone.

Affected by the outbreaks of the virulent H5N1 strain of bird flu in about 10 Asian countries, the domestic price of chicken has fallen, domestic chicken raisers said, adding that the planned market opening in 2005 has provoked even greater concern from related businesses.

They contend that the government should speed up negotiations with other countries to help push for chicken exports to other countries and areas, such as Hong Kong, Indonesia and Saudi Arabia, which have also been hit by the H5N1 avian flu, in addition to the United States.
Although Taiwan has also been affected by avian flu, it has been the much less virulent H5N2 strain, with no H5N1 cases having been reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER AWARE OF POSSIBLE GAMBLING INFLUENCE ON ELECTION

TEXT.P: Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan expressed concern that bookies taking bets on the March 20 presidential election could affect the outcome of the race.
Chen made remarks when he visited Kaohsiung Tuesday to step up investigations into allegations of vote-buying with less than one month to go before the election.

Chen, accompanied by Lu Ren-fa, state public prosecutor-general, held a meeting with the chiefs of branch police stations in Kaohsiung to declare his determination to eradicate bribery in the closely contested presidential race.

Chen noted that he has heard from grapevine reports that bookies have taken in a lot of money from gamblers in central, southern and northern Taiwan, with the longest odds for both candidates being 10 to 1.
Reports even said that some bookies, in order to evade law environment authorities, have fled to Hong Kong, Macau and mainland China, and have been calling the shots from there.

Though Chen said he has yet to secure hard evidence against the bookies, he expressed concern about the possible impact on the outcome of the presidential election because of the large amount of money involved.

"Police will form the backbone of anti-bribe operations, " Chen said, adding that prosecutors will work with police to crack down on vote-buying so that "money and violence will not be part of this year's election."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER YU LEADS OFFICIALS TO WITHDRAW EN MASSES FROM LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun led members of his Cabinet to withdraw en masse from the Legislature Tuesday in protest against opposition lawmakers' "invective and verbal personal attacks."

Angered and dismayed at opposition People First Party (PFP) legislators Chung Shao-ho and Cheng Chin-ling's calling him "a shameless politician," on a placard placed on the podium, Yu stepped down from the rostrum where he was answering questions at the Legislative Yuan assembly hall around 11:20 a.m.

Yu then asked interpellation chairman, Vice Legislative Yuan President Chiang Ping-kun, to uphold justice after he and Cabinet officials were "verbally attacked" by the legislators in an "irrational and vicious manner."
Yu led members of his Cabinet to retreat en masse from the Legislative Yuan around 1 p.m. before remarking that the Legislative Yuan authorities had not given him or the ministers justice.
He added that he and his ministers would like to return to the Legislative Yuan for another interpellation session after the Legislative Yuan authorities deal with the two PFP legislators "properly."

Commenting on the premier and his team's action, Liao Feng-teh, a party whip of the opposition Kuomintang legislative caucus, said Yu was "making much of a trifle" in an attempt to distract the focus of attention.

For their part, lawmakers from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its political ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , criticized their colleagues in opposition for the verbal attacks.
They also asked the PFP to apologize to Yu for Chung's and Cheng's move and urged the Legislative Yuan's authorities to refer them to the Disciplinary Committee for punishment.
Ker Chien-ming, convener of the DPP legislative caucus, said that "both Chung and Cheng owe Premier Yu an apology."
Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-ping said that he will convene a meeting of caucus leaders across the political spectrum to seek a "satisfactory" resolution to the problem.
It was the first time that a premier has led members of his Cabinet to withdraw en masse from an interpellation session of the Legislative Yuan since 1991.

Former Premier Hao Pei-tsun withdrew from an all-Legislative Yuan interpellation on Feb. 26, 1991 after being boycotted by the then-opposition Democratic Progressive Party legislators from approaching the interpellation podium for two hours.

DOC.HEADLINE: IF ELECTED, LIEN HOPES TO VISIT JAPAN BEFORE INAUGURATION

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Tuesday that if he wins the March 20 presidential election, he hopes to visit Japan before the May 20 inauguration.
Lien made the remarks in an interview with a group of Japanese journalists.

"Japan is one of our most important trading partners and friends. If elected, I would like to visit Japan before my inauguration to exchange views with Japanese politicians, scholars and opinion leaders in various fields on regional issues," Lien said.

Lien, who has teamed up with People First Party Chairman James Soong to challenge President Chen Shui-bian's re-election bid, said Taiwan has traditionally attached great importance to relations with Japan.
"Our two countries have maintained close ties in economic, trade, cultural and education fields for a long time. We should further strengthen our cooperation in various aspects," he added.

Lien, a former vice president who lost to Chen in the 2000 presidential election, said former President Lee Teng-hui had not consulted him before Lee unveiled the controversial "two states" or "special state-to-state relationship" model in 1999.
"It came as a surprise to me. I have never agreed with such a theory, " said Lien, who has a doctoral degree in political science from Chicago University.

Lien said he dislikes to use empty political slogans to "blur" the national identity issue. "According to our Constitution, the Republic of China is an independent sovereign country. It's an undisputable reality."

In July 1999, former President Lee described Taiwan-mainland China ties as a "special state-to-state relationship." Mainland China regarded Lee's description as a veiled move to promote Taiwan independence and has since suspended regular cross-strait dialogue on non-political affairs.
Asked about his views on Lee's political legacies, Lien said Taiwan made progress in political democratization during Lee's 12-year presidency.
"Nevertheless, Taiwan's political arena was tainted by shady links with business interests and gangsters during that period probably because of hasty political democratization," Lien said.

Meanwhile, Lien took advantage of the interview to clarify President Chen's accusation that Lien advocates putting aside the ROC's sovereignty to facilitate cross-Taiwan Strait rapprochement and reconciliation.

"In my first live TV debate with Chen Feb. 14, I proposed that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait shelve their disputes over Taiwan's sovereign status and forge cooperative ties in other fields. Chen quoted me out of context. I have never suggested that Taiwan's 'sovereign status' be shelved. I feel regret that Chen has deliberately misquoted my statement," Lien said.
He cited the longstanding international sovereignty dispute over the Spratlys in the South China Sea as an example to back up his views.

"Many countries, including Taiwan and mainland China, have claimed sovereignty to the Spratlys. But they must shelve their sovereignty dispute if they want to explore rich oil and other natural resources in the region," Lien said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 229 HIV CASES REPORTED IN HONG KONG LAST YEAR, DOWN FROM YEAR BEFORE

TEXT.P: A total of 229 HIV cases were reported in Hong Kong last year, compared with 260 in 2002, a doctor from the Health Department said Tuesday.
Speaking at a news conference, the doctor said that sexual transmission continued to be the most important mode in the spread of HIV.
Seventy percent of the newly reported HIV cases contracted the virus through having sex. Heterosexual transmission predominated in 113 cases while 48 occurred between men having sex with men.
In 2003, 56 AIDS cases were reported to the department. The number of AIDS reports has remained stable since 1997.

"It is estimated that over 3,000 people are living with HIV/AIDS in Hong Kong. The high HIV rates in neighboring cities, extensive human mobility across borders and high-risk behavior are some of the factors that may predispose Hong Kong to an upsurge of the epidemic," said the doctor. (Stanley Cheung)

DOC.HEADLINE: PARTIAL VOLUNTEER MILITARY TO BE GRADUALLY IMPLEMENTED: MND

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense will adjust the nation's military service system in a gradual manner, with a goal of enlisting 60 percent of volunteers for military service by 2012, a senior official said Tuesday.

Vice Minister of National Defense Chen Ti-tuan made the remarks in a report to the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on the feasibility of implementing an all-volunteer military service system in Taiwan.
Noting that the military now has 385,000 regular service members, Chen said a new troop reduction plan will be implemented from this year to cut the number of troops by 15,000 annually.
Under this plan, Chen said, the number of regular military servicemen and women will be lowered to 270,000 by 2012.

"By then, our weaponry systems will also have been renovated and upgraded. Against this backdrop, we can consider adjusting our military service system from conscription to a volunteer-dominated one," Chen explained.
According to the defense ministry's plan, Chen said, the volunteers-conscripts ratio in the military will be adjusted to 60 percent versus 40 percent by 2012.

In addition to weapons upgrades, Chen said several other factors must also be evaluated before a volunteer-dominated service system can be put into practice, including whether retired service men and women have been properly settled, whether the military has groomed an elite deterrent force and whether relations across the Taiwan Strait are stable.

The nation's military service system became a hot topic after the opposition "pan-blue alliance" presidential candidate, Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan, said in a televised debate with President Chen Shui-bian last weekend that if he is elected, he will replace the current conscription-dominated service system to an enlistment one. According to Lien's idea, the compulsory military service period for conscripts at peacetime should last for three months instead of the current one year and eight months.

Speaking at a regular news conference, defense ministry spokesman Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng said the ministry has traditionally refrained from making comments on candidates' visions or policy initiatives.

Nevertheless, Huang said four critical elements must be gauged in formulating a nation's military service system, namely, the threat from the enemy, financial resources, supply of regular forces at peacetime and the supply of reservists at wartime, and young people's interest in pursuing a military career.
Huang said the defense ministry has conducted an extensive study on the pros and cons of conscription and enlistment systems.

In the future, Huang said the military will adopt a two-pronged approach in recruiting service members, under which regular forces will adopt an enlistment-dominated system and reservists will implement a conscription-dominated one.

While both the defense ministry and the ruling DPP don't think introduction of an all-volunteer enlistment service system is feasible for now, the "pan-blue alliance" -- the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) -- said it will come up with a draft bill in two weeks to pave the way for implementing an all-volunteer enlistment system.

PFP legislators Lin Yu-fang and Chou Hsi-wei said an all-volunteer enlistment system is a prevailing world trend. "We must tread down this road which can help us meet the demand of a possible asymmetric, high-tech war across the Taiwan Strait," Lin said.

He said implementing an all-volunteer enlistment system doesn't require constitutional amendments. "We need only to enact a new law for the voluntary military system and retain conscription for wartime."

According to the "pan-blue alliance's" estimate, it will require an additional budget of NT$60 billion annually to implement the voluntary military service system. Under its plan, a private will be given a monthly salary of NT$30,000 to NT$40,000 and a non-commissioned officer will be offered a monthly salary of NT$40,000 to NT$60,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY TO BE ON 39-HOUR HEIGHTENED ALERT ON ELECTION DAY: MND

TEXT.P: The armed forces will be on a 39-hour heightened alert to help maintain domestic law and order before, during and after the presidential election on March 20, a military spokesman said Tuesday.
Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng confirmed that the Ministry of National Defense has designated the March 20 presidential election day as a period for special combat preparedness.

The military will be at their positions of "heightened levels of alert" in the 39 hours beginning from 5 p.m. March 19 and ending at 8 a.m. March 21 to ensure that the presidential election and the nation's first-ever referendum will be held smoothly, Huang said.

Noting that the armed forces will be well prepared against "surprise attack from outside" and "accidental crisis from within, " Huang said that the military will be on guard against any emergencies, including electoral affairs disputes, protests, terrorist attacks, threats to candidates' personal safety, and a mainland attack or efforts by Beijing to intimidate the island.

The military intelligence units, which have maintained constant vigilance against any suspicious or abnormal activities in the Taiwan Strait, have also heightened their surveillance to "uncover situations early and make quick responses" to protect Taiwan's security, Huang said.
Meanwhile, combat forces have also mapped out response options and have conducted training exercises to cope with possible "abnormal" mainland military actions, he said.
He added that as of noon Tuesday, the defense ministry has seen no abnormal mainland Chinese military activities, including movements of its missile and submarine forces.

Meanwhile, Huang noted that the just-begun joint military exercise between the United States and the Philippines conducted in the western part of the Philippines has nothing to do with Taiwan's upcoming presidential election.
Huang said the U.S. and Philippine armed forces conduct joint military drills regularly on an annual basis as the two countries maintain a mutual defense pact.
The annual military exercise has usually been conducted on Palawan Island to the west of the Philippines between Feb. 23 and March 7 each year, Huang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTRY EXPLAINS RECRUITMENT AND CONSCRIPTION POLICY

TEXT.P: A spokesman for the Ministry of National Defense explained Tuesday the factors involved in charting the nation's military service system in response to presidential candidate Lien Chan's call to make significant changes.

Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng said that while he was a spokesman for the defense ministry, he could not make comments on behalf of the ministry on the particular stances of the candidates running for president; however, he did say that he could respond as an individual.

Kuomintang candidate Lien Chan said in a debate last weekend with President Chen Shui-bian that he advocated a system of recruitment or draft for the armed forces to encourage more career soldiers and said that compulsory military service should be shortened to three months instead of the current 22 months.
Huang said that the ROC military uses four considerations when making its policy on calling and maintaining a standing army.

These are: the size of the enemy threat, the defense budget, the replacement of soldiers at peacetime and reservists that can be mobilized at wartime, and the commitment of the nation's youth to serve.

Huang said the defense ministry has recently studied the conscription and recruitment systems, and that the ministry is already planning to shift the bulk of its forces to recruits, while reservists will mainly be composed of conscripts.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANDIDATES URGED TO ARTICULATE POLICIES FOR PROTECTING FEMALES

TEXT.P: A number of women's rights groups appealed to the presidential candidates Tuesday to clearly articulate their policies for providing better protection to the island's female population.

At a press conference held at the Legislative Yuan, the women's rights activists called for the incumbent president and the opposition "pan-blue alliance" candidate to stop exchanging mudslinging and making empty promises.
The activists urged the candidates to articulate the "beef" and their vision regarding providing better protection for Taiwan's female citizens.

According to Chang Chin-li, executive director of the Modern Women Foundation, women and girls in Taiwan have been facing "three major forms of violence," namely assault and battery, sexual assault, and domestic violence.

Chang pointed out that the number of women or girls killed or physically attacked in Taiwan rose to 11,035 for 2002 from 6,057 in 1999, indicating that Taiwan's female citizens are increasingly threatened by physical violence.
Meanwhile, Chang said that the number of Taiwan women or girls sexually assaulted, attacked or abused totaled 2,400 for 2002, compared with 1,600 in 1999.
The number of women or girls who were the victims of domestic violence totaled over 17,000 for 2002, up noticeably from the 1999 figure of 11,000, Chang added.

Wang Chuei, a researcher with the National Taiwan University Office of Women Studies, pointed out that as females make up half of Taiwan's population, the country's stability hinges largely on whether they are well protected.
She called for the presidential candidates to clearly articulate their policies for better protecting females' personal safety crafted based on the concept of "gender equality."
The presidential election is slated to be held March 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS TO VISIT JAPAN, SOUTH KOREA

TEXT.P: Members of the Legislative Yuan Foreign Affairs Committee are set to visit Japan and South Korea in the coming week, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker said Tuesday.

Legislator Parris Chang, convener of the committee, said he and his colleagues in the committee, including Kuomintang Legislators John Chang and Sun Kuo-hua as well as People First Party Legislator Sun Ta-chien, will head to Japan Feb. 29 before traveling to South Korea March 2 and returning to Taiwan March 4.

Chang noted that mainland China, the host of six-party talks on the North Korean issue, knows that the United States has to rely on Beijing to mediate in the Korean Peninsula. He said he hopes that during the trip, he can learn more about the situation in the Korean Peninsula and exchange views with his Korean counterparts.

He also said that Japan has been playing a more active role in the international community and that it is promoting constitutional change. Japan's constitution was originally penned in English by U.S. occupying forces in 1946.

"It is necessary to have an understanding of the current situation in Japan, " Chang said, adding that he will also pay close attention to Tokyo's latest views on Taiwan's referendum to be held March 20 in tandem with the presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Feb. 24, or the fifth day of the second month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1500: Charles V, the Holy Roman emperor and King of Spain as Charles I, who summoned the Diet of Worms and the Council of Trent, is born.
1815: Robert Fulton, the American engineer who developed the first useful submarine and torpedo and invented the steamboat, dies at the age of 50.
1868: Andrew Johnson, the 17th president of the United States, becomes the first president to have impeachment proceedings brought against him by the House of Representatives. He was acquitted by one vote.
1885: Chester Nimitz, American admiral of the Pacific Fleet during World War II, is born. He halted Japanese expansion and ultimately destroyed the Japanese fleet with a strategy based largely on the use of aircraft carriers.
1891: The Ching court pays an indemnity to Russia for the return of Ili Valley in northwest China.
1909: The world's first color movie is shown in England.
1920: The Nazi Party, or the National Socialist German Workers Party, announces its program to set up the Third Reich.
1920: American-born Nancy Astor becomes the first woman to speak in Britain's House of Commons.
1933: The League of Nations votes 40 to one to pass a resolution refusing to recognize "Manchukuo," a puppet regime installed by the Japanese in China. Japan walks out of the international organization after the vote.
1945: U.S. forces liberate Manila from Japanese occupation.
1945: Ahmed Maher Pasha, premier of Egypt, is shot dead in parliament just after declaring war on the Axis powers.
1946: Juan Peron is elected president of Argentina.
1948: The Labor Union of Taiwan Province is established.
1950: The Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China holds its first meeting in Taipei.
1962: Dr. Hu Shih, the president of Taiwan's Academia Sinica, who proposed that literature be written in the vernacular rather than in the classical style, dies in Taipei at the age of 72.
1966: Ghana's President Kwame Nkrumah is overthrown in an army coup while he is visiting communist China. He was forced into exile in the Republic of Guinea.
1968: U.S. and South Vietnamese troops recapture the old Vietnamese imperial city of Hue after a fierce battle.
1969: A passenger plane of Taiwan's Far East Air Transport Corp. crashes in Kuijen village, Tainan County, killing all 36 people on board.
1972: The ROC severs diplomatic relations with Malta.
1974: Pakistan officially recognizes Bangladesh as an independent nation.
1976: A nine-member economic mission of Japan's Sankei Shimbun newspaper led by Nobutaka Shikanai, president of the newspaper, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1977: U.S. President Jimmy Carter cuts off U.S. aid to Argentina, Uruguay and Ethiopia because of human rights violations.
1978: Construction of the first-phase of the Taiwan Railway Administration's railway electrification project is completed and opened to traffic.
1989: Funeral rites for Japanese Emperor Hirohito, who had reigned since 1926, are held in Tokyo. His son, Akihito, becomes the new emperor.
1990: Malcolm Forbes, American tycoon, escort of Elizabeth Taylor and owner of "Forbes Magazine," dies.
1997: A fire at a Hindu pilgrim encampment in eastern India claims more than 200 lives and injures over 500 people.
2000: Chung Jung-chi, a minister without portfolio and a key member of the Kuomintang's election machine, announces his resignation from public office and also from the party in a "consciousness-raising" move.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "I do not now see a man who can love moral worth in man as he loves beauty in woman."

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC DECIDES TO SEPARATE REFERENDUM FROM PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) decided Wednesday evening to issue ballots for the presidential election separately from ballots for the referendum when the two votes are held on March 20.
The Executive Yuan, which insisted on having the two ballots given to voters together at the same time, backed down, saying it will respect the CEC's decision.

Lin Chia-lung, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan, said the Executive Yuan hoped to settle the disputes over how the ballots will be distributed so the public attention will be focused on the two questions put to the referendum.

Under the CEC's latest plan, voters at polling stations should be given the ballots for the presidential election, and cast them in boxes reserved for that purpose, before getting the two referendum ballots, each for one of the two questions in the referendum, and dropping them in boxes for the referendum.
The CEC initially preferred this method on the grounds that it minimizes the possibility of ballots ending up in the wrong boxes, which will delay the vote-counting in the presidential election.

But the CEC caved in to the Executive Yuan and chose to issue the three ballots to voters at the same time in hopes it will boost the turnout in the referendum which requires a minimum 50 percent turnout to be valid.

Under this plan, presidential election ballots put in the wrong boxes will be picked out first and tallied along with ballots in boxes for presidential votes. The ballots for the referendum will be counted after the vote-counting for the presidential election is finished.
This decision caused an uproar among the opposition parties of the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) which control 11 out of 23 counties and cities in addition to Taipei City.
Claiming it could lead to vote-fixing and might prompt chaos, they united their party members in various city halls to oppose the plan imposed on the CEC by the Executive Yuan.
Bowing to the opposition's pressure, the CEC reversed its previous decision Wednesday evening and decided to distribute the election and referendum ballots separately.
A KMT spokeswoman, Kuo Su-chun, said her party welcomes the CEC's about-face on the issue, saying that the new method is much safer .

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE EXPOUNDS VISION IN NEW BOOK

TEXT.P: Opposition presidential candidate Lien Chan published a new book Wednesday, outlining his vision for Taiwan and his views on personal traits needed to be Taiwan's top leader.

Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien said at a news conference introducing his new book, titled "Change, Then There Will Be a Hope," that if he wins the March 20 presidential election, he wants to become a respectable president, not a despotic leader.

Lien, a former vice president who has teamed up with People First Party Chairman James Soong to challenge President Chen Shui-bian's re-election bid, said he thinks that a national leader must exercise self-restraint to avoid abusing power and must demonstrate esprit d'corps and respect mainstream values.
In his view, Lien said, Taiwan has changed significantly over the past four years under the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration.

"Some of the changes are worrisome. Among others, the wealth gap has further widened and social confrontation has become more serious, " Lien noted, adding that he hopes President Chen will read his new book.
Lien, who has a doctoral degree in political science from Chicago University, said democratic development requires a humanistic spirit that is characterized by respect, equality and tolerance.

"Without these basic values, a democratic society is very likely to decline into social disorder and lose competitiveness," Lien said, adding that he has written the new book after extensive contacts with grassroots constituents around the island.

Lien said the new book explores problems faced by Taiwan in its democratic development and presents many policy initiatives for improving the nation. "The book explains my central policies, " he added.

The new book, which has eight chapters, advocates a more conciliatory policy towards mainland China than President Chen's, and suggests that Taiwan sign a peace treaty with the mainland and promising not to declare independence if Beijing renounces its threat of war.

"Taiwan should not seek independence for the sake of independence. The mainland should not push for unification for the sake of unification, " Lien said in the book. "The issue should be left for future generations to decide."

Locked in a tight race with Chen for the presidency, Lien has played down the KMT's longstanding policy of seeking eventual unification with a democratic mainland China to avoid hurting his chances with voters who fear Taiwan could be swallowed up by the communist country.

Chen says Taiwan is already an independent country that does not need to declare independence unless mainland China attacks. But Beijing has said his proposed referendum on boosting Taiwan's defenses is a step towards independence that could lead to war.

"Mr. Chen Shui-bian plays the Communist China card with the so-called 'defensive referendum, ' risking the country for his personal political gamble. He is a leader walking on a tightrope without a safety net," Lien claimed at the news conference.

In his new book, Lien wrote that Taipei and Beijing should resume fence-mending talks and eventually sign a comprehensive agreement including a peace accord. In the pact, Lien continued, mainland China would agree to renounce the use of force against the island and Taiwan would agree not to declare independence. "The two would also agree to treat each other as equals and maintain the political status quo."

At Wednesday's news conference, Lien also said if he wins next month's election, he will follow through with existing deals to buy weapons from the United States to defend against a possible attack from mainalnd China.
Lien's commitment was seen a response to criticism from Chen, wh Sho has argued that Lien would be too soft on mainland China.
Lien said he would be committed to Taiwan's defense if he wins the March 20 vote. Many opinion polls have said that neither candidate has a commanding lead in the presidential race.
"We will continue our arms procurement program," he said. "It is important for Taiwan's security. We need to continue this program in the coming years."

Taiwan buys most of its arms from the United States. In 2001, U.S. President George W. Bush agreed to a robust arms sales package to Taiwan, inclduing submarine-hunting aircraft, submarines and Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile batteries. The two sides are still negotiating prices and specifications.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT OVERSEES START OF CONSTRUCTION OF NANTOU NATIONAL FREEWAY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presided over a ceremony Wednesday in Puli township, central Nantou County to kick off construction of the Nantou section of the National Expressway No. 6.

Chen encouraged workers to complete the task on schedule and said that the completion of the project would be a boon, as it is expected to create more than 10,000 job opportunities for nearby townships and areas. He expressed the hope that he would be able to witness the inauguration of the highway upon its completion slated for December 2008 in his capacity again as the head of state.

According to Nantou County Magistrate Lin Tsung-nan, local residents have long expected the major project to start as early as possible to help improve local traffic situations, especially those in mountains, and help boost the development of nearby Tsaotung and Kuohsing townships.

Following the completion of the construction, which will link the Second North-South Freeway and enhance its service, famous tourist spots, such as Lushan and the Huisun Forest Farm, will also benefit a great deal from the project, county officials added.
Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san, as well as lawmakers Wu Duen-yi, Tsai Huan-lan and Puli township chief Ma Wen-chun and local residents also took part in the ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE TO RELAX FOREIGN LABOR POLICY

TEXT.P: Singapore's Manpower Ministry plans to relax its foreign labor policy soon as demand for skilled workers in the city-state is far outstripping supply.
Acting Manpower Minister Ng Eng Hen revealed this when he officiated at a ground-breaking ceremony Tuesday for two Singapore Airlines aircraft hangars.
He said that the job market has been looking up again and that the new jobs available will require better skilled workers.
Statistics showed 11,500 new job openings for the fourth quarter of last year, or an increase of 900 over the previous quarter's figure.
Meanwhile, SIA Engineering will employ 800 more engineers, technicians and support staff when its two hangars are ready in 2005.
The company has invested S$120 million (US$70 million) to maintain, repair and overhaul new jets like the SIA's A-345. And there has been active training and upgrading of the local workforce.
Singapore is still in need of more skilled workers like nurses, biomedical laboratory assistants and aerospace engineers, Minister Ng said.
He emphasized that Singapore's foreign worker policy must be relaxed to allow companies access to more foreign skilled workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN HIV-CARRIERS CAN APPLY FOR 14-DAY TOURIST VISA TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The ban on short-term visits to Taiwan by foreign HIV-carriers will be lifted once a draft package of revisions to the current AIDS Prevention and Control Statute is approved by the Legislative Yuan, the Cabinet said Wednesday.

The Cabinet approved the draft package proposed by the Department of Health (DOH) at its weekly meeting. The draft bill will soon be referred to the legislature for approval, a Cabinet spokesman said.

Under the current regulations, foreign HIV-carriers cannot enter Taiwan. In the past, NBA star Magic Johnson was denied a visa to visit Taiwan simply because he had been tested positive for HIV -- the virus that causes AIDS.

The DOH said it manages to detect an average of 50 foreign HIV-carriers each year when foreign citizens, including foreign spouses and migrant workers, apply for long-term resident visas. Those people are asked to leave Taiwan within a specified period of time and their names are then put on a blacklist.
Under the revised bill, those on the blacklist will be allowed to apply for a 14-day tourist visa.
Meanwhile, the revised bill requires hotel and sauna operators to provide free condoms or install condom vending machines to help promote safe sex.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL PARTIES AGREE TO DONATION BILL

TEXT.P: The four political parties in the Legislative Yuan agreed Wednesday to act on a political donation bill immediately in hopes that it will pass before March 5.
The four parties' representatives said at a joint news conference that a compromise was worked out that was suitable to everyone after painstaking negotiations.

The representatives were Chen Shei-saint for the Kuomintang, Lee Yung-ping for the People First Party, Lo Wen-chia for the Democratic Progressive Party, and Lo Chih-ming for the Taiwan Solidarity Union.
They promised on behalf of their parties to enact the bill into law as soon as possible.

According to the rules of the bill, political donations would be allowed for people who are interested in running for public office only for a specified period before the end of the terms of the incumbent for which they wish to replace.

This time is one year for the presidency, 10 months for seats at the legislature, six months for chiefs and councilors of municipal cities, counties and ordinary cities, and four months for other elected offices.

The maximum donation to a particular political party or movement will be limited to NT$600,000 (US$18,044) for an individual person, NT$4 million (US$120,293) for a private group, and NT$6 million (US$180,440) for a business.

The maximum donations to a would-be candidate for public office will be NT$200,000 (US$6,014) for any individual person, NT$1 million (US$30,073) for any private group, and NT$2 million (US$60,146) for any business.
Anyone who seek political donations without approval may face a jail term of up to three years.

Foreign donations, not to mention those coming from the mainland and Hong Kong, are off-limits to both political parties and would-be candidates. Offenders are punishable by imprisonment of up to five years.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES LOCAL BUSINESSMEN TO GIVE TAIWAN TOP PRIORITY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian told a group of local businessmen Wednesday that while he was not adverse to them investing in mainland China, their homeland of Taiwan should be given top priority when considering where to base their operations or invest.

Speaking in Nantou County, southern Taiwan, President Chen said that Taiwan is the center of Asia, not an offshore district of mainland China, and that Taiwan's economy is not a part of mainland China's economy. He encouraged businessmen to expand their businesses globally, but reminded them that wherever they are, "Be sure to make Taiwan your top concern and make the island your top priority when choosing a place to invest."

Chen said that relocating a company's manufacturing operations to the mainland while keeping its management in Taiwan is a dangerous strategy. Doing this, the president said, will jeopardize the jobs of some three million workers employed by the island's manufacturing sector.

Instead of separating the location of manufacturing operations from management, the president urged local companies to set up their research and development centers in Taiwan. This, he said, would boost the added value of products turned out by Taiwan's industry.

Saying that this year the country's economy is expected to grow at 5 percent, while the unemployment rate will be kept under 4.5 percent, the president said the economy is now healthy and that Taiwan is an ideal place for future investments.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXAMINATION YUAN PRESIDENT HONORED BY SOUTH KOREAN UNIVERSITY
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Feb. 25 (CNA) (By Chiang Yuan-chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen was rewarded Wednesday with an honorary doctoral law degree by Han-Kyong National University President Li Yong Yu in recognition of his efforts to promote democracy and human rights in Taiwan and for boosting exchanges between the two countries.

Li highly praised Yao's performance in building Taiwan's democratization and in advocating human rights in exchanges with South Korea and other Asian countries, particularly the many achievements he made while serving as a legislator of the Republic of China between 1993 and 1996.

Li also thanked Yao's prominent role in bolstering Taiwan-South Korea cultural and academic activities. Li expressed his hope that the two countries will further increase interaction based on the current cordial ties, such as the pacts inked between Han-Kyong National University and Taiwan-based National Chiayi University and National Pingtung University of Science and Technology.

Echoing Li's view, Yao pointed to the importance of maintaining peace and security in the Taiwan Strait and described it as a vital issue for both Taiwan and South Korea. "We need more closer cooperation and exchanges," he added.
Republic of China Representative to South Korea Li Tsai-fang witnessed the ceremony, in which Han-Kyong National University presented its first-ever honorary law doctorate.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINES

TEXT.P: New York Times: By backing a gay marriage ban, Bush keeps faith with his base.

In recent weeks, on a variety of fronts, President Bush has tried to allay the concerns and stoke the spirits of his restive conservative base. His impassioned endorsement on Tuesday of a constitutional amendment banning same-sex marriage, after weeks of intensive lobbying by social conservatives, was the culmination of this rapprochement.
Wall Street Journal: Before Ground Zero rebuilding, $1.3 billion has already been spent.

About $1.3 billion in insurance money to cover the destruction of the World Trade Center has already been spent, even before major reconstruction has begun, and the main beneficiaries are lawyers, lenders and real- estate developers.

Most of the world-wide attention on the project has focused on architecture, especially the competitions that selected Studio Daniel Libeskind's master plan for the site in February 2003, and Michael Arad's twin reflecting pools memorial last month. But just how the insurance proceeds are divided up will have a profound effect on the size and scope of commercial space that ultimately rises at Ground Zero.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMOUS FORT IN TAMSHUI TO CLOSE FOR 18-MONTH RENOVATION

TEXT.P: One of the most loved and cherished historical sites in suburban Taipei will be closed next month for an 18-month renovation, it was announced Wednesday.

Hung Mao Cheng, also known as Fort San Domingo, in Tamshui, a grade one historical site designated by the government, will be closed to address problems with water damage, termites and general age damage.

Repair workers at the fort, which includes a fortress and a spacious consulate building, have invited the public to make good use of the few remaining days in February to visit and savor the beauty of the fortress and elegant red-tile British consulate building, which has attracted between 400,000 and 500,000 visitors each year.

Hung Mao Cheng was originally called Fort San Domingo and was built by the Spanish in 1629. The fort fell to the Dutch in 1661 and then again in 1681 when 35,000 Ming dynasty troops led by Cheng Cheng-kung (Koxinga) fleeing the mainland from Ching dynasty troops ousted the Dutch from Tamshui. It was around this time that the fort was given its present name. In Chinese, Hung Mao Cheng literally means "fortress of the red-haired ones."

In 1867, the British leased the building and the consulate moved in the following year. The British withdrew from the consulate in 1972, entrusting it to Australia and later to the United States. Hung Mao Cheng was returned to the Republic of China in June 1980 and opened to the public in Dec. 25, 1984 after being renovated.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH-PROFILE DEBATES TO KICK OFF SUNDAY

TEXT.P: With the high-profile public debates on the two referendum questions kicking off this Sunday, the names of the representatives from the affirmative and opposition sides to the 10 debates were unveiled Wednesday.

The affirmative camp will be represented by five government officials and five legislators of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), while the opposition side will include eight people from an anti-March 20 referendum action alliance formed mainly by TV and radio personality Jaw Shau-kong, and two others recommended by the Green Party.

The two sides submitted the names of 10 representatives each to the Central Election Commission (CEC) earlier in the day and they were later revealed after a draw to decide which one will face which in the debate.

Independent Legislator Sisy Chen, who will represent the "nay" side, said earlier that she has no intention of debating another woman, but was drawn to face Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and the only woman representative on the "yea" side.

Jaw, chairman of the UFO Network and a TV host, said that this must be "god's will" for the two women, both known for their sharp wits, analytical power and ability to remain calm in the heat of the most raucous argument, to face each other in the debate.

Another surprise is Juan Ming, a scholar from mainland China and now a professor at Tamkang University, who was originally on the recommended list of the Executive Yuan's "yea" side, but ended up on the "nay" side in the final list.
Kao Cheng-yen, Green Party acting convener, said that because Juan had advocated casting invalid ballots, the party had decided to recommend him as a "nay" side representative.

The 10 debates, five each for the two questions in the referendum -- one on enhancing national defenses in the face of the missile threat from mainland China and the other on cross-strait talks on a peace and stability interaction mechanism -- will start Feb. 29 for three consecutive Sundays.

On the first question on strengthening national defenses, Executive Yuan Spokesman Lin Chia-lung will face aboriginal Legislator Chin May; Joseph Wu, deputy secretary general of the Presidential Office will challenge Chan Chao-li, a poet who is concerned with the rights of the grassroots and was one of the leaders of a 120,000-strong group of farmers and fishermen who protested in Taipei in Nov. 23, 2002 -- the largest protest rally ever by farmers and fishermen in Taiwan.
DPP Legislator Lo Chih-ming will face former Control Yuan member Yeh Yao-peng, Legislator Yu Ching will face Kao Cheng-yen and Legislator Julian Kuo will face Jaw Shau-kong.

On the second question, Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh will face off against writer Li Ao; Minister without Portfolio Yeh Chun-jung will challenge former DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang; DPP Legislator Chiu Tai-san will face National Taiwan University professor Tim T.Y. Ting; DPP Legislator Cho Jung-tai will debate Juan Ming and Tsai Ing-wen will face Sisy Chen.

After the unveiling of the list, Jaw said that the list of his action alliance covers most ethnic groups, including aboriginee, Hakka, Minnan (Taiwanese) and mainlanders, as well as several former DPP heavyweights such as Sisy Chen and Hsu Hsin-liang.

He lashed out at the Executive Yuan's list comprising five legislators, saying that Taiwan is not a Cabinet system and that the legislators have not participated in the decision-making on the referendum. He also complained that President Chen Shui-bian, who has the decision making power in calling the referendum, had decided to stay out of the debates.

Jaw reaffirmed that he supports the idea of referendum, but is opposed to the two questions in the March 20 one. He pointed out that the public can refuse to vote and that if they decide to vote, they can say no to the questions. Voters will receive three ballots on March 20 -- one for presidential election and one each for the two referendum questions.
Kao said that he also supports the referendum but will vote no to the questions.

Public interest in the referendum is building day by day after many twists and turns in the process. The government even had to change its original list of debaters after learning that it will face strong rivals and debaters known for their sharp tongues.

The CEC has to conduct the live TV debates for the two camps under the terms of the Referendum Law. It first invited the legislative caucuses of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and its ally, the People First Party (PFP) to serve as the "nay" side.
Neither party was interested in debating a referendum they see as illegal, so the CEC was forced to seek debaters from among many civic groups that were keen to challenge the Cabinet.

A total of 48 groups applied to debate on the "nay" side, forcing the CEC to draw lots as to who should take part in the debates after a coordination meeting failed to reach a satisfactory settlement among them.
Jaw's group collected enough signatures to form 21 groups for the debates, giving it a much better chance than the other hopefuls in the draw.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 90 PERCENT OF ILLEGAL MAINLAND IMMIGRANTS COME FROM FUJIAN

TEXT.P: Nearly 90 percent of the nearly 38,000 illegal mainland China immigrants seized over the past years have come from Fujian province on the southeastern coast of mainland China, the National Police Administration (NPA) said Wednesday.

NPA statistics showed that between July 2000 and December 2003, 37,804 illegal mainland China were taken into custody. Among them, 33,576, or 88.81 percent, had come from Fujian province, which is located across the Taiwan Strait from the island.
Among the Fujian illegal immigrants, most came from Pingtang County, or 17,895; followed by Changlo County, 3,090; and Fuqing County, 2,003.

In terms of gender, men accounted for the majority with 31,086. In terms of age, those aged between 31 and 35 are the largest group with 7,969, followed by those between 36 and 40, or 6,766; and those between 26 and 30, or 5,580.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PRIVACY INFRINGEMENT IN INTERVIEWS OF MAINLAND VISITORS: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Immigration (BOI) under the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) denied allegations Wednesday that it has prepared a list of questions to ask incoming mainland Chinese visitors during airport interviews that have been branded by some as an invasion of privacy.
BOI Director Tseng Wen-chang made the denial at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting.

During the session, several opposition lawmakers, including Lee Ching-hua and Feng Ting-kuo of the People First Party, quoted a private cross-Taiwan Strait marriage promotion association as claiming that some questions posed by BOI officials during interviews with incoming mainland visitors at airports have infringed upon the travelers' personal privacy.
The opposition lawmakers demanded the BOI's superior agency -- the MOI -- come up with an investigative report on the allegations within one week.
In response, Tseng said the BOI didn't begin to conduct face-to-face interviews with incoming mainland visitors until Sept. 1, 2003.

"As this is a new measure, some of our staff members might not be skillful or efficient enough in handling the interviews. There may be room for improvements. But I assure you that the so-called embarrassing 'privacy-infringing' list of questions is non-existent. I don't believe that any of our immigration officers had ever put forth insensitive questions to mainland arrivals, " Tseng told lawmakers.
Speaking on the same occasion, MOI Minister Yu Cheng-hsien said he has directed the immigration bureau to look into the reported cases.
"If any BOI staff member has ever infringed upon personal privacy during interviews with mainland arrivals, he or she will be punished in accordance with the civil service law," Yu said.

According to Tseng, 14,717 mainland visitors have so far been interviewed since the new system was implemented last September as part of government efforts to prevent entry of mainland citizens through marriages of convenience.
"Through those interviews, we have successfully prevented entry of 1,179 mainland citizens who intended to enter Taiwan and work using fake marriages as an excuse," Tseng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC MANUFACTURERS OPTIMISTIC ABOUT BUSINESS CLIMATE:TIER

TEXT.P: More than half of the domestic manufacturers polled recently are optimistic about Taiwan's economic outlook for the coming six months, with the business condition index rising to a record high of 117.48 points, according to a report made public Wednesday by an economic research institute.

The monthly report on the domestic economic climate and trends carried out by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) shows that 53 percent of the companies in the manufacturing sector polled in January held a positive view of the country's economic prospects for the coming six months, up from the December level of 51.9 percent.

Some 43.2 percent of the respondents contended that their business conditions will remain stable in the coming six-month period, up from the month-earlier level of 36.2 percent. However, about 3.8 percent, down from December's 11.9 percent, are pessimistic about their prospects, according to the report.

TIER President Wu Rong-i said that Taiwan's economy, prompted by strong demand at home and abroad, will post good performance this year if there are no major incidents that could affect economic development.
Wu, however, pointed out that the central bank could raise interest rates should international prices of major staple commodities, such as steel, continue to rise.
The TIER, set up Sept. 1, 1976, is the Taiwan's longest-established private independent research institute.

Meanwhile, the Cabinet-level of Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) forecast that Taiwan's gross domestic product will expand by 4.74 percent for the whole of 2004, or even by 5.34 percent, should the Executive Yuan's "10 New Construction Projects" worth a total of NT$550 billion clear the Legislative Yuan in the second half of this year.
The DGBAS based its optimism on a rebounding global economy boosted by the benefits of an appreciating euro and the recovering Japanese and U.S. economies.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANY OVERSEAS CHINESE TO RETURN TO VOTE IN ELECTION: OCAC

TEXT.P: More than 10,000 overseas Chinese are expected to return to Taiwan to cast ballots in the March 20 presidential election, the nation's top overseas Chinese affairs administrator said Wednesday.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting, Chang Fu-mei, chairwoman of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC), told lawmakers that 10,601 overseas Chinese had registered to vote for the Republic of China's 11th-term president and vice president as of the Feb. 9 deadline.

Chang said 1,323 of them still have legal residence in Taiwan. "According to government regulations, they do not need to register with our representative offices abroad for the election. Excluding this group of people, 9,028 overseas Chinese who do not have their legal abode in Taiwan have registered to vote," she explained.
In comparison, Chang said, only 2,800 overseas Chinese registered for the 2000 presidential election.
This time around, Chang said, the number has more than tripled the 2000 figure, indicating that overseas Chinese people are very interested in the hotly contested election.

Moreover, Chang went on, the figure does not include Taiwanese businessmen operating in mainland China who have their legal abode in Taiwan and thus do not need to register for the election in advance.
Chang said the OCAC has consistently adopted a neutral and impartial attitude in encouraging overseas Chinese to return to Taiwan to elect the nation's president.

"The commission has used many channels, including leaflets, print media, electronic media, e-mail and the Internet, to help would-be overseas Chinese voters better understand the technical details regarding the presidential poll and the referendum, " Chang said, adding that the OCAC has also cooperated with ROC overseas representative offices and overseas Chinese cultural centers in sponsoring seminars on related topics.

Meanwhile, Chang said, mainland China has distorted Taiwan's first-ever referendum as a move to promote Taiwan independence and has launched a publicity drive to sway overseas Chinese people's loyalty to Taiwan and foreign countries' support for Taiwan.

Despite this pressure from the mainland, Chang said the OCAC will continue to strengthen its services to overseas Chinese people under the principles of "reform, innovation, foresight and pragmatism."

DOC.HEADLINE: MASTER SHENG YEN LEADS TAIWAN DELEGATION TO WORLD YOUTH PEACE SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Zen Master Sheng Yen, founder of the Taiwan Buddhist group Dharma Drum Mountain (DDM) Social Welfare and Charity Foundation, has led a Taiwan delegation to Thailand to take part in the World Youth Peace Summit (WYPS), Asia-Pacific, slated to be held in Bangkok Feb. 25-29.

Five of the seven-member group are followers of Taiwan Buddhist organizations, including DDM, the sixth is a young man selected from Taiwan's business sector and the seventh, a graduate school student from National Taiwan University, according to a DDM public relations official.

Over 1,000 young leaders from around the world have arrived in Bangkok for the five-day peace summit, which is the first regional preparatory conference prior to a Global Summit in Nairobi scheduled to be held in October, the DDM spokeswoman said.

The objective of the Asia-Pacific summit is to identify outstanding youth leaders and youth organizations in the region and to develop a framework for a Youth Action Plan for World Peace for Asia-Pacific Youth by identifying the key issues effecting young people in the region and how regional youth leaders can contribute to the global efforts for peace and development.

The summit will also develop the structure for WYPS Councils of Youth Leaders in each county in the region for the continuation of WYPS programs and the implementation of the Youth Action Plan for World Peace following the summit.
During the summit, organizers will also present the WYPS-Asia Pacific Youth Awards to outstanding youth leaders for their contributions to peace-building and development in the Asia-Pacific region.
Master Sheng Yen's DDM made a donation of US$100,000 in post-quake relief aid to Iran immediately after a devastating earthquake struck the historic city of Bam last Dec. 26.

Days later, after dispatching a four-member mission to Bam for a fact-finding trip, the DDM launched a fund-raising drive to channel another US$100,000 into Iran to foster children who were orphaned and deprived of schooling by the deadly earthquake.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DECLINES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar declined against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, giving up NT$0.049 to close at NT$33.252.
A total of US$832 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$33.352 and dipped to a low of NT$33.225 during the session.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT TO ALLOW 3 INAUGURAL FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: An international airport will be inaugurated March 5 in Taichung, central Taiwan, but the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) will only allow three approved international charter flights for the time being, CAA Director General Billy K.C. Chang said Wednesday.
Chang said that "until the facilities of the newly converted airport meet international standards, the CAA will not agree to more applications for international charter flights."

The airport in Chinchuankang, Taichung County, is being converted from a military only airport to a joint civilian-military airport. Its inauguration is supposed to mark the delivery of President Chen Shui-bian's campaign promise during his 2000 election campaign to give Taichung an international airport.

Chang said, however, that in the first stage of the international airport, only domestic flights will be allowed. There are no international airport facilities and domestic and international flights cannot run simultaneously, he said. There is also no equipment to allow night landings and takeoffs, he added.

However, he said, the international charter flights scheduled for the March 5 inauguration day will have no problems, as domestic flights will still take off and land at the original Shuinan domestic airport in Taichung City, which will be closed for good that same day.

Starting from March 6, domestic flights will use the Chinchuankang facility, while the return trips of the international charter flights will have to land at CKS International Airport in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, Chang said.

He explained that the three international charters will use the military runway. To make it a standard international airport, it would not only have to have terminal facilities, but the military has requested that the government help improve 37 other runway facilities, which the CAA is incapable of doing at present.
He added that not until domestic flights have been in operation for some time will the CAA even assess the possibility of operating international services.

The two domestic air carriers that have been approved to use the facility for international charters are China Airlines, with one flight from Taichung to Tokyo, and Far East Air Transport Corp., with one flight each to Phuket and Palau.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Doctors want all patients to buy insurance.
Rejecting the Government's claim that a tax-based healthcare system is best, five hundred consultants say that systems in Europe, based on compulsory insurance, work better.
Financial Times: Review could revamp law firms.
The head of the government's review of the legal industry is to float proposals for a new type of law firm which could change the shape of the profession.
A consultation paper next month will highlight ways to relax the ownership rules governing law firms, according to people who have held talks with Sir David Clementi, the Prudential chairman and former Bank of England deputy governor who is leading the review.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA PLANNING AGRICULTURAL EXPORT SPECIAL ZONES FOR TAIWAN FRUIT

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) is planning to earmark NT$300 million (about US$9 million) in the coming three years to set up three agricultural export special zones, a COA official said Wednesday.

Wang Ming-lai, director-general of the COA's International Cooperation Department, said the plan has been worked out in line with a global promotion package aimed at boosting Taiwan's exports of agricultural produce in the hope of injecting a new lease on life into the industry.

The COA has initially decided to establish zones for locally grown bananas, papayas and green soybeans, Wang said, adding that the first such zone for bananas is expected to be opened within this year on a 1,500-hectare land lot belonging to the state-run Taiwan Sugar Corporation in southern Pingtung County.

The creation of the zones is meant to secure a strict production process for outbound shipments of locally grown agricultural produce to satisfy international standard quarantine and quality requirements, he noted.

Bananas used to be Taiwan's most popular fruit for export, especially in Japan, but its sales in foreign markets have met strong competition from the Philippines and other countries in Southeast Asia because of Taiwan's higher prices.
According to COA officials, Taiwan's export value of green soybeans grew by an annual rate of 6.4 percent in 2003, while that of papayas increased 1.9-fold year-on-year.
The COA plans to allocate a budget of about NT$60 million this year, with NT$100 million and NT$140 million allocated for 2005 and 2006, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Kerry Wins Idaho, Utah; Hawaii Results Expected Early Wednesday.
Sen. John F. Kerry of Massachusetts easily won Democratic presidential contests in Utah and Idaho Tuesday night, tightening his grip on his party's nomination as he heads into a round of potentially decisive primaries next week. Results from a third state, Hawaii, were expected early Wednesday.

DOC.TEXT:
Turkish Daily News: Al-Qaeda sounds warning.
Top Bin Laden deputy taunts Bush, rapes French headscarf ban.

The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Wednesday are as follows:
