The Moscow Times: Putin Fires Kasyanov 19 Days Before Vote.
President Vladimir Putin suddenly fired Prime Minister Mikhail Kasyanov and his Cabinet on Tuesday, saying he will appoint a new team that will reflect his vision for Russia in the second term he is all but guaranteed to win.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO INDICATION BEIJING WANTS TO INFLUENCE TAIWAN ELECTION: U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 24 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Mainland China is closely monitoring the situation in Taiwan prior to its March 20 presidential election, but there is no indication that it is prepared to influence Taiwan voters through military activities, a high-ranking U.S. Defense Department official said Tuesday.
Lowell Jacoby, Defense Intelligence Agency director, made the remarks when he reported at a hearing at the Senate Select Intelligence Committee on worldwide threats to the United States.
"Domestic political events in Taipei are the principal determinant of short-term stability in the Taiwan Strait, " Jacoby said.
"Beijing is monitoring developments in advance of next month's presidential elections and referendum, ever concerned about a Taiwan declaration of independence," he continued.
He said that "Beijing will not tolerate the island's independence and will use military force regardless of the costs or risks."
However, he went on, "we see no indication of preparations for large-scale military exercises or other military activity to influence Taiwan voters at this stage," he added.

He also noted that the mainland has continued to develop or import weapons. The People's Liberation Army acquisition priorities include surface combatants and submarines, air defenses, modern fighter aircraft, ballistic and anti-ship cruise missiles, space and counter-space systems, and modern ground equipment, he said.

During Taiwan's first popular presidential election in 1996, the mainland lobbed missiles into the Taiwan Strait near Taiwan and in the next election in 2000, then-Premier Zhu Rongji launched a blistering verbal attack on the eve of the presidential election.
Meanwhile, George Tenet, U.S. Central Intelligence Agency director, said on the same occasion that the mainland has continued to pursue a missile modernization program.

"China continues an aggressive missile modernization program that will improve its ability to conduct a wide range of military actions against Taiwan, supported by both cruise and ballistic missiles, " he said.
He also said that the greatest concern of the United States remains the mainland's military buildup, which continues to accelerate.
"Last year, Beijing reached new benchmarks in its production or acquisition from Russia of missiles, submarines and other naval combatants and advanced fighter aircraft," he said.
He added: "China is also downsizing and restructuring its military forces with an eye toward enhancing its capability for the modern battlefield."
"Expected technical improvements will give Beijing a more accurate and lethal force. China is also moving ahead with its first generation of ballistic missiles," he added.

In addition to giving an oral report and answering questions, Tenet also said in a written report that the United States is "closely monitoring the situation across the Taiwan Strait in the period surrounding Taiwan's presidential election next month. "
Mainland leadership politics -- especially the incomplete leadership transition -- will influence how Beijing deals with the Taiwan issue this year and beyond, Tenet said.

President Hu Jintao, who is also the Chinese Communist Party leader, still shares power with his predecessor in those positions, Jiang Zemin, who retains the powerful chairmanship of the party's Central Military Commission, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT CURRENCY CLEARING MECHANISM TO BE FORGED: CBC

TEXT.P: Central Bank of China (CBC) Governor Perng Fai-nan said Wednesday he believes that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will eventually forge a currency clearing and settlement mechanism.
Perng made the remarks at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Finance Affairs Committee.

During the session, opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lo Ming-tsai said that with Hong Kong banks formally opening mainland Chinese currency exchange services, the mainland currency can now more easily circulate in international markets and could even become a settlement unit in future Asian trading deals.
Against this backdrop, Lo said he is afraid that Taiwan might be marginalized in the global economy if the two sides of the Taiwan Strait fail to open currency exchange services soon.
In response, Perng said that the Ministry of Finance has allowed passengers to bring a limited amount of renminbi -- the mainland Chinese currency -- into Taiwan.

As to whether domestic banks will ba allowed to open mainland currency exchange services, Perng said this will involve technical issues that will have to be addressed. The most important prerequisite is the establishment of a cross-strait currency clearing and settlement mechanism, he added.

Perng said the central bank has tried several channels to explore the feasibility of forging such a mechanism with the mainland, including discussing the issue with high-level mainland officials during their visits to Taiwan.

"All those contacts have so far not yielded concrete results, " Perng said, adding that the CBC has asked the Mainland Affairs Council, which deals with all mainland-related affairs, to negotiate relevant issues with the mainland.
Perng said he is optimistic about the issue. "I'm convinced that a cross-strait currency clearing and settlement mechanism can be carved out in the not-too-distant future," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMANIAN VICE PRESIDENT WOOS TAIWAN INVESTORS

TEXT.P: Panamanian First Vice President Arturo Vallarino urged Taiwan investors Wednesday to invest in Panama, saying that Taiwan businesses are welcome to use Panama as a gateway to the vast American market.

Vallarino, who arrived in Taipei Sunday at the head of a large Panamanian commerce and industry delegation for a six-day official visit, was speaking at the Taiwan-Panama economic and trade summit forum, titled "Redefining Global Business, " at the World Trade Center.
Republic of China Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu led a Taiwan delegation at the summit forum.

Vallarino said that the ROC-Panama free trade agreement -- jointly ratified by President Chen Shui-bian and President Mireya Moscoso last November -- has now been put into effect, marking a new starting point of closer economic and trade ties between the two countries. "The accord will also serve as the bedrock of efforts to further bolster bilateral relations between Panama and Taiwan, " he added.

He noted that Panama is a small country, but is very interested in engaging in global trade. With its excellent geographic position -- strategically connecting the Pacific Ocean and the Atlantic Ocean with the Panama Canal -- and its free-trade harbor facilities, Panama offers a convenient bridgehead for Taiwan traders and investors interested in exploring the vast markets throughout the American Continent.

Meanwhile, he pointed out that Taiwan, despite being a small country as well, is an economic powerhouse. He said that Panama should emulate Taiwan's economic and international trade achievements and should also use Taiwan as a gateway to other markets around Asia.

For his part, Lin said that Taiwanese and Panamanian industries and businesses complement one another. The two countries maintain bilateral investment guarantee accords that were signed in 1992, he added.

Lin said that in accordance with Ministry of Economic Affairs regulations, Taiwanese industries and businesses are entitled to enjoy investment incentives from the government if they decide to invest in or relocate their manufacturing or economic operations to Panama.

Panamanian Minister of Commerce and Industry Joaquin Jacome, one of the key officials in Vallarino's 55-member entourage, said at the forum that if Taiwan businesses are interested in making inroads into Panama, they will find better niches if they invest in the telecommunications industry, shipping, operations centers or export processing zones.

Jacome said that Taiwan investors will find Panama a great place in which to invest because of Panama's membership of the System of Central American Integration and the fact that Panama's free trade agreement with the United States will take effect in 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stocks futures market were higher on Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for March moved up 42 points to close at 6,685, with 25,952 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for April rose 39 points to finish at 6,692, with 135 contract transactions, while June futures increased 54 points to close at 6,720, with 11 contracts traded.
September futures gained 58 points to finish at 6,750, with 4 contract transactions, while December futures moved up 38 points to close at 6,741, with 4 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,643 for March, 6,653 for April, 6,666 for June, 6,692 for September, and 6,703 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
March TE futures increased 2.1 points to finish at 272.1, with 7,637 contract transactions, while April TE futures rose 1.6 points to close at 272.2, with 40 contracts traded.
June TE futures gained 1.55 points to finish at 274, with 6 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
March TF futures moved up 4.6 points to finish at 1,063, with 9,721 contract transactions, while April TF futures rose 2.2 points to close at 1,060.2, with 34 contracts traded.
June TF futures increased 2 points to finish at 1,060, with only one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 55.05 points to close at 6,644.28.
The bourse opened at 6,619.69 and fluctuated between 6,672.24 and 6,595.24 during trading.

A total of 6.63 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$ 147.27 billion (US$4.43 billion) , compared with the previous trading session which saw 6.7 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$140.02 billion (US$4.2 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 2.1 percent, followed by construction stocks at 1 percent.

The other major stock categories posted gains, with foodstuff shares moving up the most at 2.3 percent, followed by textile issues at 2.2 percent, electrical shares and plastics and chemical stocks, both at 1.1 percent, bank and insurance shares at 0.3 percent, and cement stocks at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 476 to 300, with 192 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC TO REMAIN NEUTRAL IN POLLING STATION LAYOUT ISSUE: CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC), an independent service organization, will remain neutral and impartial in the upcoming presidential election and referendum vote, CEC Chairman Huang Shih-cheng said Wednesday.

Fielding questions at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan Judicial Affairs Committee, Huang said the CEC -- the top official agency in charge of national election affairs -- will heed public opinion on the issue of the layout of polling stations. The issue has been at the core of disputes over ballot and voting procedures surrounding the March 20 presidential election and referendum.

Huang said the CEC is expected to make a final decision on the layout of polling stations later Wednesday after CEC members hold an afternoon meeting to discuss two proposed versions of the polling stations' design. One of the versions was mapped out by the CEC, while the other has been proposed by a number of legislators, scholars and officials from the election commissions of several local governments.

According to the CEC, on the day of the March 20 presidential election and referendum, voters will get three ballots -- one for the presidential election, and one for each of the two referendum questions. The two questions concern whether Taiwan should strengthen its anti-missile defenses and whether the government should negotiate with Beijing on the establishment of an interaction mechanism for cross-Taiwan Strait peace.
The administration has said that it wants the three ballots to be cast at the same polling stations and that even votes placed in the wrong ballot boxes will be counted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK PRICES UP BY 55.05 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Wednesday, with the weighted index moving up 55.05 points to close at 6,644.28.
Market turnover amounted to NT$147.27 billion (US$4.43 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: SIA needs to fix worker moral issues.
Singapore Airlines' troubled labour-management relations received another public airing yesterday when the Government released feedback reflecting poor staff morale - and a roadmap on moving ahead.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Singapore to ease foreign labour policy to attract skilled workers.
The Singapore Manpower Ministry plans to relax its foreign labour policy soon as Singapore's demand for skilled workers is far outstripping its supply.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Feb. 25, or the sixth day of the second month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1901: John P. Morgan, one of the greatest financiers in the United States, founds the United States Steel Corp.
1913: The U.S. Congress passes the 16th amendment to the Constitution, paving the way for an income tax levying system.
1950: Members of the Control Yuan, the highest watchdog body of the Republic of China, file a proposal to impeach acting President Lee Tsung-jen.
1956: Nikita Khrushchev, secretary-general of the Soviet Union Communist Party, slams former Soviet Union leader Joseph Stalin at a party meeting.
1957: The Japanese Cabinet of Nobusuke Kishi is formed.
1981: Chuan Doo Huan is elected president of the South Korea.
1986: Corazon Aquino replaces Ferdinand E. Marcos as president of the Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINES NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Bangkok Post: Violence in the South / Chavalit "adding to confusion".
Deputy Prime Minister Chavalit Yongchaiyudh wants to set up a forward command for the Internal Security Operations Command (Isoc) in Pattani - - but security people feat it would only further confuse the line of command. (Francis Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Bush Seeks Constitutional Ban on Same-Sex Marriage.
President Bush called for a constitutional amendment to define marriage as a union between a man and a woman,as he expressed alarm at the gay marriages conducted in San Francisco and the potential for same sex weddings soon in Massachusetts.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Japan Times: Seoul presents concrete plan for arms talks. Japan brings up abductions. South Korea tabled a proposal on resolving the North Korean nuclear issue at six-party negotia- tions here Wednesday, while Japan and delegates from Pyongyang agreed to continue talks on bila- teral issues during a meeting on the sidelines of the talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: VALUAIR AIMS TO BE BUDGET AIRLINE WITH SOME FRILLS

TEXT.P: Valuair, one of the two Singapore budget carriers preparing to take off from Changi Airport soon, has said it aims to offer tickets at 40 percent to 50 percent the price of those of premier airlines while still providing some in-flight service.
Unlike other budget carriers, Valuair said, it is going to fly new aircraft with more leg room than usual, seats with leather upholstery, and even some modest in-flight service.
"Asian travelers are very discriminating -- they want a little bit of service," Valuair chairman Lim Chin Beng said.
The local budget airline plans to take off in May, with just two aircraft initially.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING WILL HOLD TALKS WITH TAIWAN IF RE-ELECTED: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian claimed Thursday that Beijing will "definitely" hold talks with Taiwan if he is re-elected in the March 20 presidential election.

Addressing an annual dinner party hosted by the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei, Chen predicted that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will talk about the establishment of a peace and stability framework for cross-strait interaction, an agreement on guarantee and protection of investment, opening of direct cross-strait trade, transport and postal links and other topics in a pragmatic manner.
Chen said that he is confident of winning re-election and gave an assurance that there will be no violence in the election.

With regard to the "peace referendum" to be held March 20 alongside the election, Chen said it has nothing to do with Taiwan independence or unification with mainland China and that it is aimed at showing the world the Taiwan people's desire for peace and their unity.

Chen reiterated that his "four noes plus one" pledge -- no declaration of Taiwan independence, no changing of the national title, no pushing for the inclusion of the so-called "state-to-state" description in the constitution, no promotion of a referendum to change the status quo in regards to the question of independence or unification and no abolishing of the National Reunification Council -- remains unchanged.

Referring to the outlook for Taiwan's economy, Chen said that the country's economic growth will reach the originally targeted 5 percent this year and will even top 5.5 percent should the "10 New Major Construction Projects" program worth a total of NT$500 billion (US$15.1 billion) be carried out smoothly.
The country's recent economic performance shows that policies adopted by the government over the past four years have been fruitful, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER WELCOMES U.S. REPORT ON TAIWAN HUMAN RIGHTS

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien expressed satisfaction Thursday with a U.S. government report on Taiwan's human rights situation.

Chien said that the annual report released Wednesday by the U.S. State Department's Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights and Labor, which gave Taiwan good grades, represents U.S. affirmation of Taiwan's democratic development.
It also serves as evidence that Taiwan's democracy and human rights are as mature as those of advanced nations, according to Chien.

According to the U.S. State Department's "Country Reports on Human Rights Practice 2003," Taiwan is a multiparty democracy and the island's authorities generally respect the human rights of the citizens.
Taiwan's Constitution provides for freedom of speech and the authorities also generally respect these rights in practice, it states.

Although some political influence still exists over the island's electronic media, particularly broadcast stations, the report said that the existence of about 100 cable television stations, some of which carry programming openly critical of the various political parties, have diminished the importance of political party influence over television stations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN TO HOST 8TH INTERNATIONAL ORCHID SUMMIT

TEXT.P: The eighth Asia-Pacific orchid summit is slated to open March 6 in Jenteh township in southern Tainan county and will run through March 14, with experts from 22 countries taking part in the high-profile event, organizers said Thursday.
Council of Agriculture Vice Chairman Lee Chien-chuan and Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih made the announcement jointly at a news conference.

Lee and Su hailed Taiwan's success in gaining the sponsorship, describing it as a "grand victory" in cross-Taiwan Strait competition, as mainland China has been trying to win the 2010 sponsorship. Taiwan's hosting of the event before the mainland means a lot for the country on the diplomatic front, they claimed.

Horticultural sector representatives from 22 countries, including Holland, France and the mainland, will participate in the prominent event by displaying their orchids and exhibiting their newest research and cultivation technologies.

Taiwan will soon open its first-ever orchid biotechnology park in Jenteh. The park's first-phase 23-hectare compound will serve as a venue for this year's orchid summit, which is held every three years.

The planned 200-hectare park will be one of the world's top orchid cultivation facilities and will create a competitive mechanism for Taiwan's production, marketing, research and sales of the popular flowers in the global market, Tainan county government officials said.
Taiwan cultivated orchids account for 77 percent of the world's total export value.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REITERATES DETERMINATION TO PROTECT FREEDOM OF EXPRESSION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reiterated his determination Thursday to protect freedom of expression and defend the independence of the media.

Receiving a group of radio station owners, program producers and hosts at the Presidential Office, Chen said that his determination has never changed or wavered, even though he and his administration have frequently been criticized or blamed by media outlets that have intentionally distorted events and issues.
Chen said he believes that time offers the best proof and that the public is the final judge.
A free media environment is crucial to democracy, and freedom of expression is the most important indicator of a democratic society, the president said.
He encouraged his guests to provide the people of Taiwan with good programs, to relay the people's voice and thus make contributions to the consolidation of Taiwan's democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: IBM TO OPEN PC SERVER R&D HUB IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The IBM Corporation is planning to set up a PC server research and development (R&D) center by the end of the first quarter of this year, an IBM Taiwan executive said Thursday.
IBM Taiwan General Manager Hsu Chu-sheng made the remarks while giving a keynote speech about "Taiwan on Demand" at a seminar held in Beijing.

Stating that it is important to devise more advanced PCs for modern users, Chu said the purpose behind the company's R&D center in Taiwan is to manufacture more advanced products to meet public demand for what is today a daily commodity.
Recruitment has already begun of professionals for the planned 80-member team, with about a dozen from the United States, Chu said.

IBM has so far opened eight R&D hubs and more than 20 development centers around the world, he said, adding that the planned PC server R&D hub in Taiwan will focus its studies on low- and middle-end personal computers in the initial stage.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RECEIVES THAI PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian received a parliamentary delegation from Thailand Thursday at the Presidential Office and expressed his appreciation for the friendship between Taiwan and the Southeast Asian nation.

Chen told his guests that the substantive Taiwan-Thailand relations have been increasing recently, with bilateral exchanges more diversified and closer both at the governmental and private level, even though the two nations do not have diplomatic ties.
Taiwan is Thailand's third-largest capital supplier, behind only Japan and the United States, with aggregate investment reaching US$10.5 billion between 1986 and 2002.
Taiwan and Thailand are complementary economically and the cooperation between the two countries through a well-designated division of work will be mutually beneficial, the president went on.
Chen also invited the Thai lawmakers to witness the "one million hand-in-hand rally" to be held Feb. 28 to mark the country's 2-28 Peace Memorial Day.
The activity is aimed at showing the world the Taiwan people's desire and tenacity in pursuing peace, democracy and ethnic harmony, Chen claimed.
The 20-member Thai delegation, headed by Senator Tawil Praisont, arrived in Taipei Wednesday and is scheduled to depart Feb. 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE ADJUSTS 2004 ECONOMIC GROWTH FORECAST UPWARD

TEXT.P: Singapore has revised its economic growth forecast for 2004 upward after a surprisingly strong 11 percent year-on-year expansion in the last quarter of 2003.
The Ministry of Trade and Industry said Thursday that it was now forecasting economic growth of between 3.5 percent and 5.5 percent, up from its previous forecast of 3.0 percent to 5.0 percent.
The ministry said optimistically that "the improvement in the external environment will sustain economic growth in Singapore."
For the whole of 2003, Singapore's economy grew by 1.1 percent, better than the ministry's January estimate of 0.8 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Rapes reported by servicewomen in the Persian Gulf and elsewhere.
The United States military is facing the gravest accusations of sexual misconduct in years, with dozens of servicewomen in the Persian Gulf area and elsewhere saying they were sexually assaulted or raped by fellow troops, lawmakers and victims advocates said on Wednesday.
There have been 112 reports of sexual misconduct over roughly the past 18 months in the Central Command area of operations, which includes Iraq, Kuwait and Afghanistan, military officials said on Wednesday.
Military officials said that the bulk of the charges were being investigated and that some had already resulted in disciplinary actions, but they could not provide specifics. They said a small number of the reports had turned out to be unfounded.
Wall Street Journal: Prosecutors could seek charges against chip makers.
Newly disclosed e-mail and testimony from the chip industry executives show what prosecutors believe was a global conspiracy among some of the world's largest memory-chip makers to cut production and raise prices before a sharp price spike two years ago.
The evidence -- and new activity before a federal grand jury in San Francisco -- suggests a long- running antitrust investigation may be coming to an end. Prosecutors are expected to seek criminal price-fixing charges against some chip makers, while others are weighing whether to enter plea deals and risk heavy fines, lawyers close to the case said.
Companies that have disclosed they are under investigation include the market leader, Samsung Electronics Co., and Hynix Semiconductor Inc., both of South Korea; Micron Technology Inc., based in Boise, Idaho; and Infineon Technologies AG of Germany, among others.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROMISING OUTLOOK FOR SOUTHERN TAIWAN SCIENCE PARK

TEXT.P: Sales of the Southern Taiwan Science Park in 2003 swelled to NT$155.3 billion (US$4.7 billion) , a marked more than 50 percent jump over the 2002 level, park administration director Tai Chien said Thursday.

According to Tai, the figure is expected to top NT$300 billion for 2004 amid promising business prospects. The administration also hopes to see 100 additional companies open up shops in the park, with a further 10,000 workers newly recruited for the year, he added.
The park's sales hit around NT$50.1 billion in 2001 and rose to NT$103.1 billion in 2002, with opto-electronics and semiconductor companies being the major driving force, administration tallies show.
Currently, 127 hi-tech companies -- up by 34 over the 2002 number -- have been approved to operate in the park, with promised investment totaling NT$1.3 trillion.

Thirty-one companies each are in the opto-electronics and precision instrument industries, while 25 and 22 are from the biotechnology and the semiconductor industries, respectively. A total of 55 companies have started mass operations, while 19 are preparing to do so.
The park's imports and exports totaled NT$239.98 billion in 2003, with outbound shipments worth about NT$123.28 billion and inbound shipments worth NT$116.7 billion.

The number of workers employed by companies based in the park stood at 21,374 as of the end of last year, up from the previous year's level of 15,071. The numbers registered for the end of 2001 and of 2000 were 9,467 and 6,906, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: INSURERS MAY BE ALLOWED TO BUY INTO MAINLAND CHINESE INSURANCE FIRMS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday his administration is studying the feasibility of putting together a package of measures to promote insurance service exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

Addressing the opening ceremony of a seminar on Taiwan's insurance industry, Chen said the government is considering allowing local insurers to invest in the mainland Chinese market by buying a maximum 25 percent stake in insurance companies there.

"I understand that local insurers have high expectations of entering the mainland insurance market. Relevant government agencies have been working on a detailed opening package to boost cross-strait insurance business exchanges, " Chen said, adding that his administration is seeking to negotiate with the mainland on relevant issues on the principles of "parity, dignity and reciprocity."

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT DENIES REPORTS ON ASSISTING JAPANESE POLITICIANS

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui denied reports Thursday that he used secret accounts of the National Security Bureau to provide financial assistance to Japanese politicians.
In a meeting with farmers in Hsinchu County, northern Taiwan, Lee described the reports recently published by some Hong Kong media outlets as "totally groundless."
Lee, who was in power from 1988 to 2000, accused the Hong Kong media outlets of barking up the wrong tree, saying that he is not a candidate in the March 20 presidential election.
He also suggested that Japan should stand firmly and uphold its principles in the face of pressure from mainland China.

Referring to the "one million people hand-in-hand rally" slated for Feb. 28 to mark Taiwan's 2-28 Peace Memorial Day, Lee said that it is aimed at making Taiwan's peace-loving voice heard around the world.
He encouraged the people of Taiwan to join the historic activity and show the world their sentiment regarding Beijing's missile threat.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PRESIDES OVER GROUND-BREAKING OF NANKANG EXHIBITION HALL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presided over the ground-breaking ceremony for the second world trade center and exhibition hall in Nankang, suburban Taipei Thursday.

The president, accompanied by Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i and Presidential Office Vice Secretary-General Chen Che-nan, turned over a symbolic shovel of soil at the ceremony, which was also witnessed by members of the foreign diplomatic corps stationed in Taiwan.

President Chen said that after the recent opening of the Taiwan Design Center, he was happy to attend the ground-breaking ceremony of the second world trade center and exhibition hall, believing it is another milestone for the Nankang area since the opening of the Nankang software industrial park.

The president said that the Nankang exhibition hall is the government's response to urgent needs of Taiwan businesses seeking exhibition space, saying that the cooperation of the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Ministry of the Interior has ensured that the construction began today.
"This again attests to the efficiency and the power to carry out programs of the administration," the president said.
He also said that the establishment of the Nankang exhibition hall is part of the government's vision to turn Taiwan into a "green silicon island and my commitment to build up Taiwan."
With the outstanding economic performance and the national competitiveness of Taiwan last year, he said the government has actually turned its economic vision into a prosperous reality.

He said that to upgrade national competitiveness, sponsoring international exhibitions will help Taiwan's industries obtain the most information and trade opportunities in the shortest possible time, and will also help promote the development of peripheral sectors.
The exhibition hall, coupled with the Nankang software industrial park, will make Nankang and the neighboring Neihu district even more prosperous, the president said.

The president said, "Looking ahead, we have no reason lack confidence in ourselves, " since the government has already improved the economic structure and upgraded national competitiveness over the past years.
"The development I envisioned four years ago has now turned into the prosperity we are so proud of today," he said.

The exhibition hall, which will cover six hectares, is scheduled to be inaugurated in October 2005 after the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEDP) , the nation's top economic planning agency, approved a proposal to appropriate NT$3.8 billion (US$114.8 million) for the construction last year.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) started to draft the plan for a second world trade center in 1994 and targeted Nankang as the proposed site. The project was approved by the Executive Yuan in 1996 and the CEPD began promoting the case in 1998 on the build-operate-transfer model in cooperation with the private sector.
However, because of the sluggish economy, the private sector bids failed and the MOEA then proposed to the CEPD that the central government fund the project.
Taiwan's first international exhibition hall -- the World Trade Center -- is located in the Hsinyi district of downtown Taipei.

Taiwan's ambition to transform itself into an Asia-Pacific business operations center has encountered stiff competition from Shanghai, Beijing, Hong Kong and Singapore in recent years due to the country's increasingly inadequate exhibition space, which has limited its ability to hold international trade fairs and exhibitions.

DOC.HEADLINE: REFERENDUM TO MAKE BEIJING MORE PRAGMATIC TOWARD TAIWAN: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first-ever nationwide referendum will prompt mainland China to adopt a more pragmatic attitude in dealing with cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said Thursday.
Tsai made the remarks while delivering a report to the Legislative Yuan's Interior Affairs Committee on the possible impact of the upcoming referendum on cross-strait relations.

In the referendum to be held alongside the presidential election on March 20, voters will be asked two questions -- whether Taiwan should buy more anti-missile batteries in the face of mainland China's intensified military threat and whether Taiwan should negotiate a viable cross-strait interactive mechanism on an equal footing.

As the nation's top mainland policy planner, Tsai will represent the government in a televised debate with independent Legislator Sisy Chen on the second question regarding cross-strait negotiations for establishing an interactive mechanism on March 14. Chen will represent the "nay" side in the debate.

Noting that the upcoming "negotiation" referendum supersedes the "independence vs. unification" ideological disputes among major domestic political parties, Tsai said the referendum results will help assuage domestic inter-party confrontation.

Moreover, Tsai said, the "negotiation" referendum will help forge a national consensus on future government policy toward mainland China. "If a majority of voters give a positive answer to the question, the referendum result will become an important element to maintain long-term stable cross-strait ties."

The referendum will also help narrow the distance between the government and the electorate, Tsai said, adding that no matter which party is in power in the future, the referendum results can serve as a mandate for the government to negotiate an interactive mechanism with the mainland under the principle of parity.

Since mainland Chinese leaders have on many occasions said they pin their hopes on the people of Taiwan for cross-strait reconciliation, Tsai said the referendum results will force mainland authorities to more realistically address cross-strait affairs.

Tsai further said that even if fewer than half of the voters cast a "yes" vote in the "negotiation" referendum, the result might mainly reflect procedural, rather than substantive, disputes. But she didn't elaborate on how she reached such a conclusion. Instead, she said that should that be the case, the government will continue to promote the establishment of a cross-strait interactive mechanism based on the principles of "peace, dignity and parity."

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS DEMAND NEW AIRPORT MEET SAFETY REQUIREMENTS PRIOR TO OPENING

TEXT.P: Legislators across the party spectrum on Thursday demanded that the new international airport in Taichung, central Taiwan, meet all safety requirements before it is scheduled to open March 5.

The 13 legislators were accompanied by Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san; Billy K.C. Chang, director-general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration; Fei Houng-po, vice chief of the general staff under the Ministry of National Defense and other officials to inspect the airport.

The airport in Chingchuankang, Taichung County, is being converted from a military only airport to a joint civilian-military airport. Its inauguration is supposed to mark the delivery of President Chen Shui-bian's campaign promise in last presidential election in 2000 to give central Taiwan an international airport.
The construction of the terminal started on September 4, 2003, and the work is expected to be completed this month.

Legislator Shen Chi-huei of the opposition People First Party pointed out several drawbacks to the project, including that the facility has yet to past fire safety tests, a tarmac sheltered corridor for passengers has yet to be completed, there are no refueling facilities at the airport, the outbound traffic network has yet to be comprehensively planned and what civilian aircraft must do in the event of a military exercise has not been properly addressed.
"People in central Taiwan have been waiting for an international airport for a long time, " the legislators said, but they said that security still should be a prime concern.

Minister Lin said that his ministry attaches great importance to airport security, stressing that it is a top priority. The airport will only open when it passes fire safety tests and "after the new runway is completed, it will be a new international airport, " he added.
The new airport will replace the original domestic airport in Taichung City, which will be closed for good on March 5, to fly domestic routes as well as international routes in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG SETS UP COUNCIL FOR CLOSER ECONOMIC TIES WITH DELTA REGION

TEXT.P: Hong Kong has set up a council for providing innovative ideas to develop closer economic ties between the territory and the Pearl River Delta.

Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Tung Chee-hwa Thursday appointed Victor Fung as the chairman of the new Greater Pearl River Delta Business Council and named another 31 business and corporate leaders as well as professionals as council members.
The council is aimed at fostering closer economic co-operation within the Greater Pearl River Delta Region.

Its membership profile cuts across various sectors -- including chambers of commerce, banking, shipping and textile industries, accounting, legal, logistics, technology, real estate, construction, environmental and education sectors. There are also representatives from small and medium-sized enterprises and think tanks.

The council's main mission is to come up with new business ideas on how to facilitate value-added operations and sustainable development across the boundary, and to promote two-way trade and investment. (Stanley Cheung)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AEROSPACE FIRM TO SIGN COOPERATION PACT WITH BELL HELICOPTER

TEXT.P: The Republic of China state-run Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. (AIDC) and the United States-based Bell Helicopter Textron, Inc. will ink a cooperation pact Friday in Taipei to explore business opportunities for both companies, a spokesman for AIDC said Thursday.
Michael Redenbaugh, chief executive officer of Bell Helicopter Textron, Inc., will sign the agreement on behalf of his company with AIDC executives, the spokesman said.
Redenbaugh will fly into Taiwan for that purpose from Singapore after having taken part in its annual aircraft show, the spokesman added.

Under the terms of the agreement, Bell Helicopter will grant AIDC the power to issue its approval certificates for repairs and maintenance of AH and UH military helicopters, the spokesman said, claiming that the joint venture will help create a mutually beneficial situation for the two sides.

According to the AIDC executive, the state-run company is likely to receive orders to manufacture parts and components from Bell Helicopter and to grab business opportunities of spare parts repairs and maintenance for helicopters owned by the ROC Army and countries in Southeast Asia.
Bell Helicopter Textron, Inc. headquartered in Texas, is the world's leader in making high-quality commercial and military helicopters.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIRLINES TO OFFER CHEAPER TICKETS FOR BUSINESSMEN COMING HOME TO VOTE

TEXT.P: To cope with a larger number of Taiwan businessmen planning to return home to vote in the March 20 presidential election, some airlines are considering offering reduced ticket prices or adding flights.

A Dragon Airlines Taiwan manager said the aviation company has decided to add one flight each day on March 17, March 18 and March 19 on the route from Shanghai to Taipei via Hong Kong to serve homecoming Taiwan businessmen. Passengers who fly on these three flights will not have to change airlines, he added.

The Dragon Airlines executive also said that some Taiwan businessmen's groups based in mainland China are negotiating with the company trying to obtain cheaper tickets for their members who fly back to Taiwan to vote.

Meanwhile, China Airlines and EVA Airways Corporation -- Taiwan's two largest carriers -- said that they have no plans to increase flights prior to March 20 because bookings for flights before that day are far from full. However, both the airlines have agreed to provide cheaper group tickets for those who book seats through a Taiwan businessmen's association.

According to an EVA Airways executive, bookings for flights on the route from Hong Kong to Taipei in the run-up to the presidential election day remain normal, but demand on the routes from destinations in the United States to Taiwan has increased 5 percent to 10 percent compared to the year-earlier level.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-THAI LAWMAKERS FORM AMITY GROUP TO BOOST EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Legislators from across the political spectrum formed an association Thursday to promote exchanges with Thailand's lawmaking body.
More than 10 Thai congressional members, headed by Sen. Tawil Praisont, traveled to Taipei to attend the inaugural ceremony for the Taiwan-Thailand Parliamentary Friendship Association (TTPFA).
Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien and many lawmakers were also present at the ceremony.
Legislator Chiu Chuang-chin of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, a TTPFA co-founding member, said the new organization will do its utmost to forge contacts and friendship with Thai lawmakers.
"We hope our efforts can help make the Thai Congress become more supportive of Taiwan on major international issues," Chiu explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT OPTIMISTIC ABOUT RE-ELECTION

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Thursday that she is confident that she and the president will be re-elected on March 20.

Speaking in an interview with the Central News Agency, Lu said that since Taiwan made a final decision on holding its first-ever nationwide referendum alongside its March 20 presidential election, major countries around the world no longer express dissenting views on the event.

"This indicates that they expect the re-election of President Chen Shui-bian and me in the upcoming poll and are now concerned about what Chen will announce in his May 20 inaugural speech, " Lu said in the interview.

With regard to the sensitive cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Lu said President Chen has on many occasions reaffirmed his commitment to the "four noes plus one" pledge outlined in his 2000 inaugural address.

Noting that policy continuity is the norm, Lu said Chen's reaffirmation is aimed at letting Beijing leaders and foreign governments understand that if the Chen-Lu ticket is re-elected, Lu said, there will be no dramatic policy about-face, including the policy on cross-strait relations.

The "four noes plus one" pledge refers to no change to Taiwan's official national title and flag, no holding of an "independence vs. unification" referendum and no inclusion of the "two states" dictum into the nation's Constitution during Chen's presidential term.

In Thursday's interview, Lu said she supports Chen's promise to form a nine-member special task force to promote the establishment of a viable mechanism for cross-strait peaceful interaction soon after he is re-elected.
Lu said she hopes that the proposed special task force will be a permanent body to facilitate promotion of cross-strait rapprochement and enforcement of various exchange programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEXT LEGISLATURE COULD REVISE REFERENDUM LAW TO STRENGTHEN DEMOCRACY: LU

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Thursday that the next legislature to be elected at the end of this year will be more apt to revise the Referendum Law to further strengthen Taiwan's democracy.
Lu made the remarks in an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency at the Presidential Office.
Lu noted that when the Legislative Yuan passed the Referendum Law in late November, it was done so in a rush, and there are imperfections that require revision.

Lu said it will be difficult for the current legislature to revise the law because of the political make-up of the lawmaking body, saying that after the March 20 presidential election there will be a reshuffle of the political landscape.

She predicted that after the year-end legislative election, the structure of the Legislative Yuan will be healthier, saying, "The new legislature can revise the Referendum Law to make Taiwan move toward solid democracy."

Lu was referring to the power structure of the current Legislative Yuan where the opposition alliance of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party is still the dominant force of the 225-seat body, despite the fact that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party took over the helm of the country in 2000 from the KMT who had ruled Taiwan for more than five decades.

She stressed that as a sovereign country, people have to be responsible for their deeds, and the people who will vote in the upcoming referendum understand this because of their knowledge of world events and the accomplishments of democracy.

Lu said that the knowledge and world view of the people of Taiwan has been unprecedented over the past four centuries and their abilities should not be underestimated. Taiwan people fully understand the importance of contact with the world, Lu said.
"The people of Taiwan are well aware of the impact that they have on the world and the impact of the world on them," she said.
Turning to international reaction to President Chen Shui-bian's announcement late last year that a referendum would be held on issues of national concern, Lu said that repercussions were expected.
"We finally made the international community pay attention to us," she said.
"Taiwan is rarely in the international spotlight, and from this perspective, we got what we wanted, although we had to pay a small price, too," Lu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LU TO PRESENT HER VISION FOR TAIWAN IN CEC-SPONSORED TV FORUM

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Thursday that she will expound her vision for Taiwan in a televised campaign forum to be sponsored by the Central Election Commission (CEC) for the two vice presidential candidates this Saturday.
Lu made the remarks in an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency.

"My speech in the CEC-sponsored forum will focus on my vision for Taiwan's future development, including the consolidation of our young democracy as well as Taiwan's national identity and its movement toward globalization," Lu said.
As Saturday's public TV forum for the two vice presidential candidates will be the only one of its kind to be held ahead of the March 20 presidential election, Lu said she cannot be absent from it.

"Because of my decision to attend the forum, I have to drop my plans to take part in the 'one million people hand-in-hand' rally to be held on the same day, " Lu said, adding that she regrets not being able to join the rally which is part of the activities marking Taiwan's 2-28 Peace Memorial Day.

Lu said the other vice presidential candidate, People First Party Chairman James Soong, didn't agree to her previous proposal to ask the CEC to postpone the TV forum to the next Saturday to allow her to participate in the 228 human-chain rally.

The unprecedented rally, jointly organized by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- is aimed at mobilizing at least one million people to hold hands together along Taiwan's west coast to symbolize the Taiwan people's unity in the face of mainland China's missile threat.

The Philippine Star: FPJ staying out of debate. Describing himself as a man of action, not words, Koalisyon ng Nagkakaisang Pilipino (KNP) standard-bearer Fernando Poe Jr. said yesterday he was not inclined to join a televised debate with other presidential aspirants.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN IS A DEMOCRAT: WEEKLY

TEXT.P: The Far Eastern Economic Review has praised President Chen Shui-bian as being a democrat and understanding the dynamics of representative government.

In its latest issue, the magazine said in an editorial that when the United States chastises President Chen for his plan to hold a referendum on the same day as Taiwan's presidential election, it may also be giving the unfortunate impression that it sees Taiwan as a special case among democratic societies -- one that curiously has no right to hold referendums.
"Taiwan needed to be cautioned on the need for prudence, but this should not have sent a message to Communist China that threats towards a democratic society are acceptable," the editorial said.

It said that however one views Chen's referendum, there is no doubt that he understands the dynamics of representative government. "He is a democrat, and it is impossible to disagree with him in a democratic context," it added.
"More troubling than Mr. Chen's gambit is why China's reaction has received far less than its fair share of condemnation," it said.
The editorial further said that while Chen is chided, mainland China's threats are seen as expected and normal.
"This only encourages Beijing's belief of its right to act in a bellicose manner, and that it is the responsibility of everyone else to avoid angering China," it said.
"We'd do well to remind ourselves who the democrats are in the region, despite their shortcomings," the editorial concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 26, or the seventh day of the second month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1531: An earthquake rocks Portugal, killing more than 20,000 people.
1791: The Bank of England issues the first-ever pound note.
1802: Victor Marie Hugo, the French writer who wrote such novels as "The Hunchback of Notre Dame" and "Les Miserables" and went into exile after Napoleon III seized power in 1851, is born.
1815: Napoleon Bonaparte escapes from exile on the island of Elba.
1901: Chi Hsui and Hsu Cheng-yu, leaders of the "Righteous Harmony Fist" uprising, or the Boxer Rebellion, are publicly beheaded by a court executioner in Peking (Beijing), ending two years of unrest over the presence of foreigners in China.
1906: Angered by an incident in which a French missionary stabbed and injured the magistrate of Nanchang County in Kiangsi Province, Nanchang citizens kill a total of nine English and French missionaries in the county.
1935: Sir Robert Alexander Watson-Watt, a Scottish electronics engineer and inventor, demonstrates for the first time, at Daventry in England, the radar he helped develop.
1936: An army revolt to establish a more nationalistic government fails, but three leading members of the civilian government are killed during the uprising, and Japan's military leaders gain a firm control of the government.
1936: German Chancellor Adolf Hitler opens the first factory for the production of the Volkswagen, literally the "People's Car," in Saxony.
1946: U.S. Secretary of State James Byrnes denies knowledge of a Big Three Agreement authorizing the USSR to remove machinery from Manchuria.
1951: The 22nd Amendment to the United States Constitution is passed, limiting presidents to two four-year terms in office.
1952: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill announces that Britain has developed an atomic bomb and will test it in the Australian desert.
1964: The ROC Air Force receives a number of F-104G jet fighters from the United States under a military aid program.
1970: The Executive Yuan decides to go ahead with construction on the North-South Freeway.
1974: Members of the International Academy of Trial Lawyers arrive for their 1974 conference in Taipei.
1975: The Republic of China and South Africa sign a trade agreement in Taipei.
1976: Spain gives up control of the Spanish Sahara, and the region comes to be called the Western Sahara, which is divided into two parts under the separate control of Morocco and Mauritania, respectively.
1979: Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan is formally opened.
1980: The Ministry of Finance approves the opening of Taipei branches by five European banks: Grindlays Bank (Great Britain), the European Asia Bank (West Germany), the Societe Generale (France), the Banque de Paris et des Pays-Bas (France), and Hollandsche Bank-Unie, N.V. (the Netherlands).
1981: A French super-high-speed train connecting Paris with several cities in France travels at a top speed of 380 kph, a new world record.
1982: An ancient tomb dating back to the Han dynasty (206 B.C.-8 A.D.) is unearthed in Mawangtui, in suburban Changsha City, Hunan Province.
1990: President Lee Teng-hui and El Salvadoran President Alfredo Felix Cristiani Burkard sign a joint communique for closer bilateral cooperation.
1990: Vaclav Havel, Czechoslovakia's new president, announces in Moscow that all Soviet troops will leave his country by July, ending 21 years of armed occupation.
1991: Saddam Hussein orders Iraqi troops to retreat from Kuwait and declares a great victory.
1993: Two mainland Chinese basketball teams arrive in Taiwan to play exhibition matches against local teams, marking the first time in four decades that athletes from Taiwan and the mainland will compete in Taiwan.
1995: Communist China and the United States sign an agreement mandating Chinese respect for copyrights, trademarks and patents.
1995: Barings, the London finance house, collapses after suffering losses run up in Singapore by trader Nick Leeson.
2000: ROC Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Minister Chiao Jen-ho holds a ribbon-cutting ceremony to mark the completion of 49 newly-built brick houses in a village in northern Thailand for Nationalist veterans.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Youth should be respected. How do we know that their future will not be as good as we are now? Only when a man is forty or fifty without having done anything to distinguish himself, does he then cease to command respect."

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS URGE SPECIAL PACKAGE FOR HOMECOMING VOTERS VIA MINI LINKS

TEXT.P: A group of lawmakers called on the Cabinet-level Council of Mainland Affairs (MAC) Friday to devise a special package for homecoming Taiwan people to vote in the coming presidential race and a referendum via the "mini three links."

The group of lawmakers from the opposition Kuomintang, the People First Party and the New Party made the call at a news conference held on the frontline island of Kinmen after paying an inspection tour to its facilities involving the so-called "mini three links" -- direct trade and transport services maintained between Kinmen and Matsu islands and the Fujian ports of Xiamen and Fuzhou in mainland China.

In response to the proposal, MAC Vice Chairman Johnnason Liu promised that he will put forward the issue for the MAC to study and he made it clear that the MAC will come out with a decision before the March 20 presidential election day.

About a dozen representatives of Taiwan businessmen's associations based in Xiamen, Quanzhou and Zhangzhou in Fujian province also took part in the news conference to echo their demand for such a special package in order to make their homecoming easier to vote in the presidential election and the historic referendum held on the same day.
The lawmakers suggested the MAC allow all Republic of China passport holders returning from abroad to Taiwan for the vote via the Kinmen and Matsu islands 10 days before and after March 20.

Out of concern over the capacities of the security, immigration and quarantine facilities on the two offshore islands, they proposed that the daily entry be limited to 10,000 people and they asked the MAC to answer before March 5.

Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Yu Fang-lai opined that it is necessary to settle all relevant technical issues in advance if the measure is to be adopted. He offered his viewpoint that Taiwan businessmen from mainland China travel in and travel out in groups during that period.

For the time being, only Taiwan businessmen and their families based in Fujian as well as Kinmen and Matsu residents are permitted to travel between the two sides under the framework of the "mini three links," initiated by Taiwan in Jan. 2001.
President Chen Shui-bian announced recently that starting from March 1, mainland-based Taiwan businessmen operating outside Fujian will be allowed to use the links to return to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTRY OFFERS NEW SCHOLARSHIP FOR FOREIGN STUDENTS

TEXT.P: A scholarship aimed at encouraging foreign students to study in Taiwan was formally launched by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs on Feb. 19, according to the ministry.

In a news release issued by the ministry on Friday the scholarship is divided into six categories and is expected to help 855 foreign students to study in Taiwan this autumn, compared with 564 foreign students with educational grants from Taiwan the previous year.
The number of recipients will further increase in the future each year, the news release said.

By attracting more foreign students to study in the country, the island will project its culture to overseas, improve its ties with foreign governments, schools and cultural and educational institutions, the ministry said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Two studies cite child sex abuse by 4 percent of priests.
Two long-awaited studies have found that the Roman Catholic Church suffered an epidemic of child sexual abuse that involved at least 4 percent of priests over 52 years and peaked with the ordination class of 1970, in which one of every 10 priests was eventually accused of abuse.
The human toll amounted to 10,667 children allegedly victimized by 4,392 priests from 1950 to 2002, but the studies caution that even these numbers represent an undercount. The totals depend on self-reporting by American bishops, the studies note, and many victims have never come forward out of fear or shame.
The studies were commissioned by the American Catholic bishops in 2002 in response to accusations of a massive episcopal cover-up of sexual abuse by priests. They will undoubtedly provide fodder for controversies between left and right in the church about issues like homosexuality in the priesthood and whether the celibacy requirement for priests should be revoked.
Wall Street Journal: The battle for Disney, Disney shareholders revolt widens
As they prepare for next week's annual meeting, Disney now concedes that well over 30% of the votes cast at the meeting could go against Chief Executive Michael Eisner and board members. Eisner.
The battle began with the resignation of Roy E. Disney and Stanley Gold from the Disney board. The two ex-directors, both highly critical of Eisner's performance, want shareholders to withhold support from Eisner and three other Disney directors.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AIMS TO BECOME VALUE-ADDED R&D HUB: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presided over a groundbreaking ceremony of a national agricultural and biotechnology park in southern Pingtung County Friday.

Describing the move as laying a solid foundation for building Taiwan into a value-added innovation and development center, Chen voiced the hope that the park will upgrade the country's agriculture and make it into a knowledge-based and a technology-oriented sector capable of putting out high quality products to make Taiwan more competitive after it entered the World Trade Organization in 2001.
Chen stressed that the government will fully support the park to assist the domestic agricultural industry, which is facing robust foreign competition, including that from mainland China.
Pointing to Holland's tulips and New Zealand's kiwis as an example, the president encouraged Taiwan farmers to develop new types of fine-quality produce by applying their advanced know-how.
Chen said about 30 companies are planning to open shop in the park this year, creating some 8,000 job opportunities in the initial stage and another 25,000 following its completion.

Vowing to build Taiwan into a value-added R&D center in Asia and the rest of the world, he said that Taiwan has already developed from a labor-intensive manufacturer into a technology-based society. Chen added that the country's economy is expected to grow by more than 5 percent this year and that its budgets for R&D programs will increase to account for 3 precent of gross domestic product in 2006.

According to Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i, the government has allocated NT$20 billion (about US$600 million )to establish five such parks across Taiwan in the coming six years, including this one in Pingtung, which will cost NT$12.6 billion, or 60 percent of the total budget.
For the time being, 12 companies have been approved to set up operations in the Pingtung park, which Lin called a milestone in Taiwan's agricultural development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEEKING U.S. LOANS TO BUY U.S. ARMS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense has approached the United States to obtain financial assistance to buy weapons from America, but so far no progress has been made, Minister of National Defense Tang Yiau-min said Friday.

Answering questions from lawmakers at the Legislative Yuan, Tang said his ministry, with the approval of the Executive Yuan, has been trying to get U.S. loans since last year but since a special budget for arms purchases from the United States has not yet been approved by the Legislative Yuan, the ministry has no idea how much money it will need, and negotiations with the United States are still at the preliminary stage.

As a U.S. ally of the same importance as NATO members, Taiwan is qualified to borrow money from the United States to finance its U.S. arm purchases, a vice minister of national defense from Taiwan has approached his U.S. contacts about this, but has gotten nowhere thus far, according to Tang.

The idea was brought up last year by Legislator Lin Nan-sheng, a lawmaker from the opposition Kuomintang. He claimed that buying U.S. arms with U.S. loans will bring Taiwan closer to the United States, which would not support an attack by Beijing against Taiwan while the island owes money to the United States. U.S. President George W, Bush approved the sale of a package of weapons systems to Taiwan in 2000, but the island has had problems coming up with the money at one time. The Ministry of National Defense is seeking a budget of NT$500 billion (US$14.92 billion) next year as part of the payment.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST ROC NATIONALS IN HAITI EVACUATED

TEXT.P: The government has evacuated Republic of China nationals from Haiti following reports that rebels had converged the previous day on Port-au-Prince, capital of the Caribbean country, to await orders to attack, Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien said Friday.
Chien said that the situation in Haiti will hinge on whether President Jean-Bertrand Aristide will step down amid mounting pressure to avoid a bloodbath.

He said that the ministry had begun evacuating the ROC nationals and that apart from 31 of them -- three Taiwan businessmen who are unwilling to leave, three ROC agricultural mission members and various diplomatic personnel -- all had left by road for neighboring Dominica.
The ministry has also authorized the ROC embassy in Haiti to decide whether to evacuate the embassy staff.
Referring to reports that Haiti is short of food, Chien said the ministry will donate rice and ship it as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: 14 TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN OPERATING IN MAINLAND MURDERED SINCE 2000

TEXT.P: Criminal Investigation Bureau officials said Friday that there have been 14 murder cases involving Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China since 2000 and they urged Taiwan businessmen to exercise caution while seeking business opportunities there.

Police said that in 2002, there was only one murder involving a Taiwan businessman, the fewest number in recent years, while 2001 was the highest with five murder cases. In terms of where the murders took place, Dongguan in Guangdong province had the most, with seven cases.

They said that three murders involving Taiwan businessmen have taken place this year so far alone, including a Taiwan businessman surnamed Sung who was kidnapped Feb. 17 for a ransom of HK$2 million but whose body was later found dumped in a reservoir in Guangdong province.

Another involved a Taiwan businessman surnamed Tsai who was robbed at his home on Hainan Island by four thugs Jan. 13, and another Taiwan businessman on Hainan surnamed Huang, who was stabbed and beaten to death Feb. 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL BUSINESS SALES IN JANUARY HIT RECORD MONTHLY HIGH

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) -- Taiwan's largest carrier -- posted a record single-month high in business sales of NT$7.7 billion (US$231 million) in January, with pre-tax profit hitting around NT$500 million, a CAL executive said Friday.

With deliveries of new passenger and cargo planes this year, CAL is expected to register an all-time record of NT$89 billion in business revenue for the whole of this year, barring any major incidents that could affect its operations, such as the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) last year, CAL General Manager Wei Hsing-hsiung said.

A total of seven new planes are slated to join CAL's present fleet in the coming months -- three A330-300 passenger planes in June, one B747-400F cargo planes each in July and August and two B747-400 passenger planes by the end of this year.
The new planes will help CAL simplify its fleet, lowering operation costs by about 10 percent, including costs in repair, maintenance and personnel training.
CAL opened many new routes last year, both for passenger and cargo flights.

In terms of passenger travel, it inaugurated new regular routes to Hanoi and Brisbane and launched historic charter flights to Seoul, as well as resuming services to Hawaii, last year. This year, it plans to open new routes to Hiroshima, Seattle and Houston.

In terms of cargo travel, it started services to Ho Chih Minh City and reopened operations to Manchester and Delhi last year. It is planning to offer cargo services to other destinations in Europe and India later this year.

Affected by the outbreaks of SARS, CAL posted losses of NT$1 billion in the first half of last year and recorded profits of NT$2.7 billion in the second half, leaving the carrier with net earnings of NT$1.7 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, gaining US$0.054 to close at NT$33.365.
A total of US$886 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$33.412, and was traded between NT$33.315 and NT$33.428.

DOC.HEADLINE: LARGE HAUL OF SMUGGLED CIGARETTES SEIZED OFF CHIAYI

TEXT.P: Coast guard officers seized a large haul of untaxed foreign cigarettes worth around NT$100 million (US$3 million) in waters off Chiayi, southwestern Taiwan, early Friday morning.

Acting on a tip, officers from the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) Putai operations boarded the Kaohsing-based container freighter "Tongshuen" at around 2 a.m. and discovered more than 2,000 cartons of smuggled foreign cigarettes concealed in six containers.

The coast guard officers first spotted the freighter being approached by several motorized sampans and then saw cartons of goods being unloaded from the ship onto the sampans. The officers then ordered the ship as well as the sampans to stop for inspection.
The "Tongshuen," an 800-ton freighter, regularly plies the route between the southern county of Chiayi and the outlying island of Kinmen.

This marked the largest seizure of untaxed foreign cigarettes by the CGA Putai operations in years. Previous seizures of smuggled foreign cigarettes were usually made off fishing boats or motorized sampans, the Putai coast guard said.
Following Friday morning's bust, the nine crew members and fishermen were taken back to Putai for further questioning.
The smugglers were later turned over to the Chiayi District Court on charges of violating Taiwan's tobacco and wine regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE BUST HUMAN SMUGGLING RING IN EASTERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Police busted a human smuggling ring in eastern Taiwan Friday, arresting 10 ring members as well as 12 illegal mainland Chinese women who were smuggled in to work as prostitutes.

Police said that after more than six months of surveillance, they arrested the ringleader, surnamed Chang, in January. Further investigation showed that other ring members controlled the mainland women, moving them around eastern Taiwan, including Hualien, Ilan and Taitung.

A 19-year-old woman surnamed Zhou told the police that she was brought into Taiwan last July. The ringleader told her that she had to work as a prostitute to repay the smuggling fee of NT$200,000 (US$6,042).
Zhou said that she was under the complete control of the ring and had no freedom of movement, adding that the ring also controlled several underage mainland girls.
She said that she was forced to work day and night, but the ring would not let her go and would only give her a NT$100 a day for meals.

To protect coastal security and crack down on illegal smuggling rings, police have targeted several other suspicious groups for investigation and they also urged the public to alert them of any suspected illegal activity.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Bush Shifts U.S. Stance On Use of Land Mines; Policy Slated for 2010 Won't Ban All Devices Designed to Kill Troops.
President Bush will bar the U.S. military from using certain types of land mines after 2010 but will allow forces to continue to employ more sophisticated mines that the administration argues pose little threat to civilians, officials said yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES MAINLAND CHINA TO REINFORCE HUMAN RIGHTS PROTECTION

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) urged mainland China Friday to strengthen its human rights protection and make human rights its top national development goal.
MAC Vice Chairman Liu Teh-hsun made the call after a recent U.S. human rights report said human rights conditions on the mainland China have regressed in the past year.
In contrast, the annual U.S. human rights report recognized Taiwan's progress in human rights protection, particularly in the field of political rights development.

Liu said the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, hopes that both sides of the Taiwan Strait can make human rights their ultimate national development goal and cooperate in realizing this noble goal.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE OFFICE IN BANGLADESH TO BE INAUGURATED MARCH 1

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will open a representative office in Bangladesh March 1 as part of its efforts to expand trade and investment in South Asia, Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien said Friday.
Chien told a news conference that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs sent staff members to the Bangladesh capital of Dhaka Feb. 15 in preparation for the inauguration of the new office.

"All preparatory work has been completed and the new representative office will become operational March 1, " Chien said, adding that Chen Wen-yen, a former deputy director of the MOFA's General Affairs Department, will be the ROC's first representative to Bangladesh.
The Bangladesh office will be Taiwan's second foothold in South Asia following the establishment of a representative office in India in 1995, Chien said.

"From the perspective of developing contacts in South Asia, the opening of a representative office in Bangladesh is of historic significance, " Chien said. "And substantive benefits will include expanding Taiwan's commercial exchanges and cooperation with South Asia, exploring new markets in the region, enhancing 'pro-Taiwan forces' in the international community, increasing sources for labor imports and extending the 'go south' investment policy to South Asia."

For the development of bilateral ties, Chien said, the opening of the new office will help Taiwan businessmen who invest in Bangladesh and wish to tap markets in the entire region. Moreover, he went on, Bangladesh can assist Taiwan in expanding its deep-sea fishing operations in the Indian Ocean.
Through the establishment of the new office, Chien said, Taiwan can share its economic development experience and democratic ideas with Bangladesh.
Describing Bangladesh as an integral factor for economic globalization, Chien said the country has a vast market and abundant human resources. Bangladesh workers are cheap yet well-trained, he said.

Moreover, he continued, the European Union and other advanced countries have offered special export quotas and other privileges for Bangladeshi products. "It's really a destination worthy of consideration by would-be investors," he added.

At present, Chien said, Bangladesh has more than 10 Taiwanese-funded textile and electronics manufacturing firms. Even though Bangladesh's present foreign trade remains limited, Chien said, large business groups from South Korea and other countries have been actively tapping the Bangladesh market.
"Taiwan cannot afford to lag behind," Chien said, adding that the establishment of a representative office in Dhaka can also help Taiwanese businessmen resolve visa and residence permit problems.
Asked whether the Indian government was involved in Taiwan's negotiations with Bangladesh for opening the office, Chien said India did not play any such role.

"We have spent a lot of time negotiating the representative office issue with Bangladesh. Both sides finally reached an agreement last year. The agreement was reached mainly because both sides want to increase economic, cultural and technological exchanges, " Chien said.

As for labor imports, Chien said, the issue was also touched upon during the negotiation process. "Technical details will be further discussed after our representative office is inaugurated in Bangladesh," he added.

Chien said the two sides did not talk about exchanges of aviation rights. "If any local air carrier is interested in opening direct flight services between Taiwan and Bangladesh, the government will be willing to study the feasibility," he said.

Bangladesh, located between India and Myanmar, has an area of 144,000 square kilometers and a population of more than 138 million. Eighty-seven percent of its people are Muslims. The official language is Bangladeshi, but English is also commonly used. Its annual gross national product is about US$38.3 billion, with a per capita national income of about US$300.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE BUST MAJOR CAR THEFT RING

TEXT.P: Police have busted the largest car theft operation of recent years, arresting more than 10 suspects, police said Friday.

Police were alerted of the existence of the car theft ring that was shipping stolen cars to mainland China after intercepting a car bearing false plates on the Yuanlin-Changhua section of the Chungshan Freeway last December.

Two suspects in the stolen car were arrested as they were about to drive the car to Kaohsiung Harbor, southern Taiwan, where it was to be shipped to the outlying island of Kinmen and later to the mainland.

Further investigation led police to find out that Huang Ming-chun, 42, with previous convictions for racketeering, burglary and fraud, together with several accomplices, had since early 2003 targeted an area in Taichung, central Taiwan, for stealing cars.

Police said that after the cars were shipped to Kinmen, their engine and chassis numbers were altered and they were smuggled over to the mainland port of Xiamen. The cars would then get new plates and registration in Hainan Island and be resold all over the mainland.
The ring had pocketed an estimated NT$30 million (US$906,344), police said.

Huang, who is now in hiding on the mainland, would target Toyota Camry cars less than two years old and had stolen more than 200 of them, as well as more than 100 imported cars such as Mercedes-Benz and BMW.

Police said that Huang would lure Kinmen residents with a small amount of money to serve as proxies to buy the stolen cars, which could be easily shipped to Kinmen as the customs authorities there usually do not inspect cars less than three years old.
