DOC.HEADLINE: GAMBLING RING BUSTED FOR OFFERING WAGERS ON PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: Police have nabbed five members of a Kaohsiung-based illegal bookmaking ring suspected of offering wagers on the results of the March 20 presidential election, the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) reported Friday.

Under the "Leiting 29" campaign, a crackdown on underground gambling groups, particularly those applying the Hong Kong horse racing lottery mechanism to offer bets, the CIB investigators teamed up with officers from the Kaohsiung City Police Department to make the arrests in several locations in downtown Kaohsiung late Thursday night.

The investigators discovered that the five men had been operating the Hong Kong horse racing lottery since 1999, with wager operations scattering around the island and stake money topping billions of new Taiwan dollars.
The investigators also unearthed several passbooks and nine banking accounts containing more than NT$100 million.
The CIB authorities were tipped off that wagers on the outcome of the presidential election have been rampant islandwide, particularly in central and southern Taiwan.

Betting, like other forms of gambling, is illegal in Taiwan and betting on elections is especially rare. The "Leiting 29" campaign was launched to avoid underground gambling rings from manipulating the presidential election by offering big stake wagers.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN JOINS BLOOD DONATION DRIVE TO MARK 2-28 PEACE MEMORIAL DAY

TEXT.P: Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng led the citizens of the outlying island Friday in a blood donation drive, on the eve of 2-28 Peace Memorial Day.

Lee, who was the first in a long line of people willing to roll up their sleeves and donate blood at the Kinmen County Stadium, said that the move will make the people of the island linked to those in Taiwan proper by blood, as well as by love and compassion, which he said would help heal "historic wounds."
"This will have positive significance to the ethnic integration of the ethnic groups," he added.

Yok Mu-ming, chairman of the tiny opposition New Party, who earlier initiated the 2-28 blood donation drive, "advocating blood donation to replace bloodshed," was accompanied by NP Legislator Wu Cheng-tian when he gave blood.
He said that the party worked with civic groups to launch the drive, hoping to use the blood donation to replace bloodshed and erase the stigma that stays in the memories of the Taiwan people.

Yok said that since the drive started in Taipei Feb. 7, similar activities have been held in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan and in Taichung, central Taiwan, and has collected more than 1.6 million bags, or 40 million c.c. of blood.
Yok expressed the hope that the blood drive will become a permanent mark of Peace Memorial Day.

The day remembers the tragic events that began Feb. 28, 1947, when a Taiwanese woman selling contraband cigarettes was beaten by police. The incident sparked riots followed by a brutal crackdown by the authorities throughout Taiwan in which tens of thousands were reportedly killed or imprisoned and which led to the ensuing "white terror" period.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, will stage a "one million people holding hands" event to form a giant human chain along the length of Taiwan, while the major opposition parties, led by the Kuomintang, will stage an islandwide run to mark 2-28 Day.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER RETURNS TO LEGISLATIVE FLOOR

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shui-kun returned to the often rowdy Legislative Yuan Friday, three days after he led his Cabinet ministers to walk off the legislative floor to protest insults made by two opposition lawmakers.
Before his return to the Legislature, Yu read a prepared statement outside the assembly hall that urged lawmakers to focus on policy issues and stop ridiculing administration officials.
Yu said in his eight-minute statement that the Cabinet has consistently respected the Legislature.
"I hope all lawmakers can exercise self-restraint and reason in questioning government officials as the first step to realizing the much-anticipated legislative reform," Yu said.

Yu became angry Tuesday during a question-and-answer session with lawmakers discussing the budget. Two lawmakers from the opposition People First Party (PFP) began ridiculing the premier by giving him a mock Oscar Award for "the best thug politician."

When Yu walked out of the Legislature, it marked the first time in 13 years that a premier has made such a move. The premier, appointed by the president, is responsible for defending the government's policies in the Legislature.

Yu said he feels regret that some legislators have mistaken the Cabinet's forbearance as a 'matter of course' and have habitually used abusive language and made personal attacks against administration officials.
"To attract media attention, several lawmakers have used bad language against officials at random and turned the legislative floor into a show ground," lamented Yu.

Noting that the Legislature is a venue for rational discussion and debate on major public issues, Yu said those lawmakers' distasteful behavior has seriously hurt Taiwan's constitutional democracy and made people lose confidence in the Legislature.
During Tuesday's question-and-answer session, Yu said, two PFP legislators made irrational verbal attacks on him and members of his administrative team.

"I sincerely asked them to exercise reason in their questioning and raised my hand to show my protest to the chairman of the session on five occasions. However, the two lawmakers didn't cease uttering abusive language nor did they offer any apology, " Yu recalled.
Yu said he maintained his respect for the Legislature despite facing such an insulting situation.

"I didn't leave the Legislative Yuan. I just led my administrative team to take a break from the legislative floor in a show of protest. I stayed at the Legislature, waiting for the chairman of the session to handle the issue," Yu said.
The premier stressed that his protest was necessary to protect the dignity of Cabinet ministers and to arouse the public's attention to the need for legislative reform.
In the past few days, Yu said, mainstream public opinion has shown sympathy for the Cabinet's stance and disdain for the two lawmakers' irrational actions.

Even though the two lawmakers and their party have not apologized for their actions, Yu said he still decided to lead his Cabinet ministers to the Legislature to take questions out of respect for the nation's constitutional system.
"I find comfort in our compatriots' support for the Cabinet's stance. Their encouragement and support indicate that our legislative reform agenda will eventually make headway," Yu said.
In his statement, the premier also recommended that the Legislature adopt four measures to improve its interpellation system.
First of all, Yu said he hopes that lawmakers and administration officials pose questions or make replies only after receiving approval of the chairman of the legislative session.

Since the main purpose of interpellation is for policy explanation and discussion, Yu said, the procedures and time frames for the questioning and responding parties should be handled in line with the principles of parity and impartiality in order to promote rational debate.

The scope of interpellation should be restricted to issues regarding the administration's work schedules, policy lines and other relevant affairs, Yu said, adding that the chairman of the session should order a halt to proceedings whenever lawmakers violate this principle and pose irrelevant questions.

Moreover, Yu said he hopes that the provisions in the legislators' code of conduct and the statute on the exercise of legislative power that prohibit lawmakers from reviling or insulting government officials can be strictly enforced.

Stressing that the people of Taiwan have high expectations regarding legislative reform and upgrading of legislative efficiency, Yu said he earnestly hopes that all lawmakers can exercise self-discipline and set a good model for legislative operations.
"I also hope none of our lawmakers will keep silent over a few of their colleagues' distasteful actions in the future," he added.
After delivering his statement, Yu led all the Cabinet ministers in entering the legislative conference hall to take questions from lawmakers from across the party spectrum.

Meanwhile, the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said earlier in the day it would come up with a proposal next week demanding that the legislative disciplinary committee mete out punishment to the two PFP lawmakers -- Chuang Shao-ho and Lai Chin-ling -- both of whom branded Yu as a "rascal" politician during Tuesday's question-and-answer session.
The two PFP lawmakers said they already retracted their comments on Yu at the request of Legisaltive Yuan Vice President P. K. Chiang who chaired Tuesday's session.

DOC.HEADLINE: SISY CHEN: LUCKY FOR BEING CHOSEN TO DEBATE MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: Independent Legislator Sisy Chen said Friday that she is the "luckiest one" for being chosen in a draw to debate Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, in the upcoming public debates on the referendum.

Chen, who will represent the "nay" side in one of the 10 public debates on the two referendum questions, said she feels lucky to be chosen because she considers Tsai, who will be the only woman representative on the "yea" side, or the government side, to be a respectable opponent of top caliber in professional knowledge, learning and moral standards.
The debates are being organized by the Central Election Commission in accordance with the Referendum Law. The referendum will be held on the day of the presidential election set for March 20.
The first of the 10 public debates, five for each of the two referendum questions, is set to be held this coming Sunday.

The two questions are whether Taiwan should strengthen its missile defenses if mainland China refuses to remove its missiles aimed at the island, and whether the government should negotiate with Beijing on the establishment of a peace and stability interaction mechanism.

On the first question regarding strengthening the nation's defenses, Executive Yuan spokesman Lin Chia-lung will face aboriginal Legislator Chin May; while Joseph Wu, deputy secretary general of the Presidential Office will go up against Chan Chao-li, a poet who is concerned with the rights of grass-roots voters. Chan was one of the leaders of the 120,000-strong group of farmers and fishermen who protested in Taipei on Nov. 23, 2002 -- the largest protest rally ever by farmers and fishermen in Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Legislator Lo Chih-ming from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will face former Control Yuan member Yeh Yao-peng; DPP Legislator Yu Ching will face Green Party leader Kao Cheng-yen; and DPP Legislator Julian Kuo will face Jaw Shau-kong, chairman of the UFO Network and a TV talk show host.

On the second question, Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh will face off against writer Li Ao; Minister without Portfolio Yeh Chun-jung will go up against former DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang; DPP Legislator Chiu Tai-san will face National Taiwan University professor Tim T.Y. Ting; DPP Legislator Cho Jung-tai will debate Tamkang University Professor Juan Ming; and Tsai Ing-wen will square off against Sisy Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stocks futures market were higher on Friday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for March moved up 67 points to close at 6,802, with 27,525 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for April rose 76 points to finish at 6,815, with 307 contract transactions, while June futures increased 61 points to close at 6,810, with 18 contracts traded.
September futures gained 62 points to finish at 6,826, with 5 contract transactions, while December futures moved up 35 points to close at 6,795, with 3 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,735 for March, 6,739 for April, 6,749 for June, 6,764 for September, and 6,760 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
March TE futures increased 1 points to finish at 275, with 6,704 contract transactions, while April TE futures rose 0.9 points to close at 275, with 79 contracts traded.
June TE futures gained 0.5 points to finish at 276.5, with 3 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
March TF futures moved up 13.6 points to finish at 1,082.2, with 14,651 contract transactions, while April TF futures rose 15.2 points to close at 1,083, with 64 contracts traded.
June TF futures increased 5.6 points to finish at 1,075, with 3 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 57.29 points to close at 6,750.54.
The bourse opened at 6,732.63 and fluctuated between 6,756.76 and 6,713.67 during trading.

A total of 7.69 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$ 169.82 billion (US$5.09 billion) , an increase from the previous trading session which saw 7.41 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$165.15 billion (US$4.96 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction stocks moving down the most at 0.9 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 0.1 percent.

The other major stock categories posted gains, with bank and insurance shares moving up the most at 1.9 percent, followed by textile issues at 0.8 percent, electrical shares at 0.4 percent, cement stocks and pulp and paper issues, both at 0.2 percent, and plastics and chemical stocks at at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 520 to 278, with 169 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 27, or the eighth day of the second month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
285: Constantine I, Emperor of Rome known as "Constantine the Great," is born. He adopted the Christian faith and suspended the persecution of Christians.
1782: The British Parliament votes to abandon the American War of Independence.
1844: The Dominican Republic gains its independence from Haiti.
1861: Rudolf Steiner, the Austrian philosopher, educationalist, and founder of anthroposophy, is born.
1879: Constantin Fahlberg, a chemist at Johns Hopkins University, announces the discovery of saccharine, a synthetic sweetener.
1910: Dr. Sun Yat-sen sets up a U.S. headquarters in San Francisco after organizing the Revolution Alliance in Tokyo in 1905 to sponsor an entire network of revolutionaries inside China.
1922: Dr. Sun Yat-sen issues a proclamation at a "harangue-the-troops" ceremony in Guilin, Guangxi Province, before a military expedition northward to eradicate various feuding warlords in central and northern China.
1932: British physicist Sir James Chadwick discovers the neutron, a subatomic particle which is used by scientists to render various elements radioactive.
1933: Japanese troops invade Jehol Province in northeastern China.
1933: Chancellor Adolf Hitler calls for a "God-given signal" that the communists should be crushed, as a mysterious fire guts Berlin's Reichstag, or Parliament.
1942: Japanese forces sink three Allied destroyers and a cruiser in the first phase of the Battle of the Java Sea.
1948: The Czechoslovakian Communist Party seizes power in Prague with communists given all the top jobs in the new Cabinet.
1952: The United Nations convenes its first session in its new permanent headquarters in New York.
1962: Two mutinous Republic of Vietnam Air Force planes bomb the presidential office in Saigon. President Ngo Dinh Diem escapes unscathed.
1973: Governor Yu Kuo-hwa of the Central Bank of China leaves for Saigon to sign a US$5 million loan contract with the Vietnamese government.
1973: Ronald H.C. Ho assumes office as president of the Bank of Taiwan.
1974: Osamu Itagaki, chairman of the Sino-Japan Interchange Association, arrives in Taipei for talks on ROC-Japan civil aviation relations.
1975: The ROC and Saudi Arabia sign an air agreement in which Saudi Airlines will offer flight services from Jeddah or Riyadh to Taipei or Kaohsiung and China Airlines will offer flight services from Taipei or Kaohsiung to Jeddah or Riyadh via Hong Kong.

If you speak to a man in parables, he will probably be pleased with your story; but the important point is that he should apply the moral to himself."

DOC.HEADLINE: ALL TAIWANESE ARE MASTERS OF THE ISLAND: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Saturday said that there is no difference between "new Taiwanese" and " old Taiwanese" among the 23 million people of Taiwan and that all Taiwanese are masters of the island.

The president made the comments in a feature he wrote to mark the 57th anniversary of the tragic 2-28 Incident in which the government's suppression of Taiwanese caused a bloody conflict between native Taiwanese and local residents from mainland China.

Noting that the 2-28 Incident is still a sensitive topic in Taiwan and that some people think it's best not to touch on the issue and to leave it behind, Chen said that as the nation's leader, he does not think this is the way to deal with the matter.

He said that having love for Taiwan and for the people, looking at the past and at ourselves with self-examination, and having a forgiving attitude toward others is the best way to approach the sensitive topic.
He further said that if "our hearts are filled with love, forgiveness and self-examination," then history will lead us forward, and the pursuit of democracy and justice will never falter.

Looking back on history also helps to remind the people of Taiwan of their achievements as well as the sacrifices of their forefathers, Chen said, adding that the people should always believe that they are the masters of their own land.

Noting that Taiwan has been a multi-ethnic society for some four hundred years, Chen said that the differences between the people and their leaders should definitely not be viewed as differences among the ethnic groups.

"Descendants of the aboriginal people, the Haklo, the Hakka, mainland Chinese, as well as newcomers from other nations are all masters of the big family of Taiwan, " Chen said, adding that " in today's Taiwan, there is no difference between masters and guests, nor distinction between "minority" and "majority" since the 23 million people are all an integral part of Taiwan and share in its destiny.

Reiterating that Taiwan belongs to the people of Taiwan and is not a vassal state of any other nation or people, the president said that the island should think about its future structure and form. He pointed out that "emphasizing Taiwan's separate identity is not tantamount to the 'de-Sinicization' of Taiwan."

He said that Taiwan stands at the intersection of "oceanic culture and continental culture, " and that besides its multicultural assets, the island has also absorbed the essence of Chinese, Asian as well as European and American culture.

Although Taiwan is not a part of mainland China from the standpoint of sovereignty, Chen said, "China" and "Chinese culture" are certainly a part of Taiwan from the standpoint of history, culture and blood ties.

Saying that there is no longer any distinction between "new Taiwanese" and "old Taiwanese," the president called on the people of Taiwan to trust each other and work together as all the 23 million people of Taiwan are the masters of Taiwan's present and future.

TEXT.P: New York Times: Two studies cite child sex abuse by 4 percent of priests.

Two long-awaited studies have found that the Roman Catholic Church suffered an epidemic of child sexual abuse that involved at least 4 percent of priests over 52 years and peaked with the ordination class of 1970, in which one of every 10 priests was eventually accused of abuse.

The human toll amounted to 10,667 children allegedly victimized by 4,392 priests from 1950 to 2002, but the studies caution that even these numbers represent an undercount. The totals depend on self-reporting by American bishops, the studies note, and many victims have never come forward out of fear or shame.

The studies were commissioned by the American Catholic bishops in 2002 in response to accusations of a massive episcopal cover-up of sexual abuse by priests. They will undoubtedly provide fodder for controversies between left and right in the church about issues like homosexuality in the priesthood and whether the celibacy requirement for priests should be revoked.
Wall Street Journal: The battle for Disney, Disney shareholders revolt widens

As they prepare for next week's annual meeting, Disney now concedes that well over 30% of the votes cast at the meeting could go against Chief Executive Michael Eisner and board members. Eisner. The battle began with the resignation of Roy E. Disney and Stanley Gold from the Disney board. The two ex-directors, both highly critical of Eisner's performance, want shareholders to withhold support from Eisner and three other Disney directors.

The amount surpassed the US$3.2 billion in deals announced after the 2002 show.
Asian Aerospace 2004 played host to 148 official delegations from 47 countries. Guests included top government and military leaders from around the world.
"Asian Aerospace has once again proven to be a must-attend show for aviation and aerospace companies eyeing the growing Asia-Pacific market," said Asian Aerospace Pte Ltd. president Ed Ng.
"The new business opportunities developed and the partnerships forged at the show will continue to benefit participants even after the show ends," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN CALLS FOR FEB. 28 TO BE DESIGNATED NATIONAL BLOOD DONATION DAY

TEXT.P: Opposition presidential candidate Lien Chan on Saturday called Feb. 28, or the nation's Peace Memorial Day, to be designated as "National Blood Donation Day."

Lien, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, made the appeal when he attended a "heart-to-heart" road run activity in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, to mark the 57th anniversary of the tragic 2-28 Incident, as well as to drum up support for his presidential campaign prior to the March 20 election.
Presiding over a peace torch lighting ceremony at Kaohsiung Stadium, Lien addressed the participants in the "heart-to-heart" road run activity to promote ethnic harmony.

He then changed the lyrics of a popular song to promote the idea of the "National Blood Donation Day" so that the people of the island always remember that they are linked by blood and should never be divided by suspicions.

The participants, which held chrysanthemums of different colors, then turned and hugged each other in a gesture of love and harmony among the major ethnic groups -- the Hoklo (Taiwanese) , the Hakka, the aboriginal peoples, and the mainlanders -- on the island.
They also recited the words "Please Don't Be Angry" in mandarin Chinese, Taiwanese as well as Hakka.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT HAILS HUMAN CHAIN RALLY AS MOST MOVING MOMENT

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui said Saturday that he was deeply moved when he saw more than one million fellow compatriots hold hands together to form a human chain to express their love for Taiwan.

"This is the most touching moment in my life, " an emotional Lee told a huge crowd of people gathering at the Miaoli command center for the unprecedented mass rally. "I believe it is also one of the most moving moments in Taiwan's history."

Lee, an outspoken critic of mainland China's military threat to Taiwan and an ardent advocate of Taiwan's separate national identity, said the human chain rally was a show of "people power" and the "hope for Taiwan."

"The successful 'one million people hand-in-hand' rally signifies our recognition of Taiwan's national identity and underscores our refusal of Beijing's unification proposal," Lee said, adding that the historic rally was a success for the people of Taiwan.

Through this largest-ever mass movement on the island, Lee said, the people of Taiwan have shown to mainland China and the international community their firm love for peace and aversion to mainland China's deployment of hundreds of missiles against Taiwan.

The event, which organizers said attracted about 1.2 million people, was the biggest islandwide rally in Taiwan's history. Participants expressed the hope that the rally would win the world's sympathy for Taiwan in its struggle against mainland China.

The human chain stretched 487 kilometers from the Hoping Island in the northern city of Keelung down the flat western coast to Pingtung County near the island's southern tip. Local TV stations that covered the event from helicopters said the chain was complete.
The event was jointly organized by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, of which former President Lee is the spiritual leader.

Organizers chose Feb. 28 as the date to hold the human chain rally to mark the anniversary of an uprising in 1947, known as the "2-28 Incident, " when anti-corruption protests turned violent. Soldiers with the former Nationalist government put down the demonstrations, killing hundreds, maybe thousands, of people.

The participants linked hands just before 2: 28 p.m. and held hands for about three minutes. They shouted slogans, such as "Taiwan Yes! " "Love Peace! " "Missiles No! " "Ethnic Harmony and Unity" and "Hold Hands Together to Protect Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: PEOPLE WANT A LEADER WHO SPEAKS THE TRUTH: SOONG

TEXT.P: Opposition vice presidential candidate James Soong said Saturday that Taiwan's problem today is that the people "have had enough" and want a president "who speaks the truth and really gets things done."
Soong, chairman of the People First Party, made the comments in a televised forum for vice presidential candidates sponsored by the Central Election Commission.

Soong, who is Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's running mate first addressed the families of the victims of the 2-28 Incident in his 30-minute presentation to offer them his deepest sympathy as Saturday marked the 57th anniversary of the tragic incident.

Soong said that if the Lien-Soong ticket is elected, it will advocate the "separation between politics and the economy" in cross-strait relations. He said that in the political area, both sides should maintain the status quo, while in terms of the economy, cross-strait relations should not be stalled for even a single day, as "we will lose our future if we have no competitiveness."

He also said that if the Lien-Soong ticket is elected, the new administration will seek to make the interests of the people the top priority regardless of their political affiliation or ethnicity and respect the professionalism.

He noted that President Chen Shui-bian had said in the second debate between the presidential candidates that Lien's only move over the past four years has been "to expel (former ROC President and KMT Chairman) Lee Teng-hui and team up with Soong."

Although Chen aimed to mock Lien, Soong claimed, the president's words actually attested to the fact that Lien has decided to cut off the KMT's links with corrupt "black gold" politics, which marred the latter half of Lee's rule and was one of the major reasons behind the KMT losing power after ruling Taiwan for more than five decades. Lien also wants to work with his the efficient team of the former Taiwan Provincial government, he added.

Soong, who served as Taiwan provincial governor between 1994 and 1998, said he grew up in Taiwan and has an attachment to this land. He said he is devoted to the country, adding that he contributed to Taiwan's democratization and took pride in the "silent revolution" of Taiwan's transformation.
He lashed out at the current administration for its poor economic performance over the past four years, adding that the spectre of "black gold" politics lingers.
"People question whether President Chen has really introduced reforms as he had advocated, " Soong said.

He stressed that if the Lien-Soong team is elected, the new administration will not betray the Taiwan people's insistence on freedom and democracy for more business with mainland China, but neither will it lose out on trade opportunities due to political ideology.

He said that the new administration will provide Taiwan with stability, adding that a leader should "lead, not mislead" the country and must "tell the truth and really get things done" so as to bring hope to Taiwan and to the people.

Soong pointed out that a leader should tell the people about the real situation, citing Singaporean Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong as an example by saying that when Goh was faced with the nation's economic crisis, he chose to communicate with the people and didn't blame it on the global economic situation so that the government and the people later worked together to tide over the difficulties.

Soong, who ran for president in the three-way race in 2000, also vowed to respect the Constitution, assist the president loyally, and help the people. Soong lost to Chen by a narrow margin in the 2000 election, while Lien finished a distant third.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUST PURSUE PIVOTAL ROLE IN COMING PACIFIC CENTURY: LU

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday that Taiwan should strive to play a pivotal role in what she called the "Pacific century" now taking shape, rather than seeking to integrate with mainland China.
Lu made the call in a televised campaign forum sponsored by the Central Election Commission -- the only one of its kind to be held ahead of the March 20 presidential election.

Noting that Taiwan occupies a strategic location in the Asia-Pacific region, Lu said mainland China's insistence on taking control of Taiwan is closely related to what she called its attempt to build a Chinese empire.
Without Taiwan in its control, Lu said, mainland China cannot enjoy free access to the Pacific Ocean.
In the face of mainland China's rise as a new economic powerhouse, Lu said, Taiwan must choose whether to integrate with mainland China or to glorify its unique role as a Pacific "maritime" country.
If Taiwan companies continue their exodus to mainland China, Lu claimed, Taiwan could face a crisis of being absorbed into the vast mainland market and being marginalized in the international market.
Therefore, Lu said, Taiwan should adopt a new strategic thinking to cope with the new challenges.
In her view, Lu said, Taiwan should continue reinforcing its defense capabilities and strengthening defense cooperation with the United States and Japan.

Given mainland China's persistent military threat, Lu said the opposition "pan-blue alliance's" campaign promise to replace the current conscription system with an all-volunteer one is extremely unrealistic.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG PROMISES TO GIVE PRIORITY TO BUILDING TRUST

TEXT.P: Building trust will be high on the work agenda of the new administration if the opposition "pan-blue alliance" wins the March 20 presidential election, the alliance's vice presidential candidate said Saturday.

People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong, who is Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan's running mate against President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, made the comments in a televised campaign forum sponsored by the Central Election Commission (CEC).
He said that if the Lien-Soong ticket is elected, the new administration will give priority to rebuilding the people's trust in the president and the international community's trust in Taiwan.

Ridiculing what he called President Chen's frequent policy flip-flops and Chen's confusing explanations of his "four noes plus one" pledge outlined in his 2000 inaugural speech, Soong claimed that the Taiwan people have lost their trust in the president over the past four years.

Soong further claimed that Chen's insistence on holding a controversial referendum has caused major countries around the world to doubt the president's commitment to the "four noes" pledge, which includes no change to Taiwan's status quo.
"Only when our president honors his promise will the international community trust Taiwan," Soong said.
He urged the electorate to vote Chen out in order to allow Taiwan to regain the international community's trust.
"We badly need a second transition of power between political parties. Let's use our ballots to vote out the current incompetent administration and usher in a new era for Taiwan," Soong said.
Saturday's televised forum for the two vice presidential candidates was the only one of its kind that will be held ahead of the March 20 election.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN CALLS FOR LOVE, FORGIVENESS, REFLECTION ON PEACE MEMORIAL DAY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Saturday called for "love, forgiveness and reflection" while speaking at a ceremony marking the nation's 2-28 Peace Memorial Day.

The ceremony, commemorating the 57th anniversary of the tragic 2-28 Incident, was held at a wharf in Keelung where troops sent by the Nationalist government from mainland China landed in 1947 and began a bloody suppression of "riotous" locals.

Music played by trumpet and a string quartet began the solemn ceremony. President Chen as well as the family members of some of the victims of the bloody suppression observed a moment of silence for those who suffered in the 2-28 incident.

The family members watched with tears as a group of performers reenacted the tragic event which was triggered by a clash between an old woman selling contraband cigarettes and an armed agent of the Taiwan Tobacco and Wine Monopoly Bureau on Feb. 27, 1947. Tens of thousands of people were reportedly killed or imprisoned during the protest and riots the following day and the subsequent "white terror" period.

After the moment of silence, President Chen led the family members in laying bouquets of flowers on a mock monument on the stage in honor of the victims, symbolizing that they will face the historic wound with love and reflection.
The president then presented to the family members certificates restoring the reputations of the fallen victims.

Noting that "some have said that reopening the historial wound of the 2-28 Incident will divide Taiwan's ethnic groups and destabilize society, " Chen said he disagreed with this view. "The victims included Hoklo (Taiwanese), Hakka, aboriginal people and mainlanders. They were all victims of Taiwan history."

The president said that he was deeply "moved" when he presented the rehabilitation certificates to the victims and their families. He expressed the hope that the Taiwan people will use their "forbearance and reflection" through the reexamination of the historial wound and the establishment of a memorial monument.
Chen also stressed that pluralism is a major asset of Taiwan, adding that "we should face the truth, families of the victims, and mistakes with forgiveness, compassion and firmness."

He urged everybody to take part in the islandwide "hand-in-hand" rally in the afternoon to show their determination to ensure the nation's security, saying this would be "the best way to commemorate the 2-28 incident."

Chen Chin-huang, chairman of a 2-28 foundation, recalled the sending of the troops of the 21st division by Nationalist government to land at Keelung Harbor to suppress the local population. He contrasted that episode with the current situation where mainland China has more than 500 missiles aimed at Taiwan and where "the Taiwan people face a constant threat."
He urged the people to participate in the "hand-in-hand" human-chain activity in the afternoon to convey to the world the message that the Taiwan people love peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT THE REAL WAY TO PROTECT TAIWAN: LIEN CHAN

TEXT.P: The economy is the most pressing issue for Taiwan, the "pan-blue alliance's" presidential candidate Lien Chan said Saturday at a gathering of his supporters in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
Lien, also the Kuomintang (KMT) chairman, said that a vote for him in the March 20 presidential election is a vote for the economy.
He said the "real" way to protect Taiwan is through strong economic development for the island.

Meanwhile, the "pan-blue alliance's" presidential campaign headquarters in xxxx held a "love and peace poetry recital" to commemorate the 57th anniversary of the tragic 2-28 Incident in which the government's suppression of Taiwanese caused bloody conflict between Taiwanese and local residents from mainland China.
The "pan-blue alliance" also plans to hold "heart-to-heart" 2-28 Memorial Day activities in Taipei and Kaohsiung in the afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOLDING HANDS TOGETHER TO FORM DEMOCRATIC GREAT WALL: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that the people of Taiwan have used a simple yet solemn and sacred way of holding hands together to demonstrate to the world their desire for peace.

In a speech delivered at the "one million people hand-in-hand" rally Miaoli commanding center in northern Taiwan, Chen said he is very pleased to hold hands together with all citizens from around the country in a show of Taiwan people's common determination to form a democratic Great Wall and protect their homeland with peace.

More than 1 million people held hands together to form a human chain that stretched the length of Taiwan from Hoping Island in the northern tip to Pingtung County near the island's southern tip to demonstrate their love for Taiwan and their desire for peace.

"We are using the most simple, but solemn gesture of holding hands to form a democratic Great Wall. This will send a clear message to the world: We love Taiwan. We want peace," Chen told thousands of people gathering at the Miaoli commanding center.
At 2:28 p.m., all participants to the rally held hands together and shouted slogans "Taiwan yes!" and "Believe in Taiwan! Insist on Reform!"

It was the largest mass rally ever held in Taiwan. In addition to demonstrating Taiwan people's aversion to mainland China's missile threat, the rally was also designed to mark Taiwan's 2-28 Peace Memorial Day.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 28, or the ninth day of the second month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1784: John Wesley, the British religious leader who founded Methodism in 1738, signs the "deed of declaration" formalizing the establishment of the Wesleyan faith.
1825: Russia and Britain sign a treaty settling the border between Canada and Alaska, then a Russian possession.
1854: U.S. opponents of slavery, meeting at Ripon, Wisconsin, agree to form a new political party. The Republican Party was born later in 1854.
1900: The British Labour Representation Committee, which later would become the Labour Party, is founded with Ramsay MacDonald as its secretary.
1909: Linus Pauling, the American chemist and physicist who won the Nobel Prize for chemistry in 1934 and the Noble Peace Prize in 1962, is born.
1921: Russian sailors of the Baltic Fleet and workers at Kronstadt naval base rise up against the communist government.
1922: Britain declares Egypt's independence, while it retains control of the Suez Canal.
1942: Japanese troops land in Java, Indonesia after the Japanese sink two more Allied ships on the second day of the Battle of Java Sea.
1946: Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Shih-chieh and French Ambassador to China Jacques Meyrier sign the "Sino-French Treaty Regarding the Revocation of French Extraterritorial Jurisdiction and Related Privileges in China" in Chungking.
1947: Rioting breaks out in Taipei, following an incident in which an old woman was brutally beaten by police for violating the tobacco monopoly by selling untaxed cigarettes.
1951: The Republic of China Executive Yuan approves the appointment of Dr. Chien Shih-liang as president of National Taiwan University.
1956: Indonesia and India sign a mutual aid treaty.
1967: American editor and publisher Henry Robinson Luce dies at the age of 69. He co-founded Time in 1923 and later founded Fortune in 1930 and Sports Illustrated in 1954.
1973: Forty-four additional members of the ROC Legislative Yuan are sworn in.
1976: Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, the Philippines and Thailand sign a treaty of friendship and cooperation.
1987: President Corazon Aquino of the Philippines announces full and complete amnesty to communist rebels who lay down their weapons.
1992: The ROC and the Philippines sign an official investment guarantee agreement to protect Taiwan businesspeople investing in the Philippines.
1992: The United Nations Security Council approves a peacekeeping force for Cambodia.
1995: ROC President Lee Teng-hui gives an apology to the families of the victims of the Feb. 28 Incident in 1947 during a ceremony at Taipei's New Park, where a monument commemorating the tragedy was built with government sponsorship.
1996: Russia becomes the 39th member of the Council of Europe.
1996: Britain's Princess Diana agrees to divorce her estranged husband Prince Charles.
1997: An earthquake hits western Pakistan, claiming more than 35 lives, while another earthquake in Iran destroys over 20 villages and kills nearly 1,000 people.
2000: The Philippine government urges Taipei to return to the negotiating table to resolve the fresh aviation dispute between the two sides and proposes that the talks be reopened in Manila between March 1-2.
2000: Chen Li-an, former president of the Control Yuan, formally makes known his intention to support Vice President Lien Chan, the presidential candidate of the ruling Kuomintang.
2001: Taipei and Shanghai authorities agree to further bolster sisterhood exchanges between the two mucipalities, beginning with a student exchange program.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When I find a man agrees with me in what I say without being able to profit by it by changing his conduct, or one who is pleased with my parable without being able to apply the moral to himself -- I can do nothing for such a man."

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP APPEALS TO VOTERS FOLLOWING HUMAN CHAIN SUCCESS

TEXT.P: After mobilizing more than a million people to form a human chain winding through Taiwan to mark 2-28 Peace Day, the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is hopping its presidential candidate, Chen Shui-bian, can ride the success of the Peace Day rally and win the March 20 presidential election.

The Peace Day rally's theme, "millions joining hands to protect Taiwan" is similar to the purpose of the referendum -- to unite the Taiwan people to say "no" to Beijing's missile threat against the island.

With the presidential election and the referendum only 20 days, away, the president's strategists considered the Feb. 28 rally a "rehearsal" for the presidential election, as those who attended Saturday's rally are likely to vote "yes" in the referendum and to support Chen's re-election bid.

DPP Legislator Lo Wen-chia, who is a campaign strategist for the president, said the DPP was encouraged by the good turnout at Saturday's rally. However, he said, people's memories are short and it will be a challenge to extend their enthusiasm for "protecting Taiwan" to March 20.

Ten rounds of public debates about the two referendum questions is another way to keep public attention on Beijing's military threat to Taiwan, said Legislator Chen Chi-mai, a spokesman for Chen's national campaign headquarters.

In 20 days before the people going to the polls, Chen said his party will launch a "100 campaign" to urge people to choose the No. 1 candidate -- Chen Shui-bian -- in the election and to vote "yes" for both referendum questions, represented by two naughts.

Legislator Tsai Huang-lang, the DPP whip at the Legislative Yuan said the Feb. 28 rally aroused public patriotism and raised their awareness about Taiwan's separate identity from that of mainland China. This, he claimed, will drive many "floating" voters who have no specific political preference to support Chen and his party.
Tsai said that the more people turn out to vote, the better for Chen and the DPP, and he predicted that Chen is "sure to win" if only 70 percent of the voters cast their ballots.

Chen's camp will also boost the performance of his administration, which has been ignored because of misleading information spread by the camp of Chen's rival in the race, Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan, Tsai said.

Claiming that Chen's administration has been much more aggressive and efficient in carrying out policy than the preceding KMT administration, Tsai said DPP will launch another round of campaign advertisements before March 20.

Many DPP lawmakers agree their party is dominant in southern Taiwan but is no match for the KMT in northern Taiwan. In order to win the presidential election, they feel that the DPP has to win overwhelmingly in southern Taiwan, win slightly in central Taiwan and lose only a little in northern Taiwan. Now, the DPP's top priority is to keep the people's zeal to defend the country and translate this strong feeling into support for Chen in the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIWAN DOLLAR TO MAINTAIN DEPRECIATION AGAINST U.S. DOLLAR

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar is expected to hover around against the U.S. dollar between a range of 33.35 to 33.45 this week, maintaining a trend of slight depreciation against the greenback, market dealers said Sunday.

Market dealers predicted that the local currency, continuing its depreciation trend against the U.S. dollar of last week, will further move down in value in the coming days, prompted by a weaker yen and stronger demand from local importers' for U.S. dollars.

At the same time, the yen might continue to depreciate against the U.S. dollar in the short term, moving between the 108-111 level, they said, predicting that it will be very difficult for the yen to pick up in value against the greenback at a level above 110 in the near future. It closed at 109 Feb. 20.

Market dealers forecast that the local currency will hover around against the U.S. dollar in the 33.35-33.45 range this week. The new Taiwan dollar ended at 33.364 against the U.S. dollar last Friday, a drop of NT$0.145 from the previous week's level of 33.22.

The U. S. dollar's short-term appreciation last week was ascribed to a devalued euro that was the result of rampant speculation that the European central bank will raise interest rates. However, market dealers said the euro will stand firm against the greenback at a level of 1.24 and that the U.S. dollar will gradually drift lower in the mid- and long-term.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRC MILITARY THREAT HAS NOT LESSENED OVER PAST FOUR YEARS: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday that the Chinese communist military threat toward Taiwan has not been alleviated over the past four years.
Addressing the opening of an international symposium on Taiwan's national defense, Chen said the country's national defense is a firewall against the People's Liberation Army's military attempts.

Chen said that since he spelled out his "four noes plus one" pledge during his inauguration in 2000 as a gesture of goodwill to mainland China, he has not seen the PRC reduce its military threat toward Taiwan.
On the contrary, he added, the PRC arms buildup, particularly its missile deployment targeting Taiwan, has increased rapidly over the past four years.

The PLA's speedy modernization, particularly the improving of the precision of its ballistic missiles and its large-scale deployment of missiles, are all factors contributing to the increasing changes in the military balance across the Taiwan Strait, Chen noted.
Chen quoted military intelligence as indicating that the number of the PLA's tactical guided missiles increased 11-fold between 1995 and 2003 and is still rising at the rate of one every six days.

Facing Beijing's ever-mounting military threat, he added, the Taiwan people must consolidate and jointly throw their support behind the armed forces, while the government accelerates the modernization of the military, including the building of anti-missile preparedness.

Chen stressed that the factor of "people" stills plays an important role in efforts to upgrade Taiwan's overall defense capability and competitiveness. Thus, seeking to raise the caliber of military personnel is one of the goals of national defense reform, he added.

As commander of the Republic of China armed forces, Chen said, it is his responsibility to ensure that Taiwan's national security is well protected. He added that he will refer to professional expertise from the Ministry of National Defense whenever making comments regarding military affairs.
Still, he said, he cannot agree with some of the "empty promises" made by his presidential election rival about the nation's military recruitment and conscription policy.

Chen said that while he has advocated a system of recruitment for 10 years, he has also insisted that the policy on calling and maintaining a standing army must be implemented step-by-step, with the country's national security being the top and ultimate goal.

Chen's rival, "pan-blue alliance" presidential candidate Lien Chan said in a debate with Chen last week that he advocates a system of recruitment or drafting for the armed forces that would encourage more career soldiers and that compulsory military service should be shortened to three months instead of the current 20 months.
Commenting on Lien's remarks, Chen said Lien was issuing a campaign check that is bound to bounce.

Haitian Capital descended into widespread law- lessness, with armed gangs loyal to Haitian President Jean-Bertrand Aristide executing at least two suspected rebel collaborators in public. The U.S.military prepared for possible action.

Hundreds of school teachers in the South are packing guns and taking schooting lessons out of fear they will the next victims in ongoing violence in the South. (Francis Kuo)

The Japan Times: North Korean talks end with serious differences.
Six-nation talks on North Koreas nuclear program ended Saturday without any major breakthrough even as asenior U.S. official declared them very successful and the governments involved promised to push ahead with their diplomatic efforts.

The Manila Bulletin: 112 ferry victims still missing.
Philippine Coast Guard (PCG) commandant Vice Admiral Arthur N. Gosingan created yesterday a special Board of Marine Inquiry (BMI) that will investigate the Friday dawn fire at the WG & A Super Ferry 14 off the waters of El Fraile island near Corregidor where one person was killed and a total of 112 of its 766 passengers and crew are still missing.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Long wait for the missing.
SEARCH and rescue teams of the Philippine Coast Guard (PCG) made it to the bridge of SuperFerry 14 Saturday, but smoke and intense heat prevented them from getting inside the vessel, PCG chief Vice Adm. Arthur Gosingan said.

Malacanang cannot afford to dilly-dally on the appointment of a new Supreme Court justice, since doing so would violate the Constitution, a member of the Judicial and Bar Council (JBC) said.

THE Armed Forces of the Philippines on Saturday warned the Oakwood mutineers and the Kawal Filipino that any attempt to topple the government would fail.

DOC.HEADLINE: EARTHQUAKE RATTLES EASTERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 4.2 on the Richter scale rattled eastern Taiwan Sunday. No damage was reported.

Central Weather Bureau officials said that the epicenter of the quake was located 11.6 kilometers northeast of the Hsincheng seismic station in Hualien County and originated 10.7 kilometers below the earth's surface.
The quake, which occurred at 8:54 p.m., had an intensity of 4.0 in Hualien County's Taroko, 3.0 in Ilan County's Nanao and 1.0 in Hualien City.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINES

TEXT.P: New York Times: Under pressure, Aristide leaves Haiti.
Haitian President Jean-Bertrand Aristide left Haiti on Sunday, bowing to pressure from a rebellion at home and governments abroad, U.S. and Haitian officials said.

An Associated Press reporter saw an unmarked white jet take off from Port-au-Prince's airport Sunday morning. Cabinet minister and close adviser Leslie Voltaire said Aristide was on board along with his palace security chief Frantz Gabriel.
Voltaire said Aristide, Haiti's first democratically elected president in 200 years of independence, was flying to the Dominican Republic and would seek asylum in Morocco, Taiwan or Panama.
Wall Street Journal: Rebel leader to delay attack on Haiti's capital.

Gangs of pro-government supporters who looted, robbed and careened around firing into the air from hijacked trucks disappeared from the streets of Port-au- Prince on Saturday, acting on an appeal from President Jean-Bertrand Aristide for the violence to end.

In the anxious calm that followed Mr. Aristide's call for calm, rebel leader Guy Philippe said Saturday that his fighters would hold off attacking the capital "for a day or two, " in response to a U.S. appeal he said he had read on the Internet.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Feb. 29, or the 10th day of the second month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
642 AD: St. Oswald, bringer of Christianity to northeastern England, is killed in battle.
1840: John Holland, US inventor of the submarine, is born in Ireland.
1868: Louis I, the king of Bavaria, dies in Munich at the age of 81.
1880: The St. Gotthard tunnel, providing a rail link between Switzerland and Italy, is completed, with a total length of about 14 kms.
1896: Ranchhodji Morarji Desal, Indian prime minister who was imprisoned with Mahatma Gandhi, is born.
1908: Heike Onnes, a scientist from Leyden, the Netherlands, announces he has succeeded in liquefying helium.
1912: A military coup in Peking delays Yuan Shih-kai's trip to Nanking to assume provisional presidency.
1920: Peking University begins to enroll female students.
1944: German troops begin a third major offensive against Anzio beach-head in World War II.
1948: A Jewish Stern Gang bombs a Cairo-to-Haifa train, killing 35 British troops.
1956: The United States announces its decision to enhance its military capability to help defend Taiwan against invasion from communist China.
1956: Pakistan becomes an Islamic Republic.
1956: White segregationist groups are planning demonstrations to protest a US federal court ruling that Autherine Lucy, the first-ever black student at the University of Alabama, be readmitted.
1960: An earthquake rocks Morocco, destroying much of Agadir and killing about 12,000 people.
1960: Huge Hefner opens his new Playboy Club in Chicago.
1976: Chinese golfers Hsu Chi-san and Chang Teh-kuei win the professional and amateur trophies, respectively, at the China Open, the second leg on the 1976 Asian circuit.
1984: Pierre Trudeau resigns as prime minister of Canada.
1984: An explosion on board the Makung, a cargo ship of a Penghu shipping company, kills nine people and injures 17 others.
1984: Fei Hua, former finance minister, dies in a car accident at the age of 72.
1988: Desmond Tutu, South Africa's Anglican archbishop, is arrested for demonstrating outside the parliament building in Cape Town in defiance of a ban on political activity by the white minority government.
1988: The Ministry of National Defense announces that the long-range missile Hsiung Feng II, which was developed and manufactured by the ROC, has been successfully tested and can be used in combination with the Hsiung Feng I as an anti-submarine missile.
1992: Russia establishes diplomatic ties with South Africa, ending more than 30 years of unfriendly relations.
1996: A Faucett Airlines Boeing 737 crashes at the city of Arequipa in the Andes, killing all 117 passengers and six crew members.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To know what you know and know what you don't know is the characteristic of one who knows."

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT VOWS TO WIPE OUT GAMBLING ON PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: In an all-out effort to eradicate all types of irregularities that could affect the result of the March 20 presidential race, police and prosecution authorities are determined to crack down on gambling on the election result, Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan said Sunday.
Chen made the remarks at an anti- vote buying campaign held in Taichung City in central Taiwan.

Pointing out that the prosecution authorities have obtained information related to bookmakers taking bets on the election, Chen said the relevant government agencies have kicked off an investigation into the alleged irregularities, including vote buying disguised as hosting parties or picnics.
Despite the fact that wagering is more rampant in southern regions, Chen made it clear that the government authorities will spare no efforts to wipe out all such election gambling.

The justice minister vowed immediate action on any such illegal activities discovered, even thought some of the bookies are working via the Internet from overseas to rake in profits from the highly sensitive event.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST TWO ROUNDS OF REFERENDUM DEBATE OPEN

TEXT.P: The first two of 10 rounds of televised debates about the two questions in the March 20 referendum were staged Sunday by the Chinese Television System (CTS).

The Executive Yuan's spokesman, Lin Chia-lung, debated with independent Legislator Kao Chin Su-mei over the country's missile-defense system, while Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh argued against writer Lee Ao over the possibility of setting up a negotiating framework with Beijing.

In the debate between Lin and Kao over the first question in the referendum -- whether the country should strengthen its missile defense capability in the face of Beijing's missile threat -- Kao, who was elected by the country's aborigines, questioned the wisdom in earmarking NT$700 billion (US$20.9 billion) for an anti-missile system in light of the miserable lives of the island's aborigines.

Beijing has targeted the island with 496 missiles and Kao claimed that in the event of an attack, the country would be leveled and a missile defense system would not boost Taiwan's chance if survival.
Lin countered by describing the referendum as both legal and necessary, although his opponent did not call into question the referendum's legality.

Describing the first national referendum a historic event in the country's democratic development, Lin said he is looking forward to what he called the glorious result of many democratic activists' bloodshed and struggle.
Defense capability is to a country what air is to humans, Lin said, adding that no country can survive without defenses.

Noting that 15 years ago, the people of the three Baltic states stood up to assert their opposition to rule by their powerful neighbor, Russia, and affirm their statehood via referendum, Lin urged the public to take a cue from those three states and show the world their opposition to Beijing's military threat.

He played down critics' concerns that Taiwan's purchase of anti-missile systems will trigger an arms race with the mainland, claiming that the systems will give the country the ability to survive a first strike by Beijing and give the country's allies time to come to the island's defense.

He said a referendum on the question of whether the country needs to strengthen its missile defense capability is the cheapest and most efficient way to underline Beijing's military threat against Taiwan and to seek international sympathy for Taiwan.
In the second round of debate between Hsieh and Lee, also staged by the CTS, the two argued over whether the country should negotiate with Beijing for a peaceful interaction framework.
Lee said that President Chen Shui-bian should ask the people in the unprecedented referendum whether Taiwan should declare independence rather than whether the country should negotiate with Beijing.

Without assuming a new name, Lee claimed, Taipei would play into the hands of Beijing by negotiating with Beijing as the Republic of China, whose Constitution still considers the mainland as part of its territory, that there is only one China and that the "One China" policy is the bottom line of any negotiation with Beijing.

Suggesting that the referendum is a precursor for a referendum to justify the island's separation from the mainland, Lee dared his opponent in the debate to call for a referendum on Taiwan independence rather than beating around the bush by calling for a referendum on a question that is of no importance.

Hsieh said there might be no doubt that the answer to the second referendum question is "yes" and that the government will go to the negotiating table with Beijing even if the referendum fails, but he added that a failure would weaken the government's negotiating position with Beijing and give rise to the misconception that the country is divided on the issue.

Just like Saturday's 2-28 rally that made headlines in newspapers around the world, the island will be catapulted into the international limelight again and its message will get across to the world if there is a good referendum turnout March 20.
"We all love Taiwan, so let's rally behind the government by casting votes in the referendum to show our firm national desire for peace," Hsieh said.

There are still eight rounds of debate about the referendum -- four each for the two questions -- to be staged before March 14, the last Sunday before voting day. The Central Election Commission, which has to organize the debates under the terms of the Referendum Law, has lined up one round for each question, on every Wednesday and Sunday over the next two weeks.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL CYCLE SHOW TO OPEN MARCH 10

TEXT.P: The Taipei International Cycle Show 2004 will open March 10 at the exhibition halls of the Taipei World Trade Center, organizers of the event said Sunday.
A total of 582 exhibitors from 27 countries have confirmed that they will attend the annual exhibition and will set up more than 1,800 booths to display their products, they added.
The exhibition, which is jointly organized by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council and the Taiwan Bicycle Exporters Association, will run through March 13.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLA PONDERING TAIWAN INVASION OPTION: U.S. PUNDIT

TEXT.P: A U.S. scholar of national defense affairs said in Taipei Sunday that he has learned that the mainland Chinese military has been pondering a sweeping attack on Taiwan.

Andrew Scobell, an associate research professor at the Strategic Studies Institute of U.S. Army War College, said at an international symposium on Taiwan's national defense that while he has considered a conventional and sweeping invasion of Taiwan by mainland forces impossible over the past years, he has since the beginning of 2004 not excluded the possibility of Beijing taking this option.

Scobell, author of China's Use of Military Force: Beyond the Great Wall and the Long March, said that he is positive that the mainland's People's Liberation Army has been mulling, planning and exercising this Taiwan attack scenario.

In view of this scenario, Scobell suggested that Taiwan beef up its counter-attack capabilities by strengthening its air and sea combat tactics and giving top priority to upgrading its anti-submarine and anti-torpedo capabilities.
Strategically, he said, the best way to smash a PLA attempt to invade Taiwan is to demonstrate strength and determination without being provocative.

He said the Taiwan leaders should continue to stress that if the PLA launches a military attack against Taiwan, it will be time for Taiwan to announce independence. This in turn would serve as a message to Beijing that early prevention of growing hostility across the Taiwan Strait would be the only option for mainland China to prevent Taiwan from announcing independence -- the last scenario that Beijing would like to see, he added.

In his theory titled "Coercion or Capture" presented during the symposium, Scobell said that the Beijing leadership has adopted an optimistic attitude toward cross-strait relations in the past. But the Beijing leaders have been forced to re-evaluate the situation, as Taiwan's politics have changed drastically in recent years, he said.
For most analysts and experts in Chinese affairs, Scobell said, the Beijing leaders still tend to adopt a "coercion" policy toward Taiwan rather than the "capture" option.

The problem is, he pointed out, that there is only a very thin grey line between "coercion" and "capture, " given that the PLA's action of coercion might develop into a real invasion operation, while an invasion operation might turn out only to be a drill.

DOC.HEADLINE: CARAVAN ORGANIZED TO MARK OPENING OF AIRPORT IN CENTRAL TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A caravan of cars and horses decorated with colorful flowers moved through the streets of downtown Taichung City in central Taiwan Sunday to mark the opening of an international airport in the region.

The carnival-style activities were sponsored by the Central Coordination Office under the Executive Yuan to celebrate the March 6 inauguration of the international airport in Chingchuankang, which is also an air force base.

Three chartered flights to Tokyo, Phuket Island and Palau, carrying a total of 360 lucky tourists selected through a draw, were scheduled to take off later in the day to mark the opening of Chingchuankang International Airport, which will only operate outbound charter flights in the initial stage.

Office director and former Taichung County Chief Liao Yung-lai hailed the charter flights, saying that they mark the very first step for the airport that will serve the 6 million people living in central Taiwan.

Taichung Chamber of Commerce Chairman Lai Cheng-i, who was in charge of organizing the three chartered flights in cooperation with China Airlines and Far East Air Transport Corp., said he is optimistic about the business prospects for Chingchuankang airport. He forecast that the airport will undoubtedly play a significant role after Taiwan and mainland China establish normal transport links.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER FU JEN UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT DIES OF ORGAN FAILURE

TEXT.P: A former president of Fu Jen Catholic University, Archbishop Stanislaus Lokuang, died of multiple organ failure at the age of 92 Saturday at the Veterans General Hospital in Taipei, university officials said Sunday.

Lokuang was admitted to the hospital three years ago for treatment of respiratory disease, his doctors said, adding that he then suffered from high blood pressure, arrhythmia, nephralgia, and various other complications.

Lokuang succeeded the late Cardinal Yu Pin as president of Fu Jen Catholic University in 1978 and resigned due to poor health in 1992, when he was conferred the honorary title of Rector Emeritus of the university.

DOC.HEADLINE: LUFTHANSA PLANNING TO REOPEN TAIPEI-FRANKFURT ROUTE

TEXT.P: The Germany-based Lufthansa air carrier is planning to reopen the Taipei-Frankfurt route after a hiatus of four years, the carrier announced in a press release issued recently by a Taiwan public relations company.

Lufthansa first opened its Taipei-Frankfurt route via Bangkok in July 1993, but decided to end its twice-weekly flight service in June 1996 as a result of lackluster business, according to the press release, which said that the carrier now plans to resume the route because of promising business prospects.
Lufthansa operates the largest number of flights between destinations in Asia and Europe, offering 87 weekly flights from Germany to 14 cities in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: PERCENTAGE OF DIALYSIS PATIENTS IN TAIWAN TOPS THE WORLD: DOCTOR

TEXT.P: The number of patients in Taiwan who need renal dialysis totals about 35,000, the highest figure in the world in terms of percentage of the population, a nephrology doctor said Sunday.

Dr. Yang Wu-chang, chairman of the Taiwan Society of Nephrology and a physician at the Veterans General Hospital in Taipei, said that the annual increase rate of dialysis patients also tops the world at 3,000 to 4,000, mostly senior citizens.

He attributed the high percentage of such patients mainly to the facts that there are relatively higher percentages of patients with diabetes and high blood pressure, and that Taiwan patients tend to use excessive amounts of medication that contain nephrotoxins.

Yang pointed out that people aged over 65 with high blood pressure and hyperazoturia and who have suffered from diabetes for more than 10 years tend to be potential nephrological patients needing regular dialysis treatment.

Yang suggested that people aged over 40 should have their kidneys examined once every two years, while those aged over 50 should have them checked once every year. People with hyperazoturia should have their kidney function examined once every three months, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL RACE AFFECTING OUTBOUND TRAVEL WILLINGNESS

TEXT.P: The approaching presidential election has sent a chill through domestic tourist agencies operating outbound travel, as demand for package tours departing before March 20 election day is extremely low, business sources said Sunday.

To encourage travelers to holiday abroad in the runup to the election, tourism agencies are offering reduced prices to lure customers, the sources said, adding that the election is having a major impact on their business.

Pointing to the last presidential election as an example, they said bookings for outbound travel before noon March 20 were only half full, pushing tourist agencies to lower their prices by two-thirds to cope with the situation. Those groups which left after noon March 20 four years ago were also offered at lowered prices, they noted.

To avoid losses this year, tourist agencies have organized fewer outbound chartered trips and all the outgoing groups will depart after noon at promotional prices, they said. They encouraged the public to seize the opportunity of cheap package tours.

Now that demand for pleasure trips to mainland China and Japan, as well as to destinations in Europe and other parts of the northern hemisphere, is set to peak after March 20, they said that prices probably be adjusted upward by at least 10 percent.

The Washington Post: Agencies Brushed Off Lead Warnings; WASA, Army Corps Were Told of Threat in 1994.
The D.C. Water and Sewer Authority and the Army Corps of Engineers rejected warnings from consultants who said as early as 1994 that lead contamination was a serious threat because of the way the two agencies were managing the water supply, according to records and interviews.
